webTitle: Byers threatens to sue Daily Mail

fields.headline: Byers threatens to sue Daily Mail
fields.standfirst: Byers threatens to sue Mail over claims report was 'buried'
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers is threatening to sue the Daily Mail over claims that a critical DTI inspector's report was 'buried'.
fields.body:
The government was last night struggling to contain fresh embarrassment over Geoffrey Robinson's tangled business empire as the latest investigation of the former paymaster general's political career threatened to touch his old boss, Gordon Brown.

In the wake of the writer Tom Bower's claim that Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, deliberately "buried" a critical DTI inspector's report, Downing Street authorised Mr Byers to consult his lawyers about possible defamation by Mr Bower and the Daily Mail, which is serialising his new book, The Paymaster.

Last night both said they stood "100% behind our story", which claimed to have un earthed proof of a £200,000 payment that Mr Robinson denies receiving from the crooked financier Robert Maxwell.

"The Daily Mail will be hearing from solicitors representing Mr Byers shortly," the DTI assured the Guardian.

Raising the stakes, the Mail issued a 12-point challenge to Mr Byers which it couples today with Mr Bower's account of how the Treasury's former permanent secretary, Lord Burns, was "intimidated" to protect Mr Robinson's job before he was forced out in December 1998 over Peter Mandelson's £373,000 home loan. Mr Brown later forced Lord Burns out of his job.

Convinced that the Mail is acting in desperation to prevent another Labour election landslide the Downing Street spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said: "They are in a complete rage because they are not having much effect." Pointedly throughout yesterday he and his deputies said: "Geoffrey Robinson is no longer a member of the government."

Rather that face a fresh Commons inquiry over the possibility that he lied to them, some MPs predicted that the millionaire businessman would also quit as MP for Coventry North-West before polling day. But ministers fear the spread of the "sleaze" contagion.

Contrary to Mr Robinson's repeated denials to Tony Blair and the Commons standards and privileges committee, restated by the MP again last night, Mr Bower reproduced an invoice marked "Paid".

It appears to show that the MP solicited and later obtained the £200,000 payment from Mr Maxwell's Pergamon group in late 1990 as a management payment for his role in Hollis, a now bankrupt firm that both Maxwell and Mr Robinson's companies owned at different times.

The cheque, which has never been traced, was made payable "personally" to Mr Robinson, though Mr Bower claims the MP admitted its existence in a face-to-face showdown over breakfast at the Grosvenor House hotel, where the MP has a penthouse flat. The reason for Mr Byers' involvement, and Downing Street's anger, is Mr Bower's claim that the key facts were laid out by the DTI inspector, Hugh Aldous, in December 1999, but not published the same month because they would embarrass ministers.

Instead Mr Byers issued a brief answer saying that after "thorough inquiries" the DTI would take no further action. In a statement yesterday the department made two key points:

 That the inquiry, set up the month after Mr Byers took over from Mr Mandelson, was conducted at every stage by civil servants without ministerial involvement.

 That its findings cannot be published because it was conducted under section 447 of the 1985 Companies Act which precludes publication lest the commercial interests of the company involved are "unfairly damaged".

The Daily Mail's report therefore amounted to defamation of Mr Byers, the DTI said. Mr Campbell said: "He is consulting his lawyer to see what kind of cheque the Daily Mail may be sending to charity."

But Mr Bower, a veteran investigative reporter, declined to back down.

"I take note that Stephen Byers has not denied that Hugh Aldous reported that Geoffrey Robinson misled parliament and that Byers, by not announcing that issue of public interest, allowed Robinson to declare that he had been exhonerated by the report. I do not think he would have taken that decision without consultation," he said.

David Heathcoat-Amory, shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, countered the DTI's defence by saying that after he had demanded an independent inquiry in 1998-99 no mention was ever made of either point in letters from Mr Byers. He called the official version "complete sophistry" and has written to Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, asking her to reopen her own inquiries.

MPs indicated last night that that is likely if it proves necessary to ask Mr Robinson "if he wishes to add anything to the evidence he has already given".

Mr Robinson issued his own denial yesterday. "Today's story has failed to present any new information. The claim that I was paid £200,000 as chairman of Hollis Industries has been made before and was fully investigated by the DTI who have today made their position clear about the Bower story," he said.

"My own position has been absolutely clear throughout: neither I nor any company associated with me received this money."

webTitle: Britain's towns top European pollution poll

fields.headline: Britain's towns top European pollution poll
fields.standfirst: UK faces legal action and fines after report finds 11 districts have no provision to treat waste water
fields.trailText: UK faces legal action and fines after report finds 11 districts have no provision to treat waste water.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and  David Ward
fields.body:
Britain has more towns and cities pumping raw sewage into the sea than any other country in the EU and could face legal action and hefty fines unless it cleans up its act, the European commission warned yesterday.

In a report which names and shames 37 towns and cities around Europe which have no provision to treat waste water, the UK, with 11 entries, emerged as the worst polluter in the EU. Only Spain, Portugal and Italy with seven entries apiece come close to matching Britain's tattered green credentials while Ireland and Greece can boast of having just two listings each.

Popular seaside resorts such as Brighton and Torbay are named in the report as are more northerly locations such as Dundee, Middlesbrough and Hull.

Other areas which Brussels claimed are flouting EU environmental law include Dover, Hastings, Portsmouth, Port Talbot, Bebington and Sunderland.

The UK is also the member state with the highest number of towns and cities with "inadequate facilities" to treat sewage and again the geographical spread is wide.

Britain's nominations for this category range from Aberdeen and Edinburgh in Scotland to Basildon and Canvey Island in Essex and with 22 listings out of a total 72 around Europe, the UK is again the worst polluter.

If the government does not take action to remedy the situation soon it may face the humiliating prospect of being taken to the European Court of Justice where it could be ordered to pay a large fine until it falls into line.

But local councils and water companies claimed yesterday that the EU report was out of date and unfair.

"This is like Europe ringing up Sunderland football club and suggesting it is about time they got out of Roker Park and built a new football stadium," said a spokesman for Northumbria Water. "We are very disappointed."

"In the time it has taken Europe to write this report we have spent £300m and not only built two treatment plants [for Sunderland and Middlesbrough] but also built four plants in Northumberland, two in Tyne and Wear, two in Durham and three in Cleveland."

Commission officials admitted that the report represented a snapshot of the situation around Europe at the end of 1998 but argued that little has changed since.

"If they have done a lot in the last two years they should have told us," one commission official told the Guardian.

However, a spokeswoman for Brighton and Hove city council said the city was "outraged" by the report's findings and made it clear that it disputes Brussels's claims that there were serious problems off the coast at Brighton and Hove.

Under the EU's urban waste water directive which the UK signed in 1991 all member states were supposed to ensure that towns with more than 10,000 inhabitants had "a stringent [sewage] collection and treatment system" in place by the end of 1998.

But Colin Rennie, chairman of the North of Scotland Water Authority, responsible for water treatment in Dundee, another city named in the report, said yesterday that several of the problems mentioned were close to being solved.

"It is clearly unacceptable that you can flush your toilet in Dundee and that the contents end up in the river Tay. But the good news is that we are only months away from completing the £100m Tay waste water project," he said.

Southern Water also argued that it was working overtime to improve the situation. A new treatment plant had opened at Dover and another was under construction at Hastings. Significantly the report was missing crucial data on the situation in France and Germany but Labour MEP David Bowe said yesterday that Britain still had no grounds for complaint.

"Britain called for offenders to be named and shamed, so we can't complain when we are in the front line."

webTitle: Most life peers refuse to reveal party gifts

fields.headline: Most life peers refuse to reveal party gifts
fields.standfirst: Labour takes coy line on donations in survey
fields.trailText: More than half of the life peers created since 1996 have refused to divulge how much money they have donated to political parties, despite a call for greater transparency by the committee on standards in public life.
fields.byline: Jamie Wilson  and Sally James Gregory
fields.body:
More than half of the life peers created since 1996 have refused to divulge how much money they have donated to political parties, despite a call for greater transparency by the committee on standards in public life.

Labour has promised to deliver more open government but the party's peers were the worst offenders for keeping secret their donations - 65 of 108 either refused or failed to respond to a Guardian survey about party funding by members of the House of Lords.

Of the total of 250 life peers asked to complete the recent questionnaire, 92 failed to respond while a further 34 said they did not want to take part; 72 of the peers who did answer said they had given money to a political party and 51 said they had not donated.

Across the parties, 55% of Conservatives, 45% of crossbenchers, and 22% of Lib Dem peers, failed to respond to the survey.

The results are at odds with a recent report by the committee on standards in public life which said the Lords, as a vital institution in public life and one in which the public and the media were likely to show a growing interest, should adopt greater transparency.

The amounts given by the 29 Labour peers who said they had donated ranged from £5 a month by standing order given by Lord Smith of Gilmorehill, to the £2m from Lord Sainsbury, who also promised a further £2m for the election campaign.

However, a spokesman for the science minister said that Lord Sainsbury would not reveal how much money he had given in the past. "Since David became a minister he has declared exactly how much money he has given. Before that he was a private individual and sees no reason to say how much money, or when, he has given to a political party," the spokesman said.

A number of Labour peers replied that they had refused to respond after taking advice from the Labour whips' office in the Lords.

A spokeswoman for Lady Jay, the leader of the Lords, said the government had advised ministers and peers not to respond. "It is not that they cannot respond, they are advised centrally not to do it," the spokeswoman said. "It is standard practice for all government ministers. Newspapers often use surveys and the standard advice is not to respond. As far as Labour peers go, if they ask for advice - and it is only advice, they can do whatever they want - we would advise them not to take part, as they have no control of the information and can never be sure how it will be used."

Of the peers who did respond only nine said they had given more than £5,000 to a political party.

Lord Bragg, the broadcaster who became a Labour peer in 1998, said he had made two donations of £7,500 in 1997 and a further £7,500 donation in 1999.

Lord Paul, the industrialist who joined the Lords in 1996, said that he had given between £20,000 and £30,000 to Labour every year during the past nine years.

The Conservative party treasurer, Lord Ashcroft, who gave £3m in November 1999, responded by saying: "I appreciate that your letter was something of a standard communication, but I nevertheless enjoyed the novelty of being asked whether I had ever donated money to a political party ... my contributions are disclosed in considerable detail [in the party accounts].

"I sometimes think it is ironic that I'm criticised for the alleged secrecy of my donations, when in reality I am perhaps the most transparent donor of all."

The largest Liberal Democrat donor who responded to the survey was the banker Lord Sandberg, who said he and his wife had donated £1,000 a year during the past three years.

The most interesting response came from Lord Bell, formerly Lady Thatcher's PR guru, who said: "When I worked for Thatcher she used to ask whether you would like love or money. If you said love you got a title and if you said money you got paid."

webTitle: Ragged remains of defeated Tory army fight on

fields.headline: Ragged remains of defeated Tory army fight on
fields.trailText: Time to salute the real opposition in this parliament. William Hague, whom older readers might recall as nominal leader of the Conservative party, doesn't seem to be doing an awful lot.
fields.body:
Time to salute the real opposition in this parliament. William Hague, whom older readers might recall as nominal leader of the Conservative party, doesn't seem to be doing an awful lot. One assumes that he is keeping up with his judo and, between falls, chatting busily away to his friend Sebastian Coe - although since I have never heard Lord Coe utter a single word, I wouldn't know.

I'm sure that his Australian spin-mistress, Amanda Platell, keeps him amused during the long dreary hours of the day. She is a charming and diverting woman. Many a time she and I have rubbed zinc cream on each other's noses, then nipped down to the OTB pub for a Castlemaine XXXX drinking contest, which she invariably wins.

But it all leaves the question: what on earth does Mr Hague find to do all day? He's already fired anyone who's any good from the shadow cabinet, and it can't take more than 20 minutes to prepare for prime minister's question time each week.

In the meantime, the real opposition is being carried out by a small, dedicated team of troublemakers on the Tory benches. If it weren't for them, the government would get away with everything, not just almost everything. They are like guerrillas fighting in the forests and hills, the rag-taggle remains of a defeated army. Labour may hold the towns and fields, but they never know when a sniper might open fire, a ball-bearing factory set on fire, the telegraph line brought down.

Not all of the motley crew were present for defence questions yesterday, but John Bercow was. He always is. He is indefatigable. The MP for Buckingham shot up a single longing glance at a young female colleague of mine in the press gallery, but then returned to glowering angrily at the ministerial team in front of him.

Mr Bercow is nominally a frontbench spokesman on home affairs - Mini-me to Ann Widdecombe's Dr Evilette - but he is really only happy barking away from the backbenches. Yesterday he accused the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, of making a pact with the French to destroy Nato. The notion of a secret treaty had a fine old-fashioned ring. ("If this paper were to fall into the wrong hands, Mr Holmes, the consequences for Europe would be incalculable ..")

Step forward Julian Lewis. He also attacked the French. "Are they going to allocate a single extra soldier, sailor or airman for the defence of Europe?" he demanded furiously. Mr Hoon looked flustered by all these attacks on our froggie friends. Mr Lewis, like Mr Bercow, is certainly several cherries short of a clafoutis, but that doesn't make him any less effective.

Iain Duncan-Smith - in name the main defence spokesman, but in practice an attack backbencher - had a go at the prime minister, but via the French. Who had Tony Blair meant when he said there were some people who wanted to destroy Nato? He persisted several times. Mr Hoon looked more worried.

Also in attendance were the other guerrillas: Desmond Swayne, the cad of the New Forest, Gerald Howarth, who is becoming persistent and vicious, Anne McIntosh, who I have been rude about in the past, but who is developing a nice line in anxious nagging.

Then there is Edward Leigh, red-faced with fury at the government's misdeeds, and even Michael Fabricant who has, thankfully, given up his attempt to become a world statesman and has settled for the more honourable role of troublemaker.

These people almost never miss a sitting. Where Mr Hague is in the meantime, we cannot know, though I myself have enjoyed the new version of Crossroads.

fields.headline: £200,000 question haunts Robinson
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: With a general election expected soon and the Hinduja affair still rumbling on, it is just the sort of scandal Labour must have been hoping to avoid.
fields.body:
With a general election expected soon and the Hinduja affair still rumbling on, it is just the sort of scandal Labour must have been hoping to avoid.

But yesterday the party became mired in new allegations with the publication of a potentially explosive investigation of its former paymaster-general, Geoffrey Robinson, which claims he received £200,000 from the publishing tycoon Robert Maxwell and then lied to parliament about it.

Investigative journalist Tom Bower claims to have unearthed an invoice revealing that the fee was paid to the multi millionaire MP by the entrepreneur despite Mr Robinson denying this was the case to the prime minister, the chancellor, or Sir Gordon Downey, the then parliamentary commissioner for standards.

Mr Bower also suggests the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, deliberately chose to suppress a report into the affair by his department, which revealed the former minister had misled parliament, because of a fear of unleashing a "political firestorm".

Claiming to offer "conclusive proof of Mr Robinson's sustained dishonesty", the serialisation in yesterday's Daily Mail which continues today traces the origins of Mr Robinson's wealth back to his relationship with Joska Bourgeois, an octagenarian businesswoman who had been his "lover, friend and surrogate mother" for some two decades. The book says that the MP inherited as much as $20m (£14m) on her death in 1994. Mr Robinson, who was chief executive of Jaguar in the 70s, was seen as someone who could build bridges with business leaders and was swiftly given a place on Gordon Brown's shadow Treasury team. He donated £200,000 to finance Mr Brown's research, offering him the use of his apartment in Cannes and footing some of his bills when he holidayed in Cape Cod.

When Labour won the election in 1997 Mr Robinson was appointed paymaster general. But Mr Bowers said that this appointment brought problems for Mr Robinson because of his one-time association with the Mirror Group proprietor whose mysterious death in 1991 came as his business empire started to unravel.

When Mr Maxwell needed a non-executive chairman who knew about engineering for Hollis, a small timber merchant and furniture manufacturer he controlled, he appointed Robinson.

The post was unpaid but the MP eventually demanded an annual salary of £200,000, it is alleged. The sum was paid in 1990, though he would later deny that he had ever requested or received this.

As the Maxwell empire started to disintegrate, Mr Robinson also bought the profitable parts of Hollis for a knockdown price of £2.9m and moved them to his company, Transtec, where soaring shares suggested they were worth £40m. Hollis's shareholders were then burdened with debts of £3m - ensuring there was no money to pay creditors.

Laughed off

Once a minister, Mr Robinson laughed off links with the tycoon and failed to register his directorships of three Maxwell companies with the House of Commons. But in 1998 a Tory party researcher spotted the £200,000 payment in Hollis's accounts: when questioned by Tony Blair he stuck to his line: "I never asked for the money and wasn't paid."

The book claims it was a lie unwittingly repeated by the prime minister's spokesman and believed by the Labour-dominated select committee on standards.

An internal inquiry was launched but before it could report, the existence of the £373,000 loan to Peter Mandelson emerged and Mr Robinson and Mr Mandelson, who as trade secretary was supposed to be investigating him, resigned.

Mr Robinson began hinting to Blair's close aide, Anji Hunter, that the government should protect itself from his anger by suppressing the report.

But Hugh Aldous, the investigator appointed by the Department of Trade and Industry, had unearthed the original invoice Robinson had presented in 1990, complete with the word "paid" scribbled on it by Michael Stoney, the former Hollis finance director, whom Mr Robinson had allegedly coerced into signing an affadavit denying this was the case. The 1999 report explained the invoice had been paid and reported on the alleged conspiracy between Mr Robinson and Mr Maxwell to strip Hollis of its valuable assets just before it went into liquidation.

But Stephen Byers decided the findings should remain confidential and gave a written answer announcing this conclusion on December 21, the last day of the parliamentary session before Christmas.

Bower claims, however, that the Coventry North West MP finally admitted the truth to him at a meeting at the Grosvenor House Hotel last December, but suggested he was still hoping to evade disclosure: Confronted by the journalist, Mr Robinson acknowledged proof of a cheque and invoice existed, but said: "No one knows into which account it was paid."

Two tycoons and their dogged biographer

Geoffrey Robinson

The son of a Sheffield furniture manufacturer, the millionaire businessman-politico first became an MP in 1976 but only rose within the party, becoming paymaster general, after his largely inherited wealth enabled him to develop a closeness with Gordon Brown and Tony Blair.

Educated at Cambridge and Yale, he was chief executive of Jaguar in the seventies, during which time he befriended Joska Bourgeois. Thanks to this relationship, and his burgeoning wealth from his collapsed engineering company TransTec, he now owns a £2m Tuscan villa, other properties in the south of France, a £2m mansion near Godalming, Surrey, and a Park Lane penthouse. Married with two grown-up children, and, since 1996, proprietor of the New Statesman magazine, his ministerial career collapsed in December 1998 with the disclosure of his undeclared home loan to Peter Mandelson.

Robert Maxwell

The corrupt proprietor of Mirror Group Newspapers and a one-time Labour MP, Maxwell drowned from his yacht, in November 1991. Now notorious for defrauding Mirror employees of their pensions, the Czech Jewish refugee, whose family were largely wiped out in the Holocaust, moved to Britain after joining the army in the second world war, changed his name, and launched a publishing career that would eventually made him one of the world's richest men. He spent six years in parliament as a Labour MP, but lost interest in Westminster politics after it became clear the then prime minister, Harold Wilson, would never appoint him to the cabinet.

Tom Bower

A former barrister turned professional biographer, Bower is renowned for investigating tycoons: previous biographies have focused on Maxwell, Tiny Rowland, Mohamed Al Fayed, and Richard Branson. Less than revelatory about himself, the 53-year-old refuses to talk to journalists profiling him. After reading law at the London School of Economics, where he acted as press officer to students during the sit-ins of the sixties, he briefly practised before joining the BBC as a researcher and going on to make documentaries as a producer and reporter.

webTitle: Vaz 'intervened in City sex bias case'

fields.headline: Vaz 'intervened in City sex bias case'
fields.trailText: A new row broke out last night over the judgment of Keith Vaz after it was revealed that he had used his position as a government minister to intervene on behalf of a 46-year-old Asian woman taking a sex discrimination case against a firm of City lawyers.
fields.body:
A new row broke out last night over the judgment of Keith Vaz after it was revealed that he had used his position as a government minister to intervene on behalf of a 46-year-old Asian woman taking a sex discrimination case against a firm of City lawyers.

The intervention came to light during the Commons inquiry into complaints brought against the Europe minister.

Three MPs on the standards and privileges committee were questioning Sarosh Zaiwalla - the City lawyer who was cleared of making large donations to the minister - when he admitted his relations with Mr Vaz were "very cold" following the minister's intervention in a private case involving his firm.

Mr Zaiwalla told MPs under parliamentary privilege: "I had formally complained to the cabinet secretary [Sir Richard Wilson] and the prime minister, because one of my staff took my firm to the employment tribunal under the Sex Discrimination Act because she was not given a training contract.

"At the hearing, surprise, surprise, the minister of the crown, Mr Vaz, gave evidence - his statement was read out - that the individual was a very fit individual and if he was in my place he would have given her a training contract.

"She had come from the lord chancellor's department to join my firm as an eight week contract in the hope that she would get a training contract. She did not get it, so she alleged that I had exercised bias in favour of a male white and she oddly went back to the lord chancellor's department. She was an employee of the lord chancellor's department when Mr Vaz was a minister there."

During the hearing Mr Zaiwala claimed she "boasted that Gary Hart [Lord Irvine's special adviser] is supporting the proceedings against my firm".

Mr Zaiwalla said he lost the case but has won a right to appeal, after getting a judicial review of the finding in which he had argued that the intervention of the lord chancellor's department had interfered with the balance of the case.

He also disclosed that he had discussed the matter with the minister's wife, Maria Fernandes, during an Indo-European Union economic summit in Lisbon - and she told him that the legal assistant did not have Mr Vaz's authority to produce the letter. "This was a serious matter because that meant that the court had been misled," he told MPs.

"After the matter went to the cabinet secretary, Geoffrey Bindman [Mr Vaz's solicitor] wrote to me confirming exactly what Maria had told me: that Mr Vaz had not authorised her to use the copy of the letter for the lord chancellor's file, signed by Mr Vaz."

The lord chancellor's department said it did not want comment on the case and they say the member of staff is no longer employed there.

Last night Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "This curious case once again questions the judgment of Mr Vaz. He is getting involved in a matter which has clearly nothing to do with his ministerial responsibilities. This is another question that Mr Vaz needs to answer."

His colleague, Andrew Lansley, last night wrote to the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin, formally complaining that Mrs Vaz had not disclosed his business connections with the Hinduja brothers.

Downing Street continued to defend the minister. A spokesman said: "Keith has made a detailed rebuttal of the allegations as they have come up."

webTitle: Matthew Engel: Save the Tories, call an election

fields.headline: Save the Tories, call an election
fields.standfirst:
Only someone determined to keep them alive would consider it

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Only someone determined to keep them alive would consider it.
fields.body:
The best-thumbed volume in my school library (aside from a couple of novels rumoured to have mucky bits) was a reference work called Pros and Cons, which laid out neatly in columns the arguments for and against various propositions - a crucial aid for current affairs prep and union debates.

Many of the topics have now been settled one way or the other, eg "Should we introduce bimetallism?" and "Is racial discrimination a good thing?" But there was also of course "Should we adopt proportional representation?", an argument that continues, in certain circles, in precisely the same sterile school-debate terms it did then.

On Friday Paddy Ashdown (or maybe he's Sir Paddy or Lord Ashdown of Yeovil - it's hard to keep up with fading-out British politicians) apparently said that if Labour reneged on electoral reform, they would suffer at the ballot box and "would deserve to do so", a remark which offers final proof that it is possible to spend too many evenings of your life at Liberal Democrat meetings.

A few weeks ago this column put forward the thesis that - thanks to demographics as well as William Hague - there was a historic opportunity to dismiss the Conservative party from the forefront of British politics, and that it COULD happen if the other parties could only see it. This was misinterpreted by various readers as a prediction that it WOULD happen. And they say journalists misquote people.

The argument is that the chance is there, or would be there, for the Liberal Democrats to replace the Tories as the opposition to Labour, if only they had the balls for it. This is the precise reverse of the thinking behind the secret Blair-Ashdown deal of 1997 that saw a Lib-Lab alliance as a permanent anti-Tory majority. That never made any sense. If the two parties were now in coalition, where could anti-government protest votes ever go? Either to the Conservatives, to a new third party which might be called the Liberals, or perhaps to the Coalition of Rabble-Rousing Agrarians and Petrol Protesters (Crapp).

Proportional representation is defunct in Britain because Labour activists loathe it and on this issue would - indeed already have - made a difference; because the system proposed by the Jenkins commission was insanely complex; and because the public are indifferent. In so far as it has been introduced already, it has benefited only one party: the Tories. In the 1999 Scottish and Welsh elections, they won just one parliamentary seat (Monmouth) yet, thanks to PR, they have 18 seats in the Scottish parliament and nine in Wales.

The real pros-and-cons discussion in Downing Street this weekend was different but equally absurd. It is hard to believe that anyone can still be arguing for a general election on May 3. I don't want to come the old-soldier-back-from-the-wars here, but I am certain that if Tony Blair went out and smelt the burning carcasses - and the despair - he would instantly reach the same conclusion.

There are, as Hugo Young put it on this page last Thursday, two sides to this, the moral and political, and they coincide. It is outrageous to contemplate a general election (a local one is a lesser issue) when people are actually confined to their houses because of an epidemic. The argument that they can vote by post is callous and wrong. Can a country with a Human Rights Act stop people campaigning for Crapp if they want?

It might be possible to regard foot and mouth like a flu outbreak, to be treated by injections, TLC and teaspoons of bovine Calpol. But it's too late for that. The government has gone into full shock-horror crisis mode. It cannot now pretend that there is nothing much going on.

Above all, the election is not a necessary one. The parliament has a full year to go. Electors, even if they cannot smell the charred flesh, can smell chicanery. They punished Harold Wilson in June 1970 when he tried to stage a sunshine-and-smiles election. They evened the score less than four years later during a miners' strike when Ted Heath asked "Who runs the country?" and voters decided it was a silly question.

This, Paddy (Sir Paddy/Lord Ashdown/whichever), is what could make Labour suffer at the ballot box. In 1970, the Tories were 12% behind and won. The situation now is potentially far more volatile and dangerous than it was during the petrol crisis last September when Crapp briefly seized control of the agenda. No one knows how bad foot and mouth is going to get.

In such circumstances even a 29% lead is not invulnerable, even against a party led by William Hague - if the prime minister starts to be seen as an opportunist first rather than a statesman. I begin to sense a conspiracy: a conspiracy to ensure that the Conservative party does not die.

webTitle: Hague calls for local elections to be postponed

fields.headline: Hague calls for local elections to be postponed
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The Tories today attacked Labour's handling of the foot and mouth crisis as "grossly inadequate", with the Conservative leader, William Hague, calling on the government to postpone county council elections in the areas worst hit by the disease.
fields.body:
The Tories today attacked Labour's handling of the foot and mouth crisis as "grossly inadequate", with the Conservative leader, William Hague, calling on the government to postpone county council elections in the areas worst hit by the disease.

Mr Hague said it was now "undeniable" that there could be serious problems in going ahead with elections in counties such as Devon and Cumbria on the scheduled date of May 3.

Earlier today, the shadow agriculture minister, Tim Yeo, called for hundreds of troops to be used to bury carcasses and to help arrange a slaughtering programme. Labour has assigned more than 200 army personnel the task of giving advice to farmers on how to dispose of culled animals in Devon and Cumbria.

Fifty two-man military teams were starting work at sites across Devon this morning, backed by a 30-strong planning team based in Exeter.

Mr Yeo said: "We have this morning over 60,000 carcasses rotting in open fields and almost 100,000 animals awaiting slaughter, diagnosed as diseased. The government's response is to bring in 50 two-man teams from the army to advise private contractors on how to tackle that backlog. That is a grossly inadequate response.

"We would tell the army to get on with the full task. They must be deployed with all their resources and their logistical skills, the equipment they have got, to start digging graves for those animals on site - on-farm burial," he added.

Today's attack on Labour's handling of the situation and its election strategy is the clearest signal yet that Mr Hague believes Tony Blair's plans for a general election on May 3 should be halted and the national poll postponed until June or the autumn. However, a slim majority of voters believe elections should go ahead on May 3 despite the foot and mouth outbreak, according to a poll published today.

The NOP poll of 1,000 people taken this weekend found that 47% of those asked agreed with the statement: "It is important to maintain normal life as far as possible and stick to the timetable to hold elections on May 3." But 40% favoured a delay.

Half of those surveyed believed the government has taken the right decisions in tackling the crisis, compared to four in 10 (39%) who disagreed.

Mr Hague said today: "It is undeniable now that there could be serious problems in holding county council elections on May 3. The timetable for local elections starts running next Monday - March 26.

"I think the government should promote legislation this week to allow council elections in certain counties to be postponed, if appropriate, and to take a decision on that over the next few weeks."

In Devon, some 16 county council wards have cases of foot and mouth and in half of those the Conservative party candidate is a farmer, said Mr Hague.

There is "a strong and widespread opinion" in both Devon and Cumbria that action should now be taken to permit the postponement of local elections if it proves necessary, he added.

webTitle: Election date hangs in the balance

fields.headline: Election date hangs in the balance
fields.standfirst: Public opinion indicates that the foot and mouth crisis should be brought under control before an election is announced, says political editor Michael White
fields.trailText: Public opinion indicates that the foot and mouth crisis should be brought under control before an election is announced, says political editor Michael White.
fields.body:
It is an open secret that Tony Blair wants to hold the general election on May 3. So when the Sun announced today that polling will indeed take place on May 3 ("Sun was right all along") it is behaving in its most comfortable role as propagandist for the winning side.

For whenever the election comes, there is little doubt about who will win. All the polls agree that Labour is 15-20% ahead of William Hague's hapless Tories. That is why Mr Hague and his team are gently urging postponement in the national interest; they hope that "something may turn up" and save them from their own folly.

Like Mr Blair, they solemnly invoke the national interest. Like him they are busy plotting to say dreadful things about the opposing camp when the starting gun is fired. There is an air of quiet desperation among the Tories.

It is one more reason why the Sun finally lost patience with the opposition leader over his "foreign land" speech this month. Like its proprietor, Rupert Murdoch, in every country he does business, the paper hates a loser.

But whether the election takes place on May 3 is still not quite certain. Large parts of the countryside are out of bounds; Europe and many scientists wonder if Whitehall and its vets have got their foot and mouth policy right.

Public opinion (can the Sun be far behind?) shows signs of ill-ease that a government with a huge Commons majority - and a year in hand before it has to go to the country - might put its own convenience before the need to get the outbreak, if not under control, then at least on the wane.

Lots could happen in the next few days that would make such a decision to go on May 3, local elections, general election and (it gets forgotten) the far more intrusive April 29 census, look shabby, inappropriate even.

A bit like taking the kids' nanny on holiday to the Canaries the day after the wife's funeral. Most Britons do not live in the countryside, but they do now grasp the horror afflicting rural dwellers: slaughter of much loved (and valuable) herds, mass burnings, lanes and paths closed, families trapped on farms.

That is where the "inappropriate" tag comes in. But ministers have a double answer to that. Some 95% of voters live in towns, cities and suburbs. Modern electioneering no longer involves big public meetings, most canvassing is done by phone, not up lanes, and - since this year - most voters can apply for a postal vote (PV) without a special excuse.

In other words, logistics are not a problem. The census is trickier because officials must visit every home. Delay would cost £100m. They will probably get round it.

Mr Hague and his ag-spokesman, Tim Yeo, protest that 16 out of 54 counties are affected by foot and mouth. Other local authorities, the British waterways board and the National Trust, have also taken risk-averse decisions and shut down their footpaths. Many of our council candidates are farmers, the Tory leadership adds.

At today's 11am Downing Street briefing, reporters were told: "We will listen to what people have to say. But it is our very, very strong view that it would send the worst signal that Britain is closed for business if we were not to have elections. As we have said throughout, this is a very long haul. Are you suggesting they [the elections] should be postponed for several months?"

That last point, which has taken No 10 some weeks to stumble upon, may be the best argument Mr Blair can deploy, the equivalent of the "Business as usual" signs, scrawled in cardboard and pinned to half-destroyed shops during the German blitz on British cities in 1940-41.

In other words, tourism, a far bigger industry and export earner than agriculture would suffer even more than it is already suffering if an election postponement was echoed around the world. Ministers are desperately trying to get Britons to start going to the country after weeks when they have patriotically stayed away.

What quite they do there is not clear. Not everyone can get to St Austell, where the Eden project - the dome that will really work - opened in foot and mouth-free Cornwall on Saturday. Pubs? Restaurants? A bracing walk around the car park? In many parts these are the only options still open.

Mr Blair says "Instead of Don't Go Unless, Do Go Unless" - hardly a snappy slogan, and the admen about to be employed will do better. Meanwhile the country industries are losing £100m a week as Easter and even summer cancellations proliferate.

The loss of foreign visitors, their dollars, francs and yen, would be even more grievous. A silent spring indeed. As with so much of this crisis it throws into acute relief deep questions about how we view our countryside and what it is for. Those questions will have to wait.

So - for a few days at least - should tactical questions about the election. By all means let Millbank planners and their rivals in Tory central office work on the schedules they have polished for months - and for May 3. But the polls suggest that voters would like their government to concentrate on foot and mouth this week.

They may be set to re-elect New Labour - they are. But the public mood is volatile. Voters do not love the government so much that they will overlook selfish opportunism if that if how they judge it.

webTitle: Tories and Lib Dems step up attack on Robinson

fields.headline: Tories and Lib Dems step up attack on Robinson
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats are joining forces today to increase the pressure on Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general, over a disputed payment from tycoon Robert Maxwell.
fields.body:
The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats are joining forces today to increase the pressure on Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general, over a disputed payment from tycoon Robert Maxwell.

The fallout from the row - which centres on a £200,000 payment which Mr Robinson insists he never received - has also led the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, to threaten to sue the Daily Mail.

The claim that he did take the money is made in a new book about Mr Robinson, now the MP for Coventry North West, by investigative journalist Tom Bower.

Today the Tories will ask the Commons standard and privileges commissioner Elizabeth Filkin to investigate the reports, and Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker is to table detailed parliamentary questions about the affair.

Yesterday Mr Byers took the unprecedented step of threatening to sue the Daily Mail over an allegation that, while he was trade secretary, he "buried" an official report into the business affairs of the former paymaster general, who resigned in 1998 over his home loan to Peter Mandelson.

It would make legal and political history for a current cabinet minister to appear in court over a libel action. Today the paper said it was "100%" confident of its story - and stepped up its attack, claiming the chancellor, Gordon Brown, pressured a civil servant into calling an offshore tax haven a "family trust."

The Treasury permanent secretary Sir Terry Burns refused to do so. In a statement, Mr Robinson said the article "failed to present any new information."

He added: "The claim that I was paid £200,000 as chairman of Hollis Industries has been made before and was fully investigated by the DTI who have today made their position clear about the Bower story.

"My own position has been absolutely clear throughout. Neither I nor any company associated with me received this money."

webTitle: I know there is more to do

fields.headline: I know there is more to do
fields.standfirst: The common good: the Prime Minister joins the Guardian debate on the public services
fields.trailText: Labour has the determination to reform our public services, to invest now in modernised public services and to provide the kind and quality of public services which people in this country both need and deserve. We intend to seize the moment.
fields.body:
We face what may be a historic choice over Britain's public services: between investment for the future and cuts which will turn the clock back. And a historic challenge too: to take the best of what public services can and should be and to reform our public services to bring them all to the level of the best.

Labour has the determination to reform our public services, to invest now in modernised public services and to provide the kind and quality of public services which people in this country both need and deserve. We intend to seize the moment.

I have absolutely no doubt about the vital importance of good public services for this country. Nor of the debt we owe as a society to those who, often struggling against the odds, help provide them.

It's often easy in this country for the powerful to get their voice heard. But it's hard to do so for those who don't have that access. That's why I strongly applaud what the Guardian is doing today: putting in practice its own commitment to our public services by giving those who work in them the chance and space to tell their story.

I have no doubt what their stories will be. Of course there will be frustrations and disappointments. Not enough resources. Not enough support. But I know what the overriding majority will say: they will tell a story of commitment, dedication and belief. Of public service as a vocation. Of their sense of purpose and of the value that their community - local and national - places upon them.

Because every week I meet and talk to those working in our public services whose pride in what they do - despite their concerns or difficulties - shines through in almost every word they say. I know how we depend, as families and as a country, on the commitment and talents of our teachers, doctors, nurses, police officers and hundreds and thousands of other dedicated public servants. I want to see that story told and retold. I also know how too often these same public servants feel undervalued and taken for granted. It's time for that aspect of the story to stop.

Good public services are vital for our continued prosperity as a country. More than ever before, for instance, our national economic wellbeing as a country depends upon a well-educated workforce, making sure we make the best of everyone's talents.

They are crucial, too, to our wellbeing as a society. Because they're used by everyone, public services are part of the glue of our community. They help tackle social exclusion, provide peace of mind for us all and remind us that we have responsibilities to each other as well as rights.

And it's exactly because good public services are central to a modern, prosperous and fairer society that revitalising and improving them is central to this Labour government's ambitions for our country.

That's not always been the case. For too long, our public services have been under-funded and undervalued. The result was that - despite the commitment and efforts of public servants themselves - they were losing the confidence of those who depended upon them and those who worked in them.

Turning this round was never going to be easy. It needed a change in attitude in government, reforms and massive increase in investment not just for one year but over the long haul.

I believe we've made a good start. More doctors, more nurses, more teachers. More in training - though we need many, many more. Hospitals and schools getting better. Education spending now up by £450 per pupil. Investment in school buildings tripled since 1997 to over £2bn a year. Health spending increasing over the next four years by twice the level under the Tories. Investment to take police numbers to their highest ever level. Capital investment in social housing will have increased from £1.5bn in 1997 to £4bn in 2004.

I'm proud of what we've achieved so far together. But I do accept that there is a great deal more to do.

That's why next week we will be setting out our policies and our programme on public services in Britain: a government paper which will both set out our reforming approach and make clear our commitment to public services and to public servants: the value we place upon them and the contribution they make to all our lives.

We will chart the way forward for public services in Britain. A way forward which values our public services and invests in them. A way forward which places reform and improvement in our public services at the heart of what the government is about. A way forward for the common good.

fields.headline: The breath of renewal
fields.standfirst: The common good: a leading academic joins the Guardian debate on the public services
fields.trailText: In his first term Blair established a bridgehead - the beginnings of a constitutional revolution; normalisation of relations with the rest of the EU; modest, but real, fiscal redistribution. It is time to follow the bridgehead with a breakthrough.  One of the crucial objectives of such a breakthrough would be the renewal of the public services and the culture that sustains them.
fields.body:
Three great questions now confront the Labour party. Assuming it wins the election in a few weeks time, can it finally break the umbilical cord of privilege, snobbery and inertia which has tied the British state to the Conservative party for more than 100 years? Can it develop a coherent social-democratic governing philosophy, capable of guiding it through the inevitable uncertainties and contingencies of government? Can it revive our battered, resource-starved public services, and breathe new life into the ethic of citizenship and service which is fundamental to the public realm?

The third question holds the key to the first two. A substantial election victory in May is a precondition of the progressive century of Blair's dreams, but his real test will come after polling day. He has been astonishingly successful in marginalising the Conservative party, but the job is not yet done. The forces which have produced Sharon in Israel, Haider in Austria, Berlusconi in Italy and George Bush in the US have equivalents in Britain. The threat of a hard-right resurgence will not disappear until social-democratic norms permeate the public culture and the structures of the state. In his first term Blair established a bridgehead - the beginnings of a constitutional revolution; normalisation of relations with the rest of the EU; modest, but real, fiscal redistribution. It is time to follow the bridgehead with a breakthrough.

One of the crucial objectives of such a breakthrough would be the renewal of the public services and the culture that sustains them. Social democracy and the public realm are inextricably intertwined. Without an ideologically confident and politically effective social-democratic movement to champion them, the public services are always at risk. Without a vibrant public realm, ring-fenced from the market realm, social-democratic politics cannot flourish. Public services depend on a culture of citizenship and equity - on a culture in which professional pride in a job well done or a sense of civic duty or a mixture of both replace the hope of gain and the fear of loss as spurs to action. And that is pre-eminently the culture of social democracy.

It is now dangerously attenuated. The single most important element in the New Right project of the 1980s and 90s was a relentless Kulturkampf designed to root it out. Deregulation, privatisation, so-called public-private partnerships, proxy markets, performance indicators mimicking those of corporate management and a systematic assault on professional autonomy narrowed the public realm and blurred the distinction between it and the market realm. Public functions of all kinds were farmed out to unaccountable appointed bodies, dominated by business interests and managed according to market principles. Intermediate institutions like the BBC, the universities, the schools, museums and the health service were forced, so far as possible, into a market mould. So was the senior civil service, where the frontiers of the public realm had been most zealously guarded, and in which its values had been most thoroughly internalised.

The tatty, shabby, over-stretched public services of 21st century Britain are the most obvious legacy of this Kulturkampf, but they are not the most dangerous one. Incessant marketisation has done even more damage than low taxation and resource starvation. It has generated a culture of distrust, which is nibbling away at the values of professionalism, citizenship, equity and service like an acrid fog. For the marketisers, the professional, public service ethic is a con. Professionals are self-interested rent-seekers, trying to force the price of their labour above its market value. The service ethic is a device to legitimise a web of monopolistic cartels whose real purpose is to rip off the consumer. There is no point in appealing to the values of common citizenship. There are no citizens; there are only customers. Public servants are inherently untrustworthy. If they are allowed autonomy, they will abuse it. Like everyone else, they can be motivated only by sticks and carrots. If possible, privatisation must expose them to the sticks and carrots of market competition. If not, they must be kept on their toes by repeated audits, assessments and appraisals.

Twenty years of this mean-spirited rhetoric have demoralised the public services and encouraged users who can afford it to buy their way out. The service ethic still has devoted champions among doctors, teachers, nurses, social workers, academics, broadcasters, judges, trade-union officials, local government officials and NGO workers. But danger signs are everywhere. The most spectacular have appeared in Whitehall itself. First the Scott report and then the Phillips report showed that the culture of disinterested professionalism, which held that the civil servant's duty was to serve the public interest and tell truth to power, is in tatters.

And that is only the beginning. The growing interpenetration of the worlds of politics and business; the sleaze which has accompanied it; the dumbing down of the BBC; the sponsorship culture which has invaded virtually every form of public entertainment from opera to football; the diversion of academic energies from the pursuit of knowledge and the education of the young to a desperate scrabbling for advantage in mindless assessment exercises; all tell the same story. They all show that the dykes which our Victorian ancestors built to protect the public realm from the encroaching imperialism of the market realm have been breached repeatedly.

Few social democrats would disagree with that, but the implications are more contentious than appears at first sight. The public realm cannot be resuscitated by ministerial fiat or bureaucratic intervention, no matter how well-intentioned. The service ethic is hollow without a supporting ethic of democracy and diversity. Marketisation made headway because it spoke to a widespread popular revolt against the condescension and exclusiveness of the elites that used to manage the public services, and to a well-founded popular demand for accountability. The accountability it offered was deformed and corrosive. But that does not imply a return to the public realm of the old days. Accountability should be sought through participation, openness and a willingness to listen, not the price mechanism or the iron cage of bureaucratic audit. The social democracy of the 21st century must recover the decentralist, participatory strands in its own tradition, and marry them with the equivalent strands in the social liberal tradition.

Top-down, central-state social democracy is a busted flush. It runs against the grain of the information age, and flies in the face of the cultural revolution of the last 35 years. Politely, but firmly, it should be junked. This is exactly what Tony Blair promised in his early days as Labour leader. Keynes, Beveridge and Lloyd George, he repeatedly insisted, were as much at home in the New Labour pantheon as Attlee, Bevin or Bevan. He picked up the mantle of constitutional reform and political decentralisation where the Asquith government had dropped it in 1914. The result was an astonishingly far-reaching transfer of power from the central state to lower tiers of government. Then the centralist, metropolitan side of the social-democratic tradition reasserted itself, and the revolution stalled. It is time to get back on track.

 David Marquand is the principal of Mansfield College, Oxford, a former Labour politician and a founder member of the Social Democratic party.

webTitle: Students join battle against foot and mouth

fields.headline: Students join battle against foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Final year university veterinary students yesterday started helping trained vets detect and prevent the spread of foot and mouth disease. According to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, 120 students are currently helping out and many more are on shortlists, ready and waiting to travel into the countryside.
fields.body:
Final year university veterinary students yesterday started helping trained vets detect and prevent the spread of foot and mouth disease. According to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, 120 students are currently helping out and many more are on shortlists, ready and waiting to travel into the countryside.

The trainee vets are inspecting animals, gathering animals for slaughter, packing dead animals, cleaning and disinfecting, inspecting records and carrying out government patrols of affected areas.

Yesterday's move is MAFF's latest attempt to meet criticism from farmers that its vets are failing to inspect farms as rigorously as is required to stop an epidemic that has reached nearly every corner of Britain.

On Friday, 40 final year students at Liverpool University were given a crash course in foot and mouth. They were introduced to the disease and its symptoms through videos and given a talk by a specialist. By today, most are out actually helping detect the disease.

"Some have gone to Wales, some to Carlisle and some to Stafford," said Dr Bob Ward, senior lecturer at the division of farm animal studies at the University of Liverpool.

"It's altruistic, they want to help farming. But also, they need experience. A part of their course is extramural studies, a lot of these vets would be going to work in the countryside now anyway and can't now go because of the crisis."

The government figure of 120 students does not include those ready to go but not yet in the field. At Edinburgh and at Glasgow universities only 12 students are currently helping in the countryside, but 40 students are on a shortlist.

"Those who have gone out so far have been posted to Ayrshire, but those on the shortlist can be told to go anywhere," said Professor Joe Mayhew, lecturer on veterinary clinical studies at the Royal Dick school of veterinary medicine at the University of Edinburgh.

"Many of these students are from the country and feel passionately about this. But we made it easier for them: every student has to do veterinary practice of some kind and we've said that this MAFF thing counts," he continued.

While the benefit to students of learning about a virulent disease is clear, Professor Mack Johnston of the Royal Veterinary College in London believes the experience is also traumatic for the students involved.

"One student who has been out there has been upset. He's been faced with something quite distressing. You train to be a vet because you want to help and suddenly you are killing," he said.

webTitle: Universities and teachers get nervous over Scottish exam delay

fields.headline: Universities and teachers get nervous over Scottish exam delay
fields.trailText: Scottish higher examination results are going to be late again this year, but universities are not likely to be affected, according to the Scottish Qualifications Authority - a view met with some scepticism by those burned by last year's experience
fields.body:
Scottish higher examination results are going to be late again this year, but universities are not likely to be affected, according to the Scottish Qualifications Authority - a view met with some scepticism by those burned by last year's experience

Bill Morton, chief executive of the Scottish Qualifications Authority said on BBC Radio Scotland this morning that the results will be one week late, since the authority is short of 1,600 markers, despite the offer of a 50% pay rise.

Special arrangements are being put in place so universities should receive the results earlier.

Mr Morton remained confident, however, that the situation would not mirror the problems of last year, where some students' results were inaccurate or delayed, due mainly to faulty software.

Mr Morton's confidence was not widely shared, however.

Ronnie Smith, chief executive of the Educational Institute of Scotland believes that there could be problems once again: "I don't think anyone can be sanguine or confident about this working. This far into the process they are working right to the wire, nothing is early. I wouldn't rule out the possibility of slippage happening which would have the consequence of affecting universities."

Robin MacAlpine, public affairs officer for Universities Scotland, representing 21 Scottish higher education institutions, has only been given informal assurances that universities will receive results before students.

"If we don't get the results early, it raises two problems. If we can't process information before students get their results, we can't help them when the call us. Also, today's announcement moves the higher back very close to A-level time. The gap between A-level and higher results had meant we could process one set of results before the other. However, our absolute priority is getting accurate exam results, and if a delay makes that possible then OK," said Mr MacAlpine.

Some Scottish universities are also not reassured by the SQA's confidence. One administrator remembered, "They always gave us the best case scenario, they would say, 'everything's fine, it'll be fixed in four days', and it wasn't. They are already behind, and so we aren't confident."

webTitle: Rebel museums hold out against free access

fields.headline: Rebel museums hold out against free access
fields.standfirst: Row looms as Chris Smith battles for free entry by 2002
fields.trailText: A clash was last night looming between a rump of renegade "Thatcherite" museums and the culture secretary over the abolition of admission charges.
fields.body:
A clash was last night looming between a rump of renegade "Thatcherite" museums and the culture secretary over the abolition of admission charges.

The Natural History and the Imperial War museums are among the dissidents limbering up to resist free access for all to the most important national collections.

Their stance has infuriated Chris Smith, the culture secretary, who has fought a protracted battle with both the Treasury and customs and excise to ensure free universal entry by 2002.

The Guardian has learned that having battled for three years for free access, and been stung by criticism which had questioned whether he could deliver it, Mr Smith is determined push the policy through "at any cost". A source said: "Nothing, or no one, will be allowed to stop this happening."

What has particularly angered him is the rebels' assertion that unless the public is made to pay for admission to museums "they won't fully appreciate what they are being allowed to see". Mr Smith finds this view patronising.

The confrontation is as much ideological as financial, with many of the charging museums wedded to Thatcherite dogmas of maximising revenue and marketing, while the opposing camp, led by the Tate and National galleries, stress the importance of public service, access and education.

Those museums opposing charges have grown increasingly frustrated by the chargers' stance, which one leading curator labelled as "ungrateful, perverse and sending all the wrong signals to the public about museums". Another characterised the chargers as a bunch of "I'm all right Jacks".

Mr Smith's coup in having the VAT rules altered in the budget so that museums would not be penalised if they abolished charges was welcomed by the broad coalition which had campaigned for free entry.

The Victoria & Albert immediately announced that it would "go free as soon as possible" having seen its visitor numbers halve since it introduced charges. The nearby Science Museum is also believed to be prepared to ditch its charging policy.

But the Natural History Museum, the biggest of the Kensington museums and the long time leader of the "chargers", is holding out. Its director, Neil Chalmers, merely "noted" the VAT change in the budget but refused to say whether the institution would drop its admission charges.

"The VAT issue was one of the key problems, and we are waiting for what the government has to say about compensation with keen interest before deciding anything. The museum's trustees will then be able to consider the implications for our future policy on admission charges," said Mr Chalmers.

The Imperial War Museum last night confirmed that it was still in favour of charging but refused to comment on the row, saying that the issues were "still very complicated". A spokesman said: "We must wait till our board discusses them."

David Barrie, director of the National Art Collections Fund, who led the crusade for free entry, last night said that the promise of government compensation might solve the impasse quickly.

"When we embarked on the VAT campaign we wanted to create a level playing field that would allow all national museums to go free without VAT driving their decision making," said Mr Barrie. "But we have always known that even if this goal were achieved, there would still be problems remaining for the charging museums, not least the matter of compensation. We believe that the government is willing to address these issues, and we hope that they can be sorted out quickly."

The Natural History and the Imperial War museums are among the dissidents limbering up to resist free access for all to the most important national collections. A source said: "Nothing, or no one, will be allowed to stop this happening." fields.headline: Anthony Storr
fields.standfirst: Gifted psychiatrist whose compassionate approach was born of his own childhood suffering and loneliness
fields.trailText: Gifted psychiatrist whose compassionate approach was born of his own childhood suffering and loneliness.
fields.body:
Anthony Storr, who has died of a heart attack aged 80, was Britain's most literate psychiatrist. A prolific author, journalist and radio and television commentator, he was widely respected as a fount of wisdom and good sense in a profession not particularly noted for such qualities. Like other kind and compassionate men, he was no stranger to suffering at formative stages of his life.

Born in London, Storr was a solitary, friendless child, plagued by frequent illness, including severe asthma and septicaemia, from which he nearly died. He was the youngest of four children, separated by 10 years from his closest sibling. His father, Vernon Faithfull Storr, sub-dean of Westminster Abbey, was 51 when Anthony was born, and his mother, Katherine Cecilia Storr, was 44. They were first cousins, and their consanguinity probably accounted for his asthma, from which he, like two of his siblings, suffered for most of his life. He also seems to have inherited from his mother a tendency to occasional episodes of depression.

Growing up in the privileged seclusion of Dean's Yard, Westminster, as virtually an only child, Storr was particularly affected by the trauma, shared by most boys of his class and time, of being sent away to a boarding prep school at the age of eight. There, and later at Winchester College, he was bitterly unhappy.

Having been deprived of a childhood peer group in which to learn the skills of comradeship, he was ill-prepared for the rigours of boarding-school life. Extremely slow to make friends, and showing little proficiency for games, he was bullied, and made only average academic progress. Though utterly miserable, it never occurred to him to complain to his parents, or attempt to run away, because boarding school was then a fact of life. But the sense of being a loner never left him, and was to affect the course of his career, as well as the content of his books.

What preserved his sanity and emotional equilibrium was a growing passion for music. From an early age, he attended performances in Westminster Abbey of such works as Bach's St Matthew Passion, and was later allowed to sit in the organ loft, an enormous thrill.

At Winchester, he sang in the choir, played the viola in the orchestra and piano solos in concerts. He always maintained that he would much rather have been a professional musician than a psychiatrist or writer, had he been blessed with the necessary talent and training; he freely acknowledged that his friendship with artists of the calibre of Alfred Brendel, and the musicologist Hans Keller, meant far more than would have equivalent friendships with Freud, Jung or Adler.

Storr's decision to become a psychiatrist was made soon after he went up to Christ's College, Cambridge, in 1939. His moral tutor was CP Snow, who became a lifelong friend. "I owed him a tremendous debt," Storr told me. "He was the first person who made me feel I might be any good at anything. I had disappointed my parents and teachers by not doing nearly as well as I should have. When I told Snow tentatively that I might go into psychiatry, he said, 'I think you'd be very good at it.' It was a ridiculous thing to decide one's future on a chance comment like that. The crucial thing was that he liked me, and thought I could do it."

After two years at Cambridge, Storr was given a wartime courtesy degree without taking a tripos, and continued his medical studies at Westminster hospital (1941-44), where he won prizes for medicine and surgery. He gained membership of the Royal College of Physicians in 1946.

His asthma precluded military service and, after a period as house physician at Runwell hospital, he went to the Maudsley hospital (1947-50), where he survived the ordeal of being Professor Aubrey Lewis's first senior registrar on his newly-formed professorial unit. Lewis, an obsessional polymath highly critical of his staff, undermined the confidence of everyone who worked for him.

Storr stuck it for nearly two years, then asked to be moved, thus effectively ruining his prospects for advancement within the psychiatric establishment. "I owed Lewis one thing, at least," admitted Storr. "Once you had suffered the experience of presenting a case at one of his Monday morning conferences, no other public appearance, whether on radio, TV or the lecture platform, could hold any terrors for you."

He obtained the diploma of psychological medicine in 1951, and, developing an interest in analytical psycho- therapy, went into analysis with Jung's English friend and colleague, Dr EA Bennet. He later became a member of the (Jungian) Society for Analytical Psychology. He practised psychotherapy privately, and, from 1961, combined his practice with various hospital appointments as a consultant.

Storr's reputation as a writer and broadcaster began with publication of his first book, The Integrity Of The Personality, in 1960. He was 40, and, up to that point, had not thought of himself as a writer. "I just felt the need to explain to myself what the hell I thought I was doing," he said. "For me, that is the motive for writing anything. I get intrigued by a puzzle, and writing a book is the best way to solve it."

During the next six years, 11 other books followed, of which the most notable were The Dynamics Of Creation (1972), Jung (1973), The Art Of Psychotherapy (1979), Solitude (1989), Freud (1989), his favourite, Music And The Mind (1993), and Feet Of Clay (1996).

Although he did a Jungian training, Storr declined to be labelled a Jungian, preferring to remain "an eclectic sceptic rather than a convert". His books reflected this lack of dogmatism. His love of music and literature, together with his medical and psychiatric training, enabled him to bridge the "two cultures" defined by his friend, Snow.

Storr's particular gift for rendering difficult concepts accessible, as well as his lucid, immensely readable style, made his books as appealing to lay people as to professionals, and his sales reflected this. All but two of his 12 titles have remained in print and, while sales were steady in the UK, they did particularly well in the United States, where Solitude sold 100,000 copies. The Essential Jung (1983) sold 50,000 worldwide, Freud sold 30,000 and Jung 75,000. The books were translated into 24 languages, including Korean and Malaysian, and Storr was especially charmed when Solitude was translated into Chinese for the republic of Inner Mongolia.

Perhaps as a result of his own unhappiness, isolation and depression, Storr's work revealed an abiding concern for those trapped in suffering, whether as psychiatric pat- ients, prisoners or victims of oppression and torture. He served as a member of the Parole Board (1976-77) and the Williams Committee on Obscenity and Film Censorship (1977-79), and his need to penetrate the mysteries of deviant or violent behaviour was apparent in his books on Sex ual Deviation (1964), Human Aggression (1968) and Human Destructiveness (1972).

At the same time, his understanding of human psychopathology gave him a rich appreciation of the creative possibilities inherent in mental suffering, and the powerful potential for self-healing to be found in artistic and intellectual creativity. This made him impatient with the medical model for psychiatry and its obsession with its symptomatic classification. "I want to show," he wrote, "that the dividing lines between sanity and mental illness have been drawn in the wrong place. The sane are madder than we think, the mad saner."

In 1974, Storr gave up private practice in favour of a teaching appointment at the Warneford hospital, Oxford; a post he held until his retirement in 1984. He was very happy in Oxford, enjoying dining rights at Wadham College and becoming a fellow of Green College, where he built his library from scratch.

A number of honours were granted him in appreciation of his contribution to psychiatry and literature. He was elected emeritus fellow of Green College (1984), fellow of the Royal Society of Literature (1990), and honorary fellow of the Royal College of Psychiatrists (1993). The generosity of spirit, so apparent in his writing, was no less evident in his personality, and was freely expressed in the warm support and encouragement he gave to younger psychiatrists, psychotherapists and writers, as well as to the patients who came to consult him from all walks of life.

Storr was twice married, first to Catherine Cole (the writer Catherine Storr, Obituary, January 11 2001), with whom he had three daughters before a divorce in 1970. They survive him, as does his second wife, Catherine Peters.

webTitle: Anthony Storr, the face of psychiatry, dies

fields.headline: Anthony Storr, the face of psychiatry, dies
fields.trailText: Anthony Storr, the psychiatrist who revolutionised public understanding of mental illness, has died at 80.
fields.body:
Anthony Storr, the psychiatrist who revolutionised public understanding of mental illness, has died at 80.

In books, journalism and on television and radio Dr Storr addressed everything from aggression and solitude to the roots of musical and literary creativity.

He sought, he said, "to show that the dividing lines between sanity and mental illness have been drawn in the wrong place. The sane are madder than we think, the mad saner."

Fellow psychiatrists paid tribute yesterday to Storr, whose 12 books, including Solitude, Human Aggression, and Music and the Mind, made him for decades the public face of the profession.

He died in hospital on Saturday afternoon, after a heart attack the previous evening while he was delivering an after-dinner speech at Wadham College, Oxford.

"His biggest contribution was in getting across psychiatric concepts to an intelligent public, in books which are accessible and uniquely free of jargon," said Hugh Freeman, former editor of the British Journal of Psychiatry, and a friend of Dr Storr.

"He was simply a better writer than others who tried to do this, and a delightful person - extremely helpful to a lot of younger psychiatrists - as well as a serious clinician."

In Dr Storr's most recent book, Feet of Clay, he examined gurus, from Sigmund Freud to David Koresh [head of the Waco cult in the US], emphasising once again the fine line between madness and sanity.

"When comparing the beliefs held by psychotics with the religious beliefs held by normal people," he concluded, "it is impossible to say that one set of beliefs is delusional while the other is sane .. even the most rational agnostic secretly harbours beliefs which are deeply irrational, especially in areas concerned with self-esteem and love."

Trained in the tradition of Carl Jung (though he resisted the label Jungian), Dr Storr had done more than any other writer in English to communicate the ideas of the Swiss psychotherapist, Prof Freeman said.

Some psychiatrists criticised Dr Storr for taking a "reassuring" approach to mental illness, failing to acknowledge its unsettling depths. But Andrew Samuels, professor of analytical psychology at Essex University, said his contribution had extended beyond popularisation.

"He was a very considerable historical scholar, and a pioneer in establishing the usefulness of psychotherapeutic understanding to biography, and to broad themes such as genius," he said.

Born in London, the son of the sub-dean of Westminster Abbey, Storr endured unhappy years at Winchester public school before attending Christ's College, Cambridge, where he decided to pursue psychiatry on the basis of a chance comment by his tutor, the novelist CP Snow.

He maintained he would rather have been a musician if he had had the talent.
