webTitle: Report from the conference for Italian teachers of English in Venice

fields.headline: Lost for words
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod  reports from Venice, where Italy has gathered its English teachers and the British Council is doing its best to paint the UK as a nation of linguists
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod reports from Venice, where Italy has gathered its English teachers and the British Council is doing its best to paint the UK as a nation of linguists
fields.body:
The current euro buzz phrase is "language friendly" - and the UK is plugging it for all it's worth. From sending Welsh rock singers to Alexandria or Gaelic musicians to Rome, to last week's showcase conference for Italian teachers of English in Venice, the British Council is doing its best to present us as multilingual.

While Brits are seen abroad as hopeless at languages, and while university language departments in the UK are talking of Armageddon because so few students are coming through school with the necessary language A-levels and highers, the council is factually correct to point out that there are lots of languages spoken within these shores.

In its The Power of Babel exhibition, the British Council declares: "Contrary to popular belief, the UK has always been multilingual. Gaelic, Irish and Welsh have been gradually displaced by English, itself the product of many different influences, but today they are fighting back. The older mother tongues have been joined by an astonishing variety of more recently arrived languages from all parts of the world."

Slightly bemused Italian teachers were treated to posters of Scots verse - like Robert Garioch's take on a Greek legend: "Bumpity doon in the corrie gaed whuddran the pitiless whun stane/Sisyphus dodderin efter it."

The Babel exhibition occupies a corner of the large cinema where the conference was held, and was overwhelmed by the array of publishers selling books and course materials in one language only. Behind the nod to preserving minority languages, it was business as usual for English. For English is big business. The British Council says the UK enjoys the biggest share of the international education market. The US may enrol more international students in its universities, but worldwide the UK attracts more students and trainees.

The 218,823 overseas students enrolled at British universities at the last count (in 1999/2000) are only the vanguard of a 2m-strong army of foreign nationals who are taught and sit exams for British academic, vocational and linguistic qualifications in their own countries. At a very conservative estimate, universities are boosting UK exports by more than £2.6bn a year just from the students who come here - and by and large they don't come here to learn Gaelic. Everyone, it seems, wants to learn English for reasons that have far more to do with the global dominance of the American economy than a thirst for the culture of Britain. It is a sign of the times that Sardinia, traditionally seen as a land of shepherds speaking a dialect linked to Latin, should be asking the British Council's help for a massive effort in boosting English on the island. It is an economic imperative.

Some of the tensions generated by the steamroller of English were apparent in Venice. French and German speakers seemed defensive: English wasn't the only foreign language Italians should learn. There were a lot of references to the EU's European Year of Languages and its stress on linguistic diversity.

The competition is sharpened by Italy's ambitious drive to boost modern languages in its schools from the age of six. Until this year, a second language was introduced at eight. Under Progetto Lingue 2000 this is being done earlier (many nursery schools now introduce a second language), while a third language istaught from 11 upwards. The aim is for most students to take at least one foreign language to 18.

Schools are free to choose from French, German, Spanish or English, but 80% are opting for English, and signals from the education ministry are that this must be one of the two languages taught. The project has entailed a huge training effort to get teachers' languages up to speed. Italian schools are going through the sort of upheaval experienced in England in the 1980s with the national curriculum, aimed at improving continuity in primary and secondary schooling and sorting out what is essential for children to be taught. One effect of the changes has been to make more room for languages in the curriculum.

Given the export opportunities for English, should the British Council be spending taxpayers' money staging Gaelic and Welsh concerts in Rome? The Welsh band Rag Foundation recently performed in Alexandria with the Egyptian pop and movie star Mohamed Mounir, who also sings in the minority tongue of Nubian, while Scots musicians working in Lallans and Gaelic have been to perform in Uganda and Kazakhstan.

Emphatically yes, says Dick Alford, director of the British Council in Italy: "We don't want to ram English down people's throats. We want to promote it and the exporters who benefit from it economically, but we want to approach the whole issue in a broadminded way."

Britain's experience of immigration and how to absorb children who speak another mother tongue into the education system - a theme of the Babel exhibition - is particularly relevant in Italy at the moment, Alford points out: "We can do both and be much more effective in plugging English if we don't just bang away."

While 17% of Italian visitors come to Britain to learn the language, exchanging ideas and knowledge about the success of minority languages and culture will also make it a more attractive holiday destination, he argues. (The website of the exhibition, researched by Professor Viv Edwards of Reading University, is refreshingly frank about the fact that language-teaching provision in UK schools compares unfavourably with other European countries. "It is not widely available and not a popular option, especially with boys," it states. "Official policy has been contradictory. On the one hand there was widespread agreement on the need for speakers of Japanese, Chinese and other Asian languages; on the other hand it was not considered cost-effective to provide teaching in these languages for pupils of compulsory school age.

So the council is giving enthusiastic backing to a "language passport" devised by the Council of Europe, the body of 43 member states covering eastern and western Europe. Unveiled at the conference, the European Language Portfolio allows people to record what level they have reached in different languages. Designed initially for adults and students over 16, the passport is based on self-assessment using "can do" statements covering listening, reading, speaking and writing. (The French have produced an attractive version for children.)

When it comes to speaking, these range from A1 ("I can interact in a simple way provided the other person is prepared to repeat or rephrase things at a slower rate") to C2 ("I can take part effortlessly in any conversation or discussion and have a good familiarity with idiomatic expressions and colloquialisms.")

Johanna Panthier, head of the Council of Europe's languages division, said the aim was that all citizens could use the passport, although there must be no compulsion. In some countries, such as Hungary, she said, the government was producing and distributing the passports. In the UK it will be done by the Centre for Information on Language Teaching (CILT). How the passport goes down in multilingual Britain, or whether Brits continue to travel in the expectation of being understood wherever they go, remains to be seen.

The British Council is also taking part in the Casanova project [Casanova is now seen as a good European traveller], "an online game for children in which they visit websites in Italian, French, German, Spanish and English".

Of course, the English that is conquering the world is a utilitarian version. Professor Paolo Balboni, of the University of Venice, told the conference that English had become the lingua franca of the world: "Although this may be a victory for the language, it is a defeat for British and American culture. The world is content with a simplified version of the language. Native English speakers who want to be understood at conferences, negotiations and so on have to undergo specific training."

His report on grammar for the Conservative government was suppressed by ministers - it was not the back to basics they wanted. Since then, its ideas "have lead a samizdat existence abroad". His approach is to look at language in context - "which is how English tends to be taught abroad. I think we can learn from each other. Standards of literature teaching in Britain are very good at GCSE and A-level, but there is quite a lot English teachers in Britain could learn from English language teaching abroad."

Meanwhile there is business to be done. Italy is a good market for UK publishers, enthuses Nick Beer, who is in Venice as academic manager of Penguin Italia: "The Italians are not the most fantastic language learners, so you can sell books to the same people four or five times in a lifetime - at school, university, private language school and post-retirement courses. Holland is a good market, but you can only sell them the book once."

fields.bodyText: The current euro buzz phrase is "language friendly" - and the UK is plugging it for all it's worth. From sending Welsh rock singers to Alexandria or Gaelic musicians to Rome, to last week's showcase conference for Italian teachers of English in Venice, the British Council is doing its best to present us as multilingual. While Brits are seen abroad as hopeless at languages, and while university language departments in the UK are talking of Armageddon because so few students are coming through school with the necessary language A-levels and highers, the council is factually correct to point out that there are lots of languages spoken within these shores. In its The Power of Babel exhibition, the British Council declares: "Contrary to popular belief, the UK has always been multilingual. Gaelic, Irish and Welsh have been gradually displaced by English, itself the product of many different influences, but today they are fighting back. The older mother tongues have been joined by an astonishing variety of more recently arrived languages from all parts of the world." Slightly bemused Italian teachers were treated to posters of Scots verse - like Robert Garioch's take on a Greek legend: "Bumpity doon in the corrie gaed whuddran the pitiless whun stane/Sisyphus dodderin efter it." The Babel exhibition occupies a corner of the large cinema where the conference was held, and was overwhelmed by the array of publishers selling books and course materials in one language only. Behind the nod to preserving minority languages, it was business as usual for English. For English is big business. The British Council says the UK enjoys the biggest share of the international education market. The US may enrol more international students in its universities, but worldwide the UK attracts more students and trainees. The 218,823 overseas students enrolled at British universities at the last count (in 1999/2000) are only the vanguard of a 2m-strong army of foreign nationals who are taught and sit exams for British academic, vocational and linguistic qualifications in their own countries. At a very conservative estimate, universities are boosting UK exports by more than £2.6bn a year just from the students who come here - and by and large they don't come here to learn Gaelic. Everyone, it seems, wants to learn English for reasons that have far more to do with the global dominance of the American economy than a thirst for the culture of Britain. It is a sign of the times that Sardinia, traditionally seen as a land of shepherds speaking a dialect linked to Latin, should be asking the British Council's help for a massive effort in boosting English on the island. It is an economic imperative. Some of the tensions generated by the steamroller of English were apparent in Venice. French and German speakers seemed defensive: English wasn't the only foreign language Italians should learn. There were a lot of references to the EU's European Year of Languages and its stress on linguistic diversity. The competition is sharpened by Italy's ambitious drive to boost modern languages in its schools from the age of six. Until this year, a second language was introduced at eight. Under Progetto Lingue 2000 this is being done earlier (many nursery schools now introduce a second language), while a third language istaught from 11 upwards. The aim is for most students to take at least one foreign language to 18. Schools are free to choose from French, German, Spanish or English, but 80% are opting for English, and signals from the education ministry are that this must be one of the two languages taught. The project has entailed a huge training effort to get teachers' languages up to speed. Italian schools are going through the sort of upheaval experienced in England in the 1980s with the national curriculum, aimed at improving continuity in primary and secondary schooling and sorting out what is essential for children to be taught. One effect of the changes has been to make more room for languages in the curriculum. Given the export opportunities for English, should the British Council be spending taxpayers' money staging Gaelic and Welsh concerts in Rome? The Welsh band Rag Foundation recently performed in Alexandria with the Egyptian pop and movie star Mohamed Mounir, who also sings in the minority tongue of Nubian, while Scots musicians working in Lallans and Gaelic have been to perform in Uganda and Kazakhstan. We want to promote it and the exporters who benefit from it economically, but we want to approach the whole issue in a broadminded way." Britain's experience of immigration and how to absorb children who speak another mother tongue into the education system - a theme of the Babel exhibition - is particularly relevant in Italy at the moment, Alford points out: "We can do both and be much more effective in plugging English if we don't just bang away." "It is not widely available and not a popular option, especially with boys," it states. "Official policy has been contradictory. fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: news
fields.body:
The weakest academic

Imagine what compulsive viewing The Weakest Link might be if it involved academic contestants. Now you might understand why an anonymous email dreaming up this scenario is proving so popular among academics making final preparations before this month's deadline for the Research Assessment Exercise

Question mistress: Welcome to ... The Weakest Link! Our contestants must work together to maximise their grade in the Research Assessment Exercise, but they must cut out those individuals who are not research-active, who are spoiling the departmental profile. They must vote off ... The Weakest Link!

Round one: Contestants have five years to publish at least four articles in refereed journals. But remember: you must publish your research, otherwise it won't count.

QM: You have only published 23 articles in refereed journals instead of your target of thirty-two. Who is letting you down? Whose research is only of national quality, not international? Who is ... The Weakest Link?

QM: In that round, Dr Hartebeest was the strongest link, publishing four articles in prestigious journals. Statistically the weakest link was Dr Lemur - although he wrote four articles, only one of them was published in time. Professor Aardvark, why Dr Lemur?

Prof Aardvark: He's too slow. He wants to think about his research, instead of publishing it.

QM: Dr Lemur, you are The Weakest Link. Goodbye.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@theguardian.com lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News

Title fight

Bolton Institute's staff have said they are "outraged and disappointed" by the Privy Council's decision not to grant the higher education college a university title.

"We are in the top performing group of higher education institutions, alongside the old universities," said Bolton's principal, Mollie Temple. "We therefore do not accept the QAA [Quality Assurance Agency] view that the institution is unsuitable for the title 'university', which is what has led to this decision."

The Privy Council awards university titles on the advice of the education secretary, who in turn takes advice from the QAA. There is no right of appeal within the application process. Liverpool Hope University College, meanwhile, has also been told to remove the word "University" from its title, after three judges turned down the college's appeal against an earlier government ban.

The judges said they hoped the decision would help to do away with the "continuing mischief and confusion" facing students in the reckless use of institutional titles.

Research news

Cardiff counts the cost

Cardiff University this week hosts a meeting of university heads from around the globe. The International Universities Presidents Forum includes research elites from the UK, China, Australia, Taiwan, and Canada. Vice-chancellor, Sir Brian Smith, called it "an association of Russell groups". Among issues under discussion is the "cost of privatization of a public university".

Urgent call on BSE

Researchers have been asked to submit proposals, as a matter of urgency, to develop diagnostic tests for diseases such as BSE and vCJD. More details at: www.mrc.ac.uk

Universe

My wife and I

It was revealed in the New Zealand parliament last week that Peter Davis, a Christchurch Medical School professor, has fully exploited his position as prime minister Helen Clark's husband. Davis twice used private secretary's email address to lobby for a Canadian academic friend to be flown in for an official review of a government health funding agency.

Women narrow the gap

A US Census Bureau study has found that 27.8% of American men have completed a college education, compared with 23.6% of women - a much smaller gap than 30 years ago.

webTitle: MPs want drop-outs to get recognition of years completed

fields.headline: Unnished business
fields.standfirst: MPs want drop-outs to get recognition of years completed, reports Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: MPs want drop-outs to get recognition of years completed, reports Rebecca Smithers
fields.body:
Academic unions and student leaders have given a guarded welcome to proposals from MPs to give formal recognition to the work of students who drop out of university after completing the first year of their degree.

The recommendations come in the long-awaited report later this week from MPs on the all-party education and employment select committee. In the second part of their inquiry into higher education, which looks at student retention, the MPs are understood to have urged the government's quality assurance agency to recognise all first-year modules and make them "portable" and valid for further study.

The committee concludes that quality of teaching is a major factor influencing whether or not students drop out, the Guardian has learned. Two-thirds of people who drop out do so in the first year, for example, in a clear sign that the quality of teaching affects the overall quality of the "student experience". Yet 20% of drop-outs eventually return to higher education. Students with poor qualifications and those who have scrambled for university places through the clearing system are more vulnerable to failing to complete their courses, the MPs found. But linking drop-out rates with social class has been more of a sticky wicket for the MPs, who are understood to have concluded that "the relationship between social class and non-completion is not straightforward".

But while backing the MPs' calls for a more flexible approach to recognising student progress, student and academic representatives argue that drop-out rates will only significantly fall if more financial support for students and staff is forthcoming.

"We welcome the fact that the committee has made some positive recommendations about flexibility and recognition of attainment for students who leave after completing only a part of their studies," said Owain James, president of the National Union of Students. "I am very concerned, however, that they have rejected the evidence put before them by NUS and others showing that worries about finance and genuine hardship are having a direct effect on students' performance and drop-out rates."

President of the Association of University Teachers, David Triesman, said: "Recognition of university modules and "portable" experiences can be developed through a system of the records of achievement that are championed by the Quality Assurance Agency. However, investment in teaching and clear support for new students would make the most dramatic inroad into drop-out rates."

The MPs' final report, which was given all-party agreement last week and will be published on Thursday, lists a total of 32 recommendations which MPs believe will maximise students' chances of seeing their courses through to completion. Evidence presented to the committee by the Higher Education Funding Council revealed an average drop-out rate of 17% - which is relatively low in international terms and the second lowest only to Japan. But there are concerns that the drop-out rate has remained more or less constant over the last decade, at an enormous cost to the public purse. Drop-out rates at some universities are much higher, with newer, post-1992 universities under great pressure to fill places or face a financial penalty.

Students ending up on inappropriate courses in the wrong location are a major cause for concern.

One way of improving teaching quality, the MPs conclude, is by paying academic staff more along the lines of the recommendations in the recent Bett report. They also express concern about the demands on teachers' time caused by research and assessment audits, and call for a better balance between teaching and research. Student poverty is underlined by evidence that in a lot of universities as many as 80% of students are working part-time. The MPs want that limited to 12 hours a week.

webTitle: Tips for those visiting prospective universities

fields.headline: What am I letting myself in for?
fields.standfirst: The Visit is important in choosing where to study.  John Beckett  offers some tips on finding the right place
fields.trailText: The Visit is important in choosing where to study. John Beckett offers some tips on finding the right place
fields.body:
What are universities really like? Having spent around 45 seconds talking to a university rep at a busy higher education fair and stared for considerably longer at very large reference books, glossy prospectuses and impenetrable websites, this question remains uppermost in your mind.

There really is no substitute for The Visit. Seeing your likely choices of university is an important part of the whole process. Whilst visiting many is probably impossible from both a time and a money perspective, spending a day at a few is much more realistic and will undoubtedly help your decision-making later.

The new post-16 curriculum, embarked upon by year 12 students last September, has encouraged some changes in the pattern of open-day visits. Many universities have realised that students, heavily timetabled with AS lessons throughout the year, will also be involved in AS exams in May and June, the "peak season" in the past for such open days. As a result some have moved these events forward to March or back to September and October, while others have given birth to the Saturday open day. Despite the changes, the best advice remains the same: try and visit at least a couple of universities in this way.

But where to go? If you already have some strong choices in mind, then no problem. If you are undecided then the best idea is to get a snapshot of what's available. This could involve seeing one close to home, another in a city centre and one at a single-site campus. Travel time and distance from home could be considerations for you. Do you want to be at a large or small institution, new or old?

Your school or college may well be organising visits to open days, but you can make your own arrangements. The UCAS reference book on open days (see below) gives dates and contact details.

Before the actual day, spend some time thinking about what you want to get out of the day - otherwise you'll return none the wiser. You'll want to know more about your chosen course in terms of content, teaching and assessment. What are the AS- and A-level entrance requirements? Try and talk to current students if possible - they'll give you the low-down on accommodation, workload and student life in general. Any subject talks will give an idea of what your lectures may be like. At the end of the day you will almost certainly have a gut feeling, an overall impression of the place. With over 300 institutions to choose from, an objective decision is a near-impossibility, but a few visits will give you a much better idea.

All the signs are that universities continue to set great store by these open days. It's their chance to sell themselves to prospective students. To that end, schools and colleges are beginning to receive smart leaflets advertising such events. Cardiff's leaflet describes the "opportunity for year 11 and 12 pupils, teachers, careers advisers and mature students to see university life as it really is." Westminster's open days feature presentations, campus tours and advice stalls, while Bath Spa University College has post-application campus-visit days following their main open day in May. Add to this taster courses and summer schools, some residential, and you have an array of opportunities to visit and experience living and studying at university or college.

Checklist

 Course content, teaching styles, assessment?

 Facilities - labs, computer spaces, lecture rooms, student union?

 Gap year - acceptable and encouraged?

 Entrance requirements - are there interviews?

 Graduate destinations from your course?

 Student accommodation - cost, location?

 Talk to current undergraduates.

 Cost of travelling to and from the university?

 Well-organised and informative open day?

 Can you picture yourself in this environment for three years?

fields.headline: The logical approach
fields.standfirst: Traffic had blocked Cambridge's dream of nurturing a new Silicon Valley. Now there is hope, says  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Traffic had blocked Cambridge's dream of nurturing a new Silicon Valley. Now there is hope, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Cambridge's academics, local businessmen and town planners are to investigate ways of solving the region's acute transport problems to make way for the university's expansion plans over the next 30 years.

The study, unveiled last week by Cambridge University's vice-chancellor, Professor Sir Alec Broers, has come hard on the heels of the university's announcement of ambitious plans for a billion-pound development of new research and teaching facilities on Cambridge's northwest outskirts. In the past decade the university has already overseen un precedented growth, with £500m spent on a new West Cambridge science campus. But Cambridge's aspirations to emulate California's Silicon Valley and create one of the world's centres for new high-tech companies have been seriously hampered by local traffic and housing problems. Cambridge's small city centre has been all but brought to a standstill by traffic jams, while house prices have rocketed in recent years.

The study, which will be carried out by the university's own Cambridge Futures research team, will aim to offer some solutions for these local infrastructure problems.

"Cambridge Futures draws to gether all people in the area working in a spirit of collaboration on the options to resolve the region's transport problems," said Broers, who is a member of the steering committee overseeing the study. "With five years experience and developing future options in its award-winning, and innovative, first study, Cambridge Futures is best placed to undertake this study.

The project's director, Professor Marcial Echenique, said: "This study is one of the most critical studies ever to be undertaken in the area. The result should inform planners and decision makers, both locally and nationally, as well as the local population."

The Cambridge Futures steering group is made up of local business leaders, politicians, local government officers and academics. Its first research study produced computer simulations showing how more houses could be built in the local area. The second study will build on the first study by analysing the options for alleviating the region's transport problems for the next 50 years. The researchers will identify the options, use a computer simulation model to predict the outcomes and assess each alternative, or combination of the alternatives. The public will also get a chance to see the results at an exhibition when a final report is produced. The study is expected to take 18 months.

The university's plans for further expansion focus on 120 hectares of land owned by the university on a site between the Huntingdon Road and Madingley Road in north west Cambridge. The proposals, released for consultation in advance of a planning application, include housing for students and staff, academic facilities and research centres. Some land would also be set aside for conservation areas, schools, shops and housing for local people. The development could also pave the way for three new Cambridge colleges, allowing the university to enrol thousands of extra university students.

Much of the building of the West Cambridge university science campus, meanwhile, will be completed this year. This month saw the "topping out" ceremony for the new Microsoft Research Laboratory, with the basic structure now in place. A new university computing laboratory, sports hall and a new Marconi- sponsored research building are also in the pipeline. Together the two projects represent the biggest expansion of the university in its 800 year history, and reflect the growing efforts to work closely with industry to exploit the academic talent in Cambridge.

Many of the new buildings are the result of collaborations with companies investing in research.

But Cambridge's aspirations to emulate California's Silicon Valley and create one of the world's centres for new high-tech companies have been seriously hampered by local traffic and housing problems. Cambridge's small city centre has been all but brought to a standstill by traffic jams, while house prices have rocketed in recent years. The study, which will be carried out by the university's own Cambridge Futures research team, will aim to offer some solutions for these local infrastructure problems. fields.headline: Battle commences
fields.standfirst: Owain James faces just one challenger for the NUS presidency, says  Will Woodward
fields.trailText: Owain James faces just one challenger for the NUS presidency, says Will Woodward
fields.body:
Remember the days when the presidency of the National Union of Students was a passport to fame and flattery in the Labour Party? Just ask Jack Straw, home secretary, or for that matter his deputy, Charles Clarke. And that's not forgetting potential ministers Stephen Twigg, Phil Woolas, Lorna Fitzsimons and Jim Murphy, MPs all.

The current president, Owain James, 24, is a Labour member, although he stands as an independent. But as he seeks re-election at next week's NUS conference in Blackpool, he professes no greater political ambitions. Instead, inspired by spending his early childhood in Sudan, he is hoping for a career working in international development.

His challenger in this year's elections, current NUS treasurer Helen Aspell, is not a Labour party member. She takes support from the hard left, including the Socialist Workers' Party, the Campaign for Free Education and the Alliance for Workers' Liberty. But in any case she wants to be a firefighter. She hopes to become involved in the Fire Brigades Union on equality issues, but does not want to hold office in it.

But reassuringly - or infuriatingly - the NUS conference promises to live up to its reputation of recent years: some pretty pointless platform faction-fighting, lots of shouting and, in among it all, some formal debates, this year on regular favourites - education funding, welfare, student rights and "building an active union".

Student unions send representatives - one for each 1,000 students - to the conference, who are elected or, in some cases, particularly in the further education colleges, nominated. Well-organised political machines can easily get their people in.

After informal hustings on Monday and formal hustings on Tuesday, around 1,000 delegates will vote for the president and five other full-time officers.

Neither candidate is prepared to stick their head above the parapet and call for sabbatical officers to be elected by a universal ballot of all NUS members. James, pleased he only has one challenger this year, will be re-elected by a few or lose by a few. Aspell thinks she will win.

This hasn't been the sorriest year in NUS history by any means. David Blunkett's 11th-hour pledge to rule out the introduction of top-up fees in the next term of a Labour government has taken some of the heat off James, who is backed by Labour Students this year as last (when they chose not to put up a candidate for election).

The NUS has lobbied hard against top-up fees, although the education secretary's decision had arguably much more to do with appeasing middle Britain's parents than assuaging student protest.

James logs in his credit column the announcement of the first increase in funding per student for over a decade in November - two days after the biggest student march for around 10 years, involving 17,000 people, complained that it was still falling under Labour.

The March 1 "shutdown" by students over funding was also successful. James will press the government this year to reintroduce the grant for students from low-income families. Perhaps James's most controversial internal decision was to sign up to a 30-year internet deal with ITM Activate to deliver a new NUS Online service. Some unions complained the deal was poor and much too long. But Aspell, for one, defends it and James says the NUS can give three years' notice to pull out.

James, who studied Morse (mathematics, operational research, statistics and economics) at Warwick, says that in the long term the mostly silent majority in the 500,000-strong student community could be more easily mobilised through the database established by NUS Online. With it, the union could have better fought the introduction of top-up fees, he argues. His main regret is that he hasn't made enough inroads into ending factionalism within the union which, he says, has torn it apart for 30 years.

Aspell wants to shake the union out of what she regards as its complacent attitude to the majority of its members: part-time and mature students, and students in further education colleges. The organisation has not had a bad year, she thinks, but has done the minimum that could be expected of it.

Aspell believes the organisation has been dominated for too long by the interests of 18- to 21-year-olds and those at red brick universities (including her own, Leeds, where she studied history). She has an ambitious agenda to engage part-time and mature students, students with children and students in further education colleges. James, meanwhile, insists the NUS has made great gains in further education colleges in the last year.

Beyond that, Aspell plans to link the union with the wider community, with trade unions and parents fighting education privatisation. She will campaign for the abolition of tuition fees and the reintroduction of full maintenance grants for all. Though she doesn't expect the government to deliver all her demands within her presidency, in time she believes the debate can be moved on so that taxpayers, including her future colleagues in the fire service, accept that case.

James's plans

"As the first independent president in 30 years my aim has been to put students at the heart of NUS. This year, working with Unison and the teaching unions, we organised the largest student protest for a generation.

"We won more in the last eight months than in the last eight years: the return of maintenance support in Northern Ireland, the extension of the education maintenance allowance in further education, the higher education review in Wales and the u-turn on top-up fees. It is only the start of the struggle and the return of the grant for students across the UK must remain our goal.

"Next week, students will have to choose between a candidate selected by the traditional hard left factions who have always dominated the NUS or pick the route of change."

Aspell's plans

"If we are to make gains on student funding, fight against the impoverishment of our institutions and provide a positive agenda for the education system, we have to change.

"Students have limited power: united with local community groups, trade unions, anti-racist campaigners, our voice will be far stronger. To create an NUS that is a genuine force for social change, it has to decentralise.

"NUS has the potential to be part of a movement of NGOs and the general public in placing demands on to the government.

"NUS must mean every student having the chance to be part of a vibrant, grass roots movement. That sort of community involvement is the model for the sort of union that can win back the maintenance grants that all students so desperately need."

webTitle: Oxford to drop compulsory Old English

fields.headline: Valentine's day of reckoning
fields.standfirst: Just as Seamus Heaney's Beowulf translation  is finding modern readers, Oxford may drop compulsory Old English.  Ros Taylor asks why
fields.trailText: Just as Seamus Heaney's Beowulf translation is finding modern readers, Oxford may drop compulsory Old English. Ros Taylor asks why
fields.body:
To Kingsley Amis, it was "that featureless heap of elephant's sputum". To Alison Powell, researching her PhD at Cambridge, it is a language she "fell in love with". To Luke Wiespeser, a second-year at Leicester University, it proved so compelling that his housemates repeatedly told him to shut up about it during Man Utd v Sturm Graz. To most English students, it's Beowulf. It is, of course, Old English.

Oxford is again discussing whether to drop Old English as a compulsory part of the English syllabus from 2002. Last year's attempt to oust it was headed by Corpus Christi professor Valentine Cunningham, but failed after a faculty majority voted to keep it as a compulsory first-year course.

Since then, the Old English community - represented most vocally by Dr Elaine Treharne, also of Leicester - has dug in for what is expected to be a tough fight. This time around, it seems freshers will be given a choice between Old and Middle English.

"The position of Old English in British universities is increasingly beleaguered," admits Patrick Parrinder, professor of English at Reading. "We no longer have a full-time member of staff capable of teaching the subject." He blames economic pressures. "Our priority must be to keep alive the study of Chaucer, not of Beowulf."

Yet - curiously - public awareness of Beowulf has rarely been higher, thanks to Seamus Heaney's translation that still outsells Carol Anne Duffy and Ted Hughes' Tales from Ovid on Amazon.co.uk. Judging by the speed with which Heaney's translation has leapt onto US undergraduate English programmes, it could yet be the saviour of Old English.

The problem remains that most English freshers come to university in the belief that they are studying texts in their own language. They then encounter the opening of The Dream of the Rood, generally thought to be the oldest example of a "dream vision" in English: "Hwæt! Ic swefna cyst secgan wylle, hwæt me gemætte to midre nihte. . ." ("Hwaet! I will recount the best dreams, which I dreamed in the middle of the night.")

As Dr Janie Steen, now lecturing in Old English, puts it: "I felt I had come to Oxford to read Keats sitting on a punt, not to sweat over Old English paradigms and grammar. I was sure that the literature would be boring and primitive, and that it would mostly describe hairy men beating each other up."

Her memories echo those of past and present students and lecturers in Old English. All said they would never have studied Old English had the subject not been compulsory - a point Oxford's faculty are no doubt bearing in mind this time around.

The trouble is that their colleagues in the English faculty just don't believe them. Elaine Treharne insists that she would have specialised in Hardy if she hadn't been forced to apply herself to OE.

"I doubt that," snorts David Lawton, director of graduate studies in English at Washington University in St Louis, and a keen advocate of the benefits of translation. "I would be very surprised if her natural curiosity had not led her to it." The emphasis on language during his time at Oxford, he says, deterred all but the few. "Compulsory OE has over its time done more harm than good. If it's compulsory then it's got to be well-taught. One indictment [of the current system] is that it has not produced good translation. Where is the benefit to the general reader?

"I have been to readings with Seamus Heaney in the US where someone has read the Heaney and the Old English out loud. It is quite extraordinary how you can hear the translation." Specialists in the language, he says, often feel that translation involves an "improper sense of creativity. But I think we ought to be able to correct that," he adds optimistically.

The peculiar combination of fear and reverence which Old English inspires has been a challenge in North American faculties, where the subject is widely taught but rarely compulsory for undergraduates. "The real question is how you get students to go to an Old English class," Daniel Donoghue, a professor at Harvard and the editor of Heaney's translation, told me. "Right now we don't have any courses that try to entice students to choose the subject as such. But I and my colleagues are considering introducing one."

Rather than insisting on Beowulf, Donoghue teaches a course focusing on King Alfred which simultaneously introduces students to Old English grammar, syntax and metrics. Later this year he plans to embark on Before Love, a course which will look at "erotic relationships before courtly love". It is unlikely to be boring.

One of Treharne's more surprising claims about Old English is that it can give students the linguistic confidence they need in order to tackle the more abstruse prose of literary theorists. "To work with French feminism, for example, you need to decode the technical language used by [Julia] Kristeva. Old English is analogous to that."

But is it? Emily Thornbury, an American graduate student at Cambridge's department of Anglo-Saxon, Norse and Celtic, thinks not. "I think there's a personality factor involved in separation from the mainstream of English literature. Hard-core philology has hung on in Old English partly because of that. Anglo-Saxonists seem more positivistic than most literary scholars."

Thornbury, who studied astrophysics before moving to Cambridge, believes a desire to uncover the origins of English literature is what motivates many of her colleagues. In a similar vein, Janie Steen described the shock and pleasure of discovering compound words such as gannetbæß (sea) and banhus .

If this philological approach to Old English seems to have little in common with the rest of a contemporary English Lit syllabus, it doesn't erode the belief among many of its supporters that to render it optional would be to leave Old English to wither on the vine. Unusually, Professor Malcolm Godden of Oxford University is optimistic that most students will still opt to study it. "The worry is that the minority who don't will miss out on an important part of the course, and regret it later." As for Valentine Cunningham's contribution to discussions of the new syllabus, Godden is dismissive. "He turns up sometimes and sometimes makes a speech about what used to happen 40 years ago."

But could Oxford end up following Cambridge, with its separate Anglo-Saxon, Norse and Celtic faculty? Even some academics who acknowledge the difficulty of teaching Old English are wary of such an outcome. "Cambridge have made [OE] separate," warns Lawton. "They've built a wall round it. They really quite like its separateness, and it's what will kill them in the end."

Some younger academics feel that preserving the 1,000-year-old poem at the expense of more accessible - and influential - works is a slightly contrary approach. "It is worth putting on a list of required reading, if such a list must exist," says Erik Gray, an assistant professor at Harvard. "But if there were one book that is not regularly taught that I were allowed to make required reading, it would not be Beowulf but the Bible.

"It seems short-sighted to require that undergraduates study Old English texts and yet to allow them to go on reading all of English literature without even a basic familiarity with the Gospels."

The tide does seem to be turning against those, like Treharne, who insist on the vitality of Old English. "It doesn't matter how much, as long as it's there." Few who have read Heaney's translation can question the "familiar, powerful emotions" that Donoghue finds there. "But there are also moments when it's strange," he adds. "It's that combination that appeals to me." Too strange, perhaps, to survive in a crowded Oxford syllabus.

webTitle: School report: Flower Powers counting set

fields.headline: School report
fields.standfirst: Flower Powers counting set
fields.trailText: Flower Powers counting set
fields.body:
Price: £10.56 (inc VAT)

Age/ability range: Reception/KS1

The manufacturer says:

"A simple, original concept that could become as much an institution in the way children learn to count as the abacus, counters, rods and cubes have in the past."

Fiona Masson, KS1 teacher, Cubitt Town Infants School, London E14, says:

"This is a solid, colourful product which the children liked. There were no lesson plans included and the instructions were quite basic, so the children and I had to work out what to do with it. I used it with 5- to 6-year-olds and found it wasn't so good for tens and units as suggested, although I might use it as back-up. However, I found it very useful for more basic activities, such as colour-recognition, addition and subtraction to ten, and multiplication. The children enjoyed using the petals and liked the bright colours."

Nicki Tyler, reception teacher also at Cubitt Town Infants, says:

"It provided good visual support for early addition, subtraction and multiplication work, with the children (able 5-year-olds) responding enthusiastically. The resource slotted in very well with the work we've been doing with beads and Unifix, and it made the children feel really clever."

Curriculum links

fields.headline: CD-rom reviews
fields.trailText: Astronomy - the Earth and Beyond | Ancient Greeks
fields.body:
Astronomy - the Earth and Beyond
(Anglia Multimedia, £57.58 inc VAT)

Age: KS3-4

Simulations and animations make this program an ideal complement to QCA's The Earth in Space scheme of work. The level of content is high - teachers need to check that it is appropriate for their KS3 classes. It is an excellent program for extension or research work for small groups or individuals. Some content is better suited to KS4, so focused direction by the teacher is important. The animations and voice-overs help to explain a number of difficult concepts; links to the web presented information beyond KS3 and, at times, KS4. However, this package presents many learning opportunities, especially for independent and able learners.

Ancient Greeks
(Anglia Multimedia, £57.58 inc VAT)

Age: KS2

Supports all aspects of study unit 4, Ancient Greece, and helps with important elements at KS2, such as chronology and looking at time lines, range and depth of historical knowledge and historical enquiry. Easy to install, it carries information on several themes. A notepad facility lets pupils record information as they find it; clear design and navigation makes access to the program easy, and on-screen help is also spoken aloud. The CD-rom works well as a resource for finding information on a given topic and for assessing knowledge.

You can read full evaluations of these programs at www.teem.org.uk

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Lindsey Fraser looks at Tell Me A Picture by Quentin Blake, and The Kite Rider by Geraldine McCaughrean
fields.body:
Tell Me A Picture
Quentin Blake
(National Gallery Company)
£10.99
Age: all, from 4+ yrs

For two years Quentin Blake has been the first Children's Laureate, an honour which he passes on in May. Tell Me a Picture is an exhibition of illustrations and paintings, one of several projects he has undertaken in the role. For those unable to pay a visit to London's National Gallery, this book provides a splendid alternative. Blake selects 26 pictures and, by using his own illustrations, gently suggests a number of ways in which they can be interpreted and discussed. In classrooms or on coffee tables, this beautifully produced book will widen eyes and imaginations with its invitation to wonder at what other eyes and imaginations once saw.

The Kite Rider
Geraldine McCaughrean
(OUP, £6.99)
Age: 11-16 yrs

Despite the unfamiliarity of the geographical and cultural territory, these 200 action-packed pages are thrilling and totally absorbing. Hayou, the kite rider, ricochets between heedless actions on behalf of his parents and the crushing constraints of cultural expectations that put him in eternal debt to his foul great-uncle. It's a wonderful saga, at the heart of which is a boy's grief and his naive belief in, and interpretation of, what he sees as he flies through the air on his kite. The detail is phenomenal but unobtrusive, the narrative warm, sometimes humorous, and consistently compelling.

webTitle: Secondary school choices for Year 6 pupils

fields.headline: Class politics
fields.standfirst: Who's in, who's out? Who's clever, who's not? Year 6 pupils now know which secondary school they are going to. And they talk of little else.  Joanna Moorhead  listens in
fields.trailText: Who's in, who's out? Who's clever, who's not? Year 6 pupils now know which secondary school they are going to. And they talk of little else. Joanna Moorhead listens in
fields.body:
It's two days since 11-year-old Frances heard she'd got into the secondary school she was hoping for, and she's still walking on air. "I'm feeling really happy. I'd been on the waiting list, and when my mum told me the school had phoned to say I'd got in, I cried.

"It was only then that I realised the pressure I'd been under. It really was a stressful process, and I'm very pleased it's over."

Talk to any parent with a child in year 6 in a primary at the moment and you'll hear lots about how they feel: emotionally wrung out, on the brink of divorce, candidate for the asylum, ready to jack it all in and move to the Hebrides. There can be no doubt in anyone's mind that parents, particularly those in urban areas where competition for secondary schools is sharpest, feel the stress: but what about the kids?

Frances is in no doubt that she wasn't the only one in her class, at an inner-London primary, to feel the strain. "At first when we started looking around the schools it seemed exciting - this idea of a new start, lots of new possibilities," she says.

"Then came the applications, and they were OK, too. But then people started taking tests for different schools, and you saw them looking tense and stressed-out. You knew people were working really hard, at home as well as in school.

"But the worst bit came when the results came out and some people were really happy because they'd got where they wanted and others hadn't or they didn't know and they were still really worried. There are some people in my class who still haven't got a place anywhere, and it's quite difficult now when you talk to them. One girl I know wanted to go to the school I'm now going to, and I worry a bit that she'll be jealous because I've got in and she hasn't."

Frances herself applied for five schools, and got immediate offers of places from three. But that didn't mean the stress was over: she had to choose between two of them, which she liked equally. "It was hard to know which one to go for - they both had good things and bad. One school only gave you seven days to make up your mind, so the pressure was on." Then came her latest offer, from the school whose waiting list she'd gone on to, and it was decision time again. "I knew in my heart this was the school for me, but I still had to go through everything with my mum and dad to make sure I was doing the right thing," she says.

Rachel Prior, year 6 teacher at the Holy Ghost School in Balham in south London, says the anxiety that parents feel filters through, and increases through the year. "They feel under pressure - it doesn't always show at school but I've been hearing about children getting up at night in tears because they're worried."

Do they talk about it a lot amongst themselves? "They certainly seem to, especially at first, and then of course they talk about the results when they come through, and about who is going where. What's really difficult is when one child hasn't got into a particular school and another child has - and even though it might be that they didn't fulfil the entrance requirement because they lived in the wrong area, that child still feels he's failed."

Where children are bound for an independent secondary, parental financial worries can have a knock-on effect on the kids, too, says Prior. "Families talk about things very openly these days and children know there are financial implications to a particular school, and they take on that worry as well."

For James Browning, 11, one of Prior's pupils, the stress started with all the traipsing around potential secondaries back in October.

"Most of the schools we looked round had open evenings, and it was really tiring to have to go to these one after another after a long day at school and then homework," he says. "Also at some places the headteachers gave really long speeches and you were up really late - and then you were back in at school the next morning with another evening of it ahead.

"I was lucky - I applied to three schools and I got into the one I really wanted. But I heard of people applying for six or even 10, and sitting loads of tests as a result."

Parents are increasingly concerned at the effects of all this on the children themselves. "I think it's too much for a lot of them," says one mother who doesn't want to be named. "At our school five girls applied to the same school and four of them got in - what must it feel like to be the fifth? It's quite unpleasant - how must it be to suffer that kind of rejection at 10?

"One girl I was talking to, a friend of my daughter's, was almost in tears after the offers came through and she told me she thought she'd let her parents down. You have to ask what are we putting our children through."

The prospect of torn friendships is another big concern for the children. Ten-year-old Charlie d'Auria and 11- year-old Lexy Lyne have been close friends since reception class: now they're off to different secondaries and both are worried about it. "It's something I think about quite a lot," says Charlie. "Lexy did apply to the school I'm going to, so there was a possibility we might end up together. I knew it was unlikely to work out that way, so I didn't hope too much. But I'm a bit upset now I know we'll be at different places - I'm hoping we'll still see a lot of each other at weekends, though."

Both Charlie and Lexy say discussions about who had applied where, and later who was going where, dominated their class for many weeks. "You could tell people were anxious about where they'd be going," says Lexy. "Three-quarters of our class did at least one entrance exam, and in the days leading up you'd feel really nervous and keep thinking about it. Eventually our teacher asked us not to ask other people where they were going: it was fine if they just said it without being asked, but we weren't allowed to question people."

Psychologist Trevor Jellis, director of the Stein Clinic in Harley Street, which deals with stress in families, says that from the child's point of view, the hardest part of the secondary schools transition is worries over losing friends. That's interesting because talk to parents and you'll find they usually give that aspect hardly any weight at all: but from the kids' point of view, it's hugely significant. "Children do worry about it, although clearly they are very resilient and most manage to adjust well at their new schools," he says. "Also, life is about adjustment and there is clearly a learning experience here, too."

Jellis admits that secondary school transition is often stressful for all concerned, but says it's difficult to advise parents about how to avoid it.

"Parents are told they're in this great situation because they've got choice, but when you hear about all the stress it makes you think the reality of this 'choice' is the worst thing of all," he says. "Every parent wants the right education for their child, and in areas where schools select there are inevitably going to be people who are disappointed because their first choice doesn't accept their application. You know it's a risk, but most parents aren't going to let it put them off - there's a sense in which you've really got to suck it and see. You make a statement about what you believe is best, and sometimes you're going to have to make do with what's left. And there's no doubt that will have an effect on the child concerned as much as on the parents."

webTitle: The school I'd like: Dare to be different

fields.headline: Dare to be different
fields.standfirst: Competition: The school I'd like In this week's preview, Kate Caryer, 16, who has cerebral palsy, describes the school of her dreams. Plus how to enter (and win fabulous prizes)
fields.trailText: Competition: The school I'd like In this week's preview, Kate Caryer, 16, who has cerebral palsy, describes the school of her dreams. Plus how to enter (and win fabulous prizes)
fields.body:
Differences make the world go round. Kids need to learn that more than "the rotation of the earth" in science! Schools must teach differences and celebrate them. At the moment schools do the opposite, trying to make everybody normal. Take school uniforms - they take away kids' background and identity and make school boring and colourless. The worst thing about a uniform is making all children look the same. In my dream school there will NOT be any uniform!

The school I'd like will be open for 48 weeks a year, but the children will have a certain amount of set time to spend out of school. The children and teachers can choose when to have their holidays. This is very important, because I think it's wrong for non-Christian children to get two weeks over Christmas and then have to go to school on Diwali or their own special days!

Every child needs help, and every child can give something special. For example, a child in care might need someone to chat to. Maybe she is very good at maths and understanding people who have problems. To meet her needs as well as celebrating her gift the school should set up co- counselling, where the people doing the counselling also get counselling themselves.

Some kids' "needs" and "gifts" don't go hand in hand, like the example above. My ideal school would work around this. Take this example: a child who is labelled as having severe learning difficulties can teach other kids how to go along at their pace and take life as it comes.

In my dream school, standards will be set for every child separately. I don't like the way children are expected to do one thing by seven and another by 11. This is very harmful to all children. The children who do well think they're better than the kids who can't read!

I think teachers should be called by their first names and children should be encouraged to say what's bad about THEIR school and be taken seriously! Needless to say, every school should welcome all children in their catchment area and be fully accessible for all disabilities. They should recognise that differences do make the world go round!"

Kate Caryer, 16

How to enter

If you are aged five to 18 you have until Friday, March 30 to enter the competition. Simply describe "The School I'd Like" (in words, or using drawings, plans, tape recordings - whatever you like) and send your entry to us, accompanied by an entry form. To get an entry form, just email education@theguardian.com or write to Education Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Please include a postal address so we can send the form to you.

The prizes

The winner in each of the three categories - primary; lower secondary (years 7-9) and upper secondary (years 10-13) - will receive a top-of-the-range Toshiba laptop computer, a digital camera and a lightweight projector, plus Microsoft software worth around £3,000 for their school. The total value of each prize is around £10,000.

Two runners up in each category will each win a Toshiba digital camera for their school.

webTitle: Help plan for 1.4m with learning disabilities

fields.headline: Help plan for 1.4m with learning disabilities
fields.trailText: The government will today promise a better deal for more than 1.4m people with learning disabilities in the first white paper on the subject for 30 years.
fields.body:
The government will today promise a better deal for more than 1.4m people with learning disabilities in the first white paper on the subject for 30 years.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has decided to close the last long stay hospitals after evidence they institutionalise residents and reduce opportunities for independence. Their remaining 1,500 beds will be phased out by 2004.

There will be a five year programme to modernise services already costing about £3bn a year. It will include more individualised day care facilities, better housing and more job opportunities.

Mr Milburn will say that those with learning disabilities have been "marginalised and neglected by central government policies for decades".

The white paper, Valuing People: A new strategy for learning disability for the 21st century, will promise £2.3m to fund advocacy services to help users to exercise their rights. A national information centre will be set up in partnership with the charity Mencap.

The government estimates there are 210,000 people with severe learning disabilities in England and 1.2m with moderate disabilities. Each will get a health plan and a designated health professional to supervise their care. Financial support will increasingly be paid to individuals and their carers, instead of being channeled through local authorities.

Up to £50m a year will be put into a development fund for better facilities. Ministers will set targets to increase numbers in employment, currently less than 10%. And local authorities will be told to provide more choice of housing. "It will no longer be acceptable for an authority to say there are certain areas where people with learning disabilities should not live," a Department of Health official said.

 Tony Blair's offer of £100m a year more for primary healthcare would alienate GPs if he expected them to work even harder, the British Medical Association warned yesterday. The prime minister said every GP surgery would get £5,000 to make improvements such as extra clinics, extended opening hours and better cancer services. Those meeting locally agreed performance targets would get a further £5,000 to spend as they wished at the end of the year.

"I see no reason why staff who do a good job for the public should not be rewarded for what they do ... The aim is clear. It is to empower local doctors and nurses to drive forward progress in the NHS," Mr Blair said.

John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's GPs committee, said: "If extra money in reality means even more work, doctors will feel alienated ... Practices deserve rewards for the changes they have already made, and will not be able to cope if additional work is required before those incentives can be received."

Mr Blair appointed David Colin-Thomas, a Runcorn GP, as the government's first "primary care tsar" overseeing a national strategy. He also announced plans to cut red tape for family doctors by allowing other NHS staff to authorise patients' applications for passports, shotgun licences, postal vote and other forms.
fields.bodyText: The government will today promise a better deal for more than 1.4m people with learning disabilities in the first white paper on the subject for 30 years. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has decided to close the last long stay hospitals after evidence they institutionalise residents and reduce opportunities for independence. Their remaining 1,500 beds will be phased out by 2004. There will be a five year programme to modernise services already costing about £3bn a year. It will include more individualised day care facilities, better housing and more job opportunities. Mr Milburn will say that those with learning disabilities have been "marginalised and neglected by central government policies for decades". The white paper, Valuing People: A new strategy for learning disability for the 21st century, will promise £2.3m to fund advocacy services to help users to exercise their rights. A national information centre will be set up in partnership with the charity Mencap. The government estimates there are 210,000 people with severe learning disabilities in England and 1.2m with moderate disabilities. Each will get a health plan and a designated health professional to supervise their care. Financial support will increasingly be paid to individuals and their carers, instead of being channeled through local authorities. Up to £50m a year will be put into a development fund for better facilities. Ministers will set targets to increase numbers in employment, currently less than 10%. And local authorities will be told to provide more choice of housing. "It will no longer be acceptable for an authority to say there are certain areas where people with learning disabilities should not live," a Department of Health official said.  Tony Blair's offer of £100m a year more for primary healthcare would alienate GPs if he expected them to work even harder, the British Medical Association warned yesterday. The prime minister said every GP surgery would get £5,000 to make improvements such as extra clinics, extended opening hours and better cancer services. Those meeting locally agreed performance targets would get a further £5,000 to spend as they wished at the end of the year. "I see no reason why staff who do a good job for the public should not be rewarded for what they do ... The aim is clear. It is to empower local doctors and nurses to drive forward progress in the NHS," Mr Blair said. John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's GPs committee, said: "If extra money in reality means even more work, doctors will feel alienated ... Practices deserve rewards for the changes they have already made, and will not be able to cope if additional work is required before those incentives can be received." Mr Blair appointed David Colin-Thomas, a Runcorn GP, as the government's first "primary care tsar" overseeing a national strategy. He also announced plans to cut red tape for family doctors by allowing other NHS staff to authorise patients' applications for passports, shotgun licences, postal vote and other forms.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My 15-year-old son was a chatty little boy, but is now more interested in his computer than anything else. He is doing well academically and his teachers' only complaint is that he's too quiet in class. I worry that he is too quiet in general and has no friends.
fields.trailText: Leading experts answer your problems
fields.body:
Friends are very important during adolescence, not just to provide support and someone to talk to and share anxieties with, but as the arena where teenagers grow up socially and find out who they are, what they're like.

Some young people are happier on their own and prefer doing their own thing but they are a small group; others are difficult to make friends with because they are too demanding or let people down, and get rejected; some don't have friends because they are shy and don't have the social skills to make contact, though they'd like to. My advice would be to encourage social contact and activity, but not to push it too hard. Sometimes anxiety and lack of confidence is specifically around school peer groups. Sometimes there's the possibility of bullying; sometimes the group in your child's year may simply not be very nice. So find another group; maybe connected to a leisure activity or a hobby. A peer group away from school can be much less threatening than a rowdy big group in the playground. Also, whatever the group is, be it stamp-collecting or swimming, they immediately have something in common, which is an excellent route to making friends.

John Coleman
Director of the Trust for the Study of Adolescence

Academic achievement isn't the be-all and end-all, but the fact that this boy is doing well in his studies means he's still tuned into the external realities and requirements of life, or he wouldn't be able to concentrate.

If he wasn't working at school I'd be more worried. Is he eating and sleeping well? If not, there could be some early signs of a depressive disorder. But a lot of teenagers are a bit withdrawn. I can understand that this parent wants him to be more jolly, to be one of the crowd, but you have to bear in mind that there are many different types of personality, and young people find many different paths into adult life. Parents often want their children to be like them, or to be how they would like to be, and perhaps this parent is very sociable; but you have to live with the fact that your teenager is a different person from you. I would allow this chap to grow up as he is.

This parent is evidently worried and needs to discuss it with someone; talking to one of their son's teachers might put their mind at rest. To some extent the boy might think they're being intrusive, but it would give some sort of expression to their concern.

Peter Wilson
Director of Young Minds, the children's mental health charity

Some children are naturally introverted, are reserved and like their own company, and this can be more of a problem for the parents than the child; if he's happy in his own skin, then that's OK. Lots of children at this age exhibit this kind of behaviour; some change quite radically at the transition between childhood and adulthood and though I hate to use the phrase, it may be a phase. It depends if this parent has noticed other things, too. Is he unable to sleep, off his food, morose, lethargic, snappy where once he was quite placid? If a child is emotionally upset, you see changes in behaviour. Are there any health problems like headaches, stomach upsets? These can be indicators that something is wrong that the child is not prepared to talk about. If the parent has a good relationship with the child, they should check out a few things. Is it possible he's being bullied? If he's pretty capable at school he may be targeted as a swot. From the tone of the letter, I doubt that drugs are the problem, but it's a possibility. Or maybe body image; a lot of 15-year-olds are still quite puny, and if he feels he's not developing or if he's short in stature he may be worried. The main thing is to try and keep the lines of communication open. Children aren't always up for long, meaningful discussions, but mealtimes are a good time to drop in some "How are you doing?" questions along with the general chat.

Elaine Douglas
Chartered psychologist

Coming next

My sister, who is 13, has bi-polar disorder and is worried about missing lots of school. She really needs private tuition but my LEA says it doesn't do that. Is it possible and where should we inquire?

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. webTitle: On the Web: Animal Habitats | Tourism

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.standfirst: Animal Habitats | Tourism
fields.trailText: Animal Habitats | Tourism
fields.byline: Compiled by Jim Merrett and Amanda Grimwood
fields.body:
Animal Habitats

Animal Watch
www.cuug.ab.ca:8001/~animal/

Suitable for: KS1 & 2 teachers & pupils

Well illustrated, covering habitats in 12 different parts of the world, including polar, mountain, temperate, rainforest and urban areas.

Worksheet
www.educate.org.uk/teacher_zone/classroom/science/downloads/

Suitable for: KS1 teachers

Useful worksheet that can be printed off. Different parts can be coloured in, according to whether they feature characteristics shared by all animals or only by some. A simple key to help identify minibeast families and introduce the use of a key can be found by adding the following to the above website address: sc_minibeast_key.pdf

Information Sheet
www.icteachers.co.uk/resources/resources_science.htm#Biology (then click on pdf under minibeasts)

Suitable for: KS2 teachers

Practical information sheet that can be printed off. Provides space for recording minibeasts, their habitats and their characteristics to aid identification.

Fen Habitats
www.wildlifetrust.org.uk/suffolk/redgrave/nhistory/habitats.htm

Suitable for: KS1 & 2 teachers & pupils

Excellent use of photographs which show the various categories of habitat covered such as open, aquatic and enclosed. Photos include habitats plus various animals and plants. Of particular interest to schools seeking a contrasting region to their own.

Franklin Institute
sln.fi.edu/tfi/units/life/

Suitable for: KS2 pupils & teachers

Select "Neighbourhoods" and "Living Things" and investigate an ecosystem. Good at introducing and using an extended scientific vocabulary, defining habitats and the processes linked to them, such as competition.

Tourism

Facts and figures (1)
www.britishtouristauthority.org

Suitable for: KS3/4/A-level/teachers

The official site of the British Tourist Authority, this includes key facts and figures - inbound tourism; domestic tourism; employment; tourism expenditure and short-term tourism forecasts for the UK. A useful background/ introduction to a more detailed study of the topic.

Facts and figures (2) www.staruk.co.uk

Suitable for: KS3/4/A-level/teachers

This is the official website of the tourism research liaison group, which is made up of representatives of the national tourist boards of Britain, England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland and the Department for Culture, Media and Sport.

Worldwide tourism

www.world-tourism.org

Suitable for: KS4/A-level/teachers

An extensive site that covers many aspects of the work of the World Tourism Organisation (WTO). The section on the International Year of Ecotourism (2002) includes a helpful definition of ecotourism. At KS3, a lot of teacher guidance would be necessary.

Case study (1) - Dartmoor
www.dartmoor-npa.gov.uk

Suitable for: KS3/4

An excellent site, which includes lively and user-friendly educational fact files. These require Acrobat Reader to download, but can be printed out as classroom resources. Areas covered include general facts and figures, planning and land-use issues.

Case study (2) - The Peak District
www.peakdistrict.gov.uk

Suitable for: KS2/3

The education zone of this site is wonderful. Pupils can take a virtual walk in the Dark Peak, accompanied by a virtual ranger.

Case study (3) - Yosemite Park, US
www.yosemitepark.net

Suitable for: KS3/4/teachers

This site also contains a virtual tour. Whilst more of a marketing site than an educational one, in the FAQ section there is information on the Yosemite Valley Plan, which details the devastation caused by flooding in 1997 and explores the issue of conservation versus tourism
