fields.headline: So you want to learn...Museum-keeping
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.body:
Fuzz been in yet? Sorry?

The fuzz. Filth. Pigs. Have they raided the joint today? Pigs? Joint? What is this?

Come on, you art galleries are all at it. Displaying mucky snaps of kiddies in the buff? We don't do that here.

Come off it, what about that picture over there? What?

Those fat little geezers with nothing on. Those are putti

Putty!? Tell that to the old bill! They're nippers with no clothes on. And they're quite common in pictures of the time.

Oh yeah! Yes. It happens to be my period.

Really? The afternoon shift? No, no. It's my speciality. I'm the keeper of these pictures.

You own all these? You must be worth a bob. No. I'm the keeper, not the owner.

So what does a keeper do? That depends on the size and type of the organisation. In a large gallery the keeper may concentrate entirely on collection development and maintenance, perhaps also the planning of the restoration and conservation of exhibits. In smaller galleries keepers may be involved in administration, display work for exhibitions, visitor education, public speaking, personnel and general management. Keepers of commercial galleries may also be expected to take part in marketing and sales.

How do you get into the job? There is no single,defined route into the profession, and many people enter museums having developed skills and gained experience in previous jobs. This is particularly true of jobs in information technology, fundraising, marketing and personnel.

What are they looking for? A genuine interest in caring for and interpreting artefacts and their history, and some knowledge of the organisations that do this, is the best background to start with. Although people who work in this profession have varied backgrounds, they all possess elements in common: they are highly qualified, motivated and committed. Apart from specialist knowledge in art, other desirables are creativity and innovation skills, especially in smaller galleries. And of course communication skills if you're dealing directly with the public.

Is there a good career structure? Generally speaking, in a large museum/gallery the route is from keeper to registrar keeper to head of collection management and finally museums director.

What about qualifications? They come almost exclusively via postgraduate degree, for instance a postgraduate diploma in cultural heritage. The applicant's first degree is expected to be in a related subject such as art history, fine art and so on. Most practical undergraduate art courses require a prior foundation year in art and design before the degree programme begins. Practical work experience, paid or unpaid, will help applicants get places on postgraduate programmes.

Is there a more practical way in? There is a modern apprenticeship scheme available for 16- to 24-year-olds and there is a series of NVQs up to level 5. These qualifications allow entry to the sector and possible progression through the NVQ system up to curator level. The traditional academic route is still the most popular.

The Cultural Heritage National Training Organisation
www.chnto.co.uk

Learndirect
0800100900 May be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Dear me
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock  enjoys playing agony aunt to the really desperate
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock enjoys playing agony aunt to the really desperate
fields.body:
I have received many letters and e-mails from fellow lecturers around the country asking for help in solving their work-related problems. A big thank you to all concerned and I hope that things work out well, especially Ms O'Neill in Leamington Spa: you are right, cardboard ones always work best. I would never consider plastic.

A very popular theme among correspondents is how to deal with difficult students. My advice is to avoid them completely. Distance learning always works well for me. This is where I put as much distance between myself and the student as possible.

And isn't voice-mail a godsend? You never have to answer the phone when a student rings. When they turn up at your office in person things get more difficult. But with the help of obliging colleagues and the removal of your nameplate from the door all but the most determined student will be fended off. It all boils down to the very essence of good teaching: proper planning.

Many people are concerned about what to wear to college. In the case of Mr Shreeve from Morpeth I strongly recommend the smart casual look. If you are quick you should find at least one branch of C&A open to revitalise your summer wardrobe. And I am sorry, I cannot help you with your query about stain removal.

Ms Kyriacou from Bristol voices the concern of many when she asks why students always appear young and slim when wearing lycra, whereas lecturers are inclined to come across as frumpy and fat. Such concerns have caused many colleagues to perform below their best in class. You are not alone, but the answer to Ms Kyriacou's question is simply that students are young and slim. Lecturers are not.

Harassment in the workplace is a serious issue, so the next topic needs some careful handling. Several people have asked for advice on how to successfully harass other people at college, particularly students. I am sending details of a video on the subject to all concerned. In the meantime, remember that shouting at a student who has not handed in an assignment never works. Threatening to throw their mobile phone at the wall is more likely to succeed. (Thanks to Mr Laing of Burnley for this handy tip.)

Running a business from college premises is something with which many of you are experiencing problems. For some it is a question of how to recreate the kind of photocopying scam that you enjoyed before the service contract ended. New machines do take a while to hack into, but I am sure that your businesses will not suffer too much. Have you tried visiting another college? You may be pleasantly surprised to find it easy to use the copiers without being questioned. Wear a sober suit and aim to visit when an inspection is taking place.

For Mr Draper in Gwent I can only agree with you when it comes to transporting sheep at the weekends in the college minibus. You really must think up more excuses when booking the vehicle. How many times can you take catering students on field trips? But you are certainly not lying when you claim to be using the minibus for fieldwork.

Thank you for your messages. I do hope to reply to all of them shortly, but please do not ask me to pass comment on letters of resignation. I simply cannot cope with anymore on this subject.

fields.headline: Farm crisis hits colleges
fields.standfirst: Chris Dyke  calls for immediate action to rescue agricultural colleges from foot and mouth catastrophe
fields.trailText: Chris Dyke calls for immediate action to rescue agricultural colleges from foot and mouth catastrophe
fields.body:
"There's just myself here." Those few words delivered in a delightful French accent by the receptionist marked the transformation of what is normally one of the country's busiest agricultural colleges into a ghost town.

Kirkley Hall in Northumberland is inside the exclusion zone marking out the start of the foot and mouth crisis. So it is now shut and, apart from the receptionist, deserted.

Across the country, a third of agricultural colleges are silent. In Wales the shutdown is almost total. On ministry advice, all six colleges are closed. Staff living on farms are asked not to come in.

Closures have been gradual, explained Claire Russell at Usk College in Gwent. "First we had to close the college farm, with students restricted to classrooms. Then we had to close the college to all staff and students from a farming background."

It's not all gloom, however. Most colleges are adapting to the situation very quickly. At Brooksby College near Leicester, the main campus is closed because of the farm on site, but students can use another part of the college sited in Melton Mowbray.

Some, such as Duchy College near Plymouth, are rapidly developing distance-learning packages and using the internet to keep in touch.

fields.headline: Tangled web
fields.standfirst: The new national funding for post-16 is a mess, says  Victor Farlie
fields.trailText: The new national funding for post-16 is a mess, says Victor Farlie
fields.body:
One of the last roles of the training and enterprise councils (TECs) before they are shut down is to be "agents" of the new learning and skills councils (LSCs) in re-contracting for all work-based learning across England. The TECs are to be undertaker for the current system and midwife to the new. The formula funding system invented by DfEE officials is now being tested for real.

The new costs for different areas throw up winners and losers. Who would have thought that a training provider in Wandsworth would have a higher cost allowance than one in Hammersmith or Tower Hamlets?

Ministers decided the new administrative areas for the local learning and skills councils in London following a split vote of the now-defunct London Development Partnership. No one knew at the time that the funding system would be directly influenced by this outcome. Hackney and Hammersmith, for instance, have lost between 6% and 12% of their area budgets. These losses will also put in jeopardy funding from the European Union that some areas in the boroughs claim under Objective 2.

Why has Hertfordshire been allocated more funding to promote learners from disadvantaged backgrounds than Manchester, Merseyside, Tyne and Wear and South Yorkshire? Is something happening there that we don't know about? In local government, this type of formula and its impact would be challenged.

The funding system for the next 16 months will have "cushioning and dampening" effects to prevent excessive gains or losses for training providers. But the pricing structure depends on figures that are now two years out of date. In London the cost of training has escalated rapidly, fuelled by TECs needing to safeguard their commercial interests and achieve performance levels. The targets set by civil servants have worsened the problem.

In 16 months, the Learning and Skills Council will be confronted with a thorny political issue - whether to siphon budgets from colleges and adult learning to meet the shortfall arising from the switch to national rates of funding, or to allow work-based learning to decline. The Treasury would no doubt be unimpressed to pay more for less output. Headline figures mask this issue.

Employers are not happy at the near 33% cut in funding for training the over-19s under the new system. These young adults achieve higher qualifications, stay in training longer and produce a more balanced workforce. Curiously this is the biggest gap to be closed in reaching the government's national training targets next year.

The new system demands new computer software, but it doesn't work properly. Weeks are now being lost and TECs are wasting considerable staff time. Training providers complain about moving goalposts, but in reality no goalposts have yet been erected! Only the shape of the ball is known.

The new system requires no information to assess provision for equal opportunity targets. One of the TEC system's features has been the heavy prescription on ethnic minority performance, particularly in the crucial modern apprenticeships. Managers' great fear is that the good work invested in by the government will be lost by administrative oversight. It has flagged up equal opportunities in the new system. Unfortunately, the policy document risks becoming a glossy publication with little substance.

Here in west London our strategy is to put pragmatism before petulance. All the staff want one thing: to make the system work well and ensure the transition from old system to new goes well. The unintended consequences are that work-based learning could become the poor relation to other post-16 funded activity. Any review of the funding formula later this year will be a critical test of the learning and skills councils' capacity to learn and reflect a more realistic set of arrangements that can withstand public scrutiny beyond the next financial year.

Victor Farlie is deputy chief executive of West London TEC

fields.headline: College days
fields.standfirst: Jack Dee
fields.trailText: Jack Dee
fields.body:
Born: September 23, 1961

Occupation: Comedian, actor and ineffectual escape artist who's kept much of the nation entertained by his antics in Celebrity Big Brother.

Attended: Peter Symond's sixth-form college, Winchester

Dates: 1978-80

Courses: English and drama A-levels

Vacation work: During holidays he found employment in an artificial leg factory.

A tutor recalls: "Jack was always a student who liked to be different from other people."

Teenage ambition: "To reform the Church of England" (he wrote this on a careers form at college).

His interview about becoming a clergyman ended early when he admitted he didn't go to church.

fields.headline: The all-in-one shop
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston reviews the government's big idea for keeping teenagers on track
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston reviews the government's big idea for keeping teenagers on track
fields.body:
Your 13-year-old son is finishing a phonecall to a pal. "See you later at Connexions," he says. Calm that leaping heart. The lad is not heading off to licensed premises two years earlier than you did. He's actually referring to the government's new youth service.

Not obvious, is it though? The name lacks the clarity of, say, "Toilets" or "Tourist Information" and even the coded implications of "Sauna".

When Connexions signs start sprouting up in a dozen areas around the land from April (see table), they will stir some memories of those ubiquitous 1980s winebars, all with names ending in "s".

Anne Weinstock, head of Connexions, crisply dismisses the suggestion that the title will be a problem.

"We will have to promote it," she says, adding that young people in the "Pathfinder" areas where Connexions pilot schemes have been tested for the past year have been clear what it is about.

Perhaps there is no label which can precisely and concisely convey the essence of this undoubtedly big and innovative idea of a one-stop shop where any 13- to 19- year-old can drop in for help.

Does that in itself indicates a kink in the concept? If it can't be clearly summed up in a word or at least a phrase, shouldn't that set lights flashing? So, Anne Weinstock, in six words, what is Connexions? And please refrain from saying "multi-agency" or "holistic" - two words which inevitably crop up in attempts to explain it.

For a second she is taken aback. But 27 years working with young people, including some very tricky customers, has put her in much tighter spots.

"It's an integrated advice, guidance and support service for youngsters," she retorts, moving swiftly on to her favourite analogy. She sees it as being like the casualty department she went to a couple of years ago with a broken arm. First she was assessed by a triage nurse and told she would have to wait to be treated - not so long as the drunk sleeping it off in the waiting room but longer than the victims of a road accident who had just been stretchered in.

For the first time a teenager will have a one-stop shop, a place where he or she can get information and guidance on careers, health, family relationships, housing, sex and addiction . . . on the spot.

"One of the things I understand about young people having worked with them for 27 years, is that you can't offer them anything that you can't show them the same day," Weinstock says.

The teenager with a drink or drugs problem who is suddenly in the mood to get advice about it needs to be seen before the urge goes.

The adolescent girl traumatised by her parents' acrimonious divorce who has started sleeping with a string of older men needs a complex response from a range of professionals. However as services have been organised until now, it has been very difficult, if not impossible, so the theory goes, for such a youngster to get to the right help.

"People are acting in silos looking at one problem," says Weinstock. "What young people are saying to us when we research what's wrong, is that no single person is working with other agencies to sort out all the problems they have."

Now there will be one person. The key and new figure to emerge as the Connexions linchpin will be the personal adviser.

"The notion is that one professional person will act as advocate and broker for the young person.

"The youngster goes to one person with whom they develop a relationship of trust."

Where will these special people come from? The intention is that many of them will be working with youngsters in, for example, careers guidance, youth work or the voluntary sector, and will now undergo additional training for the task. A diploma is currently being developed.

"We've put the personal advisers, from drug-action teams and youth- action teams, the leaving-care advisers along with the career and youth workers all into one pool," says Weinstock ."We get the fusion of skills - the synergy we need to meet young people's needs."

The impetus for Connexions came from a report by the Social Exclusion Unit, Bridging The Gap (July 1999), which discovered that 161,000 16- and 17-year-olds were languishing outside education, training and work for long periods after the school leaving age of 16.

A Connexions card with a chip in it will be available to every 16- to 19-year-old from the autumn. This will enable the service to know when, for instance, a youngster is not in school, college or training when they should be. Apparently teenagers canvassed about the card have overlooked the sinister implications of this tracking device because it offers discounts on travel.

The DfEE's prospectus which introduced Connexions makes clear that it will give "particular priority to getting and keeping on track those young people who are most at risk of encountering obstacles to a successful transition to adulthood".

Ministers have since been stressing that Connexions must be a quality service for all 13- to 19-year-olds, and Weinstock stresses it too. At least 85% of the age group are expected to call on Connexions just for advice on careers, and which route they should be taking at 16.

This is one of the worries among sceptics of the project. Why should the vast majority of youngsters wanting careers advice have to troop to premises also specialising in the serious problems of a minority?

Won't there be a risk of encouraging some kids to find problems they didn't have? And what guarantee is there that youngsters with major problems will stroll in simply because help is all under one roof?

And what are parents to be told? Even in 2001, who will expect to be informed if their 13-, 14- and 15-year-old children are confessing to multiple sexual partners or heavy drugs habits?

Like the diploma for personal advisers, the procedure for informing parents is still being worked out, Weinstock says.

Where are they?

The 12 Connexions partnerships announced by ministers today:

 Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

 North London

 South London

 Lincolnshire and Rutland

 Cornwall, Isles of Scilly, Devon, Plymouth and Torbay

 West of England

 South Yorkshire

 Cheshire and Warrington

 Cumbria

 Coventry and Warwickshire

 Black Country

 Shropshire, Telford and Wrekin

webTitle: Threat of industrial action by lecturers

fields.headline: Election strike risk
fields.standfirst: Industrial action by lecturers is looming ever closer, reports  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Industrial action by lecturers is looming ever closer, reports Peter Kingston
fields.body:
A lecturers' strike on May 1 which would embarrass Labour two days before the possible general election polling day is looking more likely this week.

Natfhe, the lecturers' union, has sent every college principal a demand for a flat-rate £3,000 pay rise for 2001-2002 backed by a threat to take industrial action starting on May 1.

The Association of Colleges' chief executive, David Gibson, warned Natfhe to back off. He accused the union of busting the joint union-employers approach to bargaining with ministers which has operated for the past year and established a 3.3% pay increase for the current year.

And he said that Natfhe's action will put at risk the £150m for the Teachers Pay Initiative.

Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, was due to announce how the first £50m of this was to be distributed among colleges.

Ministers, anxious to settle the colleges' pay dispute before launching an election campaign, hoped that the package, details of which were revealed by Guardian Further two weeks ago, would do the trick.

It is not just the possibility of strike pickets on the eve of polling day which makes the politicians nervous. College lecturers do not expect to excite much public sympathy. There is potentially more embarrassment in the inevitable invocation of Conservative union legislation to try to prevent industrial action.

Natfhe's £3,000 demand, described as an "interim" claim on behalf of managers as well as lecturers, was decided at the union's conference on January 20.

It was crafted as the first step in a staged award to come into effect over the next four years to restore further education lecturers' pay-relativity with salaries in schools. Lecturers' pay has fallen about 10% behind that of teachers.

Gibson has sent every principal a draft reply which he advises each sends to Natfhe's general secretary Paul Mackney.

The letter advises the union boss that the principal in question won't negotiate with him, but will wait for the "established collective bargaining machinery" to proceed.

Natfhe relayed its claim to the Association of Colleges at the end of January.

On February 27, David Gibson responded that the AoC took staff pay "extremely seriously" but that their interim claim ought to be "routed through the national joint forum", ie the combined unions-AoC negotiating body.

Denying AoC claims that he was being forced into escalating a dispute by a left-wing group on his executive committee, Mackney said it was simply a question of lecturers finally losing patience. This was only reinforced by the realisation that the £50m, although welcome, was just 2% of the lecturers' pay bill, while a similar scheme has yielded 8% for school teachers.

"Members at the conference told me that the talks with the AoC had generated some useful agreements but in the end hadn't dealt with the two main issues - pay and excessive work loads."

Natfhe was putting in its claim early this year to avoid previous experiences of running on to the end of the college year and being unable to mount action.

Mackney added that Natfhe was legally bound to deal with each college individually. "Whilst we respect the national bargaining mechanism, if there's a dispute it's with each employer."

fields.headline: Eriksson demands professional spirit
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson has stressed the importance of a good atmosphere in the England squad as he prepares his side for the vital World Cup matches against Finland at Anfield on Saturday and Albania in Tirana next Wednesday "It's very important to me. If you don't have a good ambience then you will not get a good result," he said.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson has stressed the importance of a good atmosphere in the England squad as he prepares his side for the vital World Cup matches against Finland at Anfield on Saturday and Albania in Tirana next Wednesday "It's very important to me. If you don't have a good ambience then you will not get a good result," he said.

While Kevin Keegan was England's coach it was widely believed that club cliques had developed in the squad, particularly relating to the Manchester United and Liverpool players.

But Eriksson said he was not bothered if players did not dine together. "I make the line-up when we play, not when we're eating," he said.

"I can't tell Paul Scholes to have a cup of tea with Sol Campbell, or for players to share rooms. There are reasons why Scholes and Beckham should have tea together as they are friends. It's about having respect," he said.

As to his approach to discipline Eriksson said: "It's not exactly rules. I'm not making 10, 15 or 20 rules and putting them up on the board saying 'this is the regime'. But coming on time, behaving like professional English football players. We are here to get to know each other, to practise, to eat, to rest and to play. That's it."

Eriksson admitted he had been lucky in the timing of his appointment as England coach given the depth of young talent at his disposal.

"It is good that I have taken over when a English clubs are doing so well in Europe and I am lucky coming into the job when there are so many good, young players. webTitle: The benefits of BT's FutureTalk Award programme

fields.headline: Get your prizes
fields.standfirst: The BT FutureTalk Award programme has enabled a range of schools to find new uses for the net, says Louis White
fields.trailText: The BT FutureTalk Award programme has enabled a range of schools to find new uses for the net, says Louis White
fields.body:
While the power of the internet has been regularly discussed in regards to online streaming video, it is the power of streaming audio that enabled St Aidan's Church of England High School in Harrogate to win the top £25,000 prize from the BT FutureTalk Award programme.

Pupils from St Aidan's school will link up with three other local schools to establish and run an internet radio station for the benefit of both the communities and schools.

St Aidan's school will be co-ordinating the project that also involves two schools from Boston Spa, Boston Spa Comprehensive and St John's Catholic School for the Deaf, and another school from Harrogate, St John Fisher RC High School. Students will collaborate to produce a series of high-quality programmes as well as manage the internet radio station, design the website and commission the programme.

It is the brainchild of the head of IT at St Aidan's, Chris Burt. "Basically we weren't able to stream the video cost-effectively with the bandwidth we had. I worked out it would be more cost effective to stream audio," Burt said.

"The more we looked at commercial stations the more attractive it became. If students are sick or can't attend school, they can listen in so they won't miss a class.

"The children will make up the programmes which includes recording, interviewing, producing programmes that are of interest to themselves and curriculum-based. It will be a great learning experience.

The second school to be awarded the top £25,000 prize is the Claypool School in Horwich, who are teaming up with Rivington and Blackrod High School in Horwich and Blackrod Cluster Group South African schools from the Gauteng Province in Pretoria.

The project will enable primary and secondary school students in Britain and South Africa to communicate via videoconferencing and email and share ideas and strategies on a range of PSHE issues.

"I went to the Gauteng province of South Africa last year as part of a group to look at creativity and teaching through learning in their country," said deputy head teacher Jeremy Atkinson. "It gave me the idea to communicate via the internet.

"The normal schools in the townships are supported by the private schools. The money will help to provide training, oversee the installation of the equipment and provide them with general help. "The focus of the project is personal wellbeing for the students. The main issue for primary schoolchildren is bullying. Videoconferencing will be used initially to ask students from each country what it means to them, how it effects them, their own experience and how they handle it. The high school students will discuss subjects such as Aids as that is a big issue in South Africa."

An online art gallery caught the eye of the judges and awarded Brampton Manor Secondary School in Newham, East London, £5,000 to explore its idea.

The project will incorporate not only local schools but stretch across the globe to include America, Germany and India. As well as being displayed at participating schools, the web gallery will also be set up at either the Whitechapel Gallery, Tate Modern or East London University.

"We will be working with a resident artist who will show the students how to use Photoshop and children will be communicating with each other using webcam," said project co-ordinator Olivia Foskett-Chipping.

Community spirit is big among most schools as they strive to develop an all-round learning process. One school which has taken that even further is Malton Community Primary School in North Yorkshire.

"We have a long-running French language course and strong links with the teaching training programme in Nice, France," said ICT co-ordinator, Tim Hiley. "We have a large cluster of schools that weren't getting much chance to speak French.

"For the past four or five years we have had teachers comingfrom Nice and they have wanted to keep that link going. Now that is possible via the internet."

The BT FutureTalk Awards Programme, backed by the Guardian, was launched in January 2000 to help support school curriculum projects using ICT. A total of £300,000 in prizes will be distributed during each academic year for two years.

BT Futuretalk - judges' view

Last term there were 296 entries, involving over 1,500 schools, for the awards - many of a high standard. We were especially pleased to have our first winner from Wales and a number of outstanding applications from Scotland.

We're always looking for strong, clearly-explained ideas with a clear objective in mind. Sometimes the simplest aims - such as Benjamin Britten High School's project, in which year 10 pupils teach year seven how to create a website in HTML - are the most compelling. Try not to let your application become bogged down in the jargon of government targets and strategic aims. Get to the purpose of the project, and then explain how the technology will help them deliver it.

Malton's Video Link Français, for example, was an outstanding example of how videoconferencing can transform language teaching. On occasion, though, email and face-to-face contact can be just as effective.

The judges want to see innovative projects for food technology (where ICT is underused) and for new areas of the GNVQ and A-level curriculum, as well as citizenship. Plans need to be exciting or stimulating for the students, too, which is why St Aidan's online radio station scored highly.

Lornshill Academy's collaboration with two Swedish schools to measure and track acid rain impressed us all. Like all the best applications, it had a well thought-out timescale, a careful budget and was linked to the national curriculum. Lornshill had also researched its partner schools' facilities closely and knew what extra equipment they needed.

Ros Taylor

webTitle: Assessment: Setting and marking exams no longer needs to be a chore for teachers.

fields.headline: Goal setting
fields.standfirst: Setting and marking exams no longer needs to be a chore for teachers. Phil Revell investigates online assessment
fields.trailText: Setting and marking exams no longer needs to be a chore for teachers. Phil Revell investigates online assessment,
fields.body:
Year seven pupils at Telford's Blessed Robert Johnson Catholic college are sitting an assessment. Nothing unusual about that; in fact some would say that today's students are assessed too often and with too little result. But for BRJ's year sevens the test represents a welcome change. There are no deep sighs as the weaker students find questions way beyond their capability. Everybody seems to be working steadily; in fact the whole group seems to be enjoying the test, even the teacher.

Richard Lawson isn't fond of tests. They have to be set, which can take some time if the questions are to be both challenging and differentiated. "Then you have to spend a couple of hours marking," he says. "And if they are lucky the group will see their results a week later."

Not this time. BRJ's year sevens are doing a Goal assessment. Lawson didnÍt set it and he doesn't have to mark it either. It's an online assessment system that claims to offer a differentiated test for all subjects in the national curriculum - at all levels.

Half an hour after the lesson the results were available. Each child has been given a national curriculum level and the group's individual strengths and weaknesses are laid out for the teacher to use for future planning.

"Part of the motivation for trialling this was the need for a baseline test for ICT," says Lawson. In the lesson is Sarah Jones from the Telford and Wrekin LEA ICT team. The authority is looking at the software, evaluating its possibilities, but Lawson wants the system now. "This has huge potential for saving teachers' time," he argues.

Goal was launched in the autumn. It's the brainchild of Gareth Newman who was head of the successful Brooke Weston city technology college in Corby before retiring in 1998. "The idea for this was in my head long before I left Brooke Weston," says Newman. "I'd realised the potential of ICT but what I didn't have was the programming skill and capability to translate the idea into action." Newman teamed up with education entrepreneur Wynnford Dore, and Goal was the result.

The aim was to create a tool which would release teachers from the routine of setting and marking assessments while at the same time providing quality data which could be used to plan lessons. At the moment it faces no real competition in the education marketplace. Some products, such as Plato and SIR, offer a combination of content and assessment, but Goal appears to be alone in offering across-the-board assessment linked to National Curriculum levels.

"There has been a lot of consultation with teachers and with people who have experience in question setting," says Newman. The questions are in a multiple-choice format and are downloaded over the internet.

Connectivity is an obvious issue, but Newman insists that the system is designed for use even by schools with relatively low access speeds. Answers are available on the

Goal website, often within the hour. No two tests are the same because each student answers questions which have been tailored to their ability. Assessments are preceded by screening questions which identify strengths and weaknesses.

This individual approach created some problems for the Goal programming team and it was some time before the random-question generator was coming up with question groups which reliably matched national curriculum levels, but Newman reckons that the problems have been solved.

At Staffordshire's tiny St Johns First School the system is running on just two machines, but headteacher Andrew Kirby is enthusiastic. "It takes a week for the older children to do a test, the younger ones need more support, either from staff or older children. In reality it doesn't disrupt the teaching process."

Kirby estimates that his teachers would have to spend six hours to produce the results that Goal spits out at the touch of a button. "The time-saving is a huge factor for us, but the diagnostic element will help us to develop our teaching."

It's a point underlined by Richard Lawson at BRJ. "The quality of the information means that teachers aren't flying by the seat of their pants," he says. "It's informed decision-making about the content of future lessons."

And the children? What do they think about using their computer time to do assessments? "Some questions were quite easy, but others were more of a challenge," says Leila at BRJ. "The most difficult one was the Turtle where I had to do the coordinates in my head. I'd like to do more tests like this."

With results that can be dropped straight into a SIMS assessment manager program and a time-saving measured in several hours a week, that's a wish she is likely to find coming true sooner rather than later. www.goalplc.co.uk

Assessment 1: Meeting criteria

Sally Caplan is ICT coordinator at the Holy Family technology college, Walthamstow, a Catholic comprehensive with over 1,000 pupils.

We teach ICT for an hour a week in year seven, and across the curriculum in years eight to 13. For KS3 we have subject-specific tasks, which are assessed by both the department and myself.

At KS4 we have just introduced the ICAA certificates of competence. English and RE do word processing and DTP; maths do spreadsheets, and next year science will do data logging.

We have integrated ICT into every subject area, so our students do not see it as a separate subject. When planning the work and assessment, I work with departments and help them to devise tasks that will meet the ICT criteria at the same time as meeting their own subject criteria. We think it's important that pupils know why they are using ICT, and so every child has to do an evaluation sheet or "what I did" sheet to give evidence that they know what they did and why they did it.

Our ICT assessments have been good predictors of GCSE grades, and were approved in our Ofsted inspection. The school uses SIMS for assessment, and I use Excel to analyse the stats. It's very important to work closely with departments, have "what I did" sheets, tell the students what is expected and have differentiation.

It's also good to encourage independent learning through activity sheets that contain the task and the expectations, and "how to". But before you give the work to students, get the staff to do the tasks themselves first.

Assessment 2: Across the curriculum

Drew Buddie is ICT coordinator at Royal Masonic School, Rickmansworth, Herts, an independent girls' boarding school of 750 pupils aged 4-18

All pupils in the prep school use ICT for a minimum of one hour a week. This is then supported by use of individual, stand-alone computers in every class. In the senior school, all pupils from years seven to 11 have 70 minutes of discrete ICT per week.

We assess ICT through projects in other subjects. Pupils are also given an instruction sheet by the ICT department which outlines the features we want to assess - accuracy, features used, variety, audience, neatness, combination of packages (scanning text, images, charts, tables etc), research (use of the internet), attributing sources plus discretionary marks for effort and distinctiveness.

The class then has a couple of weeks to produce the coursework. It is marked by the geography department, according to its criteria, as a piece of geography coursework. It is then marked by the ICT department, according to its criteria, as a piece of ICT coursework showing ICT skills.

We also incorporate self-assessment in this process, which motivates the pupils to take a pride in their work.

I would strongly encourage schools to embrace the notion of students (no matter how young) evaluating their own and each other's work. The benefits are many, not least of which is a more amiable, team-like atmosphere in even the most uncooperative of groups.

webTitle: Assessment: Using the preparing and marking facilities available on the internet can make testing easier.

fields.headline: Easy assess
fields.standfirst: Using the preparing and marking facilities available on the internet can make testing easier, says Terry Freedman
fields.trailText: Using the preparing and marking facilities available on the internet can make testing easier, says Terry Freedman.
fields.body:
If you want to take some of the blood, sweat and tears out of the processes of assessment and recording, there are alternatives to the large, fairly costly programs, especially for individual teachers and, in secondary schools, departments.

First, what sort of utilities are available for creating tests, crosswords, matching exercises and so on? All teachers know that word searches, cloze (replacing words with astericks) exercises and vocab tests are excellent ways to check pupils' understanding before moving on to the next topic. But preparing them and marking them afterwards are inordinately time-consuming.

Fortunately, there are three facilities in particular which are not only good, but free: Discovery, Hot Potato and TexToys. All create web pages instantly: link these to your school website or intranet, and you can rapidly build up a bank of resources that is easily accessible to both staff and pupils.

Even if you only have an age-old "stand-alone computer at the back of the classroom", and a web browser is installed, you can use these files - although for the Discovery version you will need internet access too.

The Discovery puzzle website at www.ictineducation.org and there are several examples at the Discovery quiz centre mentioned earlier.

An alternative is the Hot Potato suite of programs, which are free for educational use. You can download them from http://www.web.uvic.ca/hrd/hotpot/ Again, several types of test and puzzle are available, and these are much better in some respects than the Discovery ones. Why? Partly because there are many more options in terms of configuring responses: with Discovery you have to accept correct and incorrect, as far as I can see, whereas with Hot Potato you can choose other responses.

Another plus point is that questions which require answers in sentences can be included. If pupils put an extra space in the answer, or use slightly different words to the teacher's correct answer, they are not completely penalised because the feedback shows which parts of the pupil's answer were correct.

TexToys program www.cict.co.uk/software/textoys/ consists of two programs: WebRhubarb and WebSequitur. Rhubarb is a cloze program while Sequitur is a logic/story-building program. Both, like Hot Potato, allow the teacher to set up a number of options.

While Hot Potato goes some way towards allowing you to automate the marking of tests which go beyond multiple choice and true/false questions, the teacher still has to mark pupils' work with comments, rather than ticks and red marks. Markin software provides a fast way of adding comments. Copy/paste the pupil's work into Markin, then add comments by clicking on the appropriate buttons, and then email the work to the student (or save it back as an RTF document).

You could, of course, configure Word or any other half-decent word processor to do the same thing, but Markin makes it easy to set up and, furthermore, counts up the number of annotations made in different categories. The program is free, but is limited to short texts unless you register for £20. For schools, the price is £20 for the initial licence, and then a certain amount per pupil: see www.cict.co.uk/software/markin/education_site.htm

Whatever assessment tools you use, you need some time to analyse the results. This is where standard office software applications, such as Excel, come into their own. A fairly standard spreadsheet will let you calculate totals, averages and how many times work was handed in or not handed in, using the count function and its variants, and predicted grades, using the IF function or a lookup table.

 Terry Freedman is an ICT adviser and the author of several books on ICT. See www.ictineducation.org.uk for further details

Assessment dos and dont's

Do


 Set open-ended tasks as far as possible. For example, say "Produce a set of rules for using the internet", rather than "Use Word to produce a set of 10 rules for using the internet; include one piece of clip art." If you put a ceiling on the task, you won't know if the pupils who reach the target could have achieved even more.
 Assess the thinking process rather than computer skills. This means adopting a problem-solving approach rather than a skills-based approach.
 Be clear on what you are trying to assess, especially in the context of another subject: advanced work in the other subject may be quite low-level in terms of ICT (and vice-versa!).
 Keep track of pupils' progress throughout the term, and record your thoughts in your markbook. Remember: your professional judgment is a key component of assessment, and the notes you make will constitute part of your evidence base.

Don't

 Disassemble the national curriculum level indicators: they are not designed to be used as a competencies checklist.
 Rely on just one assessment at the end of the key stage: it's important to assess the pupils on a regular basis to inform your teaching strategy, and to build up a picture of each individual.
 Discount the value of asking pupils to evaluate their own work, and to use this as a basis for one-to-one discussions.

Assessment 3: In different years

Jo Feeney is ICT coordinator at William Bellamy Infant School, Dagenham, with 350 pupils.

We have a purpose-built ICT suite for teaching the children ICT skills. Each classroom also has an internet-ready PC to help consolidate and apply ICT skills. That's important: it means the pupils can be taught a particular skill, and then apply it in their ordinary lessons.

We assess ICT in each year group through the use of end-of-year assessment targets which are monitored and assessed as an ongoing process. The targets we set match directly to the QCA's scheme of work and documentation, although I think the QCA targets do not stretch the children's capabilities.

To ensure that our assessments are valid, we have related the assessment criteria directly to local and national initiatives. Also, each pupil has an individual assessment record to inform future teachers of the child's knowledge and understanding.

fields.headline: Soundbytes
fields.trailText: US starts backlash against ICT
fields.body:
US starts backlash against ICT

In a new and disturbing trend, a number of US educationalists have signed a computer moratorium calling for a halt to the spread of ICT into the curriculum. The movement, believed to have the backing of President George Bush, is a setback for progressive voices within education and could spark debate about the future of ICT in Britain's schools.

Professor Stephen Heppell of the ICT in education research institute, Ultralab, at Anglia Polytechnic University, says: "This is bad news. Our aim should be to prepare children for what the economy is going to be like in future."

Heppell, who visited the US, recently spoke head-to-head with a number of proponents of the moratorium. He found the critics of ICT were disappointed by its application in the classroom, found it did not significantly contribute to raising standards and believed it offered very poor value for money.

Responding to the critics Heppell believed that instead of the "content is king" approach to learning, schools should be looking at how use of ICT could encourage creativity and participation.

Want some good ideas?

A Liverpool teacher whose special needs pupils download data from a robotic telescope via the Internet, and a school in Worthing where children produce computer animations on graphical calculators are just two of many examples featured in an online book, Good Practice and the Use of ICT.

The book's editor Joyce Wood of the Science and Technology Policy Research Unit at the University of Sussex has interviewed 150 teachers as part of a project known as THEO   Teachers Helping Each Other.

She says: "Historically teachers have always had to reinvent the wheel. I thought they would benefit from seeing how each other's approaches work."

Any teacher who would like to become involved in the project can e-mail THEO and the book can be downloaded free at www.rm.com/reports (click on Good Practice).

Teacher help on the net

A new website, described by one expert as a "geek-free zone", was launched last week by the DfEE to help teachers swap good ideas and best practice in ICT.

Named TforT - short for teachers for teachers - the site has been designed to help teachers - especially those undergoing NOF (New Opportunities Fund) training - to reflect on their experience of ICT in the classroom.

The idea is to provide a chance for professionals to make their voices heard and influence future policy. TforT.net.

Calling unhealthy teens

Embarrassed by spots and acne? Developing a drink problem? Troubled teenagers in need of comfort and reassurance can find solace from a visit to Doctor Ann's Virtual Surgery. With a home page index that looks like a hospital notice board   the web pages include health quizzes, a guide to what's legal and information on diseases such as CJD and BSE.

The most fascinating section is the teen mag style problem pages. "Dear Breast Implanter" is advised that her operation would cost around £3,000. But, says the good doctor, "Don't even think about it. Just don't even BEGIN to think about it." Sage advice. www.doctorann.org

The lean-over toy

To kids of all ages it looks like simply the best toy imaginable. To the boffins at Ultralab it is a tool to explore how a four-to eight-year-old might learn about the way they lean! The eTui is a cuddly battery-powered robot, a psychedelic tortoise bristling with sensors and computer chips that enable it to "see" obstacles and find its way around them. The design owes a lot to asking children what they wanted from a toy. With the research and development completed, Ultralab is looking for a commercial sponsor - possibly a toy company ¾ to put eTui into production.

Oh no, Access Denied

At a glance, RM's educational games website educationcity.net has much on offer - spelling, grammar, maths problems and appealing animation flash files.

It also costs money to subscribe and, as I was not willing to to fork out, I had to imagine the treats in store.

However, if the games are anything like as well designed as the attractive home page and the primary and secondary phase menus suggest then this site is likely to appeal to its target audience.

As for my rejection, instead of the usual message in a box I had a kindly looking owl in a mortar board advising me I needed to subscribe while next to him a cartoon dragon turns away in horror with the speech bubble, "Oh no, Access denied!"

webTitle: Wising up to the ultimate resource

fields.headline: Wising up to the ultimate resource
fields.standfirst: John Davitt picks out the creativity theme at this week's education bonanza in Birmingham
fields.trailText: John Davitt picks out the creativity theme at this week's education bonanza in Birmingham
fields.body:
Too often the good ICT ideas developed in classrooms don't get shared and teachers have little chance to learn from colleagues. This year the focus on creativity at the Education Show (National Exhibition Centre, Birmingham, March 22-24) is particularly welcome as several exhibitors will offer tools for teachers which will help them share and support each other. A performing arts website will be launched by the British Educational Communciations and Technology agency (stand P38). The site (www.performingwithict.net) contains case studies for music, arts and drama and even offers an on-line facility for projects and schools to submit information about their own work. Becta is also hosting a three-hour internet safety seminar on the first day of the show.

Learning & Teaching Scotland (C58) has put much care into building effective online learning environments and its new flagship learning environment, Pioneer, will be on show. This is in tandem with several life skills software packages that bring a serious message through bright screen simulations and activities.

But the ultimate learning resource is another person and suddenly the ICT world is wising up to this. Companies such as Brainfuse (C1) have built online environments where students and tutors communicate online in real-time. Special facilities exist within the site for blind and visually impaired pupils.

Elsewhere, 2Simple (SW25) will launch its latest integrated package, Infant Video Toolbox, which allows teachers to cover all the major requirements of key stages one and two, and even includes the delights of a branching database. The hidden jewel in these resources is a set of screen recordings of the software in action with a calm human voice speaking directly to the teachers.

Softease (B63), which seems particularly attuned to teachers' needs, has produced a series of National Curriculum Packs built around its exemplary multimedia software, Textease. The packs provide print and electronic resources to fulfil many of the cross-curricular requirements laid down in QCA guidelines. Have a look also at Textease Studio now sold with 80 free exercises across its key stage range. The way its spreadsheet and databases work and the creative use of appropriate clip art offer a real alternative to Microsoft Office.

Granada Learning (B41) continues to gather in the competition and now boasts a stable of software and training opportunities second to none. Its Primary Toolkit is a comprehensive resource and it will also be showing its new internet subscription service, www.primary-zone.com

The New Opportunities Fund for teachers training in ICT is having a major effect on ICT considerations in schools. It also neatly illustrates the troubled path followed when a centralised and over-directed approach is taken to training. One size never did fit all where learning is concerned. "Imagine what we could we have done if we had been given the money (approximately £450 per teacher) to spend as we saw fit?" lament most senior managers I meet in schools. Find out about schools' experiences so far at New Opportunities Fund (S39) You can also pick up pointers here to the various providers who are at the show.

As projection costs drop many schools are considering the use of projected images from the computer screen as part of whole class teaching. Whiteboard manufacturer Promethean (P70) will display handheld devices for students which increase the interactivity of the board. Teachers talking to teachers and evaluating resources is the primary intention of Teachers Evaluating Educational Multimedia (Teem) project (A61) and staff will be on hand to advise teachers and show them the best of software on offer.

Finally, there are few software success stories to match that of The Skills Factory (SW1) which builds software to help teachers manage and keep literacy and numeracy records. Now the 10,000 teachers using the software can link to a massive Online Resource Bank (ORB TM), with thousands of lesson plans and teaching ideas created by schools already using the system. It's a fine example of ICT at its most powerful.

BETT retrospective

Homework from C4

On the back of the launch at BETT of products such as JustWrite primary literacy resources, Channel 4 has made great strides in developing home resources such as the BAFTA award-winning Homework High, (www.homeworkhigh.com). Made for and by its users, the site gives students out-of-hours access to expert help from qualified teachers.

Portable Macs

High interest in Apple Computer's video-editing software during the BETT show has spawned machines for the education market. The style star is the new PowerBook, a one-inch thick, portable computer with a massive 15.2-inch screen screen and G4 processor in a sleek titanium case. It's a complete mobile video-editing suite - just add a camera. Even more useful for schools will be the new Imacs in Flower Power or Dalmatian design. They have CD-writers built in to let you record and edit your own sound and video and produce your own CDs.

Build your own film set

LEGO Mindstorms was another BETT star attraction, with simple robotic control gears and motors linked to control and modelling software. They have now entered the animation and video-editing market with A Lego and Steven Spielberg MovieMaker Set, which has a digital camera, software and a stage with actors so that students aged 8-16 years can make animations. The pack, at £159, includes more than 400 props and a booklet on film techniques.

Interactive maths

Following on from a successful BETT debut for Easiteach, the interactive whiteboard-based approach to whole-class maths teaching, RM will be launching MathQuest a new key stage 3-4 maths resource at the Education Show.

fields.headline: Learning the language sites
fields.standfirst: Whether it's French or Chinese you're after, there's a website to help, says John Bald
fields.trailText: Whether it's French or Chinese you're after, there's a website to help, says John Bald
fields.body:
There's mixed news from Ros Walker, who is running the government-sponsored training in computers in language teaching for the Centre for Information on Language Teaching (CILT). The good news is that the course's 400 places could be filled twice over if CILT could find enough tutors.

The bad news is that linguists are still having to make do with old computers that don't have sound cards, won't run the latest software and keep crashing. This limits access to programs that accept speech to children with up-to-date machines at home.

Walker reports another snag with Tell Me More (see below) in the hands of the mischievous - its voice recognition system, she says, works on tone rather than pronunciation, so that you can get an apparently correct result by humming nonsense into it.

One recent development to appeal to the committed is Microsoft's multi-language pack with Office 2000 (student/teacher price £119). It offers grammar and spelling checks for most languages studied in schools.

Produced for multinationals, the pack gives immediate feedback on errors as you write, with suggested corrections and grammatical notes. This is no fool's paradise - you need to understand the notes in the foreign language, and to be reasonably accurate in the first place. But the system enables A-level and GCSE students to improve their work without having to wait for the teacher to mark it, and should be equally useful to teachers preparing materials. Teachers from the CILT course, who mostly have access to Office 97 rather than 2000, are finding the "insert-comment" feature makes marking stand out effectively.

Dorling Kindersley's GCSE Revision CD-roms (French, German, £9.99 each), are closely linked to syllabuses and provide good, systematic practice at foundation or higher level. These also need a sound card. The programs keep records, and help you focus your practice on points of weakness. The interactive element, which lets you listen to short snatches of language read by native speakers and then record your own version, is also well-targeted. I had a tendency, for example, not to pronounce the "v" in German words sharply enough. Conscientious work with either program would improve most people's grade.

The net provides you with free sites for GCSE students from the Guardian, Channel 4 and the BBC. Each has features which you can pick and mix to meet your own needs. Channel 4 (www.homeworkhigh.com), for example, offers excellent feedback from highly skilled teachers on individual pieces of written work in French. You can use a library of answers to thousands of previous questions, or send in your own (Wednesdays only).

The Guardian site has a good selection of exercises, and the BBC's Bite-size video clips help with listening as well as reading and writing. Bite-size question analysis offers good detail for higher level in French and German. Some features on the BBC site, notably "ask a teacher", were not up and running when I was researching this article. The Guardian site also contains all of its previously published Eyewitness texts in French, German, Italian and Spanish since 1999.

Tell Me More: Chinese (£99, www.auralog.com), applies advanced techniques to a difficult language. This seemed enticing, but I soon hit snags. The pictures accompanying the early dialogues are chosen to illustrate Chinese culture, and I could see no link between them and the monosyllables I was supposed to reproduce. Sometimes the computer told me I had got an answer right, sometimes wrong, but I had no idea of the meaning of what I was pronouncing, and could see no way to improve my efforts.

The language program uses the same film-set format as European languages in this series, and you select the exercises and lessons you want from a menu. This, for me, was at the root of the problem - I had no idea of what to try first, or of how to make sense of the lessons. Auralog has done well even to tackle such potentially rewarding language, but this program needs much clearer instructions on the initial stages - perhaps a "getting started" pamphlet - if its good users are not to turn to bad language.

Channel 4 (www.homeworkhigh.com), for example, offers excellent feedback from highly skilled teachers on individual pieces of written work in French. You can use a library of answers to thousands of previous questions, or send in your own (Wednesdays only). The Guardian site has a good selection of exercises, and the BBC's Bite-size video clips help with listening as well as reading and writing. Bite-size question analysis offers good detail for higher level in French and German. Some features on the BBC site, notably "ask a teacher", were not up and running when I was researching this article. The Guardian site also contains all of its previously published Eyewitness texts in French, German, Italian and Spanish since 1999. Tell Me More: Chinese (£99, www.auralog.com), applies advanced techniques to a difficult language. This seemed enticing, but I soon hit snags. The pictures accompanying the early dialogues are chosen to illustrate Chinese culture, and I could see no link between them and the monosyllables I was supposed to reproduce. Sometimes the computer told me I had got an answer right, sometimes wrong, but I had no idea of the meaning of what I was pronouncing, and could see no way to improve my efforts. The language program uses the same film-set format as European languages in this series, and you select the exercises and lessons you want from a menu. This, for me, was at the root of the problem - I had no idea of what to try first, or of how to make sense of the lessons. Auralog has done well even to tackle such potentially rewarding language, but this program needs much clearer instructions on the initial stages - perhaps a "getting started" pamphlet - if its good users are not to turn to bad language.

fields.headline: Somebody to talk to?
fields.standfirst: With the dangers of internet chatrooms at the forefront of debate, Peter Palmer finds that confused teenagers, faced with a new set of rules, often have nowhere to turn for help
fields.trailText: With the dangers of internet chatrooms at the forefront of debate, Peter Palmer finds that confused teenagers, faced with a new set of rules, often have nowhere to turn for help
fields.body:
A growing number of parents are worried about their children when they are on the internet, given the lurid nature of certain teenage chatrooms and the ease with which adults can infiltrate what are supposed to be teenage-only preserves. Most schools run such well-filtered and protected systems that their pupils cannot get anywhere harmful, but at home it's a different story.

Most of the big internet service providers run a "chatroom" system with headings such as sport, business, over-50s or teens. People adopt a user name such as Naughty Angel or Rude Rodent and enter a room with up to 150 other users. A constant babble of typing is going on in the main window where everyone can see and respond to everyone else. Usually the hosts (service providers) supervise the main chatrooms, where they root out bad language or sexy talk and ban offenders. Sadly, though, even here not everything is supervised. You can "whisper" to an individual, ie hold a private conversation with someone in a separate window, and these are uncensored. This is where the real danger lies - it is quite easy for a newcomer to say, for instance, that they are a 16-year-old lad, but in fact turn out to be a 55-year-old paedophile.

In fact, in Microsoft Network (MSN) chatrooms, anyone can be a host and create their own chatroom, which operate under titles such as Hot Teens!, Teens Flirting! and Young Girls Chatting to Older Men. These rooms appear to be unsupervised and the host is responsible for behaviour in the room. You have to apply for membership for chatrooms hosted by service providers, giving your date of birth. Only teens can enter teen sites, and, ironcially, parents and teachers who ought to visit these sites no longer can because of these very restrictions.

So what are they being restricted from? A newcomer cannot fail to notice the striking openness and honesty between respondents - they feel safe in their anonymity so they have no reason to lie. But a worrying aspect is the large number of cries for help. Broken families and moving away from relatives mean kids often have no one to turn to for help. Many do not feel able to go to a teacher, and most do not belong to a church or other religious organisation so have no support there either. School counsellors cannot be trusted as they may tell their problems to the school or parents. Alex, 16, said he will "never trust a counsellor again" after his parents were told of his problems.

What's worse, many teenagers are floundering. A new morality is rearing its head that has its own rules. Many teenagers in these chatrooms take the term "having sex" to mean full, penetrative sex. Any other sexual activity seems acceptable at 12 years old, although most "chatroomers" indulge from 14-15 years. Experimenting with lesbian, or bisexual activity, has also become increasingly common. This is apparently "OK" and, if that is all they have done, the new morality does not believe they have had "sex". There are no feelings of right or wrong; the only test is whether both partners feel happy about it. The results of a survey published recently on the BBC children's website showed that 85% of teens thought "snogging" in a school corridor was "OK".

The worst sin now is "two-timing"; the rule is one boyfriend to one girlfriend. The second worst is not being honest with each other. My research suggests most girl respondents seem to have sex at 15-16 years, usually with an older lad of 18-20, and this is considered normal. Although a girl's partner is usually two to three years older, heterosexual relations are often between girls of 15-17 and men of 22-25 years. Jayne, 17, told me that she has a 35-year-old taxi-driver boyfriend, who is divorced. She said she wanted a more loving and stable relationship than males of her own age could give.

Faced with an upside-down set of values, where do desperate teenagers turn? They often cannot get through to the underfunded ChildLine, and numerous searches for "Teen Help" found no professional sites, although the NSPCC has a one and runs a helpline and email service. The award-winning site, Pupiline, is run by a 16-year-old who was being bullied at school. It has a lot of good information on it, and an email help line.

One of the MSN UK Teen chat rooms has "!!!! Advice Room for Teens" which is staffed by teens. It opens every evening for help and has around 100 visits a week. It also has a site with information on a wide range of topics from eating disorders and abuse to self-harming and pregnancy. There is email support, a discussion notice-board and links to other useful sites. Boy-girl relationships are the commonest problems, but pregnancy, eating disorders, depression, suicidal feelings and "cutting" (self-harm) ones are frequent.

Pressure of exams is increasing, but bullying and abuse rarely arise. The most frightening thing is how many girls report rape. A typical story relates how 15-year-old Gem was at a club flirting with "a guy of 22". They went outside to cool off and kiss. But before she knew it, she was being raped. He did not use a condom. Gem told no one, not even her best friend. She did not know if she was pregnant or infected, and it was weeks before she could even tell someone online. After several online discussions she was persuaded to go to her doctor she was healthy, and not pregnant. Then the adviser asked her if there was an adult she could trust to talk to about it, and she came back a week later to say she had "told her mum who had been great".

Another case was Sarah, 15. She became constantly depressed, ate very little and when she felt low she cut her arms with a razor. Her parents were always arguing, she said. She felt they hated her and she was afraid they may break up. Sarah used to be good at school, but her work began to deteriorate. She needed professional help, but would not tell anyone.

The adviser gave her ChildLine and Samaritan telephone numbers to call, but when she returned to the advice room another day she said that she tried, "but her voice just wouldn't work". She kept coming back to the help room and got understanding, comfort and support. Last week reported that she "hadn't cut herself for two whole weeks!" She emailed her adviser saying: "Thanks very much for all the advice you have given me these past few weeks. I really need to get things sorted."

Ealing Youth Service has a Youth2Youth website and email support service, and has trained young people who run a telephone help line twice a week. Peter Bradley is the clinical supervisor for the Y2Y service which has been running for three years, and has just received a £125,000 lottery grant to expand. He says it aims to supply a "quality listening service" although the demand for advice is so great. The main problems he finds are boy-girl relationships and parent problems, but, surprisingly, not drugs. Depression is a concern; one client has a 54-page dossier.

Advice online can work, and it need not cost too much. Demand is great and it just needs more caring teachers and adults to set up other websites and support lines to meet it.

These findings are based on research by the author in chats with more than 200 young people over four months. All names used have been changed.

peter.palmer@hotmail.co.uk

Further information

 ChildLine 0800 11 11

 NSPCC Kids Zone: 0808 800 5000 and www.nspcc.org.uk

 Ealing Youth Service: Youth2Youth: 020 8896 3675 (every Tues and Thurs, 6.30-9.30pm only); and www.youth2youth.co.uk

 Advice Room for Teens: chat.msn.co.uk

 Teens Chat rooms; !!!! Advice Room for Teens (from 7pm) and HelpRoom for information

 /communities.msn.com/helproom

 Pupiline (especially for bullying): www.pupiline.net

 Superhighway Safety: Safe use of the Internet is a free pack published by the Department for Education and Becta, covering issues such as acceptable use policies and setting up school websites. It also advises on filtering systems, internet monitoring organisations and intellectual property and copyright.

fields.headline: CD-roms
fields.trailText: Kudos | CID 2001 | Exodus | Keyclips V4.1 | Fruity
fields.body:
Kudos

(Cascaid, annual licence £240, cheaper if purchased through local careers service. Demo disc available, see www.cascaid.co.uk)

This enables students to discover which careers suit their abilities and skills. Answering a series of questions produces a personal profile which is matched against a database of nearly 700 careers. From jobs requiring few qualifications to graduate careers, there are details including pay and labour market information. Pictures of people at work can be added for an extra £75, worksheets and teacher notes are £15. Suitable for 13- to 20-year-olds, it is excellent starting point for choosing a career.

CID 2001

(Careersoft, annual licence £140; for demo disc, see www.careersoft.co.uk)

Text, pictures, sound and videos of more than 830 jobs enable students of all ages and abilities to investigate the world of work. Includes a short quiz to help generate job suggestions. Descriptions include extensive links to related websites. The program includes Special CID designed for those with special needs. Add-ons, for which there is an extra charge, include a text-to-speech facility and a localising program for adding own text, videos or pictures.

Exodus

(Careers Europe, annual licence £120; for demo disc available, see www.careerseurope.co.uk)

Information about education, training and employment opportunities in Europe and beyond. There are 492 fact sheets which cover topics such as Hotel Schools in Switzerland, Moving to Indonesia and Student life in Sweden. Searchable by country, job title or key word.

Keyclips V4.1

(Lifetime Careers, annual licence £155; for demo disc,see :marketing@wiltshire.lifetime-careers.co.uk)

Database of 480 multipage Clips leaflets on specific careers, NVQs, help with CVs and applications. A short quiz can be used to suggest leaflets that match personal preferences, or searches can be run by job title, subject or careers library classification Index (CLCI) code.

Fruity

(Highflyers Publishing, £65)

Careers game based around a fruit machine. Good for getting the attention of younger pupils or those not interested in anything to do with careers. Players can choose from Make a Film, Run a Hotel / Newspaper / Supermarket or Organise a Wedding. Provides insight into the different jobs that contribute to each and the importance of teams.
