webTitle: Using the web to search for a career

fields.headline: Click on a future
fields.standfirst: Embarking on your chosen career - at university, college or in the workplace - can feel like entering minefield. But Irene Krechowiecka shows that the web has a lot to offer your search
fields.trailText: Embarking on your chosen career - at university, college or in the workplace - can feel like entering minefield. But Irene Krechowiecka shows that the web has a lot to offer your search
fields.body:
More popular than Britney Spears but just lagging behind Playstation cheats, ucas.com boasts 1.5m hits a week and is one of the most visited education sites on the web. Like other good quality careers information resources, it's revolutionising the way people investigate their future.

Originally designed for researching imminent university applications, the site now carries information that's much more widely applicable. One parent I know was surprised when shown how to check degree course entry requirements at a year nine parents evening: "That seemed a long way into the future, but was really useful and gave my son a realistic idea of what to aim for and which options to choose."

As the number of schools and homes with internet access grows so does the potential for enabling students to be better informed. Andrew Jones, head of the sixth form at Keswick School, has been running an open evening for parents on using the web to help with university choice and applications for a couple of years. "They really value these sessions. Being able to access the same information their children use at school gives them the chance to be involved without interfering."

Some careers services have also exploited the potential of new technologies. Norfolk Careers (www.norfolk-careers.co.uk) uses its site to make a range of resources available to schools and individual users. As well as careers information, training materials, labour market information and ideas for lessons, those maintaining traditional libraries can print pages of address labels for providers of free careers information. However, its information manager, Nigel Turpin, is well aware that the internet does not provide all the answers, and stresses the importance of maintaining a more "traditional" careers library.

"Not everything we have can be made available on the site," he says. "For example, there's little high quality guidance software currently available for free through the web, whereas KUDOS, a CD-rom-based career match program, can be used in all our careers centres.

"Although there are some resources not worth buying because a free website does something very similar, we're conscious that not everyone has home access or fast, reliable connections." Nor are cheap web solutions an alternative to expensive staff. Chris Shingler, Norfolk Career's corporate affairs manager, recognises that however well designed the website it's no substitute for one-to-one guidance.

"Students are now better informed and more able to find what they need using our content and other web resources, but being aware of all the options can mean they need more guidance." Perhaps the worst advice to give is suggesting someone type the word careers in a search engine. The millions of sites that offer such information range from the excellent to the misleading or irrelevant. Services like Norfolk help alleviate this by selecting and checking the links on their site.

A good, regularly updated source of web addresses is BBC Education's Webguide (www.bbc.co.uk/education/webguide) which reviews sites that support careers education. The new NGfL career development site (careers.ngfl.gov.uk) is another useful tool for finding quality information quickly. John Francis, head of multimedia production and publishing at Becta, has a team of moderators who scrutinise resources submitted by publishers and other providers of careers information before they are included on the site. "These practitioners are able to provide an objective view which ensures all material we recommend has immediate practical relevance and is both up to date and accurate. In many cases, links are to specific resources rather than home pages, so it removes searcher frustration."

Manchester University's Careers service (www.netwise.ac.uk) has, in internet terms, a long history of providing web-based resources. It is constantly evaluating the relevance of what it offers to students and is planning some interesting new features such as sending interview tips to students' mobile phones just before the event.

Terry Dray, one of the service's senior managers, sees the site as a very public shop window for their services. "If you're going to use the web you must offer something that's credible. If it's not responsive or updated regularly it won't get used. We've worked at developing a sense of community by inviting regular contributions and responding to them.

"Our student poll, which asks for opinions on topical issues, is popular and engages users. What we put on our site reflects the quality of the service we offer. It's a good way for potential students to evaluate the support they'll get if they join us."

Careers 1: University choice

Peter French is head of sixth form at Cockermouth School, Cumbria, a comprehensive with 1,250 pupils aged 11-18

In the past I used to feel advising sixth formers on university choices was a hit-and-miss affair, but things have changed. Access to much better information - almost all of it internet-based - is behind that change, but we've had to take the time to learn to use it well. There's a confidence among our year 13s that's quite striking.

They're happy with their choices and I'm reassured by how realistic and well informed those have been. We had 95 students applying through the UCAS system this year,and two-thirds had offers before Christmas. I wasn't surprised; the applications were excellent. We start the process of discovery early in year 12. The information they need is available on every computer in school and through their home computers. Many of the intranet resources originally designed for sixth formers are used regularly by pupils from year nine upwards. Course entry information on the UCAS database, for example, is useful for them when choosing their GCSE options. As well as providing easy access to relevant information, we concentrate on giving pupils and staff the tools to deal with it effectively. This includes training sessions on how to get the best out of the web. The tutorial staff work closely with our career adviser on this - it's certainly not a case of just giving pupils a list of websites. Wonderful though this bountiful supply of information is, we couldn't manage without human guidance to make sense of it all.

Careers 2: Email careers guidance

Will Ritchie is a careers adviser for Grampian Careers, a private company (ex-local authority) covering about 45 secondary schools, plus several colleges and special schools in the Grampian region

About nine months ago my job changed significantly when I became an online careers adviser. As part of a small team I concentrate on delivering guidance by email in a service available to people of all ages. It complements a wide range of enabling and self-help resources on our website. It's an effective way of meeting the varied needs of individual clients.

The work uses the same skills as face-to-face guidance, but not being able to see the person you're advising does create new challenges. Without visual clues, writing and questioning take on a higher level of importance. It's possible to develop a really constructive relationship with someone in this way, as the dialogue often goes on for quite a while - however long it takes to resolve their problem.

The "talk back" feature on our site - a series of moderated discussion boards - gives registered users a chance to discuss career concerns, share experiences and get help from our staff. We have active boards on subject choice for standard grade courses and a general career choice board.

All areas of our website are well used. The freedom to do substantial research first means users are able to get the most from individual guidance sessions.

www.grampiancareers.com

Career do's and don't's

Do...

 Check anything you use at home also works at school. Some sites could be filtered, fail to run on a network or need a plug-in that's not available.

 Suggest paths through websites you're recommending to students. Help them get where they want quickly by highlighting relevant sections.

 Consider making PowerPoint presentations to demonstrate the potential of a website. This overcomes the problem of slow or temporarily unavailable sites and provides ready-made handouts.

 Make sure students have email access to benefit from the further help, alerts and newsletters that are widely available.

 Produce worksheets that encourage documentation of research. Students find it all too easy to spend hours looking at excellent information, then forget where it was or what it said. Put these on your intranet.

 Provide a session for parents showing what's available. If they can access your resources from home or school, they can support their children's research.

 Ensure human guidance is available to help students make sense of the information they're gathering.

 Look at Becta's new resource, Connecting Careers and ICT. This free publication and related support material, including ideas for careers lesson using ICT, is available on www.becta.org. uk/careersict

Don't...

 Expect all websites to look the same as the last time you used them because many are being constantly updated.

 Overlook the potential of your "ordinary" software. A dedicated CV package may benefit your students lessthan using a word-processor to create their own CV.

 Overwhelm with long lists of sites, but rather show how to use a select few well. Encourage students to add to these by reviewing sites they've found useful.

 Renew annual subscriptions to CD-based programs without first checking whether there is something similar available free on the web. Ask for demonstration copies of software before buying.

Career websites

UCAS
www.ucas.com

Database of all higher education courses that can be applied for through UCAS, all Access courses for mature students, and further education courses in some cities. Searches can be done by subject, location or institution. Matches show brief details such as entry requirements and type of course. Institutional information includes details of accommodation costs and open days as well as providing web and email links. A growing number of institutions provide entry profiles - detailed information on selection, content and career outcomes for specific courses. The advice section includes links to Curriculum 2000 statements for all institutions.

Prospects Web
www.prospects.ac.uk

Take a couple of days exploring this one as it's packed with excellent information, interactive tools and vacancies -and keeps on growing. Primarily for undergraduates, it's an invaluable resource for students of any age aiming for a graduate career. Use it to check what you can do with any degree, to find statistical information on the destination of last year's graduates, and to track down a job or postgraduate course. It also includes detailed profiles on hundreds of graduate occupations and employers. Check out Quickmatch for help with finding careers to match your strengths and interests.

Citizens First
citizens.eu.int

One of the best information sources on work, study, job- seeking, comparability and recognition of qualifications across Europe. Choose the country you're in, then the country you want to go to.

BBC Essentials
www.bbc.co.uk/essentials

Everything you need to know about work, study, travel, money and life in general. fields.bodyText: More popular than Britney Spears but just lagging behind Playstation cheats, ucas.com boasts 1.5m hits a week and is one of the most visited education sites on the web. Like other good quality careers information resources, it's revolutionising the way people investigate their future. Originally designed for researching imminent university applications, the site now carries information that's much more widely applicable. One parent I know was surprised when shown how to check degree course entry requirements at a year nine parents evening: "That seemed a long way into the future, but was really useful and gave my son a realistic idea of what to aim for and which options to choose." As the number of schools and homes with internet access grows so does the potential for enabling students to be better informed. Andrew Jones, head of the sixth form at Keswick School, has been running an open evening for parents on using the web to help with university choice and applications for a couple of years. "They really value these sessions. Being able to access the same information their children use at school gives them the chance to be involved without interfering." Some careers services have also exploited the potential of new technologies. Norfolk Careers (www.norfolk-careers.co.uk) uses its site to make a range of resources available to schools and individual users. As well as careers information, training materials, labour market information and ideas for lessons, those maintaining traditional libraries can print pages of address labels for providers of free careers information. However, its information manager, Nigel Turpin, is well aware that the internet does not provide all the answers, and stresses the importance of maintaining a more "traditional" careers library. "Not everything we have can be made available on the site," he says. "For example, there's little high quality guidance software currently available for free through the web, whereas KUDOS, a CD-rom-based career match program, can be used in all our careers centres. "Although there are some resources not worth buying because a free website does something very similar, we're conscious that not everyone has home access or fast, reliable connections." Nor are cheap web solutions an alternative to expensive staff. Chris Shingler, Norfolk Career's corporate affairs manager, recognises that however well designed the website it's no substitute for one-to-one guidance. "Students are now better informed and more able to find what they need using our content and other web resources, but being aware of all the options can mean they need more guidance." Perhaps the worst advice to give is suggesting someone type the word careers in a search engine. The millions of sites that offer such information range from the excellent to the misleading or irrelevant. Services like Norfolk help alleviate this by selecting and checking the links on their site. A good, regularly updated source of web addresses is BBC Education's Webguide (www.bbc.co.uk/education/webguide) which reviews sites that support careers education. The new NGfL career development site (careers.ngfl.gov.uk) is another useful tool for finding quality information quickly. John Francis, head of multimedia production and publishing at Becta, has a team of moderators who scrutinise resources submitted by publishers and other providers of careers information before they are included on the site. "These practitioners are able to provide an objective view which ensures all material we recommend has immediate practical relevance and is both up to date and accurate. In many cases, links are to specific resources rather than home pages, so it removes searcher frustration." Manchester University's Careers service (www.netwise.ac.uk) has, in internet terms, a long history of providing web-based resources. It is constantly evaluating the relevance of what it offers to students and is planning some interesting new features such as sending interview tips to students' mobile phones just before the event. Terry Dray, one of the service's senior managers, sees the site as a very public shop window for their services. "If you're going to use the web you must offer something that's credible. If it's not responsive or updated regularly it won't get used. We've worked at developing a sense of community by inviting regular contributions and responding to them. "Our student poll, which asks for opinions on topical issues, is popular and engages users. What we put on our site reflects the quality of the service we offer. It's a good way for potential students to evaluate the support they'll get if they join us." Careers 1: University choice Peter French is head of sixth form at Cockermouth School, Cumbria, a comprehensive with 1,250 pupils aged 11-18 In the past I used to feel advising sixth formers on university choices was a hit-and-miss affair, but things have changed. Access to much better information - almost all of it internet-based - is behind that change, but we've had to take the time to learn to use it well. There's a confidence among our year 13s that's quite striking. They're happy with their choices and I'm reassured by how realistic and well informed those have been. We had 95 students applying through the UCAS system this year,and two-thirds had offers before Christmas. I wasn't surprised; the applications were excellent. We start the process of discovery early in year 12. The information they need is available on every computer in school and through their home computers. Many of the intranet resources originally designed for sixth formers are used regularly by pupils from year nine upwards. Course entry information on the UCAS database, for example, is useful for them when choosing their GCSE options. As well as providing easy access to relevant information, we concentrate on giving pupils and staff the tools to deal with it effectively. This includes training sessions on how to get the best out of the web. The tutorial staff work closely with our career adviser on this - it's certainly not a case of just giving pupils a list of websites. Wonderful though this bountiful supply of information is, we couldn't manage without human guidance to make sense of it all. Careers 2: Email careers guidance Will Ritchie is a careers adviser for Grampian Careers, a private company (ex-local authority) covering about 45 secondary schools, plus several colleges and special schools in the Grampian region About nine months ago my job changed significantly when I became an online careers adviser. As part of a small team I concentrate on delivering guidance by email in a service available to people of all ages. It complements a wide range of enabling and self-help resources on our website. It's an effective way of meeting the varied needs of individual clients. The work uses the same skills as face-to-face guidance, but not being able to see the person you're advising does create new challenges. Without visual clues, writing and questioning take on a higher level of importance. It's possible to develop a really constructive relationship with someone in this way, as the dialogue often goes on for quite a while - however long it takes to resolve their problem. The "talk back" feature on our site - a series of moderated discussion boards - gives registered users a chance to discuss career concerns, share experiences and get help from our staff. We have active boards on subject choice for standard grade courses and a general career choice board. All areas of our website are well used. The freedom to do substantial research first means users are able to get the most from individual guidance sessions. www.grampiancareers.com Career do's and don't's Do...  Check anything you use at home also works at school. Some sites could be filtered, fail to run on a network or need a plug-in that's not available.  Suggest paths through websites you're recommending to students. fields.headline: CVs: The power of presentation
fields.standfirst: David White is assistant headteacher at The City School, Sheffield, a comprehensive with 1,300 pupils
fields.trailText: David White is assistant headteacher at The City School, Sheffield, a comprehensive with 1,300 pupils
fields.body:
I'm keen on developing innovative ways of using generic programs for careers education. Word, PowerPoint, Front Page and Publisher have a lot to offer that's often overlooked. There's real value in showing youngsters how to fully exploit the potential of software commonly used in the workplace and which they often have easy access to at home.

Our year 10 pupils, for example, produce CVs and applications for their work experience placement using Word or Publisher. Doing this using pen and paper rarely caught the imagination of less able pupils, as attractive presentation was often not their strong point. But being able to produce something about themselves that looks good does a lot for self-confidence.

Creating presentations on themselves with PowerPoint or making business cards using Publisher is done with lots of enthusiasm. We've got students producing personal web pages, currently only for use on our intranet, but this is something they'll be able to develop to promote themselves to employers in future. We deliver all this through English, Guidance or ICT lessons with support from Clare Ward, our careers co-ordinator.

We're providing additional work experience for students which gives them the opportunity to use these skills. Some are helping our staff transform normal lessons into ICT-based resources while others have been visiting feeder primary schools to work with pupils and teachers on using computers in the classroom.

The biggest difference, compared with our pre-ICT days, is the level of motivation. Students will happily stay after school or carry on at home. It raises awareness of what's required by employers and removes many of the barriers that previously prevented them communicating these effectively.

webTitle: School prizes for the best website

fields.headline: School prizes for the best website
fields.trailText: trail
fields.body:
School and college website designers have only until the end of term to get their entries in for the 2001 Becta/Guardian School and College Website Awards.

The deadline is Friday April 13. Individual pages submitted for entry, or a significant proportion of whole websites, should have been created between May 1, 2000, and April 13, 2001.

In this, the competition's third year, schools and colleges are again being invited to try for substantial hard- and software prizes provided by the sponsors NTL, RM, Research Machines ICL and Granada Learning.

Please note that websites entering the Web Nose Day Award category must have been "live" during the week after Red Nose Day (March 16, 2001) . Entries to this category need to show creativity, group work and community involvement, illustrate both the serious and the fun side of Comic Relief and demonstrate any fund-raising activities related to Red Nose Day .

The other three award categories are: the School/ College Award for whole websites showing an awareness of community and accessibility to all; the Learners' Award, which showcases pupils' work; and the Teaching Resources Award, which carries innovative teaching and learning materials that are part of a website or individual pages.

To enter and find out about previous winning entries, look up www.becta.org.uk/websiteawards to register your interest. There are five categories in all: email queries should be sent to: Webawards@becta.org.uk

webTitle: Websites that can be accessed from the National Grid for Learning

fields.headline: From museums to outer space
fields.standfirst: There's a whole new range of websites you can access from the National Grid for Learning, says Stephen Hoare
fields.trailText: There's a whole new range of websites you can access from the National Grid for Learning, says Stephen Hoare
fields.body:
Special needs included

Teachers searching for elusive special needs resources can take heart. Becta is relaunching its inclusion website with a database of around 1,000 items - many of them newly selected. This should be operational at this week's Education Show in Birmingham, says Becta's head of special needs and inclusion, Chris Stevens.

Following a user survey, Becta has redesigned its search engine. In one click a drop-down menu selects a list of suitable items; a second click allows teachers to order. Magic. Web address: inclusion.ngfl.gov.uk

New links

Media and e-commerce made their debut on the grid at last January's ICT in education show, Bett 2001. Click on the media button and you are directed to a range of educational sites, from BBC Online's news from around the world and Channel 4's educational resources for teachers to the Guardian's education site, theguardian.com/education. Gathered from the grid's Virtual Teachers' Centre, the e-commerce sites include those of educational suppliers such as Anglia Campus, Espresso and Eduweb. The improved portal design should ease navigation. Som of the latest editions include: Regional and Community, a series of regional learning directories; Favourite Sites; and a user- friendly registration form for newcomers. www.ngfl.gov.uk

Virtual museums

Fans of Channel 4's The 1940s House can access it direct from the grid via a weblink. The Imperial War Museum is hosting an exhibition to go with the series. This is one of more than 70 new sites added to the portal since January to cover museums and art galleries, libraries and archives and community grids. The 24 Hour Museum provides up-to-the-minute details on all UK museums and heritage attractions.

Or you can pay a virtual visit to the British Museum and the V&A. Other online attractions include the British Film Institute education service; Bradford Libraries community history project, Reader2Reader; and a site developed by Tyne and Wear archive service, Westall's War - an account of German second world war bombing raids on Newcastle.

New favourites

The host of the grid's new section, Favourite Sites, is Hattie Hayridge aka Holly the blonde computer face of the BBC comedy series Red Dwarf. Hayridge is directing educationally minded surfers to the Hubble Telescope web link. "I've obviously travelled around in space. It's great to click on the Hubble Telescope, and have a look around and see what I'm missing while I'm here on Earth," she says.

Hattie's other faves are no less interesting or educational. Africam Today shows updated film from a game reserve and the chance to go on virtual safari while Latin News is exactly what it says it is - the news read in Latin!

Keeping up to date

Lifelong learners, teachers, parents and young people can now get a quick update on the latest sites from the NGfL's user-friendly content guide, What's New?

Push the parent button and you will see sites that support children's learning; push the child button and children can summon up online help with their homework. Teachers can keep up- to-date with the latest resources and adult learners can check out suitable online material. Among events being flagged up is a conference on the Classroom of the Future.

Fun with words

A new link is the National Literacy Trust's Reading Is Fundamental website. It aims to stress the fun element of reading for both children and parents. Get your children to go to the Word Fun section for a host of activities about books and reading. There are interviews with authors and illustrators, book reviews, competitions and an online story by teen author Rosie Rushton, where children can vote on the outcome. The site has top tips for adults on helping them with reading, and a links section recommends reading and book- related sites. www.rif.org.uk

fields.headline: 'Revolutionary' learning disability white paper launched
fields.trailText: The government has promised "a revolution in care" for people with learning disabilities, with the launch of the first white paper of its kind in 30 years.
fields.body:
The government has promised "a revolution in care" for people with learning disabilities, with the launch of the first white paper of its kind in 30 years.

Community care, improved day services, social inclusion and a greater say for people with learning disabilities are key elements.

Remaining long-stay hospitals are to close, a five-year programme will be set in train to modernise council day services and people will be able to buy their own services under an extension of the "direct payments" scheme.

The strategy will be backed by a new £100m learning disability development fund, £6m to develop advocacy services and £2m for research.

The white paper, Valuing People: A New Strategy for Learning Disability for the 21st Century, outlines four "key principles": civil rights, inclusion, independence and choice.

People with learning disabilities will be able to choose and purchase their care, rather than receiving services determined by their local councils. Advocacy services are also to be boosted.

Launching the proposals, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, said: "A revolution in care is needed to increase opportunities for thousands of people, their carers and families. Alongside better services, there will be a new drive to improve education and employment opportunities."

Other plans include a national forum for people with learning disabilities, a national learning disability information centre and helpline with charity Mencap, a learning disability task force, a national citizen advocacy network and national service objectives, underpinned by new targets and performance indicators.

Specialist local services for people with severe challenging behaviour, integrated services for children with severe disabilities and individual health plans are also to be developed.

Nearly 1.5m people in England have learning disabilities. Of those, 210,000 have severe disabilities, and are long-term health and social services users. Around 1.2m are intermittent users of social care and health services.

Learning disabilities organisations welcomed the proposals. Dr John Harris, chief executive of the British Institute of Learning Disabilities (BILD), applauded the white paper as a "bold blueprint for celebrating diversity".

He said the paper "sets out an ambitious agenda to deliver services that will guarantee people with a learning disability rights, social inclusion, choice and independence".

Simon Cramp, a Mencap trustee with a learning disability, said: "At last the government is putting individual choice at the heart of learning disability services. We want to make our own choices.

"We want the opportunities and all the basic services so that we can live the life that non-disabled people take for granted."

Su Sayer, chief executive of charity United Response, said: "It is time for society to move on from treating people with learning difficulties as if they were unable to work, to participate in everyday activities and have full rights as citizens."

Mr Milburn promised that the white paper would look at people's lifelong needs and would have cross-government backing.

But BILD's Dr Harris warned: "The big question is whether such an ambitious programme, involving unprecedented collaboration between and across agencies at all levels and over a sustained period of time can deliver the goods."

The government also announced a £25m education package to identify and tackle learning difficulties in young children, and a working group to develop practical guidance on identifying special educational needs (SEN) in children under two.

The package includes £11m to train early years and child care SEN specialists, including up to 850 area specialists who will be working in every registered early years and child care setting by 2004; £3m to set up a regional network of SEN experts to work with local authorities; and £11m to fund services to help young children with SEN.

webTitle: We will negotiate, say Macedonian Albanians

fields.headline: We will negotiate, say Macedonian Albanians
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Ethnic Albanian rebels battling for greater rights in Macedonia said today they were willing to negotiate a peaceful settlement to their week-old insurgency, but warned the country's government to respond or the fighting would continue.
fields.body:
Ethnic Albanian rebels battling for greater rights in Macedonia said today they were willing to negotiate a peaceful settlement to their week-old insurgency, but warned the country's government to respond or the fighting would continue.

"We are determined to realise our demands, and urge Macedonian authorities and non-government figures to make public as soon as possible if they want this to be resolved peacefully or not," the rebels said in a communiqu obtained by the Associated Press.

"Macedonia's ignorant view and hypocritical disrespect of the Albanian demands and patience has surpassed all limits," it said. "We urge the international community to recognise our demands which are for peace, not for war."

The statement, signed simply "National Liberation Army - Tetovo branch," ended with a warning that if talks were rejected, "we will bear no responsibility for the future chain of events."

Although there was scattered shooting and limited shelling overnight in Macedonia's second largest city, Tetevo, there were only periodic explosions today and no clear sign of rebel presence. Reflecting the relative calm, buses resumed running and people took to the streets.

Since the fighting began one week ago, more than 2,300 ethnic Albanians have crossed the border to Albania - a tenfold increase from the usual number of crossings - said Kris Janowski of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees.

The Slav-led Macedonian government did not immediately react to the rebels' statement. But officials repeatedly have said they have no intention of negotiating with the rebels whom they have branded as "terrorists."

Earlier today the Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, said "there will be no negotiations," and accused the rebels of "ethnic extremism" that threatened to undermine the stability of the Balkans.

"Ethnic extremism is the beginning of the end of peace in the entire region," Mr Trajkovski said in a sombre appearance in the Macedonian capital, Skopje. He declared his forces "strong enough and determined to halt the terrorists and defend the country."

Ethnic Albanians account for at least a quarter of Macedonia's 2m people, and although ethnic relations in Slav-dominated Macedonia have been relatively trouble free, substantial numbers of the minority feel they are being treated as second-class citizens.

"Our people have for decades been insulted, discriminated against and banned from all civilisation traditions in Macedonia. These are the main reasons that forced the Albanians to take up weapons and fight for their rights," today's communiqu said.

Slavic officers defending Tetovo dismissed the insurgents' predictions of victory and said they'll fight to the end to defend the country's borders.

fields.headline: Man with a mission
fields.standfirst: As an election looms, Rebecca Smithers quizzes Michael Wills, the minister in charge of technology, and looks at other parties' policies
fields.trailText: As an election looms, Rebecca Smithers quizzes Michael Wills, the minister in charge of technology, and looks at other parties' policies.
fields.body:
It is now 18 months since Michael Wills was appointed the first ever minister for learning and technology, charged with the task of putting new technology at the heart of education policy.

Even the extra responsibilities he has picked up, which he describes as Tony Blair's so-called "minister for Britain", appear not to have dimmed his enthusiasm.

"We've done a lot but there is so much more to do," he said, presumably wondering how many more policy announcements he can slip out of the Department for Education and Employment before the election.

He is the first to admit that when he arrived at the DfEE, information communications technology seemed "remote and detached from mainstream education". But now he believes it is "an integral part" of the reforms that David Blunkett and his team are implementing.

On the schools front, Wills has made it a priority to get out and about and talk to heads, teachers and governors, with major feedback from 15 regional road shows over the past 12 months. "Virtually every initiative I've announced has been the result of talking to teachers at the road shows and through constant dialogue with the profession," he explains. "Technology is a fast-moving field and we don*t necessarily have all the answers."

A speech in January at the annual ICT in education BETT conference was littered with new policy announcements including completion of the first stage of the "ICT revolution in schools", that is, securing the investment to fund basic equipment for all schools throughout England.

The next phase will be the delivery of high quality training for teachers to ensure that schools make the most of what they have. Half the teaching profession has apparently been signed up for training with 60 approved providers, financed by the New Opportunities Fund.

The two stages will eventually come together to provide a virtually unrecognisable "classroom of the future" for the benefit of entire learning communities beyond the traditional school age group. Blackboards, and even whiteboards, will be relegated to history and video conferencing will allow lessons to be taught by "virtual" teachers. Of course, there is the looming distraction of the election, although ICT itself is unlikely tofigure highly.

In the forthcoming campaign Labour is likely to hold up ICT as a means of increasing standards in education and as a learning tool for everyone. The need to end the "digital divide", whereby those who are socially and educationally disadvantaged by poor literacy or numeracy are further alienated by lack of access to technology, will also be put forward by David Blunkett.

"It all boils down to equality," explains Wills. "It is down to the government to ensure that the new technological opportunities are available to all."

In anticipation of the poll, Michael Wills has produced a 34-page pamphlet in which he argues the important role ICT is playing in raising standards in schools and creating new opportunities. In it, he accuses the Tories of displaying "a blithe indifference ... verging on hostility" to the ICT revolution. As Wills points out, the internet is hardly mentioned in their core policy document, Believing in Britain, and they are committed to abolishing the Standards Fund which finances the National Grid for Learning.

"The only reference in Believing in Britain to ICT in education and training is one which promises rather vaguely to 'allow more flexibility'," he says.

Two main goals underlie all Labour's policies on ICT, says Wills. The first is that every child should leave school fully capable of using new technology as 90% of jobs involve some sort of interaction with ICT.

The second is to use ICT in the classroom to help drive up standards. Wills welcomes new evidence from the British Educational Communications and Technology Agency ), showing clearly that ICT raises standards in the classroom.

The government's generosity in terms of offering subsidised computers to teachers was hit by a glitch, when the first phase of the computers for teachers scheme ran into problems because of the tax implications. But the demand was enormous leading to 28,492 applications. Of these, 28,116 succeeded while 376 either withdrew from the programme or did not meet the criteria. The second phase was launched in January, this time open to maths teachers who teach at key stage three.

Transformation of ICT infrastructure in schools has, on paper at the very least, been impressive. In 1996 only 5% of primary schools had internet access, now it's 90% - along with virtually all secondary schools. Wills says this is "an incredible achievement, given the dire situation we inherited when we came to power," pledging that "by 2002 every school in the country will be on-line."

But the pace of further change depends not just on the capabilities of the kit, but also the enthusiasm of those using it. So until now schools have edged along at different rates, some being given a massive push by an enthusiastic ICT coordinator, others held back by a cautious, luddite headteacher.

Schools still worry about how they can finance replacement of existing computer equipment without a continued rolling programme of funding. Even the small amounts of extra cash for heads announced in the Budget are, in most cases, likely to be spent on more pressing requirements.

Some teachers also fear the training material presented to them by NOF providers is not of high enough quality. Money is not available to release staff for training and teachers are expected to complete training in their own time. Connectivity, too, is a national issue. It is catered for in the standards fund but is not always taken up by local education authorities due to financial difficulties. To use the net as an efficient and effective tool, high-speed broadband connectivity is essential but not always affordable by the average school.

Wills hopes all these issues will be addressed in various ways. A procurement advisory service, for example, is to be launched as a two-year pilot to advise and help on choosing kit, as well as after-sales support. But he is only too aware of the problems in an areawhich attracts high expectations. "At the end of the day technology is a powerful tool for teachers," he says, "but it's not a magic bullet."

The Conservatives

 Expand cross-curricular use of ICT, with a better marriage between good teaching practice and ICT.
 Give teachers greater confidence in the use of ICT. As part of their "free schools" policy, for example, schools would be able to employ non-teaching ICT professionals.
 Encourage schools to adopt an applications-based, rather than an acquisitions-based, approach, towards ICT.
 Scrap the Standards Fund which finances the National Grid for Learning, but build on the best of the grid.

The Liberal Democrats

 Improve ICT support for teachers by establishing educational charitable trusts to arrange the lease of equipment and services so that teachers and heads can dedicate more time and resources to teaching rather than the buying and maintainance of computer equipment. This plan will further build on the recently established e-learning foundations.
 Through the general proposals to spend an additional £3bn over and above existing spending levels on education, the Liberal Democrats will also increase funding for ICT equipment purchase and maintainance and ICT training for teachers within schools.

webTitle: Overcoming the language barrier in Wales

fields.headline: Overcoming the language barrier in Wales
fields.standfirst: The lack of Welsh speakers in health and social care is having a serious impact on the quality of service delivery. Maggie Murray reports
fields.trailText: The lack of Welsh speakers in health and social care is having a serious impact on the quality of service delivery. Maggie Murray reports.
fields.body:
Welsh speakers in Wales who need health or social services may find that their treatment is delivered in a foreign language - English.

For the autistic Welsh-speaking child who needs speech therapy or the elderly stroke victim who reverts to the mother tongue, there are long-term consequences when services are not delivered in the users' first language, according to experts in the field.

"This isn't just a debating point but something that has a real impact on the lives of those who use social or health care in Wales," says Dr Dai Lloyd, Plaid Cymru assembly member for health and social services.

"There are not enough Welsh speakers in health and social care in Wales. In Swansea, where I work part-time as a GP, there are no Welsh-speaking speech therapists and so the therapy has to be given in English, which is completely unsatisfactory. I know, as a health professional, that a better diagnosis can be obtained when you communicate with someone in their first language," says Dr Lloyd.

Gwenan Llwyd-Evans, of the Wales Language Board, says that, under the provisions of the Welsh Language Act of 1993, the public sector in Wales has a duty to treat Welsh and English on an equal basis when providing services to the public in Wales.

The board has put forward a series of recommendations to the Welsh assembly aimed at improving the problems faced by Welsh speakers, including:

 Asking for funding criteria which would require grant applicants to include in their proposals how they intend to provide for the needs of Welsh speakers.
 Commissioning service reviews, inspections, advice and research, including bilingual service delivery, and language and care issues as standard practice in briefs and methodologies and in performance-reporting frameworks.
 Making sure there is regular liaison with training providers and accreditors so that language and care issues are integrated into college and work-based training. .
 Analysing language use in the health service in Wales, and stimulating serious shortfalls through co-ordinated recruitment and training initiatives.

A Wales consumer council report published last year, Welsh in the Health Service, says there are four key groups who have been experiencing difficulties.

The first is people with mental health problems. The report says: "Since the aim of any mental health care is to restore the normal balance of the mind, the Welsh language cannot be ignored as a factor if it forms a significant part of the normal life and thought processes of any patient".

The second area is learning disabilities or special needs. "There is significant anecdotal evidence that Welsh speakers with learning disabilities do respond better to stimulus in their first language," according to the report.

The elderly and young children are the other groups identified. "Elderly people may suffer genuine distress and confusion when obliged by illness or frailty to move from their normal Welsh-speaking environment," says the report. It also points out that children who are most likely to be monolingual users of services are particularly affected by the lack of Welsh-speaking practitioners.

"Like any of us, if we are talking about something that is intimate. We want to be able to talk freely in the language that we feel most comfortable in and this is something I was very aware of when I was working with Childline Cymru," says Peter Clarke, the children's commissioner for Wales.

"In the future, my office will be looking at issues that affect Welsh-speaking children who are not able to access services in their own language. Major service providers have to ask themselves how responsive their service really is if they are not providing services in the language of the child's choice."

Ann Owen, who heads the community practitioners and health visitors association in Wales, has a background of working as a health visitor for 15 years in north-west Wales where the caseload was 60 to 80% Welsh speaking, and has seen the problems at first hand.

She says: "In many parts of Wales, provision in Welsh is inadequate. Trying to carry out a developmental assessment on a three-year-old without the appropriate language skills, for example, is impossible. How can you pick up on something like abuse when you are dealing with vulnerable children under stress and establish a relationship of trust, where there is no meaningful communication? These are real issues that are affecting those who use the services."

She added: "There is a general recruitment crisis in social care staff here and this means that it is very difficult to fill posts with people who can speak the language. The problem is not just in the predominately in the areas where there is a lot of Welsh spoken - it can be just as much of an issue in a city like Cardiff.

"Although there is a shortage of staff, social work training in Wales has a philosophy of trying to normalise bilingual professional practice and the training programmes reflect that in a way which is not apparent in the health service."

According to data from the central council for education and training in social work (CCETSW), 15% of social services staff in local in Wales are Welsh speakers. The figure varies between 96% in Gwynedd, whose population is predominately Welsh speaking, to 0.7% in the industrial south in Rhondda Cynon Taf.

"All the training programmes that are validated by us must show policies that promote and increase learning opportunities in Welsh and an understanding of language sensitivity relevant to social work practice" says Rhian Huws Williams, head of CCETSW in Wales.

fields.headline: Express writers opt for redundancy
fields.trailText:
5pm: At least two senior journalists on the Daily Express newsdesk are believed to have held redundancy talks, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 20: Express rivals angry at new signing
Celebrity stalker: Jason Fraser profile

Mar 19: Catchpole quits Mirror for Express

Mar 19: NUJ calls for Express action
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
At least two senior journalists on the Daily Express newsdesk are believed to have held talks with the paper's management about voluntary redundancy.

Head of news Sean Rayment and at least one other senior staff member have spoken to managers about what is being dubbed "fast track" redundancy - which would allow them to leave before the compulsory 90-day consultation period.

It is understood Mr Rayment, a former Daily Mail staffer, has been urged to reconsider by managers at the paper, who consider him too valuable to allow him to leave.

Any departures at the heart of the newspaper's planning operations will come as a blow to management.

But it is believed the redundancies are the tip of the iceberg, and that tens of other journalists are likely to volunteer for "fast-track" redundancy.

The news will dismay the NUJ, which has made clear it believes journalists on the paper need to stick together to resist cuts.

At a union meeting last week in the Express Newspapers' canteen, NUJ national newspaper organiser Jeremy Dear called for journalists to hold fire on redundancy as long as possible to preserve solidarity with those journalists who had to stay at the paper.

But many staff at the paper believe the union is powerless to prevent a massive reduction in the number of journalists.

fields.headline: Anyone share my chocolate?
fields.standfirst: Rosie Walford finds two schools, continents apart, but linked up by the net and a bond common to all children
fields.trailText: Rosie Walford finds two schools, continents apart, but linked up by the net and a bond common to all children
fields.body:
In an open concrete school building, a cluster of Ghanaian children in yellow uniforms place their drawings on a scanner, and falteringly double-click. Several thousand miles away in a Cambridge computer room, year eight will elaborate those same maps of an African village with captions for the web. They will also send back chatty emails about pizza and Boyzone.

For one year, the British and African classes are being linked by internet in a project connected with Comic Relief Web Nose Day last Friday. Effiduase School doesn't have a phone line, but this is no obstacle to its determined link coordinator, Nurrudin Boateng. He downloads on a laptop in town, then lugs a computer, projector and scanner to the barebones school. The children exchange everyday lives- such as how Valentine's Day is being celebrated locally, or the topography of wildly dissimilar environments on the journey to school. British children describe sweet shops; their Ghanaian contemporaries send video footage of men with machetes, and poorer children selling plantain from boxes on their heads.

When the mails arrive, unexpected debates start up in the Cambridge classroom - why are the Ghanaian children so vocal about God? Do they really collect water before breakfast? Geography comes to life.

But the link goes beyond the artifice of cyberconnection, well beyond geography and ICT: the Cambridge children are avid chocolate lovers, while the Effiduase community are cocoa producers. The Ghanaian children's parents grow cocoa for the Fair Trade brand Dubble, which British children can find (or request) at their local shops. The ICT link bears living testimony to this global interconnection via the "chocolate chain" - and for teachers at Parkside, it has proved a popular way to enliven lessons.

In PHSE it has provided a natural context to discuss "choices about spending money". The Cambridge pupils quickly saw how by choosing Dubble, which pays fair prices for its cocoa, they individually could affect the fortunes of communities in Ghana. Their imaginations were inflamed enough to practise national curriculum rubrics of "confidence and responsibility" and "playing an active role as a citizen" - they went to lobby local supermarkets about stocking more fair trade brands.

"Even percentages become interesting when taught in terms of cocoa, milk and sugar proportions," said one Parkside teacher. "These and other cross-curriculum ideas came free and ready-made in 'Pa Pa Paa', a Fair Trade lessons pack from Comic Relief, who launched Dubble to promote teen awareness of Fair Trade."

In art, the Cambridge children have used insights about the farming lives of their e-pen friends to design posters about Dubble and Fair Trade.

"In drama, we took details from the Effiduase children's mails as starting points for scripting TV 'ads' about fair trade," Susanna, 13, explained. "We were shocked to hear that our pen pals had never eaten chocolate - one bar costs a month's cocoa farming earnings, at least." Personal contact, via the ICT link, has clearly brought a compelling sense of reality to the classroom. "Children really focus, act maturely, when we work around the Ghana link," says the schools' head of humanities and link coordinator, Jacqueline Billings. In the words of 12-year-old Felix: "It makes you feel you are doing something useful at school."

And they are. For this particular link also plays its part in the real-life promotion of Fair Trade. Nuruddin sends letters, maps and digital video. Parkside, being a media specialist school, has lavish edit facilities to cut the most telling material into a succinct form. Among interactive games set in the "Chocolate Chain", and teacher's downloads linking fair trade chocolate into curricula for key stages 2 and 3, the evolving interaction between Parkside and Effiduase is posted on www.Dubble.co.uk in a section called "Dubble Lives".

Without the extra effort of building their own school links, teachers anywhere can tap into the action by visiting the Dubble site. They'll be watching a new relationship between two schools grow, and Billings believes the month-by-month progression of Dubble Lives, as well as its adaptability across the curriculum, should help the concept stick in classrooms everywhere, as it has in her own.

Observing another school's link is certainly an easy win. The British Council's Central Bureau for International Education Training can help interested teachers set up links in developing countries; it will even fund technical training and connection costs. But it still takes considerable teacher time to establish objectives and joint project ideas, then a continuing effort to carry it off.

For the class in Ghana, the significance of this - or any - website is still a little mystifying. But a health-improving latrine has just opened in the village funded by the premium from fair trade cocoa sales. The chocolate connection is very real.

"It's wild to think that I'm on a website whose address is on the back of a bar of chocolate,' says Gemma, 12, from the edit suite. "Apart from feeling famous, I like to think that what we're doing is making a difference, getting people to buy Dubble and other things that are Fair Trade."

l For other teacher resources and communications technology: www.becta.org.uk/international, www.unesco.org/education/e_learning

Comic Relief and Day Chocolate Company launched Dubble in October 2000 as a vehicle to promote Fair trade, a long-term solution to poverty. It's the only fair trade product targeted at schoolchildren. The smooth milk chocolate crispy crunch is available in Tesco, Waitrose, Safeway, Sainsbury, Co-op, Asda, Blockbuster and wholefoodshops. Teachers can get a free lesson pack by contacting Comic Relief on 0207-820 5555.

Free primary and secondary teaching packs on Fair Trade and chocolate are available from Comic Relief. Each has full colour pull-out pictures, stories, pupil sheets and teacher information and comes in the shape of a huge chocolate bar! To order send your name, address, teaching position, tel. and email address to: Comic Relief's PaPaPaa, Education Direct, PO Box 105, Rochester, ME2 4BE Or log on to www.Dubble.co.uk

webTitle: Galbraith to retire at next election

fields.headline: Galbraith to retire at next election
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The Scottish environment minister, Sam Galbraith, today announced he was to resign from politics at the next election due to ill health.
fields.body:
The Scottish environment minister, Sam Galbraith, today announced he was to resign from politics at the next election due to ill health.

The 55-year-old - who was heavily criticised in last year's Scottish higher exams fiasco - had a lung transplant 11 years ago.

His decision to stand down as an MSP means there is likely to be a byelection for the Scottish parliament in his Strathkelvin and Bearsden constituency on May 3, the expected date of the general election when he will automatically quit as a Westminster MP.

Mr Galbraith said: "I have looked after health, education and the environment - something that touches everybody's lives. These have been great times and some of the best times of my life."

And he joked: "I am going back to learn my violin. If anyone has heard me play, they will realise why I need further lessons."

The Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish, said: "Your plain speaking, the fact that you do not suffer fools gladly and are often outspoken has been a breath of fresh air in Scottish politics and you are, of course, very well liked by your colleagues on the back benches and in the parliamentary party. You have truly served Scotland with distinction."

Mr Galbraith announced his decision to the first minister during a half hour meeting this morning.

He later told reporters: "I think I have been a very privileged man. I have been a minister in the first Labour government for almost 20 years, and a member of the first Scottish cabinet.

Mr Galbraith, a trained neurosurgeon, entered the Westminster parliament in 1987, winning his seat from the Tories.

Mr Galbraith was Scottish education minister during last summer's exams fiasco and the heated debate north of the border over the repeal of section 28, the law preventing the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

He lost the education portfolio during the reshuffle that followed Mr McLeish's appointment as Scottish first minister after the death of Donald Dewar. His final Scottish ministerial duties were for environment, culture and sport.

At Westminster he served as an opposition spokesman on Scottish affairs and health until 1992, when he switched to employment.

webTitle: In brief: Tarantino to resurrect Travolta in Pulp Fiction prequel

fields.headline: Tarantino to resurrect Travolta in Pulp Fiction prequel
fields.standfirst: Plus: Jurassic Park III has star in an uproar; Mick Jagger comes clean about Julia Ormond; Kate Moss moves into movies; Albert Finney prefers a smoke to the Oscars
fields.trailText: Plus: Jurassic Park III has star in an uproar; Mick Jagger comes clean about Julia Ormond; Kate Moss moves into movies; Albert Finney prefers a smoke to the Oscars
fields.body:
 Reports from Hollywood suggest that Quentin Tarantino plans to resurrect John Travolta's career once again, by signing the 46-year-old star to star in the prequel to Pulp Fiction. The film, provisionally titled The Vega Brothers, will be based on the characters of Vincent Vega, the role played by Travolta in the 1994 hit, and Vic Vega, portrayed by Michael Madsen, who appeared in Tarantino's earlier film Reservoir Dogs. The film is expected to begin production next year after Tarantino finishes his current film, Glorious Bastards, a second world war epic that is currently being shot in France.

 William H Macy has been venting his spleen over his latest role in Jurassic Park III. It seems that the constantly evolving script, which was still being updated mid-shoot, has really got the Fargo actor's goat. According to Heat magazine, Macy claimed: "Who launched a $100m (£70m) ship without a rudder? What kind of idiot is that? And who's getting fired for this? But that's the way they make these movies. I think someone should be shot." The third instalment of the prehistoric adventure, which is being directed by relative newcomer Joe Johnston, stars original cast members Sam Neill and Laura Dern.

 Los Angeles Magazine has revealed some top Hollywood secrets about why stars lost out on roles in particular films. According to the magazine, Julia Ormond didn't get a role in producer Mick Jagger's new film because she's "totally boring" while ER's Julianna Margulies was rejected from the same movie because, "I don't think she means anything." Meanwhile, the article suggests that Julianne Moore scooped the Clarice Starling role in Hannibal because rival choices Calista Flockhart and Hilary Swank were considered too thin and Angelina Jolie and Cate Blanchett were too tall.

 Model Kate Moss is so keen to break into films that she is adapting her favourite book into a film script. The 27-year-old millionaire is working with Nuns on the Run producer Michael White on a script for The Good Fairies of New York by Martin Miller, a fantasy novel about a pair of Celtic fairies exiled to New York. It is not clear whether Moss will work in front or behind the camera.

 Meanwhile, veteran Oscar nominee Albert Finney is remaining calm about this Sunday's ceremony and has confessed that he may not even show up. The 64-year-old actor has been nominated for his fifth Oscar, as best supporting actor for Erin Brockovich, but does not expect to win."Always a bridesmaid, never the bride. I'm not keen on the Oscar brouhaha," he said. "It's a very long evening, and not exactly my idea of a good night out, sat there for five hours in a non-smoking environment."

fields.headline: Travel, the easy way
fields.standfirst: Stephen Hoare gets transported to Mission Control, Houston, and the Great Barrier Reef, courtesy of a virtual field trip
fields.trailText: Stephen Hoare gets transported to Mission Control, Houston, and the Great Barrier Reef, courtesy of a virtual field trip
fields.body:
"Houston, we have a problem." Appollo 13 astronaut Jim Lovell's famous comment in 1970 must have been ringing in the ears of special needs teacher Mike Griffiths who had been working on the video link-up between NASA and his school in Slough, when suddenly it all went wobbly.

Griffiths, deputy head of Arbour Vale School, was on a world trip to meet the people his pupils had video conferenced with as part of the Global Leap project that happened on 29 February last year. It was a 16-hour marathon linking schools across 14 countries and 24 time zones. Besides NASA, the tour took Griffiths to South Africa, and Australia's Great Barrier Reef courtesy of his sponsor, video conferencing equipment supplier Picturetel. But now a computer glitch at Houston threatened to take him off the air.

Griffiths, who was set to do the video conference in a space suit, said: "Yes, actually we did have a problem. There was no socket in the astronaut's headsets so I couldn't be heard." The technical boys swung into action and within minutes a link was up and running, though without the live pictures of Griffiths doing his astronaut training.

This cautionary tale should serve as a reminder that technology is not fool-proof. Video conferencing has come a long way in the past few years and costs have come down to a price schools can afford. But do not expect the moon! Unless you are prepared to pay for the very best, the images of the people on your video-link are likely to be ever so slightly jerky and out of synch as well.

For very high quality pictures you need a lot of bandwidth - ideally an ASDL connection and category 5 (Cat 5) cabling within the school itself. But you can achieve good results with ISDN and multiple phone lines and as schools get wired for the internet, video conferencing is set to benefit as it can be carried out using local or wide area networks. A spend of £15-18,000 will buy state-of-the-art kit - a voice-activated pan and tilt digital web camera with zoom lens, audience microphones and extra cameras which could provide close-up pictures of text for example. A more basic version can be had for as little as £400 which includes a set-top box containing the software to convert a normal TV screen into a video conferencing monitor.

And then there are the phone bills to consider. While NASA is happy to put its technical boffins and astronauts on the line free, voice and data phone charges will be in the region of £80 an hour. A popular video conference destination, NASA has its hands full with sessions booked with schools across America and the rest of the world. Early booking is recommended.

Video conferencing which offers privileged access to places where pupils would not normally be admitted or to distant or exotic locations is something educational supplier Global VideoCom calls the "virtual field trip". Jane Gorst, account manager for Global VideoCom, says: "A video conference such as the NASA experience does not just teach maths and science, it inspires." Much nearer home, many UK art galleries and museums offer video conferencing. Liverpool Museum, for example, invites pupils and teachers to dial up for a guided tour of exhibits. In the geology department, a curator illustrates a talk on dinosaurs by holding up bones to the camera and showing close-ups of exhibits like coprolite - dinosaur droppings.

Preparation for a video conference will typically see pupils researching information on a website, and then framing questions which they will later have the chance to put to an expert on the TV screen. When pupils at Arbour Vale School tuned in to the Great Barrier Reef at 2pm they watched a dive taking place at 5am local time. With a voice headset and a webcam attached to her goggles, diver and marine biologist Jennifer Long answered pupils' questions directly by pointing out the fish and corals and the effects of global warming and pollution. For the children, the impact was immediate. Griffiths says: "This is not a passive activity. It isn't about sitting back and watching the TV."

Video conferencing may be a less powerful tool than e-learning and the internet and it is not as widely used. But in spite of convergence, it remains popular with teachers and is continuing to win converts.

fields.headline: Rev Ian Paisley
fields.standfirst:
Antrim North (1970-)

Ask Aristotle about Ian Paisley
fields.trailText: It is one of Ulster's many ironies that while some of the steam seems to be draining from the Rev Ian Paisley, the forces of Paisleyism seem likely to advance as Northern Ireland polarises further.
fields.body:
It is one of Ulster's many ironies that while some of the steam seems to be draining from the Rev Ian Paisley, the forces of Paisleyism seem likely to advance as Northern Ireland polarises further.

On the surface, Rev Paisley continues to be the same sulphur-and-brimstone voice of paranoid protestant unionism, still attacking the Pope and Roman Catholics but focusing against the protestant establishment in the shape of the Ulster unionists. However he has become a little quieter of late.

And David Trimble has almost replaced the Pope as his chief figure of hate. Rev Paisley dubbed the Good Friday agreement "the greatest betrayal ever foisted by a unionist leader on the unionist people."

Although age and illness have knocked some decibels off his foghorn voice, his message seems to be getting through, as shown by the DUP's September 2000 victory in the Antrim South byelection. Lord (Gerry) Fitt, the former SDLP leader, is sure that Paisley's DUP will win more seats from the David Trimble's UUP while Sinn Fein will advance further at the expense of the SDLP at the imminent general election.

It is the class aspect of Dr Paisley and Paisleyism that outsiders most frequently miss. I still remember my shock a quarter century ago when I saw him chatting warmly with Bernadette Devlin (now McAliskey), the brilliant young republican newly-elected for Mid-Ulster. What could he possibly have in common with this Roman Catholic demanding a united Ireland? The answer was simple: they were both working class, and hated both the British and the Ulster establishment. Dr Paisley's church and party represent the poor of protestant Northern Ireland, while the Ulster unionists speak for its middle classes. On social legislation he almost invariably votes with Labour.

He was ordained into his Free Presbyterian church by his father, a dissident Baptist. After local schools in Ballymena, he obtained his enormous biblical knowledge at the South Wales Bible College, Belfast's Reformed Presbyterian Theological College and South Carolina's Bob Jones University.

Dr Paisley began in politics in 1959 by forming the Ulster protestant association to prevent Belfast's dockworkers from being seduced by Gerry Fitt's Marxism. In 1964 he was jailed for three months for protesting the "Romish tendencies" of established Presbyterians. He was jailed for six weeks for blocking a largely Catholic civil rights march in 1968. He established the protestant Unionist party in 1970, capturing North Antrim in 1971 from patrician Henry Clark in 1971, when the Democratic Unionist party emerged. He was elected to the European Parliament in 1979.

The 1997 general election saw the Rev Paisley revert to his traditional campaigning ground. His manifesto was based around a pledge of no participation in talks involving Sinn Fein unless weapons decommissioning occurred first. fields.headline: Shaun Woodward
fields.standfirst:
Witney (1997- )

Ask Aristotle about Shaun Woodward
fields.trailText: There will be few wet eyes among the political classes if Shaun Woodward fails to find a seat to contest in time for the general election. He made himself a political orphan in December 1999 when he resigned from the Conservative party and announced his intention to sit on the Labour benches. fields.body:
There will be few wet eyes among the political classes if Shaun Woodward fails to find a seat to contest in time for the general election. He made himself a political orphan in December 1999 when he resigned from the Conservative party and announced his intention to sit on the Labour benches. Many - in his new party as well as his old one - found this sudden conversion shocking. He had never hidden his support for one nation Conservatism, but he had continued anti-Labour diatribes until hours before he crossed the floor.

Nonetheless, Conservatives who complained that Mr Woodward's defection was driven solely by ambition missed the point. Far from thriving in his new party he has been forced to wander the country as a political curiosity, awaiting a possible Millbank raid on a safe Labour constituency with an ageing, pliant MP willing to be kicked upstairs to the Lords in order to squeeze in this prize defector.

Many doubt that this raid will ever take place. In 1997 Labour found a haven in Newport East for another former Tory, Alan Howarth, now a Labour minister. But Mr Howarth's defection, abandoning the safe seat of Stratford on Avon, was considered over three years and taken in two stages, including years as a semi-detached Tory. In contrast, Mr Woodward's defection seemed almost petulant.

The spark which led him to walk out was the Conservative party's defence of section 28, a never used piece of legislation restricting the right of local authorities to teach same-sex education in schools. When Labour proposed abolishing the section, Conservative whips made it clear that their MPs were expected to vote against.

Similar anger at this leaden-footed approach to homosexuality later caused Ivan Massow, a prominent young Tory, to defect. In both cases, the defections left Tory wets still in the party disappointed that the defectors had not chosen to stay and fight their corner.

Ill feeling against Mr Woodward is undoubtedly compounded by his wealth. He is married to a Sainsbury heiress, Camilla, the daughter of former Tory minister Sir Tim Sainsbury. He is said to be the only Labour MP with a butler and lives in grand style in Oxfordshire.

This has not stopped him playing up his modest beginnings as the son of a porter and a barmaid. And there is certainly no doubt that he was a clever, ambitious young man. After a double first in English literature at Jesus College, Cambridge, he entered television, becoming a producer at the BBC and working on programmes such as Panorama and That's Life.

In 1990 he was headhunted by the Conservative party chairman, Chris Patten and became communications director at central office. With Saatchi & Saatchi, he devised the "Labour Tax Bombshell" posters which helped swing the 1992 election in John Major's favour. Mr Woodward had joined the Conservative party in 1988 and was pipped at being selected that year for the seat of Woodspring by Dr Liam Fox.

In 1995, after Douglas Hurd announced his retirement, he was selected for Witney in preference to Francis Maude. Once in the Commons, he was one of the few who backed Stephen Dorrell for the leadership, before switching to the equally Europhile Kenneth Clarke.

In his maiden speech he defended country sports - a stance not likely to go down well with the Labour opponents of fox hunting who will now decide whether or not he gets a chance to continue his Westminster career.

fields.headline: Nick Raynsford
fields.standfirst:
Greenwich (1992- )

Ask Aristotle about Nick Raynsford
fields.trailText: In an era when ex-Tory millionaires are welcomed into the Labour fold, it seems strange that a highly skilled, widely respected Labour minister should hide his origins in the squirearchy by calling himself 'Nick'. The name of the minister for housing and planning is actually Wyvill Richard Nicolls Raynsford. The Raynsfords of Milton Malsor Manor, near Northampton, can trace their ancestry back to 15th century squires.
fields.body:
In an era when ex-Tory millionaires are welcomed into the Labour fold, it seems strange that a highly skilled, widely respected Labour minister should hide his origins in the squirearchy by calling himself 'Nick'. The name of the minister for housing and planning is actually Wyvill Richard Nicolls Raynsford. The Raynsfords of Milton Malsor Manor, near Northampton, can trace their ancestry back to 15th century squires.

This does not stop him from being one of the government's most skilled technical experts. While minister for London he carried through the 413-clause Greater London Authority Act, the longest piece of legislation since the Government of India Act 1948. Since he knew so much about this Livingstone-curbing act, Tony Blair at first thought Mr Raynsford should contest for the mayoralty. But this uncharismatic, balding technocrat was thought no match for the 'Great Entertainer' and Frank Dobson was thrown in instead.

Nick Raynsford has kept smiling, most recently launching his major reform of property conveyancing: making selling a house almost as easy as selling a car. When MPs from impoverished northern slums complained that the £300 cost was too much for houses selling for £4,000, he agreed to consider special dispensation.

Mr Raynsford is a housing specialist with finely honed political skills. After Repton and Sydney Sussex, Cambridge, he did a diploma in art and design at the Chelsea School of Art. A social housing enthusiast, he worked for the Society for Cooperative Dwellings, then for SHAC (London's sheltered housing aid centre), and then for Raynsford Morris, a housing consultancy in which he was a partner and director.

He joined the Labour party after campaigning against evictions and a motorway though Fulham. Elected and re-elected to Hammersmith and Fulham council, he was selected to contest the 1986 byelection caused by the death of its popular sitting Tory MP, Martin Stevens, and won the seat, beating in the process Roger Liddle, then standing for the SDP and now back in the Labour fold as No 10's policy adviser on Europe. Despite becoming an active and constructive soft-left MP, he lost his seat a year later after the local Labour council increased rates by 50%.

Remaining in the public eye, Mr Raynsford failed to be selected for safe Vauxhall or Rotherham, but was chosen for marginal Greenwich, then held by SDP's Rosie Barnes. He ousted her in 1992.

Although normally genial and anxious to please, he warned the John Smith leadership against sleepwalking into oblivion by "simply relying on the incompetence and failure of the Tories to deliver us a victory." Tony Blair named him a housing spokesman under Frank Dobson. In 1997 he became under secretary for environment and transport with responsibility for London. His promotion to minister of state two years later showed the PM's appreciation for his high level of unflappable competence.
