fields.headline: John Redwood
fields.standfirst:
Wokingham (1987- )

Ask Aristotle about John Redwood
fields.trailText: Even the Tory MPs most shocked by William Hague's February 2000 sacking of John Redwood privately admitted to questions about his hardhitting behaviour. A man of undoubted high intelligence, his over the top attacks sometimes made one look for the men in white coats. By general consensus, Mr Redwood is a Tory version of Tony Benn: his approach is similar to Mr Benn's pseudo-Marxist mindset in its fondness for black-and-white theories expressed in prefabricated phrases.
fields.body:
Even the Tory MPs most shocked by William Hague's February 2000 sacking of John Redwood privately admitted to questions about his hardhitting behaviour. A man of undoubted high intelligence, his over the top attacks sometimes made one look for the men in white coats. By general consensus, Mr Redwood is a Tory version of Tony Benn: his approach is similar to Mr Benn's pseudo-Marxist mindset in its fondness for black-and-white theories expressed in prefabricated phrases.

It is his brilliance which carried him from his humble roots in a Canterbury council house to top jobs in City merchant banks. It was this same brilliance which enabled him to disguise the greed underlying Thatcherism in a series of books elevating it to a new philosophy.

And it was his enormous capacity for hard work which enabled him to rise as fast as he did. It is said that he wrote his PhD dissertation for Magdalen College, Oxford, on the tube, while travelling towork at merchant bankers Robert Fleming.

Despite these virtues, his somewhat patchy personality sets him apart. In normal discourse, he seems most intelligent and reasonable. But grasping a Commons dispatch box he can soar over the top like an unguided missile. His unblinking eyes, his jerky movements and the almost-mechanical perfection of his brain makes it clear, apart from the pointed ears, why he has been tagged a 'Vulcan'.

Mr Redwood makes the mistakes of the out-of-touch brilliant. He thinks opponents will be persuaded by pure logic. When secretary of state for Wales, he failed to master the Welsh national anthem, and thought nobody would mind that he never slept in the principality. When chided, he was shocked that anyone could complain that he preferred sleeping with his wife in Wokingham.

His singlemindedness is evident from his belief that he can still capture enough Tory minds to consider become party leader, despite his setbacks in challenging John Major in July 1995, trying to succeed him in May 1997, and having been sacked by Mr Hague in 2000. He is not deterred by the fact that his "snobbish arrogance" put off even Europhobe Teresa Gorman. Nor by the success of Ann Widdecombe in appealing to Tory gut instincts.

His confidence is based on his rapid rise. The youngest ever Oxfordshire county councillor, at 21 in 1973, he urged the sale of council houses. Three years later he was arguing for privatising nationalised industries, and being invited to meet Mrs Thatcher. He had less sex appeal at the polls: fighting the 1982 Peckham byelection against Harriet Harman, he lost his deposit despite the fact that the Tories were riding high in the polls. After becoming Mrs Thatcher's head of policy unit, her Tories found him his safe seat at Wokingham for 1987.

Although Mr Redwood has never reached high office, he has left a lasting mark on the political landscape. He worked with Mrs Thatcher as she created the dominant British political ideology of the last 30 years. More importantly, he effectively ended her successor's political career by picking up the gauntlet when John Major challenged the party to "put up or shut up" when he briefly resigned as leader of the Conservative party in 1995 and stood for re-election.

fields.headline: Michael Heseltine
fields.standfirst:
Henley (1974- )
Tavistock, Devon (1966-74)

Ask Aristotle about Michael Heseltine
fields.trailText: As Michael Heseltine fades from political sight the jury is still out on whether he was a failed man of destiny or all smoke and mirrors. Certainly his walkout from Margaret Thatcher's cabinet during the 1985 Westland crisis was the work of a great actor. His most solid achievement may be his publishing business, built up from nothing to become one of Britain's largest magazine owners. A self-made millionaire, Mr Heseltine has the style to match.
fields.body:
As Michael Heseltine fades from political sight the jury is still out on whether he was a failed man of destiny or all smoke and mirrors. Certainly his walkout from Margaret Thatcher's cabinet during the 1985 Westland crisis was the work of a great actor. His most solid achievement may be his publishing business, built up from nothing to become one of Britain's largest magazine owners. A self-made millionaire, Mr Heseltine has the style to match.

One has always had to distinguish between Mr Heseltine's flashy pretences and his constructive reality. He was named defence secretary in 1983 with a brief to curb defence expenditure in the wake of the Falklands war, but instead concentrated on a propaganda war against the CND, even setting up a separate department for the purpose. His theatrical instincts, which led him to undertake stunts such as donning a flak jacket for public appearances, infuriated the generals and admirals who knew Swansea-born Hezza had shed his national service Welsh Guards uniform within nine months for the hopeless seat of Gower in 1959.

The strength of his ambition was never in doubt, even if we doubt Sir Julian Critchley's story that Mr Heseltine told him while at Pembroke College, Oxford in 1952 that he intended to be in the cabinet by the 1990s. In fact he was deputy prime minister by 1995, achieving the position by trading the votes of his 35 supporters to keep John Major safe from John Redwood's leadership challenge. By then, his first severe heart attack in Venice in 1993 had made it clear that his poor health disqualified him from the top job.

His political career began to take shape in the mid-1960s - he read the local paper every week for a year to swot up on local issues and won the Devon seat of Tavistock in 1966. He used his maiden speech to attack Labour's prices and incomes bill, which aimed to freeze wages, and also fought Barbara Castle's Transport Act.

His first run in with Mrs Thatcher came in 1975 - by which time he had moved to become MP for Henley, a seat nearer his London businesses - when he voted against her in the second round of the leadership campaign - despite supporting her in the first. He won a standing ovation at the party conference for denouncing nationalisation and in 1976 he was forced to apologise for waving the mace above his head in a moment of madness in the Commons. In 1981, he was dubbed 'Mr Merseyside' after he visited the city following the Toxteth riots and, although he was sympathetic to the poll tax at the start of its legislative process, by the end he was a firm opponent.

In 1985 he resigned from the Cabinet over the government's backing for the sale of Westland helicopters to an American firm. Mr Heseltine favoured an Italian consortium that could have bailed out the ailing military hardware manufacturer and prevented it from turning to Sikorski for help. But there is doubt about whether the European consortium ever existed. He could not put flesh on it for me then, or in his recent memoirs. I suspect that his goal in resigning was to draw attention to Mrs Thatcher's high-handedness and anti-Europeanism.

Throughout his career, Mr Heseltine has been the leading Tory advocate of government interventionism on the side of entrepreneurs. He wanted to achieve this through regional governments - which the Thatcher cabinet rejected - and urban development corporations, which it expensively accepted.

Mr Heseltine's big-idea imagination saw the possibility of redeveloping rundown east London as a great "east London corridor", with the Millennium Dome as its centrepiece. It also led him to advocate the ambitious European project. But unhappily for him, however, in the last decade his Europhilia has been swamped by the Europhobia of most of his party colleagues, and he has found himself increasingly aligned with his Blairite "opponents".

He has had two consolations in these troubles: the success of his Haymarket group publishing empire means that he is worth more than £300m and the arboretum at his £1m house near Banbury continues to flourish.

fields.headline: Army general (retd), London
fields.standfirst:
Sir Michael Rose
Final salary: c. £150,000
fields.trailText:
Sir Michael Rose
Final salary: c. £150,000
fields.body:
Having failed the Foreign Office exam, and coming from a family with a military tradition, I joined the army in 1964 faut de rien. I decided to try it for a couple of years and see if anything else came up. In 1968, when the British army found itself without any operational commitments in the world, I tried to leave, but circumstances persuaded me otherwise. If I had left I would probably have become a banker.

I joined the Coldstream Guards, but was seconded on a number of occasions to the special forces, including the Parachute Brigade.

Service was the most important factor for me: above all, service to soldiers who depend on their officers for their well-being.

I felt appreciated by those soldiers, whose judgement I valued. Appreciation was also shown by the oppressed and destitute peoples of the world who benefited from the peacekeeping operations in which I was involved, including Bosnia. However, while politicians generally praise military action, it is difficult to find examples of support being given in situations other than war.

Pay was never a factor for me. At the start of my career I was underpaid; by the end I was adequately paid. What keeps soldiers in the army are the rewards associated with being in an efficient, tight-knit organisation. Soldiers who do not grouse are atypical. However, in many ways and compared with those elsewhere, British soldiers are well looked after. Most complaints come from inadequate resourcing and the risks that consequently have to be taken, both in training and on operations. One of the greatest matters of concern to soldiers relates to the other ranks pension. Any attempt to reduce pension rights will adversely affect retention within the ranks.

I was fortunate never to have a job that I did not find stimulating, or one in which I felt inhibited by dogma. I did, though, find separation from my wife and children difficult at times. webTitle: TV review: Science And The Swastika.

fields.headline: The devil's work
fields.trailText: Science And The Swastika
fields.body:
Science And The Swastika (Channel 4) was a chilling examination of the Faustian pact between German biologists and the Nazi Party. The irritating music, which seemed to be striving to sound like Hannibal, told you it was chilling, but was quite unnecessary. The world being portrayed was so insane and appalling that it needed no props. Germany's doctors, already proponents of eugenics and happy that the exodus of Jewish physicians had freed up the top ranks of their profession, were only too willing to do the devil's work.

This was the first in what promises to be an enlightening four-part series about the Nazis' treatment of science. Biology was the natural starting point because Hitler's desire to build the master race underpinned his philosophy (if Mein Kampf can be so designated) and politics. He had read books on eugenics while writing his tract and borrowed from scientific thought in arguing that the German nation had to be cleansed. He didn't tell doctors what to do; he sought to do what doctors were telling him.

There was no attempt to sensationalise, other than in the plangency of the strings. The story - and the madhouse-world that was 30s Germany - was sensational enough. A world where, at the behest of doctors, people were forcibly sterilised because they were alcoholics; where children were encouraged to inform on dysfunctional members of their family; where 5,000 disabled children were murdered and their deaths reported to a secret committee established by Hitler to oversee euthanasia.

There seemed to be a moral lesson here. Germany was the leading scientific nation in the world in the 1930s, and its doctors appeared to think they could do anything. They were presented not as cartoon villains, but as people who believed they were working for the benefit of mankind. The son of leading eugenicist Alfred Ploetz even dared to call him utopian. They were seeking to eliminate disease; unfortunately, large numbers of people had to be eliminated first.

The process began with the voluntary sterilisation of those with disorders that were believed to be hereditary; then came compulsory sterilisation; then euthanasia. The first gas chambers were built to murder 100,000 psychiatric patients and disabled people; the technology was then transferred to the death camps. The programme demonstrated the way in which the "utopians" became agents of extermination, each stage of degradation pinpointed.

There was little attempt to demonise the doctors, not even Hitler's personal physician Karl Brandt, who oversaw much of the euthanasia programme and was executed at Nuremberg in 1948. Once the eugenic idea - the notion that the race was perfectible - had taken hold, the process assumed a terrible logic. Doctors were making war on the messiness of human life; they dispensed with the Hippocratic oath and sought to play God.

The programme had found two eyewitnesses. The testimony of one, a retired civil servant who had been forcibly sterilised because doctors wrongly believed that his deformed hands and feet were hereditary, was moving. He told how before 1933 he had played happily with his boyhood friends; then with the rise of the Hitler Youth they had abandoned him because of his imperfections. His words were more powerful than all the archive footage in shedding light on a sick society.

I felt less comfortable with the other witness, a 101-year-old paediatrician from Leipzig who appeared still to support many of the policies pursued in the 30s and described his loathing for the "idiot" children who were murdered. Had he ever been prosecuted, one wondered? And was he not too old now to be paraded in this way?

This programme did not need to look for individual monsters; what stood condemned was the monstrousness of the machine that science and society became under the Nazis. Everyone, as the historian Daniel Goldhagen has argued, bore some of the guilt for drifting with the tide. Only one doctor refused to take a post vacated by a Jewish academic in the purge of 1933. One among many thousand. From that moment on, Germany was moving towards mechanised destruction, and science and medicine were tuning the engine.

fields.headline: Learning from the microchip
fields.standfirst: Why does education seem to resist technology?
fields.trailText: Why does education seem to resist technology?
fields.body:
Technology governs society. Much as we like to pretend otherwise, all social change derives from changing technology. Democracy, feminism, globalisation each required an enabling technology: the mass media, contraception, the microchip. Education is strangely resistant to technological change, and slow to respond to social change. The classroom and the lecture hall have hardly changed at all throughout the last century, while family life, work and leisure have all been transformed. Why?

It is not as if education is a particularly successful social enterprise. I believe history will judge the 20th century model of state-controlled compulsory education as a failure. More than a century of elementary schooling has produced "the long tail of underachievement" in the UK. One in six of our young people hate school, fail to reach adequate standards, disrupt their classes or play truant. This disaffection has prevailed for over 100 years.

I suppose there are two reasons why, against all the evidence, we continue to tinker with the reform of formal education, and try to make the unworkable work. The first is that children do not have a vote. The second is that no one has proposed a plausible alternative to schools. If I were tyrant for a day, I would extend suffrage to include everyone over the age of 11 - and encourage "home schooling". But technology achieves more than tyrants.

E-learning is seen as a supplement to teacher-led education, not an alternative. We have computers in classrooms (often unused), distance learning supported by summer schools, online higher education with local face-to-face tuition. I have been experimenting with e-learning and find that I can make good progress without a teacher. No surprise there. Of course, I don't need a formal qualification. And there lies the rub.

I am more and more persuaded that the critical difference between "education" and "learning" is qualifications. We hate school because of exams; we enjoy lifelong learning because of the fascination of personal development. Perhaps the most hopeful way forward will be progressively to transfer the assessment of qualifications from human examiners to computer programmes. That is not far off.

Technology rules, OK. It will be advances in technology that ultimately transform education. In the meantime, do not underestimate the effects of the major social changes of the previous century (democracy, feminism, globalisation) on schools and universities.

The shift from meritocracy to democracy is the most significant and least understood. It can be simply described. Meritocratic societies seek to identify the best people, educate them well and offer them positions of leadership. Democratic societies aim to provide lifelong learning for all their people. They know learning pays - for individuals, organisations and the whole community. For such societies, the priority is access.

The issue of equity between men and women, rich and poor, black and white, presents a major challenge to higher education. The problem is that our traditional idea of a university is essentially meritocratic and selective in a world that is determined to become democratic and comprehensive.

Education is a service. It provides an interesting test case for the thesis that the market is superior to planned provision. Why should higher education not be privatised? What is certain is that the social provision of elite higher education (the Oxbridge model) cannot deliver what we now want. The combined thrust of technological and social change (e-learning in a free market) is likely to produce revolutionary change in education before long.

Sir Christopher Ball is chancellor of Derby University and chairman of the Global University Alliance. He founded the national Campaign for Learning and chairs a new research group, The Talent Foundation.

fields.headline: Leo Burnett buys internet shop
fields.trailText: Advertising agency Leo Burnett has boosted its interactive offering with the acquisition of the new media agency Hard Reality, writes Claire Cozens .
fields.body:
Advertising agency Leo Burnett has boosted its interactive offering with the acquisition of the new media agency Hard Reality.

The company will be merged with Leo Burnett's own web agency, Leonardo.

Steve Barton, chief executive of Leonardo, said the merger marries together Hard Reality's creative expertise with Leonardo's strengths in direct marketing.

"Our centre of gravity was very much in the direct marketing arena but we've been increasingly working with Hard Reality over the past three to four months," Barton said. Current clients include zed, Kellogg's and Handspring.

"This move is part of Leo Burnett's plan to build brands and business holistically across all services and all forms of media," said Steve Gatfield, chief operating officer for Leo Burnett Worldwide.

webTitle: Why the Ufi's chief is moving on

fields.headline: Wright off
fields.standfirst: Just as the Ufi is picking up, its chief is moving on. Why, asks  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Just as the Ufi is picking up, its chief is moving on. Why, asks Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Wanted - man or woman to run the hottest revolution since Caxton. That's not quite what the job ad for a new chief executive for the Ufi - formerly the University for Industry - says.

But according to its current incumbent, it's a job in the vanguard of e-learning. And that, she reckons, could be the biggest revolution since the invention of printing. Not only that. Ufi could put Britain at the international cutting edge of e-learning.

Which begs the question: if the jobs is such a humdinger, why is Ann Wright quitting?

"I think this is the right time," she says. "I think it's important that I've implemented the model and set it on its way."

The former Sunderland University vice-chancellor explains that she signed up for three years and those are now up. She could stay on if she wanted to.

They have been tough years. Ufi has weathered a stiffer buffeting than many new ventures and now may be entering calmer waters, a different structure from Gordon Brown's original grand design from the early 1990s.

It has seen off hostility from the higher and further education sectors - the former indignant about the misuse of the "university" title, the latter suspicious that Ufi was invading its territory.

Now it looks likely to hit its targets: two and a half million people will have called its "learndirect" telephone helpline by April; 900 "learning centres" have been set up, many in spots where the public naturally congregate, 600 partner organisations are mucking in with them and there are 71 "hubs", or regional centres of operation.

Government makes plain its backing for the idea. There has been talk of Ufi eventually being recognised as having been a construct as momentous as the Open University, which was also set up by a Labour government. Certainly ministers see Ufi as a critical tool for bringing about its key wishes of social inclusion and widening participation.

So why, when things are starting to get more interesting, is Wright leaving? Isn't it a bit like doing all the hard work in a play only to have your part stolen by some Hollywood name when the film is made?

Either the experience has been dire or she must have something pretty special to go to by way of a new job.

Wright points out that she will remain on the Ufi board.

"And I've accepted a role with the DfEE as e-learning advisor."

That can't be all. There's got to be something in the offing which she can't talk about yet. On the other hand, she has moved around quite a bit in her career to date.

"I've done really quite a range of things in the last 10 years."

Her first full-time job was as English lecturer at Lancaster University. Her field was George Bernard Shaw and theatre of that period. She moved to the then Hatfield polytechnic. "It was a wonderful challenge. I wanted the opportunity to create new degrees in the early days of the polytechnics."

From there, in 1984, she went to the Council for National Academic Awards. As registrar in the arts and humanities she is proud of having pushed the boundaries of what should be considered degree material.

"It was quite a challenge to persuade people that a discipline like dance could lead to a PhD."

She went as deputy rector to Liverpool polytechnic in 1986, then as rector to Sunderland poly, steering it through to university status.

Was persuading people that Ufi would get off the ground harder than convincing crusty academics about doctorates in dance?

"It's always a challenge to be able to visualise what's not there.

"It's the kind of thing that when you finally see it, you say: Oh yes, of course . . ."

She reckons the public is much more aware than even three years ago about on-line services, partly because of all the publicity about dotcoms.

Since last April, 72,000 punters have registered for 160,000 courses.

Clearly Wright thinks that's a good start, but the first milestone is still some way off.

"I'll feel we've really succeeded when people don't have to ask what learndirect is and it's just a part of their lives and work."

webTitle: Scotland to review child protection procedures

fields.headline: Scotland to review child protection procedures
fields.trailText: The Scottish education minister has ordered a wide ranging review of child protection procedures in the wake of an inquiry into the death of a three-year-old girl. David Mitchell reports
fields.body:
Scottish education minister Jack McConnell has ordered a wide ranging review of child protection procedures in Scotland in the wake of an inquiry into the death of a three-year-old girl.

Kennedy McFarlane from Dumfries died in May last year after a blow from her mother's boyfriend sent her crashing against the leg of a bed. Thomas Duncan, 33, was later jailed for life at the high court in Edinburgh.

Earlier this month an independent inquiry by consultant pediatrician Helen Hammond concluded the death could have been prevented had social workers and others heeded the warning signs from repeated concerns, referrals and hospital admissions.

The inquiry also recommended that an audit of child protection processes across Scotland be carried out to look at the consistency and quality of practice among individual agencies and agencies working together.

Announcing the review, Mr McConnell said: "Although a lot has been done to improve child protection in recent years, we must do all we can to ensure our systems do not fail those vulnerable children that rely on them. I am determined that we will do our best to prevent a repeat of this kind of incident.

"It is vital that we do more than just talk about joined-up working. We must ensure that everyone - local government, agencies and departments - work better together locally to give the best service possible to our young people. No child should ever fall through the protection net just because professionals fail to work closely together."

The review will be carried out by the social work services inspectorate and health department with support from the schools and police inspectorates. No timescale has been given but it is likely to last up to 18 months.

The last major overhaul of child protection legislation came in 1995 with the introduction of the Children (Scotland) Act. But this was largely a result of the 1992 Orkney and Fife inquiries and is now seen as in need of updating.

Anne Stafford, head of policy at Children 1st, formerly the Royal Scottish Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children, said she did not believe a "root and branch" overhaul of child care legislation was required.

"Very few children die each year at the hands of their parents in Scotland. But one child is one too many and so we welcome this look again the child protection system," she said.

"We have known the messages for a long time and we do have systems in place. But it is important to think about the relationships between teams working together and to make sure the system is working well nationally, and not just in patches."

The Association of Directors of Social Work welcomed the review but said it hoped it would take a wider view of services aimed at helping and supporting children and families.

"Agencies involved in child protection have increasingly worked well together to deliver improved services. But it is right that from time to time progress is reviewed and the systems in place checked to ensure they are working effectively," said vice-president Carole Wilkinson.

"Councils in the past have been criticised for having too narrow a focus. It is important that we ensure children who need help with their education, getting on with their families, and with their offending or drug misuse also get attention."

fields.headline: Battling China's deforestation
fields.standfirst: New figures reveal that billions of trees have been planted since 1981. It is still not enough, says John Gittings
fields.trailText: New figures reveal that billions of trees have been planted since 1981. It is still not enough, says John Gittings in Shanghai.
fields.body:
Most people in China have planted trees at some time or another, especially if they are officials doing their civic duty on national tree planting day. When the day was celebrated this month for the 20th successive year, an unbelievable figure was released for the number of trees planted since the first year in 1981.

The total, said the national greening commission (whose remit is to "greenify" China) amounted to some 35bn trees. Forest coverage had now reached 16.55% of China's land mass, as against only 12% two decades ago.

There were also encouraging figures for the length of windbreaks planted to prevent the desert from encroaching and to preserve soil and water in upland regions.

This should be a success story, yet everyone knows it is the reverse. Lakes and marshlands are drying up at an alarming rate in the watersheds of the Tibet-Qinghai plateau; Beijing is hit every year by more severe sandstorms; severe summer floods in central China are blamed on the denuded hills upstream. Indeed the commission's own report ended on a very different note from the one with which it began.

"Due to various factors," it concluded according to the China Daily's summary, "desertification, soil erosion, flooding, drought and other kinds of natural disasters still occur in China, and they are sometimes very harmful."

"The report shows that every year, an average of 2,460sq km [950sq miles] of vegetated land in China deteriorates into desert and another one million hectares of land suffers from serious land erosion."

So where have all those billions of trees gone?

As the environment become a more topical and politically acceptable subject, more people are posing the question. It was discussed at length during the National People's Congress in Beijing this month, particularly by specialists in the advisory body (the Chinese people's political consultative conference or CPPCC) which meets at the same time.

There is more than one answer, says one of the experts who attended the discussions.

"It may be true that they have planted those billions, but whether the trees will survive is another matter. They need care and attention over a long period of time, and they will only get it if there is proper management or an economic incentive to do so."

Windbreaks which surround commercial crops in inner Mongolia are much more likely to be properly maintained than those built in nonproductive areas to keep the encroaching desert at bay.

Hillsides where local farmers have a commercial stake in long-term forestry will also do better than those over which the community forages for firewood. Second, even where the new planting is properly maintained, it will take years - probably decades - before it can produce the same climatic benefits as the timber which it has replaced.

A third problem until recently has been a lack of forethought in planting. "They go in for monoculture and do not plant indigenous trees," says the expert. "A lot of eucalyptus is planted in the south but its leaves will not degrade."

Where timber is planted for periodic renewal, it is often felled on a wholesale basis so that vast areas are cut at the same time leaving the ground once again perilously denuded.

Anyone who travels in the west of China will soon encounter entire hillsides where the timber has been razed to the ground, or travel on roads where the tree cover on both sides has been felled for tens of kilometres.

China's richer communities may even pillage the tree resources of their rural interiors. Shanghai now boasts of its success in having transplanted 70,000 mature trees from its suburbs and from neighbouring provinces.

They include magnolias weighing ten tons and aged between 80 and a hundred years old, transported up to 700km from Anhui province.

Another 150,000 trees, says the city's gardening bureau, will be imported in the next two years.

Shanghai is another world in every sense from Tibet, where an experimental project has been launched to seed parts of the plateau by helicopter with grass and shrubs as well as trees. People are becoming more aware that in the headwaters of the river systems a mixed cover is more efficient.

Even if this works, the benefits should be set against exploitation of timber elsewhere in Tibet - a balance sheet which for political reasons is difficult to strike.

It is an uphill task in both senses of the phrase. There are, however, encouraging signs of a greater understanding on the need to plant and maintain trees on a long-term basis, says the CPPCC expert. Tree planting, after all, has deep roots in Chinese culture.

"Still planting trees at seventy!", wrote the 18th century poet Yuan Mei. "Yet mock not at my 'foolishness', dear neighbours. / It's true that mortals must die, / But fortunately no one can foretell when."

fields.headline: Emergency help for rural businesses
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government today attempted to deflect mounting criticism of its handling of the foot and mouth crisis by announcing a package of measures designed to aid rural businesses, many of which have been hard hit as visitors stay away from the countryside.
fields.body:
The government today attempted to deflect mounting criticism of its handling of the foot and mouth crisis by announcing a package of measures designed to aid rural businesses, many of which have been hard hit as visitors stay away from the countryside.

The countryside minister, Michael Meacher, told MPs that he understands the severity of the situation and will encourage the public to go back to areas of the countryside unaffected by the disease.

He said: "Large parts of the country are not affected by foot and mouth, but members of the public wrongly believe that the whole of the countryside is out of bounds. This has had a devastating and unnecessary impact on many areas which depend on visitors."

He said the government will offer new guidance to the public and encourage tourists to return to uninfected areas. English Heritage will reopen more than 200 properties from April 1 and the National Trust will be opening 150 properties by the same date, he said. A wider network of public footpaths and waterways will also be opened.

Mr Meacher also announced practical help for businesses, including a cut in business rates for small businesses in areas of greatest need and a mandatory 50% rate relief for all food shops in small rural settlements.

"I've had discussions with the major banks, and they fully understand the situation," Mr Meacher said. "They made clear they are keen to support customers whenever possible, by perhaps extending lines of credit or arranging capital repayment holidays."

The Tory environment secretary, Archie Norman, welcomed the measures "as far as they go" but urged the government to guarantee immediate relief.

"Businesses in the countryside need help now and not in a few months time," Mr Norman said. "The acid test is when cash relief affects the bank accounts of the businesses concerned."

fields.headline: Charity management: the issue explained
fields.trailText: How to keep the cash flow flowing? It's the issue that underpins all others in the charity manager's mind. Traditional funding, from foundations and members, is being spread very thin. The 185,000 registered charities in the UK and Wales are joined by up to 5,000 new ones every year and there is not enough money to go around.
fields.body:
How to keep the cash flow flowing? It's the issue that underpins all others in the charity manager's mind. Traditional funding, from foundations and members, is being spread very thin. The 185,000 registered charities in the UK and Wales are joined by up to 5,000 new ones every year and there is not enough money to go around.

Many charities are looking to business to diversify their revenue streams. Companies, keen to bolster their public image, are happy to work with charities, provided there is real benefit to both sides. This could mean working with a company's stakeholders, taking advantage of its IT and management expertise, or getting some help with branding and public relations.

New regulations and changing perceptions of how charities should be run mean you can't oversee a sloppy operation any more. Bad accounting and wasteful use of resources mean you'll lose funding, lose support and, in a worst case scenario, be investigated by the newly beefed-up Charity Commission. The 21st century charity is one that's run as efficiently as a business, so get some help from the experts.

Some charities are looking to plug any skills gap they may have, by recruiting trustees from diverse backgrounds. Those with financial, accounting and fundraising skills are becoming a sought after commodity, with many charities taking the expensive route of advertising for the right people. The new Tustee Act, which came into force on February 1, gives trustees greater freedom in how they manage the charity, especially on the investment side. But to take proper advantage of this, you'll need trustees with investment skills.

Public concern that there are too many charities on the beat, and that not all are using their resources responsibly, also needs to be addressed. The NSPCC was slammed for using £20m of its annual £75m income on public education and campaigning rather than direct services. Justifying overheads and explaining that fundraising and awareness raising is not an optional extra, but an integral part of your work, has, therefore, become very important.

The new charity accounting regulations, otherwise known as Sorp, could help. They encourage transparency and openness and make the case for using annual reports to explain, in greater detail, why money has been allocated in a certain way. Research by the NCVO suggests the public wants more information on how charities are run, so give them what they want.

Pooling your resources is one way of saving on overheads. The Cancer Research Campaign and the Imperial Cancer Research fund are considering a merger and Shelter and Crisis have gone into partnership with the government-funded Millennium Plus homeless project. Shelter provides the advice to homeless people and Crisis the accommodation. The Charities Aid Foundation says it has had more enquiries from charities about collaboration and mergers in the past year than ever before. Sharing infrastructure costs, such as a finance manager or computer system, is just one of the way charities can collaborate.

But, thereafter, take the upper hand in the public relations war. Don't just respond to press criticism, give them good, positive news stories and explain the work you do.

webTitle: Gameshow prize out of this world

fields.headline: Gameshow prize out of this world
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: The winner of US reality TV show Survivor is to be launched into space, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The victor of US reality TV show Survivor will win a prize that is literally out of this world.

In an initiative that will outshine any prize yet offered on a gameshow, Survivor will send next year's winning contestant into space.

The producer of the show, dreamt up by former Carlton boss Lord Waheed Alli, is in talks with the Russian Space Agency to send the winner to the International Space Station, which is currently under construction.

The final frontier for the advertising industry is also about to be reached - the space station will carry advertising.

The Russian Space Agency and US space buffs last year created an organisation called Mircorp to examine commercial opportunities for the existing Mir space station.

But ideas about renting out Mir for space tourism or leasing it as a film set were dashed when it began to deteriorate. Mir is due to crash-land back on earth this week.

Now Mircorp is looking at commercial tie-ins for the US-led International Space Station, which will be completed in 2006.

Gert Weyers, project manager for Mircorp, said the group was working with Survivor's US producer to launch a contestant into space.

"They are definite plans, we will go through with the project. 2002 will see a contestant go up to the International Space Station in an extra seat," Mr Weyers told Radio 4's Today programme.

He also said Mircorp was seeking advertisers and sponsors to have their names emblazoned on the space shuttles being sent up to the station.

"Commercial and sponsorship deals and the opportunity to advertise in the space station itself are future markets Mircorp has identified. The space sector is a viable market," said Mr Weyers.

Pizza Hut plastered its name across one of the rockets sent to the station, whose launch was seen by 500m people around the world, according to Mr Weyers.

webTitle: Football in need of George's green fingers

fields.headline: Football in need of George's green fingers
fields.trailText: The importance of a nice piece of turf can never be understated
fields.body:
Footballers tend to respond positively to a nice bit of turf. Michel Platini was so impressed with the pitch in Seville before France's 1982 World Cup semi-final with West Germany that he took off his shoes and socks so that he could feel the cool, damp blades tickling the soles of his feet.

When I told the former Manchester United goalkeeper Alex Stepney that I had seen him play for English League v Scottish League in Middlesbrough, he smiled. "I always enjoyed playing at Ayresome Park," he said wistfully. "It had the finest surface in the country".

It was a response guaranteed to delight any Boro fan over 35 years of age. Every visiting team praised our glorious grass. We were proud of it. I spent many happy childhood hours gazing at that pitch (admittedly, there was usually nothing much happening on it to distract me).

The secret of its benign, lush greenness was never revealed, though local cynics, of whom there were at least 20,000 at every home game, opined that it was because of the amount of shite it had had on it over the years.

It was because of Ayresome Park's majestic verdure that the stadium was chosen to host some of the group matches of the 1966 World Cup. Priorities have changed in football since then. It's hard to imagine today's FA selecting a Third Division ground as a venue for an international simply because of its herbage.

Instead the FA opts for Villa Park. On Sunday, Arsène Wenger complained that the pitch there is the worst in the Premiership. The home manager John Gregory appeared to agree with him.

Not that the rest of the country has much to be smug about. Over the past few years, surfaces everywhere have deteriorated, starved of sunshine by ever-growing stands. The pitch at Old Trafford has sometimes looked like it has entertained a particularly truculent herd of wildebeest (they played a rugby league international on it, which pretty much amounts to the same thing), the Stadium of Light appears to have been covered with a job lot of unsavoury brown carpet tiles, and the turf at the Millennium stadium, Cardiff, is being relaid more often than a sumo wrestler's breakfast table.

There's no comfort to be found in Middlesbrough either. The illustrious Ayresome Park pitch is now patched into lawns all across Teesside, while its replacement at the Riverside is mucky and mushy with a thin sprinkling of green across the top. It looks like pease pudding that's been allowed to lurk at the back of the fridge for several months beyond its sell-by date.

For nostalgists keen to be reminded of the days when the Baseball Ground might have been used to re-enact El Alamein and players had to be pulled from the mud by traction engines, this may be reason to cheer, but it can't be good for football. A rutted surface turns a powerful shot into what Trevor Brooking invariably refers to as "the dreaded shinner" and a half-hearted cross deflects into the net off a divot. The game is reduced to a lottery.

In the short term this may seem a pleasing alternative to the predictable state of today's Premiership. Over time, however, the effects would not be so pleasing. You don't have to be a tactical genius to work out that a short-passing game will be ineffective in a ploughed field; that route one is the best way to avoid getting bogged down in the mud. Ugly surfaces tend to encourage ugly football.

Fifa is more than happy to issue directives forcing players to tuck their shirts into their shorts and keep their socks pulled up, so it's strange that it has done nothing to ensure a minimum standard for pitches. The England and Wales Cricket Board long ago organised a body to inspect playing surfaces and report on any that failed to make the grade. The result has been a widespread improvement. Maybe it's time football's governing body followed suit.

If it does, it shouldn't have to search far for the ideal candidate to head up the new organisation. A few years ago George Graham was asked about his garden. "Being a footballer," the immaculately clipped and neatly groomed Scot replied, "I like a lawn as a feature."

At the start of last week he was back on a similar tack. "The rain has killed off my lawn. I'm very proud of my lawn." He's a football man, he's no-nonsense, he's passionate about grass and, what's more, he's available.

The England and Wales Cricket Board long ago organised a body to inspect playing surfaces and report on any that failed to make the grade. The result has been a widespread improvement. Maybe it's time football's governing body followed suit. If it does, it shouldn't have to search far for the ideal candidate to head up the new organisation. A few years ago George Graham was asked about his garden. "Being a footballer," the immaculately clipped and neatly groomed Scot replied, "I like a lawn as a feature." At the start of last week he was back on a similar tack. "The rain has killed off my lawn. I'm very proud of my lawn." He's a football man, he's no-nonsense, he's passionate about grass and, what's more, he's available.

fields.headline: BBC regains ground in 10pm news war
fields.trailText:
4.30pm TV overnights: The BBC won the battle of the bulletins last night by pulling in 1m more viewers than ITV, writes Jason Deans.
Mar 8: ITV in fresh News at Ten row
Special report: battle of the bulletins
fields.body:
The BBC is clawing back lost ground in the 10pm news war, winning the battle of the bulletins last night by pulling in 1m more viewers than ITV.

The BBC Ten o'Clock News got 6.6m viewers and a 31% audience share; while News at Ten had just 5.6m viewers and a 26% share, according to unofficial overnights.

This was despite ITV's bulletin having a slightly better inheritance from Who Wants to be a Millionaire? than its BBC1 counterpart had from Silent Witness.

Silent Witness was watched by 8.8m overall and 8.9m in its final 15 minutes.

Millionaire averaged 9.3m viewers and 9.2m in its last quarter hour.

News at Ten was the clear ratings winner in the early weeks of the 10pm news battle, which began on Monday January 22.

But in recent weeks, the BBC1 Ten o'Clock News has performed better.

The bulletin has no doubt benefited from viewers' tendency to turn to the BBC for information on national crises, such as railway safety and foot and mouth disease.

BBC1 has also been more competitive earlier in the evening, attracting good audiences for crime dramas such as Silent Witness and In Deep and high ratings for the Phil Mitchell shooting storyline in EastEnders.

Elsewhere last night, ITV docusoap Airline beat BBC1 quiz show the Weakest Link from 8.30pm.

Airline pulled in 10.3m viewers and a 40% share, while the Weakest Link had 7.6m.

fields.headline: The Guardian graduate jobs email
fields.trailText: If you are still unsure on what career path to take, you could do worse than get a new book - Putting First What Matters Most, by Jane Cleland. Do her self-assessment test and the job that best fits your lifestyle will apparently leap off the page. With that in mind, here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.
fields.body:
If you are still unsure on what career path to take, you could do worse than get a new book - Putting First What Matters Most, by Jane Cleland. Do her self-assessment test and the job that best fits your lifestyle will apparently leap off the page. With that in mind, here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.

As usual, we take a look at the best graduate jobs offered by Guardian Unlimited Jobs - the website devoted to finding you the best vacancies.

For all you newly signed up graduates, one thing to watch out for with this email is the URL links included. All of them work but may be too long for your email format. If they do not work when you click on them, try cutting and pasting the whole URL (weird codes and numbers included) into your internet browser.

If you were too busy putting first what matters least at the weekend, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 17 March)

If you're sending off job applications and not including your referees, then you might be missing a trick - particularly if you've got some hot names lined up. Ian Wylie suggests that good references from people who are held in esteem in your industry can place you above the pack.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,458084,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Sarah Richardson looked at the variety of job options you have upon getting a degree and followed two graduates who had done the same degree but taken very different career paths.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,458082,00.html?bnr=email.grad

NEXT WEEK'S RISE looks at how the advertising industry is selling itself to graduates in a bid to pick up the next generation of account execs. There's a look at what working nights will do to your career and to the rest of your life, and there's even some much needed advice on how to get out of debt.

This week's RISE GOLD is a look at the five most common mistakes that everyone makes when compiling their CVs - don't worry, we've all done it. Ian Wylie offers his five steps to CV heaven.

http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,3956174,00.html?bnr=email.grad

THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP

Now could be the time to sort out your referees and find someone whose name will impress on your CV. Trawl through you family friends to find anyone with a Knighthood or similar honour - it always stands out and it could be the thing that gets your CV noticed and you into an interview.

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS.

If you've spent the last three years playing computer games, it could be about to pay dividends. Studio 33 is looking for 2-D and 3-D artists for its "next-gen" console game projects. Based in the North West.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888109314,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Energy company Innogy is looking for graduates who want to work in the IT sector. The ad reads, "Does the thought of narrow-minded managers making your decisions, suffocating your potential appeal to you ... then walk away!" I think they're serious.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888108221,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If the visual arts are your thing, the Customs House arts complex in South Tyneside is looking for a Visual Arts Development Officer and a Marketing Assistant. Salaries a bit on the low side but it could be a great place to work.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888109075,00.html?bnr=email.grad

The Japanese Ministry of Education has this week's most interesting proposal. It is offering 20 postgraduate Research Scholarships for UK graduates to study in Japan from 2002. A love of noodles will help as you'll probably end up living on them.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100109504,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you want to become a copywriter and you hate the big cities, a Cotswolds company wants to train you up. Beware, the ad says they have a "new approach to marketing that's blowing our clients' socks off". At least you've been warned.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888109015,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Graduates with engineering degrees not quite ready to step out of the world of academia should look at Cranfield's engineering doctorate. They're paying a tax-free stipend of at least £11,500 pa for research in a variety of areas over four years.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100109470,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Urban Mines based near Leeds is looking for a grad with a science degree and an interest in recycling to help local companies to "develop new and existing markets in recycled materials".

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888108657,00.html ?bnr=email.grad

And finally, if you know the best place to eat in Mogadishu, Real Holidays in Islington in London has the job for you. They want grads with plenty of globetrotting under their belts to advise their upmarket clients in the ways of travel.

fields.headline: Archie Norman
fields.standfirst:
Tunbridge Wells (1997-)

Ask Aristotle about Archie Norman
fields.trailText: Archie Norman's promotion to the Tory frontbench as shadow environment secretary in 2000 has not been a success. Sometimes stumbling and inarticulate, though undoubtedly bright, Mr Norman was no more qualified for this job than for his previous post as chief executive and deputy chairman of the Conservative party.
fields.body:
Archie Norman's promotion to the Tory frontbench as shadow environment secretary in 2000 has not been a success. Sometimes stumbling and inarticulate, though undoubtedly bright, Mr Norman was no more qualified for this job than for his previous post as chief executive and deputy chairman of the Conservative party.

As an intelligent and focused individual, this failure must have come as a shock. He has self-belief - shown by his fixed grin - and he cannot understand how others do not share his faith.

Both in and outside politics, his rise has been meteoric. The son of doctors, he was educated at Charterhouse, Emmanuel College, Cambridge, and the Harvard Business School. He worked at the efficiency experts McKinsey's, where William Hague was one of his protégés.

He went on to hold directorships on Geest and Railtrack boards before becoming the group finance director of Kingfisher, then Britain's largest retailer, at 32. Within five years, he was group chief executive and by 42 he was chairman, earning £3m a year.

Although he had been involved in various business-associated political campaigns, including one on the net book agreement, it was only in 1996, on the advice of Francis Maude, that he decided to go for safe Tunbridge Wells, vacated by Sir Patrick Mayhew. Mr Norman won easily, although his majority was halved to 7,506.

But his inability to cope adequately in the Commons shows how difficult it is to translate skills learned in other fields into parliament. "Just because Asda checkout girls smile at him, he thinks he's got the common touch," joked Lord Parkinson.

In the Commons, he backed William Hague for the leadership. In return, Mr Hague made him vice-chairman of the party, and entrusted him with its reform and reorganisation. The resulting "Blueprint for change" irritated many in the party proposing to double membership from 300,000 (a failure so far), encourage more female and ethnic members and merge the party's voluntary and professional wings.

MPs were indignant that he wanted the election of leaders to be decided by party members and his "bonding session" for MPs at Eastbourne was boycotted by Sir Edward Heath, Michael Heseltine and Nicholas Soames.

His politics are straight Hagueite: against the euro and sceptical of the national minimum wage. His pride stems from his claim: "I am the only FTSE-100 chairman ever to sit in the Commons". Unfortunately for Mr Norman, he might just be the last.

fields.headline: Ann Widdecombe
fields.standfirst:
Maidstone and the Weald (1987- )

Ask Aristotle about Ann Widdecombe
fields.trailText: Never has a rightwing schoolmistress given so much pleasure to so many as did Ann Widdecombe in October 2000, when the Tory home affairs spokeswoman fell flat on her face after proposing, in her own inimitable style, a £100 on-the-spot fine for cannabis use.
fields.body:
Never has a rightwing schoolmistress given so much pleasure to so many as did Ann Widdecombe in October 2000, when the Tory home affairs spokeswoman fell flat on her face after proposing, in her own inimitable style, a £100 on-the-spot fine for cannabis use.

The whole of the liberal left, the police and even the young trendies on the Daily Telegraph and Daily Mail, tore into her.

They chortled too when seven of her shadow cabinet colleagues rushed to confess they had experimented in their youth with cannabis. Then came the additional blow of Miss Widdecombe's nephew confessing to the News of the World that he had been jailed for drugs use. It was quite a kicking for an MP who had risen from Tory obscurity to media darling in less than a decade.

But these setbacks have not written off her hopes of winning the party leadership - and Miss Widdecombe may yet be the "second coming" of Thatcher - frustrating Michael Portillo's hopes of taking the same job if William Hague fails to dismantle the Labour government's majority at the next election. Her simple authoritarian appeal has a resonance among the grey-haired rank and file members who now dominate the shrunken Tory party and the increasingly rightwing and europhobic Tory MPs.

Partly because of her operatic style, and partly because of her absolute commitment to hard-right views, she has risen in prominence and is arguably the only Tory apart from Mr Hague and Mr Portillo most voters could name. For many, her proposals to extend sentences and spend millions on "secure" detention centres for the 75,000 asylum seekers arriving annually in Britain struck a chord.

Even her oft-proclaimed virginity seems more appealing to the primitive right than Mr Portillo's delayed admission of bisexuality - although some voters of course will be puzzled by her defence of capital punishment but opposition to fox hunting.

In an even more calculated fashion than her equally reactionary party colleague Baroness Young, Miss Widdecombe has assiduously cultivated Britain's "moral majority". A member of the society for the protection of the unborn child from her Oxford days, she was also an early opponent in the Commons of laws allowing easier abortion.

An opponent of ordaining women or divorced men, she first criticised very publicly, and then deserted the "weak kneed liberals" in the Anglican Church into which she was born to return to the Roman Catholic church in which she had been educated. Her reception into the Catholic Church was no private personal affair. Amidst massive self-generated publicity she became the first person since the Reformation to be received into the Catholic Church in the crypt of the Commons.

A fairly restrained eurosceptic herself, Miss Widdecombe is a throwback to the pre-war imperial Tories. Although born in Bath in 1947, her early life was spent in colonial Singapore where her father, James, was head of naval supplies. She still visits regularly her amah (nanny) there, and is a known admirer of the country's cleanliness under its authoritarian government.

When she returned to Bath, she attended a strict Catholic convent, La Sainte Union, where eating meat on Friday was still a mortal sin. She said: "Religion was pushed down your throat. We were forced to go to mass and benediction, but not allowed to attend our own [Anglican] church."

She went on to Birmingham University for a BA in Latin and then Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford, where she studied PPE. Very attractive when young, she had a three-year romance at Oxford but it clearly ended before any lasting damage was done. Asked about sex, she answers: "Yuk! Spare me! That's one thing I don't miss." She prefers her cats.

Miss Widdecombe got the political bug at the Oxford Union, where she was secretary and then treasurer, and helped fellow Tory Michael Ancram in his two 1974 elections. In 1982 she made her name with Lady Olga Maitland as co-founders of women and families for defence, the CND-baiting group. She fought the hopeless seat of Burnley in 1979, where she halved Labour's majority. In 1983 she fought Dr David Owen at Plymouth Devonport, losing again.

Her luck turned when she was selected for the Tory stronghold of Maidstone, which had turned down Margaret Thatcher 25 years before, becoming its first woman MP in 1987. She made her maiden speech in a defence debate, enthusing about Trident as "an effective nuclear deterrent". Her headstrong qualities became apparent in support of David Alton's effort to drastically reduce the time limit for permitted abortions.

In 1988 she launched her own private member's bill to curb abortion, using tactics which affronted fellow anti-abortionist Tories such as Dame Elaine Kellett-Bowman. A decade later, her office walls were still covered with posters showing foetuses.

She strengthened her reputation with the hard right by telling those who had voted for a Liberal Democrat in place of the IRA-murdered Ian Gow that the IRA would be "toasting their success".

When Mrs Thatcher was deposed in November 1990, Miss Widdecombe refused to dine with Edwina Currie and Emma Nicholson, whom she labelled as anti-Thatcher "traitors". She later backed Douglas Hurd as Mrs Thatcher's successor. Despite this, John Major promoted her to under secretary for social security, no doubt to appease Thatcherites. There she said there was "no reason why a person on social security should not be able to afford a normal healthy diet."

She became embroiled in serious controversy after her promotion to minister of state in the Home Office, under fellow rightwinger Michael Howard. She later fell out with Mr Howard over his sacking of Derek Lewis, director general of the prison service, and devastatingly accused him of having "something of the night" about him.

Not only did this quip destroy Mr Howard's hopes of becoming party leader after the 1997 election, it also made Miss Widdecombe something of a celebrity. A rare Tory woman, she rose rapidly with Hague as leader, joining the shadow cabinet as health spokesman in 1998. She made a barnstorming, noteless speech to the party conference - a performance she repeated in Blackpool in 1999, this time as shadow home secretary.

There she won some unexpected plaudits from the left for her emphasis on the need for prison reform and education. But those plaudits became brickbats in Bournemouth in 2000 where her ill thought out references to drugs enraged colleagues and left her looking foolish.

But those plaudits became brickbats in Bournemouth in 2000 where her ill thought out references to drugs enraged colleagues and left her looking foolish. Ask Aristotle about Ann Widdecombe

webTitle: Macedonian crisis does not mean war in Balkans

fields.headline: Macedonian crisis does not mean war in Balkans
fields.standfirst: The Macedonian government's military rhetoric is fuelling tension in the region, writes the Guardian's Balkans specialist Jonathan Steele
fields.trailText: The Macedonian government's military rhetoric is fuelling tension in the region, writes the Guardian's Balkans specialist Jonathan Steele.
fields.body:
The crisis in Macedonia is still far from being another full-scale Balkan war, nor is it just a matter of time before it becomes one.

Nevertheless, the situation is precarious. The good news is that, on the political side, the coalition government of ethnic Albanian and Macedonian parties has not fallen apart and, at the weekend, even the opposition Albanian party supported a parliamentary resolution and condemned the gunmen whose sudden emergence earlier this month surprised almost everyone.

The gunmen have also been condemned by the government of Albania, as well as by Albanian politicians in nearby Kosovo.

There are, however, some major causes of strain. Albanian politicians do not like the hardline rhetoric adopted in the last few days by Ljubco Georgievski, the Macedonian prime minister, who continues to insist the fighters have come from Kosovo, rather than being natives of Macedonia.

Mr Georgievski also says that there is no need to make any concessions because Albanians already have full civil rights in Macedonia. This is proving an irritant to the ethnic Albanian leadership, which believes the gunmen have a point in demanding better rights. It is the use of force they object to.

Meanwhile, the Macedonian government seems increasingly to be turning to the military option. It is beefing up its forces near Tetovo, apparently in readiness for a ground assault.

This is dangerous since it is unlikely to work. The gunmen will probably slip away and may re-emerge near the other largely Albanian town of Gostivar. This would almost certainly widen the crisis.

Nato has promised to send more troops to guard the border between Kosovo and Macedonia, in an attempt to cut the movement of Albanian guerrillas and gunmen. This makes sense as a preventive measure, although the border can never be fully sealed.

Nato should urge the Macedonian government to abandon its military escalation and start a dialogue with the elected Albanians for new constitutional arrangements.

The guerrillas are not yet demanding to sit at the negotiating table, so the Macedonian government would not lose face by opening talks. If, on the other hand, it starts a major offensive in which Albanian civilians are killed, ethnic polarisation will inevitably increase.

fields.headline: Editors greet Express signing with dismay
fields.trailText:
12.15pm update: Desmond's move means rival picture editors can no longer buy Jason Fraser's pictures, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 20: Express snaps up top photographer
Mar 19: Catchpole quits Mirror for Express
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Fleet Street picture editors are aghast this morning at the news top celebrity snapper Jason Fraser has gone to work in-house for Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell.

One picture desk staffer on a national newspaper told MediaGuardian.co.uk "a lot of picture editors will be worried" to discover they will no longer be able to buy Mr Fraser's pictures.

Worse, the photographers who work for Mr Fraser on an affiliate basis will effectively be put out of action as the Express will have first call on their pictures.

"This changes the balance of power in Fleet Street," said one newspaper executive.

"Before Desmond took over, the Express wasn't even in the bidding for stock celebrity pictures.

"It couldn't afford them and it didn't seem to be interested - everything went to the Mail, the Sun and the Mirror.

"Now the boot seems to be on the other foot and this is going to make life difficult for everyone," he added.

Mr Fraser made his name after he captured Princess Diana kissing Dodi al Fayed. But he has managed to dominate the market for celebrities on holidays, covering all the top destinations in the mediterranean and caribbean either himself or affiliated photographers.

One picture desk executive said: "Like all agencies he can come up with a lot of rubbish but he has a knack of pulling things out of the bag."

After Christmas, for instance, Mr Fraser produced the long lens shots of Prince Andrew on holiday in Thailand keeping the tabloids in pictures for at least a week.

He was also responsible for the pictures of Michael Winner on holiday recently.

Mr Fraser confirmed neither he nor any of his affiliates would be able to sell work to any other tabloid newspapers.

However, archive sales will be available through Fraser Woodward, the company of which he was once a director.

"I won't be selling at all," said the 34-year-old paparazzo. "My loyalty is now to Express Newspapers and Northern & Shell.

"And no one I work with will take photographs for other newspapers."

Mr Fraser added: "I won't even be taking photographs... I'm more likely to take holiday snaps."

Last year, work by Mr Fraser or his affiliates accounted for 75 front-page splash pictures in the British press.

Insiders say Mr Desmond's plan to use Mr Fraser to guarantee access to top celebrities could backfire as many distrust him after unwanted coverage in the past.

But Mr Fraser denied they would be put off by his appointment.

"I've taken portraits of the last two prime ministers, I've covered Northern Ireland and earthquakes around the world," he said.

He added his work had never been the subject of a complaint to the Press Complaints Commission.

Mr Fraser will be appointed to the board of management at Northern & Shell, putting him above the papers' editors.

webTitle: NHS quality and performance: the issue explained

fields.headline: NHS quality and performance: the issue explained
fields.trailText: At the heart of Labour's NHS reforms is the belief that the NHS should be dependable - that it should be able to guarantee "fair access and high quality to patients wherever they live".
fields.body:
At the heart of Labour's NHS reforms is the belief that the NHS should be dependable - that it should be able to guarantee "fair access and high quality to patients wherever they live".

When the government came to power in 1997, it said the NHS was in danger of losing public confidence; it was aloof and paternalistic, slow to respond to medical advances and suffered from huge variations in access to services and treatments - the so-called "postcode lottery".

Since then, the government has attempted to reform the NHS with a vast inter-linking network of measures aimed at setting, monitoring and enforcing clear national standards of care and quality, making the service more dynamic, patient-friendly and safer, cutting waiting times and giving patients more choice over where and when they are treated.

The 1998 white paper A First Class Service - Quality in the new NHS sets out how these measures will be introduced. Standards of care will be set through the National Institute of Clinical Excellence (Nice), and through national service frameworks (NSFs).

The latter spell out how specific services - so far, coronary heart disease and mental health, with more planned - should be organised to ensure the best quality and fairest access.

Nice produces guidance about which treatments work best, and which drugs should be available on the NHS. In Scotland this role is carried out by the Health Technology Board for Scotland.

Standards will be delivered locally through clinical governance - essentially a kind of quality assurance audit of treatment, self-regulation of clinicians and improved training for staff.

Scotland and Wales will develop their own quality assurance and accreditation systems.

Monitoring of standards will take place in England and Wales principally though the Commission for Health Improvement (CHI), which also has the power to investigate failing services, and the Audit Commission.

The Clinical Standards Board for Scotland will monitor trust performance north of the border and ensure clinical guidelines are implemented.

A performance assessment framework has been established for England, identifying six key areas of NHS performance. Each year tables are published comparing health authority and trust performance.

National performance assessment frameworks are being developed in both Wales and Scotland. The six areas of performance are: health improvement; fair access to services; effective and appropriate delivery of health care; positive outcomes from health care; efficient use of resources; and an overall high quality of experience for patients and carers. The NHS plan, published in July 2000, introduces a further package of measures designed for the "protection of patients". These include: new mechanisms for dealing with poor performing doctors, including the national clinical assessment authority and reforms to the doctors regulatory body, the General Medical Council.

The NHS plan also pushes forward the performance agenda: it promises a "limited number of ambitious but achievable national targets" such as shorter waiting times for treatment.

It also introduces financial incentives for trusts in England - but not in Wales or Scotland - to raise performance standards, whereby the best performing trusts have access to a National Health Performance Fund worth £500m a year by 2004.

The first few months of the systems has thrown up a dilemma for the NHS over how it handles performance monitoring. How does it identify examples of poor practice, and publicise them, without alienating the NHS by "naming and shaming", or undermining public confidence in the NHS?

The new approach has come under fire in some quarters for being too centralised and prescriptive. Labour has promised "earned autonomy" for health services who perform well - but there is suspicion that this is the reward for doing it Labour's way.

webTitle: Dutch investigate foot and mouth outbreak

fields.headline: Dutch investigate foot and mouth outbreak
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth crisis spread further into Europe today as the Dutch agriculture ministry confirmed it is investigating four suspected cases of the disease in the Netherlands.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth crisis spread further into Europe today as the Dutch agriculture ministry confirmed it is investigating four suspected cases of the disease in the Netherlands.

Preliminary results on four goats had shown signs of the highly contagious disease and more tests were being conducted, the ministry said. Final results should be available on Friday.

The ministry said the farm and three companies that had handled the animals were under observation, and the areas around them were closed for a six mile radius. About 300 head of cattle and four goats were to be destroyed tomorrow as a precautionary measure, said spokeswoman Martina de Ham.

The animals were from a farm near the eastern town of Oene in the province of Gelderland. Tests were being conducted on all livestock within two miles of the farm, the ministry said.

Yesterday the government lifted six day old restrictions on transporting cloven hoofed animals to slaughterhouses, except in a small area of Gelderland. The ministry said there was no immediate plan to reimpose the restrictions outside the quarantined area.

Dutch farmers already have destroyed thousands of cattle, sheep, goats and deer imported from Britain and France after the disease was discovered in those countries. Until today there had been no serious symptoms detected in the Netherlands.

The number of cases in Britain has risen to 368 since the outbreak began last month, but only six cases have been detected on the European continent, all on a cattle farm in north west France last week. The French government says the disease has been contained.

The Dutch were hard hit by international ban on buying livestock and meat products from Europe. Dutch farmers sold more than 9bn guilders (£2.6bn) worth of meat and animals in 1999.

fields.headline: Friends of the Earth joins Ford for traffic initiative
fields.trailText: 4pm: Ford has joined forces with Friends of the Earth to find a solution to London's traffic problems, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Ford has joined forces with Friends of the Earth to try to find a solution to London's traffic problems.

A fleet of electric cars will hit the streets of the capital this summer as part of a sustainable motoring project called "Think about London".

It forms part of a larger Ford study in to the future of sustainable mobility. Ford hopes to get the governmental backing for the project.

"We hope to work with central and local government to look at issues like provision of recharging points, subsidised parking and what part these vehicles might play in emission controlled zones in urban areas," said Dr Wolfgang Schneider, vice-president legal, governmental, legal and environmental affairs of Ford Europe.

"In addition to the air quality benefits, we will also be examining ways of working with the London boroughs to improve congestion."

London businesses such as creative agencies, media firms and internet companies are being asked to volunteer to take part in the project.

They will be offered one of 15 "Think City" electric cars at cut price.

In return they will be asked for feedback on how the vehicles are used and ways in which they can help to solve city transport problems.

The two-seater Think City car has been created by Ford to study the development and marketing of a range of "environmentally-sensitive" vehicles for use in urban areas.

The car produces zero emissions, runs silently, has 0-50kph acceleration in seven seconds and a top speed of 90kph.
