webTitle: How to stage a council strike

fields.headline: How to stage a council strike
fields.standfirst: Workers in councils across the country are considering striking - but the process that has to be completed before any action can begin may test the hardiest worker's resolve, writes David Harding
fields.trailText: Workers in councils across the country are considering striking - but the process that has to be completed before any action can begin may test the hardiest worker's resolve, writes David Harding.
fields.body:
"Being on strike," says John Mulrenan at the London Borough of Southwark, "I find it both exhilarating and worrying at the same time. It depends on how confident you are of winning."

"When you are confident not only is striking a just cause, it is an extremely enjoyable experience."

Mr Mulrenan, a full-time lay official with Unison at Southwark, is a veteran of town hall strikes. In the 1980s he was on the picket lines over pay. In 1999, he was there again. He admits that being on the picket line can be very boring, and industrial action is never undertaken lightly. But it is something hundreds, even thousands, of local government workers embark upon every year.

This year has seen industrial action take place among council workers across Scotland, in Hackney, Plymouth and Knowsley. Torbay, Walsall, Hammersmith and Bristol could all soon follow suit, hinting at a new militancy at local level.

"I think there is a resurgence, a willingness to take action over the last two or three years," says Mr Mulrenan.

Low pay, deteriorating working conditions and increased privatisation have combined, say those in local government, to make town hall workers more determined to defend their position. Falling unemployment levels have made them increasingly more confident to do this through industrial action.

But the process that has to be completed before any action can begin may test the hardiest worker's resolve. The rules on how and when industrial action can take place are governed by two pieces of legislation: the Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992; and the Employment Relations Act 1999.

These acts, legacies of the Thatcherite era in British industrial relations and a cautious attempt by New Labour to try and reverse some of those policies, put formidable barriers in the way of unions attempting action.

A typical attempt at strike action would go something like this. Once negotiations between employees and the employer break down, the union would embark upon a consultative ballot of members to see if there is any desire for taking action. If yes, the local union will make an application to the national executive to hold a formal industrial ballot.

This ballot will ask two questions of the members. Are they prepared to take strike action; or are they prepared to take action short of a strike, such as an overtime ban? An official ballot has to be carried out by a recognised independent body such as Electoral Reform Services or Unity Ballot Services.

The union has a duty to identify all those taking part, though there is increasing controversy over whether that should mean a full list of names or just the departments balloted. This caught the RMT out earlier this year when a court ruled that its members could not proceed with a 24-hour strike on the London Underground because it had not identified who was taking part.

If a yes vote is given for strike action, the union then has to decide whether to go ahead. It has 28 days to enact action. If no action is taken within that time then it loses the right to strike.

A union also has to give seven days notice to employers to inform them what action they will take, tell them who is going to be involved and who will be affected. The whole process could leave the unions with a bill approaching £10,000.

"The unions have to be very clear and stick to the law," says Paul O' Shea, regional secretary with Unison's south west region,

The days of the caricatured trade union member downing tools over the merest inconvenience have long gone.

These rules, say union members, are designed to check any initial enthusiasm for action. "They take the heat out of the situation," says Martin Smith, an organiser with the GMB London region.

Getting an accurate figure on how many local government workers take action each year is difficult. In 1999, Office for National Statistics figures show that 35,000 working days were lost to action across the public sector. By last year that had climbed to just over 53,000.

Although strike action has declined over recent years - figures from the international Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development show Britain has the eighth lowest total among 23 member countries - there is a belief that this could change in local government.

"There is an increase in militancy amongst members and those coming into the movement. I think there's going to be a lot of action," says Mr Smith.

These acts, legacies of the Thatcherite era in British industrial relations and a cautious attempt by New Labour to try and reverse some of those policies, put formidable barriers in the way of unions attempting action. A typical attempt at strike action would go something like this. Once negotiations between employees and the employer break down, the union would embark upon a consultative ballot of members to see if there is any desire for taking action. If yes, the local union will make an application to the national executive to hold a formal industrial ballot. This ballot will ask two questions of the members. Are they prepared to take strike action; or are they prepared to take action short of a strike, such as an overtime ban? An official ballot has to be carried out by a recognised independent body such as Electoral Reform Services or Unity Ballot Services. The union has a duty to identify all those taking part, though there is increasing controversy over whether that should mean a full list of names or just the departments balloted. This caught the RMT out earlier this year when a court ruled that its members could not proceed with a 24-hour strike on the London Underground because it had not identified who was taking part. If a yes vote is given for strike action, the union then has to decide whether to go ahead. It has 28 days to enact action. If no action is taken within that time then it loses the right to strike. A union also has to give seven days notice to employers to inform them what action they will take, tell them who is going to be involved and who will be affected. The whole process could leave the unions with a bill approaching £10,000. "The unions have to be very clear and stick to the law," says Paul O' Shea, regional secretary with Unison's south west region, The days of the caricatured trade union member downing tools over the merest inconvenience have long gone. These rules, say union members, are designed to check any initial enthusiasm for action. "They take the heat out of the situation," says Martin Smith, an organiser with the GMB London region. Getting an accurate figure on how many local government workers take action each year is difficult. In 1999, Office for National Statistics figures show that 35,000 working days were lost to action across the public sector. By last year that had climbed to just over 53,000. Although strike action has declined over recent years - figures from the international Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development show Britain has the eighth lowest total among 23 member countries - there is a belief that this could change in local government. "There is an increase in militancy amongst members and those coming into the movement. I think there's going to be a lot of action," says Mr Smith.

fields.headline: NHS staff: the basics
fields.trailText: • Just under one million people work in the NHS - equivalent to around 780,000 full time staff - making it the biggest single employer in Europe, if not the world. Around 500,000 of these are "front line" staff, such as nurses and doctors, providing health care direct to the public.
fields.body:
 Just under one million people work in the NHS - equivalent to around 780,000 full time staff - making it the biggest single employer in Europe, if not the world. Around 500,000 of these are "front line" staff, such as nurses and doctors, providing health care direct to the public.

 The NHS is suffering severe staff shortages, particularly in nursing and midwifery, and in certain medical specialties. There are also recruitment and retention problems in physiotherapy and general practice.

 The NHS plan, published in July 2000, commits the government to hiring 7,500 more consultants, 2,000 more GPs, 20,000 more nurses and over 6,500 more therapists and other professionals by 2004.

 The government has announced a range of measures to attract and retain staff, including incentive payments, better working conditions, more opportunities for career development and help with accommodation in high-cost areas of the country.

 The government also wants to "modernise" the NHS professions. Its NHS plan outlines measures which will: "break down" the barriers between clinical groups; ensure clinical work is monitored for quality; ensure skills are constantly updated and encourage more joint working between NHS and social care staff.

webTitle: Best of both worlds in BHP merger

fields.headline: Best of both worlds in BHP merger
fields.trailText: Metal and mining groups BHP and Billiton yesterday said that their proposed £20bn merger would leave them with a unified management structure but separate stock market listings and assets.
fields.body:
Metal and mining groups BHP and Billiton yesterday said that their proposed £20bn merger would leave them with a unified management structure but separate stock market listings and assets.

The structure for the new venture, to be called BHP Billiton, has been driven by the desire to retain primary listings in both the London and Australian stock markets.

The new grouping will be the world's second largest mining company. Had the Australian-based BHP taken over Billiton, it would not have secured inclusion in the FTSE index because it was foreign-based. It would therefore not be included in FTSE index tracking funds.

UBS Warburg, BHP's financial advisers, said that a Billiton bid for BHP had been ruled out because it would have caused tax problems for many of the Australian company's private shareholders.

Paul Anderson, BHP's chief executive, said: "There's no question that this is the proper combination and will create more value for both sets of shareholders." The merger will leave BHP shareholders with a 58% interest in the new venture and Billiton shareholders with 42%.

Rival mining group Anglo-American, which has been tipped as a possible counterbidder, said it would be studying the proposal with interest.

The market welcomed yesterday's announcement, lifting Billiton shares to a new high for the year and ensuring that Anglo would have to pay a large premium if it were to intervene.

The boards of BHP and Billiton have sought to discourage intervention by a third party. Should either board decide to walk away from yesterday's deal, it would have to pay $100m (£69m) compensation to its erstwhile partner. However no payment will be made if shareholders reject the deal.

Mining groups RTZ and CRA adopted a similar dual listing structure when they merged five years ago.

BHP and Billiton said no ownership would change as part of the deal. This prevents partners in the mining venture from exercising pre-exemption rights triggered by change of ownership.

BHP has agreed to spin off its steel business to its shareholders in order to focus the new venture on mining and petroleum.

fields.headline: Gullane profits almost double
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: The company that produces Thomas the Tank Engine, Sooty and Art Attack has boosted it profits by 80%, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The company that produces Thomas the Tank Engine, Sooty and Art Attack has almost doubled it profits.

Gillane Entertainment's pre-tax profits for the second half of 2000 have grown by 80% to £4.3m

The sharp rise came on the back of a 78% hike in revenues (excluding revenue from the Thomas the Tank Engine feature film) to £13.3m.

If the movie revenues are included - Gullane made only a small profit on the film because of its limited investment - the total for the period comes to £20.3m.

Gullane shares, which have outperformed the media sector by 25% in the past six months, were up 5.9% by late morning, valuing the company at £180m.

"Our three leading properties - Art Attack, Sooty and Thomas - are expanding rapidly. New productions, further distribution deals and higher merchandise revenues are playing a full part in our growth," said William Harris, chief executive of Gullane.

"This progress will be supported by a fully focused acquisition programme."

A 26-part Thomas the Tank Engine & Friends TV series has gone into production, and Gullane is planning to make 78 episodes by next summer.

ITV has also recommissioned Gullane shows Art Attack, Sooty, ZZZAP! and Mystery for 2001.

webTitle: Granada chief to keep Arts Council role

fields.headline: Granada chief to keep Arts Council role
fields.trailText: 3pm: Arts Council chairman Gerry Robinson was today given a further three years in the post by culture secretary Chris Smith.
fields.body:
Arts Council chairman Gerry Robinson was today given a further three years in the post by culture ecretary Chris Smith.

Mr Robinson, chairman of Granada, was first appointed to the position in May 1998 and this extension will run until January 2004.

His continued role at the Arts Council of England comes at a crucial time. Last week it was announced the body is to amalgamate with the 10 regional arts boards to create a single arts funding organisation.

"He has brought about changes to the Arts Council and its Regional Arts Boards which will continue to benefit the arts and their audiences," he said.

"In particular he has fashioned a more strategic role for the Arts Council. He has been a great champion of the arts, and I look forward to the continuation of his excellent work in furthering the cause of the arts in this country."

Mr Robinson is not paid for the post but is able to claim reasonable expenses. He was a supporter of the Labour party prior to the last general election.

fields.headline: Chime Online profits climb 43%
fields.trailText: 3pm: Chime Communications has bucked the anti-dot.com trend by turning a profit on its web division, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Lord Bell's Chime Communications has bucked the anti-dot.com trend by turning a profit on its internet division.

Chime Online, the year-old internet arm of the advertising to PR group, produced an operating profit of £2m on revenues of £11m in its first year.

Chime's pre-tax profits grew by 43% to £14.3m in 2000, on turnover that was up by 55% to £147.9m.

"Our income growth is impressive, our profit growth is above average and our profit margin is at top levels for our industry," said Lord Bell.

"Our growth strategy gives us many opportunities for good acquisitions and our organic growth record underscores a very strong group of brands.

"The first few months of 2001 are well ahead of last year," he said.

fields.headline: Hasselbaink hits out at 'old' Chelsea
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has criticised Chelsea for failing to invest in youth and says the club is going nowhere. The Dutch striker says the Blues have too many old players and compares them unfavourably with one of his former clubs Leeds United.
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has criticised Chelsea for failing to invest in youth and says the club is going nowhere. The Dutch striker says the Blues have too many old players and compares them unfavourably with one of his former clubs Leeds United.

Hasselbaink, signed by Chelsea last summer for £15m, says: "I'm 28, but I'm one of the youngest players of the squad, and this is very bad. We have a good team, but we are old. We must recruit young blood or look for it in Chelsea's youth system."

He cites Leeds as the example Chelsea should be following. "Leeds are doing the right things. They sign a high quality player but at the same time they continue to look after their youngsters."

Hasselbaink is frustrated that having suffered relegation with Atletico Madrid in Spain last season - despite having scored 25 goals - he joined a Chelsea side who have failed to make an impact in either the Premiership or Europe.

His concerns increased on Saturday when Chelsea's faint hopes of a Champions League spot were all but dashed after the 4-2 home defeat by Sunderland.

"One year I play for a team that is relegated and the next I play for a team that goes nowhere," he says. "Sometimes I think I am in the wrong place at the wrong time. I'm not very lucky with the teams I choose to play for."

He has also been the butt of training ground humour. "When we train my team-mates are constantly saying stupid things. They say 'Hey, Jimmy, do you know where we were last season without you? Now you are here and we're trying not to get relegated.' "

webTitle: Bobos bow to Bertrand's discreet charm

fields.headline: Bobos bow to Bertrand's discreet charm
fields.trailText: Comment: Paris this morning was like any Monday. Nothing has changed, and yet, everything has changed, writes Marie Guichoux.
fields.body:
In Paris this morning the Metro is running, motorists are insulting one another, and the cafes are laying out their tables on the streets.

Like any Monday. Nothing has changed, and yet, everything has changed.

For 25 years it was a bastion of De Gaulle's heirs. Now it is in the hands of a Socialist, Bertrand Delanoë, who can stick in his scrapbook his most famous response: "You recognise me?" Winning Paris is the best remedy anyone has invented for lack of fame.

Our Bertrand is not your Ken. He is not red but rather a tender shade of pink, and has nothing of the provocateur. Everyone has forgotten that in his 30s he was No 3 in the Socialist party ranks, and that, approaching his 50s, he was not the Socialist hierarchy's first choice: they were thinking of someone more flamboyant to lead the battle of Paris.

This handicap turned into a major asset. At least this one will not dream of the presidential elections and will take care of us and our city, thought Parisians, tired of seeing the town hall used as an electoral war room and national springboard.

Bertrand the discreet has promised to bring morality back into Parisian public life, and no one had much trouble believing him, since the town hall facade has cracked so much in recent years, revealing the RPR system's scandals of every kind.

It is a revolution without revolutionaries, a gasp of fresh air that ends in a change of era. The bobos (bohemian bourgeois) and the lilis (liberal-libertarians) of the capital want to improve their quality of life.

The environment, pollution, public transport head their list of worries. And Bertrand Delanoë has nursed them with practical proposals: a tramway on the boulevards around the capital, 2,000 nursery places, 60 reception classes - even the restoration of the Molitor swimming pool, a 1930s building on the outskirts of the Bois de Boulogne which has become a sad wreck.

Nothing compared with the pharaonic projects of the late François Mitterrand, who was Delanoë's political mentor. But time are changing, and modesty is at stake. Furthermore the new mayor - a man both proud and confident - must not believe himself the ghost of Mitterrand and start dreaming of great projects.

You would not forgive me for forgetting a biographical detail: the new man of Paris "came out " two years ago. This won him a vengeful outburst from a beaten RPR candidate, who grumbled privately: "It's the Cage aux Folles at the town hall!"

Otherwise, in Paris, nobody cares. And that too is a beautiful victory.

 Marie Guichoux is a senior editor at the daily Libération

fields.headline: Publicis stalls on Interpublic offer
fields.trailText:
2.30pm update: Publicis has said it wants to know more about Interpublic's offer for True North. By Claire Cozens
Mar 19: Interpublic swoops for True North
fields.body:
True North's biggest shareholder, Publicis, has said it will need more details about Interpublic's offer before agreeing to sell its 9% stake.

In a bizarrely-worded press statement, Publicis said it had "learnt that the True North saga [has] ended" and that it had "known for years that True North could not have a future as an independent group".

Publicis said it believed the offer, which values the company at £1.39bn, was "at the bottom end of the price range", but refused to comment further on whether it would agree to sell its shares.

The hostile tone of the statement stems from the long-standing feud between Publicis and True North following their bitter divorce.

The two companies joined forces in 1989 to create a global network called Publicis Communication.

In 1997 they split acrimoniously and Publicis chairman Maurice Levy launched a hostile takeover bid for the US company. The bid failed, but Publicis retained a 9% stake in True North.

fields.headline: Microsoft fleshes out web strategy
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Microsoft has unveiled plans to dominate the internet with new software expected to be even bigger than Windows, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Microsoft has for the first time spelt out details of how it plans to extend its dominance in the computing world to the internet with new software expected to be even bigger than Windows.

Bill Gates is hoping to convert the 230m people who use Microsoft software to his latest technological development and ultimately knock internet giants such as AOL Time Warner and Yahoo! off their perches.

Microsoft's much-vaunted ".Net strategy" was unveiled last summer but was derided as badly conceived and confusing by journalists and analysts alike.

Microsoft expects the new system, tentatively called HailStorm, to be as big as Windows, its dominant PC software.

The move will pit the software giant directly against the likes of AOL Time Warner and Yahoo, who are also currently building their businesses around cross-platform internet services.

It will effectively integrate Microsoft's operations, from its free Passport service that lets users store passwords and credit card numbers so they don't have to keep typing them in, to Hotmail and MSN Messenger, Microsoft's instant messaging service.

Instead of just buying a plane ticket from Microsoft's Expedia, when users subscribe to HailStorm's services they will be able to use any platform - computer, handheld device or mobile - to buy products, order currency, download destination information and then find out whether the plane is on time.

In its final form, HailStorm will act as a simple organiser for users who can access all the services while on the move.

In order to develop HailStorm, Microsoft has to work with competitors such as Apple and Palm, as well as sign up e-commerce companies including eBay.

"The whole vision of having multiple devices can only work if magically, behind the scenes, the information is moving between those devices without the user having to be involved," said Mr Gates, Microsoft's chairman and chief software architect.

Mr Gates said he believed Microsoft customers, of which there are 230m worldwide, would be willing to pay for these type of services as well as forking out for computer software such as Microsoft Office.

The step towards subscription-based internet service could speed up the desperately required revamp of the internet industry, which has hitherto relied on banner advertising and sponsorships.

HailStorm, which will launch next year, is the first set of services to clearly define what the company plans to do with .Net

fields.headline: US politician joins Britney in Pepsi advert
fields.trailText: 2pm: US senator Bob Dole is to appear alongside Britney Spears in a new advert for Pepsi, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
In an extraordinary move US senator Bob Dole is to throw his weight behind Pepsi by appearing in a new advert alongside Britney Spears.

The revelation comes as Pepsi prepares to debut the new Spears advert on the internet before its breaks on TV.

But teen temptress Spears may be eclipsed by the appearance of Senator Dole, who is shown viewing the singer's performance.

It is highly unusual for politicians to endorse particular brands, let alone appear in their advertising.

But the Republican politician, who lost out to Bill Clinton in the 1996 US presidential elections, has already endorsed Pepsi in a US advert screened last month during the Super Bowl.

The ad will be shown on the internet two hours before its US TV primetime screening during the Oscars coverage on March 25. It is the first time Pepsi has premiered an advert online.

Related story

webTitle: US rightwingers fight to control courts

fields.headline: US rightwingers fight to control courts
fields.standfirst: A battle to remould the judiciary in America could have even more significant implications than last year's turbulent election, writes Julian Borger
fields.trailText: A battle to remould the judiciary in America could have even more significant implications than last year's turbulent election, writes Julian Borger.
fields.body:
The conservative right controls the US executive and legislature by the narrowest of margins. Now, in a quiet but crucial struggle under way in Washington, it is trying to use that advantage to remould the third branch of government, the judiciary, in its own image.

The battle's first volleys were fired yesterday, when the leaders of the American Bar Association (ABA), the US lawyers' professional body, were summoned by President Bush's chief legal adviser, Alberto Gonzalez, and told its half-century-old role as a vetting filter for federal judicial appointments might be at an end. If so, it will be treated just like any another pressure group.

If the ABA is knocked off its perch, it would represent a decisive victory for the Federalist Society, a conservative group little known outside US legal circles, but one which has amassed a significant degree of power behind the scenes, in law schools and legal firms around the country.

All this may sound dusty and arcane, but it could yet prove to be even more significant for the long-term future of the US than last year's turbulent election. In the States some of the defining policy judgments of recent decades have been made by the courts, including Roe v Wade, guaranteeing the right to an abortion, or Brown v the Board of Education, desegregating schools.

The Federalist Society is seeking to gain control of the federal courts in order to recast the American legal landscape for a generation. In particular, the Federalists, drawing their inspiration from the writings of James Madison, one of the nation's "founding fathers", want to cut back the role of central government to the minimum possible.

They are opposed, in particular, to Washington's role in promoting racial equality through affirmative action. They are against sexual harassment and gender equality laws, which they see as an infringement on the rights of private organisations.

The Federalists are also opposed to the powers of the environmental protection agency - pollution control, they argue, should be regulated by the free market or, at most, by local or state government.

Meanwhile, the ABA, which is identified with the legal status quo of the postwar era, has been painted as hopelessly liberal by the conservative right. The irony underlying the current situation is that the conservatives, for all their faith in states' rights and limited federal government, were brought to power in December by an act of federal intervention in what is normally considered a state matter.

Federalists would generally argue that debates over the conduct of elections in any state are the exclusive concern of the courts of that state. However, when the Florida supreme court ordered a manual recount of votes in the presidential election claimed by George Bush, it was Ted Olson, a leading member of the Federalist Society, who argued the case for federal intervention, and it was Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, the society's two patrons in the supreme court, who helped Bush ultimately to prevail.

Mr Olson is now solicitor general, and is in the company of plenty of other Federalists in the new administration. Spencer Abraham, the anti-regulation energy secretary, is a founder member, as is his chief legal adviser, Lee Liberman Otis.

Filling judicial posts was never a priority for the Clinton administration, and many vacancies on federal district and appeals courts around the country went unfilled for years. The Bush administration has taken control of the judiciary much more seriously, and has made filling the 100 currently vacant positions a priority.

The young team that has been assembled to vet candidates is made up exclusively of Federalists, several of whom worked as clerks for Justices Scalia and Thomas. Others were staffers for Kenneth Starr, President Clinton's leading inquisitor in the impeachment drama, and another Federalist leading light.

Social liberals have watched the steady rise of the Federalists with alarm. The Institute for Democracy Studies (IDS), a liberal watchdog, has analysed the society's burgeoning power and sees it as a threat to the advances made towards racial and sexual equality in the "great society" era of the 60s.

Alfred Ross, the IDS president, said yesterday: "The growing role of the Federalist Society and other rightwing legal groups opens the door to populating the federal judiciary and administrative agencies with extremist ideologues who are determined to overthrow the legacy of social justice in America."

fields.headline: Charity finance: the basics
fields.trailText: • Charity finances are in a precarious position. Problems include short-term funding, intense fundraising competition, a drop in the value of equities and the vagaries of the VAT system.
fields.body:
 Charity finances are in a precarious position. Problems include short-term funding, intense fundraising competition, a drop in the value of equities and the vagaries of the VAT system.

 Annual accounts are subject to scrutiny by charity committees and the media - and can sway public confidence in charities if they show too much spending on overheads and not enough on projects. The new statement of recommended practice (SORP) is designed to tackle this, making charities more transparent and accountable.

 Charities are faced with a plethora of auditing requirements from different funders. Donors, including the national lottery, government departments and grant-making trusts all have different criteria for charity audits.

 Chancellor Gordon Brown introduced tax incentives to boost charity finances in 2000, but charity managers don't think he went far enough

 The new Trustee Act gives much more freedom to how charity money is invested, but charities need to start investing their reserves in a more socially and environmentally responsible way.

webTitle: Scottish local government: the issue explained

fields.headline: Scottish local government: the issue explained
fields.standfirst: Scottish local government has a close relationship with parliament and the executive, but difficulties are developing between the two sides over issues such as proportional representation. Simon Parker explains
fields.trailText: Scottish local government has a close relationship with parliament and the executive, but difficulties are developing between the two sides over issues such as proportional representation.
fields.body:
Being part of the Scottish political scene must be a little like being in an episode of the US sitcom Cheers - everybody knows your name. This is partly because many of the country's politicians share the same background. They have grown up in the country's central belt, attended one of its handful of universities, joined the Labour party and served on one of the country's 32 councils.

Take Angus McKay, now the Scottish executive's finance and local government minister, but still finance convenor at Edinburgh city council in July 1999. Or the late Donald Dewar, who gave after dinner speeches at the kind of local government conferences that, in England, could only command the likes of local government minister Hilary Armstrong for any length of time.

These ties make the relationship between local and central government north of the border enviably close, but that does not mean Scottish councils have not been affected by the shockwaves from the devolution settlement. Labour's grasp on the country has already been eroded by proportional representation (PR) in Holyrood, where the party is in coalition with the Liberal Democrats. This, in turn, has put the issue of extending PR to local authorities on the agenda, threatening to further loosen Labour's grip.

Pressure has grown for movement on local PR, with the Scottish executive's Kerley report recommending the single transferable vote for council elections. Labour's local politicians naturally object to potentially giving up their power, and the party's backbenchers at Holyrood look set to scupper any attempt to introduce the system.

In terms of changing local government itself, the executive has chosen a different policy line to that plotted in England. Scotland, for instance, is not forcing its councils to change their political structures. Some, including Edinburgh, are voluntarily adopting Westminster-style executive cabinets, but there is no mechanism for electing a city mayor.

Scotland is ahead of England in reforming local government finance. Spending guidelines, which used to set upper limits for local authority spending, have been abolished, although Scottish ministers retain capping powers. Local government spending allocations and council tax are being set over a three-year period and the formula for handing out funds is to be simplified.

It is not just finance that is being shaken up. The 25-year-old Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) lost four of its members earlier this year. The pull-out was led by Glasgow city council, which felt it had received a raw deal in last year's three-year local government finance settlement. It was followed by other authorities voicing concern over the cost of Cosla membership. They included SNP controlled Clackmannanshire, which objected to what its leaders saw as a Labour-dominated organisation.

The remaining members have insisted that Cosla undergo a root and branch review of its function, size and costs. Like Scottish politics as a whole, the convention will have to adapt quickly to a new political climate.

webTitle: Academy punishes Hollywood studios over Oscar campaigns

fields.headline: Academy punishes Hollywood studios over Oscar campaigns
fields.trailText: DreamWorks and Sony Pictures Classics have had tickets for Sunday's Oscar ceremony withdrawn after their campaigns for Gladiator and Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon broke Academy rules
fields.body:
DreamWorks and Sony Pictures Classics have both been punished by the Academy for violations of the rules surrounding Oscar campaigning, reports Variety.

The penalties come amid an unprecedentedly vigorous and comprehensive marketing surge for the five Best Film nominations as Sunday's ceremony approaches. The offending films are DreamWorks' Gladiator and Sony's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon - the two most-nominated movies in competition.

In the case of Gladiator, the studio was penalised for using an image of an Oscar statuette in print adverts, while Sony Classics transgressed by sending DVD copies of Ang Lee's martial arts romance to Academy members who had already received a video version. Each studio was forced to surrender four tickets to Sunday's show at the Shrine Auditorium.

More significantly than these minor penalties, however, is the climate they reveal. The $28.2m (£19.76m) box-office boost that falls, on average, to the Best Film winner has this year inspired highly unorthodox campaign drives in an unusually open field of Oscar candidates.

Nominated stars are making more public appearances than ever and the studios have increased spending on TV spots. Rather than the usual excerpts from films, promo ads for Traffic and Chocolat employ stars (such as Michael Douglas and Johnny Depp) to sing the praises of their directors and producers.

Actors seem to be realising that the Oscar nod may be a once-in-a-career privilege as well. "They recognize this as their time," an unnamed publicist tells Variety. "I've known people who later regretted not getting out and promoting themselves. People assume that if they're in the running this year that they'll be in it again. And that's not always the case."

fields.headline: David Willetts
fields.standfirst:
Havant (1992-)

Ask Aristotle about David Willetts
fields.trailText: David Willetts has consistently backed every rightwing cause: the poll tax, the Tories' NHS reforms, which he pioneered, and proposals to raise the pensionable age to 67. He urged the unemployed to undercut wage standards to get jobs and opposed a national minimum wage, predicting 1m job losses from it.
fields.body:
David Willetts has consistently backed every rightwing cause: the poll tax, the Tories' NHS reforms, which he pioneered, and proposals to raise the pensionable age to 67. He urged the unemployed to undercut wage standards to get jobs and opposed a national minimum wage, predicting 1m job losses from it.

Nobody has doubted Mr Willetts' high intelligence, only the quality of some of his judgments. He is an intellectual Thatcherite, a member of her No Turning Back cheering clique. After serving in her policy unit at No 10 he became director of studies at the rightwing centre for policy studies before inheriting the safe seat of Havant in 1992.

Despite this he is suspect among unbending Thatcherites because he tried to cosy up to John Major when he became prime minister.

David Willetts has also been constrained by two nicknames at war with each other. First he was tagged "Two Brains" by Michael White of the Guardian. This stuck as it became clear that on his coolly creative calculations rest Tory hopes of matching their spending plans with their tax promises. Used sardonically, it also conveys his special quality of superior omniscience.

The other nickname, the Young Dissembler, arose from his unconvincing effort, while he was party whip, to explain away his memo to the members' interest select committee, in which he noted that the committee's Tory chairman, Sir Geoffrey Johnson-Smith, "wants our advice". The Sunday Times exposed the document, claiming that Mr Willetts had wanted the committee's Tory majority to smother an inquiry into Neil Hamilton's cash-for-questions affair, thus compelling his resignation as paymaster general (1996). Mr Willetts pleaded his inexperience as a junior whip for using "want" in the archaic sense of "lacks" but Robert Harris, writing in the Sunday Times, was not convinced and sneered that this argument required "a special kind of idiot, who takes a first in PPE at Christ Church".

It would be wrong to suggest that this Birmingham-born 44-year-old is completely a dried up rightwing stick. As shadow social security secretary (1999- ) he was one of the seven members of the shadow cabinet who pulled the rug from under shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe in the wake of her proposal for zero tolerance for cannabis users, by confessing to youthful indulgence. He said, "I had two puffs, didn't like it and have never had any experience of drugs since."

fields.headline: Dennis Skinner
fields.standfirst:
Bolsover (1970-)

Ask Aristotle about Dennis Skinner
fields.trailText: Dennis Skinner is unique, part parliamentary court jester, and part leftwing crusader. Familiar throughout the nation and loathed and liked with equal passion within Westminster, his great days may now be over.
fields.body:
Dennis Skinner is unique, part parliamentary court jester, and part leftwing crusader. Familiar throughout the nation and loathed and liked with equal passion within Westminster, his great days may now be over.

Although warmly welcomed back in 2000 after his cancer specialist gave him the all clear, MPs have only seen a muted version of Mr Skinner since his return. Once Labour's leftwing Cromwell, the unyielding, incorruptible, puritanical, abrasively proletarian conscience of the hard left, he has recently seemed to pull his punches.

Even before his illness, Tony Blair's affectionate tolerance of this NEC member made him seem less a menace, more a mascot, who, in Ken Livingstone's words, was "allowed to do terrible things on the best carpet." He could hardly kick with conviction the shins of a Labour government starting to help ex-miners, even if he was the last known defender of Arthur Scargill.

Despite his age, Mr Skinner can still sometimes display the brilliant timing of his humorous, ego deflating interjections of old, but he would be the first to admit that attacking divided Tories since the mid-1990s has been much like shooting fish in a barrel. Still, he remains fiercely class conscious, enraged when it is suggested that he might live in middle class Chelsea with his American girlfriend. She was his researcher until he separated from his wife Mary in 1989.

The end of his marriage also put him at odds with his two brothers, once extolled by him as the "Clay Cross martyrs" - Clay Cross being the pit village of his Derbyshire youth.

Mr Skinner was the third of nine children of the miner Edward Skinner, who was sacked after the 1926 general strike, and Mr Skinner's thin skin can be attributed to the failure of his father ever to give him the praise he craved. As a star student, he entered Tupton grammar school at 10 and is remembered for trying to become a heel-and-toe champion and singing Cole Porter lyrics in local workingmen's clubs.

At 17 he followed his father into the mines, first at Parkhouse colliery, near Clay Cross, then at Glapwell colliery, near Chesterfield. By 1966, at 34, he was president of the Derbyshire miners. Selected to succeed another miner, Harold Neal, he became the MP for Bolsover with a majority of more than 20,000 in 1970.

From the beginning he was the anthracite of the hard left, backing any other leftwing faction when not defending his own miners' caste. He opposed all punishment of left rebellions or expulsions, no matter how disruptive. Early in his career he earned his famous tag, Beast of Bolsover, from MP actor Andrew Faulds, after he accused Mr Faulds of lobbying for the Arabs. Mr Skinner's dislike of oil from the Middle East came from the fact that it competed with his coal.

The height of his political career was in the 1980s - he was a member of Labour's NEC from 1988 and the terror of the Tory benches. But Labour MPs sometimes resented his showmanlike parliamentary interventions, such as his suggestion to Margaret Thatcher on the day she resigned that she become the head of the centralised European bank.

He was notably embarrassed on his 65th birthday shortly before the 1997 general election when John Major congratulated him on becoming a pensioner. Surprisingly, he failed to regain his NEC position in 1998, but was returned again in 1999 despite poor health. Mr Skinner remains determined to run again at the next election despite mutterings about his age.

In battling for lefty and miners' causes, Mr Skinner learned an important lesson: "I realised that you could get into trouble with a dull speech. But if you can keep them laughing, you can get away with murder." He has done that for more than 30 years in his grumpy Derbyshire growl.

Early in his career he earned his famous tag, Beast of Bolsover, from MP actor Andrew Faulds, after he accused Mr Faulds of lobbying for the Arabs. Mr Skinner's dislike of oil from the Middle East came from the fact that it competed with his coal. The height of his political career was in the 1980s - he was a member of Labour's NEC from 1988 and the terror of the Tory benches. But Labour MPs sometimes resented his showmanlike parliamentary interventions, such as his suggestion to Margaret Thatcher on the day she resigned that she become the head of the centralised European bank. He was notably embarrassed on his 65th birthday shortly before the 1997 general election when John Major congratulated him on becoming a pensioner. Surprisingly, he failed to regain his NEC position in 1998, but was returned again in 1999 despite poor health. Mr Skinner remains determined to run again at the next election despite mutterings about his age. In battling for lefty and miners' causes, Mr Skinner learned an important lesson: "I realised that you could get into trouble with a dull speech. But if you can keep them laughing, you can get away with murder." He has done that for more than 30 years in his grumpy Derbyshire growl. Ask Aristotle about Dennis Skinner

fields.standfirst:

Motherwell North (1987-1997)

Ask Aristotle about John Reid
fields.trailText: Though Dr John Reid smiles on television, he is a hard man with a past. A Glaswegian ex-communist trusted by Tony Blair to deliver the goods, Dr Reid has now been charged with saving the Northern Ireland peace process after Peter Mandelson's implosion. Though Dr John Reid smiles on television, he is a hard man with a past. A Glaswegian ex-communist trusted by Tony Blair to deliver the goods, Dr Reid has now been charged with saving the Northern Ireland peace process after Peter Mandelson's implosion. If he does so, the highest offices in the land may be open to him in New Labour's expected second term. If he fails, expect this ambitious fixer to crawl from the wreckage nonetheless.

Born in Lanarkshire in 1947, John Reid comes from Catholic mining stock. His father was a postman and his mother a factory worker, but he broke away from his roots thanks to hard work and a good education. This culminated in a doctorate in economic history at Stirling University: a well-informed and sometimes brilliant analyst, Dr Reid is no dim central belt machine politician.

He joined the Communist party in 1973, leaving it to become a professional Labour party activist with close links to Neil Kinnock. He reaped his reward in 1987 when he won the ultrasafe seat of Motherwell North (now Hamilton North and Bellshill). He voted for Tony Blair as party leader in 1994 and by the end of that year was deputy spokesman on defence.

As a junior defence minister after the 1997 election he succeeded brilliantly with the strategic defence review, cutting military costs while winning over the defence chiefs. Friends noticed how he came to love the technicalities of defence administration, able to recite missile specifications at the drop of a hat and fond of taking the salute at parades.

In spring 1999 he was promoted to the cabinet as secretary of state for Scotland, a post greatly diminished in importance by devolution. Despite this, he built his profile, prepared to put the government's case on any issue against tough TV interviewers. He had to cope with the fall out after Donald Dewar, Scotland's respected first secretary, died in 2000, standing by as Mr Dewar's successor Henry McLeish took the Scottish executive down an increasingly nationalist path.

He will no doubt have been glad to escape to the more challenging fields of the Northern Ireland office in January 2001. Here he will have to cope with another, even more unpredictable devolved executive as well as the demands of the ex-terrorist organisations.

He will be judged on two things: whether he persuades the IRA to decommission at least some of its weapons and whether he secures the implementation of the Patten police reforms.

But as one of Tony Blair's current favourites he may not get the chance. After all, another reshuffle beckons after the general election.

fields.headline: Jeff Rooker
fields.standfirst:
Perry Bar (1974-)

Ask Aristotle about Jeff Rooker
fields.trailText: Politicians go to unusual lengths to avoid being seen as decent humans. When able Jeff Rooker announced that at 58 he would not stand again for Perry Barr, rumours spread that he was planning to become mayor of Birmingham. When I asked, the normally outspoken Mr Rooker dodged answering. I later found out that his wife was seriously ill.
fields.body:
Politicians go to unusual lengths to avoid being seen as decent humans. When able Jeff Rooker announced that at 58 he would not stand again for Perry Barr, rumours spread that he was planning to become mayor of Birmingham. When I asked, the normally outspoken Mr Rooker dodged answering. I later found out that his wife was seriously ill.

It was typical of Mr Rooker not only to advocate but to do the decent thing. Or if he could not, to pay the penalty without complaint. This occurred in 1993 when, as spokesman on higher education, he urged charging university students tuition fees, not yet party policy. He loyally accepted being sacked for being ahead of his time.

His straightforwardness has always endeared him, not least during his recent career when he has tried to explain what was being done to correct the inadequacies of Britain's pensions systems. Despite the fact that the platform lost the vote, he won many plaudits for a rousing speech which closed the pensions debate during the last Labour conference. He has never tried to hide behind civil servants' obscurantisms when taking on his opponents, always preferring blunt simple language in his Brummie accent.

It probably comes from not having been a lawyer. The son of a factory worker, he trained as a production engineer, working in various factories in and around Birmingham for 14 years before becoming a lecturer on the subject.

Having won a Birmingham city council seat at 25 in 1967, he was selected for his natal, Tory-held Perry Barr four years later, and captured it in February 1974, thus helping to confirm Harold Wilson's second term as prime minister.

He has always been a soft-left loner, willing to rebel against a Labour government or faction when he thinks them wrong. He was one of the first to attack Harold Wilson's 'Lavender List' of honours recommended for the business friends of his secretary, Marcia Williams, latterly Lady Falkender. With the late Audrey Wise, in 1977 he secured the Rooker-Wise amendment to the Finance Act, ensuring an increase in personal allowances in line with inflation. In 1980 he introduced a bill to abolish the House of Lords. Although on the left, he was one of the 30-odd soft-left MPs who abstained from voting for Tony Benn as deputy leader in 1981, preventing him from beating Denis Healey.

Although he became a Treasury and environment spokesman, and once filled in for Tony Blair at PMQs, Mr Rooker's progress was limited by his aversion to factions and slates. When Labour won in 1997 he was named food safety minister under agriculture minister Jack Cunningham. The job was initially seen as a safe backwater for his outspokenness, but the BSE crisis soon raised his profile. His handling of this thorny issue and of GM planting made him a widely popular minor hero, acclaimed on all sides for his bravery. Even the Daily Telegraph's sketchwriter, Quentin Letts, praised him for having "withstood criticism of the beef-on-the-bone ban where a weaker minister might have folded."

fields.headline: Ralph Thomas
fields.standfirst: Film director from an era of British movie hits
fields.trailText: Film director from an era of British movie hits.
fields.body:
The film director Ralph Thomas, who has died aged 85, was half of the formidable duo - the other was producer Betty Box (Obituary, January 16 1999) - who, in the 1950s and 1960s, gave the Rank Organisation a run of box-office successes with the Doctor series of movies. The couple worked together for more than 30 years, and Thomas spent longer with Rank than any other director.

What his younger brother, Gerald, was to the Carry On pictures, Ralph (pronounced "Raaf") was to the Doctor series. Starting with Doctor In the House (1954), most of them starred Dirk Bogarde, in his matinée idol days, as a shy, young houseman up against his bombastic chief Sir Lance- lot Spratt (James Robertson Justice) and getting into trouble with various starlets.

The rights to Richard Gordon's novel, Doctor In The House, had been available cheap for several months before Thomas and Box snapped them up, but the pair had a tough time convincing Rank executives that Bogarde could play light comedy. In the end, however, Bogarde starred in eight films directed by Thomas, whom he consid-ered a surrogate father.

Thomas was born in Hull, the son of a Shell manager. He had planned to study law but, in 1932, joined the Bristol Evening World as a 17-year-old cub reporter. An article on Oscar Deutsch, of the Odeon cinema chain, brought him to the attention of Deutsch, who offered him work at his Sound City studios at Shepperton. It was the classic story; he started on 25 shillings a week as a clapper boy, and rose through the camera, sound, art and editing departments, and was cutting features before the second world war.

Thomas, who had been in the 9th Lancers voluntary reserve, joined the armoured regiment when war was declared, and rose to the rank of major, being awarded the Military Cross. In 1946, he rejoined Rank, and his early trailers so impressed Sydney Box, a producer at Gainsborough's Islington studios, that he gave Thomas his first directing assignment in 1948.

After a few minor films, Thomas joined forces with Sydney's sister, Betty, to make The Clouded Yellow (1950), an excellent man-on-the-run thriller, written by Eric Ambler and featuring Trevor Howard and Jean Simmons. Thomas again demonstrated his professionalism with Appointment With Venus (1951), set during the German occupation of the Channel Islands.

In between the Doctor films, he directed a good stiff-upper-lip submarine war drama, Above Us The Waves (1955) with John Mills. In the following year, he had his hands full directing Katharine Hepburn and Bob Hope in the comedy The Iron Petticoat. Hope arrived at Pinewood with an entourage of gag writers, who immediately began rewriting the script, and Hepburn objected to playing his stooge.

Thomas then honoured his promise to Bogarde to give him a break from the frivolities of St Swithin's hospital and provide him with more meaty roles: in Campbell's Kingdom (1957), a Canadian-set adventure; The Wind Cannot Read (1958), about a doomed love affair between a British officer and a Japanese girl in India; and A Tale Of Two Cities (1958), in which Bogarde was an effectively languid Sydney Carton. All were efficiently made on a bigger British budget, in a vain attempt to challenge Hollywood.

Because the Technicolor remake of The 39 Steps (1959) was designed to fill a gap in the studio schedules, Thomas had only six weeks' preparation. There was no time to develop a fresh script, which is why it followed the 1935 Alfred Hitchcock version so closely. In fact, on its own terms, the film, starring Kenneth More, was pacey and entertaining.

Probably the best film Thomas directed was Conspiracy Of Hearts (1960), a moving drama of courageous nuns sheltering Jewish children from the Nazis in Italy. This was followed by No Love For Johnny (1961), one of the few British films about politics, with Peter Finch as an ambitious Labour MP.

By the early 1960s, however, Thomas's films began to seem quaint against the British new wave, which dealt vigor- ously with working-class life. Box and Thomas went on to provide the public with cheery comedies such as No, My Darling Daughter (1961) and A Pair of Briefs (1962). Bogarde, leaving his serious work with Joseph Losey, returned for a James Bond spoof, Hot Enough For June (1964), and The High Bright Sun (1965), a stodgy romance set in Cyprus. But he refused the last Doctor movie, Doctor In Clover (1966).

Thomas transplanted the character of Bulldog Drummond to swinging London in Deadlier Than The Male (1966) and Some Girls Do (1968). The climax of his career came with Percy (1971) and Percy's Progress (1974), limp comedies about a penis transplant. By the 1970s, British cinema was fighting for its life, and he worked on several projects that never reached the screen. In the early 1980s, he wrote a dozen television scripts for the series Doctor's Daughters and was consultant on Doctor In The House.

He is survived by Joy, his wife since 1944, their daughter Jill, who runs an animation film company, and son Jeremy, a film producer.

Thomas once said: "I'm not anxious to make films that have a message. Generally speaking, I look for a story that is a reflection on the modes and manners of the times." His films certainly did that.

 Ralph Thomas, film director, born August 10 1915; died March 17 2001

fields.headline: BBC loses 'symbol of change' as Jones quits
fields.trailText:
11.30am update: The BBC today moved to limit the damage from the sudden departure of one of Greg Dyke's closest associates. By Matt Wells.
Mar 20: BBC culture defeats Dyke guru
Mar 20 2000: The report that shocked the suits
fields.body:
The BBC today moved to limit the damage from the sudden departure of one of Greg Dyke's closest associates.

It confirmed that Gareth Jones, the human resources director brought in to lead Mr Dyke's cultural revolution at the corporation, had decided to quit after reportedly becoming "frustrated" with the task.

In a joint statement issued by Mr Jones and the director general, the corporation insisted the former business school guru had never intended to stay at the BBC for more than two years.

But Mr Jones is barely a year into his contract, and the corporation was struggling to present his resignation as routine.

Mr Dyke admitted he had lost a "symbol of change".

Mr Jones joined in January last year "to assist the new director general, Greg Dyke, with his plans for restructuring the BBC", the statement read.

Mr Jones added: "That work is well on track and I remain 100% behind the changes Greg is introducing.

"I never envisaged when I joined that I would be here for more than two years and it is now down to everyone at the BBC to really make the change happen."

Some BBC sources suggested Mr Jones had been frustrated by the scale of the task at the BBC. He was better as a consultant than an "agent of change", said one.

But Mr Dyke was effusive in his praise.

He said in the statement: "Having worked with Gareth before, I was very keen for him to come and help my in my first two years. His contribution has been invaluable. Gareth is one of the best in his field.

"He is a symbol of change and has generated enormous energy around the BBC. He has been a tremendous asset. I will miss him and I wish him well." Mr Jones is credited with the "petals" management structure introduced by Mr Dyke last year. The "one BBC" plan was designed to bring management closer to staff. He will stay at the BBC until a successor is found. The role is being advertised.

fields.headline: Composer wins Bond fight
fields.trailText: The question of who wrote one of the world's most famous pieces of music was finally settled yesterday in the high court.
fields.body:
The question of who wrote one of the world's most famous pieces of music was finally settled yesterday in the high court.

Monty Norman was awarded £30,000 libel damages for a newspaper article that said he did not write the theme for the James Bond films.

Mr Norman, 72, sued the Sunday Times over the article it published in October 1997 under the heading, "Theme tune wrangle has 007 shaken and stirred". He said it "rubbished" his whole career.

The two-week hearing before Mr Justice Eady and a jury in London looked at whether the theme's composer was Mr Norman, who has the work registered with the Performing Rights Society and who has received the royalties, or that of his fellow composer John Barry.

Times Newspapers denied libel and argued that Mr Barry was the composer of the tune, described to the court as "one of the most famous pieces of music in the world".

Mr Barry, 67, whose soundtracks include those for the films Born Free, Zulu and Midnight Cowboy, along with the soundtracks to many Bond films, told the jury that Mr Norman's claim that he alone wrote the tune was "absolute nonsense".

The signature music was was first heard in the 1962 film Dr No in which Sean Connery's Bond penetrates the installation of the movie's ill-intentioned namesake in the Caribbean. Also on hand is Ursula Andress as Honey Ryder.

The case for Times Newspapers was that Mr Barry was brought in to write the theme at a late stage, six months into the project, as Mr Norman had "run out of inspiration".

Mr Norman, an award winning composer who has written music for stage and film musicals such as Expresso Bongo, Irma La Douce, Songbook and Poppy, described the article as "scurrilous". He said it damaged his reputation not just by saying he did not write the Bond theme but by suggesting that he had been dishonestly taking the credit, and the royalties, for a composition that was not his own.

Times Newspapers now faces costs estimated to be well in excess of £500,000.

Mr Barry was not in court yesterday, and was believed to be back at his New York home.

But Mr Norman was there to hear the jury announced its unanimous verdict after about four hours of deliberation. He said: "I am absolutely delighted - and vindicated. The Sunday Times always said that they were only interested in the truth. Well, now they've got the truth."

The Sunday Times said it was disappointed with the outcome of the case, having considered John Barry's account of events in 1962 relating to the Bond theme's creation as "compelling".

A spokesman for the paper said: "This was always going to be a difficult case given the complexities of the expert musical evidence. The fact that all of the truly independent witnesses of what happened in 1962 are no longer alive made matters even more difficult." Press association

fields.headline: BBC bags Booker Prize
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: The BBC has snatched back the rights to the Booker Prize for Fiction from Channel 4, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC has snatched back the rights to UK's most prestigious arts awards, the Booker Prize for Fiction, from Channel 4.

But the announcement immediately led to a row between the two broadcasters, with Channel 4 insisting it hadn't even bid for what is the most prestigious award in the literary calendar.

A spokesman said Channel 4 had said in February it would no longer be covering the Booker. "We wanted to change our coverage of literature," he said.

But the BBC claimed it had started talking to the organisers of the literary awards before the end of last year about taking over the TV contract.

"They were talking to us long before Channel 4 said they didn't want it anymore," a BBC insider said.

BBC2 will broadcast live coverage of this year's Booker dinner and awards ceremony in October, as well as a 60-minute preview documentary the weekend before.

The BBC has also promised further Booker-related coverage on its radio, digital TV and online services as part of a three-year deal.

"As Britain's leading arts broadcaster, we aim to bring viewers and listeners the key events in the cultural calendar and the Booker is one of the most prestigious of all," said Roly Keating, BBC controller of arts commissioning and digital channels.

A BBC spokeswoman said no decision had been taken about who would present the Booker show.

Channel 4's coverage was presented by Sir Melvyn Bragg and Muriel Gray.

The Channel 4 spokesman said it had decided to drop its Booker coverage because it already lined up a number of arts award-related shows in the autumn, including coverage of the Sterling prize for Architecture, the Turner prize for art and the new year one photography event.

The broadcaster has also commissioned a 4 x 60-minute arts documentary series, to be produced by LWT and presented by Lord Bragg, on "cultural ideas and literature", which will go out at around the same time as the Booker, the spokesman added.

TV coverage of the literary awards event was originally produced by LWT for Channel 4 until 1987, when the BBC took over for a 10-year stretch.

While the Booker is one of the leading dates in the arts calendar, it has never brought in a big audience.

Last year's Channel 4 show drew just 600,000 viewers and a 3% share of the audience between 8 and 9pm when it was aired in early November.

webTitle: Nato calls for 1,000 troops to aid Skopje

fields.headline: Nato calls for 1,000 troops to aid Skopje
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in the Balkans
fields.trailText: Nato is seeking 1,000 extra troops to beef up its operations on the volatile border between Kosovo and Macedonia as Europe moved last night to bolster the Skopje government against attacks by ethnic Albanian guerrillas.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels, Rory Carroll  in Tetovo  and Nicholas Wood  in Gostivar
fields.body:
Nato is seeking 1,000 extra troops to beef up its operations on the volatile border between Kosovo and Macedonia as Europe moved last night to bolster the Skopje government against attacks by ethnic Albanian guerrillas.

George Robertson, the alliance's secretary general, announced the move in a flurry of diplomatic and military activity designed to defuse the latest Balkan crisis.

"We'll be asking individual Nato members to add to the troops they have in Kosovo in order that more flexibility can be given to the task," he said.

Nato sources said that 1,000 more men were needed to boost patrolling reconnaissance along the rugged 70-mile frontier, although redeployment within the 42,000-strong K-For might be enough. Britain has no plans to add to the 5,500 men it already has in Kosovo, the Ministry of Defence said.

During the day, Macedonian armour moved into Tetovo, the largely Albanian city that has become the focus of the clashes.

"The Macedonian security forces will soon start a final operation to destroy the terrorists," a government spokesman in Skopje said. "That will happen when our commanders in the field decide that there will be minimum risk of losing lives of security forces."

A presidential adviser later added: "The president has told the generals to flush [the NLA] out of the Republic of Macedonia. .. There is a sense in the back of everyone's minds that if they do not do so now the rebels will pop up elsewhere in the country."

As EU foreign ministers expressed "deep concern" about the situation, its foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, flew to Skopje to encourage it to isolate the extremists behind the attacks.

Britain was last night tabling a resolution at the UN security council, but it is unlikely that a new UN force would be set up at this stage.

Anna Lindh, the Swedish foreign minister, and current chairperson of the EU's rotating presidency, said that the first priority was for Nato to police the highly porous Kosovo-Macedonian border more effectively. Another option would be to alter the mandate of K-For in Kosovo to allow it to operate in Macedonia, though this might meet opposition from Russia and China.

In Moscow, President Vladimir Putinimplied that western policy was to blame. "Those who armed Albanian separatists now do not know how to handle them," he said.

Underlining his concern, Lord Robertson broke diplomatic ground by joining EU foreign ministers before convening a crisis meeting at Nato headquarters.

"What is necessary .. is to interdict as much of the supplies, the traffic that might be going into Macedonia, so Nato is committed to tightening its controls of the border," he said.

"We are determined that we will starve the limited number of localised extremists from being able to carry out their mischief."

EU officials said that Mr Solana was also urging Macedonia to do more to integrate its ethnic Albanian minority - up to 30% of the 2m population - to defuse resentment and radicalisation. But ethnic Macedonians blame the west for incubating the insurgency.

From the prime minister who feels betrayed, the soldiers who feel unsafe and the fleeing refugees, anger is swelling at the perceived double standards of Nato and the UN.

Officials say the sense of betrayal is acute; Skopje overcame misgivings to help Nato during its campaign to oust Yugoslav forces from Kosovo.

Thousands of Macedonians have demonstrated in front of the parliament in Skopje, accusing its government and the west of doing too little.

A sense of events slipping out of control grew on Sunday night when the prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, accused the west of breeding Europe's answer to the Taliban regime in Afghanistan.

He also claimed that Nato would not recognise that the guerrillas came from UN-administered Kosovo because that would be to admit failure.

webTitle: Key skills a disaster, says researcher

fields.headline: Key skills a disaster, says researcher
fields.trailText: The government's new key skills programme is "a complete disaster", according to researchers investigating the revamped curriculum for post-16 students.
fields.body:
The government's new key skills programme is "a complete disaster", according to researchers investigating the revamped curriculum for post-16 students.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, introduced the new qualification in three subjects - communication, numeracy and information technology - last September as part of the new Curriculum 2000 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

The qualification is designed to help students meet the needs of industry.

But according to research by the Institute of Education in London, the new qualifications are unpopular with students and teachers and for the most part ignored by universities and employers.

Ken Spores, co-director of the study, funded by the Nuffield Foundation,said: "Key skills is a disaster. The kids don't like it and teachers think the delivery and assessment of the course is too complicated."

He claimed last night that civil servants were also concerned.

"It's more than just teething problems. We are stuck with this until we get another model - they have begun to realise all is not well." He recommends scrapping the qualification for the post-16 curriculum and instead concentrating on supporting its introduction at GCSE level.

Interviewed in the Guardian's education supplement today, Dr Spores said: "The new arrangements offer some breadth but we may have lost some of the enrichment elements of the old curriculum. The pace of work is frantic at AS-level and the key skills programme is in deep trouble."

His views are based on interviews with students at 25 sixth-forms and further education colleges. He said students were finding the tests difficult and expected high fail rates. But they also felt they were not recognised by universities. Key skills can be studied as separate subjects or as part of the AS-level and A-level course. Most students are expected to take four or five AS courses in their first year, before concentrating on three in their final year.

A survey by the Secondary Heads Association published yesterday showed that maintained schools have changed their timetables to accommodate key skills work - but that far fewer independent schools have. Key skills were being assessed for students in 95% of maintained schools but only 56% of independent schools.

A spokesman for the Department for Education and Employment said: "We are running a major programme of guidance and support to help improve the confidence and competence of teachers to deliver key skills. So far over 20,000 teachers and college lecturers have benefited directly from the programme.

"Assessment is rightly rigorous. Candidates have to pass individual tests in each of the key skills and demonstrate through project work they can use the skills in different contexts."

The SHA survey also said that 85% of students are taking four AS-levels at 17. Ministers hoped the changes would encourage students to take a wider range of subjects rather than confining themselves to all arts or all sciences. But according to the Nuffield research, this is not happening.

fields.headline: Major series starts today
fields.trailText: Public services will be a major issue in the general election - whenever it is eventually called. Today sees the start of a major Guardian series highlighting the views of the people who deliver those public services.
fields.body:
Public services will be a major issue in the general election - whenever it is eventually called. Today sees the start of a major Guardian series highlighting the views of the people who deliver those public services.

What does the future hold for public services? Where do voters stand on the subject of privatisation? What are the challenges facing the public services in the 21st century?

Also on the site today:

News: Reform for learning disabilities

Health secretary Alan Milburn will today promise a "better deal" for people with learning disabilities.

Watch out for updates later in the day

Homelessness: Rebuff for homeless campaign

A campaign to encourage supporting homeless charities instead of giving to beggars has raised just £10,000.

Local government: Pay row could lead to council strikes

Union leaders have warned that councils in England and Wales could face a wave of industrial action if they do not increase their pay offer for local government staff.

Plus breaking news on the site later today:

Housing:

Councils are told exactly how good their performance will have to be if they are to be allowed to borrow money from the commercial markets to renovate their housing stock.

Social care:

The Scottish executive announces a review of child protection services in the wake of the case of Kennedy MacFarlane, the three-year-old Dumfries girl who died after being attacked by her mother's boyfriend last year.

Keep logging on throughout the day to catch up with the very latest news

webTitle: Greek priests revolt as church backs Pope's visit

fields.headline: Greek priests revolt as church backs Pope's visit
fields.trailText: A bitter row has erupted in Greece's Orthodox church at the prospect of a historic visit to the country by the Pope.
fields.body:
A bitter row has erupted in Greece's Orthodox church at the prospect of a historic visit to the country by the Pope.

Many clergy are furious at a decision by the holy synod, the Greek church's ruling body, to lift long-standing objections to what will be the first papal visit since the "great schism" of 1054 split Christianity into eastern and western branches.

The ailing pontiff wants to make a flying visit to Athens in May as part of a millennial pilgrimage retracing the path of St Paul from Syria to Malta. He plans to offer symbolic prayers on the Hill of the Pnyx, an area of Athens to the west of the Acropolis where St Paul preached to the Athenians.

Both liberal Orthodox members and the Vatican hope the visit will help to bridge the divide between the two churches. But Greece's conservative rank-and-file clergy, in the grip of a nationalist fervour fuelled by what many saw as western - read Catholic - aggression against fellow Orthodox Serbs during the wars in Bosnia and Kosovo, are urging a boycott. They are angry at Rome's perceived refusal to show "humility and repentance" and to apologise for centuries of alleged misdeeds against Orthodox Christians.

Many in the Greek church view the fall of Constantinople at the hands of crusaders in 1204 as darkly as they do the siege of the city by Ottoman Turks in 1453 that led to the end of the Byzantine empire.

The union of Greek clerics, which represents about 8,000 parish priests, warned of widespread protests and described the Pope as "the arch-heretic" and the "grotesque two-horned monster of Rome". It threatened a mass bell-ringing protest during the visit.

In a petition last Friday to Archbishop Christodoulos, the leader of the Greek church, the country's monasteries said the visit would be divisive and "scandalise the consciousness of the faithful". Monks from the independent all-male community of Mount Athos, one of the most revered centres of Orthodoxy, also threatened to join the protests.

The police and security services in Greece and at the Vatican have been alerted about the potential for trouble.

Besides theological and political disputes with the Vatican, there are suspicions here that it is trying to poach Orthodox believers in eastern Europe. "Some of our followers see the Pope as a latter-day Napoleon," Yiannis Hadjifotis, a former spokesman for the Church of Greece, said.

The main targets of Orthodox fears are the Eastern Rite (or Uniate) churches, which follow Orthodox traditions but profess loyalty to the Pope. "They are the Trojan horse of the Catholic church," an Orthodox bishop said.

Only about 50,000 of Greece's 10.2m citizens are Roman Catholics - though there are thought to be some 200,000 Catholic worshippers among the growing immigrant population.

The Catholic church in Greece welcomed the decision by Orthodox leaders to allow the visit but expressed concern at the rhetoric of its opponents. "Conservative elements in the Orthodox church have very long memories," a spokesman said. "His holiness has nothing to do with the wrongdoings of Catholics of the Middle Ages, for which we have apologised as a church."

Attempts at reconciliation between the two churches have stalled in recent years, although in 1999 the Pope visited predominantly Orthodox Romania and Georgia. Vatican sources said last week that a visit to Athens could also influence the Russian Orthodox church, which has close links with the Greek church, and possibly pave the way for a historic trip to Moscow.

The embattled leaders of the Greek church appealed to the faithful not to overreact to the Pope's visit. "The faithful are called upon to trust their church leadership and not be led astray by distorted interpretations," the synod said.

Orthodoxy is stipulated in the Greek constitution as the "prevailing" one, and the Orthodox church wields significant political and economic influence.

The outspoken Archbishop Christodoulos has been engaged in a bitter battle with the Socialist government over plans to remove the statement of religion from state identity cards. He organised a petition against the plan in the country's churches that he hopes will attract 3m signatures.

His decision to persuade the reluctant synod to agree to the Pope's visit is seen as an olive branch to the prime minister, Costas Simitis, who is keen to avoid international embarrassment on the issue.
