fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £160.54
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £39.08

Sean Ingle = £19.82

Paul MacInnes = £15.01

Scott Murray: Chelsea v Sunderland - Sunderland to lead at half-time, Chelsea to lead at full-time £5 @ 28/1

Trying to win a fortune with a small stake is the elusive goal of many punters. But the principles of successful gambling must still apply. Namely, the odds must be greater than the chance of the event actually occurring. Specifically, the bet must be value.

Half-time/full-time betting is a minefield. Typically, if a team is priced at 6/4, they would be 11/4 to be winning at half time and at the final whistle. They would be 4/1 to be level at the break and successful at the end and 33/1 to come from behind at half time to win the game. The odds of 6/4 suggest the team has a 40% chance of winning the game. If you back all the possibilities for your team in the half-time/ full-time market you are giving them a 50% chance of winning (11/4 = 27%, 4/1 = 20% and 33/1 = 3%). So by betting like this, you give the bookmaker 10% extra equity on your money.

I am not saying this market never offers value for the serious gambler. It's just that there have to be more compelling reasons than you offer before I risk my hard earned cash.

Charlotte Freemantle of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Newcastle v Middlesbrough, Boro to win - £5 @ 3/1.

The period from mid-March until the end of the season can often produce surprising results. Struggling teams begin improving as the threat of relegation increases. Teams in mid-table suffer dips in form as the players realise there is little left to play for and start thinking about the beach.

Unfortunately, bookmakers recognise these patterns and often reflect them in their prices. Teams with huge incentives are cut in price and often do not represent value for punting purposes.

Having said that, Middlesborough did look value at 3/1 for the north-east derby with Newcastle. Earlier in the season they might have been 4/1 for this game, and although the odds makers reflected Boro's dire need to get a result, I don't think they reacted enough. Newcastle's injury crisis and their lack of motivation meant Boro should probably have been nearer to the 9/4 mark.

You made a bold selection, and thanks to Alen Boksic, it paid dividends. Congratulations.

The Prince of Punts: CIS Cup final, Kilmarnock to beat Celtic at half-time - £5 @ 6/1

Hmmmmmmmmm. Betting on cup finals is risky at the best of times. Can we predict how the teams will react to the big-match pressure? (Although, come to think of it, just how big is the CIS Insurance Cup final? But that's another subject).

My experience is that the first half of cup finals are often cagey affairs, with players more interested in not making mistakes than providing the brilliance which might lead to a goal.

If you thought Killie were capable of thwarting Celtic for a long period, and events proved you correct, then backing the draw at half-time at odds of around 6/4 would have been a more viable option.

On the whole, I would avoid betting on cup finals. Because of the pressure the formbook is often tossed aside, and making a prediction with any degree of certainty proves impossible.

They would be 4/1 to be level at the break and successful at the end and 33/1 to come from behind at half time to win the game. The odds of 6/4 suggest the team has a 40% chance of winning the game. If you back all the possibilities for your team in the half-time/ full-time market you are giving them a 50% chance of winning (11/4 = 27%, 4/1 = 20% and 33/1 = 3%). So by betting like this, you give the bookmaker 10% extra equity on your money. I am not saying this market never offers value for the serious gambler. It's just that there have to be more compelling reasons than you offer before I risk my hard earned cash. Charlotte Freemantle of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Newcastle v Middlesbrough, Boro to win - £5 @ 3/1. The period from mid-March until the end of the season can often produce surprising results. Struggling teams begin improving as the threat of relegation increases. Teams in mid-table suffer dips in form as the players realise there is little left to play for and start thinking about the beach. Unfortunately, bookmakers recognise these patterns and often reflect them in their prices. Teams with huge incentives are cut in price and often do not represent value for punting purposes. Having said that, Middlesborough did look value at 3/1 for the north-east derby with Newcastle. Earlier in the season they might have been 4/1 for this game, and although the odds makers reflected Boro's dire need to get a result, I don't think they reacted enough. Newcastle's injury crisis and their lack of motivation meant Boro should probably have been nearer to the 9/4 mark. You made a bold selection, and thanks to Alen Boksic, it paid dividends. Congratulations. The Prince of Punts: CIS Cup final, Kilmarnock to beat Celtic at half-time - £5 @ 6/1 Hmmmmmmmmm. Betting on cup finals is risky at the best of times. Can we predict how the teams will react to the big-match pressure? (Although, come to think of it, just how big is the CIS Insurance Cup final? But that's another subject). My experience is that the first half of cup finals are often cagey affairs, with players more interested in not making mistakes than providing the brilliance which might lead to a goal. If you thought Killie were capable of thwarting Celtic for a long period, and events proved you correct, then backing the draw at half-time at odds of around 6/4 would have been a more viable option. On the whole, I would avoid betting on cup finals. Because of the pressure the formbook is often tossed aside, and making a prediction with any degree of certainty proves impossible.

fields.headline: Scottish NHS plan: the basics
fields.trailText: • Scotland published a national plan, setting out how its health services should develop, in December last year.
fields.body:
 Scotland published a national plan, setting out how its health services should develop, in December last year.

 The document outlines tough action on waiting times - no patient will wait longer than 9 months for treatment, and from October 2001 no woman with breast cancer who needs urgent treatment will be seen within one month. By 2005 no patient urgently referred for cancer treatment will have to wait more than two months.

 Access to health services will be improved - every NHS board will develop one stop clinics, and pharmacists will be encouraged to offer advice in high street pharmacies. Nurse prescribing will be extended and NHS 24 - offering round the clock telephone advice - will be rolled out in pilot areas in 2001.

 Telemedicine pilot projects will begin in April 2002 in each health board to cover populations living in remote or rural areas.

 NHS management will be restructured with unified NHS health boards in each area, fewer managers and a stronger local identity for the NHS in each board area.

webTitle: Scottish NHS plan: the issue explained

fields.headline: Scottish NHS plan: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Action on waiting
fields.body:
Action on waiting

The plan promises:

 By 2003 no patient will wait longer than nine months for treatment (currently 12 months in Scotland and 18 months in England)

 By 2002 the maximum wait for angiography will be 12 weeks from seeing a specialist, and 24 weeks from angiography to surgery or angioplasty

 By October 2001 women who have breast cancer and need urgent treatment will get it within one month where appropriate

 By October 2001 the maximum wait for children needing urgent cancer treatment will be one month

 By 2005 no patient urgently referred for cancer treatment will wait more than two months.

Improvements in access

The plan promises that:

 Every NHS board will set a programme for the redesign of services (like one-stop clinics), building on the 44 national pilot projects already underway

 NHS 24 will be rolled out in pilot areas in 2001 offering 24-hour access to health advice from nurses

 Scotland's 1,100 pharmacists will expand the range of services they offer to include repeat prescriptions. They will also offer more health advice to customers in high street pharmacies

 £1m pounds will be invested in improving the health services available in small and medium-sized workplaces

 More nurses will be trained to prescribe treatments and certain drugs - the range of treatments will also be increased

 No patient will wait longer than 48 hours to see an appropriate member of the primary care team, including a GP

 By April 2002 people in remote and rural Scotland will see pilot projects to expand telemedicine rolled out in all health boards with a remote population.

Rebuilding a national NHS

The plan proposes that:

 New unified NHS boards will be created to integrate local decision making and increase local accountability

 A reduction in the number of NHS boardrooms from 43 to 15, and the number of ministerial appointees by one-third or around 100 posts

 Unified NHS boards will have greater staff and local authority representation. They will also have joint responsibility for health improvement and developing NHS services

 There will be single comprehensive local health plans in each NHS board area

 A stronger local identity for the NHS will be developed, and the proliferation of names and logos will end

 The management and decision making structure of the NHS will be subject to a long-term review.

webTitle: Regulator forces Railtrack to speed up repairs

fields.headline: Regulator forces Railtrack to speed up repairs
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, has taken legal action to force Railtrack to restore Britain's rail network to normal operation by the time the summer timetable comes into effect on May 21.
fields.body:
The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, has taken legal action to force Railtrack to restore Britain's rail network to normal operation by the time the summer timetable comes into effect on May 21.

Mr Winsor served an enforcement notice on Railtrack after it said that at least 16 passenger lines would not be ready by the company's own May deadline.

He said it was clear that he needed to "concentrate the minds" of the rail operator, which had originally indicated that all safety work that needed to be carried out following the Hatfield rail crash would be completed by Easter.

Mr Winsor said: "Information provided to me by Railtrack suggests that, after Easter, 16 passenger and two freight services will still face emergency timetables or running normal timetables with significant delays.

"In certain cases, the recovery dates are later so as to reflect specific circumstances on particular routes. I am making this enforcement order to commit Railtrack to its own revised timetable."

The routes affected by the continuing delays include Connex South Central's Rugby to Clapham Junction service, which Railtrack told the regulator it would not be able to restore to normal service until June 30.

Other affected routes include Connex South Eastern's Folkestone to Dover line, West Anglia's Finsbury Park to Moorgate service, and Silverlink's London Euston to Birmingham service.

Railtrack also said several Northern Spirit lines serving Leeds would only be restored to normal service "as soon as reasonably practicable".

Mr Winsor said it was clear Railtrack was in breach of its licence. He said that the level and extent of disruption and uncertainty caused by the ongoing repair work "has been unprecedented and remains unacceptable".

He added: "Operators have contracts for the supply of, and are paying for, a serviceable network, and I consider it a reasonable requirement that they should not face the sort of disruption they have faced and still face."

fields.headline: Keith Vaz
fields.standfirst:
Leicester East (1987- )

Ask Aristotle about Keith Vaz
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz, the most ambitious and flexible of politicians, is an ideological weathervane, always ready to track the wind. In a decade he has crossed the political spectrum of his party, from membership of the hard-left Campaign group to ultra loyalism to New Labour. Throughout he has stood out for his energy, style and displays of political double-jointedness that have astounded even fellow politicians.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the most ambitious and flexible of politicians, is an ideological weathervane, always ready to track the wind. In a decade he has crossed the political spectrum of his party, from membership of the hard-left Campaign group to ultra loyalism to New Labour. Throughout he has stood out for his energy, style and displays of political double-jointedness that have astounded even fellow politicians.

Early in his Commons career he called for Salman Rushdie's novel, Satanic Verses, to be withdrawn while defending the right of minorities to have their say. Later this once arch-Eurosceptic denounced those in his party critical of the European Union. And in 2001 he appeared to survive the controversy over his role in passport applications by two Indian businessmen, the Hinduja brothers, being cleared of wrongdoing by the Hammond report into the episode even as he came under heavy fire for failing to cooperate fully with an inquiry by the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin.

This tendency towards over-exuberance masks Mr Vaz's real achievements. Elected for Leicester East in 1987, he was the first Asian MP since 1929 and the first ever Asian minister in the Commons. (Baron Sinha of Raipur preceded him in the Lords in 1919 - a fact forgotten by most newspapers.)

Mr Vaz is a Goanese Catholic born in 1956 in Aden, where his father was the correspondent for the Times of India. The family moved to Twickenham when he was nine. He went from Latymer upper school in Hammersmith to Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge, where he was a contemporary of the prime minister's spin doctor, Alastair Campbell, the BBC's political editor Andrew Marr and the novelist and Labour ally Robert Harris.

Like them he made his mark at the university. He secured first class honours in law, going on to study at the College of Law before practising first as a solicitor and then, from 1991, as a barrister.

He also grew up with politics. His widowed mother, Merlyn Lobo, is now a councillor in Leicester and his BBC presenter sister, Valerie Vaz, has frequently sought Labour candidacies as a leftwinger.

It was no surprise that Keith Vaz should follow the same route, at first unsuccessfully, coming a poor third in 1983 as Labour's candidate for hopeless Richmond and Barnes, a year later losing Surrey West by 50,000 votes.

These disappointments made him an outspoken advocate of "black sections" within the Labour party, then a real cause of controversy. The stance may have helped him win selection for Leicester East - a seat with some 16,000 non-white voters, mostly Gujaratis - but if it did, his supporters must have been disappointed when he turned against black sections on entering parliament.

In the 1987 election, Mr Vaz took the Leicester seat from the sitting Conservative, Peter Bruinvels, a flamboyant rightwinger famous for offering to act as public hangman.

In parliament, he made his mark as an outspoken supporter of people who had lost money in the collapse of BCCI, many of them among his Asian constituents. He has settled down somewhat after his marriage in 1993 to fellow lawyer Maria Fernandes, a Kenyan-born Goanese Catholic. They have a son and a daughter.

In 1992 he became a Labour frontbench spokesman, a success which turned to disappointment when he became one of a dozen Labour opposition frontbenchers denied office in Tony Blair's first 1997 government.

Instead, he became a parliamentary private secretary serving Tony Blair's close friend Derry Irvine. Then came the magic endorsement: Lord Irvine said his PPS was "utterly brilliant", "the most incredible networker I have ever met".

This backing from so well connected a source must have assisted Mr Vaz's rapid ministerial promotion, from parliamentary secretary in Lord Irvine's Lord Chancellor's department to minister for Europe at the Foreign Office. In that job, Mr Vaz has not shone quite as brightly as some of his predecessors, who made the post one of the most important in the government outside the cabinet. But he has coped well enough, showing all the enthusiasm of a recent convert to the European ideal until hit by the passport controversy of early 2001.

webTitle: NHS quality and performance: the basics

fields.headline: NHS quality and performance: the basics
fields.trailText: • Labour came to power in 1997 determined to drive up standards in an NHS it believed was aloof and paternalistic, inefficient, slow to respond to the needs of patients and unable to guarantee universally high standards of quality.
fields.body:
 Labour came to power in 1997 determined to drive up standards in an NHS it believed was aloof and paternalistic, inefficient, slow to respond to the needs of patients and unable to guarantee universally high standards of quality.

 The government's 1998 white paper A First Class Service - Quality in the new NHS introduced a range of measures to set, monitor and enforce universally high standards of quality and performance.

 These include: national service frameworks; the National Institute for Clinical Excellence; quality assurance at local level through clinical governance; and the Commission for Health Improvement (CHI).

 The NHS plan, published in 2000, introduced a further range of quality measures, aimed particularly at tackling poor performing doctors, and a new financial incentive system for trusts in England whereby the best performing trusts will have access to a £500m National Health Performance Fund.

 In Scotland, quality issues will be addressed through the Health Technology Board and Clinical Standards Board for Scotland. In Wales, performance assessment will be carried out by CHI, although its remit will not be as wide as in England.

fields.headline: Michael Portillo
fields.standfirst:
Kensington and Chelsea (1999-)
Enfield Southgate (1984-1997)

Ask Aristotle about Michael Portillo
fields.trailText: Tory delegates at the 2000 conference should have been provided with a couch for shadow chancellor Michael Portillo's voyage around his psyche. Never has a major political figure so lived up to the words, "To thine own self be true".
fields.body:
Tory delegates at the 2000 conference should have been provided with a couch for shadow chancellor Michael Portillo's voyage around his psyche. Never has a major political figure so lived up to the words, "To thine own self be true".

Mr Portillo's voyage of rediscovery was all the more wondrous since everyone was able to witness the shock that pushed him into the political abyss. He lost his "super-safe" Tory seat to Stephen Twigg, a gay Blairite stripling. That helped Mr Portillo confront his own exotic background on the BBC as the son of an exiled Spanish republican intellectual and a Kirkcaldy Liberal Democrat teacher.

The resultant catharsis has had political repercussions. Mr Portillo made his comeback for affluent Kensington and Chelsea mainly because they saw him as a "son of Thatcher". But that is not how he has reinvented himself. In the u-turns he has imposed on his leader William Hague as his "loyal" shadow chancellor Mr Portillo has emerged as a centre-right inclusivist, in contrast to authoritarian-right Ann Widdecombe, his rival for the succession should William Hague falter.

To win that battle, Mr Portillo will need all his subtlety. He must not appear to be disloyal so as to avoid the Tory "traitor" tag which bedevilled Michael Heseltine. He must also help unmask the insanities of rival Miss Widdecombe without showing his hand, as happened when the Mail on Sunday found seven fellow shadow cabinet members anxious to confess their youthful cannabis experiments. Mr Portillo himself did not say whether he had tried cannabis but he has admitted to trying homosexuality in his university years.

Mr Portillo's need for subtlety must be frustrating because his party has moved into the far-right positions he abandoned after his 1997 election defeat. Tory MPs are already three-quarters Eurosceptic rightists.

The one thing Mr Portillo knows intimately is the ethos of allegiance change. Born in Bushey in 1953, he was a keen supporter of Harold Wilson while at Harrow County grammar school. He was converted to Conservatism at Peterhouse, Cambridge University, by the rightwing guru, Maurice Cowling, who also recommended him for his job as a researcher at Conservative central office.

His ambition was enormous. In 1983 he contested Perry Barr, Birmingham against Jeff Rooker, who increased his majority ninefold. As an adviser, he continued to push for the privatisation of British Gas and the deregulation of bus transport, serving Cecil Parkinson, the then trade and industry secretary.

His luck was phenomenal, as demonstrated by the IRA Brighton conference bomb. Mr Portillo left the Grand Hotel an hour before the bomb exploded and was then selected from more than 200 aspirants for the byelection caused by the death of Southgate MP, Sir Anthony Berry, who was killed by the bomb.

From his maiden speech, he crusaded against high taxation and for freeing nationalised monopolies. He backed bills against abortion and favouring capital punishment. A parliamentary private secretary to John Moore and an assistant whip by 1986, his 1987 re-election campaign attracted the support of lobbyist Ian Greer.

An under secretary for social security from 1987, he withdrew benefit entitlement from unemployed school leavers who refused to join youth training schemes. He also scrapped the social fund which provided grants and loans to the poor and curbed the benefit system and new personal and occupational pensions, claiming previous systems had encouraged people to "live off the state".

As a reward, he was promoted minister of public transport, offsetting moderate transport secretary Paul Channon. Mr Portillo excluded British Rail from his effort to build the Channel tunnel with private funds and pushed local authorities to dispose of bus enterprises. He urged on Mrs Thatcher the privatisation of British Rail and the tube.

By 1990 he was being mentioned by Norman Tebbit as a possible future Tory leader and he sought Mrs Thatcher's approval by taking over the poll tax as local government minister, telling her, "There is nothing in the whole world I would rather do." He despaired when she wanted to step down in 1990, brushing aside Mrs Thatcher's permanent private secretary, Sir Peter Morrison, when he tried to ban him from dissuading her.

His 1992 appointment to the cabinet as chief secretary to the Treasury was taken to mean that prime minister John Major was serious about cutting expenditure - Mr Portillo promptly cut funds for inner cities. But he was discreet in expressing his Euroscepticism and also voted, in February 1994, against reducing to 16 the age of homosexual consent.

His extreme caution was again shown when he refused to challenge John Major for leadership of the party in June 1995, even on the joint ticket offered by John Redwood, although his ally John Whittingdale set up an office and battery of telephones to do so. His reward, promotion to defence secretary, brought out his worst expression of super-patriotism, including his chauvinist "Who Dares Wins" speech which wowed only the 1995 Tory conference. He enthused the right but infuriated gays by refusing to allow them to serve in the forces.

Between his defeat in May 1997 and his re-entry into parliament for Kensington and Chelsea in November 1999, he managed to swivel his position from hard-right to centre-right. He even managed to confess to his earlier homosexuality, although his former lover, Nigel Hart, insisted he had been economical with the truth. Mr Hart recalls Mr Portillo saying: "I've just worked out that the first time I slept with you was the day after I slept with [my future wife] Carolyn for the first time."

His extreme caution was again shown when he refused to challenge John Major for leadership of the party in June 1995, even on the joint ticket offered by John Redwood, although his ally John Whittingdale set up an office and battery of telephones to do so. His reward, promotion to defence secretary, brought out his worst expression of super-patriotism, including his chauvinist "Who Dares Wins" speech which wowed only the 1995 Tory conference. He enthused the right but infuriated gays by refusing to allow them to serve in the forces. Between his defeat in May 1997 and his re-entry into parliament for Kensington and Chelsea in November 1999, he managed to swivel his position from hard-right to centre-right. He even managed to confess to his earlier homosexuality, although his former lover, Nigel Hart, insisted he had been economical with the truth. Mr Hart recalls Mr Portillo saying: "I've just worked out that the first time I slept with you was the day after I slept with [my future wife] Carolyn for the first time." Ask Aristotle about Michael Portillo

webTitle: The report that shocked the suits

fields.headline: The report that shocked the suits
fields.standfirst: First published in the Guardian March 20, 2000
fields.trailText: Gathering dust in a Harvard archive is a document every BBC employee should read. Because Greg Dyke loves it. Janine Gibson and Maggie Brown reveal its mystery author, a man at the DG's right hand with job losses on his mind
fields.body:
Gathering dust in a Harvard archive is a document every BBC employee should read. Because Greg Dyke loves it. Janine Gibson and Maggie Brown reveal its mystery author, a man at the DG's right hand with job losses on his mind

The most remarkable thing about the leaks of Greg Dyke's blueprint for the new BBC last week was not the headline figure 1,000 jobs to go nor the news that some of the corporation's longest-serving executives might soon be getting their coats. The truly amazing thing was that the BBC, one of the leakiest organisations ever, had managed to keep it quiet for so long.

So why did some of the greatest gossips in a notoriously gossipy industry fail to reveal the secret plan emerging from Dyke's review of the corporation, which began when he joined in the autumn? Simple: they didn't know. In fact, no one knew. They still don't.

It didn't stop them speculating. 'Isn't it incredible,' gasped one of the BBC's most acclaimed programme makers, 'how everything that Birt has done is being swept away? It's as if he's never been.'

A note from Dyke, sent to every member of staff on Thursday after the trade magazine Broadcast splashed on the story, was confiding and reassuring, while still failing either to deny the reports or unveil the plan. Affectionately signed 'yours, Greg' it described the story as speculation and reminded staff that he would announce his plans in a couple of weeks.

So with staff none the wiser, the rumour mill went into overdrive. And the name on the lips of those who know enough to know how little they know was Gareth Jones, the BBC's new director of human resources and legal affairs. Professor Jones, who joined the corporation in November to replace Margaret Salmon, was Dyke's first senior appointment. A former colleague of the new DG, he is something of a mystery to the broadcasting types. Aged 39, he was professor of organisational development at Henley Management college, where he was known for his skills in helping managers effect wide-scale cultural change in their organisations.

This is his speciality, honed with companies including Polygram International and at academic institutions including the University of East Anglia, the London Business school and the voguish French business school, Insead.

Happily, there is an insight into Jones's thinking on the difficulties of changing a company's culture. Gathering dust in the archive of the Harvard Business Review, an illustrious publication, is an article authored by the mastermind behind Dyke's plans. In 1996, along with Rob Goffee then an LBS professor Jones wrote What Holds the Modern Company Together. It is a key report.

The article shows the influences behind Dyke's plan the massive cultural sea change he wants to effect, removing the endless managers and helping BBC staff to have fun again. It also shows the motivation behind his 'put up or shut up' speech to staff when he formally took over, when he told them to leave if they didn't like it. Jones's model would not tolerate creative types bitching about the job instead of doing it.

Jones's theory is built on the twin virtues of 'sociability' and 'solidarity', which can be combined in varying ratios to achieve various ends. There is no single ideal, according to this theory, and different models can work in different areas. A 'mercenary' culture can work for a highly competitive, sales-driven organisation where employees expect to work very hard for vast rewards and early retirement. However, for the BBC, it seems the 'communal' model, where sociability and solidarity meet harmoniously, would be the ideal.

Four years ago, Jones and Goffee described the BBC as undergoing an 'uncomfortable transition'. As Birt tried to focus the corporation on efficiency and productivity dividing producers from broadcasters and establishing the internal market the BBC became fragmented, they wrote.

'With its communal culture heading toward a fragmented one, the BBC faces no alternative but to invent itself,' they concluded. How does an organisation change its culture? Jones and Goffee offered a series of steps: promote the sharing of ideas, arrange casual gatherings, reduce formality, limit hierarchical differences, 'act like a friend', create a sense of urgency and stimulate the will to win.

But, they warned, 'before attempting to change levels of sociability or solidarity, a manager needs to think a bit like a doctor taking on a new patient. The patient's past and current condition are not only relevant but also critically important to assessing the best future treatment'. A questionnaire is provided, with which to assess your organisation's culture, with statements such as 'people here do favours for one other because they like one another' to which the responses are either 'low, medium or high'. One BBC staffer simply burst out laughing in response to that question last week.

Some degree of choosiness will no doubt be appropriate when selecting the BBC's future tactics from the list. Limiting hierarchical differences and redesigning the organisational chart one of the five recommendations for increasing sociability is clearly well under way. Introducing an annual company picnic might not be wholly welcomed. So far, Dyke's grand plan to turn the BBC into a more productive and happy place has been painted as a slaughter of hundreds of top and middle managers, who will find themselves competing for a vastly reduced number of posts. And that slaughter will happen it will be vital to meet the promised target of reducing spending on administration from 24% of the BBC's total income to a justifiable 15%.

But the real shock to the BBC system will not be the erasure of the current divisions between producers and broadcasters, nor the redistribution of budgets, nor even the rumoured move of Alan Yentob from director of television. According to those who have spoken to Jones, whose touchy-feely style involves chats with key executives over pints of beer, it will be the culture change that is intended to create an effective atmosphere.

The Dyke team want to create a fast-reacting organisation, where programme makers feel valued, and where ideas and creative juices flow freely. They want the new departments to be 'small and specialist', reasoning that this is how programme makers work best.

It's no accident that one of the few decisions made in the period of wait ing for the blueprint has been an acceptance that the new digital channels BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge can move into a loft-style office in Mortimer Street, central London, far from the tentacles of the 'big brother' BBC Television Centre, in White City, west London.

A further symptom of the new style is Dyke's much commented-upon dislike of lengthy paper policy documents he refuses to read them and a desire for a much better system of internal communication. Nothing is sacred even the role of Ariel, the BBC's Pravda-like internal weekly newspaper, previously deemed essential for the dissemination of Birtspeak, is up for debate.

For many programme makers, the term BBC was associated with Birt and the corporate centre: it was an institution they might have belonged to, but from which they felt alienated. The policy of sending favoured managers off to expensive business school courses at Wharton in the US or Insead is being stopped. So, probably, is the exclusive link with the University of Bradford, which runs a BBC management scheme. The aim is to create a BBC scheme, drawing on the best of business courses.

Dyke's team have also been appalled by the civil service feel of the BBC, evidenced by fusty old-fashioned practices such as 'boarding' applicants for 'posts' rather than holding interviews for jobs. The new brooms shake their heads at the quaint idea that staff 'go on annual leave' instead of holidays.

One trusted aide last week said the bottom line was simple. 'What does all this mean for Mrs Smith on her sofa? More money to be spent on better programmes. That's it.' Or as another remarks: 'The key thing is for the BBC to deliver stonking good programmes to the public, and everything else stands in the way of that.'

But the hushed tones and enforced secrecy surrounding Dyke's blueprint cause some old hands to cite the mark of Birt. Carolyn Reynolds, one of the executives trusted to write the plan, is a former McKinsey consultant who joined BBC Worldwide. Robin Foster, who assisted, went on extended leave the moment the blueprint was handed over. 'I'm surprised Dyke hasn't issued a consultation plan. That's what ought to happen,' said a critic.

The expressed fear is that the change will be so sharp and swift that a further shakedown will be needed in 18 months. The great variation in the predictions of job losses comes from the estimates made by those informed of the outline plan. Though several hundred will go at first, Dyke will not immediately lay down targets for further restructuring within the 16 new departments. That will be left to their new heads.

The programme makers should have nothing to worry about save any personal aversion to company picnics and the like, but of course the waiting seems endless. As one key senior executive said last week, 'I've put all my plans on hold until I know what the final version is.'

For, in a period of great change, there are countless tales of people rushing to grab territory and rubbish old rivals or enemies. Some of the governors are thought to be unnerved by the thought of their director-general line-managing 16 separate departments. Some staff are running a book on who will be the first senior manager to go. Whatever Dyke promises about his all-new BBC, it's not all sweetness and light.

fields.headline: The rumour mill
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are wearing a stupid jumper that says 'I kiss football' on it
fields.trailText: According to the Daily Mail, Arsenal and Real Madrid are in a two-way fight for the services of Andriy Shevchenko. The Ukranian international is top of the Serie A scoring charts with AC Milan, but he told the press this week: "I am still a Milan player and I want the club to finish this season the best we can. But Milan are not the last team I'll be playing for."
fields.body:
According to the Daily Mail, Arsenal and Real Madrid are in a two-way fight for the services of Andriy Shevchenko. The Ukranian international is top of the Serie A scoring charts with AC Milan, but he told the press this week: "I am still a Milan player and I want the club to finish this season the best we can. But Milan are not the last team I'll be playing for."

Bobby Robson is set to dip into his newly found cash supply by making an £8m bid for Paris St Germain's Laurent Robert. The Mirror believes that Robson has already spoken to PSG about a deal.

A convenient loophole in Uefa rules looks set to allow Manchester United to bring in cover for the injured Fabien Barthez ahead of their Champions League quarter-final with Bayern Munich next month. A Uefa spokesman told the Daily Mail: "If any club cannot count on the service of at least two registered keepers due to injury or illness, they can bring in a replacement." Spurs' Ian Walker, Rangers' Lionel Charbonnier, and Real Madrid's Bodo Illgner are the names believed to be on Sir Alex Ferguson's list.

Trevor Francis has denied that Arsenal are about to sign centre-half Darren Purse. "There are plenty of rumours that go around football and I am pleased to say that it is just a rumour", the Birmingham boss said. "I have not heard anything about that. At this moment, Darren is very much one of us. He is having a fantastic season."

David Pleat has revealed that Spurs were interested in signing Richard Rufus from Charlton. Spurs' director of football confirmed he is also keen on Southampton's Dean Richards. "Richards and Richard Rufus were the two centre backs I took to Italy in 1995 when I looked after the Endsleigh League team over there," he said "and they both looked good young players."

Martin O'Neill is confident of tying Henrik Larsson to a new Celtic contract. "I hope and expect to come to an agreement," he said, "but even if we didn't Henrik still has a couple of years left to run and he's not the type of fella to turn round and say, 'That's it, I'm off,' the next morning."

Middlesbrough are considering a £1.5m pre-deadline offer for Luton defender Matthew Taylor.

fields.headline: New Media Markets
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 16
fields.trailText: The Disney Channel has been elbowed aside from joining ONdigital in favour of the new Wellbeing Channel.
fields.body:
The Disney Channel has been elbowed aside from joining ONdigital in favour of the new Wellbeing Channel.

European cable operators are aghast at European parliament plans to standardise middleware in digital TV set-top boxes and ensure that all future set-top boxes will support all cable, terrestrial and satellite.

Asda is to launch a home delivery service on Open at the end of April.

NTL last week reported record revenues totalling £586m, up £26m on the previous three month period.

BSkyB and ONdigital this week disputed forecasts from research agency Optimedia for the growth of digital TV.

Flextech's axing of SceneOne, a nine-month-old channel, is a rare event, but such closures are becoming more commonplace.

webTitle: Pay row could lead to council strikes

fields.headline: Pay row could lead to council strikes
fields.trailText: Union leaders have warned that councils in England and Wales could face a wave of industrial action if they do not increase their pay offer for local government staff. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
Union leaders have warned that councils in England and Wales could face a wave of industrial action if they do not increase their pay offer for local government staff.

Wage negotiations stalled last month after the local government employers' organisation (EO) said authorities simply could not afford to go above a 3% increase.

The unions immediately rejected the offer and are calling instead for a £1,000 flat rate, across-the-board rise.

The two sides enter a new round of talks today, but the EO appears to have no new money to put on the table. A spokesman said: "The feedback we're getting from councils is that 3% in cash terms is the limit which they can go to." Some authorities had already budgeted for a pay increase of just 2.5%, he added.

The employers also believe that a flat rate increase, which will boost wages at the bottom of the pay scale, will not address the staffing problems local government faces. The EO says recruitment troubles are focused on higher paid jobs and is pushing for a percentage pay increase.

This essentially unchanged position will infuriate the "big three" local government unions, Unison, the T&G and the GMB.

Unison's head of local government, Malcolm Wing, yesterday confirmed that the 3% offer remained unacceptable. "Industrial action is a real possibility this year. None of us want it, but we won't shy away from it."

EO officials appear to have written off the possibility that the unions will take the 3% offer. They are predicting three possible outcomes from today's talks: the unions could move towards strikes, one of the sides could go into arbitration, or the talks could end in deadlock, but with both sides still trying to find a solution.

fields.headline: Battle commences
fields.standfirst:
Owain James faces just one
           challenger for the NUS presidency
fields.trailText:
Remember the days when the presidency of the National Union of Students was a passport to fame and
           flattery in the Labour Party? Just ask Jack Straw, home secretary, or for that matter his deputy, Charles
           Clarke. And that's not forgetting potential ministers Stephen Twigg, Phil Woolas, Lorna Fitzsimons and
           Jim Murphy, MPs all.
fields.body:
Remember the days when the presidency of the National Union of Students was a passport to fame and flattery in the Labour Party? Just ask Jack Straw, home secretary, or for that matter his deputy, Charles Clarke. And that's not forgetting potential ministers Stephen Twigg, Phil Woolas, Lorna Fitzsimons and Jim Murphy, MPs all.

The current president, Owain James, 24, is a Labour member, although he stands as an independent. But as he seeks re-election at next week's NUS conference in Blackpool, he professes no greater political ambitions. Instead, inspired by spending his early childhood in Sudan, he is hoping for a career working in international development.

His challenger in this year's elections, current NUS treasurer Helen Aspell, is not a Labour party member. She takes support from the hard left, including the Socialist Workers' Party, the Campaign for Free Education and the Alliance for Workers' Liberty. But in any case she wants to be a firefighter. She hopes to become involved in the Fire Brigades Union on equality issues, but does not want to hold office in it.

But reassuringly - or infuriatingly - the NUS conference promises to live up to its reputation of recent years: some pretty pointless platform faction-fighting, lots of shouting and, in among it all, some formal debates, this year on regular favourites - education funding, welfare, student rights and "building an active union".

Student unions send representatives - one for each 1,000 students - to the conference, who are elected or, in some cases, particularly in the further education colleges, nominated. Well-organised political machines can easily get their people in.

After informal hustings on Monday and formal hustings on Tuesday, around 1,000 delegates will vote for the president and five other full-time officers.

Neither candidate is prepared to stick their head above the parapet and call for sabbatical officers to be elected by a universal ballot of all NUS members. James, pleased he only has one challenger this year, will be re-elected by a few or lose by a few. Aspell thinks she will win.

This hasn't been the sorriest year in NUS history by any means. David Blunkett's 11th-hour pledge to rule out the introduction of top-up fees in the next term of a Labour government has taken some of the heat off James, who is backed by Labour Students this year as last (when they chose not to put up a candidate for election).

The NUS has lobbied hard against top-up fees, although the education secretary's decision had arguably much more to do with appeasing middle Britain's parents than assuaging student protest.

James logs in his credit column the announcement of the first increase in funding per student for over a decade in November - two days after the biggest student march for around 10 years, involving 17,000 people, complained that it was still falling under Labour.

The March 1 "shutdown" by students over funding was also successful. James will press the government this year to reintroduce the grant for students from low-income families. Perhaps James's most controversial internal decision was to sign up to a 30-year internet deal with ITM Activate to deliver a new NUS Online service. Some unions complained the deal was poor and much too long. But Aspell, for one, defends it and James says the NUS can give three years' notice to pull out.

James, who studied Morse (mathematics, operational research, statistics and economics) at Warwick, says that in the long term the mostly silent majority in the 500,000-strong student community could be more easily mobilised through the database established by NUS Online. With it, the union could have better fought the introduction of top-up fees, he argues. His main regret is that he hasn't made enough inroads into ending factionalism within the union which, he says, has torn it apart for 30 years.

She has an ambitious agenda to engage part-time and mature students, students with children and students in further education colleges. She will campaign for the abolition of tuition fees and the reintroduction of full maintenance grants for all. Though she doesn't expect the government to deliver all her demands within her presidency, in time she believes the debate can be moved on so that taxpayers, including her future colleagues in the fire service, accept that case.

"As the first independent president in 30 years my aim has been to put students at the heart of NUS . This year, working with Unison and the teaching unions, we organised the largest student protest for a generation.

"We won more in the last eight months than in the last eight years: the return of maintenance support in Northern Ireland, the extension of the education maintenance allowance in further education, the higher education review in Wales and the u-turn on top-up fees. "Next week, students will have to choose between a candidate selected by the traditional hard left factions who have always dominated the NUS or pick the route of change."

"If we are to make gains on student funding, fight against the impoverishment of our institutions and provide a positive agenda for the education system, we have to change.

"Students have limited power: united with local community groups, trade unions, anti-racist campaigners, our voice will be far stronger. To create an NUS that is a genuine force for social change, it has to decentralise.

" NUS has the potential to be part of a movement of NGOs and the general public in placing demands on to the government.

" NUS must mean every student having the chance to be part of a vibrant, grass roots movement. That sort of community involvement is the model for the sort of union that can win back the maintenance grants that all students so desperately need."

fields.headline: US advertisers shun Oscars
fields.trailText: 12pm: The downturn in the US economy has hit one of the country's most extravagant events, the Oscars, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The downturn in the US economy has hit one of the country's most unashamedly extravagant events, the Oscars, as advertisers shun Hollywood's annual shindig.

The Academy Awards are second only to the Superbowl in the US advertising calendar and the country's biggest advertisers have traditionally chosen to premier their new campaigns during the annual broadcast.

While the male-dominated Superbowl is the Holy Grail for car and beer companies, the female-oriented Oscars are the highlight of the year for cosmetics and hair-care advertisers.

But this year, ABC, which broadcasts the awards, is struggling to persuade advertisers to pay the usual premium.

Many slots for this Sunday's broadcast are still unsold and ABC has slashed the price of a 30-second slot by almost a third to £660,000.

Cosmetics company Revlon is among the major US advertisers to have said it will not advertise during the awards.

The company said it had abandoned the tradition to "manage expenses" and that it was looking at "smarter" ways of spending the money.

The average price for a 30-second commercial during the Superbowl was £1.35m, down slightly from £1.39m in 2000.

As recently as last month, ABC was optimistically claiming the average price of a 30-second slot would rise slightly, from £860,000 to £920,000.

This was because the network had signed deals with many of its regular advertisers months ago, before the economic slowdown began to bite.

Unlike the Superbowl, which moves from network to network, the Academy Awards have been broadcast on ABC since 1976.

This means the network has long-term deals with advertisers, making the price of advertising less volatile.

But if ABC has to sell of its remaining slots at rock-bottom prices - as now looks likely - its regular advertisers will think twice about paying the full whack next time round.

Related story
Dec 21: VW in Superbowl ad deal

webTitle: Leicestershire social services scores high marks

fields.headline: Leicestershire social services scores high marks
fields.standfirst: A joint review report finds that 70% of users and carers consider Leicestershire's social services 'good or excellent'. David Batty reports
fields.trailText: A joint review report finds that 70% of users and carers consider Leicestershire's social services 'good or excellent'. David Batty reports.
fields.body:
Leicestershire social services department provides well-targeted community-based services that meet the needs of most local people, according to a joint review report published today.

The report by the audit commission and the social services inspectorate found that 70% of users and carers consider Leicestershire's social services "good or excellent".

Key strengths included an emphasis on supporting a high proportion of adults and children in the community rather than institutions, and committed staff and managers who work well in partnership with others - particularly when caring for people with mental health problems and young offenders.

Leicestershire county council covers a relatively affluent area, although it contains pockets of deprivation and high numbers of people from ethnic minorities. It spends less on social services per head of population than most other local authorities, particularly on children's services and mental health.

The joint review also praised the range of information leaflets available on services and how to gain access to them, and the clear eligibility criteria for both adults and children.

However, the review team pointed to several areas where improvement was needed. They called on the authority to improve care standards in two children's homes and to modernise services for people with learning disabilities. The lack of specialist services for people from ethnic minorities was also criticised, as was the lack of individual appraisal in managing staff performance. Monitoring of services also focuses too much on processes rather than the outcomes achieved for service users.

Director of the joint review, John Bolton, said: "Leicestershire is an authority that has made significant progress in the last couple of years, particularly with regard to the relatively low level of both adults and children who are placed in residential care. Undoubtedly work is needed to improve the quality of some services, especially for children and people with learning disabilities, but the authority is in a good position to build upon its strengths and raise the standards of social care provided to local people."

The joint review called on the authority to improve care within all children's homes by improving links with the rest of social and other services to develop a more open and less defensive culture. The review team also recommended staff supervision on a regular basis. They also called for improved coordination with health services for children with disabilities, reviews of the supply of home care, thresholds for children-in-need services, as well as child protection and support to those at risk from neglect.

Leicestershire council's director of social services, Tony Harrop, welcomed the report's praise for staff and the authority's success in supporting a high proportion of children and adults in the community.

He said: "We approached this review as an opportunity to obtain an informed, external view of how well we are doing and to advise us on what we could improve in the future. The report's conclusions are a spur to us to continue to develop both the range and quality of our services."

webTitle: Party Politics: The country needs Kennedy, if he behaves like a liberal

fields.headline: Party Politics: The country needs Kennedy, if he behaves like a liberal
fields.standfirst: He should be making the case against Straw's excesses
fields.trailText: He should be making the case against Straw's excesses.
fields.body:
In any given election, significant numbers of people vote Liberal Democrat who have no idea what the party stands for. There have been notorious byelection polls showing that as many as a third of the voters believe the Lib Dems reflect, for example, their own fierce anti-Europeanism.

Of all the parties, the Lib Dems' support depends least on their perceived ideological identity. All those years of Paddy Ashdown's prophetic vision have still come to this: a scrambling around, for at least half their votes, among people who just can't stand the other two, and don't much care about the finer points of what the third lot thinks.

This sounds like a dubious faculty. In fact it's a kind of liberation. It doesn't prevent the party taking positions. To be taken seriously, that is what it has to do. But such position-taking, since it's not being widely listened to, can afford to be less rigidly chained to the vulgar populism that mesmerises other parties. When Charles Kennedy is asked about the euro, yes or no, his monosyllabic clarity, so baffling to interviewers schooled in double-talk, is arresting to witness.

At his pre-election conference in Torquay, however, he sounded different. He barely came over as a liberal at all. There was scarcely anything different between his discourse and his rivals'. It seems that with an election beckoning, the Lib Dem leader thinks he should sound safely familiar, knocking the other two but junking what is unique about his own party.

What Mr Kennedy thinks is bold, the 1p income tax rise, isn't bold at all. It brings some vestigial benefit in terms of political honesty. Lib Dems can beat their pious breasts as they announce this cute positioning. But the promise has no interest. For one thing, we all know they won't be able to do anything about it. For another, it's fatuous to try to outbid Labour on public spending.

The Lib Dems tried that last time, only to find their tax-rise promise hugely outdistanced by Labour's actual spending. As things stand, Labour have cornered the market in the politics of spending. By giving all his effort to following them down that track, Mr Kennedy simply joins an auction at the centre of centre-ground politics where the Tories have been dragged as well. I don't believe it's likely to add a micro-percentage to the Lib Dem vote.

Where the Lib Dems are different, on the other hand, Mr Kennedy was silent. This concerns, in a word, their liberalism. The country has never stood in greater need of liberalism being reaffirmed. The encroachments on it, by a home secretary who grows ever more defiantly hostile to liberal principles, multiply by the week.

The criminal justice and police bill gives the police draconian powers against demonstrators of all kinds, not just the animal liberation front. New powers are being proposed to seize assets merely on suspicion of criminality. Juries and not merely judges may soon be allowed to know about past convictions before a trial begins.

Worst of all in this systematic erosion of the presumption of innocence, the double jeopardy rule has been recommended for abolition. It's an iniquitous proposal, prompted by one notorious case, which proves only that in a populist environment easy cases make even worse law than hard ones.

How a murder jury, retrying what's been announced by the court of appeal as a defective acquittal, is supposed to bring an open mind and fair justice to its work is a question so far answered only by wishful blather about the need not to let them know about the history of the case. Riddled with anomalies, the law commission's destruction of a basic rule is none the less accepted by much bien pensant opinion: final proof that liberal principles, unless reasserted, are heading for the rocks.

In parliament, the Lib Dems have a decent record in this field. They're sometimes a bit slow. On double jeopardy, all they've said so far is that they remain to be persuaded. But they will oppose letting juries know whether the accused in the dock has a criminal record. Their stubbornness in the House of Lords prevented Jack Straw getting his way, first time round, in the curtailment of jury trial. Simon Hughes, the front-bench spokesman on home affairs, has an excellent grasp on the issues and diligent command of the detail of bills that might be open to amendment.

Charles Kennedy is a liberal too. But with him there's a problem. Roaming round the platform at Torquay, letting his stream of consciousness run on, he somehow found no room for the core of liberalism. He alluded to justice and liberty, but dwelt predominantly on the money. Outspending Gordon Brown seemed more important than putting Jack Straw on the liberal rack. Hammering William Hague for the last Tory government's record on crime was accompanied by no ringing defence of the value system, in the courts and in the prisons, with which a decent liberal society should seek to improve upon it.

This has become quite a hard speech to make. There is evidence that the Tories' own efforts to rebalance trials against the defendant, which Straw is emulating, have not worked. For example, the Home Office itself has published evidence that abolishing the right to silence has had the very outcome its opponents predicted.

"Police officers," it reports, "were sceptical about the impact .. on 'professional' criminals .. Legal advisers were concerned about the potential impact of the provisions on vulnerable suspects." Six years on, abolishing the right to silence has "not led to any discernible increase in charges or convictions". Despite that, criticising illiberal penal and judicial regimes remains painfully unfashionable.

Here, however, lies the Lib Dems' unique role and historic opportunity. There ought to be scope for a Tory party that was still sensitive to traditional rights and liberties to take an oppositionist stance against the Straw excesses. But Mr Hague and Ms Widdecombe sold that pass long ago. The Lib Dems have the field to themselves, if only they will march to the high ground standing vacant.

The defence of individual liberties, the protection of due process, a challenge to the crudities of prison, an insistence that certain rights are inalienable even against the Sun: here is a Lib Dem agenda that needs to be taken beyond parliamentary committees, and out of party gatherings where everybody agrees with it, to the widest audience.

Whether the audience will be listening is another matter, and whether it will vote accordingly still another again. But that's the beauty of the Lib Dems' situation. Their principles need not impede their vote. To those who do listen, however, hearing liberalism defended would be an inspiration. That kind of vote may well have existed in Romsey, and may still do so. Mr Kennedy was good in that byelection, standing up for asylum seekers. Now he needs to find an idiom that lets him talk with passion about issues nobody else will touch.

webTitle: Was scrapping the three-A-level system such a good idea?

fields.headline: Generation exhausted
fields.standfirst: The new AS-levels were meant to encourage teenagers to study a diversity of subjects. Instead they are doing more of the same - and working 60 hours a week in the process. So was scrapping the three-A-level system such a good idea?  Phil Revell  reports
fields.trailText: The new AS-levels were meant to encourage teenagers to study a diversity of subjects. Instead they are doing more of the same - and working 60 hours a week in the process. So was scrapping the three-A-level system such a good idea? Phil Revell reports
fields.body:
It was going to broaden the post-16 academic diet, increase choice for sixth-formers and raise standards. But Curriculum 2000, in place for just six months, has already run into problems.

Sixth-formers are typically working 50- and 60-hour weeks to keep up with the demands of the new courses. And, as the exam season approaches, schools, too, are feeling the strain. This summer they will have to run three virtually simultaneous sets of exams - GCSEs, AS-levels and A-levels. Already stretched by teacher shortages and threatened industrial action, many schools will be forced to use local halls and buy in exam supervisors, and all face a huge bill from examboards.

Meanwhile, Key Skills, the government's flagship programme to meet the needs of industry, and a core component of Curriculum 2000, has been declared "a complete disaster" by Dr Ken Spores at London's Institute of Education, who has been evaluating the Curriculum 2000 reforms as part of a research study for the Nuffield Foundation. And as if that wasn't damning enough, his research has also shown that most sixth-formers are not choosing a wider range of subjects than before - thus undermining the very basis of the project.

Curriculum 2000 was the result of the Dearing Report into post-16 education, published in 1998. The report criticised the fact that a sixth-former in England studying A-levels typically had 15-18 hours of taught time a week, compared with up to 30 hours in France or Germany. Moreover the A-level, despite being admired for its rigour, represents early specialisation. In Europe young people study much broader-based qualifications such as France's baccalaureate.

Ministers were keen for English students to experience the same broad diet, with a mix of arts and sciences. "Students should be able to undertake more than three subjects in the first year of the sixth form," said Baroness Blackstone when the changes were first announced. In addition, "key skills should be more widely taught - industry increasingly requires students with better understanding of communication, maths and IT."

So Curriculum 2000 was launched, and this year's lower sixth became guinea pigs again. This age group was the first to experience the national cur riculum, the first to sit tests at 7 and 14, the first to experience target-led teaching. They are now expected to study up to five subjects for a year at the new AS-level. The new Advanced Subsidiary Level is a qualification in its own right. At the end of the first year of sixth form, students will take their AS-level exams, before dropping back to the traditional three subjects in their second, A-level, year.

But Dr Spores, who has surveyed a large number of schools and colleges for Nuffield research has found that the new courses are so demanding that hardly any students are opting for five subjects. And despite the expectation that 17-year-olds would study a mix of arts and sciences, the Nuffield research has also found that choice appears to be following traditional patterns, with students choosing subjects that reflect their strengths. Nathan Dippie certainly isn't. Although he is one of the minority who is doing five subjects at AS-level, they are a fairly predictable mix: physics, chemistry, biology, maths and geography. He has taken the unusual step of studying five subjects because he's undecided about his future, torn between medicine and an interest in geophysics. His AS-level choice keeps both options open, but at a price.

"I get no free study time at college," says the 16-year-old from Shropshire. "And I get about 15 hours a week of homework. I've got a part-time job and I try to have a social life. I'm an actor with a local theatre company and I dance, which involves three visits a week to the dance studio. It's extremely difficult to juggle all of this. I come in at 10pm from dance class and I know that there is two and a half hours of school work to be done. Most nights I don't get to bed until midnight or 1am."

Even in the independent sector most students have been advised to limit themselves to four subjects. Dulwich College in south London is a prestigious independent school with an excellent reputation. At A-level the school averages nearly 25 points per candidate, but sixth-formers are typically studying four AS-levels.

"I'm doing English, history, French and theatre studies," says 17-year-old Toby Ross, who attends the school. "Most people are only doing four." Toby is coping well, but at the expense of other things. "It would be nice if there was more time for things like school plays," he says. "I wanted to direct something this summer, but there's no time."

The head, Chris Henstock, broadly supports Curriculum 2000. "Fundamentally I believe in the changes," he says. "At my school there are more kids doing a variety of subjects." But he is also concerned about the knock-on effects of the workload.

"We used to run a community involvement programme," he explains. "But students aren't putting themselves forward. Short courses in Japanese, archaeology, astronomy, business French hare been squeezed out. A lot of these led to a qualification, but the school can no longer afford them and the students no longer have the time."

Meanwhile, at the highly academic King Edwards Handsworth Grammar School for Girls in Birmingham, Elspeth Insch OBE is another head teacher with mixed feelings about the reforms.

"The lower sixth appears to be working harder than sixth-formers have ever worked in the past and in some ways I'm happy about that," she say. "But my girls get just seven free periods a fortnight - there isn't much free time."

Most of the King Edwards girls are following four subjects, but even so curriculum enrichment programmes such as the school's community service provision have been hard hit.

"Our girls used to hear children read at local primary schools. Very few have the time for that now." Insch is also worried about the effect on her staff. "The extra subject represents a 25% increase in workload across the board and it has added to classroom numbers, which were already too big. The marking load is horrific."

And this isn't all. Many sixth formers are also studying for the new Key Skills qualification. This covers three of the generic skills which the government thinks individuals need in order to be effective members of the workforce: communication (written and oral), application of number (numeracy by any other name), and information technology.

"Key Skills is a disaster," argues Dr Spores. "The kids don't like it and teachers think the delivery and assess ment of the course is too complicated."

The new course has certainly resulted in some bizarre situations. High-fliers who got A* at GCSE in English or maths are being told they have to do the programme, and computer buffs who have produced websites are being put though programmes of basic IT.

"We complained," said one group of further education students at Stourbridge College in the West Midlands. "We said the course was a complete waste of time, but we were told that Key Skills was compulsory."

In fact, Key Skills is not compulsory, but schools and colleges are under intense pressure to persuade students to take the course because they have been funded to provide it, and inspectors will want to see that the money has been spent. And yet the Nuffield research has found virtually nobody with a good word for the new course, not even the employers it was introduced to please.

Stourbridge is certainly aware of the strength of feeling about Key Skills. "It has been an issue this year," says college principal Sadie Walton. "I know that staff and students are unhappy about the programme.We know we need to get this right for students. If we don't they'll vote with their feet."

There is already anecdotal evidence that some colleges are experiencing a higher drop-out rate this year, as a result of the Curriculum 2000 package. For many less able students, it seems, the pressure is simply too much. It seems ironic that a reform intended to broaden the 16-19 experience could be having the opposite effect. What's more, sixth formers have effectively lost a term of tuition - instead of attending classes in the summer term of the lower sixth, they are taking exams.

Ken Spores emphasises the ongoing nature of the Nuffield research - definitive findings aren't expected for some months. He is broadly supportive of the new curriculum, but argues that ministers need to urgently rethink aspects of the reforms.

"There are gains," he said. "The new arrangements offer some additional breadth, but we may have lost some of the enrichment elements of the old curriculum. The pace of work is frantic at AS-level and the Key Skills programme is in deep trouble."

webTitle: Report urges better chatroom protection for children

fields.headline: Report urges better chatroom protection for children
fields.standfirst: Full report here
fields.trailText: British children are not properly protected from paedophiles on the internet, a Home Office-sponsored report says today.
fields.body:
British children are not properly protected from paedophiles on the internet, a Home Office-sponsored report says today.

The Internet Crime Forum - who represent police, social workers, the internet industry and civil liberties groups - spent nearly two years examining cases of abuse of children through the net.

The study - called "Chat Wise, Street Wise - children and internet chat rooms" - urges a review of the law to tackle adults who target children for abuse on the internet.

Numerous examples of abusers "grooming" children, often through winning their confidence by pretending to be teenagers in online chat rooms, were looked at.

Although it does not call for a sweeping reform of the law, it does recommend internet service providers set up "safe haven" spaces within their domains. It also calls for cyber police to monitor the areas, and some form of "kitemark" to reassure parents the sites were safe.

Children and parents are also to be given advice on net etiquette, such as never giving out email or home addresses, their phone number or details about which school they attend. A special police hotline will also be set up for parents to report suspected cases of grooming.

More than 5m children under 16 in the UK are online, with 1.15m admitting to using chat rooms. There are thought to be around 100,000 chat rooms on the web.

The report - which will now go to the home secretary, Jack Straw, for consideration - comes as concern over the safety of children on the net grows in the UK.

London's Saatchi gallery was forced to defend an exhitibition of photographs containing pictures of naked children after an expose in a Sunday tabloid newspaper.

The paper claimed the photographs had already been posted on child porn sites on the web.

More than 2,000 men in the USA have been convicted of internet sex offences in the past six years - but prosecutions are more rare in the UK as defence barristers can argue any police operation constitutes entrapment.

Last year one of the designers of the Lara Croft computer game, Kenneth Lockley, was jailed for 18 months after trying to incite an undercover police officer to lure child for sex.

fields.headline: Automatic for the people
fields.standfirst: The Audi A4 has gained weight - but it's all muscle. And its new gearbox turns driving into an arcade game
fields.trailText: The Audi A4 has gained weight - but it's all muscle. And its new gearbox turns driving into an arcade game.
fields.body:
Without wishing to seem unduly abrasive about this, I would suggest that the world pretty much divides between people who agree that the Audi A4 is king of the saloons and people who have no taste. The A4 is a large, relatively expensive German luxury item and is therefore, under all but the most forgiving analyses, vulgar as hell. But it carries its vulgarity lightly, without waving a metaphorical wedge of £20 notes in the air, in the manner of most Mercedes, and without seeming to be stolen, in the manner of all BMWs. It is a triumph for style and snobbery alike.

As with all Audis, A4s are also built so solidly that each one now emerging from the factory will probably outlive petrol and still be fully functional when we are all humming around in battery-operated pods or sitting at home in corrugated huts and grunting at each other, depending on how you see the future panning out. This makes an A4 a good long-term investment - even though it doesn't really have to be, since most people in the market for a new A4 will be trading up every two years or so, or getting their company to do so on their behalf.

Compared with the model of two generations ago, the new car seems to have gained weight - but muscle, rather than flab. The doors on an Audi always close with a reassuringly expensive clunk, but they seem even more gratifyingly thick and solid on the new A4. The old angular boot has now been entirely smoothed over, losing the car's one concession to flash and making it appear still more lordly. Inside, further elements on the dashboard appear to have been backlit in the customary red, ensuring that the car lights up like Hong Kong by night. Best of all, the A4 comes with a multi-CD changer which allows you to post all six CDs through the single slot in the dashboard while in the driving seat. What this does away with is the traditional boot-loading drama, which requires you to rack the CDs in something worryingly reminiscent of an eight-track cartridge and then climb into the trunk of your car with it. It's amazing this routine ever caught on.

I drove a two-litre A4, suitable for the withering of most other road users. It was fitted with a Multitronic gearbox, which Audi is very excited about and which means that the car functions as an automatic, but has a simulated manual override. For anyone with even a mildly competitive nature, these dual-function gearboxes typically lay down a challenge. The challenge is: can you drive this car better than this car can drive itself?

And I have to report that, in my case, no I could not. In every head-to-head confrontation between me and the car, the Audi whupped my sorry ass. In order to do battle, you have to shift the gear stick from Drive to Multitronic, which always looks easy enough on programmes such as Thunderbirds, but, while travelling at speed through a busy motorway intersection, can actually be fraught with its own anxieties. If this is a nervy moment, it's because it seems to have something in common with the action of throwing a fast-moving car into reverse and thus imaginably causing the engine to eject through the bonnet and the remains of the car to land in a field five miles to the rear.

However, trust me: when you move the gearstick across into the Multitronic bay, absolutely nothing changes. By rights, the on-board computer should flash a message from the gearbox on to the screen on the dashboard, saying something like, "Fancy yourself, do you, big boy?" or "Listen, sonny: leave the gear changes to someone who actually knows", but this doesn't happen.

Instead, you are now free to match the gear to the speed of the car, by tapping the gearstick in the direction of the plus or minus symbols. And if you're me, you will soon have the rev counter peaking wildly and the engine howling with derision. At which point you will push the gearstick back to Drive and admit defeat.

The fact is, every time I tried to stick my oar in, the automatic gearbox revealed itself to be doing a largely unimprovable job. Better, I reckoned, to sit back and let it get on with it. I'm sure David Coulthard, for instance, could skilfully use the Multitronic to find a little extra push for an over-taking manoeuvre, or to slow the car down smoothly on a steep gradient. But I would still argue against the system on the grounds that it goes against what is surely the founding principle of automatic cars - namely, laziness.

The whole point of owning an automatic is to indulge in one-hand, one-foot driving, preferably from the ergonomically unsound slouching position modelled by fat cops in American television shows, and hopefully with the stereo up too loud. Bolting a simulated manual option on to an automatic is like serving a conscience-saving side order of beans and pulses with a plate of fish and chips.

Better, with the A4, to go fully automatic. There are few nicer places to slob around.

webTitle: Spielberg film to show dark side of Abraham Lincoln

fields.headline: Spielberg film to show dark side of Abraham Lincoln
fields.trailText: The Oscar-winning director is planning a biopic of the American president based on a biography that claims that far from being an emancipator, he was a racist
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg is to question the integrity of America's most celebrated president in his forthcoming biopic of Abraham Lincoln, according to a report in the Sunday Times. Spielberg's movie, to be adapted from a biography by the Harvard professor Doris Kearns Goodwin, will portray "Honest Abe" as a manic depressive racist blighted by marital problems.

Spielberg is said to identify with Lincoln, who, like the director, was tormented by stress and medical problems. "This is a project close to his heart," says a source at his studio, DreamWorks. "But he is not interested in a sugary confection."

Goodwin - whose previous works include Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream and The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys: An American Saga - believes the fondly held view of Lincoln as a moral crusader and devout family man is unsustainable. "There's more to say, not all palatable to the American public who like their saints saintly."

According to the Sunday Times, White House papers show that the "Great Emancipator" did not start the American civil war intending to free the country's 3.5m slaves. By modern standards he was racist, claiming in private that black people were "morally inferior" and that they should be "pack[ed] back to Africa where they will not cause us any more problems."

Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan and Amistad have both been subject to allegations of historical inaccuracy. If the Lincoln biopic is as confrontational as suggested - and, given Spielberg's pedigree of dewy-eyed patriotism, there may be reason to doubt that - more controversy will surely follow. Before work begins on the presidential pic (expected in the autumn), Spielberg must complete work on his current projects, A.I., with Jude Law, and Minority Report, with Tom Cruise.
