Report of the Session of the Research group of the European Commission for the Control of Foot-and-mouth disease. FAO, Rome, pp139-143. Callens et al, 1998. ibid, pp129-138. Donaldson, 1986. Rev.Sci.tech.Off.int Epiz., 5(2), 315-321. Woolhouse, 1996. Epidemiol.Infect., 363-371. The current delayed slaughter response favours new infections, and unrecognised animals with FMD could therefore be expected to result in between 5 and 50 new infections within 7 days. Airborne spread within the neighbouring 3-5 km frequently occurred in the 1967/8 outbreak under 'unfavourable' conditions on calm, warm, dry spring days and up to 100 km under cooler, moist airflows with higher humidity. The reported delays of 3-4 days from suspicion of infection to slaughter are therefore too slow to be effective in preventing longer distance spread, and establishment of infection in new areas. It must be noted that the longest recorded distance of airborne transmission occurred exactly at this time of year (the winds of March 7th and 10th), and previous longest recorded (Denmark to Sweden) also occurred at the latitudes (54-560N) of Cumbria/south of Scotland (ie climatically very similar).  Haydon et al, 1997. J. math. Appl. Med. Biol., 14, 1-9.(information also from other sources) Donaldson, A.I. et al, 1982. Veterinary Record, 110, 53. The epidemiology of FMD involving sheep is far too uncertain to have confidence that a mass cull within 3 km would be effective, or scientifically justified. In the FMD epidemic in Greece in 1994 the infection in sheep 'faded out' although control measures were poorly implemented. (Callens et al, 1998, Kitching, 1998). In the Macedonian outbreak of 1996, FMD infection entered sheep subclinically and as many as 50% sampled 2 years later had evidence of past infection, but again this source did not result in the outbreak perpetuating itself. Experimental studies suggest sheep produce relatively little virus for onward transmission (compared to cattle, and over 1000 times less than pigs; Sellers, 1971) and are often poor at perpetuating infection by contact. The cull of sheep is therefore not supported by evidence whereas extremely active control of pig and cattle infections are. However the 'fade-out' scenarios mainly occurred under hot, dry conditions, (with the exception of Tunisia in 1989), whereas under cool, moist conditions, with overcast skies, long distance spread over land (1-100 km, beyond the restriction zones) is possible ), particularly from cattle and pig sources, and has already thought to have occurred in this outbreak (Vet Record, March 9th 2001). Further, since sheep are the most sensitive species for becoming infected with virus, there is simply no information available on how many animals have become infected within or beyond the 3 km restriction zones, especially those which may have received windborne virus from the first infected pig farms. It simply cannot be concluded that infection has been restricted to areas planned for the cull.  Sorensen, K.J., & Naletoski, I. (1998). Report of the Session of the Research group of the European Commission for the Control of Foot-and-mouth disease. FAO, Rome , pp 176-181. Callens, M., et al. 1998. ibid, pp 129-135. Kitching, P. 1998. A recent history of FMD. J. Comp. Path., 118, 89-108 Sellers, R.F 1971. Quantitiative aspects of the spread of FMD. Vet. Bull., 41, 431-439. The UK mass cull, therefore, unless it had occurred much earlier and involving all cattle and pigs in the restricted zones would be nowhere near sufficient to prevent infection in cattle and sheep beyond the 3 km radius. Since clinical screening in sheep is so poor a guide to recognition (Callens, 1998, ref above), almost certainly the cull would be a temporary measure and a prelude to later larger culls (which would be very vigorously opposed) in the areas beyond the 3 km restriction, and/or the later use of vaccination. What are the effective alternatives? An emergency vaccination strategy, with stamping out of infected cases, was vigorously promoted and financially supported by the EU and was very effective in the control of type A FMD in Albania (Berlinzani et a, 1998) and neighbouring Macedonia in 1996, with elimination of outbreaks within 12 weeks and 3 weeks respectively. The former was the first outbreak in the region and therefore international responses were delayed; in the latter an area as large as Cumbria was involved and 120,000 cattle were vaccinated, and 4,500 cattle destroyed.  Berlinzani, A, Brocchi, B.,& Simone, F. (1998). Report of the Session of the Research group of the European Commission for the Control of Foot-and-mouth disease. FAO, Rome, pp166-175. Sorensen, K.J., & Naletoski, I. (1998). Ibid, pp 176-181. Emergency vaccination is an approved form of FMD control in Europe and there is significant preparedness to mount an effective vaccine based response, which MAFF and the EU has been funding for at least 15 years. A decision to use emergency vaccination is very likely to be approved without delay by the European Commission since the current outbreak meets almost all the criteria outlined in their policy guidelines (European Commission, 1999): A high density of susceptible animals, (Cumbria, Dumfrieshire, mid-Wales and west Devon have very high ruminant densities favouring rapid transmission.) An infrastucture that is capable of rapidly deploying vaccination (we have highly motivated and technically competent farm staff used to vaccinating their own animals and hundreds of veterinarians and veterinary students available to undertake the work) Predicted airborne spread of the virus (a situation that favours the use of vaccination). Although pig farms are less involved in the current locations, climatic conditions favour airborne spread from cattle farms, which paradoxically are not destined for the proposed cull. A suitable vaccine exists (there are at least 500,000 doses (equal to 1,000,000 sheep doses ) of type O vaccine at Pirbright, UK and about 10 million in the European Vaccine bank). The incidence slope; new outbreaks are occurring daily (a rise to a record of 37 new cases on 17/3) and a very significant reservoir of infection is still present awaiting slaughter, capable of generating new waves of infection. Distribution of outbreaks; widespread outbreaks are seen as an indication for vaccination (29 counties, 17th March). However the main foci could be surrounded by an immune barrier by ring vaccination, an approved EU approved strategies (see below). Public reaction to stamping out; a significant negative reaction is seen as an indicator for vaccine use, since the reaction would be damaging to eventual control (non-compliance) and international opinion to Europe Likelihood exists of the European Commission request for regionalisation of the vaccinated population; the position of the comittee which framed the Report was that there would be no reason to refuse a request to regionalise the outbreak by vaccination if 1) the disease control measures would be fully enforced, 2) the protection and surveillance zones are subjected to strict controls, and 3) the control of movement of animals and their products is effective, each of which can be expected to demonstrably be the case with current EU opinion on MAFFís capabilities. Another indication for vaccination is 'an overwhelming of the capacity to kill and dispose of carcasses within a short time period' (ibid, p 5); patently the case in this outbreak where the delayed slaughter and disposal brings a risk of onward transmission. European Commission, 1999. Strategy for Emergency Vaccination against Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD). http://europa.eu.int/comm/dg24/health/sc/scah/index_en.html However, what the Emergency Vaccination report fails to consider is the value of prevention of virus entry into hill sheep and wildlife populations in upland areas: this should be a strong indicator for vaccination, since a huge cull (in effect, total depopulation) if control by slaughter is the only option. What are the advantages of emergency vaccination Emergency vaccination is of proven use in FMD control (European Commission, 1999, Salt, 1997). It can be used in two ways, simultaneously or separately; to create an immune barrier ('ring' or 'belt' vaccination, creating immunised zones) to prevent spread through populations at risk from airborne or local spread of infection, or to 'dampen down' infection within known FMD infected areas where there is a recognised urgent need to reduce virus transmission and to prevent onward spread beyond the restricted area.( European Commission, 1999, p5). Rapid reduction in virus circulation and new cases; as noted for Macedonia, effective and rapid deployment of vaccination reduced the total period of reported FMD cases to 3 weeks, despite over 18 villages in two districts being involved and avoided establishment in the sheep population of the region. Vaccination limited the slaughter to only 4500 animals. It is capable of enormously reducing the risk of airborne and vehicular spread to unaffected areas, vastly increasing public confidence within and outwith restricted areas in the control process. Vaccination is also seen as ethically and publically acceptable, a rational response to an exceptionally infective condition and which has a very rapid response. Public acceptance, and farming compliance would be expected to be exceptionally high compared to mass culling. The activities can be undertaken by personnel who are not in short supply (as are veterinarians at present); most farmers could undertake, with brief training and with additional support (veterinary students are one resource). It enables valuable germ-plasm to be saved. The current culling policy is unacceptable for its impact on rare breeds and high genetic quality stock; emergency vaccination can enable this to be mitigated. Present recommendations under the rapid system (3 months) for regaining FMD freedom require that vaccinated animals are slaughtered. This would give a short opportunity before slaughter to enable germ plasm (particularly semen) to be collected and stored, which could be later be tested with internationally approved tests (ie in the OIE Manual of Standards for diagnostic tests) recommended for FMD freedom in germ plasm, and later used in re-establishment of the breed line. If vaccinated animals were not slaughtered, a 12 month period would need to elapse after the last case before international recognition of live trade.  Salt, J. (1997). Vaccination against FMD. Veterinary Vaccinology, Elsevier Press. pp641-649. An effective vaccine is available and approved for emergency use. Two banks of vaccine for emergency use occur in the UK, the International vaccine Bank and the European vaccine bank, both held at Pirbright (the latter bank has also deposits of vaccine in 3 other countries). These banks have 0.5 million and 10 million cattle doses of suitable O type available, which translates to about 22 million sheep doses. Callis, J.J (1997). Problems of vaccine distribution (vaccine banks). Veterinary Vaccinology, Elsevier Press. pp703-704. The aim of vaccination is two fold; to protect stock against the disease, but of even greater significance to the national herd, to vastly reduce the proportion of animals which could amplify virus to a point where it is unable to create new cases and naturally does out, or more as required the limited cases can be detected and stamped out. The proportion of each flock herd to be effectively immunised must be at least 70%, preferably at least 80% (Salt, 1997; and Professor Ahl, Tubingen, formerly Chair of EU Animal Health and Welfare Ctte, FMD Emergency vaccination working group); a very achievable figure in the UK where very high compliance is expected, and in such an emergency as this it would be expected that farmers would be anxious to achieve near 100% vaccination rates. It is often said that the FMD vaccine is a poor one, and therefore emergency vaccines are specially formulated to achieve high and rapid responses (below). Salt, 1997, reference above. These emergency vaccines have a high "payload" in order to be rapidly effective as a single shot; they have been shown to be effective as early as 3 days after immunisation, in prevention of infection and disease, within between 4 and 7 days all immunised cattle and sheep being prevented from becoming 'amplifiers' capable of onward transmission. (Cox et al, 1998, Salt et al,1997) This period is shorter than the period between the proposed cull and the expected start of the slaughter!!! Further high payload vaccines are considered effective against almost all strains of the virus type O, therefore expected to be effective in the UK epidemic.  Cox et al, 1998. Report of the Session of the Research group of the European Commission for the Control of Foot-and-mouth disease. FAO, Rome, pp139-143 Salt et al,1997, Vaccine 16,7, 746-754 Vaccine delivery to farmers in Cumbria would in my opinion be expected to result in near 100% vaccination rates within 5 days, and almost complete herd immunity in 10 days. A reduction in cases to nil could be expected within 3 weeks, although restrictions and the few remaining incubating cases that remain. The ramifications for farmers of emergency vaccination are almost certainly better than the current culling policy; but depend on whether MAFF opts for one of the following options: Vaccination in the restricted zones to prevent transmission and risk to surrounding areas, followed by slaughter of vaccinated animals and active cases. This would enable a return to FMD free status in 3 months under the OIE Animal Health Code (see: www.oie.int), and despite the apparent severity of the requirement that vaccinated animals would be eventually slaughtered, the latter could occur in a progressive, orderly manner , allowing germ plasm from very valued blood lines to be stored for later re-stocking/breed resuscitation, and be more acceptable locally than mass culling. The vaccination could be restricted to sheep and pigs, since they have the principal risk of rapid virus amplification and disease is more difficult to detect. Fewer herds would therefore require emergency culling and the outbreak should be curtailed in 3 weeks. Vaccination in the restricted zones, plus ring vaccination to prevent onward transmission; more effective at outbreak control, but if vaccinated flocks/herds would be culled the impact on 'healthy' flocks would be high and apparently nonsensical. However in national terms, return to free status would be regained after 3 months of disease freedom and after cull of the last vaccinated animals. Vaccination as (b) but without culling of vaccinated animals unless FMD is diagnosed as present in the herd/flock; under this system return to free status12 months after the last case of disease. The economic loss associated with loss of the livestock trade is seen as the 'strongest argument against implementation of emergency vaccination' (European Commission, 1999) but needs to be set against the economic loss to other sectors (tourism etc) Vaccination would hugely reduce the compensation package, greatly reduce the compensatory loss of during re-stocking, and the cost of rural aid programmes after the outbreak. Importantly it would reduce the length of time from current to the last case of infection, which could be 2 months or longer (as it was in the more restricted 1967 outbreak) under the culling system or about 3 weeks under vaccination scenario. How quickly could movement of vaccinated animals be resumed, once disease is controlled? Free movement of vaccinated animals from free areas should be permitted is logical (European Commission, 1999), and the report provides criteria for animal movement after vaccination. It can be assumed to be resumed from 60 days after the completion of the emergency vaccination, provided that an effective and reliable surveillance system is in place aided by the recent tests that distinguish animals which have met virus from those which are merely vaccinated (Panina and Ahl, 1998), Working group on Emergency Vaccination, EU Animal health and Welfare Ctte, 1998).  Panina and Ahl, 1998, Working group on Emergency Vaccination, EU Animal health and Welfare Ctte, Report of the Session of the Research group of the European Commission for the Control of Foot-and-mouth disease. FAO, Rome, pp276-278 European Commission, 1999. Strategy for Emergency Vaccination against Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD). http://europa.eu.int/comm/dg24/health/sc/scah/index_en.htmle Doesn't vaccination interfere with our FMD free status? European policy of non-vaccination has the objective of creating a European herd which is without evidence of antibodies to FMD virus, since the latter might indicate animals which carry infection after exposure. Since antibodies can also arise from vaccination, very considerable effort has been made in the 1990's to develop tests that distinguish antibodies resulting from those from infection. At least 5 different tests have been developed and validated (an entire European Union funded Concerted Action was devoted to this-research summarised in over 15 papers in the supplement of the Vet Quarterly, 1998, 20, suppl 2) and these now transform our ability to distinguish vaccinated animals which have not met the infection, and they can identify the important category of those which have been vaccinated in an emergency situation and subsequently become infected upon severe virus challenge. The international recognition ('standardisation') of these tests for the purposes of international trade is ongoing, and the Scientific Ctte of the European Commission was 'of the opinion that the application of NSP-tests allows for an earlier lifting of the restrictions on the movement of vaccinated animals'. Changes to the Animal Health Code of the OIE in respect of testing vaccinated animals as part of the process of regaining FMD freedom, and are under consideration by the OIE, Paris. Amendment of the Animal Health code could occur within 2 months, given the strong European consensus on the use of these tests. Therefore at WORST with emergency vaccination UK exports would be curtailed for 12 months; at best the period could be as short as 3 months after the last case has been slaughtered if the OIE Animal health code was amended this spring. Example peer-reviewed papers; Bergmann, I.E., et al, 2000. Improvement of a sero-diagnostic strategy for FMD virus surveillance in cattle under systematic vaccination, Arch Virol., 145 (3), 473-489. Sorensen, K.J., et al. 1998. Differentiation of infection from vaccination in foot-and-mouth (shortened title). Arch Virool, 148 (8), 1461-76. In other words, if DG-Agriculture was to follow the recommendations of its Scientific Committee and recognise the use of the post-vaccination surveillance system (something it could do in days), and at a later date at its annual meeting this spring the Office Internationale des Epizooties in Paris (OIE) was to amend its animal health code, then FMD free status could be rapidly regained by vaccinated herds without a need for culling, unless shown to be infected. This decision could well be made in the next few weeks if MAFF pressed for it and would completely change the economic arguments (effect on livestock trade) against vaccination. With current regulations emergency vaccination conducted by an effective veterinary service with stamping out of remaining active cases, would at worst result in 12 months loss of the export trade. Surely MAFF should consult with the NFU and other bodies to determine if they would accept this financial loss rather than the enormity of the proposed regional cull. What's going on? webTitle: Farms' suppliers hit hard but expecting no payout

fields.headline: Farms' suppliers hit hard but expecting no payout
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Rural businesses supplying farmers warned yesterday they would be among the hardest hit by foot and mouth yet be unlikely to receive any government compensation.
fields.body:
Rural businesses supplying farmers warned yesterday they would be among the hardest hit by foot and mouth yet be unlikely to receive any government compensation.

Carr's Milling Industries, which sells fertiliser, feed and machinery to farms, joined a lobby of businesses adamant that their trade would suffer through cancelled orders and soaring delivery costs. Chris Holmes, Carr's chief executive, saidhis firm - which is in Cumbria, near infected farms - had expected to sell 175 tonnes of fertiliser from February to April, but so far had sold less than 30 tonnes.

Carr's also had to bear the cost of delivering to single farms in infected areas, to avoid spreading the virus. Mr Holmes said it was impossible as yet to gauge the damage to agricultural suppliers . "It is a damage limitation exercise for us at the moment," he said.

Richard Wood, chairman of Genus, an artificial insemination firm, appealed to the environment minister for compensation for agricultural suppliers. Turnover at Mr Wood's Cheshire firm has halved since the crisis broke and 714 staff are on reduced pay or hours.

Syngenta, a big producer of seeds, herbicides and pesticides, was also having trouble delivering orders.

But some meat processors reported a return to normal levels of business after the lifting of restrictions on livestock movements in most areas.

webTitle: Chief vet's visit fails to pacify militants

fields.headline: Chief vet's visit fails to pacify militants
fields.standfirst:
Farmers are furious after being barred from a meeting to explain the slaughter policy in Cumbria, the worst hit county

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The smell of burning carcasses wafted across the north of Carlisle yesterday as corduroy-trousered men and women gathered to meet the government's chief vet, who had come from London to face the masses in a pub.
fields.byline: Angelique Chrisafis, Paul Brown  and  Kirsty Scott
fields.body:
The smell of burning carcasses wafted across the north of Carlisle yesterday as corduroy-trousered men and women gathered to meet the government's chief vet, who had come from London to face the masses in a pub.

Jim Scudamore, chief veterinary officer, had chosen to explain his culling policy in the heart of the Cumbria farming community: the Auctioneer drinking house on a grey industrial estate, next to a deserted cattle market and behind an empty showroom of polished Range Rovers perched on rocks.

The irony was perfect. Watercolours of sheep grazing in the fields hung on every flocked wall at the Auctioneer. But half a mile down the road, residents were gagging on the stench of diseased animals which had been burning for 14 days and nights in the county worst affected by foot and mouth.

"We're having terrible trouble with the fleeces: they won't burn," said Liz Gwyther, a farmer.

Behind the net curtains of hotels were "Vacant" signs. "This is a ghost town," she said.

Mr Scudamore arrived at the Auctioneer to explain why farmers should accept the decision to cull 300,000 healthy sheep within a two mile radius of infected farms.

Farmers who arrived to meet him were furious to find themselves barred entry to the pub and vowed to blockade farms to stop the Ministry of Agriculture from culling healthy sheep.

Reports had said he would meet farmers face to face, and some had driven 500 miles to make their point. In fact Mr Scudamore met only a handful of vets and two National Farmers Union representatives. They told him that government measures to curb the spread of the disease were not working, and there was a chance all livestock in Cumbria could be dead within a month. The county is the worst affected in Britain.

In Devon, too, farmers were increasingly desperate. The battle against foot and mouth was being lost, NFU regional director, Anthony Gibson, said. "It seems to be one step forward and two steps back."

The national total of infected animals and those in close contact with them that needed to be destroyed passed the 300,000 mark yesterday. Martin Atkinson, Mr Scudamore's deputy in London, said it was clear the epidemic had not reached its peak. After a record 28 cases were found on Sunday, another nine were notified yesterday.

In Cumbria Mr Scudamore said the preventive cull of healthy sheep neighbouring infected farms would go ahead. It could begin within two days in Scotland but was likely to take weeks to begin in Cumbria due to "logistical problems", including a shortage of vets.

He said a regional group of farmers and stakeholders would be set up to discuss the cull, and owners of pedigree and high quality breeds of highland sheep could write to the ministry to request that their animals be spared.

It was "regrettable" that the carcasses of infected animals still lay festering across Cumbria, and the government's priority was to shorten the wait between diagnosis and slaughter of infected stock.

Outside the pub, farmers from healthy farms stood beside art gallery owners and members of the tourist industry waved banners saying "Aid for Cumbria" and "Silence of the lambs for Blair's election".

Gordon Dixon, who has 500 sheep near Kirkbride, a mile from an infected zone, said he would block ministry officials from entering his farm with tractors "if my sheep haven't got the disease _ We will not use guns, but we will use machinery. There is a network of farmers and a directory of mobile phone numbers of farmers who are preparing to help each other blockade farms. Farmers stick together."

The leaders of last September's fuel protests were outside the pub to support farm blockades. David Hanley, a leader of Farmers for Action, said: "It is outrageous that Mr Scudamore will not see us for 10 minutes. The ministry has not kept farmers informed of the situation. We have to watch the news to know whether our animals are to be killed.

"If a cull of healthy animals is called, we will wait for farmers to invite us in, then we will help them block roads. If we face arrest for doing it, they'd better build bigger prisons to house us."

Peter Allen, an NFU spokesman in Penrith, who farms sheep just outside the killing zone, was one of the few who met Mr Scudamore to negotiate terms of the cull.

"There was a feeling around the country that we were being irresponsible," he said. "We must take whatever action is necessary to stop the spread of the disease, and we have to look at it in perspective." He said 80% of NFU members would support the cull of healthy animals.

Asked about farmers who planned blockades he said: "That is their personal decision. I have got to sympathise with them, and I hope they find the best way forward. They have to understand the science behind the government's decision."

Neil Frame, a Cumbrian vet who met Mr Scudamore, said the disease was out of control in the county. "It is probably in our nasal passages and in every supermarket by now."

4The cull of healthy sheep is expected to re-start in Scotland today. More than 1,800 were killed at the weekend on two farms, in Morayshire and Aberdeenshire, that had links to the infected Longtown market in Cumbria.

Up to 30 farms could be involved in the latest stage of the Scottish cull, half of them in Dumfries and Galloway, the only Scottish region with confirmed cases.

The county is the worst affected in Britain. In Devon, too, farmers were increasingly desperate. The battle against foot and mouth was being lost, NFU regional director, Anthony Gibson, said. "It seems to be one step forward and two steps back." The national total of infected animals and those in close contact with them that needed to be destroyed passed the 300,000 mark yesterday. Martin Atkinson, Mr Scudamore's deputy in London, said it was clear the epidemic had not reached its peak. After a record 28 cases were found on Sunday, another nine were notified yesterday. In Cumbria Mr Scudamore said the preventive cull of healthy sheep neighbouring infected farms would go ahead. It could begin within two days in Scotland but was likely to take weeks to begin in Cumbria due to "logistical problems", including a shortage of vets. He said a regional group of farmers and stakeholders would be set up to discuss the cull, and owners of pedigree and high quality breeds of highland sheep could write to the ministry to request that their animals be spared. It was "regrettable" that the carcasses of infected animals still lay festering across Cumbria, and the government's priority was to shorten the wait between diagnosis and slaughter of infected stock. Outside the pub, farmers from healthy farms stood beside art gallery owners and members of the tourist industry waved banners saying "Aid for Cumbria" and "Silence of the lambs for Blair's election". Gordon Dixon, who has 500 sheep near Kirkbride, a mile from an infected zone, said he would block ministry officials from entering his farm with tractors "if my sheep haven't got the disease _ We will not use guns, but we will use machinery. There is a network of farmers and a directory of mobile phone numbers of farmers who are preparing to help each other blockade farms. Farmers stick together." The leaders of last September's fuel protests were outside the pub to support farm blockades. David Hanley, a leader of Farmers for Action, said: "It is outrageous that Mr Scudamore will not see us for 10 minutes. The ministry has not kept farmers informed of the situation. We have to watch the news to know whether our animals are to be killed. "If a cull of healthy animals is called, we will wait for farmers to invite us in, then we will help them block roads. If we face arrest for doing it, they'd better build bigger prisons to house us." Peter Allen, an NFU spokesman in Penrith, who farms sheep just outside the killing zone, was one of the few who met Mr Scudamore to negotiate terms of the cull. "There was a feeling around the country that we were being irresponsible," he said. "We must take whatever action is necessary to stop the spread of the disease, and we have to look at it in perspective." He said 80% of NFU members would support the cull of healthy animals. Asked about farmers who planned blockades he said: "That is their personal decision. I have got to sympathise with them, and I hope they find the best way forward. They have to understand the science behind the government's decision." Neil Frame, a Cumbrian vet who met Mr Scudamore, said the disease was out of control in the county. "It is probably in our nasal passages and in every supermarket by now." 4The cull of healthy sheep is expected to re-start in Scotland today. More than 1,800 were killed at the weekend on two farms, in Morayshire and Aberdeenshire, that had links to the infected Longtown market in Cumbria. Up to 30 farms could be involved in the latest stage of the Scottish cull, half of them in Dumfries and Galloway, the only Scottish region with confirmed cases. What's going on? webTitle: Ads aim to bring back rural visitors

fields.headline: Ads aim to bring back rural visitors
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A multi-million pound advertising campaign to encourage people to visit the countryside will be launched tomorrow, as the government attempts to save rural businesses from bankruptcy.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt  and  Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
A multi-million pound advertising campaign to encourage people to visit the countryside will be launched tomorrow, as the government attempts to save rural businesses from bankruptcy.

Advertisements will run in newspapers and on radio at national and local level, emphasising that visitors are not at any risk of passing on foot and mouth so long as they steer clear of livestock.

Janet Anderson, the tourism minister, will also fly to New York today to "nail the lies" over the disease that are dissuading thousands of Americans from paying spring visits. The British tourist authority is backing up her message with advertising saying that foot and mouth poses no threat to humans.

In a speech before leaving, Ms Anderson said: "In America, they all think the UK is closed. They think we are under siege with a funeral pyre in every field."

The trip reflects the importance of the US market. Some 4m visited the UK last year, spending £2.5bn. Although the number of transatlantic trips has not fallen, New York travel agents report a slowdown in bookings for this summer, the traditional time for trips to the countryside as opposed to cities.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, yesterday appealed to the media to be responsible in the way in which they report the crisis. "The truth is that the countryside isn't closed."

A spokesman for the environment department said that the government had to put over a difficult message, and the advertisements would have straightforward information rather than glossy pictures. "We do not want people treading across farmland. But equally we want people to know that the countryside is open."

The advertising will fuel criticism that ministers have over-reacted to the outbreak. Ominous warnings led the National Trust to close all its rural properties, while British Waterways has also closed rural canals. Ministers are hoping to persuade the trust to reopen some of its properties.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, will today announce measures to help businesses affected by foot and mouth. At a meeting of the rural taskforce, he will announce that thousands of rural businesses will be allowed to defer statutory payments by three months. The payments include business rates and VAT.

The groups to benefit will extend well beyond agriculture. They are likely to include hotels and bed and breakfast businesses, whose takings have fallen by up to 50%.

The response to the crisis is also designed to clear the way for a general election on May 3. Downing Street is still determined to press ahead with the election, to demonstrate that Britain has not closed down and also allow Tony Blair to benefit from his sky high position in the polls. fields.headline: Slaughter 'spreading disease'
fields.standfirst:
Damning report on Maff strategy

Full text: vet's report on animal culls
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Agriculture's mass slaughter policy is scientifically mistaken, helps to spread the disease, is agriculturally and economically suicidal, and could be be illegal under European law, documents obtained by the Guardian suggest.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Agriculture's mass slaughter policy is scientifically mistaken, helps to spread the disease, is agriculturally and economically suicidal, and could be be illegal under European law, documents obtained by the Guardian suggest.

A seven-page paper prepared by one of Britain's most prominent vets, who has close associations with the world foot and mouth disease centre at Pirbright, Surrey, draws on academic research into outbreaks around the world and proposes emergency vaccination as the quickest and most effective way to bring the disease under control. Vaccination would, it says, end the public's horror of mass funeral pyres and decomposing carcasses and help restore confidence in Britain's farmers.

"The infection is simply too infectious under British conditions in high-density stock- rearing areas for control by slaughter policy, especially where the authorities have proven unable to slaughter within two days. The speed of the response in many cases can be seen to have contravened EU law which requires slaughter and safe disposal without delay and with no risk of spreading the virus," the paper says.

The report was written for Elm Farm research centre, the world's leading organic farming research organisation, whose projects are funded by Maff, the EU and others. The centre is planning a legal challenge to the ministry's policy.

The document, whose author asked to remain anonymous, suggests that the long delays in slaughtering and disposing of carcasses have already led to new infections and that each unrecognised animal with foot and mouth could be expected to result in between five and 50 new infections within seven days.

"The reported delays of three to four days from suspicion of infection to slaughter are too slow to be effective in preventing the spread of the disease beyond 3-5km and the establishment of infection in new areas."

The report paints a dismal picture of the spread of the disease and suggests that the government has no idea how far it has spread. "There is simply no evidence available on how many animals have become infected beyond the restriction zones, especially those which may have received windborne virus from the first infected pig farms. It simply cannot be concluded that infection has been restricted to areas planned for the cull," it says.

It proposes immediate emergency vaccinations which can "enormously" reduce the risk of airborne and vehicular spread of the diseases to unaffected areas and would increase public confidence. "It is also ethically and politically acceptable, a rational response to an exceptionally infective condition and which has a very rapid response. It could result in near 100% vaccination rates within five days and almost complete immunity in 10 days. A reduction of cases to zero could be expected within three weeks."

The government has sev eral options, according to the paper. The first would be to vaccinate all sheep and pigs in the restricted zones to prevent transmission and risk to surrounding areas, followed by the "orderly slaughter" of all vaccinated animals and active cases. This, it says, would curtail the crisis within three weeks and allow Britain to regain its foot and mouth-free status within three months.

Another option would be to vaccinate in the restricted zones and then in a ring around them. This, the paper says, would be more effective at controlling the outbreaks but would also mean the regional destruction of healthy flocks, which is seen by the public and farmers as nonsensical. However it, too, would enable Britain to quickly regain its FMD-free status.

The third option would be to vaccinate animals without culling them unless foot and mouth is diagnosed as present in the herd. This would, says the report, damage the £400m-a-year export trade but should be set against the loss to other sectors, which have been estimated at up to £9bn. "At worst with emergency vaccination, exports would be curtailed for a year, at best for as short as three months", the paper concludes.

Crucially, it says, Britain could regain its FMD-free status and its export trade faster than the government has suggested, because new scientific tests have transformed scientists' ability to distinguish vaccinated animals that have not met the infection and also those that have been vaccinated and then met the virus. The EU scientific committee, the paper suggests, believes "these tests would allow an earlier lifting of restrictions on the movement of vaccinated animals".

The ministry has so far dismissed vaccination as a viable option, but other countries, including the United States, now favour a mix of slaughter and emergency vaccination to combat outbreaks. Nationally, the National Farmers' Union is still opposed to vaccination, but the Cumbria branch has called for limited vaccination as the crisis has worsened.

fields.headline: Homeless campaign raises just £10,000
fields.trailText: A controversial £240,000 government advertising campaign aimed at persuading the public to support homeless charities instead of giving to beggars has raised just £10,000 in four months, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A controversial £240,000 government advertising campaign aimed at persuading the public to support homeless charities instead of giving to beggars has raised just £10,000 in four months, it emerged yesterday.

Launched in the run-up to Christmas, the campaign triggered a furious reaction from Shelter which warned that it risked labelling all homeless people as cheats and drug addicts.

Critics of the Change A Life campaign will seize on the small amount raised as evidence that the attempt to dissuade the public from giving on the streets has backfired.

The government's rough sleepers unit revealed yesterday that it had raised a fraction of what was spent in advertising. But a spokeswoman insisted that the main aim of the campaign had been to encourage volunteering and gifts in kind. "It has raised £10,000 in the first four months of a 12-month campaign, which is a lot of money considering it was not meant to be a fundraiser."

The rough sleepers unit did not disclose yesterday how many people had volunteered - that figure will be revealed later this year - but the spokeswoman said the campaign had been "inundated" with offers of help.

The posters feature beggars holding signs urging members of the public who "really want to help" to call Change A Life.

Academics have expressed the fear that stopping giving money to beggars would lead to a rise in crime. In an open letter to Tony Blair, almost 60 social policy experts described the strategy as "misguided".

Hartley Dean, professor of social policy at Luton University, said: "I think in the week following Comic Relief there are some comparisons to be drawn. I would want to know what success they have had in terms of attracting volunteers, but in terms of cash donations it doesn't seem to be a proportionate investment.

"It is consistent with the evidence of local 'diverted giving' schemes. There was a scheme in Winchester, where the town council and main shopkeepers decided they didn't want beggars seen around the city centre, which raised quite a lot of money initially and then tapered off quite rapidly."

The donations will be divided between Crisis, Centrepoint, the Salvation Army and the National Homeless Alliance.

webTitle: Blue wave dampens French left's gains

fields.headline: Blue wave dampens French left's gains
fields.standfirst: Paris was cause for celebration, but the right triumphed too
fields.trailText: They got the jewels, but missed the crown: the left's joy yesterday at its historic capture of France's two biggest cities, Paris and Lyon, was tempered by the pounding it received in the provinces.
fields.body:
They got the jewels, but missed the crown: the left's joy yesterday at its historic capture of France's two biggest cities, Paris and Lyon, was tempered by the pounding it received in the provinces.

And while the conservative president, Jacques Chirac, will be lamenting the loss of the capital he ran as mayor for nearly 20 years, there were plenty of reasons for him to take heart from the right's robust showing in this weekend's nationwide municipal elections.

"We don't have to change our policies, but we clearly have to adapt our way of governing," admitted the Socialist party chairman, François Hollande, noting that the ruling leftwing coalition's strong national record on boosting economic growth and cutting unemployment had not sufficiently impressed local voters.

The left lost around 30 important towns and cities in Sunday's second-round run-off, while half a dozen key ministers were humiliated in their bid to wrest provincial conservative strongholds from the right, or even to retain town halls they had run for years.

Commentators warned that the "blue wave" that brought the Gaullist RPR party and its centrist allies, the UDF, to power in town halls around the country would lead to the defeat of Lionel Jospin's Socialist-led government if repeated in parliamentary elections next year.

"The blue wave that swept across France's regions weakens Jospin more than the gains in Paris and Lyon strengthen him," wrote the left-leaning Libération, and the rightwing Le Figaro agreed: "Despite its murderous divisions and culpable errors, the right is in a majority in the country. Based on yester day's results, parliamentary elections would see the 'plural left' back in opposition."

The decline of Mr Jospin's coalition allies, the Communists - who in Nimes on Sunday lost the last town they ran with a population of more than 100,000 - combined with the strong performance by the Greens will create strains within the ruling plural left alliance and may force Mr Jospin into a cabinet reshuffle.

Indeed, looking ahead to the parliamentary and presidential elections due in spring 2002, the right may find it easier to rally its troops than the left does to run its Socialist-Communist-Greens coalition.

"The right wing is alive and well, make no mistake about it," said Stephane Rozes of the polling organisation, CSA. Michele Alliot-Marie, the RPR chairwoman, said the right had a nationwide majority that extended even to Paris, where the left won a majority of seats on the city council despite polling fewer votes.

The right's biggest challenge will be to avoid the in-fighting that cost it the town halls of both Paris and Lyon. In disarray ever since Mr Chirac dissolved parliament in 1997, the right has been torn apart by squabbling egos. Mr Chirac's weakness after the 1997 general election led to leadership challenges, including from Philippe Séguin, the RPR's defeated mayoral candidate in Paris, and François Bayrou, head of the UDF, who lost to the Socialists in Lyon.

Senior rightwing politicians such as the former prime ministers Alain Juppé and Edouard Balladur have redoubled their efforts to unify France's conservative forces under a single banner before the polls in 2002.

For Mr Chirac's bid to win re-election to the Elysée palace, the loss of Paris was a heavy blow. But it may not yet prove a disaster, since even when helped by a catastrophic conservative campaign in the capital, the left still failed to poll an absolute majority of votes.

"The blue wave that swept across France's regions weakens Jospin more than the gains in Paris and Lyon strengthen him," wrote the left-leaning Libération, and the rightwing Le Figaro agreed: "Despite its murderous divisions and culpable errors, the right is in a majority in the country. Based on yester day's results, parliamentary elections would see the 'plural left' back in opposition." The decline of Mr Jospin's coalition allies, the Communists - who in Nimes on Sunday lost the last town they ran with a population of more than 100,000 - combined with the strong performance by the Greens will create strains within the ruling plural left alliance and may force Mr Jospin into a cabinet reshuffle. Indeed, looking ahead to the parliamentary and presidential elections due in spring 2002, the right may find it easier to rally its troops than the left does to run its Socialist-Communist-Greens coalition. "The right wing is alive and well, make no mistake about it," said Stephane Rozes of the polling organisation, CSA. Michele Alliot-Marie, the RPR chairwoman, said the right had a nationwide majority that extended even to Paris, where the left won a majority of seats on the city council despite polling fewer votes. The right's biggest challenge will be to avoid the in-fighting that cost it the town halls of both Paris and Lyon. In disarray ever since Mr Chirac dissolved parliament in 1997, the right has been torn apart by squabbling egos. Mr Chirac's weakness after the 1997 general election led to leadership challenges, including from Philippe Séguin, the RPR's defeated mayoral candidate in Paris, and François Bayrou, head of the UDF, who lost to the Socialists in Lyon. Senior rightwing politicians such as the former prime ministers Alain Juppé and Edouard Balladur have redoubled their efforts to unify France's conservative forces under a single banner before the polls in 2002. For Mr Chirac's bid to win re-election to the Elysée palace, the loss of Paris was a heavy blow. But it may not yet prove a disaster, since even when helped by a catastrophic conservative campaign in the capital, the left still failed to poll an absolute majority of votes.

fields.headline: Eyre departure prompts Cohen promotion
fields.trailText:
10am: Tony Cohen, one of the Pearson TV's top exec, has been promoted to the RTL board, reports Amy Vickers.
Mar 19: Eyre quits RTL
fields.body:
Tony Cohen, one of the most senior executives at Pearson TV, has been promoted to the board of RTL in the wake of Richard Eyre's sudden departure.

Currently chief executive of worldwide production for Pearson TV, Mr Cohen will join the RTL group management board as CEO of the RTL group's production business.

Bruno Chauvat, managing director of the RTL group, will assume Mr Eyre's responsibility for strategy at the company.

In a statement today, RTL confirmed Mr Eyre would leave at the end of the month. However, It did not provide any reasons for his departure or details of his next move.

It had been rumoured Mr Eyre might take a sabbatical to write a book.

Reports suggest Mr Eyre had been frustrated at RTL for some time and decided to quit after failing to become chief executive.

In a statement, Mr Eyre said: "The business logic for the merger of Pearson Television and CLT/Ufa was compelling and the RTL group now has one of the world's leading content businesses and is well positioned for growth.

"This was one of my primary tasks and, now it is complete, I have chosen to take the opportunity to think radically about my next steps."

News of Mr Eyre's departure was leaked ahead of the publication of full-year results at RTL on Wednesday, at which Mr Eyre will present.

Before Pearson/RTL, Mr Eyre had been chief executive of the ITV network, a position that still remains vacant.

fields.headline: Express snaps up top photographer
fields.trailText:
9.30am:Richard Desmond has secured the services of the scourge of celebrities everywhere, the paparazzo photographer Jason Fraser, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 19: Catchpole quits Mirror for Express

Mar 19: NUJ calls for Express action
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Richard Desmond has secured the services of the scourge of celebrities everywhere, the paparazzo photographer Jason Fraser.

The celebrity snapper who broke the first pictures of the love affair between the late Diana, Princess of Wales and Dodi Fayed and took the photographs of Robbie Williams and Geri Halliwell on holiday in the south of France, has a reputation as one of Britain's top photographers.

He claims to have been responsible for 75 newspaper splashes last year and is believed to have made up to £1m out of the Diana and Dodi kiss picture.

His decision to join Mr Desmond has stunned the industry - sources say it will have cost the group up to £1m a year to compensate him for loss of earnings with other newspapers.

Mr Fraser's hiring by the newspaper group underlines the importance to the Express boss of celebrity scoops and top class celebrity photographs.

He is joining Northern & Shell and Express Newspapers as executive director, where he will take responsibility for securing celebrity photographic exclusives for the Express, Sunday Express, the Daily Star and OK! magazine.

Mr Desmond said in a statement that Mr Fraser "will play a pivotal role in the building of a successful future for our publications and businesses".

The hiring, for an undisclosed sum, is consistent with Northern & Shell's strategy of hiring expensive "names" to staff his papers at the expense of journalistic footsoldiers.

The Express group yesterday hired Mirror columnist Charlie Catchpole as a celebrity TV columnist for the Express, and the group has famously secured the services of former Sun football writer Brian Woolnough in a deal believed to be worth some £200,000 a year.

But last week it was disclosed that Mr Desmond wants to axe 145 jobs at the Express group in a bid to cut costs.

webTitle: United set to catch young Italian stars

fields.headline: United set to catch young Italian stars
fields.trailText: Manchester United's global tentacles are about to reach out to Italy, with the Premiership champions ready to form a partnership with the Italian club Atalanta.
fields.body:
Manchester United's global tentacles are about to reach out to Italy, with the Premiership champions ready to form a partnership with the Italian club Atalanta.

United, who recently announced a multimillion-pound link-up with the New York Yankees baseball club, already have a partnership with Belgium's Royal Antwerp and are seeking to spread their empire to France, South Africa and the Republic of Ireland.

As a result of the proposed tie-up with Atalanta, United would have first option on the club's young stars, who won last season's Italian youth cup and are in this season's final. Atalanta would benefit from United's marketing expertise.

Senior figures from Old Trafford and the Serie A club based in Bergamo, northern Italy, exchanged visits last week, and more meetings are planned.

Sir Alex Ferguson's assistant Steve McClaren watched Atalanta win the youth cup final first leg against Bari 1-0 last Wednesday, the day after Atalanta's president Ivan Ruggeri and director of football Giuseppe Marotta met the United hierarchy and watched the 3-0 win over Sturm Graz.

Ruggeri revealed: "United will be following our results and our young players all the time. They are seeking to work with other clubs, and we were the club they chose in Italy. They are willing to share their ideas and are well known as a club that develops its own youngsters.

"They are ahead of us in so many respects, especially the commercial side. We plan to build a new stadium, and they will be able to give us good advice."

The Wales manager Mark Hughes has persuaded Ferguson to allow Ryan Giggs to join his country's World Cup squad after all. But the United winger will not travel to Armenia tomorrow for Saturday's Group Five game. He will join up on Sunday to prepare for the Ukraine match in Cardiff next week.

Giggs has only recently returned to light training having not played since February 20 and Hughes has won a minor battle to have him available at all. He has had hamstring trouble and suffered flu last week.

United's goalkeeper Fabien Barthez will miss France's friendlies against Japan and Spain and may also be out of the Premiership game at Liverpool the following weekend.

He sustained a thigh injury in warming up on Saturday and United told France's team doctors that he would be unable to play for around two weeks, a diagnosis now confirmed by the French.

Jesper Blomqvist, 27, United's Swedish international winger who has been out for nearly two years with injury, fears his career may soon be over. He has not played a senior match since United's 1999 Champions League final victory over Bayern Munich and has suffered a relapse of knee trouble during rehabilitation at his former club IFK Gothenburg.

webTitle: Finns fear being stung in Anfield's 'beehive'

fields.headline: Finns fear being stung in Anfield's 'beehive'
fields.trailText: Finland's coach Antti Muurinen tried to play the underdog card yesterday in assessing his team's chances against England on Saturday.
fields.body:
Finland's coach Antti Muurinen tried to play the underdog card yesterday in assessing his team's chances against England on Saturday.

"Going to Anfield will be like sticking our heads in a beehive," said Muurinen, who is still unsure whether the hub of his team, Liverpool's Jari Litmanen, will be fit. The Finns hope their key striker will not suffer a reaction after playing his first game for a month, against Derby on Sunday, since damaging a calf muscle on February 15.

Muurinen thinks that although the sides drew 0-0 in Helsinki, when England were under their caretaker coach Howard Wilkinson, things will be different with Sven-Goran Eriksson now at the helm.

"England's recent victory over Spain is a clear indication of their power," he said. "And you only have to look at the way English teams are playing in Europe at the moment to know it will be a tough challenge.

"They have so much quality up front. Players like Owen, Scholes and, naturally, David Beckham, whom we have to keep a close eye on. His passing skills and accuracy in dead-ball situations are tremendous."

Muurinen can support his argument that Finland are the underdogs by pointing to his injury list. Of the regular starters, Derby's midfielder Simo Valakari and the Genk defender Juha Reini are both out.

Bolton's goalkeeper Jussi Jaaskelainen, who had just begun to challenge Antti Niemi for a starting place, has twisted his knee and is out for the season, as is Barnsley's versatile defender Janne Salli.

As a result, the young Ajax defender Petri Pasanen is likely to get another start. "Petri had a good game against Luxembourg. He is mature for his age and he's got skill on the ball, so he'll get his chance, I'm sure," said Muurinen.

"Up front, we might even try two forwards, like we did against Luxembourg. Jonatan Johansson is one of the best in the Premiership, while Mikael Forssell and Shefki Kuqi are quickly learning their trade in the First Division."

Muurinen admits, however, that Finland's best chance of scoring will come on the counter-attack, which places even greater emphasis on Litmanen.

The 30-year-old has been struggling with injuries but came through 66 minutes of Liverpool's draw with Derby.

"His calf should be OK now and he's desperate to play on Saturday, but we'll have to prepare for the worst as well," said Muurinen. "If he cannot play, it must not be the end of the world.

"We have lots of players working abroad and we don't have to go out against any team just trying to defend. We had more than one or two chances to score against Greece and England in the autumn, and this time we'll have to take advantage."

 The Blackburn midfielder David Dunn is out of England's Under-21 European Championship qualifier against Finland at Barnsley on Friday night. Dunn, the Under-21s' captain, has been struggling with a toe injury and has been advised to rest. He will therefore miss the England game but is expected to be fit when Blackburn return to First Division action at home to Burnley on Sunday week.

Muurinen thinks that although the sides drew 0-0 in Helsinki, when England were under their caretaker coach Howard Wilkinson, things will be different with Sven-Goran Eriksson now at the helm. "England's recent victory over Spain is a clear indication of their power," he said. "And you only have to look at the way English teams are playing in Europe at the moment to know it will be a tough challenge. "They have so much quality up front. Players like Owen, Scholes and, naturally, David Beckham, whom we have to keep a close eye on. His passing skills and accuracy in dead-ball situations are tremendous." Muurinen can support his argument that Finland are the underdogs by pointing to his injury list. Of the regular starters, Derby's midfielder Simo Valakari and the Genk defender Juha Reini are both out. Bolton's goalkeeper Jussi Jaaskelainen, who had just begun to challenge Antti Niemi for a starting place, has twisted his knee and is out for the season, as is Barnsley's versatile defender Janne Salli. As a result, the young Ajax defender Petri Pasanen is likely to get another start. "Petri had a good game against Luxembourg. He is mature for his age and he's got skill on the ball, so he'll get his chance, I'm sure," said Muurinen. "Up front, we might even try two forwards, like we did against Luxembourg. Jonatan Johansson is one of the best in the Premiership, while Mikael Forssell and Shefki Kuqi are quickly learning their trade in the First Division." Muurinen admits, however, that Finland's best chance of scoring will come on the counter-attack, which places even greater emphasis on Litmanen. The 30-year-old has been struggling with injuries but came through 66 minutes of Liverpool's draw with Derby. "His calf should be OK now and he's desperate to play on Saturday, but we'll have to prepare for the worst as well," said Muurinen. "If he cannot play, it must not be the end of the world. "We have lots of players working abroad and we don't have to go out against any team just trying to defend. We had more than one or two chances to score against Greece and England in the autumn, and this time we'll have to take advantage."  The Blackburn midfielder David Dunn is out of England's Under-21 European Championship qualifier against Finland at Barnsley on Friday night. Dunn, the Under-21s' captain, has been struggling with a toe injury and has been advised to rest. He will therefore miss the England game but is expected to be fit when Blackburn return to First Division action at home to Burnley on Sunday week.

fields.headline: Women lead as overseas volunteers
fields.trailText: Professional women are for the first time making up the majority of volunteers overseas, but rarely get the opportunity of a foreign posting in their regular careers, according to an investigation of gender prejudice by the international development charity VSO.
fields.body:
Professional women are for the first time making up the majority of volunteers overseas, but rarely get the opportunity of a foreign posting in their regular careers, according to an investigation of gender prejudice by the international development charity VSO.

It found the number of women volunteers signing up for service abroad has trebled over 20 years, reflecting women's higher qualifications and changing patterns of family life. Last year VSO had 1,130 women working abroad and 840 men.

But women took only 15% of international assignments in companies that commonly regarded overseas experience as a key factor in deciding promotion, according to research for VSO by Hilary Harris, director of research at Cranfield University's school of management.

She said the VSO experience exploded myths about women that were damaging their career prospects by denying them the chance to work abroad.

"There are three very potent assumptions: first that women are not interested in posts abroad; second that family ties prevent them accepting posts abroad; and finally that women sent on overseas assignments are doomed to fail in the face of prejudice in certain countries.

"Yet the VSO figures offer evidence, not only that women are interested in challenging postings overseas, but that they thrive when given the opportunity to do so," she said.

"We have to ask: by denying women such experience, have we created a new glass ceiling? Women make up 30-40% of middle management, but represent just 1% of all chief executive officers."

An NOP poll commissioned by VSO found 51% of women would like the chance to work overseas. But more than 80% of women and men thought it was harder for women to gain respect in some foreign cultures. More than 60% of women and men said it was difficult for women to take up posts abroad because of family commitments. And nearly half said it was harder for women to work abroad than men.

VSO said these public attitudes contrasted sharply with the evidence of its returning women volunteers.

Most of the women volunteers were in their twenties and fifties. The older volunteers said they were prompted by freedom from family ties, an urge to see the world and travel with a purpose. The younger volunteers saw VSO as a boost to career prospects and said they were attracted by the sense of adventure.

Ruth Lewis, the charity's director of recruitment, said: "Here is evidence of a pool of female talent and ability waiting to be tapped, not just by VSO, but by the wider business community."

fields.headline: Clifford steps into Spice Girls row
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Max Clifford is helping a mother to get proper credit for her dead son's work on a Spice Girls film, reports Jessica Hodgson.

Mar 20: Four-year battle to get film broadcast
fields.body:
The mother of one of the two producers of Spice Girls documentary Raw Spice is using PR expert Max Clifford to ensure her dead son gets his share of credit for the film.

The film, which features previously unreleased footage of the Spice Girls before they became famous, is being screened tomorrow night and has already been the subject of a protracted legal battle.

Now Matt Bowers's mother, Helen, is trying to ensure her son, who died before the film was cleared for broadcast, has become involved too.

She is determined that her son gets appropriate credit for the programme.

Mrs Bowers has been particularly keen that the Sun newspaper should not get an exclusive story on the programme.

She is thought to have been angered by coverage in the Sun of her Matt's relationship with Royle Family star Caroline Aherne, and wanted to make sure the relationship was kept out of the film's publicity.

"I was contacted by Helen Bowers, who was concerned that she was not being consulted about the way her dead son was being presented in the publicity package for this film," said Mr Clifford.

Mr Bowers made the film with partner Neil Davies but they were unable to do anything with the footage because the Spice Girls launched a legal battle to stop it being screened.

"Mrs Bowers was concerned Neil Davies was being presented as the major partner in this equation," said Mr Clifford.

"Mrs Bowers was concerned and upset that her dead son was being cast aside in the publicity for this programme."

A Granada spokeswoman said: "We have been liaising with Max and his client Helen on all aspect of the press and publicity surrounding this programme, and as far as we know both parties will be happy with it."

It is thought that Mrs Bowers and Mr Clifford were in negotiations to get images from the film into OK!

Mr Bowers filmed the then unknown Spice Girls up until 1995 with his business partner Neil Davies.

But he died from cancer died four years ago and Mr Davies was forced into a legal battle on two fronts to get the film aired - one against the Spice Girls and the other against two other members of the firm who claimed the videos as assets

The row was resolved last year in the high court when Neil Gaudino and Steve Newman were ordered to give the tapes back to Mr Davies.

Related story

webTitle: How BT got the numbers wrong

fields.headline: How BT got the numbers wrong
fields.standfirst: Shareholders demand changes as debts reach £30bn and options run out
fields.trailText: Investors in British Telecom are expected to demand a dramatic board room shake-up today, write David Teather and Jill Treanor.
fields.body:
Investors in British Telecom are expected to demand a dramatic board room shakeup today that could include the resignation of the firm's top two executives.

At a dinner hosted in BT Centre in the shadow of St Paul's, the company's beleaguered directors will meet with some of the City's most powerful shareholders.

It is invitation only but interest from the wider City community is immense. The company is weighed down by debts of £30bn, more than the GDP of many small countries, and its options are running out. The share price has crumbled from £15 at the end of 1999 to just £5 yesterday.

Anxious for action by the former monopoly to reduce its debts, the shareholders are expected to agree to support the biggest cash call in British corporate industry - providing the chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, and chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, pledge to begin seeking their successors.

"Our real point is that we want to see some action," one senior investor in the company said last night. "Action is really what we want to see after a period of total inaction". Another said: "They have been too reactive for too long. They really need a clear strategy going forward."

BT is regarded by some as a wasted opportunity to build a national champion in a rapidly globalising market. BT, which was privatised in 1984, was at the forefront of deregulation and one of the first in the world to be exposed to competition.

Much of the company's debt is a result of the auctions for next generation mobile phone licences in Britain and Germany, together accounting for around £10bn. These new networks will mean mobile users will be able to access the web at 10 times the fastest connections currently offered by to day's computer modems. The auctions were, unfortunately for BT, at the height of the dot.com boom when the potential for wireless internet had not yet been muddied by the sharp change in sentiment.

The fresh demands for a new strategy come less than six months after Sir Peter unveiled a grand plan to pay down the mountain of debt by splitting BT into five different companies. By the end of 2001, he promised, the company would raise the first £10bn by a partial flotation of its mobile phone holding company, BT Wireless, and Yell, its Yellow Pages division.

But BT has been a victim of bad timing again. The turmoil in world stock markets that has sent the shares in telecoms companies nosediving has dampened any appetite for new shares among investors. The difficult flotation of Orange earlier this year (a company which had otherwise done little wrong) has provided ample evidence that investors no longer regard telecom shares as a must have. BT is being forced to rethink its plans, including cutting BT Wireless loose entirely through a full demerger. Investors are also likely to indicate that they would stomach a cut in the company's dividend.

BT had hoped a rights issue would not be necessary but it faces a once unthinkable downgrading from the influential credit rating agency Standard & Poor's next month. Last night Moody's, an international ratings agency, threatened to cut its debt ratings and expressed concern that the company would not be able to pay off its debts fast enough. If this happens, BT will face an extra £150m-200m in interest charges.

The appointment as finance director of Philip Hampton, credited with breaking up another former state-owned company, British Gas, has proved popular with the City. Investors are divided over whether he should be groomed as the heir to Sir Peter. Sir Iain, who has spent his working life at BT, will be reluctant to step down before his official retirement next year. BT has found it difficult to fully shake off its nationalised culture and has been outmanoeuvered by rivals. The mantle of national champion has long since been taken by Vodafone, which is worth more than three times the market valuation of BT. Instead of pushing out into new markets, BT is in a period of retrenchment and licking its wounds.

BT has got used to fighting a rearguard action. Yesterday it hit back against critics who said it had pocketed £250,000 from Comic Relief calls on Red Nose Day.

The former state monopoly is perceived in the City to have failed in some key areas. While Vodafone has brazened its way through world markets with deal after deal to create a genuine world power, BT has failed to create a global company - aborting mergers with the likes of Cable & Wireless and the US company MCI. In mobile phones, BT Cellnet has been left behind by Vodafone and is on the verge of surrendering second place by subscriber numbers to Orange. BT has also failed to fully exploit the internet and found itself floundering compared with the likes of Freeserve, which have proved more imaginative over new services and pricing.

BT's international ambitions have perhaps had a little too much of the empire about them. While Vodafone pursued a strategy of taking full control of its overseas affiliates, BT was happy to take minority stakes in south-east Asian businesses in the belief that it would wield more influence than it perhaps had. Now many of those stakes are back on the market to help cut the company's debt.

It was very different 17 years ago when a fresher faced Sir Iain persuaded the government that flotation on the stock market was the radical way forward for the company. For every share on offer, there were almost 10 applications. Yesterday, the share price was at a two-year low.

Among those thought to have a ticket to today's meeting are investment compa nies Henderson and Gartmore, both of which refused to comment last night. But it will not be only the City watching with interest. The company still has 1.75m small shareholders as keen as the highly paid fund managers to see their investment take a turn for the better.

Under pressure - Men in charge

Sir Peter Bonfield, chief executive

Sir Peter Bonfield has a samurai sword in his office given to him by the Japanese firm Fujitsu as a leaving present. It was a reminder, the company said, that telecoms was a tough market which would need some serious survival skills.

Hired by BT in 1996, he has had to learn how to scrap.

Sir Peter, 56, had not run a quoted company before and was in large part hired because of his international experience - he spent a substantial amount of his career in the US and Japan, including Texas Instruments and ICL.

He has been largely responsible for the drive into overseas markets but saw his credibility in the City damaged by the aborted merger with US group MCI.

Born in Hertfordshire and educated at Loughborough University, Bonfield 's favourite word to describe himself is "normal". His father was an engineer, his mother a nurse, and they lived in a "normal semi-detached house". He is described by one former colleague as a "straight up and down career executive".

Short and with the accent of estuary man, Sir Peter could hardly seem more different to the lofty Sir Iain, more characterised by his clipped vowels.

Sir Iain Vallance, chairman

Sir Iain Vallance is the architect of the modern BT. It is a sobriquet that the the Oxford-educated Vallance was happy to accept - at least before its recent woes.

He is said to have BT written through him like a "stick of rock", having started with the company's parent the General Post Office in 1966. His father was Post Office director in Scotland.

He joined the board of the telecoms company in 1981 and played a crucial role in privatisation. It was Vallance who was ideologically attuned to the Tory administration - arguing that the markets would be the best place to raise money to upgrade the system.

He was named chief of operations shortly after flotation, and was chief and executive and chairman by 1987.

For many, Vallance was seen as too cautious, too redolent of the old state-owned monolith. But to supporters, he understood the need to take tough restructuring measures involving the losses of thousands of jobs.

His undoubted failure was that BT did not become a global player. Mergers with Cable and Wireless and with MCI of the US which would have vaulted BT into the top rank both failed at the final hurdle.

webTitle: Anthony Storr, the face of psychiatry, dies

fields.headline: Anthony Storr, the face of psychiatry, dies
fields.trailText: Anthony Storr, the psychiatrist who revolutionised public understanding of mental illness, has died at 80.
fields.body:
Anthony Storr, the psychiatrist who revolutionised public understanding of mental illness, has died at 80.

In books, journalism and on television and radio Dr Storr addressed everything from aggression and solitude to the roots of musical and literary creativity.

He sought, he said, "to show that the dividing lines between sanity and mental illness have been drawn in the wrong place. The sane are madder than we think, the mad saner."

Fellow psychiatrists paid tribute yesterday to Storr, whose 12 books, including Solitude, Human Aggression, and Music and the Mind, made him for decades the public face of the profession.

He died in hospital on Saturday afternoon, after a heart attack the previous evening while he was delivering an after-dinner speech at Wadham College, Oxford.

"His biggest contribution was in getting across psychiatric concepts to an intelligent public, in books which are accessible and uniquely free of jargon," said Hugh Freeman, former editor of the British Journal of Psychiatry, and a friend of Dr Storr.

"He was simply a better writer than others who tried to do this, and a delightful person - extremely helpful to a lot of younger psychiatrists - as well as a serious clinician."

In Dr Storr's most recent book, Feet of Clay, he examined gurus, from Sigmund Freud to David Koresh [head of the Waco cult in the US], emphasising once again the fine line between madness and sanity.

"When comparing the beliefs held by psychotics with the religious beliefs held by normal people," he concluded, "it is impossible to say that one set of beliefs is delusional while the other is sane .. even the most rational agnostic secretly harbours beliefs which are deeply irrational, especially in areas concerned with self-esteem and love."

Trained in the tradition of Carl Jung (though he resisted the label Jungian), Dr Storr had done more than any other writer in English to communicate the ideas of the Swiss psychotherapist, Prof Freeman said.

Some psychiatrists criticised Dr Storr for taking a "reassuring" approach to mental illness, failing to acknowledge its unsettling depths. But Andrew Samuels, professor of analytical psychology at Essex University, said his contribution had extended beyond popularisation.

"He was a very considerable historical scholar, and a pioneer in establishing the usefulness of psychotherapeutic understanding to biography, and to broad themes such as genius," he said.

Born in London, the son of the sub-dean of Westminster Abbey, Storr endured unhappy years at Winchester public school before attending Christ's College, Cambridge, where he decided to pursue psychiatry on the basis of a chance comment by his tutor, the novelist CP Snow.

He maintained he would rather have been a musician if he had had the talent.

fields.headline: Anthony Storr
fields.standfirst: Gifted psychiatrist whose compassionate approach was born of his own childhood suffering and loneliness
fields.trailText: Gifted psychiatrist whose compassionate approach was born of his own childhood suffering and loneliness.
fields.body:
Anthony Storr, who has died of a heart attack aged 80, was Britain's most literate psychiatrist. A prolific author, journalist and radio and television commentator, he was widely respected as a fount of wisdom and good sense in a profession not particularly noted for such qualities. Like other kind and compassionate men, he was no stranger to suffering at formative stages of his life.

Born in London, Storr was a solitary, friendless child, plagued by frequent illness, including severe asthma and septicaemia, from which he nearly died. He was the youngest of four children, separated by 10 years from his closest sibling. He also seems to have inherited from his mother a tendency to occasional episodes of depression.

There, and later at Winchester College, he was bitterly unhappy.
