Extremely slow to make friends, and showing little proficiency for games, he was bullied, and made only average academic progress. Though utterly miserable, it never occurred to him to complain to his parents, or attempt to run away, because boarding school was then a fact of life. But the sense of being a loner never left him, and was to affect the course of his career, as well as the content of his books.

What preserved his sanity and emotional equilibrium was a growing passion for music. From an early age, he attended performances in Westminster Abbey of such works as Bach's St Matthew Passion, and was later allowed to sit in the organ loft, an enormous thrill.

At Winchester, he sang in the choir, played the viola in the orchestra and piano solos in concerts. He always maintained that he would much rather have been a professional musician than a psychiatrist or writer, had he been blessed with the necessary talent and training; he freely acknowledged that his friendship with artists of the calibre of Alfred Brendel, and the musicologist Hans Keller, meant far more than would have equivalent friendships with Freud, Jung or Adler.

"I owed him a tremendous debt," Storr told me. "He was the first person who made me feel I might be any good at anything. I had disappointed my parents and teachers by not doing nearly as well as I should have. When I told Snow tentatively that I might go into psychiatry, he said, 'I think you'd be very good at it.' After two years at Cambridge, Storr was given a wartime courtesy degree without taking a tripos, and continued his medical studies at Westminster hospital (1941-44), where he won prizes for medicine and surgery. He gained membership of the Royal College of Physicians in 1946.

His asthma precluded military service and, after a period as house physician at Runwell hospital, he went to the Maudsley hospital (1947-50), where he survived the ordeal of being Professor Aubrey Lewis's first senior registrar on his newly-formed professorial unit. Lewis, an obsessional polymath highly critical of his staff, undermined the confidence of everyone who worked for him.

Storr stuck it for nearly two years, then asked to be moved, thus effectively ruining his prospects for advancement within the psychiatric establishment. "I owed Lewis one thing, at least," admitted Storr. "Once you had suffered the experience of presenting a case at one of his Monday morning conferences, no other public appearance, whether on radio, TV or the lecture platform, could hold any terrors for you."

He obtained the diploma of psychological medicine in 1951, and, developing an interest in analytical psycho- therapy, went into analysis with Jung's English friend and colleague, Dr EA Bennet. He later became a member of the (Jungian) Society for Analytical Psychology. He practised psychotherapy privately, and, from 1961, combined his practice with various hospital appointments as a consultant.

Storr's reputation as a writer and broadcaster began with publication of his first book, The Integrity Of The Personality, in 1960. He was 40, and, up to that point, had not thought of himself as a writer. "I just felt the need to explain to myself what the hell I thought I was doing," he said. "For me, that is the motive for writing anything. I get intrigued by a puzzle, and writing a book is the best way to solve it."

During the next six years, 11 other books followed, of which the most notable were The Dynamics Of Creation (1972), Jung (1973), The Art Of Psychotherapy (1979), Solitude (1989), Freud (1989), his favourite, Music And The Mind (1993), and Feet Of Clay (1996).

Although he did a Jungian training, Storr declined to be labelled a Jungian, preferring to remain "an eclectic sceptic rather than a convert". His books reflected this lack of dogmatism. His love of music and literature, together with his medical and psychiatric training, enabled him to bridge the "two cultures" defined by his friend, Snow.

Storr's particular gift for rendering difficult concepts accessible, as well as his lucid, immensely readable style, made his books as appealing to lay people as to professionals, and his sales reflected this. All but two of his 12 titles have remained in print and, while sales were steady in the UK, they did particularly well in the United States, where Solitude sold 100,000 copies. The Essential Jung (1983) sold 50,000 worldwide, Freud sold 30,000 and Jung 75,000. The books were translated into 24 languages, including Korean and Malaysian, and Storr was especially charmed when Solitude was translated into Chinese for the republic of Inner Mongolia.

Perhaps as a result of his own unhappiness, isolation and depression, Storr's work revealed an abiding concern for those trapped in suffering, whether as psychiatric pat- ients, prisoners or victims of oppression and torture. He served as a member of the Parole Board (1976-77) and the Williams Committee on Obscenity and Film Censorship (1977-79), and his need to penetrate the mysteries of deviant or violent behaviour was apparent in his books on Sex ual Deviation (1964), Human Aggression (1968) and Human Destructiveness (1972).

At the same time, his understanding of human psychopathology gave him a rich appreciation of the creative possibilities inherent in mental suffering, and the powerful potential for self-healing to be found in artistic and intellectual creativity. This made him impatient with the medical model for psychiatry and its obsession with its symptomatic classification. "I want to show," he wrote, "that the dividing lines between sanity and mental illness have been drawn in the wrong place. The sane are madder than we think, the mad saner."

In 1974, Storr gave up private practice in favour of a teaching appointment at the Warneford hospital, Oxford; a post he held until his retirement in 1984. He was very happy in Oxford, enjoying dining rights at Wadham College and becoming a fellow of Green College, where he built his library from scratch.

A number of honours were granted him in appreciation of his contribution to psychiatry and literature. He was elected emeritus fellow of Green College (1984), fellow of the Royal Society of Literature (1990), and honorary fellow of the Royal College of Psychiatrists (1993). The generosity of spirit, so apparent in his writing, was no less evident in his personality, and was freely expressed in the warm support and encouragement he gave to younger psychiatrists, psychotherapists and writers, as well as to the patients who came to consult him from all walks of life.

Storr was twice married, first to Catherine Cole (the writer Catherine Storr, Obituary, January 11 2001), with whom he had three daughters before a divorce in 1970. They survive him, as does his second wife, Catherine Peters.

fields.headline: BBC culture defeats management expert
fields.trailText: A management expert appointed to lead Greg Dyke's transformation of the BBC's culture of bureaucracy is to quit after little more than a year, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
A management expert appointed to lead Greg Dyke's transformation of the BBC's culture of bureaucracy is to quit after little more than a year in the job.

Gareth Jones, who advises on how to tackle the most difficult corporate problems, is understood to have found his task at the BBC too frustrating. BBC sources confirmed last night that his decision to leave would be announced today.

Mr Jones is credited with the "flower petals" management structure introduced by Mr Dyke last year. The "one BBC" plan was designed to bring management closer to staff.

Mr Jones, a surprise appointment as director of human resources, made his name with a book called The Character of a Corporation: how your company's culture can make or break your business. Before joining the BBC, he was professor of organisational development at Henley management college, and worked as a consultant at Pearson Television, when Mr Dyke was chief executive there.

A BBC source said last night that Mr Jones had found his time at the corporation "frustrating".

Over the past year Mr Dyke has attempted significant changes in the organisational culture of the BBC. He has tried to make himself more accessible to staff through open meetings, and communicates most often through emails signed simply "Greg".

Many changes have been welcomed by staff. Mr Dyke has instigated plans to divert millions of pounds from the administration to programme budgets. But the windfall for programmes is yet to bear fruit. The BBC's Sunday night drama series, in particular, are suffering from poor ratings.

fields.headline: Brits come out top in TV watching league
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The internet has failed to stunt the growth of the British couch potato, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The internet has failed to stunt the growth of the British couch potato with new figures showing we watch more television than ever before.

Europeans now spend more than three hours a day watching television and TV viewing has risen in every European country, in some cases by nearly 100%.

The Italians and Spanish watch the most at just over four hours per day but the British are not far behind with just over 3.5 hours.

Published today, the research gives the lie to the widespread expectation that the internet boom would lead to a drop in TV viewing.

They form part of a major study into European media consumption by the World Advertising Research Centre and media agency The Media Edge.

In the last three years, the number of people using the internet has grown from a European average of fewer than one in 10 - 8.8% - to more than a third.

Those in northern countries are the highest users of the internet, while those in warmer countries are less addicted.

In Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Finland more than 50% of the population claims to be a regular user.

The UK also performs well with 46% of the population using the internet.

But there is still a big north/south divide, with just 12% and 11% of Spanish and Italians respectively describing themselves as "regular" users.

As well as spending more time in front of the TV or on the internet, European consumers are increasingly being bombarded with junk mail.

The survey found that Europeans receive an average of 74 items of direct mail, with the Swiss getting a massive 211 items - nearly 18 every month.

Surprising though it may seem, the British get off lightly with an average of just 68 items a year.

But Britain has lost its position as the best-read country in Europe.

Ten years ago Britain had Europe's highest national daily newspaper circulation figures in Europe, with 40.5% of the population reading a paper every day.

By 1999 that figure was down to 31.4%, while Germany, which has seen the consumption of national newspapers double in the past 10 years, now has a figure of 39.1%.

"Today's typical European consumer is not only exposed to more channels of communication than ever before, from mobile, to satellite and cable, to internet, but also actively consumes more media than ever before," said Charles Courtier, managing director for Europe, the middle east and Africa at The Media Edge.

"With the arrival of widespread digital technology, he or she will be able to exercise more control of what, when, and how they consume," he said.

We are already starting to see this with the launch of TiVo and interactive television.

"Increasingly, the challenge for marketers will be to find ways to appeal to the individual consumer on a personal level as they will have the power to block what they don't regards as relevant.

"Traditional forms of directive advertising, increasingly have less and less relevance to today's 'information overloaded' consumer," he added.

The complete results of the study are published today in the 2001 European Marketing Pocket Book.

webTitle: PCC tightens rules for City journalists

fields.headline: PCC tightens rules for City journalists
fields.standfirst:
More about the Mirror share deal scandal
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The press complaints commission has tightened rules governing the financial dealings of journalists, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The press complaints commission yesterday tightened rules governing the financial dealings of journalists, following last year's complaints about share-tipping in the Mirror's City Slickers column.

In an attempt to bolster the editors' Code of Practice the PCC published guidance for newspapers urging journalists to declare their share dealings in an internal register, and widening the definition of the transactions involved.

The move was interpreted yesterday as a climbdown by the Treasury, which had indicated it wanted journalists to disclose their interests at the end of articles.

Lord Wakeham, the PCC chairman, stressed that the editors' code had not been changed, simply strengthened by the addition of a "note". He said: "I hope all editors will look at its terms and examine the internal procedures of their own newspaper or magazine in this area accordingly."

The extra provisions were demanded after the City Slickers financial columnists Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell were sacked for dealing in shares they had tipped. The editor, Piers Morgan, was censured by the PCC for selling shares shortly after they had been tipped in the column.

The guidance is intended to stave off calls for statutory regulation. It applies the "Private Eye test": that journalists should avoid dealings that would embarrass their publications if details were printed in the satirical magazine.

Even small interests should be disclosed to editors. But a full disclosure by all staff involved in an article, including the writer, the story editor, and the commissioning editor, was thought impractical. In some cases the declaration would be longer than the article itself.

fields.headline: Spice Girls film makes it to screen
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A documentary about the Spice Girls' early struggles for success is finally to be broadcast, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
After four years of legal tussles and a last-ditch attempt by Victoria Beckham to have it blocked, a documentary about the Spice Girls' early struggles for success will finally be broadcast tomorrow.

The film depicts the transformation of Melanie Brown, Melanie Chisholm, Emma Bunton, Geri Halliwell and the then Victoria Adams into Spices scary, sporty, baby, ginger and posh. But the story of how the documentary came to air is almost as intriguing as its on-screen insights.

Raw Spice, made by the film-maker Neil Davies, features an interview with the "sixth Spice Girl", Michelle Stephenson, who left before the group shot to fame, footage from when the band lived together in Maidenhead in Berkshire and rehearsed for their first pop industry showcases, and a film of their first public performance.

Victoria Beckham threatened to seek an injunction if Raw Spice, to be broadcast on ITV this Wednesday, was not pulled. Former colleagues of the film-maker also insisted that they owned the material, and took him to court.

Further intrigue was added at the weekend when Mr Davies refused to speak about the film. Aides confirmed he was attempting to sell his story to a tabloid newspaper. "It has been a bit of an ordeal, but it looks as if we've got there at last," said an insider at one of the production companies involved.

The project began when Mr Davies was working at the BBC in 1994 and wanted to make a film about a girl band. A friend put him in touch with Geri Halliwell, who had just become a member of the group that would become the Spice Girls.

Mr Davies and his co-producer Matthew Bowers, a former partner of the comedian Caroline Aherne, filmed the group for several months. The Spice Girls did not become famous until the release of the number one hit Wannabe two years later, after which the footage was removed from Mr Daviess house while he was on holiday. Mr Davies said the material had been stolen by two former colleagues, Steve Newman and John Gaudino.

The tussle was complicated by the death of Mr Bowers from cancer and the jailing of Newman for drugs offences. It ended last year when a judge ruled that Mr Daviess former colleagues had taken the material simply because it had soared in value since the band became worldwide stars.

After the court case, ITV commissioned Mr Davies to compile a documentary based on the material, and he linked up with Yorkshire Television and a number of other independent producers.

The programme shows early signs of a power struggle between Bunton and Halliwell, and features an interview with Chris Herbet, now manager of the Popstars band HearSay, who brought the Spice Girls together but was later dropped.

"Raw Spice has been cut from the eight-hours worth of candid and intimate filming. Stripped bare of the hype that was to follow, the film reveals just how far the girls lives, looks and voices have changed," Yorkshire says in its publicity material.

fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers is threatening to sue the Daily Mail over claims his report was 'buried', reports Michael White.
fields.body:
The government was last night struggling to contain fresh embarrassment over Geoffrey Robinson's tangled business empire as the latest investigation of the former paymaster general's political career threatened to touch his old boss, Gordon Brown.

In the wake of the writer Tom Bower's claim that Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, deliberately "buried" a critical DTI inspector's report, Downing Street authorised Mr Byers to consult his lawyers about possible defamation by Mr Bower and the Daily Mail, which is serialising his new book, The Paymaster.

Last night both said they stood "100% behind our story", which claimed to have un earthed proof of a £200,000 payment that Mr Robinson denies receiving from the crooked financier Robert Maxwell.

"The Daily Mail will be hearing from solicitors representing Mr Byers shortly," the DTI assured the Guardian.

Raising the stakes, the Mail issued a 12-point challenge to Mr Byers which it couples today with Mr Bower's account of how the Treasury's former permanent secretary, Lord Burns, was "intimidated" to protect Mr Robinson's job before he was forced out in December 1998 over Peter Mandelson's £373,000 home loan. Mr Brown later forced Lord Burns out of his job.

Convinced that the Mail is acting in desperation to prevent another Labour election landslide the Downing Street spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said: "They are in a complete rage because they are not having much effect." Pointedly throughout yesterday he and his deputies said: "Geoffrey Robinson is no longer a member of the government."

Rather that face a fresh Commons inquiry over the possibility that he lied to them, some MPs predicted that the millionaire businessman would also quit as MP for Coventry North-West before polling day. But ministers fear the spread of the "sleaze" contagion.

Contrary to Mr Robinson's repeated denials to Tony Blair and the Commons standards and privileges committee, restated by the MP again last night, Mr Bower reproduced an invoice marked "Paid".

It appears to show that the MP solicited and later obtained the £200,000 payment from Mr Maxwell's Pergamon group in late 1990 as a management payment for his role in Hollis, a now bankrupt firm that both Maxwell and Mr Robinson's companies owned at different times.

The cheque, which has never been traced, was made payable "personally" to Mr Robinson, though Mr Bower claims the MP admitted its existence in a face-to-face showdown over breakfast at the Grosvenor House hotel, where the MP has a penthouse flat. The reason for Mr Byers' involvement, and Downing Street's anger, is Mr Bower's claim that the key facts were laid out by the DTI inspector, Hugh Aldous, in December 1999, but not published the same month because they would embarrass ministers.

Instead Mr Byers issued a brief answer saying that after "thorough inquiries" the DTI would take no further action. In a statement yesterday the department made two key points:

 That the inquiry, set up the month after Mr Byers took over from Mr Mandelson, was conducted at every stage by civil servants without ministerial involvement.

 That its findings cannot be published because it was conducted under section 447 of the 1985 Companies Act which precludes publication lest the commercial interests of the company involved are "unfairly damaged".

The Daily Mail's report therefore amounted to defamation of Mr Byers, the DTI said. Mr Campbell said: "He is consulting his lawyer to see what kind of cheque the Daily Mail may be sending to charity."

But Mr Bower, a veteran investigative reporter, declined to back down.

"I take note that Stephen Byers has not denied that Hugh Aldous reported that Geoffrey Robinson misled parliament and that Byers, by not announcing that issue of public interest, allowed Robinson to declare that he had been exhonerated by the report. I do not think he would have taken that decision without consultation," he said.

David Heathcoat-Amory, shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, countered the DTI's defence by saying that after he had demanded an independent inquiry in 1998-99 no mention was ever made of either point in letters from Mr Byers. He called the official version "complete sophistry" and has written to Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, asking her to reopen her own inquiries.

MPs indicated last night that that is likely if it proves necessary to ask Mr Robinson "if he wishes to add anything to the evidence he has already given".

Mr Robinson issued his own denial yesterday. "Today's story has failed to present any new information. The claim that I was paid £200,000 as chairman of Hollis Industries has been made before and was fully investigated by the DTI who have today made their position clear about the Bower story," he said.

"My own position has been absolutely clear throughout: neither I nor any company associated with me received this money."

fields.headline: Rugrats movie backed by Weetabix
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Weetabix, AOL UK and gift retailer Clintons are to promote the release of the second Rugrats movie, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Weetabix, AOL UK and gift retailer Clintons are to promote the release of the second Rugrats movie.

Released on April 6, Rugrats in Paris - The Movie stars the voices of Susan Sarandon as the Rugrats's Parisian nemesis Coco La Bouche with John Lithgow as her sidekick Jean-Claude and Debbie Reynolds as Lulu Pickles.

AOL UK will distribute free CDs in Asda stores throughout the UK featuring a trailer of the movie, games and a free 90-hour trial of the AOL service.

Weetabix is to insert Rugrats pencil grippers into packets of Weetos, backed by a national TV and cinema advertising campaign to coincide with the movie's UK launch.

Rugrats toys, produced by Vivid Imaginations, will be distributed through Clintons stores.

"We are delighted to be working with these key family brands on behalf of our newest Rugrats movie," said Benvon Crumpler, marketing director at Nickelodeon International.

Rugrats is screened on Nick UK and on BBC 1's Saturday morning show, Live and Kicking.

The first Rugrats movie, released in March 1999, became one of the top grossing non-Disney drawn animation movies of all time, taking $100m at the US box office, $160m internationally and £14m in the UK.

fields.headline: Stick to burgers, marketeers tell McDonald's
fields.trailText: McDonald's plan to open hotels and American-style diners could backfire horribly, say marketing experts. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
McDonald's plan to open hotels and American-style diners is a dangerous marketing move and could backfire horribly, according to marketing experts.

They say the company, whose trademark golden arches are recognised all over the world, should stick to burgers rather than risk losing all through diversification.

Having issued a warning to Wall Street of poor forthcoming profit figures, the fast food giant needs to find new ways of boosting profits.

It has come up with a plan to lure ageing customers into its fold through "upmarket" McDiners and even McHotels.

Although still at the experimental stage, the proposals have not convinced brand experts.

"It's the difference between the holy grail of increasing profits and the poisoned chalice of debunking, disenfranchising the brand you had in the first place," said Nick Moon, head of European brand strategy at Futurebrand.

McDonald's should stick to fast, convenient and consistent food, developing food innovations and extending into new franchise areas such as football grounds, he added.

"The diner idea is against the principles of what McDonald's stands for. And with hotels it is trying to leverage the brand into an already competitive market.

"McDonald's should partner an hotelier rather than go it alone," he said.

The burger king has already bought in to other company's skills with the acquisition of coffee chain Aroma and a stake in sandwich bar Pret A Manger.

Interbrand deputy chairman Simon Jones said when a successful brand could no longer grow through opening branches, it had to think ahead.

"The irony is that the stronger the brand the more difficult it is to stretch," he added. "If the hotels flop under the McDonald's name, it'll be horrific for the brand."

Landor marketing director Alec Rattray said the initiatives may reveal fundamental changes within the company.

"If this is about McDonald's turning in to a different company with different services, doing business in a different way, it is powerful."

He said McDonald's reputation for service could mean successful forays into theme parks and business schools.

fields.headline: Publisher nurses 'bruising' £59m loss
fields.standfirst:
Shake-up at Future Network after over-ambitious year
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Future Network, the magazine publisher, yesterday admitted it had been "just too ambitious" last year as it posted pre-tax losses of £59m.
fields.body:
Future Network, the magazine publisher, yesterday admitted it had been "just too ambitious" last year as it posted pre-tax losses of £59m.

The firm, which publishes titles ranging from PlayStation2 magazine to Total Film, also confirmed a restructuring at board level to ease the concerns of investors who have watched the value of their shares fall sharply in the past year.

Greg Ingham, Future's chief executive, said 2000 had been a "bruising" experience. The group was forced to make successive profit warnings towards the end of the year after the discovery of inflated revenues in its French division, softening advertising and delays in the launch of new games consoles on which many of its titles are dependent. Last month, it announced the closure of 20 titles and the loss of 350 jobs.

"The general level of investment and ambition seemed optimistic but achievable. But in reality it was too ambitious," Mr Ingham said. "We tried to do too much and our management systems and sometimes our performance let us down. We had too thin a management team."

Roger Parry, who runs the European business of US media group Clear Channel, will fill the newly created role of deputy chairman leaving Future founder Chris Anderson to focus on group strategy. The board will also be strengthened by Colin Morrison who takes the role of chief operating officer and has solid publishing experience at the likes of Axel Springer and Emap.

Ian Linkins who has occupied the role of finance director for 10 years is stepping back to group finance manager and the search is on for a replacement. Mr Ingham said the decision had been made voluntarily.

"The only scapegoating going on was by the press," he said. "We don't think all our woes piled up at Ian's door. None of us had really had plc experience and we now have a far richer, broader, deeper level of experience on board."

Elisabeth Murdoch joined the board as a non-executive director last year.

Investment in online ventures and new launches this year has been scaled back to £12m from the previous year's £35.7m, during which it launched some 34 titles.

Of this year's figure, £4m will go into new media, £3m has already been written off against titles that are now closed and the rest is related to the Microsoft Xbox magazine, which will launch in the US later this year. There are no other titles slated for launch.

The company said it would place more emphasis on the licensing of titles and content to overseas markets instead of trying to launch magazines from scratch. It is still exploring options for Business 2.0, the company's highly successful title for the e-economy.

Mr Ingham refuted comparisons between Future and the dot.com businesses that its share price has aped. "We still have a very sound fundamental business," he said. "This is not a matter of starting from scratch."

The company reported a 28.6% increase in revenues to £254m, with much of the growth coming from the US.

The company has the worldwide licence for the official Xbox title and has improved its share of the UK games magazine market from 52% to 57%. Its shares fell 0.5p to 97p.

fields.headline: Acquisition gives Interpublic top spot
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: WPP was last night knocked off its spot as the world's biggest advertising and marketing group when Interpublic emerged as winner to buy troubled US rival True North Communications for $2.1bn (£1.5bn).
fields.body:
WPP was last night knocked off its spot as the world's biggest advertising and marketing group when Interpublic emerged as winner to buy troubled US rival True North Communications for $2.1bn (£1.5bn).

The all-stock deal will bring together leading clients such as Coca-Cola and Compaq Computers and give Interpublic access to True North's suc cessful FCB Worldwide agency. It is also expected to produce savings of $25m a year.

Interpublic and True North - numbers three and four in the world - will have combined annual revenues of £7.2bn slightly ahead of London-based WPP.

Sir Martin Sorrell's company has been one of the leading consolidators in the sector and controls advertising agencies J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather. Its name was linked with True North but sources close to the British ad agency said the company had ruled out any formal offer early on. Lorna Tilbian, analyst at WestLB Panmure, said the merger had obvious advantages to Interpublic but should have little operational impact on WPP, whose shares fell 21.5p to 773.5p.

Meanwhile, Interpublic will swap 1.14 of its shares for each of True North's under the merger terms. The deal values True North at $40.24 (£28.28) per share, just 2% over its closing price on the New York stock market last Friday.

The tie-up was met with early scepticism in the markets which marked down the shares of both companies. But New York-based Interpublic said True North had some very strong businesses.

The independence of True North has been in doubt since it lost the critical Chrysler car group account to rival Omnicom.

New York-based Interpublic, whose agencies include McCann-Erickson and Lowe Group, said the deal would add to its earnings per share this year and in 2002.

David Bell, True North's chief executive, will become vice chairman of Interpublic, with John Dooner, Interpublic's chief executive, staying in the top position.

fields.headline: Digital rise cuts analogue fees
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Towards a single ITV
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The ITV companies will are likely to pay £85m less for their analogue licences next year because of the growth in digital television, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The ITV companies will are likely to pay £85m less for their analogue licences next year because of the growth in digital television, it was disclosed yesterday.

Estimates from the Independent Television Commission suggested that the ITV companies, dominated by Granada and Carlton Communications and SMG in Scotland, will pay about £250m between them in 2002. That compares with a forecast of £335m for this year and £360m in 1999.

The main reason for the sharp fall is the intention of the ITV companies to do a deal with BSkyB and appear on the Sky Digital platform from the end of this year.

The licence fee consists of a small cash payment each year, accounting for 25% of the total sum, and a percentage of revenues generated from analogue homes. As part of the government's push to encourage digital take-up there is no fee attached to the digital spectrum - the more people watching ITV via digital, the less the franchise holders pay.

The ITC was publishing terms for the final seven licences that have not been renewed by the ITV companies. The terms are non-negotiable and the companies have until March to accept them or have the 10-year licences put back out to tender.

The sharpest increases were for Central and Scottish, which in 1991 bid notional amounts knowing they had no rival bidders. The ITC has attempted to set all the fees at the price they believe they would fetch under open bidding

Central will pay £7.6m a year plus 17% of qualifying revenues while Scottish pays £1.7m a year and 11%. Others included Granada, £4.1m and 15%, and LWT, £4.9m and 17%. Shares in Granada closed 1.5p higher at 184.5p and Carlton ended 6p up at 466p. SMG fell 7p to 207p.

webTitle: Altered states in Europe and the US

fields.headline: Altered states in Europe and the US
fields.standfirst: Public spending in France puts Britain to shame, while even America is catching up fast. David Walker reports
fields.trailText: Public spending in France puts Britain to shame, while even America is catching up fast. David Walker reports.
fields.body:
Eat your heart out Will Hutton. During the winter in France, a book entitled Our State (Notre Etat) - all 800 pages of it - has been selling faster than the latest Harry Potter. It is sharply critical. France's public sector sprawls, with its 5.4m employees and spending equivalent to 54% of GDP. Ancient privileges and anomalies abound. Top bureaucrats have the right always to travel first class, even on suburban trains; officials can ask for a more powerful car for their grade, but never one with a smaller engine capacity. They are strongly unionised and have tight links with the political establishment - 40% of members of the national assembly are civil servants with a right to return to their jobs. Their capacity to resist reform was shown recently when the Jospin government had humiliatingly to abandon staff reorganisation in the ministry of finance.

The French state is, by international standards, generously endowed. Spending per pupil has increased by 2.4% a year on average over the past decade but attainment test results show persistent gaps. France has one police officer for every 265 people, against one for every 296 in Germany and one for every 380 in the United Kingdom. What do they all do? There are 1,700 mobile gendarmes and 13,000 CRS whose job it is to "keep order" which an audit said they did for one third of their time; the rest they spent hanging around.

But the French state is bound up closely with French identity and criticism in this new book shares very little with the Anglo-American liberal attack on government associated with the Reagan and Thatcher eras. Few want to abolish the Ecole Nationale D'Administration which churns out high flying officials. The authors of Our State themselves turn out to exemplify the way the French state dominates business and politics - one of the authors Roger Faroux was head of the industrial group Saint Gobain. The introduction of profit-making companies into, say, schooling would be resisted tooth and nail, even by reformers. "The real problem," according to Mr Faroux, who supports the left in political life, "is not the size of the state - whether it is too big, not enough. What we need in this volatile century is a fast state."

Public sector reform in France is thus not about diminishing the role of government, but making it less bureaucratic, more flexible. In some sectors this has been happening quietly. French health provision, a mixture of public and voluntary (and some private hospitals) paid for by a comprehensive health insurance scheme has been undergoing profound changes intended to reduce the bed count and better align provision and need. Some 17,000 redundant bed spaces have been cut in the past four years and a further 20,000 are due to go in much-needed rationalisation during the next four.

And in France, public sector reform is not a rallying cry for the political parties. The Jospin government has just announced a 33,000 increase in civil service employment as part of its bid to cut unemployment. The local authority elections held earlier this month were largely a beauty contest between left and a right wing in extraordinary disarray. The debates about the future of Lyon, Paris and Marseille were only marginally about services. Perhaps that is because, in comparison with UK cities, places such as Nantes and Lille enjoy very high standards of public transport, schooling and housing.

Modernisation

Elsewhere in Europe there is less concern with the size of the public sector than its effectiveness. In Italy a modernisation programme has been in train since 1996 and despite the country's reputation for sclerosis big changes have taken place in public administration. German bureaucrats, who still in British terms wield wide powers and command deep public respect, could sleep safely in their beds were Gerhard Schröder to lose the German elections due to be held next year. As for the Social Democrats, they remain umbilically linked with the unions representing public sector workers and their reforms are softly softly.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development notes too that in many countries the proportion of public employees in the civil (central or federal) service has fallen relative to those in local or regional administrations.

The public sector does not pay too badly either. In most countries the ratio between annual gross average earnings in the public sector and the private sector shows civil and public servants earning more.

That is true even in the US, which for the past 20 or so years has been the source of most of the experiments - vouchers for schools, contracting out, "arm's length management" - tried by British governments. American political tradition was always reluctant to approve high taxes for public purposes, except defence and policing and, since Roosevelt, income in old age.

The Reagan legacy

The largest American bureaucracies were and remain those associated with the military, prisons and social security. The American "state" is relatively small at about 33% of GDP and certain functions - including of course the death penalty - are jealously kept by local authorities. The US is home to what is called the "new public management", a body of ideas associated with a book published in the Reagan era. This was Reinventing Government by Osborne and Gaebler, which argued that the public sector no longer had itself to provide housing, schooling even roads. Its job was "strategy".

Private contractors could be employed to do the services more cheaply and more efficiently. Government has constantly to measure itself against competitive providers of services. Public managers had to take risks, become more like entrepreneurs.

Of course it did not work out like this in practice, despite the enthusiasm for the agenda shown by Vice-President Al Gore when Bill Clinton replaced George Bush as president in 1992.

Many American towns and cities do use private contractors for street services but public service employment has shown no dramatic fall. The reason is in part recent American economic prosperity which has seen tax revenues rise along with public spending. George W Bush is now proposing a dramatic tax cut of $1,800bn, but also a significant spending increase which if Congress has its way could be as high as 7% in total.

As recession bites, tax revenues will fall and pressure on spending and public sector jobs may grow. But the great "tax revolts" in California and other states in the late 1970s and early 1980s that led to drastic cuts in public employment are unlikely to be repeated.

The Americans, like the French, seem broadly comfortable with the quantity and quality of public services they get. In no other advanced country, with the exception perhaps of New Zealand, is there evidence of the agitated debates about public service employment and its costs that have become familiar in the UK in recent years.

fields.headline: Better pay and due respect
fields.standfirst: We don't believe in privatisation any more. Alan Travis examines the results of our special poll
fields.trailText: We don't believe in privatisation any more. Alan Travis examines the results of our special poll.
fields.body:
The detailed results of the special Guardian/ICM poll show that a sea change has taken place in voters' attitudes towards the public sector. Where privatisation was once seen as a panacea for the problems of the public sector it is now appears to be dead as a populist political force. The figures show that this is not just the view, as might be expected, of Labour and Liberal Democrat voters, but is also widely held by many Conservative voters.

The ICM poll also demonstrates that the public do agree that, in general, public sector workers are underpaid and undervalued and they also strongly want to see a measure of respect restored to those who work in the public service. An overwhelming 75% say that society has less respect now than it did 20 years ago for those who work in the public sector.

The extent to which the pendulum has swung against the privatisation culture is demonstrated by the 76% who say they want to see the railways brought back into the public sector and is nearly matched by the 60% who want to see an end to private prisons.

Many of the massive flotations of the 1980s now appear to be part of the cross-party consensus. While there is overwhelming support to bring the railways and prisons back into public ownership the same cannot be said for the telecommunications industry. Some 48% say BT should be left as it is and only 40% say it should be renationalised, with Labour voters split evenly down the middle.

But, surprisingly, when voters are asked about the principle of public service there is overwhelming support for the idea that in general public services should not be run for profit. Interestingly the "not for profit" principle transcends the political parties with 61% of Tory voters supporting the idea alongside 68% of Labour and 64% of Liberal Democrat voters. It also crosses the age groups and social classes.

The anti-privatisation swing in the public mood is confirmed by strong opposition to the government's proposals to privatise the national air traffic control service, with 72% disapproving of the idea and only 14% of Labour and 14% of Conservative voters thinking it a good move.

This support for the public service and the not-for-profit principle now appears to be a genuine cross-party consensus. So while generally 61% of all voters say they agree that public services should always or usually be run by the government or by local authorities it is a view which is also shared by 52% of Conservative voters. Only 13% of Tory voters say they agree with the view that public services should always or usually be run by private companies - a salutory thought for the more diehard Adam Smith wing of the Conservative party.

But there is no cause for celebration for the Labour government either. It's favoured approach of "public-private sector partnerships" only draws support from 25% of voters and is more popular amongst Tory voters (32%) than among its own supporters (23%).

Perceptions of pay

The ICM poll shows that half the public believes that public sector workers are underpaid compared with those doing similar jobs in the private sector. Only 8% say they are overpaid with one in four saying they are "paid about right". The feeling is strongest in the south of England where 60% say public sector workers are underpaid and weakest in the north where it falls to 40%.

Despite the fact that the overall size of the public sector has shrunk in the last 20 years the fact that one in three families includes someone who works in the public services shows what a significant political force it remains.

The fact that public sector workers are seen as underpaid however has to be tempered by the results which were given when those surveyed were asked how much they thought an experienced classroom teacher, nurse and police officer outside London were paid. In each case the average given: £17,330 for a staff nurse, £19,010 for a classroom teacher and £20,540 for a police officer, was a good £3,000 to £4,000 below the current figure for these core public sector workers outside London. The results seem to indicate that voters are three to four years out of date when it comes to their knowledge of public sector pay settlements as all these three groups have had significant above-inflation pay increases in the past three years.

A flat 'no' to more tax

Usually when opinion pollsters pose the question, the public overwhelmingly says it is willing to pay extra in taxes to pay for improvements in public services. The conventional political wisdom is that these people lie to the pollsters and promptly vote for the party that is most likely to deliver them tax cuts. In this case the voters appear to have taken a more honest line. When asked if they would be prepared to pay more tax so that those who worked in the public sector were better paid, a majority, 54%, flatly said they were not. Only one in three was willing to pay more. Even amongst Liberal Democrat voters, whose party renewed its pledge at the weekend to put a penny on income tax to pay for improved education, some 55% said they were not prepared to pay more in tax to fund salary increases for public service workers.

In fact, as last month's Guardian/ICM poll showed, the voters now see very little difference between the tax and spend policies of either Labour or the Conservatives. The voters regard both parties as equally likely to raise taxes. Only 24% now expect that Labour will spend more than the Tories if they are re-elected and in fact, more voters, some 29%, believe that the Tories would spend more than Labour.

As this month's special Guardian/ICM poll shows there is overwhelming trust and support for public services now in Britain but at the same time there is widespread scepticism that a second term Labour government will bring a big boost in public spending.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,001 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between March 16-18 2001. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Partners in crime and health, and education

fields.headline: Partners in crime and health, and education
fields.standfirst: Seumas Milne on the uneasy political relationship with PFIs
fields.trailText: Seumas Milne on the uneasy political relationship with PFIs.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair took over as Labour leader and rewrote the party's historic clause four commitment to common ownership of the economy, his deputy, John Prescott, lobbied for an explicit commitment to some public ownership of vital industries and services to be included in the new version. Blair overruled him and the revamped clause only promised an economy where "those undertakings essential to the common good are either owned by the public or accountable to them". The difference was to prove crucial. New Labour in power has enthusiastically pressed ahead with the private colonisation of public services.

This now comes under the government's more appealing and fashionable catch-all rubric of "public-private partnerships" - preferred as a term partly because, in most cases, they do not involve the direct sale of public assets. The policy reflects a strain of government thinking that sees the state's role as a guarantor and facilitator rather than a direct provider of services, as well as New Labour's mistrust of the public sector and its convert's embrace of the market. But critics argue that the government's insistence on handing over more of the management, control and effective ownership of public service provision to companies obliged to pay a return to their shareholders is already proving more expensive in many cases, and is often delivering lower quality services. Creeping privatisation, they complain, is also undermining the public service ethos and the influence of democratic government, as power slips from the purchaser to the provider and the big corporations move into the heart of health and education.

At the centre of the controversy is the private finance initiative (PFI) - currently the main form of public-private partnership - which is increasingly the treasury's preferred form of paying for investment in new hospitals, schools and prisons, as well as transport and local government.

Where in the past government borrowed to invest in new infrastructure, PFI is essentially a long-term leasing arrangement, under which private consortia borrow the cash to build and run new schools, hospitals and prisons (excluding direct clinical and teaching services) for anything up to 60 years in exchange for an annual fee from the taxpayer.

So far, around 150 PFI contracts worth more than £14bn have been signed, with a further £20bn worth of deals in the pipeline - and other public-private partnership arrangements, such as the government's heavily contested plans for the London tube, following a similar pattern. Although PFI was launched in 1992 it only really took off under Gordon Brown's stewardship.

Although part of PFI's political attraction undoubtedly remains that the investment is "off balance-sheet" and not counted as part of public debt, that is no longer the main justification, when government finances are in surplus and the ratio of debt to national income is well below its own limit of 40%. Now ministers insist PFI's principal benefit is the transfer of risk to the contractor and the greater efficiency and value for money they believe is offered by the private sector. But so far, genuine evidence of value for money is hard to come by, while risk transfer appears more imagined than real - if a PFI contract has to be terminated, because, for example the contractor has failed to deliver, the contractor still has the right to be compensated. The best the government has been able to come up with to justify its enthusiasm is a report by PFI consultant Arthur Andersen claiming savings of 17% over traditional forms of public investment. In fact, the "savings" were based simply on estimates prepared by health trusts and local authorities, who are obliged to show savings to win investment approval, set against a notional public sector comparator, widely regarded as arbitrary and rigged.

Since PFI does not bring any new cash and the public sector can always borrow money more cheaply, it is not surprising that PFI schemes have resulted in fewer hospital beds, worse terms and conditions for new employees, cost overruns and a squeeze on other funding priorities. And although prisons are sometimes cited as a PFI success story, the £13m windfall profit which Carillion and Group 4C have made out of Altcourse prison in Liverpool casts some doubt on the rigour of the contracting process.

Although evidence of PFI's value for money is still at best futuristic, it is a lot harder when it comes to the savings made from contracting out local and other public services in the 1980s and 1990s - and about where those savings came from. When London bus services were contracted out, there was a cost saving of 18% in the first six years. Part of that was achieved through shedding labour and moving depots out of expensive inner city areas. But more than 80% of the saving was achieved through a 14% reduction in bus drivers' wages. Changes to the law since then mean such cuts in terms and conditions can now only be applied to new employees. The result is a two-tier workforce; private sector efficiencies are still being achieved at the expense of public service workforces.

In the run-up to the 1997 election, Michael Portillo remarked privately that the real challenge for the next Conservative prime minister would be the privatisation of the provision - rather than the funding - of public services. It seems likely that a significant part of that challenge will have been met by New Labour.

fields.headline: The best of both worlds
fields.standfirst: Too many ministers still believe that private is always better than public. Polly Toynbee says the government can learn from both approaches - but it will cost money
fields.trailText: Too many ministers still believe that private is always better than public. Polly Toynbee says the government can learn from both approaches - but it will cost money.
fields.body:
Public service is good. We should all pay more tax for more of it. The common weal is worth more than private wealth. Yes, say the opinion polls, this is what most people want now after 18 miserable years of public squalor.

Yes, but it depends how you ask the question. Ask about some of the public services people encounter and it is not all a story of armies of civic angels toiling day and night for the greater good, let alone for the good of the particular citizens trying to get some service out of them. Most people hold in their head two opposite models of the public servant. The ideal is embodied in favourite teachers, home carers, librarians, caretakers or doctors. But on the other side of the coin are the dragon bureaucrats, the clockwatchers, the obstructive no-can-do officials, unsackable time-servers with jobs for life who love to say no. In the late 1970s the nation fell out of love with a public service that served its employees first and the citizen came a poor second. The exaggerated winter of discontent, when rubbish filled the streets and bodies lay unburied, only embedded itself in political mythology because it struck a deep chord. Whose servants were they, anyway?

Now public sector strikes are largely over and much has been privatised (remember trying to get through to the gas board to book a repair or attempting to get a new telephone this side of six months?), yet some of the bad old public service remains. Ask the people who are evicted because their local authority is unable to process their housing benefit. Try getting a parking permit in many boroughs: they take the cheque but never again answer the phone or open their office doors. Try getting planning permission for a minor kitchen extension. The local swimming pool shuts at arbitrary hours because the attendants take duvet days and no one has done anything about absentee rates. What of the GP surgeries that never open at evenings or weekends for working people? Or receptionists throughout the public sector whose job is to keep people away? The council switchboards that shut down at 4.58 sharp? The social workers who refuse to work with local charities for professional reasons? Trades and professions who guard their demarcations jealously against all comers? Who does not have a grievance against some sclerotic and obstructive branch of the public sector?

Ask those who work in the public sector about their management, about the way their own work is organised, about the timeservers and the obstacles: off the record, they might say some different things to the general tenor of the interviews we conducted in these pages. But both attitudes are often simultaneously true: they love their jobs, they care about what they do, they earn less than they might because of their commitment - and yet the mismanagement drives them to distraction. (Mind you, most of them know nothing of the mismanagement in the private sector too.)

Plunging headlong into PFIs - selling off large chunks of hospitals and other public goods (30 years' rental is three political lifetimes) - New Labour proclaims its lack of confidence in public services to deliver, ever. Curiously, it confesses Labour's own uncertain about its ability to improve public sector management: in other words, to govern effectively.

Private bungles

Too many ministers, from Mr Blair and Mr Brown downwards, parrot the mantra that private is always better run than public, especially in building contracts. "I want booking a hospital appointment to be as easy as booking an airline ticket" the prime minister famously proclaimed. He might look at what just happened to BA's airline ticket delivery this week, with its catastrophic installation of a new computer system, and ask if private really always does it better? He might look at the privately contracted computer systems installed in government departments that have gone bottom-up. He might consider the Channel tunnel rail link disaster, the financial collapse of Canary Wharf under its first builders, or the crashing world of dot.com all about us. The the private bungles are just less visible: there is never the same fuss.

New Labour was born and bred in the 1970s, and there it remains ideologically - somewhere back in the days when Harold Wilson made sarcastic remarks about the nationalising tendency: "Oh, so you want to make Marks & Spencer as efficient as the Co-op, do you?" But they know nothing of the private sector's defects, that imagined Nirvana where everything runs at maximum efficiency, where the grass is greener and everyone has a nice day. To imagine that the private sector is always enterprising, dynamic and prudent is as grand a folly as believing that public service is peopled by nothing but saints and heroes. (Consider trying to get a private home appliance mended or delivered at a fixed time or outside working hours.)

Small start

There are ways to get the best out of both. In his approach to the NHS, Mr Blair had the right idea when he jumped ahead to establish NHS Direct and high street walk-in clinics. Any time of the day or night, anxious patients can get professional advice by phone. Any time in the day without an appointment, anyone can walk into a clinic and see a doctor. Suddenly, the NHS starts to look fresh and user-friendly. It required stepping on the corns of old practices and professional pride, but the public liked it - and it had nothing whatever to do with privatising or PFIs. A small start, but an emblem of what might be.

Labour's distaste for local government springs from seeing it close-up in some of the worst areas they represent: they have only ever seen the whole ruined civic culture in near-terminal financial decline. And yet it remains and always will be the prime deliverer of every day public services for most people.

Worst cases are not the main story: the audit commission provides ample evidence of top performers doing well for others to emulate. But they require trust and letting go from the centre (apart from those failing badly). The proposed new city mayors may help galvanise local enthusiasm. Proportional representation is an absolute necessity to break up the worst rotten boroughs and one-party states, ensuring a lively opposition everywhere.

But above all, the one simple ingredient that will transform the public culture from Whitehall downwards has to be fat slabs of money guaranteed over many years without fear of arbitrary cuts. Money has the power to draw in the visionaries and enthusiasts as long-term planning makes creativity possible. High reward and high regard go hand in hand to create high value services and management. Yes, throw money at it and watch it bloom.

webTitle: How Thatcher stumbled on her Big Idea

fields.headline: How Thatcher stumbled on her Big Idea
fields.standfirst: Larry Elliott on the public asset sell-offs that transformed the mindset of Whitehall
fields.trailText: Larry Elliott on the public asset sell-offs that transformed the mindset of Whitehall.
fields.body:
Privatisation defined Margaret Thatcher as nationalisation defined Clement Attlee. One radical government in the middle of the 20th century extended state control over large chunks of the economy, another radical government used its long hegemony at the end of the century to put the private sector back in charge.

Tony Blair's willingness to extend privatisation into areas - such as air traffic control - where even the Conservatives feared to go during their 18 years in power is an indication of how the mindset of Westminster and Whitehall was transformed.

Yet the idea that privatisation was a carefully thought-out strategy to sweep away Labour's collectivist edifice and replace it with a share-owning democracy is false. Mrs Thatcher stumbled upon privatisation almost by accident, using it as a pragmatic answer to the problem of ballooning public debt caused by the deep recession of the early 80s. The need to raise cash quickly came first; only later was the denationalisation campaign given an ideological underpinning.

Moreover, privatisation was not even a Conservative invention. The first stab at selling off state assets to raise cash came when the Callaghan government, at the behest of the International Monetary Fund, sold 17% of its shares in BP in May 1977, two years before Mrs Thatcher came to power. Labour needed to raise money quickly, and selling shares was a reasonably painless way of doing so.

But there was little evidence that Mrs Thatcher quickly saw the possibilities of privatisation. The idea was not a feature of the 1979 Conservative manifesto, and the sell-offs between 1979 and 1983 were small-scale and tentative. The Thatcher government decided to offload companies such as Amersham International, which it saw no reason for the state to own, but in 1983 the structure of British industry was much the same as it had been in 1979.

Golden age

Three factors then combined to make the second Thatcher administration the golden age of privatisation. First - and most important - there was the need to raise money. Despite Mrs Thatcher's efforts to reduce public spending, higher unemployment meant that by 1983 the government's finances were deep in the red, with a deficit of around 4% of GDP.

In addition, the treasury's determination to keep tight control over the nation's purse strings meant that nationalised industries were forced to cut back and even scrap investment plans. Private control would enable companies to circumvent the Treasury mandarins and find sources of new money from the capital markets of the City.

The second factor was the sense that privatisation of services in the public sector offered the prospect of better value for money. Again this trend started slowly, with the decision in the early 1980s to hand over refuse collection and street cleaning to a private company, Brengreen, run by David Evans, who later became a Conservative MP. Evans's sales pitch was that council-delivered services were being run for the benefit of staff rather than rate-payers, and that not only could Brengreen do it cheaper, it could also do it better.

Brengreen was the start of something big. Within a couple of years, many more councils were either contracting out refuse collection and street cleaning or forcing their own direct labour forces to match the terms on offer from the private sector. Mrs Thatcher and her closest advisers quickly saw how the same arguments could be applied nationally.

Finally, there was the desire on the part of the Conservatives to change Britain's political culture. At the end of the 1970s, Mrs Thatcher's desire to roll back the state had a certain resonance, but by the start of her second term that message had been blurred by four years of job losses, plant closures, industrial strife and social unrest. What she came up with - more by luck than judgement - was the idea of popular capitalism, the notion that buying and owning shares would no longer be the preserve of the wealthy.

The right to buy

Again, there was a template for this notion - the Conservative right-to-buy legislation which had enabled council tenants to buy their homes at bargain-basement prices. This had proved politically popular during Mrs Thatcher's first term, but ministers were unsure about what would happen when they announced the first big privatisation - that of British Telecom - in 1984. The enthusiasm of the public for the £4bn sell-off exceeded their wildest expectations. With the offer almost 10 times subscribed, the result was massive, instant profits for the 2.3m applicants.

The privatisation of British Telecom was a seminal moment. In its wake, ministers were no longer hesitant about denationalisation, but saw it as their Big Idea - a way not just of making money but of ridding Britain of socialism for ever. By the time of the next big privatisation - British Gas in 1986 - the public relations machine had been ratcheted up with the unashamedly downmarket "Tell Sid" advertising campaign, aimed at convincing Labour's traditional voters that the government was handing out "free" money. After British Gas, came the year of privatisations - 1987 - with British Airways, Rolls-Royce and British Airports Authority floated on a rip-roaring stock market in the first half of the year and BP proving to be the first setback for the government when its £7bn flotation was fatally undermined by the global share crash.

From 1987 onwards, the real question was what would be left in the public sector once the privatisation process was over. Steel, water and electricity were sent down the denationalisation slipway in the rest of the Conservative party's third term, leaving only a rump of the old public sector. John Major's government sold off the remnants of the coal industry for £1bn and came up with the massively flawed blueprint for the privatisation of the railways. Again looking to save money in the wake of recession, Major and Kenneth Clarke also unveiled the private finance initiative, a way of using private capital to fill the gaps in infrastructure spending.

This, then, was Labour's legacy in 1997. In opposition it had been trenchant in its condemnation of the dark side of privatisation - the self-enrichment in the boardroom, the conversion of public-sector monopolies into private-sector monopolies, the short-changing of the public purse by selling off assets on the cheap, the effect on working conditions. But in power it has been a different story. Even armed with a majority of 179, Labour has meekly accepted the new orthodoxy.

webTitle: Susie Orbach on the market and moral panic

fields.headline: The payoff
fields.standfirst: Susie Orbach on how the market induced our moral panic
fields.trailText: Susie Orbach on how the market induced our moral panic
fields.body:
It's hard to look at the rich list above without it arousing ambivalence. Feelings of disgust, envy, exclusion and desire jostle inside of us as we recognise the ways in which we are inevitably tainted by our society's recent love affair with money. A love affair in which money is no longer regarded as something to be used but has become imbued with value in itself, as an aspiration, as the sign that one is worthy, competent and significant.

Over a 20-year period, as Thatcher brought Britain into an embrace of neo-liberalism, almost everything about a value system based on caring, sharing and justice was derided and then ditched. Individual enterprise, personal ambition, the drive to accumulate and display were heralded as the way to build a strong Britain. A new era of exploitation of labour was ushered in with a freshly honed rhetoric and ideology to match.

In this, the public sector and respect for the work of professionally trained public service teachers, social workers, doctors and nurses respect was eroded. These were not the jobs that the young were encouraged to aspire to. A new narrative of Britain began to emerge.

It was the exceptional individual, the exceptional skills, the risk-taking high-roller who now commanded respect. The dry unimaginative members of the Surrey commuter belt who had peopled the city were transformed into dynamic Gordon Gekko figures.

Richard Branson became the iconic face of the new capitalism - daring, free, unstuffy. Entertainers and entertainment of all kinds became celebrated. Management consultants who had honed their skills in business became de rigueur for the reshaping of public services, which now saw themselves not as administrating and delivering health services, for example, but as creating competing profit centres in their market.

Money, money and money became - and have remained especially for many young people - the aspiration, with Who Wants to be a Millionaire, so-called reality TV and the national lottery as the unashamed embraces of these values. Wealth rules OK.

Meanwhile the caring professions are denuded of aspirants. The pay is lousy, the respect has gone and the control over one's own professionalism eroded.

So is it any wonder that there is a moral panic on, that the once shared values of justice and equity, are on the decline?

Social values can't be divorced from the world we live in. Morality is not simply a function of conscience; we create and imbibe sets of values in relation to the economic moment. Internal markets in public institutions are not neutral. They affect how we see one another. Students become numbers, viewers a demographic category, animals productive or unproductive economic units, visitors to cultural institutions, consumers.

The language of the market - acquisition, efficiency, growth - transforms the landscape inside of us. The market is not a phenomenon outside of us that we can simply critique, it becomes a motivating force shaping our desires and our attitudes towards our needs in powerful and often disconcerting ways.

And let's be clear, we are drawn to the market for many reasons. Firstly, it has become so all-pervasive, so emotionally, economically and geographically global as it enters almost every aspect of our lives, both intimate and public, that to ignore it means to situate oneself outside what has become the social currency.

Then, too, the market has established a grip on our consciousness because it is impressive. It can display products of human ingenuity and enterprise that are quite wondrous - the fruits of our cultural and scientific endeavours. But at the same time, the market feels daunting because the intellectual and economic enterprise behind the making of the new technology that has been transforming our lives can seem quite incomprehensible and humbling. We may use it without understanding it. And yet we don't want to feel left out, uncomprehending or insignificant.

Enter branding: the ingenuous solution to the loss of place, the sense of insignificance induced by high technology, high speed production and globalism. Now through artifice, the large, incomprehensible world can appear seemingly smaller and knowable. Branding becomes our way to belong, to feel recognised, to take our place and to acknowledge others. We do this not through the promotion of a shared set of values and agendas which we fight for but by wearing Nike, signing on with AOL, taking our coffee with Starbucks and identifying with the aspirational aspects that adhere to those products.

This is how we are encouraged to find a place for ourselves today. We enter the global village. We belong. The rapacious, marauding, destructive force of the market is occluded. The values of community which once forged civic life and civil society are synthetised and encrypted by the brand makers.

As money, consuming and entertainment dominate the space vacated by a shared consensus and a civic society, the making of money, the wearing of brands and the making of celebrity become the most plausible game in town. It's hard for us to separate ourselves from these new replacement values - and so much more impossible for kids whose world is dominated by this form of acceptability. It's a question of society reaping what it has sown.

As politicians hand over their responsibilities to the markets then individuals in society absorb the values promoted by corporate culture: the acquisitive, anything goes, monopolising (pace niche marketing) culture. We can't yank ourselves back to sounder values by a dose of moralism, by do-goodism. It would be naive to hope that such a strategy could work.

If government is not going to decisively intervene in ways that show responsibility, sustainability and fortitude, if it can't properly reward certain basic practices such as child rearing and teaching and challenge the greed of industries like banking, pharmaceuticals, insurance, if it lets the bully press cow their behaviour, if accommodation is its long suit, then the moral climate it ends up creating will be the opposite of its intent.

 Susie Orbach is a psychoanalyst and writer. © Susie Orbach 2001

If government is not going to decisively intervene in ways that show responsibility, sustainability and fortitude, if it can't properly reward certain basic practices such as child rearing and teaching and challenge the greed of industries like banking, pharmaceuticals, insurance, if it lets the bully press cow their behaviour, if accommodation is its long suit, then the moral climate it ends up creating will be the opposite of its intent.  Susie Orbach is a psychoanalyst and writer. © Susie Orbach 2001

webTitle: How the potent language of civic life was undermined

fields.headline: How the potent language of civic life was undermined
fields.standfirst: John Sutherland  laments the demise of robust vocabulary
fields.trailText: John Sutherland laments the demise of robust vocabulary.
fields.body:
Future lexicographers, looking back at the period from the end of Thatcher to the zenith of Blair, will observe symptomatic slippages in the language of civic discourse.

Britain has never, in modern times, had a handy term for "the public good". William Morris's archaism "Commonweal" came nearest, perhaps. But it doesn't trip off the tongue as easily as the French bien commun.

The cluster of words associated with the public or common good which are currently available to English speakers have, palpably, shrunk in potency over the last few administrations. They no longer resonate as they once did; bells without clappers.

Say "service", for example, and most will think nowadays of "service sector" - that booming segment of the modern white collar economy where greed ("wealth creation") is good. The service sector does not "serve" (in the Miltonic sense of "They also serve") any more than the modern "armed services" serve. It "works" - with robotic efficiency.

Sometimes the perversion is officially authorised. As rail passengers have become "customers" (defined solely by cash nexus; going nowhere, paying something) so Whitehall approves the term "social entrepreneurs" for "public servants". (For many decades now, "enterprise" has been the favoured euphemism for "capitalism"). In such usages, human relations are - to coin a brutalism - "marketised". "Benefit" (doing good to others) is reified into "monetary handout. Pieces of silver".

A whole range of other formerly big words have lost their big resonances. In 1946 the compound "welfare state" was, in Orwell's Newspeak, "doubleplusgood". Men and women would have died for it (this, as John Ruskin observed in Unto This Last, is the acid test of any social ideal).

The first element, "welfare", has been subverted over the last 20 years by conjunction with "queen" (in the US) and "fraud" (in the UK). The word "state" nowadays throws back the jeeringly inevitable echo "nanny". "Welfare state" is now, even for the Labour party whose grand historic achievement it was, obscurely shameful. A pejorative for our times.

In the 1960s debate, led by Richard Hoggart and Raymond Williams (liberal and Marxist leftist respectively), "culture" was an unequivocal plus word. A summum bonum. It has been corroded by such routine modern usage as "culture of neglect", "compensation culture", or "culture of racism". Another pejorative.

And if - as our spokespeople incessantly have - you vilify "institutionalised racism", can you ever again invoke, with Bagehotian approval, our glorious British institutions? Or, after the (legitimate) scorn heaped on "community care" (for the undenizened mentally ill) can you invoke, nostalgically, Weberian Gemeinschaft - the harmony of the wheelwright's shop? "Community" is not a pejorative: merely a vacuum, a non-entity. Its place is taken by a fund of "social capital" (monstrous hybrid).

And if the beautiful word asylum is indelibly linked to "bogus" can it ever again mean "place of refuge or asylum"?

Thatcher victrix. It is not just "society" that has been annihilated as a linguistic referent, but a whole range of connected ideals which dignified political discourse and motivated civic behaviour ("service", so to call it). Current "strong words" are paralysing negatives: "sceptic" ("Eurosceptic"); "stealth" (with Proudhonian suggestion that all tax is theft); "sleaze"; "bogus"; the "cash-for" prefix and the "-gate" suffix.

One of the favourite terms of politicians applauding themselves is "robust" (as in "our response to this issue will be prompt and robust"). But the vocabulary of modern life, where it touches on the realities of social existence, is chronically un-robust.

The "poor" we always have. But no modern politician is wholly comfortable with the blunt term. "Underclass" had a brief vogue, until its Nietzschean connotations of an irredeemably "lumpen" mass poked through.

We prefer to see "poverty" as a condition you can be "lifted out of". The "indigent" (or, as the Victorians robustly called them, "able-bodied paupers") are reworded as "the homeless" or "rough sleepers" (a conjunction that evokes Teddy Roosevelt's cavalry charging up the hill at Santiago). The "workshy" are the "long-term unemployed". Only the truly ugly (racists, Neo-Nazis, skin-heads and rednecks) have the privilege of robust language.

It is the responsibility of politicians and parties to work for the public good. What is striking about governments of the present era is how an ideology of nervousness ("prudence") has been inscribed into their core rhetoric. They habitually decline to put anything right. Instead they undertake to "address" the problem. "Address" commits you to nothing more than careful inspection. In the face of a disaster for which someone in authority bears manifest responsibility (some awful exposé from the prisons, hospitals, or children's homes) we are piously assured, not that measures will be taken, but that "lessons have been learned". That is, a good resolution is made for the future.

The present custodians of the common good, in their linguistic soul, see themselves as doing or making nothing. They merely "deliver" (or "roll out", as one might lay a carpet) what, by implication, others have done or made. They aspire no higher than to be a kind of service provider or political parcel force: getting the goods (common or otherwise) from there to here.

 John Sutherland is professor of English at University College, London.
