webTitle: Why some angels are natural born carers

fields.headline: Why some angels are natural born carers
fields.standfirst: It's no surprise  so many women are in public service work, says Madeleine Bunting
fields.trailText: It's no surprise so many women are in public service work, says Madeleine Bunting.
fields.body:
Until about 1790, angels were always portrayed as male, but by the 1800s they had become female. Virtue had been feminised. The perception of women shifted from being erratic, irrational and dangerous (witches and shrews) to being the spiritual superiors of men, civilising, emotionally sustaining and binding of families and communities. In the 19th century, they were expected to play this role solely in the home, but in the 20th century they moved out to play this role in public also and women make up over 70% of the public sector workforce, dominating the nation's caring and implementing the vision of the common good from running parks to housing estates. The welfare state is the angel state, it's promise to care for you from cradle to grave is delivered largely by women.

This 19th-century definition of women as emotional labourers is evident in many of the interviews published on these pages. Again and again, women emphasise the emotional rewards of their work. Often their whole sense of identity is bound up with caring, so Catherine Coogan, a home carer, describes a life of seamless caring: "Before being a home carer, I was a wife and mother nursing is something which my family does - you could say that caring runs in the family." The relationships formed among fellow public servants and with the public is the main source of job satisfaction. Rhian Wood, an A&E acting nurse manager, says she loves nursing, "It's such a rewarding job you build up close relationships very fast."

It is this emotional engagement - sometimes in exceptionally difficult circumstances - which women talk about readily, rather than pay. (Angels aren't supposed to be paid.) Sandra Sampson, assistant manager of a family centre, even went as far as saying she does her work for the sheer love of children, her pay is a bonus. Janice Edmonds, a nursery nurse, professes not to notice her pay rises much. Irene Lucas, director of city contracting services, is absolutely clear: "I'm not remotely concerned about remuneration, it comes way down my list of priorities."

Vocation is a word which springs quickly to many of these women's lips. Vocation comes from the Latin to call; it is a Christian concept of being called by God to undertake a particular task or service in your life. The Christianity may have disappeared, but what has persisted is the idea of a profound sense of personal purpose, and doing what you should be doing with your life. At its best, that purpose and usefulness can enrich a sense of value and belonging in the world, as many of these women indicate.

At its worst, the concept of vocation reinforces the poor deal which emotional labour earns from the public purse. If the government took half of its rhetoric on the gender pay gap seriously, it could go a long way to solving the problem overnight by increasing the pay of its millions of female public sector workers. Professions dominated by women are always underpaid - the most notorious case being that of the mostly female NHS speech therapists who have recently won their case for a pay review. Even more disturbing is the evidence that when women enter new professions in significant numbers, pay levels drop. Work done by women is consistently discriminated against - if a woman can do the job, the job loses status and pay - and women to some extent collude with this, conforming to a gender identity of being caring and unmaterialistic. The result is that the angel state has been a public sector on the cheap, subsidised by women's aspirations to virtue.

Lynn Punter, a rehabilitation worker, puts this conflict over pay and vocation graphically: "I'm paid just under £20,000 a year and I'm quite happy. I dealt with it a long time ago. It's seen as a vocation and people think that's your motivation so you don't need money as well." Her claims to have resolved the conflict are not entirely convincing as she wrestles with other people's definition of her work as vocation.

But the real issue for the government to grapple with is how vocation collides with the managerial state. How do you quantify empathy, patience, forbearance and intuition? The single, biggest complaint emerging from these women's interviews is that their work is marginalised and unappreciated in the rush to improve "efficiency" which is measured by such things as throughput. This is perceived by some of these women as an all out assault on their professional integrity - the standards they set themelves in their work - and their autonomy. In the bid to increase management control and raise standards, there is a real risk of a decline in standards caused by an emotional disengagement in jobs where the quality of relationship is crucial, such as health, education and social work.

Philomena Francis, an NHS art therapist, sums up the issue starkly: "I tend to be called on to do long term work so our throughput is low. On the other hand, there is pressure to get results and throughput is one of the main measures of success in the health service.." Francis dreams of setting up her own practice to resolve these kinds of dilemmas, identifying a key issue for the government whose hopes of innovation depend on keeping the likes of Francis within the NHS.

More broadly, there is the question of whether a younger generation of women will be so powerfully influenced by the angel gender identity. Do 18-year-old girls see themselves as more compassionate, more emotionally empathetic and less materialistic than their male contemporaries?

There is plenty of evidence that they don't, and the consequence could be a hefty bill to pay for the services that until now altruism has subsidised.

fields.headline: Fitness instructor, Leeds
fields.standfirst:
Lascelles Freckleton
Salary: £4 to £5 an hour
fields.trailText: Lascelles Freckleton. Salary: £4 to £5 an hour.
fields.body:
I suppose that like all fitness instructors I am involved in selling a dream. But what is important is how honestly you are allowed to sell it. I feel that here I have the freedom to sell it as honestly as I can.

There is a great attraction for most people in getting in shape, developing an attractive body and trying to hang on to your youth. I suspect there is less promotion of "the body beautiful" in a public gym. We don't have any sexy posters on the wall here. The equipment in most Leeds council gyms cannot match the big names - such as Virgin Active and the David Lloyd centre - but our standards have improved in recent years, and we do offer people the chance to get fit for a reasonable price.

I did consider joining a private gym, closer to my home, but the money wasn't any better. And they wanted me to act as a salesman as well, even asking me to put in some leg-work to sell memberships. It was a new health club that wanted to establish itself. But I didn't feel too good about that. I became a fitness instructor to get out of sales jobs. I didn't want to reach sales targets. I've had enough of that in the past.

Leeds City Council offers the Bodyline Card, annually or monthly. It's a good deal for regular users and I often explain to people how it can work out considerably cheaper. But I'm helping people, not pushing a product. There's nothing in it for me. I'm happier that way.

With obesity at record levels, we need to educate people in keeping fit. I like to think of us as a preventative medicine. If people came to us more often, they wouldn't have to visit their doctor as much. Keeping people healthy: that can be a cause for satisfaction.

webTitle: We may not be rich, but we are useful

fields.headline: We may not be rich, but we are useful
fields.standfirst: As the Guardian  interviews show, public servants are that rare breed in the modern world - they actually enjoy what they do. Richard Sennett on the power of making a contribution
fields.trailText: As the Guardian interviews show, public servants are that rare breed in the modern world - they actually enjoy what they do. Richard Sennett on the power of making a contribution.
fields.body:
The splendidly monickered Lascelles Freckleton does not quite fit Margaret Thatcher's image of a government worker: he is waging war on fat in a public gym. It's a war this fitness instructor, who earns £5 an hour, doesn't believe he could pursue as effectively in a private health club. In the public gym he doesn't need to sell the "body beautiful", he's not pushing a product, he can deal honestly with just how fat we are. So he has turned down private offers that would net him a much bigger salary.

Reviled in the Thatcher years as people who couldn't cut it in business, or perhaps worse, as starry-eyed do-gooders, public servants were themselves put on a starvation diet, heckled by auditors and assessers, or forced to wring profits out of good works. The most consistent, and most surprising, finding of the Guardian's interviews with public service workers lies in the immense gap between what "reformers" of the public sector say it is like, and the ways workers actually doing the work see themselves.

Scientists in white lab coats and clip-boards did not conduct this survey; instead, the Guardian's journalist-army fanned out over the country, posing some simple questions to nearly 200 public servants: what do you earn, what's your job like, what are your problems? The answers come from bigwigs managing billions of pounds or thousands of workers, as well as from proles cleaning toilets; the work spans flying military planes, handling elephants in zoos, herding the public in museums, as well as teaching, medicine, and that bête noir of the reformers, social work.

Edgy and evasive

The numbers could have been even bigger, but the political traumas of public service have made many offices edgy. The Royal Mint, for instance, whose PR is farmed out to a private firm, proved evasive; a flack for the Home Office, when asked if a journalist could interview a cleaner, replied: "We do ministers, not cleaners." Many individuals feared speaking out - a midwife in an NHS hospital thought being frank about the hospital's problems would lead to professional punishment, so there was no use in talking.

The sceptical, if not outright punitive, climate of public service "reform" influences in a subcutaneous way those who do speak out. They are almost relentlessly upbeat. Of course they want to emphasise the value of the work they do. But even more, they want to make clear that they are not private-sector castoffs.

Thus Michael Foot, managing director of the financial services authority, who makes a whopping £235,000, emphasises that he could earn something like 10 times that amount in an American investment bank, but finds public-sector work more challenging and interesting. With very few exceptions, from top to bottom, the public servants say they are in it neither for money nor for security: their work is, if anything, demanding or stressful as well as badly paid.

The British public sector is smaller than the Italian and bigger than the American, but its peculiarities have to do with quality rather than quantity. The Italian civil service is truly a sink-hole of uncles, nephews, and political cronies; its productivity is appalling. The American civil service is more efficient, but also more of a revolving door, employees coming and going between the public and the private sector.

The British public sector is both relatively efficient and a service in which people make life-long careers. The dustmen who appear in the Guardian survey think of themselves pursuing a career as much as do teachers; tasks may change in time, but the work has a fixed institutional frame.

In this, public-sector work differs from the leading edge of modern capitalism, the flexible private sector in which workers are constantly "rebranding" themselves, flitting from employer to employer, from one kind of work to another. When public service work is privatised and made short-term, as in the BBC where many people work on three-month contracts, the result can seem catastrophic, entailing a personal loss of focus or preventing just the opportunity to do worthwhile things which have, however, no immediate profit reward.

It's striking to me in this regard that almost no one in these interviews talks about their unions. In Italy, public sector unions are conspirators with the state in immobilising public services; in the US public-sector unions frequently set the quality agenda in confrontations with government. The British workers in this survey speak of themselves as more self-directed; if you didn't know who paid their salaries, you might mistake them for self-employed.

The water regulator, Philip Fletcher, makes a neat distinction: "As water regulator I am a public servant, thought what I do is very different from what I used to do as a Whitehall civil servant. Here, I run my own show." At a less grand level, Judy Tomkinson, the local registrar at Newcastle-under-Lyme, speaks like a Jewish matchmaker about the marriages she conducts.

This feel-good factor is more than self-advertisement: there's little personal whingeing in situations of scarce resources that would entitle people high or low to whinge. Why, then, can't reformers of the public services understand what makes a fitness trainer, a cleaner, a registrar or a financial services manager tick?

Part of the misunderstanding is inherited. Public service became confused at an early stage with charity work. The poor visitors of the 19th century performed a service of sorts, bringing castoff clothes to the masses along with well-meaning advice. The anthropologist Mary Douglas tartly observes that such charity wounds: help is inseparable from condescension, pity for the poor generates the fear of being held in contempt. The first Peabody Trust housing estates institutionalised this problem, nanny estates which rigidly controlled from above everything from where to hang out washing to where to plant flowers.

Well-meaning conservatives now might well want to free the needy from this demeaning yoke. And indeed, the public-service workers who speak in the Guardian interviews depict themselves as useful rather than charitable - quite another matter.

Being useful makes for a much more equal connection between people than compassion: the giver and receiver equally gain. Thus a poorly paid dog-handler for the customs says she loves her job just because she is doing something valuable in ferreting out drugs; a road sweeper in Islington says: "When I look back at the street I've just done and all the piles of rubbish are gone and it's clean, I'm pleased." In all these interviews, usefulness is the reason for the feel-good factor in public service.

I think back, in this regard, to an investment broker I interviewed in New York a few years ago, the kind of man Michael Foot might have become if he had gone into the private sector. The broker asked me, his voice dripping with irony, "You get paid to think?" He made something like £6m a year, but in a job he hated. People needed him only for the moment of doing a deal, and he treated others in the same way. Year after year he followed the same path; though the money piled up he was increasingly bored.

At first I shed no crocodile tears, but in time I understood his problem: he could disappear from the face of the earth and no one would notice. Whereas public service does matter. From several encounters like this I've come to wonder if beneath the contempt that critics feel for public-service work there isn't something more akin to jealousy. Modern capitalism, particularly in its flexible, short-term form, isn't very good at forging sustained bonds between people; it isn't very good at defining long-term purposes at work; most of all, it isn't very good at making people feel they have some compelling claim on others by doing something useful.

Whatever the motives, attacks on the public services have created a mess.

Privatising the railroads destroyed workers' morale as well as the service itself; running the health services like a business proved bad for sick bodies - the list is endless.

To its great credit, this government has begun to sort out some of the mess with more cash. The chancellor's most recent Budget is particularly good at addressing the personnel shortages that have afflicted the public services in the past, caused by the Tory conviction that public servants were idly twiddling their thumbs.

The scope of the problem can be understood by a few statistics: it would take 1.8 American general practitioners to see the number of patients seen by a British colleague in the course of the working day; a tube supervisor in the London underground is responsible for 1.4 times the number of riders a supervisor in the New York subways is meant to control.

Conservative legacy

But the Conservative legacy has got under Labour's skin socially. This government still believes that to attract young people to public service work, what you need to do is first pay them more money, and second offer them the chance for a rapid rise in the police, education, or health services in competition with other employees.

Better pay is all to the good, as are opportunities to advance. Still, these policies derive from the logic of what makes business tick. In education, the public service I know best, young people are most likely to be turned off by excessive administration, bureaucratic regulation, and impossible student numbers. Indeed, competition between teachers severely weakens the esprit de corps that is necessary for schools to work.

In medicine at its mundane level, social inclusion seems a more powerful drive: one recent study shows that the Jamaicans or Pakistanis cleaning hospital bedpans could make 13% more cleaning houses, but prefer official jobs to being treated as domestic servants.

Good policewomen, another study reveals, have stayed in this thankless work because they have preserved some corner of themselves from reality's invitation to cynicism.

Of course, we are all ambitious and like to think of ourselves as efficient. But neither alone lures people into public service. This survey shows what does.

To the hard-headed businessman or politician, being useful may seem ephemeral, the sort of thing the vicar goes on about while the effects of Saturday's dinner party wear off. Ephemeral, unless you make a career of it.

 Richard Sennett is professor of sociology at the London School of Economics.
fields.bodyText: The splendidly monickered Lascelles Freckleton does not quite fit Margaret Thatcher's image of a government worker: he is waging war on fat in a public gym. It's a war this fitness instructor, who earns £5 an hour, doesn't believe he could pursue as effectively in a private health club. In the public gym he doesn't need to sell the "body beautiful", he's not pushing a product, he can deal honestly with just how fat we are. So he has turned down private offers that would net him a much bigger salary. Reviled in the Thatcher years as people who couldn't cut it in business, or perhaps worse, as starry-eyed do-gooders, public servants were themselves put on a starvation diet, heckled by auditors and assessers, or forced to wring profits out of good works. The most consistent, and most surprising, finding of the Guardian's interviews with public service workers lies in the immense gap between what "reformers" of the public sector say it is like, and the ways workers actually doing the work see themselves. Scientists in white lab coats and clip-boards did not conduct this survey; instead, the Guardian's journalist-army fanned out over the country, posing some simple questions to nearly 200 public servants: what do you earn, what's your job like, what are your problems? The answers come from bigwigs managing billions of pounds or thousands of workers, as well as from proles cleaning toilets; the work spans flying military planes, handling elephants in zoos, herding the public in museums, as well as teaching, medicine, and that bête noir of the reformers, social work. Edgy and evasive The numbers could have been even bigger, but the political traumas of public service have made many offices edgy. The Royal Mint, for instance, whose PR is farmed out to a private firm, proved evasive; a flack for the Home Office, when asked if a journalist could interview a cleaner, replied: "We do ministers, not cleaners." Many individuals feared speaking out - a midwife in an NHS hospital thought being frank about the hospital's problems would lead to professional punishment, so there was no use in talking. The sceptical, if not outright punitive, climate of public service "reform" influences in a subcutaneous way those who do speak out. They are almost relentlessly upbeat. Of course they want to emphasise the value of the work they do. But even more, they want to make clear that they are not private-sector castoffs. Thus Michael Foot, managing director of the financial services authority, who makes a whopping £235,000, emphasises that he could earn something like 10 times that amount in an American investment bank, but finds public-sector work more challenging and interesting. With very few exceptions, from top to bottom, the public servants say they are in it neither for money nor for security: their work is, if anything, demanding or stressful as well as badly paid. The British public sector is smaller than the Italian and bigger than the American, but its peculiarities have to do with quality rather than quantity. The Italian civil service is truly a sink-hole of uncles, nephews, and political cronies; its productivity is appalling. The American civil service is more efficient, but also more of a revolving door, employees coming and going between the public and the private sector. The British public sector is both relatively efficient and a service in which people make life-long careers. The dustmen who appear in the Guardian survey think of themselves pursuing a career as much as do teachers; tasks may change in time, but the work has a fixed institutional frame. In this, public-sector work differs from the leading edge of modern capitalism, the flexible private sector in which workers are constantly "rebranding" themselves, flitting from employer to employer, from one kind of work to another. When public service work is privatised and made short-term, as in the BBC where many people work on three-month contracts, the result can seem catastrophic, entailing a personal loss of focus or preventing just the opportunity to do worthwhile things which have, however, no immediate profit reward. It's striking to me in this regard that almost no one in these interviews talks about their unions. In Italy, public sector unions are conspirators with the state in immobilising public services; in the US public-sector unions frequently set the quality agenda in confrontations with government. The British workers in this survey speak of themselves as more self-directed; if you didn't know who paid their salaries, you might mistake them for self-employed. The water regulator, Philip Fletcher, makes a neat distinction: "As water regulator I am a public servant, thought what I do is very different from what I used to do as a Whitehall civil servant. Here, I run my own show." At a less grand level, Judy Tomkinson, the local registrar at Newcastle-under-Lyme, speaks like a Jewish matchmaker about the marriages she conducts. This feel-good factor is more than self-advertisement: there's little personal whingeing in situations of scarce resources that would entitle people high or low to whinge. Public service became confused at an early stage with charity work. The anthropologist Mary Douglas tartly observes that such charity wounds: help is inseparable from condescension, pity for the poor generates the fear of being held in contempt. The first Peabody Trust housing estates institutionalised this problem, nanny estates which rigidly controlled from above everything from where to hang out washing to where to plant flowers. Well-meaning conservatives now might well want to free the needy from this demeaning yoke. Being useful makes for a much more equal connection between people than compassion: the giver and receiver equally gain. webTitle: Tony Blair: I know there is more to do

fields.headline: I know there is more to do
fields.standfirst:
The common good: the Prime Minister joins the Guardian debate on the public services

Special report: election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The common good: the Prime Minister joins the Guardian debate on the public services.
fields.body:
We face what may be a historic choice over Britain's public services: between investment for the future and cuts which will turn the clock back. And a historic challenge too: to take the best of what public services can and should be and to reform our public services to bring them all to the level of the best.

Labour has the determination to reform our public services, to invest now in modernised public services and to provide the kind and quality of public services which people in this country both need and deserve. We intend to seize the moment.

I have absolutely no doubt about the vital importance of good public services for this country. Nor of the debt we owe as a society to those who, often struggling against the odds, help provide them.

It's often easy in this country for the powerful to get their voice heard. But it's hard to do so for those who don't have that access. That's why I strongly applaud what the Guardian is doing today: putting in practice its own commitment to our public services by giving those who work in them the chance and space to tell their story.

I have no doubt what their stories will be. Of course there will be frustrations and disappointments. Not enough resources. Not enough support. But I know what the overriding majority will say: they will tell a story of commitment, dedication and belief. Of public service as a vocation. Of their sense of purpose and of the value that their community - local and national - places upon them.

Because every week I meet and talk to those working in our public services whose pride in what they do - despite their concerns or difficulties - shines through in almost every word they say. I know how we depend, as families and as a country, on the commitment and talents of our teachers, doctors, nurses, police officers and hundreds and thousands of other dedicated public servants. I want to see that story told and retold. I also know how too often these same public servants feel undervalued and taken for granted. It's time for that aspect of the story to stop.

Good public services are vital for our continued prosperity as a country. More than ever before, for instance, our national economic wellbeing as a country depends upon a well-educated workforce, making sure we make the best of everyone's talents.

They are crucial, too, to our wellbeing as a society. Because they're used by everyone, public services are part of the glue of our community. They help tackle social exclusion, provide peace of mind for us all and remind us that we have responsibilities to each other as well as rights.

And it's exactly because good public services are central to a modern, prosperous and fairer society that revitalising and improving them is central to this Labour government's ambitions for our country.

That's not always been the case. For too long, our public services have been under-funded and undervalued. The result was that - despite the commitment and efforts of public servants themselves - they were losing the confidence of those who depended upon them and those who worked in them.

Turning this round was never going to be easy. It needed a change in attitude in government, reforms and massive increase in investment not just for one year but over the long haul.

I believe we've made a good start. More doctors, more nurses, more teachers. More in training - though we need many, many more. Hospitals and schools getting better. Education spending now up by £450 per pupil. Investment in school buildings tripled since 1997 to over £2bn a year. Health spending increasing over the next four years by twice the level under the Tories. Investment to take police numbers to their highest ever level. Capital investment in social housing will have increased from £1.5bn in 1997 to £4bn in 2004.

I'm proud of what we've achieved so far together. But I do accept that there is a great deal more to do.

That's why next week we will be setting out our policies and our programme on public services in Britain: a government paper which will both set out our reforming approach and make clear our commitment to public services and to public servants: the value we place upon them and the contribution they make to all our lives.

We will chart the way forward for public services in Britain. A way forward which values our public services and invests in them. A way forward which places reform and improvement in our public services at the heart of what the government is about. A way forward for the common good.

fields.headline: Air traffic controller, Heathrow
fields.standfirst:
Angus MacCormick
Salary: £44,000
fields.trailText: Angus MacCormick. Salary: £44,000.
fields.body:
I have been an air traffic controller for 10 years, eight of which have been spent at Heathrow. I'm also a representative of the air traffic controllers' union (IPMS).

My colleagues who work for national air traffic services, Nats, provide services from Aberdeen to Southampton airport, as well as being responsible for en-route traffic in UK airspace and over the Atlantic. Safety is our business and this includes looking after the safety of people on the ground as well as those flying.

One of my essential roles is to aid aircraft in an emergency and those assisting with emergencies, such as search and rescue and police. I also assist in the defence of the nation, and work cloely with the military services.

Most people make their way into ATC, not as a job, but as a vocation. I am very fortunate in doing something I love doing and this, and our professionalism, are reflected in the quality of service that we are able to provide. I am not motivated by financial incentives but more by professional pride in doing something well.

But it is important to give stability to controllers and we benefit from good terms and conditions. My salary is £44,000. Qualified controllers earn from £26,000 to £54,000 depending on qualifications and experience. We have a very low staff turnover and sickness rate.

Although our company is now commercially aware, and that is quite right, it should never put profit first. Nats makes a surplus now, but the important thing is that this allows us to provide a service, rather than us having the sole intention of making a profit, as all private companies have to do. There are some things that are too important to be left to private individuals and business. The first thing controllers are taught is to be safe, orderly and expeditious. That is our motto.

Safety does not come from an external regulator or instruction from the government. An ethos of safety comes from within. It is not about money.

fields.headline: Home Office interpreter
fields.standfirst:
Odette King
Salary: £26,000
fields.trailText: Odette King. Salary: £26,000.
fields.body:
Most of the Home Office interpreters nowadays are freelance, but I've been on staff since 1979, translating Farsi and Dari, which is the Farsi dialect spoken in Afghanistan. I'm based at Heathrow, but I can be sent to any port, including Dover and Harwich, when the need arises.

I'm of Iranian origin and married a British man in 1976. The job has changed tremendously. When I started, there were three flights a day from Iran and I was dealing with a multitude of practical difficulties, from lost papers to medical treatment. Now, with the problems in the world, I'm dealing mostly with refugees and you're in the frontline.

The interviews are very pressurised and can last anything from two to eight hours. Asylum claimants bring their own interpreters and there are sometimes problems between us, with the other interpreter interrupting for the sake of it, for example. But you have to be completely open-minded - you're just a medium, after all.

You also cannot allow yourself to get involved emotionally, though some of the refugees have very harrowing tales. One woman from Afghanistan recently had seen all five of her children killed with a grenade.

The basic salary for my grade is £12.79 an hour or £20,000 a year, but with overtime and London weighting, I make around £26,000 - plus, of course, pension, holiday and sickness benefits.

I used to work late, but now my flight from Tehran comes in at about noon and I do nine to five, Sunday to Thursday. I also do some freelance work for the police. I've got an 11-year-old daughter and the civil service is much better now about working round family life.

I'm not sure there's a lot of Farsi interpreting work in the private sector. I would consider it seriously if I was approached. But the job I do now is like a glove that fits very well.

fields.headline: Army major
fields.standfirst:
Anna Kimber
Salary: c. £32,000
fields.trailText: Anna Kimber. Salary: c. £32,000.
fields.body:
Hoping to progress straight to university, a month before my A levels I discovered I had to take a year off. Wishing to do something constructive and to earn some money, at that late stage the army's gap year commission was the only viable option. A quick - thoughtless - phone call to the army's careers office changed my life forever.

I ended up at Sandhurst for three weeks before being commissioned for the year and posted to a Royal Navy base in Hong Kong, one of life's little ironies.

Once at university, and by then sponsored by the army, I spent time having immense fun at the university's most social club, the officer training corps.

For me it was easy. I knew I was going back to Sandhurst. I did worry that once out of training with a "proper" commission, I would discover that I knew very little about the regular army. I was right.

I knew nothing of the leadership challenges I would face all over the world and the satisfaction it brought. I discovered to my horror that I enjoy stressful and adverse situations and devising solutions to rectify them. I knew nothing of the word "responsibility" until as a young officer, I had to command 70 soldiers in West Belfast and, the next year, had to travel the length and breadth of Bosnia setting up contracts so that the troops could sustain themselves.

I had real responsibility at a very young age, including responsibility for people's lives. Fortunately, I am pleased to be able to reflect that after nine years ,the overriding reason I joined the army in the first place still holds true wherever I go. The people.

fields.headline: District inspector of fisheries, Grimsby
fields.standfirst:
Richard Tomasson
Salary: £32,000
fields.trailText: Richard Tomasson. Salary: £32,000
fields.body:
I am a local manager in the sea fisheries inspectorate for a district from the Tees to halfway down the Wash.

Our main job is enforcing regulations, the surveillance of fishing boats and inspecting the fish that they land. If we suspect an offence has been committed we arrange the prosecution.

Since I started in 1980 the common fisheries policy has come in and occupies most of the enforcement work. Rules are more complex: once fisherman couldn't land below a certain size or use too small nets but now we have quotas and the nets are a regulated geometry.

The legislation fills a six- inch thick book that both we and the fisherman are expected to know. We try to establish a good relationship with the fisherman but we don't have the time to talk that we used to and gather local information.

Aside from enforcement, we administer fishing boat licensing, collect data on catches and, increasingly, deal with environmental matters. The ministry gives permits for construction below the high water mark - like planning permission in the sea - and we offer advice on the applications. If there is an oil spill, we are involved in the mopping up.

But much of the job is office based. Fishermen keep a log book of their catches so enforcement can come down to paper work. Advice - because we are also concerned with the industry's infrastructure - can be e-mailed out or dealt with on the telephone.

In such a specialised field it is difficult to know how salaries compare. I earn £32,000 - I suspect a lot less than people managing a similar-sized private company. But I like an interesting life and a challenging job. However, a starting salary is £11,000 and - since we ask for two years professional experience and a degree - recruitment is not easy.

Rules are more complex: once fisherman couldn't land below a certain size or use too small nets but now we have quotas and the nets are a regulated geometry. The legislation fills a six- inch thick book that both we and the fisherman are expected to know. We try to establish a good relationship with the fisherman but we don't have the time to talk that we used to and gather local information. Aside from enforcement, we administer fishing boat licensing, collect data on catches and, increasingly, deal with environmental matters. The ministry gives permits for construction below the high water mark - like planning permission in the sea - and we offer advice on the applications. If there is an oil spill, we are involved in the mopping up. But much of the job is office based. Fishermen keep a log book of their catches so enforcement can come down to paper work. Advice - because we are also concerned with the industry's infrastructure - can be e-mailed out or dealt with on the telephone. In such a specialised field it is difficult to know how salaries compare. I earn £32,000 - I suspect a lot less than people managing a similar-sized private company. But I like an interesting life and a challenging job. However, a starting salary is £11,000 and - since we ask for two years professional experience and a degree - recruitment is not easy.

fields.headline: Still papering over the cracks
fields.standfirst: Is Gordon Brown is spending too little too late?  Larry Elliott  investigates
fields.trailText: Is Gordon Brown is spending too little too late? Larry Elliott investigates.
fields.body:
Doctors nearing retirement are being offered £10,000 golden handshakes to keep them in general practice. Headteachers are notching up thousands of air miles in their search to fill classroom vacancies. Universities are struggling to keep hold of their brightest young lecturers. After four years of a Labour government, Britain's public sector exists as it has for decades, papering over the cracks and somehow surviving against the odds.

This is the key issue at the election: how can Labour improve delivery of public services? For the first election in a generation, the big economic issue is not tax cuts. Labour has succeeded in changing the nature of the debate, with the Conservatives fighting the forthcoming election on the defensive, forced to match Labour's spending commitments. As one Treasury source said in the aftermath of the Budget: "We have set out our vision of what we want to do for public spending and what we want to do to tackle poverty. It is up to the Tories now to say what they would do."

These are important shifts, but privately Labour insiders know they have barely scratched the surface of what needs to be done. Two big challenges are looming. The first is both ideological and fundamental: what sort of left-of-centre party does Labour want to be? On the one hand, there is the American low-taxation model, where people pay their own way but where the downside is that people pay more and a city as affluent as New York City lacks a direct mass transit system into the heart of Manhattan from Kennedy airport. On the other hand there is the European model, where spending is higher and services superior, but taxes are higher. The British model sits uneasily between the two.

For the time being, Mr Brown is in the happy position of being able to spend like a European while taxing like an American. That will not last, and here lies the second big challenge. Labour can be generous over the next three years - increasing spending by far more than the economy's trend rate of growth - because Britain has enjoyed a long period of sustained economic growth and Mr Brown donned his hairshirt in the government's early years. But that happy state of affairs may not last for ever. The storm clouds gathering in America and Japan could portend more difficult times ahead, in which high levels of spending will only be affordable if Labour is prepared to countenance higher taxation. There is not the slightest inkling that it is ready to fight this sort of bloody political battle.

Little has changed

What sharpens this as a critical test for Labour is that the truth is that the public sector under Tony Blair is little changed from the public sector under John Major. Gordon Brown has now loosened the purse strings after two years in which Labour actually spent less than the Tories had been planning, but - despite all the spin about how things are getting better - all that he has done so far is compensate for the retrenchment in 1998 and 1999.

Kenneth Clarke can scarcely credit it. With the Tories heading for the electoral rocks in late 1986, the former Conservative chancellor tried one last roll of the dice. In his November Budget he announced minuscule increases in spending in the hope that his Labour shadow, Gordon Brown, would lose public credibility by refusing to swallow the poisoned pill. Mr Clarke was wrong. Mr Brown not only swallowed the pill, he swallowed it with relish. In order to prove his Iron Chancellor credentials, he not only kept to Mr Clarke's hideously tough plans but managed to cut public spending in inflation-adjusted terms during Labour's first two years.

For those in the Labour party expecting instant financial relief after 18 years of Conservative rule this all came as a bit of a nasty surprise. Whatever they had voted for, it certainly was not for further cuts. Mr Clarke, who admits that he would have torn up his plans had John Major won in 1997, says that there was no economic reason to justify the squeeze on public spending in Labour's first two years. "There was no crisis to justify it and Britain's schools and hospitals still bear the scars", he says.

There is a lot of truth in what Mr Clarke says. The reason the public realm looked shabby under the Conservatives compared with the gleaming edifices of the private sector was that public spending increased more slowly than the economy as a whole - by just 1.6% a year over the 18 years between 1979 and 1997. In Labour's first two years it was cut by 0.6% on average. Spending on the NHS increased by just 2.2% under Brown, compared with 3.1% under the Conservatives. Whatever is said now, these were painful decisions and they caused real damage.

Mr Brown's argument is that he had no choice but to establish his credentials, and that he is using the hard-won credibility to start putting things right now. There is some truth in this analysis, since history is littered with the baleful stories of Labour chancellors making generous spending commitments early on and then coming off second best in battles with financial markets alarmed by the lack of economic discipline. In fact, however, Mr Brown used the power of the markets as something of a smokescreen. While the risks of a Labour government being faced with a debilitating mid-term crisis were real enough (although by no means as high as they had been in more difficult economic times) Mr Brown and his advisers had no intention of simply throwing money at schools and hospitals. They believed that first they had to counter the prevailing wisdom of the Conservative years: that anything the public sector could do, the private sector could do better.

Wasteful and inefficient

Margaret Thatcher certainly had no love for the public sector, considering it to be wasteful, inefficient and in need of an injection of private-sector entrepreneurship. But she was also cutting with the prevailing cultural grain, which by the late 1970s had seen the collectivist values that had underpinned the growth of the public sector in the 1950s and 1960s eroded by the growth of individualism. The message from the films and television of the 1970s - movies such as Get Carter and O Lucky Man! - mirrored public perception of local government embroiled in Poulson-style sleaze, a police force mired in corruption, and public services that were shoddy and unresponsive to the needs of those using them. Big government, in other words, was bad government.

The shortcomings of the Conservative approach soon became apparent. As afflu ence increased in Britain during the 1980s and 1990s, people wanted better healthcare, better schools, better universities. They also wanted better transport and safer streets. What they got instead was spending that did not match that of the economy as a whole, leading to a prolonged period of relative decline. One area where the market was not allowed to work - and is still not allowed to work - was public sector pay, where the government has used its power as a monopoly employer to keep salaries below the proper going rate, while at the same time using a barrage of targets - often indiscriminately - in an attempt to make the public sector work like the private sector.

Labour has bought into the target-based approach, even though it is clear that some of those employed in the public sector lead to perverse outcomes, such as concentrating health resources on reducing waiting lists rather than on treating those most in need of care.

The government's case is that by avoiding the macro-economic mistakes of the past, it is now in a position to make a sustained investment in public services. Falling debt interest payments and lower unemployment mean that more than 80p in every additional pound can go on "productive" public spending rather than "wasteful" public spending. But there is a very real risk that the public sector is so enfeebled that the surge in spending now is simply too little too late, and that Britain is now so far adrift of standards of provision elsewhere in the developed world that it will never be able to catch up.

This is the real risk for Labour. It has done enough in its first term to win a second, but the public will be far less forgiving next time. They will expect results, not excuses.

Catalogue of decline

Public spending as a % of GDP

1979-80 44.8%

1988-89 39.1%

1998-99 38.5%

2003-4 40.5% (projected)

 Spending on health grew by an average 3.1% 1979-97 and by 4.7% 1997-2001

 Spending on education grew by 1.5% 1979-97 and by 3.6% 1997-2001

Public employment

 In 1979, the public sector employed 7,449,000

 In 1999, the public sector employed 4,697,000

Biggest employers

 2,622,000 are employed in local government of which 1,241,000 are in education, 388,000 are in social services

 855,000 are employed in central government

 1,131,000 are employed in NHS trusts

Pay gap

 In 1976, a teacher earned 40% more than the average non-manual worker, today the gap is just 10%

 In the six years since 1995, public sector pay has risen by less than 20 % compared with a rise in the private sector of over 30%

Women

Over a third of all female employees work for the public sector. They make up 80% of the NHS, 71% of local government, 72% of teachers and 50% of central government.

fields.headline: Clinical psychologist, Sheffield (part-time)
fields.standfirst:
Diana Shapiro
Salary: £45,000 pro rata
fields.trailText: Diana Shapiro. Salary: £45,000 pro rata.
fields.body:
I'm totally committed to the NHS and public services. I worked as a research assistant after I graduated and became very frustrated, realising I wanted to apply psychology and engage with people's real life issues. I like the fact my work makes a difference.

Clinical psychologists work in a range of settings, from contributing to trauma care to working with children. At times it will be face-to-face work with individuals, at other times we're helping to shape services.

I'm head of the staff counselling and consultation service for a health trust, a self-referral service for staff with problems. The stress levels in the NHS are significantly higher than in comparative organisations. Health care is pretty demanding work. People who go into public sector jobs are often quite altruistic, but we're all vulnerable.

But I'm passionately committed to the NHS. I want to offer the best to people at a free point of access - I don't want shareholder value getting in the way of service delivery, as in Railtrack. I do know people who have gone to work in private secure hospitals or independently as therapists or trainers. I probably wouldn't make much more in the private sector because I'm at consultant grade - if I was working full time I would earn something like £45,000, an excellent salary.

If I was looking for something to improve, it would be better resourcing and better accommodation. The space and administrative support are dire.

There's also the tip of the iceberg feeling - you want to help people, but you're flooded with too many referrals. Psychological treatments are fairly time-consuming and there is tremendous pressure to move away from longer-term therapy to brief intervention. People want psychologists and say they value us, but they don't put the money where their mouths are because there are so many competing priorities.

fields.headline: The common good
fields.standfirst: This is not the Rich List, the Power List or the Fame List. Guardian journalists interviewed 200 public servants - from a hospital porter to a general. Their voices are not often heard. The results are surprising - and inspiring
fields.trailText: This is not the Rich List, the Power List or the Fame List. Guardian journalists interviewed 200 public servants - from a hospital porter to a general. Their voices are not often heard. The results are surprising - and inspiring.
fields.body:
The public mood is changing

Over more than 30 pages today and tomorrow we have constructed a mosaic of voices. They are men and women who are often talked about but heard only rarely. They are the voices of people who work in our public services - people who, in some fundamental sense, work for the common good.

Why are we giving so much space, not to an election or a Budget, a royal death or a foreign war but to Britain's public services and the people who make them work? At the most elevated level, because a civilized society is judged on how it provides for its citizens. Decent public services - schools, hospitals, railways - are both prerequisites for and measures of a decent nation. They say something about who we are and how we take care of each other.

The more immediate answer is that an election is coming - an election which may well turn on the quality of our public services. Whenever a candidate is questioned, on radio or television, he or she will routinely insist that the "real issues people care about" are education or health or transport. So today we are taking the politicians at their word, speaking to the people who empty our bins, teach our children, cure our sick and generally make Britain's wheels go round. It has been an ambitious project: nearly 200 Guardian journalists have interviewed a public servant - from the highest ranking diplomat to the poorest-paid school cleaner, from the celebrated museum director to the unsung local librarian. It was never meant to be a scientific survey, and inevitably there will be gaps. But the point of a mosaic is that the small fragments build towards a large picture. Those who speak here may not always work for the formal public sector but they are people who, even indirectly, serve the common good. After years of debate about them, today we have the chance to hear their voice.

Moreover, this election demands a debate on public service more insistently than any previous contest. For this campaign has been defined by Labour as a referendum on the importance of public provision. Gordon Brown's Budget sought to present a choice to the electorate: either increased public spending under Labour or a generous tax cut under the Conservatives. The fact that Labour seems on course to win that contest marks a historic shift. After years in which voters chose tax cuts over the centre-left's promise of greater public spending, they now appear to have switched sides. A Labour victory will be a mandate to fund our national services properly.

And now is certainly the time. For, at long last, economics and politics have come together to shine on the public realm. There is, for once, money to spend - billions of it. The chancellor speaks of a surplus close to £20bn, while some believe his forecasts are, if anything, too pessimistic. The result is that even the £4bn he spent in this month's Budget, including £2bn extra for schools and hospitals, was deemed too cautious by City analysts Deloitte & Touche: even they reckon he could have spent more! For the first time in our postwar history, Britain's problem has become how to spend it. The chancellor complains of more than £7bn allocated for capital spending and a Whitehall machine that has managed to use up just £2.2bn of it. It is a rare moment indeed: Britain has both the will and means to fund decent public services.

There is a last political explanation for the urgent relevance of this debate. The Labour government is, by its own admission, staking its future on improvement of the basic social infrastructure of our country. On this, prime minister and chancellor speak with one voice, confessing that if public services are not improved by the end of their tenure they will have failed. That single objective is now the Labour "project." The government will stand or fall on its achievement. As Matthew Taylor and Gavin Kelly argue in tomorrow's paper, "If the case for universal public services cannot be won now it could be lost forever."

Our public services are in chaos and decay

So much for the politics. What makes this debate truly urgent within, but also far beyond, Westminster is the simple truth about our public services: that they are in a state of crisis, chaos and decay. Despite the inspiring and upbeat testimony of the public servants themselves - men and women who remain devoted to their work and to the people they help every day - it is a matter of grim consensus that too many of our core, collective needs are not met properly. We see the evidence before our eyes every day: doctors' waiting rooms jampacked with people, hospital corridors overflowing with patients on trolleys, schools turned riotous by too-large classes and too-few staff. Elsewhere in the public realm, even where funded privately, it is the same picture: rural bus routes closed, trains which arrive late or not at all.

Alongside the anecdotal evidence there is a mountain of statistical data, some of which is charted in detail over the following pages. But to pick just a few revealing numbers. One World Health Organisation study found that up to 25,000 Britons who die of cancer each year would survive if British care were up to the best standards in the European Union. Or take education. If we were to construct a league table of EU countries, ranked according to how many over-16s are still in school, guess who comes bottom? We do, with Germany and France 20 percentage points ahead of us. A 1999 survey found that one in five British adults cannot add up the change in their pocket.

Why are these two most basic services lagging so far behind? Here's a big clue: money. On healthcare we spend little more than a third per citizen of the amount paid out in the US and just over half the sum spent in France. We spend less than the latter because we tax less. The total tax take here for 1999 was 36.6% of GDP; in France it was 46%.

Those numbers may explain the parlous state of our public services, but they too need an ex planation. How did Britain get itself into this mess? The answer may begin in the very origins of the modern public realm.

The post-war era, from 1945 to 1979 may be remembered fondly now as the golden age of the public sector. It was, after all, the Attlee government which founded the NHS and expanded vastly our notion of the collective sphere by nationalising key industries. But there are important qualifiers. First, we struggled, at least after 1960, to invest on a French or German scale. While our economic growth in that period was healthy enough, at around 3%, our European neighbours were doubling that rate - and spending the money on rebuilding their infrastructure, from well-equipped schools to lean, sleek railways. Britain may have expanded higher education spending in the 60s, but the devaluation of 1967 and the IMF crisis of 1976 triggered deep cuts in public sector investment. Meanwhile France and Germany surged ahead.

More deeply, historians now reflect that the public sector never quite put down the political, even cultural roots found on the Continent. In France the institutions of the state became intertwined with French identity itself; that never quite happened here. Principled advocacy for the ideal of public provision was scarce. Instead, the public sector became associated with incompetence and even corruption - from the Ronan Point disaster to the Poulson affair, from British Rail to the sleaze-ridden Met. Public servants were saddled with a reputation for stroppiness, laziness and unionised militancy.

This was the soil that sprouted Thatcherism. It grew into a two-decade rundown of public services, fed by that 1970s national mood of despair. With the exception of the police, our collective agencies were put on a starvation diet, forced to do more and more work with less and less money. Teachers' pay went into freefall, sending them plummeting down the professional ladder. Doctors and nurses saw their workload increase while the buildings around them crumbled.

Blair may be missing a shift in public mood

Perhaps even more withering than the economic assault was the cultural war Thatcherism waged on the common realm. Backed by their cheerleaders in the press, Conservatism denigrated public servants - demonising teachers and social workers especially - and disparaged the very idea of public service. In the Thatcherite imagination, those who worked for the common good were losers who couldn't get a job in the private sector. For them, private was always fitter, stronger and more efficient. Since there was no such thing as society, society's members had no duty to provide for each other. We could purchase whatever we needed, not as citizens but as consumers. The 80s privatisations rammed home the message: private good, public bad.

Many Britons hoped that era would come to an end on May 1 1997. But it has not been that simple. For one thing, Labour famously refused to give an instant blood-transfusion to the public services: instead it maintained the starvation policy by sticking to the Tories' spending limits for their first two years. They say that 24-month fast bought them the credibility they needed for a 10-year programme of renewal - but the public services paid a desperate price.

Second, the culture of denigration has lingered on. Whether Chris Woodhead's barely-concealed disdain for teachers or Tony Blair's lament that he still bore "the scars on [his] back" from his battles with the public sector, much of the old, Thatcherite rhetoric still hovers in the national air. Labour's defence is that voters will only give more money to the public services when they see those services are held to strict account and are sufficiently reformed to use taxpayers' money wisely. Ministers say they remember the bad old days, when the public sector was grossly inefficient and couldn't deliver a letter - let alone decent health or education. They don't dare put Labour's fate in its hands again.

The result is the familiar, punitive language applied to public service. Whether it be the countless performance targets laid down by Whitehall, the refusal to give a serious hike to public workers' pay or the Treasury's near-dogmatic insistence on public-private partnerships in transport and elsewhere, the message is the same: the public sector on its own cannot be trusted. Government ministers or commercial boardrooms must keep public servants on a tight leash, watching or controlling their every move. In this regard, we suspect this thoroughly modern government may be uncharacteristically out of date. For a new mood seems abroad, one that no longer believes everything public is rubbish and everything private sparkles. When Britons hear "private" they now think of Railtrack; that's why even 71% of Tory voters tell our pollsters today they would welcome the return of a nationalised British Rail.

The mood is changing, moving away from the lazy caricatures of old. Over the next two days we hope to build on that shift, shedding some truer light on the public servants who make Britain work. As we hope their stories show, they are people of dedication, altruism and often bravery. Tomorrow we will look for solutions to the problem we have sought to describe here. But first we should listen to the people who form nothing less than the backbone of our country - and we should celebrate them.
