Decent public services - schools, hospitals, railways - are both prerequisites for and measures of a decent nation. They say something about who we are and how we take care of each other. The more immediate answer is that an election is coming - an election which may well turn on the quality of our public services. Whenever a candidate is questioned, on radio or television, he or she will routinely insist that the "real issues people care about" are education or health or transport. So today we are taking the politicians at their word, speaking to the people who empty our bins, teach our children, cure our sick and generally make Britain's wheels go round. It has been an ambitious project: nearly 200 Guardian journalists have interviewed a public servant - from the highest ranking diplomat to the poorest-paid school cleaner, from the celebrated museum director to the unsung local librarian. It was never meant to be a scientific survey, and inevitably there will be gaps. But the point of a mosaic is that the small fragments build towards a large picture. Those who speak here may not always work for the formal public sector but they are people who, even indirectly, serve the common good. After years of debate about them, today we have the chance to hear their voice. Moreover, this election demands a debate on public service more insistently than any previous contest. For this campaign has been defined by Labour as a referendum on the importance of public provision. Gordon Brown's Budget sought to present a choice to the electorate: either increased public spending under Labour or a generous tax cut under the Conservatives. The fact that Labour seems on course to win that contest marks a historic shift. After years in which voters chose tax cuts over the centre-left's promise of greater public spending, they now appear to have switched sides. A Labour victory will be a mandate to fund our national services properly. And now is certainly the time. For, at long last, economics and politics have come together to shine on the public realm. There is, for once, money to spend - billions of it. The chancellor speaks of a surplus close to £20bn, while some believe his forecasts are, if anything, too pessimistic. The result is that even the £4bn he spent in this month's Budget, including £2bn extra for schools and hospitals, was deemed too cautious by City analysts Deloitte & Touche: even they reckon he could have spent more! For the first time in our postwar history, Britain's problem has become how to spend it. The chancellor complains of more than £7bn allocated for capital spending and a Whitehall machine that has managed to use up just £2.2bn of it. It is a rare moment indeed: Britain has both the will and means to fund decent public services. There is a last political explanation for the urgent relevance of this debate. The Labour government is, by its own admission, staking its future on improvement of the basic social infrastructure of our country. On this, prime minister and chancellor speak with one voice, confessing that if public services are not improved by the end of their tenure they will have failed. That single objective is now the Labour "project." The government will stand or fall on its achievement. As Matthew Taylor and Gavin Kelly argue in tomorrow's paper, "If the case for universal public services cannot be won now it could be lost forever." Our public services are in chaos and decay So much for the politics. What makes this debate truly urgent within, but also far beyond, Westminster is the simple truth about our public services: that they are in a state of crisis, chaos and decay. Despite the inspiring and upbeat testimony of the public servants themselves - men and women who remain devoted to their work and to the people they help every day - it is a matter of grim consensus that too many of our core, collective needs are not met properly. We see the evidence before our eyes every day: doctors' waiting rooms jampacked with people, hospital corridors overflowing with patients on trolleys, schools turned riotous by too-large classes and too-few staff. Elsewhere in the public realm, even where funded privately, it is the same picture: rural bus routes closed, trains which arrive late or not at all. Alongside the anecdotal evidence there is a mountain of statistical data, some of which is charted in detail over the following pages. But to pick just a few revealing numbers. One World Health Organisation study found that up to 25,000 Britons who die of cancer each year would survive if British care were up to the best standards in the European Union. Or take education. If we were to construct a league table of EU countries, ranked according to how many over-16s are still in school, guess who comes bottom? We do, with Germany and France 20 percentage points ahead of us. A 1999 survey found that one in five British adults cannot add up the change in their pocket. Why are these two most basic services lagging so far behind? Here's a big clue: money. On healthcare we spend little more than a third per citizen of the amount paid out in the US and just over half the sum spent in France. We spend less than the latter because we tax less. The total tax take here for 1999 was 36.6% of GDP; in France it was 46%. Those numbers may explain the parlous state of our public services, but they too need an ex planation. How did Britain get itself into this mess? The answer may begin in the very origins of the modern public realm. The post-war era, from 1945 to 1979 may be remembered fondly now as the golden age of the public sector. It was, after all, the Attlee government which founded the NHS and expanded vastly our notion of the collective sphere by nationalising key industries. But there are important qualifiers. First, we struggled, at least after 1960, to invest on a French or German scale. While our economic growth in that period was healthy enough, at around 3%, our European neighbours were doubling that rate - and spending the money on rebuilding their infrastructure, from well-equipped schools to lean, sleek railways. Britain may have expanded higher education spending in the 60s, but the devaluation of 1967 and the IMF crisis of 1976 triggered deep cuts in public sector investment. Meanwhile France and Germany surged ahead. More deeply, historians now reflect that the public sector never quite put down the political, even cultural roots found on the Continent. In France the institutions of the state became intertwined with French identity itself; that never quite happened here. Principled advocacy for the ideal of public provision was scarce. Instead, the public sector became associated with incompetence and even corruption - from the Ronan Point disaster to the Poulson affair, from British Rail to the sleaze-ridden Met. Public servants were saddled with a reputation for stroppiness, laziness and unionised militancy. This was the soil that sprouted Thatcherism. It grew into a two-decade rundown of public services, fed by that 1970s national mood of despair. With the exception of the police, our collective agencies were put on a starvation diet, forced to do more and more work with less and less money. Teachers' pay went into freefall, sending them plummeting down the professional ladder. Doctors and nurses saw their workload increase while the buildings around them crumbled. Blair may be missing a shift in public mood Perhaps even more withering than the economic assault was the cultural war Thatcherism waged on the common realm. Backed by their cheerleaders in the press, Conservatism denigrated public servants - demonising teachers and social workers especially - and disparaged the very idea of public service. In the Thatcherite imagination, those who worked for the common good were losers who couldn't get a job in the private sector. For them, private was always fitter, stronger and more efficient. Since there was no such thing as society, society's members had no duty to provide for each other. We could purchase whatever we needed, not as citizens but as consumers. The 80s privatisations rammed home the message: private good, public bad. Many Britons hoped that era would come to an end on May 1 1997. But it has not been that simple. For one thing, Labour famously refused to give an instant blood-transfusion to the public services: instead it maintained the starvation policy by sticking to the Tories' spending limits for their first two years. They say that 24-month fast bought them the credibility they needed for a 10-year programme of renewal - but the public services paid a desperate price. Second, the culture of denigration has lingered on. Whether Chris Woodhead's barely-concealed disdain for teachers or Tony Blair's lament that he still bore "the scars on [his] back" from his battles with the public sector, much of the old, Thatcherite rhetoric still hovers in the national air. Labour's defence is that voters will only give more money to the public services when they see those services are held to strict account and are sufficiently reformed to use taxpayers' money wisely. Ministers say they remember the bad old days, when the public sector was grossly inefficient and couldn't deliver a letter - let alone decent health or education. They don't dare put Labour's fate in its hands again. The result is the familiar, punitive language applied to public service. Whether it be the countless performance targets laid down by Whitehall, the refusal to give a serious hike to public workers' pay or the Treasury's near-dogmatic insistence on public-private partnerships in transport and elsewhere, the message is the same: the public sector on its own cannot be trusted. Government ministers or commercial boardrooms must keep public servants on a tight leash, watching or controlling their every move. In this regard, we suspect this thoroughly modern government may be uncharacteristically out of date. For a new mood seems abroad, one that no longer believes everything public is rubbish and everything private sparkles. When Britons hear "private" they now think of Railtrack; that's why even 71% of Tory voters tell our pollsters today they would welcome the return of a nationalised British Rail. The mood is changing, moving away from the lazy caricatures of old. Over the next two days we hope to build on that shift, shedding some truer light on the public servants who make Britain work. As we hope their stories show, they are people of dedication, altruism and often bravery. Tomorrow we will look for solutions to the problem we have sought to describe here. But first we should listen to the people who form nothing less than the backbone of our country - and we should celebrate them.

webTitle: Comment: David Marquand joins the public services debate.

fields.headline: The breath of renewal
fields.standfirst:
The common good: a leading academic joins the Guardian debate on the public services

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The common good: a leading academic joins the Guardian debate on the public services.
fields.body:
Three great questions now confront the Labour party. Assuming it wins the election in a few weeks time, can it finally break the umbilical cord of privilege, snobbery and inertia which has tied the British state to the Conservative party for more than 100 years? Can it develop a coherent social-democratic governing philosophy, capable of guiding it through the inevitable uncertainties and contingencies of government? Can it revive our battered, resource-starved public services, and breathe new life into the ethic of citizenship and service which is fundamental to the public realm?

The third question holds the key to the first two. A substantial election victory in May is a precondition of the progressive century of Blair's dreams, but his real test will come after polling day. He has been astonishingly successful in marginalising the Conservative party, but the job is not yet done. The forces which have produced Sharon in Israel, Haider in Austria, Berlusconi in Italy and George Bush in the US have equivalents in Britain. The threat of a hard-right resurgence will not disappear until social-democratic norms permeate the public culture and the structures of the state. In his first term Blair established a bridgehead - the beginnings of a constitutional revolution; normalisation of relations with the rest of the EU; modest, but real, fiscal redistribution. It is time to follow the bridgehead with a breakthrough.

One of the crucial objectives of such a breakthrough would be the renewal of the public services and the culture that sustains them. Social democracy and the public realm are inextricably intertwined. Without an ideologically confident and politically effective social-democratic movement to champion them, the public services are always at risk. Without a vibrant public realm, ring-fenced from the market realm, social-democratic politics cannot flourish. Public services depend on a culture of citizenship and equity - on a culture in which professional pride in a job well done or a sense of civic duty or a mixture of both replace the hope of gain and the fear of loss as spurs to action. And that is pre-eminently the culture of social democracy.

It is now dangerously attenuated. The single most important element in the New Right project of the 1980s and 90s was a relentless Kulturkampf designed to root it out. Deregulation, privatisation, so-called public-private partnerships, proxy markets, performance indicators mimicking those of corporate management and a systematic assault on professional autonomy narrowed the public realm and blurred the distinction between it and the market realm. Public functions of all kinds were farmed out to unaccountable appointed bodies, dominated by business interests and managed according to market principles. Intermediate institutions like the BBC, the universities, the schools, museums and the health service were forced, so far as possible, into a market mould. So was the senior civil service, where the frontiers of the public realm had been most zealously guarded, and in which its values had been most thoroughly internalised.

The tatty, shabby, over-stretched public services of 21st century Britain are the most obvious legacy of this Kulturkampf, but they are not the most dangerous one. Incessant marketisation has done even more damage than low taxation and resource starvation. It has generated a culture of distrust, which is nibbling away at the values of professionalism, citizenship, equity and service like an acrid fog. For the marketisers, the professional, public service ethic is a con. Professionals are self-interested rent-seekers, trying to force the price of their labour above its market value. The service ethic is a device to legitimise a web of monopolistic cartels whose real purpose is to rip off the consumer. There is no point in appealing to the values of common citizenship. There are no citizens; there are only customers. Public servants are inherently untrustworthy. If they are allowed autonomy, they will abuse it. Like everyone else, they can be motivated only by sticks and carrots. If possible, privatisation must expose them to the sticks and carrots of market competition. If not, they must be kept on their toes by repeated audits, assessments and appraisals.

Twenty years of this mean-spirited rhetoric have demoralised the public services and encouraged users who can afford it to buy their way out. The service ethic still has devoted champions among doctors, teachers, nurses, social workers, academics, broadcasters, judges, trade-union officials, local government officials and NGO workers. But danger signs are everywhere. The most spectacular have appeared in Whitehall itself. First the Scott report and then the Phillips report showed that the culture of disinterested professionalism, which held that the civil servant's duty was to serve the public interest and tell truth to power, is in tatters.

And that is only the beginning. The growing interpenetration of the worlds of politics and business; the sleaze which has accompanied it; the dumbing down of the BBC; the sponsorship culture which has invaded virtually every form of public entertainment from opera to football; the diversion of academic energies from the pursuit of knowledge and the education of the young to a desperate scrabbling for advantage in mindless assessment exercises; all tell the same story. They all show that the dykes which our Victorian ancestors built to protect the public realm from the encroaching imperialism of the market realm have been breached repeatedly.

Few social democrats would disagree with that, but the implications are more contentious than appears at first sight. The public realm cannot be resuscitated by ministerial fiat or bureaucratic intervention, no matter how well-intentioned. The service ethic is hollow without a supporting ethic of democracy and diversity. Marketisation made headway because it spoke to a widespread popular revolt against the condescension and exclusiveness of the elites that used to manage the public services, and to a well-founded popular demand for accountability. The accountability it offered was deformed and corrosive. But that does not imply a return to the public realm of the old days. Accountability should be sought through participation, openness and a willingness to listen, not the price mechanism or the iron cage of bureaucratic audit. The social democracy of the 21st century must recover the decentralist, participatory strands in its own tradition, and marry them with the equivalent strands in the social liberal tradition.

Top-down, central-state social democracy is a busted flush. It runs against the grain of the information age, and flies in the face of the cultural revolution of the last 35 years. Politely, but firmly, it should be junked. This is exactly what Tony Blair promised in his early days as Labour leader. Keynes, Beveridge and Lloyd George, he repeatedly insisted, were as much at home in the New Labour pantheon as Attlee, Bevin or Bevan. He picked up the mantle of constitutional reform and political decentralisation where the Asquith government had dropped it in 1914. The result was an astonishingly far-reaching transfer of power from the central state to lower tiers of government. Then the centralist, metropolitan side of the social-democratic tradition reasserted itself, and the revolution stalled. It is time to get back on track.

 David Marquand is the principal of Mansfield College, Oxford, a former Labour politician and a founder member of the Social Democratic party.

webTitle: Vote of confidence in public services

fields.headline: Vote of confidence in public services
fields.trailText: A new cross-party consensus among voters which overwhelmingly supports public services has emerged in Britain.
fields.body:
A new cross-party consensus among voters which overwhelmingly supports public services has emerged in Britain, leaving privatisation dead as popular political force, according to a special Guardian/ICM opinion poll.

The survey shows that all voters, including Conservatives, now want to see public services run by the government or by local authorities and overwhelmingly reject the idea that public services should not be run for profit. The results show that there is little, if any, appetite for further privatisations and represent a major vote of confidence in public services.

The Guardian poll shows that the public feel strongly that those who work for public services are underpaid and undervalued. More than 75% feel that those who work in the public service no longer enjoy the respect they did 20 years ago.

Only one in four voters, including 23% of Labour supporters, back the government's idea of public and private partnerships running public services, and the voters have finally consigned the Thatcherite idea of wholesale privatisation to the dustbin of history. Only 6% of voters, and just 13% of Tory voters, are now prepared to support the idea that private companies should always or usually run public services.

The emergence of this sea change in public opinion in the country that once boasted of selling the world the idea of privatisation is underlined by the hostility of voters of all parties - including the Tories - to future privatisations such as air traffic control. It is underlined by the overwhelming support for the return of the railways (76% of all voters) and private prisons (60% of all voters) to the public sector, although most voters say that they do not want to see BT renationalised.

What is striking is that Tory voters now clearly share these traditional Labour and Liberal Democrat views, with 61% of Conservative supporters saying they do not believe the public services should be run for profit. Some 71% of Tory voters want to see the railways renationalised and 60% want to see an end to private prisons. The emergence of this new cross-party consensus seems to indicate a new level of trust in the public sector which has not been seen for 20 years.

The public certainly seem to think that those who work in public services are underpaid and undervalued, and that their status has fallen sharply since the 1970s. About half of voters say that those who work in the public sector are underpaid.

The public sector is still politically significant. About 35% of voters say they or someone in their immediate family work for a public service.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,001 adults aged over 18 by telephone between March 16- 18 2001. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Sins of the flesh
fields.standfirst: Stanley Spencer may have found Christ in Cookham, but his soul knew little peace, says  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Stanley Spencer may have found Christ in Cookham, but his soul knew little peace, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
In 1974, when Stanley Spencer's reputation was pretty much at its nadir, the Tate bought the painter's curious "leg of mutton" portrait, a study in oils of a bespectacled yet otherwise naked Spencer hunkered down beside his wife, Patricia, spread-eagled on an old stripy bed in a rather uncomfortable post-coital moment. A joint of meat looks horribly raw in the foreground.

The Tate still owns the work (Double Nude Portrait: the Artist and His Second Wife, 1937) and it's in Tate Britain's latest show. This gutsy reappraisal of this long-mocked English painter - set in a near-monastic setting designed by architect Claudio Silvestrin - attempts to elevate Spencer to the status of a Balthus, a Dix, or a Hopper. Maybe curators Patrick Wright and Timothy Hyman are right. Yet the "leg of mutton" portrait and the worst of Spencer's Cookham landscapes suggest he hovers awkwardly between the world of prewar London Transport posters, English whimsy, folksy religious sentiment and an embarrassingly immature attitude towards sex.

The Tate show divides Spencer's work into key periods: before the first world war; the aftermath of the war; the 1930s, when he became rather neurotically besotted with sex; his social-realist work as war artist from 1940; and his last, haunting paintings, concerning his first wife's early death and his own impending demise from cancer.

The early works are a cartoonish blend of Giotto and Samuel Palmer. His Last Supper is convincing: here the apostles' legs stretch under white togas as if to a fixed point under the table; with Christ at their head, they are as one, physically and spiritually. The postwar works come from the Oratory of All Souls at Burghclere, Hampshire. This gauntly awkward meeting of red-brick memorial chapel and almshouses, designed by Lionel Pearson and built between 1923 and 1927, was designed to house Spencer's canvases: his cycle of post-first world war oils depicting the psychological stresses endured by common soldiers.

There is something wonderful about stepping into a Home Counties chapel and coming across England's own cut-price version of Giotto's Arena Chapel in Padua. As a student at the Slade School of Art, Spencer had been much influenced by the "primitive Italians". At Burghclere his pictures are mostly of traumatised soldiers coping with war or in the uncertain process of rehabilitation. "By this means I recover my lost self," he said. A self lost in the war. These are paintings of redemption, all the better for being tucked away in a cosy corner of southern England.

After the postwar works come the nudes, including some fine pencil drawings made in 1931 of Spencer's first wife, Hilda. Then the naked, meaty stuff and the cycle of paintings of Christ in the streets of Spencer's home town of Cookham. By this time, Spencer felt we could all be redeemed by a kind of collective hippie love-in. So he painted a veritable orgy set in a "village in Heaven" around the Cookham War Memorial. "I am on the side of angels and dirt," he said.

Spencer avoids the sexual obsessiveness of his contemporary Eric Gill, but you can't help wanting him to put it away, as it were (especially when you see the Lavatory 1 and Lavatory 2 pencil drawings of the early 1940s, which make an uncomfortably literal link between sexual curiosity and bowel movements). He should stick to what he does best, exploring the possibility of spirituality in a world in which cannons appear to have driven Christ far from England's green and pleasant land.

Spencer often paints idealised English landscapes - it was fashionable to do so in the years before the second world war, when suburbia and the machine world were embracing the countryside like the tentacles of a man-made octopus. But you feel he has something to say again with his wonderfully immediate Christ in the Wilderness sequence of small, square oils dating from the time he spent alone, between wives, in a room in Swiss Cottage.

And then, after the finely crafted social-realist war work, he has a last fling, creatively, if not physically, with his first wife, Hilda. There's the touching Hilda and I at Pond Street (1954), painted four years after her death; the artist is shown opening a coffin-like box of flowers that reach for her body like the gentlest tendrils. Then there is the terrifying Crucifixion of 1958 (in Cookham High Street, of course) and the deathly self-portrait painted as he faced the truth of his own coffin.

Spencer's genius - he does have this - is to take the suffering of war or of his Christ or of sexual desire into homely English settings. Home for Spencer, no matter where else he lived and worked, was Cookham, a small Berkshire town on the Thames. With the detritus of Spencer's work over 50 years removed, an artist of depth and talent emerges. He never could get the connection between sexuality or sensuality and spirituality. Yet, when he rises above what he perceived as "dirt", he is an English angel. Slightly damaged, of course, like Blake and Coleridge, who try to reconcile some of the same forces and feelings, and occasionally profound.

A joint of meat looks horribly raw in the foreground. The Tate still owns the work (Double Nude Portrait: the Artist and His Second Wife, 1937) and it's in Tate Britain's latest show. This gutsy reappraisal of this long-mocked English painter - set in a near-monastic setting designed by architect Claudio Silvestrin - attempts to elevate Spencer to the status of a Balthus, a Dix, or a Hopper. Maybe curators Patrick Wright and Timothy Hyman are right. Yet the "leg of mutton" portrait and the worst of Spencer's Cookham landscapes suggest he hovers awkwardly between the world of prewar London Transport posters, English whimsy, folksy religious sentiment and an embarrassingly immature attitude towards sex. The early works are a cartoonish blend of Giotto and Samuel Palmer. His Last Supper is convincing: here the apostles' legs stretch under white togas as if to a fixed point under the table; with Christ at their head, they are as one, physically and spiritually. The postwar works come from the Oratory of All Souls at Burghclere, Hampshire. This gauntly awkward meeting of red-brick memorial chapel and almshouses, designed by Lionel Pearson and built between 1923 and 1927, was designed to house Spencer's canvases: his cycle of post-first world war oils depicting the psychological stresses endured by common soldiers. There is something wonderful about stepping into a Home Counties chapel and coming across England's own cut-price version of Giotto's Arena Chapel in Padua. As a student at the Slade School of Art, Spencer had been much influenced by the "primitive Italians". These are paintings of redemption, all the better for being tucked away in a cosy corner of southern England. After the postwar works come the nudes, including some fine pencil drawings made in 1931 of Spencer's first wife, Hilda. Then the naked, meaty stuff and the cycle of paintings of Christ in the streets of Spencer's home town of Cookham. By this time, Spencer felt we could all be redeemed by a kind of collective hippie love-in. So he painted a veritable orgy set in a "village in Heaven" around the Cookham War Memorial. "I am on the side of angels and dirt," he said. fields.headline: Quality childcare key to development
fields.standfirst: For every research paper that suggests working motherhood damages children, there are many more which indicate the positive effects on their social and cognitive development, argues Stephen Burke
fields.trailText: For every research paper that suggests working motherhood damages children, there are many more which indicate the positive effects on their social and cognitive development, argues Stephen Burke.
fields.body:
Questions about whether the children of mothers who work full-time during most of their pre-school years do less well at A-level and are more at risk of unemployment and stress were recently raised by research published by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. Such research did little but confuse and inflict more unwarranted guilt on parents about going back to work when most have little choice but to do so. It also casts uncalled-for aspersions on a childcare sector which continually struggles with its professional status.

This was a study of 1,236 people born in the 1970s, when times were very different. The children in this study were pre-schoolers almost thirty years ago. The terrain for working parents and the childcare options available then were quite different. Working mothers were much rarer; the range of high quality daycare that parents and children are able to access today was almost nonexistent; and our knowledge of the psychological development of under fives was scant. The number of childcare places registered in the thousands, not the hundreds of thousands that exist today. There were no early excellence centres, no OFSTED regulation, and no early learning goals that encourage the basic learning skills that we take for granted today.

For every research paper that suggests working motherhood damages children, there are many more that are often conveniently forgotten and which indicate the positive effects on the social and cognitive development of children.

Sustainable employment, be it full time or part time, is the surest route out of poverty. Parents who engage in lifelong learning are better able to support their children's learning. A mother's qualifications are the biggest single predictor of a child's success at school. Well trained women are also far more likely to get sustainable jobs that pay. Initial findings from the longitudinal British Effective Provision of Pre-School Education (EPPE) project revealed that a mother's educational qualification level showed a clear association with a child's cognitive attainments. Parents need childcare in order for them to take up work and study. High quality childcare is known to improve children's educational achievement and health. Effects are especially powerful for those children facing poverty-related disadvantages.

Quality childcare is key, particularly in the first three years of life when a child's cognitive and language development is crucial. Children in daycare settings that meet quality standards also have better language comprehension and school readiness and fewer behavioural problems than children whose daycare settings fail to meet quality standards. Good quality learning experiences have immediate, measurable gains on the cognitive and social development of young children and lead to lasting enhancement of school performance.

Quality childcare helps support broader health and wellbeing by reducing poverty and social exclusion, reducing stress and isolation, supporting parenting, encouraging an understanding of good nutrition and healthy diets, promoting physical activity and reducing child accidents.

It is time for a much more measured and responsible debate about work and family life in Britain - a debate which focuses upon the most important years of a child's life and one which doesn't cause unnecessary anxiety to the majority of parents in this country. During National Childcare Week in May, Daycare Trust will publish a new report on the benefits of quality childcare for children. The week will celebrate the growing number of childcare places, the extra help for parents on lower incomes towards the costs of childcare, and moves to improve the quality of childcare. It is time for childcare planners and providers to listen to children and parents and to deliver what they want and need.

 Stephen Burke is director of the national childcare charity Daycare Trust.

fields.headline: Dietician, Manchester
fields.standfirst:
Ray Green
Salary: £20,000
fields.trailText:
Ray Green

Salary: £20,000
fields.body:
Ten years ago I was a carpenter, when I decided to retrain for the health service. I have been a health centre dietician for six years. It was my first job in the NHS.

I work with weight-reducers, diabetics, people with raised cholesterol and people who are underweight. Half my job is educating communities on how to eat, half is visiting patients at home. I work part-time, four days a week, starting at around 8.30 and leaving at 5. I spend the fifth day with my two-year-old son, by choice. The job gives me that flexibility.

I enjoy it, I am driven by the service aspect and I don't find it stressful. There are times when I feel valued and times when I don't. Often I see patients who have already been given advice by their GPs. Sometimes it's the wrong advice, but patients take a GP's word over a dietician's because GPs are put on a pedestal.

I earn £20,000 a year. In a commercial nutrition company I would earn £26,000. There are a lot of complaints about wages in the health service. But the amount my patients earn is a pittance compared to my salary.

I would never consider the private sector. Money is not everything. I would not have the variety I have now. There would be nothing as rewarding as educating a community in how to fight obesity.

In two words, public sector work is hard work. You can't gauge how your efforts will be received. Often I won't see the benefits of my work for years.

fields.headline: Carer, Oxfordshire
fields.standfirst:
Brenda Harding
Salary: £5 an hour
fields.trailText:
Brenda Harding

Salary: £5 an hour
fields.body:
Our clients are people who can no longer look after themselves. We visit them two, three or four times a day in their own home, washing and dressing them, giving them medication and meals, comforting, reassuring. We take over from the hospital.

I have 12 clients, one of them is bedridden, some are recovering from a stroke. My oldest at the moment is 93. You must never assume you know what they want. You ask them, give them a choice, even Barbara - she can't speak, but she speaks with her eyes and her smile.

I absolutely love the work. You feed them, but they feed you back. It's the niceness about them that gives you your strength. And my colleagues in the Wychwoods are a good team, there's never any cattiness.

The advantage of it being a public service is that, if you're ill or there's an emergency, there's always back-up. We get paid £5 an hour, time-and-a-half on Saturday, double on Sunday, plus a mileage allowance.

the morning and go back and forth until I finish putting them to bed at 9 or 9.30 in the evening. I work 10 days, then have a weekend off.

If the client is on the social (has the service provided free), you don't have to rush too much. But if they're doing it privately, you worry. It limits the care they have because they can't afford more. We must get it done in that half-hour. Why can't they all have council protection?

fields.headline: Marine Surveyor, Walton-on-Thames
fields.standfirst:
Andy Rudge
Salary £36,000
fields.trailText:
Andy Rudge

Salary £36,000
fields.body:
I am the surveyor-in-charge at the Harwich marine office in Walton-on-Thames. My responsibilities include upholding all UK legislation regarding merchant shipping and domestic vessels as well as surveying. I issue certificates for UK vessels and examine UK seafarers to make sure they are competent.

I have the power of inspection, including foreign vessels - making sure they comply with international regulations. I also investigate complaints about breaches of regulations by any vessel in a port within my jurisdiction. I am very satisfied with my job and feel particularly valued. I provide an important public service.

In just one day I'll offer quite a lot of advice for the industry about all sorts of matters, from information for small craft to a company wanting to know the regulations for passenger carriage in the area. This Harwich Marine Office is located with the coastguard so we also give information about high tides and sea conditions.

In the private sector I would be paid up to £25,000 more working for a classification society. It is a lot more money, but the hours are longer and you are under more pressure.

I know marine surveyors who have gone to work for a classification society who have come back because of the stress. To be honest, I am satisfied with my pay because I am not under the same commercial constraints.

I have a disabled daughter who requires treatment at Great Ormond Street hospital. My job allows me to take time off to take her there. I have met numerous mothers and fathers at the hospital who work in the private sector and are under constant pressure to return to work. I don't get that.

I would say that I am under more stress these days, but so are a lot of civil servants, thanks to the big cuts in manpower and the increasing time constraints.

There was a shake-up five years ago in the marine sector with a 25% cut in manpower in the first year. IT and technology have helped, but the lack of manpower in the service is now recognised by the management.

fields.headline: Careers adviser, Portslade
fields.standfirst:
Mary Harper
Salary: £19,000
fields.trailText:
Mary Harper

Salary: £19,000
fields.body:
It's quite a diverse job. I'm helping young people develop their full potential and promote equal opportunities. I don't tell people what to do, I help them make their own decisions by giving them guidance and advice.

Most of the students I speak to are under 19 and are asking about courses and training. Queries about university are the most common, especially regarding financial problems. Quite often a whole range of personal and social issues can be thrown up that have a huge impact on decision-making.

Because I am providing a service and helping people, this creates a feeling of being valued and important. I'm paid £19,000 a year. I don't know how much I'd earn if I worked privately. I presume it would be more because the clients would be adults needing advice on career changes who would pay. We offer the service to students for free.

For me personally this is an adequate salary. Pay is not necessarily the most important factor. There are a whole host of issues that affect whether you're happy in a job. I could work somewhere else for more money but not enjoy the job at all.

I work an average office week - 37 hours, Monday to Friday. There's occasional evening work for parents' evenings and extra careers sessions. I don't get paid overtime for this but I get given holiday instead, which is fine with me.

fields.headline: Home carer, Age Concern, Manchester
fields.standfirst:
Catherine Coogan
Salary: £7,280
fields.trailText:
Catherine Coogan

Salary: £7,280
fields.body:
I have been a home carer for Age Concern for about eight years in all.Before that I was a wife and mother. My neighbour worked as a carer and I thought I wouldn't mind doing that. At the start I went on a three-month training course with Age Concern, but training is ongoing here, we are always getting roped into things.

Although I am not a trained nurse, nursing is something that my family does - you could say caring runs in the family. Different clients have different needs, so what I do depends on them. The age range is from 65 to 100. Some have dementia and Alzheimer's - it is not unusual for Age Concern to have to deal with people with mental health problems.

I do everything from shopping to housework, giving people baths, social visits, washing and ironing, cooking meals and putting them to bed. Two mornings a week I work at the centre, bathing people who can't bath at home. The rest of the time I go on home visits in the mornings and evenings. I finish at about 9.30pm.

I love my job, I wouldn't do it if I didn't. You get satisfaction from knowing that you are helping people and that is definitely important to me.

You do feel valued, you can tell that people appreciate what you do for them. I couldn't say how people perceive my job, but I think that the public appreciate it. Sometimes the families of the people I look after can be a bit awkward, but generally they are appreciative as well.

I work Monday to Friday, 30 hours a week. My pay is £120-£140 a week and I am happy with that. I would probably get more in the private sector, but the conditions are good and I am happy here.

fields.headline: Principal personnel advisor, Leeds
fields.standfirst:
Christina Atkinson
Salary: c.£30,000
fields.trailText:
Christina Atkinson

Salary: c.£30,000
fields.body:
Leeds council, as you may be aware, is a huge body with something like 32,000 employees. There are several departments offering a whole range of services from education, to health, and training to our residents. As a member of the personnel team my job is to try and maintain some degree of cohesion in the structure.

My job is more to do with the organisational, the policy side of the delivery. The other departments already provide the public services. We help them with strategic development. The service aspect of it is actually quite important. Mostly ours is an internal service , where we are helping the members of the council but sometimes it is an external service as well. We look at applicants for jobs.

I think my job is a worthwhile one. But do I regard it as a vocation? Times are changing. People have ceased to think of only professions like nursing or teaching as specific vocations. The whole concept is now more aligned to organisational performance. Of course whatever you do you have to be committed.

For me, choosing to work in the public sector is actually quite important. I feel I am putting something back to the system. I guess this is speaking for most of us who work in the public sector. In the private sector, the idea of service is not quite the same. Money is an important issue, it does become significant after a time. I earn in the band above £30,000 -it keeps me going and I am not unhappy.

Certainly people do not come to the public sector expecting a lot of money, if they did they would not have come. Even the people at the top of the group are not quite high earners in that sense.

fields.standfirst:
Bill Burns
Salary: £15,000
fields.trailText:
Bill Burns

Salary: £15,000
fields.body:
I've been in the job for four years in May. Before that, I worked for Scottish & Newcastle [the brewing group] doing the same thing. The main difference in the public sector is the money - about £5,000 less. But I was made redundant because S&N were bringing in contract security and this appealed to me.

Conditions otherwise are more or less the same. It's shift work - 3pm to 11pm and 7am to 3pm. We get good holidays, a pension, and the opportunity to go on plenty of courses, which is great.

There are CCTV cameras at all of our campuses and we monitor the images relayed on screens at the main security office at Craighouse campus. We keep an eye on student residences, check fire and intruder alarms regularly and deal with noise complaints from neighbours, and any cases of theft. We also deal with car parking and access control. The police prefer us to handle noise complaints ourselves - they are busy enough and they seem to think we will be more severe.

Proper security is a new thing in higher education - janitors used to do it - and I think it takes people a bit of getting used to. In a company, people expect to see uniformed security staff. In a university they might not be sure what we're there for. They might not always realise that they can come to us for assistance.

It tends to take longer to bring in changes in terms of security measures in the public sector, probably because they're not used to having this level of security. They aren't perhaps wary enough.

I do have very good job satisfaction. I speak Arabic and German because I served in the army and I know a lot of the foreign students appreciate speaking to someone in their own language if they've got a problem, so that comes in handy.

webTitle: Senior ward sister, Stepping Hill hospital, Stockport

fields.headline: Senior ward sister, Stepping Hill hospital, Stockport
fields.standfirst:
Chris Stewart
Salary: £24,500
fields.trailText:
Chris Stewart

Salary: £24,500
fields.body:
I have been the sister on ward B3 at Stepping Hill hospital in Stockport for 15 years. It's a very busy medical ward specialising in chest complaints.

I'm responsible for a team of 24 nurses. I oversee their training and development and make sure they are confident and competent. My objective is to ensure a high standard of patient care, working closely with the doctors and other disciplines - for example the physios, social workers, speech therapists, to name but a few.

I haven't worked in the private sector and I haven't a clue what I'd earn if I did. My job satisfaction is here. I love my job. I'm on the ward where I'm with the patients and the team. I see myself as their role model.

Nursing is one of the most privileged jobs in the world. I feel proud to work in this hospital. I respect the quality of care it gives. I would want my family to come here if they needed treatment.

I trained at this hospital and qualified in 1983. I got promotion as sister within two years. One of the things that helps me empathise with the team is the fact that I started at the bottom and worked my way up.

I wouldn't want to work in the private sector - waiting for the patient to ring a bell so that I can take in the silver teapot. I'm on a Nightingale ward. It's a long open ward without bays. The important thing is that patients can see the nurses all the time. In the private sector people can feel quite isolated.

I've just been on the RCN clinical leadership course. I've learned a lot that will help me put into practice lots of new ideas which will definitely improve patient care.

Working in the public sector, we are valued. These days we are given much more autonomy and we work closely with senior management. We are told when we are doing well. Perhaps we'd like that more often, but then perhaps we don't thank people ourselves as much as we should.

fields.headline: Housing standards 'too tough'
fields.trailText: The "excellence" test councils must pass if they are to access a £160m government fund to refurbish housing stock is so tough that many local authorities may not bother trying, housing professionals have warned.
fields.body:
The "excellence" test councils must pass if they are to access a £160m government fund to refurbish housing stock is so tough that many local authorities may not bother trying, housing professionals have warned.

Councils have campaigned for years to be allowed to escape the constraints of public borrowing rules. This would allow them to avoid transferring their homes to housing associations, which can borrow from the private markets.

Last year in a sop to councils the government said some local authorities would be allowed to borrow from the fund if they achieve excellent or three-star best value ratings from the housing inspectorate.

But of the 20 housing inspections so far carried out, no council has been awarded three stars.

The chief housing inspector Roy Irwin today set out proposals for the criteria for achieving excellence at the Chartered Institute of Housing in Wales conference.

The guidance explains that council housing services not only have to be excellent but need to show signs they will improve.

Speaking to SocietyGuardian.co.uk, Mr Irwin defended the criteria: "If it was easy it would have no value. It is tough but I don't think it is any way impossible."

But the Chartered Institute of Housing (CIH) warns there is a danger that money will go unspent because of the tough standards expected by the inspectors.

CIH director of policy John Perry pointed out that Harrogate and Carrick councils, which are well known in the sector for good housing services, have only achieved two-star ratings from the inspectorate.

"The danger is that people will look at Harrogate and Carrick and think if they can't achieve three stars neither can we."

He claimed that the promise of relaxed borrowing would be meaningless if no councils could achieve excellence.

The government has set aside £160m for 2002-03 in borrowing approvals as an incentive for councils to achieve excellence. The cash is regarded by many as the first step towards municipal housing achieving its holy grail of borrowing funds from the money markets.

Mr Irwin said he was confident that within the first 100 inspections at least "some" would achieve three-star ratings.

It is understood that the Mr Irwin has come under pressure from housing minister Nick Raynsford not to apply the guidance too strictly.

After successfully negotiating an agreement in principle from the Treasury for relaxed borrowing for some councils, Mr Raynsford is keen to see the policy implemented in practice.

webTitle: US groups send arms to rebels

fields.headline: US groups send arms to rebels
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in the Balkans
fields.trailText: Albanian-Americans are contributing recruits, money and weapons to the rebellion in Macedonia, believing it to be as important a struggle as the war in Kosovo two years ago, community leaders said yesterday.
fields.body:
Albanian-Americans are contributing recruits, money and weapons to the rebellion in Macedonia, believing it to be as important a struggle as the war in Kosovo two years ago, community leaders said yesterday.

The rebel National Liberation Army (NLA) published advertisements in Albanian-language newspapers in the US on Saturday, calling for volunteers and donations, and held recruitment campaigns at the weekend.

"About 20 people have gone already," Dervish Jahjaga, editor of Bota Sot, an Albanian-language newspaper in New York, said. "And if the fighting continues like this and spreads to western Macedonia, then hundreds will go .. More than went to Kosovo perhaps."

Several hundred Albanian-Americans, mostly from New York, joined the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) to fight the Serbs in 1998 and 1999. Some of the same volunteers, known as the Atlantic Brigade, are reportedly joining the NLA.

Homeland Calling, the same organisation which raised money and bought arms for the KLA, is currently performing the same function for the new group.

Members of Homeland Calling have also been browsing gun fairs, where regulations on weapons purchases are looser than in gun shops, in recent weeks.

The NLA and Homeland Calling appear convinced that Nato will not intervene against the rebels in Macedonia. In the wake of troop withdrawals from Bosnia announced last week, the insurgents believe that George Bush's administration does not have the stomach to fight its former Albanian allies.

Even if Nato were to make a concerted effort to stop arms flowing into Macedonia from Kosovo, Mr Jahjaga said, the guns would simply come across from Albania.

"There are so many ways for weapons to go across. There are very high mountains for them to go across. And everyone in Albania has weapons," he said. "Weapons are not a problem. Peace is the problem."

The New York Times yesterday reported that the NLA had succeeded in raising $500,000 (£350,000) in donations from Albanian-Americans who view the situation of the Albanian community in Macedonia as comparable to the plight of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo under Yugoslav rule.

Mr Jahjaga said reports were coming in to New York that Bulgarian paramilitary groups were intervening on the Macedonian side, aided by weapons supplies from both Greece and Bulgaria. He denied that the aim of the Albanian rebels was to partition Macedonia and create a greater Albania.

"This is a battle for equal rights," he said.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's next challenge looks to be finding a suitable boffin to replace DeAnne Julius on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee.
fields.body:
 Gordon Brown's next challenge looks to be finding a suitable boffin to replace DeAnne Julius on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee.
Julius's term expires in May and she is said by colleagues to yearn for a well-paid job in the City.
If she does decide to go, the Treasury will want another woman on the committee and the usual candidates should start polishing their CVs.
One who already fancies her chances is Diane Coyle, the economics editor at the Independent who is stepping down in May (how handy).
Predicting who Gordon will chose is fraught with danger, as this article from May 29 1997 shows: "The chancellor has made three out of the four outside appointments to the Bank of England's new monetary policy committee," it confidently began, naming David Currie, economics professor at the London Business School, and John Flemming, warden of Wadham College. Both names turned out to be wrong, the author of course being Diane Coyle. Better luck this time, eh?

 The Mobile News Awards held at the Park Lane Hilton last Thursday evening proved to be a memorable occasion for those who witnessed Michael Barrymore as guest speaker.
Barrymore's attempt to read what appeared to be extracts from Finnegans Wake did not go down with the crowd, which booed and heckled the "star".
"Don't fucking talk while I'm on stage," Barrymore shouted at one point, perhaps overcome with emotion.
Luckily, Frank Skinner arrived and took matters in hand as MC, while Barrymore looks a likely candidate for any future editions of Celebrity Big Brother.

 The awards were also not a happy event for Sir Richard Branson, who turned up with 20 Las Vegas showgirls to promote something. The organisers were wise to old Beardy's attempt to hijack someone else's parade - in this case the big four mobile operators who sponsored the event - and put a stop to it after some fierce arguments.

 It's easy to sneer (thank goodness, or this column and so many others would have nothing to write about). So I'm happy to make it clear that Robert Kiley (the London Underground czar appointed by Saint Ken) is off for a well-earned visit to the US this week, and let's hear no sneering and sniping about this being an absolutely crucial time for negotiations between LT and the Treasury over the tube's funding arrangements.

 It's a welcome return to our Dog of the Day feature, where City analysts show they are worth every penny. Today's is a special international award to Joe Rooney at Lehman Brothers. Rooney backed buying up Japanese equities, seeing "plenty of scope for improvement in profitability".
An excellent strategy, and one hardly dented by the Nikkei's 40-point fall yesterday.

 The office for national statistics is investigating how its figures showing a fall in the dole queue below 1m managed to leak out days in advance to all newspapers. As exclusively revealed here, the DfEE dished out press releases well before the official publication. Somehow the phrase "going through the motions" springs to mind.

fields.body:
In a short piece appended to a report on page 7, March 15, we referred to public attitudes towards social workers but neglected to say that these were revealed in a survey commissioned from NOP by the magazine Community Care. The campaign to restore public confidence in social workers is a joint one between the Local Government Association and Community Care.

A headline on the lead story in the Saturday Review, March 17, was stretching a point when it said that the artist Stanley Spencer visited China "just before the Cultural Revolution". Spencer visited China, as the piece said, in 1954. He died in 1959, still well before the beginning of the Cultural Revolution in 1966.

The "Macedonian" rebels referred to in a headline on page 13 yesterday - Macedonian rebels recruit and advance - were, in fact, ethnic Albanian rebels in Macedonia.

Victor Sylvester, one of the signatories of a letter about Delroy Lindo and the Metropolitan police, page 19, yesterday, was accidentally described as a member of Haringey Trades Council. In fact, he runs the Roger Sylvester Family Campaign. Haringey Trades Council was a separate signatory.

webTitle: Leader: European reform may now suffer

fields.headline: After Paris, paralysis?
fields.standfirst:
European reform may now suffer

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The second round of French local elections at the weekend produced headline victories for the left in Paris and Lyon, but equally striking - because unpredicted - success for the right elsewhere.
fields.body:
The second round of French local elections at the weekend produced headline victories for the left in Paris and Lyon, but equally striking - because unpredicted - success for the right elsewhere, as well as an interesting green turn in a number of towns. If the American presidential contest was not evidence enough, the French results show incumbents do not automatically get the benefit of the good times. France is in a fine state. Growth and job creation are up and unemployment has been falling. But for how much longer will prosperity last as the weather turns dark in the west and the far east?

To date Europe looks relatively well insulated. Most trade is "internal". Equity markets likely to be hit less hard by the collapse of the dot.coms than Wall Street. The momentum of the past few years has not yet petered out, though there are disturbing signs in Germany, which is more exposed to decline in American markets. The weakness of the euro is only an advantage if the Americans and Japanese are buying; that, however, does not look likely for a while. But policy-makers could brace economic confidence.

Survey shows the advent of the euro-in-your-purse next year is engendering optimism, at least in France. Preparing for the event might be a bigger engine of prosperity if the European central bank were not so constipated in its approach to interest rates. Or if the European Union could, collectively, engage with the agenda of market reform. As the former CBI boss, Adair Turner, pointed out yesterday, nobody with any sense now backs American-style liberalism against "Rhenish" welfare in the productivity or long-haul growth stakes. But there are problems with job creation and constraints on enterprise in Germany, France and Italy, which are recognised across the political spectrum. Breaking through them requires political leadership willing to confront vested interest. But Italy is in the throes of an election, where few contenders want to upset anyone. In Berlin Gerhard Schröder blows hot and cold. Laurent Fabius, the French finance minister, has drawn up a useful aide mémoire on business expansion with Stephen Byers. But his prime minister, Mr Jospin, may read the election as a warning. The Paris coalition's already weak commitment to structural change may now dissipate at a time when cuts in agricultural support and easement in labour markets are more necessary than ever.

webTitle: British couple fight on for internet twins

fields.headline: British couple fight on for internet twins
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The British couple battling to keep the "internet twins" will have their case heard in the high court in London next month.
fields.body:
The British couple battling to keep the "internet twins" will have their case heard in the high court in London next month.

Judith Kilshaw and her husband Alan, who claim they paid an American baby broker £8,200 in adoption fees for the nine-month-old sisters, will argue their case during a private hearing starting on April 2. At present the babies, named Belinda and Kimberley by the Kilshaws, are in the care of Flintshire social services. The authority wants them to be made wards of court.

Yesterday the couple, from Buckley, north Wales, were in defiant mood. On her arrival at a preliminary hearing at Birmingham Priory court Mrs Kilshaw said: "All we did was try to give two children a decent home."

The hearing coincided with a UK screening on Channel 5 of a showdown, on the Oprah Winfrey Show between the Kilshaws and Californian couple Richard and Vickie Allen, who also claimed they paid for the girls. The Allens later gave up their claim on the babies.

fields.body:
There have been some thrills and spills since 1995, when Inke Berth was struck by the bold adverts that sprang up all over Germany, urging citizens to buy up "the people's shares" - as Deutsche Telekom , Europe's largest telecoms operator, was privatised.

In the autumn of that year, the 35-year-old freelance camerawoman bought 60 shares in Deutsche Telekom for €14 or 28 marks. As one of the private investors the company was trying to encourage, she received a discount of 50 pfennigs per share. Then in 1997, as she watched the share price rise, and just as the Neuer Markt was taking off, Inke bought a further 60, this time for €20. After she saw the price climb further, she went for another 150 for €39 apiece.

At the beginning of last year when the shares were at €95 - just €17 below their highest value - she sold them all, bar 35 bonus shares which she was obliged to keep.

Her imagination now captured by the new equity culture, Inke bought 56 shares at €95 apiece in media group EM.TV .

Then she learned a salutary lesson, as the Neuer Markt slumped and private investors had their fingers burnt. Even now her Deutsche Telekom shares have not recovered, standing at around €29, while the EM.TV share price has slumped to €6.

She had now caught the investment bug, scouring the financial pages, watching business channels for tips, and tuning into what her media friends had to say. Last April, when most young people decided to play it safe and stick to bonds, Inke bought 25 shares in T-Online for €27. "They've fluctuated quite a bit, but I've decided to sit on them."

The decision that has excited her the most has been her July 2000 purchase of 63 shares in Cargo Lifter , which plans to use airships to revolutionise air travel from 2002.

She feels she has found her feet as a private investor, and unlike a lot of Germans has managed to escape the worst of the falling market.

"There's so much money in Germany and so many people willing to invest. You just have to look at Britain to see how well individuals can do out of it. In Germany it's been quite hard for people to get their heads around this type of gambling, as it doesn't really fit the careful German mentality."

fields.headline: Germans share in the misery
fields.standfirst: Hostile bids, privatisation, shareholder value. It's all new to the mittel class. So is the idea that prices can go down
fields.trailText: Hostile bids, privatisation, shareholder value. It's all new to the mittel class. So is the idea that prices can go down
fields.body:
Germany is hardly the only country where large sections of the population are nursing burnt fingers. In Germany, however, the lesson may prove a harsher one than elsewhere.

Germans are relatively recent recruits to the concept of wider share ownership. Bonds have traditionally been the investment vehicle of choice. It was the privatisation of Deutsche Telekom in November 1996, attracting 1.5m small investors, which prompted the change. It was a success that was to be underpinned by the spectacular success of the Neuer Markt - the Frankfurt stock exchange's answer to Nasdaq. From its launch in March 1997 Neuer Markt provided the perfect platform for companies seeking capital and investors eager to cash in on the fashion.

The rise of share ownership came at a crucial time in the development of corporate Germany. The old ways of Rhineland capitalism with its cosy links between businesses and banks, which were often shareholders too, was coming under pressure. International investors were demanding change. Corporate heavyweights, anxious to tap international markets and raise their profiles in key markets were prepared to go along. Stuttgard-based Daimler bought Detroit's Chrysler. German companies like BASF and, more recently, Siemens headed for Wall Street.

Shareholder value had become the watchword along the Rhine. The snag is that shareholder value did not sit entirely comfortably alongside the traditional German social market economic model. For many, their company was a source of employment, rather than of dividends.

The social nature or stakeholder model of German capitalism is deeply ingrained. Big companies were - and still are - at the heart of the communities where they are based. Take BASF and Bayer, two huge chemical combines. Ludwigshafen and Leverkusen, their respective bases, are dominated by their giant plants; for many in Ludwigshafen BASF is landlord as well as employer. It provides heating and waste water services to the surrounding community. Bayer even owns the football team, which plays in the German equivalent of England's premier league.

This corporatism looked doomed last year when Vodafone pushed through what was, in effect, Germany's first, successful, hostile takeover bid - for Mannesmann. The mould appeared broken, and analysts expected to follow the trail blazed by Vodafone's pinstriped chief executive Chris Gent.

The German government was prepared to be helpful. Finance minister Hans Eichel introduced reforms to sweep away the punitive taxation on capital gains realised when companies sold shares in other companies. Given that banks and insurers had often been sitting on stakes built up years before and carrying huge potential tax burdens, the move was seen - and indeed was presented in Berlin - as a way of opening the doors to widespread corporate restructuring.

As old-economy Germany was bracing itself for change the new economy was taking off, too. Companies queued up to join the Neuer Markt - more than 300 all told. Investors piled into the shares. On March 10 last year the Neuer Markt topped 8,500. But like its American cousin, Nasdaq, the Neuer Markt's bubble was about to be punctured.

Investors were waking up to the staggering values being put on companies that had yet to make money. They began to sell. The malaise spread. In Germany the Neuer Markt, with its once heady mix of fast growing hi-tech stocks, took the brunt. It now stands at less than a quarter of its all-time high. Amid the general free-fall, some stocks fell faster than others, sending regulators reaching for the rulebooks and angry investors phoning their lawyers. But while share prices were tumbling rapidly, the pace of corporate change has appeared glacial. Cynics might be forgiven for wondering whether Germany has paid anything more than lip service to the concept of shareholder value.

Restructuring turned out to be little more than a couple of failed bank mergers and rumours of deals which never saw the light of day. Construction group Philipp Holzmann could be seen as more representative of the real face of corporate Germany than the outcome of the Vodafone/Mannesmann bid battle.

Just as Vodafone was besieging Mannesmann, Holzmann rocked Germany by revealing a black hole in the accounts which threatened it with bankruptcy. Chancellor Gerhard Schröder stood firmly behind a rescue operation, persuading creditor banks to back a deal by promising state aid. Last week Holzmann warned that it had not, as expected, broken even last year but had recorded a net loss of €50m.

As for shareholder value, critics have been quick to point out that Daimler Crysler now has a market capitalisation roughly that of Daimler alone before the merger. Few US executives would expect to survive such a turn of events. Jürgen Schrempp, the architect of the deal remains at the helm of DaimlerChrysler, at least for the time being. As long as he keeps the backing of long time shareholder Deutsche Bank - which has around 15% of DaimlerChrysler shares - Mr Schrempp looks secure.

Ron Sommer, the head of Deutsche Telekom, has also been under pressure after the company's share price crash. An ongoing row about whether the company knew its property portfolio was overvalued in the balance sheet as far back as 1995 has not helped.

But the German government is the telecom group's biggest shareholder, and Berlin is still backing Mr Sommer.

So has the reformist optimism which flowered last spring withered? Not according to Alison Cottrell, at UBS Warburg. The combination of investors wanting to buy shares, companies wanting to raise cash and banks willing to sell long-held stakes means, according to Ms Cottrell, that there is a momemtum behind the process of change.

For example, take last week's results from Comdirect, a subsidiary of Commerzbank and one of Europe's largest discount stockbrokers.

The contrast between the first and last quarters of last year is marked. The number of orders per account in the first three months was just over 60 - double the average for the previous year. The figure for the final quarter was less than 25. Activity in the first quarter of this year has been similarly modest, according to Comdirect executives. In other words, investors piled into the market in the run-up to the peak and have kept faith with stocks despite the slump.

Max Dietrich Kley, the deputy chairman of BASF and president of the German institute for share promotion, points out that the benefits of the Eichel reforms have not yet come through because the reforms themselves have yet to come into effect. He argues that change is taking place, with companies aware that they have to compete internationally and that they have to match international standards. "I think everyone understands that we have to create value, not destroy it."

Nor does he believe that the roots of the nascent shareholding democracy are quite as shallow as they might appear. "When you compare the situation in the US, we don't see much difference.'

webTitle: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Now Voyager | All The President's Men | Life | Lolita | Raising Arizona | Cricket
fields.body:
Films

Now Voyager (Irving Rapper, 1942) 3.05pm, TCM
The absolute epitome of what used to be called the woman's picture. Bette Davis is depressed and repressed, Hollywood style; suave psychiatrist Claude Rains prescribes a cruise and ditching the specs so she can gaze into the eyes of handsome, unhappily married Paul Henreid on their shipboard fling. And those inspired lines: "Oh, Jerry. Don't let's ask for the moon. We have the stars..." Cue Max Steiner's soaring, sobbing, Oscar-winning music.

All The President's Men (Alan J Pakula, 1976) 8pm, Sky Cinema
How Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein traced the Watergate break-in back to President Nixon's office. William Goldman's masterly, Oscar-winning screenplay extracts all the suspense of the investigation and its riveting detail, without getting bogged down. And Pakula is in his element, showing reporters Redford and Hoffman - and Jason Robards as editor Ben Bradlee - delving into many shades of mucky dealing from their gleaming, bright-lit newspaper office.

Life (Ted Demme, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier
Eddie Murphy and Martin Lawrence are a pair of odd-couple cons locked up together for life in a Mississippi prison farm. It's a comic alternative to The Shawshank Redemption, that at times matches Darabont's sensitivity and humanity: watching the bickering pair growing old together is surprisingly moving.

Lolita (Adrian Lyne, 1997) 10.10pm, FilmFour
A fairly decent attempt to film Nabokov's indecent novel about a man's love for an under-age nymphet, and the whole emotional trauma of love. In raising the girl's age by a couple of years Lyne undermines the book's satirical intent, but he stays closer to the novel than Kubrick's 1961 version. And there are some fine performances - Jeremy Irons as the bemused and distressed Humbert; Frank Langella the shadowy Quilty, and Dominique Swain a seductive Lolita.

Raising Arizona (Joel Coen, 1986) 10.10pm, Sky Cinema
Nicolas Cage is in his element in this wild farce. He's the world's worst robber, hitching up with police woman Holly Hunter and stealing one of a set of quins when the couple prove childless. Hoving into view come old convict buddies John Goodman and William Forsythe, then the somewhat less friendly bounty hunter, the Lone Biker of the Apocalypse (Randall Cobb): a Coen brothers love-it-or-hate-it special.

Sports

Cricket 10pm & 4am Zee TV
As Australia strolled to a 16th successive victory in the first Test against India, it was difficult to see what could make this series anything but another stroll for the Aussies. Then VVS Laxman scored 281 runs as India won the second Test. Which all goes to make this third meeting a must-see. Highlights are on at 10pm before the fourth day starts at 4am.
