webTitle: Revenue bonds worked for the New York subway. And they could be the answer to the London Underground funding debacle.

fields.headline: Bonds for beginners
fields.standfirst:
Revenue bonds worked for the New York subway. And they could be the answer to the London Underground funding debacle
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Revenue bonds worked for the New York subway. And they could be the answer to the London Underground funding debacle
fields.body:
The row about who should own and control London Underground - finally to be settled this week? - goes to the heart of a constitutional issue: Treasury control versus devolution of responsibility for public services to local authorities. The Blair government's public-private partnership (PPP) for the tube has been promoted and managed from the heart of Whitehall but has not been made to work as envisaged. Surely the time has come for open-minded reconsideration of prudent, locally accountable revenue bonds. They have a proven track record and would facilitate devolution.

Labour has steadfastly refused to discuss a fall-back should the temporary privatisation of the tube fail: a miserable piece of amateur administration. High annual payments by the Treasury (or, more to the point, by the taxpayer) are now inevitable - so they ought to consider how these payments can be most effectively used.

It was always open to the government simply to carry on with state ownership and direct grants while improving on the present (government-appointed) management. Another option would have been a return to the situation when the Greater London Council ran the tube: to hand it over to Mayor Ken Livingstone and Bob Kiley as a job lot, together with some kind of promise (hard to believe and unenforcable in practice) of year-by-year cash grants. Neither of these is attractive.

The best plan is - still - to follow through the logic of devolving London' s government: hand the underground over to Kiley and Livingstone and allow the capital's elected leaders to take responsibility for its financing by issuing revenue bonds.

Bonds ought to have a great future, whatever now happens in London. A revenue bond can be issued with the security of a dedicated stream of user fees, fares, grants or taxes; it would be sold through the private capital market system and bought by the investing public, whether private or institutional. An agreed level of government grant guaranteed over specified intervals would be necessary but for most public sector investment projects it is a reasonable request. Grant guarantees were necessary in any case under the original PPP. There is now the precedent of the seven-year commitment of government grant to the train-operating companies following the privatisation of British Rail. There need be no further recourse to local or national government guarantees of repayment. The chart shows the role of bonds of this kind in paying for investment in the New York subway.

London's underground and other British transport operations produce considerable net revenues. Therefore a cash flow already exists to support the issue of revenue bonds in London and elsewhere. Outside London they could be used by the regional development agencies in projects where a revenue flow is in prospect.

Issuing a bond imposes a healthy discipline: a clearly defined and distinct legal structure which has separate accounts, transparent statements of assets and liabilities, clear and enforcable objectives, a long-term capital plan with long-term financing commitments and a degree of isolation from day to day politics for the directors. It separates good management and procurement from efficient financing.

In the US, local authorities or state governments create "public benefit corporations", allowing the public sector to retain control while separating the financing source and responsibility from the general activities of government. In the UK, a similar structure could be a trust. There are many precedents. Trusts were common in the 18th century as a means of funding and procuring local services - indeed they were the very beginnings of local government.

Trusts can be effectively scrutinised. New York state government retains a firm control of the governance and, through the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) board, the operation of public transport. MTA bonds are rated by Wall Street credit agencies and are sold in the private capital markets. The governor of New York state appoints the chair and several board members of the MTA. The mayor of New York city and officials of the suburban county governments in the region make other appointments to the board.

The MTA prepares a 20-year statement of capital needs and from this formulates a five-year plan. This must be approved by the New York state legislature which sets a cap on the maximum volume of bonds to be issued for each five-year period. On some occasions, there are state-wide referendums about issuing a bond.

Some have claimed that there were problems with bonds issued for refurbishing the New York subway. They confuse two entirely separate issues. The MTA, as a New York state government entity, has issued and repaid bonds successfully since 1982. It was New York city - a different thing - which faced difficulties back in 1975 with bond repayments.

In the UK, the Treasury would have to give general consent if this type of financing were to proceed. But the UK will need significant investment if crumbling infrastructure is to be rebuilt. Scrutiny arrange ments and the discipline demanded by bond-holders would assure the chancellor as he let go of the purse-strings. He would please the financial markets, which are hungry for good bond issues.

The squabble over the tube is simply a visible manifestation of a struggle between central and local government over how best to re-invest in the nation's capital stock. It surely cannot be right to have a handful of civil servants and ministers in Whitehall making all the decisions for the whole country. Revenue bonds, possibly subject to local referendums, offer a responsible - and local - solution. Are any parties in the market for a good manifesto idea?
 Stephen Glaister is professor of transport at Imperial College, London and Tony Travers is director of the Greater London Group at the London School of Economics

Scrutiny arrange ments and the discipline demanded by bond-holders would assure the chancellor as he let go of the purse-strings. He would please the financial markets, which are hungry for good bond issues. The squabble over the tube is simply a visible manifestation of a struggle between central and local government over how best to re-invest in the nation's capital stock. It surely cannot be right to have a handful of civil servants and ministers in Whitehall making all the decisions for the whole country. Revenue bonds, possibly subject to local referendums, offer a responsible - and local - solution. Are any parties in the market for a good manifesto idea?  Stephen Glaister is professor of transport at Imperial College, London and Tony Travers is director of the Greater London Group at the London School of Economics s.glaister@ic.ac.uk

fields.headline: Radio
fields.trailText: Sex And The Scientist | Performance On 3 | File On 4
fields.body:
After years of observing black-capped chickadees, Susan Smith discovered that females regularly "mate extra-pair with socially-dominant males". In earthier terms, they go up-market for a bit on the side. As Peter France reports in Sex And The Scientist (11.0am, Radio 4), that was a turning point in modern ornithology. Male observers had not spotted the habit because they were culturally averse to female promiscuity.

Jean Sibelius was fascinated by mythology so it's strange that he only ever wrote one opera. It's even odder that it had to wait for tonight's Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3) to get its first British airing. The single act of The Maiden In The Tower offers a highly dramatic tale of threatened love. It made its first appearance in Helsinki in 1896, with the composer on the rostrum, and seems hardly ever to have been performed since.

One of the unremarked consequences of our expanding population is that a lot more of us are dying - about 630,000 a year at present. Admittedly, some 70 per cent are cremated but that leaves 186,000 needing graves. Unfortunately we are fast running out of sites. As Jolyon Jenkins reports for File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4), planning applications for new cemeteries bring a storm of objections and few get permits. But crematoria are also under attack as atmospheric polluters, particularly from the mercury in their clients' teeth.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Nowhere to run
fields.trailText: Nowhere to run
fields.body:
Somerset

Any story concerning the local effect of foot and mouth disease is out of date as soon as written. At the school gate and the checkout, people exchange the latest word. I was told that 9am was the best time to talk to a farmer who, single-handed, keeps a dairy herd and some beef cattle.

By that time he has been up for three and a half hours, scraped the yard, fed and milked the cows nearest the farmhouse and can snatch breakfast before going two miles on the tractor to repeat the process for animals further away. He was on the telephone to Taunton. Had the suspected case at Henstridge been confirmed or cleared? His farm is within the critical 8 km radius so he cannot move stock while suspicion remains, and he needed to move eight beef animals urgently because they were almost 30 months old, after which (despite the impeccable record on their passports) they are unsaleable because of BSE regulations.

The answer was that the Henstridge case was still unproven so he could not move them. A few days later, none of the 230 cases nationally were in South Somerset. We had escaped the horrors endured elsewhere but were not unaffected. One local flock of sheep had lambed in late January. Their nursery paddock near the barn is low-lying and after heavy rainfall, waterlogged. The lambs had mud up to their bellies and some were lame but they could not be moved.

Another flock nearby was due to lamb in April on higher and drier land but an agricultural consultant had advised their owner to abandon the sheep and concentrate on holiday lets. Since then, foot and mouth has closed the countryside down and made holiday cancellations much more likely.

webTitle: Law: Marcel Berlins on fat-cat lawyers.

fields.headline: Marcel Berlins
fields.standfirst: Fat-cat lawyers are detracting from the many thousands more who do so much free work
fields.trailText: Fat-cat lawyers are detracting from the many thousands more who do so much free work.
fields.body:
I wish Jack Straw had been at the conference I took part in on Saturday. His recent outburst against lawyers (they have no social conscience and agree on only one thing, extracting money from clients) was unpleasant, but also wrong and immensely unfair. The conference united barristers and solicitors, at all levels, who give up some of their time to work pro bono (from pro bono publico - for the public good - for free). They provide the last chance of access to the law for people who have a just cause but can't afford a lawyer or get state aid. The pro bono movement doesn't get anything like the publicity that the fat-cats attract, but there are many more committed solicitors and barristers quietly doing free work and giving free advice in unglamorous parts of the country than there are greedy lawyers getting obscenely rich at taxpayers' expense.

As you know, I yield to none in my cynicism about many facets of law and lawyers. But the kind of people I met at the weekend are the genuine article, not deserving Straw-type abuse. The problem now is that the government is beginning to treat pro bono activities not, as they should be, as a last resort in addition to state-funded work, but as an easy, cheap way to fill the gaps that drastic expenditure cuts have left. The more voluntary pro bono there is, the easier it is for the government to shed its responsibilities. This is bad.

 "Send for Sydney", the familiar cry resounds wherever barristers foregather to discuss their misery. "Only Sydney can save us; without him we are doomed," is the slogan on every lip in the Temple, on every Inns of Court T-shirt.

They refer, of course, to Sir Sydney Kentridge, patron saint of all things barristerial. When several members of the bar were accused - horrors of horrors - of overcharging, who did the Bar Council get to fight for the profession in the House of Lords? When The Boss himself, Lord Irvine, was accused of sex and race discrimination over the appointment of his friend as his special adviser, who did he hire to fight his corner (successfully)? When the Bar . . . but you get the picture. The 78-year-old South African has become the all-purpose saviour. But now he faces his biggest challenge. He has been chosen to lead the Bar's forces against the evil army of the Office of Fair Trading (OFT). Brandishing the historic Sword of the Independent Profession, St Sydney's aim will be nothing less than forcing the OFT publicly to renounce its notorious Two Articles of Faith:

1. The QC system is rubbish.

2. Lots of other restrictive practices are bad.

In this awesome task he will be assisted by the universally feared warriors known as the "Bar committee considering the OFT report". It will be a fight to the finish, or at least until the government decides it has better things to do than to mix it with the lawyers.

 I'm delighted to see that the Lord Chancellor, Lord Irvine, who has not sat as a judge in the House of Lords for more than 14 months and is clearly missing the experience, has made arrangements to fill the void. He has become the visitor at University of London's Royal Holloway College. His job, according to the newsletter announcing it, is to be "the final authority to which disputes between students and the college are referred". As judicial appointments go, it's not quite what he's used to, but even lord chancellors have to take what they can get these days.

webTitle: Law: A new rape law that is barely out of the starting blocks may violate fundamental human rights.

fields.headline: Should we be shielded from the past?
fields.standfirst: A new rape law that is barely out of the starting blocks may violate fundamental human rights.  Clare Dyer on a question of questioning
fields.trailText: A new rape law that is barely out of the starting blocks may violate fundamental human rights.  Clare Dyer on a question of questioning.
fields.body:
Dozens of rape trials in England and Wales are on hold, awaiting a decision from Britain's highest court, the House of Lords. Next week the law lords will be asked to decide whether an act of parliament which came into force only last December breaches the right of men accused of rape to a fair trial.

At issue is whether a woman who claims she was raped should face questions on her past sexual experiences with the accused or other men, if his defence is that she consented on the occasion in question.

To the embarrassment of the home secretary, Jack Straw, the lords are poised to use new rights given to them last October by the Human Rights Act to make their first declaration of incompatibility - a ruling that a statute duly passed by parliament violates fundamental human rights. Lawyers for the home secretary will be in court to defend the new rape law.

Part of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act, it was pushed through parliament by Home Office ministers against vociferous opposition by lawyers in both houses. Opponents, including the former Lord Chief Justice, Lord Bingham, argued that the law, in trying to protect women, went too far and stripped defendants of the right to a fair trial. Bingham is now the senior law lord but, given his vocal objection in House of Lords debates he will no doubt consider himself disqualified from sitting on the appeal.

The law, modelled on US and Canadian "rape shield" laws, was enacted after years of lobbying by women's groups to spare alleged rape victims the ordeal of intrusive and irrelevant grilling about their sex lives. As the conviction rate for rape has plummeted, women's organisations have argued - backed up by studies in the US and Canada - that allowing defence lawyers to cross- examine the alleged victim about her sex life not only brings before the jury evidence which is irrelevant to the issue of consent, but prejudices them against her and predisposes them to acquit guilty men. As one barrister observed: "If you can portray her as a slapper, you're home and dry." Another who took part in a recent academic study of defence counsel in rape trials described his role as undermining the woman's personality.

The law lords have given a coalition of women's groups led by Justice for Women the right to intervene in the appeal by making written representations that the new law should be retained. Opponents of the law argue that it would prevent the jury from being told even that the defendant and his accuser are husband and wife. Vera Baird, QC for the women's groups, argues that background information about the relationship could be presented by agreement between prosecution and defence, as long as the jury were directed that it was irrelevant to the issue of consent.

Just how relevant is the fact that a woman consented to have sex, with this man or others, on earlier occasions, to the question of whether she consented this time? In the case which goes to the lords on Monday, a man who can be named only as Y because he still faces trial claims his accuser willingly had sex with him a week before the incident in which she says he raped her. His case came up for trial the day after the new law came into force and his counsel claimed he would be denied a fair trial if he was barred from putting that evidence before the jury. The trial judge decided that the rape shield law prevented the jury from hearing the evidence. The appeal court concluded that it would "unfairly distort the trial process" if the jury could not be told that the two had recently had consensual sex together.

The law lords must now decide whether excluding the evidence would make the trial unfair. In the not so distant past, a woman with numerous sexual partners was assumed to be untruthful. That myth has gone and a woman's sexual history is no longer considered relevant to her credibility. But a second belief still lingers: that a woman who "sleeps around", or one who had sex before with the accused, is more likely to have consented on this occasion too.

Under the new law, protested the crown court judge in the Y case, "the sexual activity of a prostitute or someone as chaste as a nun will never be known because it cannot be explored". The government introduced the new law to remove the discretion of crown court judges who were too freely allowing women to be asked irrelevant and humiliating questions about their sex lives.

Helena Kennedy QC, Labour peer, long-standing women's rights advocate and veteran of the criminal courts, supports the motive but thinks it went a little too far. "I've always been a very strong champion for reform in this area, but I think women's groups do a disservice to themselves by making the argument for a blanket ban on all questions to do with sexual history because it's just not as straightforward as that. There are occasional times when sexual history will be relevant, but finding the right formulation for that is difficult.

"There are circumstances in which the limitations are too tightly drawn because they would operate as an injustice to the accused. But the real thing we need is very good training for judges on how easily one can be drawn into unfairness in this area by allowing cross-examination which basically is about undermining the woman in the eyes of the jury."

Despite its tight restrictions, the new law includes a gaping loophole through which defence lawyers will no doubt lead their clients in droves. No questions about a woman's sexual past can be asked if the issue is whether she consented. But there is another defence to a rape charge - that the man truly believed the woman was consenting, even if she wasn't. If that is his defence, the gates are wide open to his counsel to paint the woman as a "slapper" or a "slag".

Many rape defendants run the two defences as alternatives. If the new law survives, they invariably will and the purpose of the law will be defeated. The judge would have to direct the jury that they must put the evidence of the woman's past sexual experiences aside in deciding her state of mind (did she consent?) but that they can take it into account in deciding his (did he think she was consenting?).

The appeal court thought this would force juries to try to perform impossible mental gymnastics. Anyway, said the three judges, it was "common sense" that a woman - or a man, for that matter - would be more likely to have sex willingly with a previous sexual partner than with a total stranger.

Kennedy points out: "Every defence lawyer says to their client, 'You're saying she was consenting but you might have been wrong. Are you telling me that's what you genuinely believed?' and the answer is going to be 'Yes.' It becomes a big let-out."

She thinks one answer is to add a requirement that the man's belief that the woman consented has to be reasonable in the circumstances. The Home Office sex offences review, a blueprint for reform of the whole field of sex crimes, recommends keeping the "honest belief" defence but weakening it by requiring the accused to show he took reasonable steps to ensure the woman was freely agreeing. This addition would bring our rape laws broadly into line with the rape shield law in Canada, which last year survived a human rights challenge before the country's supreme court.

At a time when rape convictions are at an all-time low, it could mean that fewer guilty men go free to strike again.

webTitle: Real Lives: Amelia Gentleman joins the Russian TV crew filming the dead bodies of victims of fires, crime, and car accidents for primetime viewing

fields.headline: TV to die for
fields.standfirst:
They prowl the streets of Moscow, filming in close-up the dead victims of fires, crime, and car accidents - and their bulletins make some of the most popular TV in Russia. Amelia Gentleman joins the Road Patrol

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: They prowl the streets of Moscow, filming in close-up the dead victims of fires, crime, and car accidents - and their bulletins make some of the most popular TV in Russia.
fields.body:
As dusk settles over Moscow, the Road Patrol team is beginning to get anxious about its failure to find any corpses. The entire day has been spent driving through the city from traffic accident to police station to domestic crisis, and the only success so far has been to catch two crumpled Ladas smashed together in a snowdrift. A slightly injured passenger has already been taken to hospital; instead the cameraman is forced to film a patch of blood-stained snow, before stamping off, muttering: "We're wasting our time. This is rubbish."

So a wave of happy relief sweeps over the team when they receive the final call of the day. A retired engineer has spent the evening lying in bed drinking vodka and smoking, setting himself and his home alight; a raging fire is consuming a central Moscow apartment block.

The team arrives just in time to film the man's burning belongings as they are hurled from a fifth-floor window that is still gushing thick smoke; blackened pages from photograph albums float through the night. Jumping over a tangle of hosepipes, the camera crew runs past the firemen and up the sealed-off stairway to where the dead engineer's widow and daughter are standing speechless over his body.

This moment is recorded for the programme, and supplemented with shots from inside the smouldering flat, lingering on a vast collection of empty vodka bottles. "He looked as though he died in his sleep," the cameraman says. "But we filmed his feet, which had burnt a little."

Outside, a group of children, no older than seven, crowd around - impressed by the team's trademark turquoise jackets. "Wow. Road Patrol," they say.

Broadcast four times a day, seven days a week, Road Patrol is one of Russia's most popular programmes - attracting viewers with its voyeuristic intrusion into the disasters that strike the capital every day. In 15-minute snatches, an assortment of murders, crash deaths and apartment infernos are flashed across the screen. Newly arrested suspects are led out from their police cells and goaded towards on-screen confessions - with a casual approach to the presumption of innocence before guilt is proven. The hysterical grief of victims is recorded. Dead bodies are shown in close-up on primetime television. This is not a show for the squeamish, but its success is immense.

The format was created in the mid-1990s by a group of shrewd television executives who had latched on to the public's growing enthusiasm for televised crime and disaster - subjects glossed over for decades by relentlessly positive Soviet news broadcasts, which were dedicated primarily to the country's agricultural and industrial successes. The show regularly tops its channel's weekly ratings and advertisers compete to have names painted beneath the red lightning arrows on the side of its reporters' cars.

The show's editor, Andrei Chereshnev, is a little defensive about its success, aware that the content is rather strong for western tastes. He insists that this is not entertainment because there is a strong moral message to the show; he claims it is designed to help people - like a horrifyingly graphic public safety warning. "The main purpose is to inform people about the dangers of drinking and driving or of drug abuse. This kind of approach is far more effective than handing out government information leaflets," he says, reclining in a black leather chair. "There is probably a small percentage of people who watch it just for the nasty pictures, but they're a minority because we're quite careful about what we show. We'd only do a close-up on a headless corpse if police wanted help in identifying it."

The reporting teams have managed to persuade themselves that the show makes people feel happy. "We cheer people up. They look at all the terrible things that are happening elsewhere in the city and cross themselves, saying, 'Thank God it wasn't me.' It helps people realise that their own lives are not so bad."

At the end the of evening dispatch, figures for the day's murders, car crashes, drunk drivers and violent attacks are listed. When the programme first appeared, viewers complained that this information heightened people's fear of crime to such an extent that they were afraid to go out. Six years later, the show rarely triggers outrage; mainstream news broadcasts have begun to include equally graphic footage of dead disaster victims. "People aren't shocked by our programme - it takes a lot to shock people here, but we realise it could never be shown in Europe or America because tastes are very different," Chereshnev says. Dozens of viewers telephone every day to tip off the programme about the location of developing catastrophes. Moscow police also ring in, happy to be filmed for the show.

No one likes to admit that Road Patrol may simply be satisfying the public's appetite for violent disaster. But in a quiet moment, the cameraman points out that the reporting teams are under immense pressure to provide an ample supply of bleeding flesh. "Sometimes people ring up complaining that there hasn't been enough blood. Ratings drop," he said. There is a lucrative market for bootleg greatest-hits videos that bring together the worst moments ever filmed.

The reporters charged with scouring the city for disaster have developed a refined brand of morgue humour to help them cope with their work. They have sinister euphemisms for the mutilated corpses they come across. A murder victim whose arms and legs have been chopped off is called a "samovar" (a reference to the torso-shaped Russian kettle); those who have simply been chopped up are referred to as "Lego"; people who have thrown themselves from the roofs of buildings are "parachutists"; those who have drowned themselves are "divers"; the travelling morgue van, with its cold-storage facilities, is called "Baskin Robbins" (after the US ice-cream company). To the uninitiated, conversation with the team is extremely bemusing.

Beneath the bleak humour, they claim to work to a strict ethical code. "We may be cynical but we have our limits. We don't like filming dead children. Yesterday we found a baby that someone had thrown into a rubbish bin in the street. We didn't film that," the presenter says. Instead the team made up their quota of material when they came across two teenage heroin addicts hanging from the ceiling of an apartment block stairway. "They'd run out of money for drugs so they killed themselves," the reporter says. Later there was an elderly woman who had slipped on the ice and fallen under a tram, so they were able to use that too, filming her greying body lying by the road, covered in a thin layer of snow. In a sombre voiceover, the presenter reported that the tram line was out of action for half an hour after the incident.

Aside from the unsatisfactory road accidents, today's most successful report is the interview with a young boy accused of stealing a leather jacket from a man in an apartment-block lift. Police remove him from the police station cage to be interviewed. After a few minutes of aggressive questioning, the reporter asks him if his mother knows he is in jail, and the boy turns his face to the wall and begins to weep. The cameraman (who would rather be filming wildlife documentaries) lingers on the boy's shuddering back before spending several minutes trying to film sunshine through the police station's barred window. Satisfied, the reporter confides later: "It looks good when they cry." A few hours later the boy's humiliation is broadcast to millions.

This is a wearying job. "I've stopped having nightmares, but I can never bring myself to watch the programme," the cameraman says. "I still can't cope with the sight of bits of brain on the pavement, or dismembered hands or feet. I hate the sound of people crying in pain, begging for help. But it's my job to film it; my brain has learned to wash away the memories."

webTitle: Charlotte Raven: On why foot and mouth won't swing it for Hague, and on Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned.

fields.headline: Charlotte Raven
fields.standfirst: Why foot and mouth won't swing it for Hague
fields.trailText: On why foot and mouth won't swing it for Hague and on Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned.
fields.body:
As the foot and mouth crisis deepens, common sense seems to suggest that it would be grotesque to go ahead with an election. Even supposing that the arguments about access and the exclusion of rural dwellers from the process prove fallacious, there is still the question of tone. According to almost everyone, holding the poll in this climate would be like holding your daughter's wedding on the same day as your father's funeral.

The juxtaposition of weeping farmers with baby-kissing parliamentary hopefuls is as difficult to picture as the face Blair would have to fashion to reconcile the competing requirements of an election and a national emergency. The rictus grin that normally comes into service on these occasions would have to be replaced by something more suitable - a slight downturn of the mouth to suggest that the nation's suffering is his suffering. Then, on top of that, he has to find a glint - just the hint of a glint - to communicate his conviction that, but for the general terribleness of everything, we'd be living in the promised land.

"If things weren't so crap, they'd be great" is not an election slogan to inflame the passions of the apathetic masses. No one is going to get up on the morning of May 3 with an overwhelming urge to pay tribute to a feelgood factor that can't be seen with the naked eye.

The question is: does this matter? Given that most people were going to vote for Blair without any real reason for doing so, it could be argued that the crisis will make no difference one way or the other. If everyone was rushing to the polls with a blood-and-guts desire to go for Labour, they might be thrown off balance by the emotional impact of the footage of ravaged farms and burning corpses. In this scenario, it wouldn't matter that no one blames Labour for what happened. The decline in the national mood would be reflected in lower turnouts and, for those who do vote, a greater sense of detachment from the party most will support.

In other words, this crisis would matter if most people weren't already reconciled to voting without really caring. It can only affect the outcome if the electorate see the ballot as a means of expressing their innermost beliefs - an old-fashioned idea of democracy that was never going to apply to this election. Whenever it is held, the result of the coming ballot will bear no relation to the real feelings of the participants. A Blair landslide, inevitable as it now is, will reveal very little about the priorities of the people who produced it. It certainly won't tell us anything about their politics. Some of them will quite like Labour, but a sizable proportion of them won't. The seeming paradox of the massive popularity of a party about which no one has a good word to say is attributable to a shift in consciousness whereby voting is no longer an expression of political will. When people go to the polls this year, they will put crosses where the crosses should be. Then they will go to the bank or wherever and fill in other meaningless bits of paper with the same absent-minded detachment they brought to the execution of their democratic right.

When voting is detached from life, it is immune to circumstances. However we feel about the state of the nation, we will still write a cheque for the phone bill and voting Labour now has the status of a low-level administrative task. The outcome of the next election would be the same if Blair declared tomorrow that the only way of curbing foot and mouth was to shoot all the farmers within a three-mile radius of infected areas. Everyone would hate him for it but that fact wouldn't stop them from trotting along to their polling stations and voting for the monster they were dissing not 10 minutes before. Such dimness can only be explained by the fact that people no longer believe that voting for a person implies some agreement with them.

This disjuncture between what voters like and who they end up supporting is normally attributed to economics. Thus, in a time of economic security, voters are prepared to overlook what disagreements they have with the present administration and vote for more Brownian magic. This would make sense if the feelgood factor were as uncomplicated as this model suggests.

In fact, many of us are feeling pretty bad. We may be better off but the money means nothing when our third-world infrastructure prevents us from living in anything like a civilised fashion. People do care about this but as long as they are voting like robots, there is no reason for the Blairites to address it. There is as much need for him to come up with a radical second-term agenda as there is for my local grocer to come up with a brand new reason why I should buy my daily pint of milk.

From Baddiel to worse

I've sometimes wondered what I'd do if, God forbid, I was ever the subject of Private Eye's parody diary. How could you carry on doing whatever you did when Craig Brown has revealed you as a shallow, self-adoring sham? My respect for the acuity of these pieces and my certainty that, if it were me, I would stop what I was doing RIGHT AWAY means that I am baffled by the sight of celebrities who don't heed this final warning. Having been "done" by Brown, they should, by rights, pick up their hats and disappear into the night. Otherwise, the sight of them going on in the manner for which they had been hauled to public account is too sad for anyone, their audiences included, to bear.

I wonder if David Baddiel and Frank Skinner ever read Brown's version of their Unplanned show. Watching their Comic Relief reprise of this astonishing format, I was inclined to think they probably hadn't. The reason I have kept so quiet while all around me are slagging off Baddiel is because I detect within him a deep-rooted sense of his own talentlessness. My resolution was broken on Friday when, after making fun of Billy Connolly's penis - ignoring the fact that the capering, naked Connolly, who exposed himself on Piccadilly Circus as his contribution to Comic Relief, probably owned the rights to that gag - he had a go at Melinda Messenger on the grounds that she was thick. No other comedian working today, not even Jasper Carrott, would have sunk so low. And no one who really thought he was clever would have a go at a page-three model for not getting enough GCSEs.

Baddiel's lack of self-belief is as palpable as his arrogant attempts to disguise it are crude and unedifying. I don't wish him ill, I just wish he would play out this drama somewhere else.

fields.headline: No 1842
fields.standfirst: Jerry Springer
fields.trailText: Jerry Springer
fields.body:
Age: 57.

Appearance: At least once a month in Pass Notes.

I thought so. You did him in February. True, but a fascinating new fact has come to light.

Go on: The Sultan of Sleaze is planning to put himself forward for a "people's peerage" for services to TV.

What service has he performed for TV? You obviously missed his seminal "My Sister Slept With My Three Husbands", the revealing "I'm Pregnant and Have to Strip", and the unforgettable "I Married a Horse."

Thank goodness it wasn't a sheep. Please, people are suffering out there.

But his shows are loathsome! Michael Parkinson certainly thought so, calling him "disgraceful, common, disgusting and revolting".

Anyway, how can he be made a peer? He's American. That's what you think. Jerry was born in Hampstead Garden Suburb in 1944. He lived in Finchley until his parents emigrated to the US in 1949. Jerry would like to style himself Lord Springer of Hampstead.

How heartwarming. Why does the Lords appeal? He loves working with dysfunctional people who wear outrageous clothes. Remember, this was the man who put the transvestite in TV.

What does he think he would bring to the Other Place? A bit of (bleep) pizzazz to the (bleep) boring debates. Peers could settle their differences with some therapeutic abuse and a spot of fisticuffs.

You haven't supplied many facts about his career. No, we may need those when we return to him next month, but think law course, politics, unfortunate episode in brothel, mayor of Cincinnati, failed bid to become governor of Ohio, award-winning newsman, king of trash TV.

Most likely to say: "This is entertainment, not a counselling service."

Least likely to say: "And was the noble and learned lord any good in the woolsack?"

fields.headline: Brewers target youthful excess
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest drink manufacturers yesterday warned that attempts to reverse Britain's bingeing culture could take a generation, as they launched the first national advertising to cut drunkenness in young people.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest drink manufacturers yesterday warned that attempts to reverse Britain's bingeing culture could take a generation, as they launched the first national advertising to cut drunkenness in young people.

They also challenged the government to use television and cinemas to try to make drunkenness as unacceptable as drink-driving, when they unveiled a £1m campaign portraying excess as a sexual turn-off, a recipe for violence and a route to depression.

The unprecedented attempt to change habits among the young follows concern that Britons are among the worst offenders in Europe.

The Portman Group, funded by manufacturers to promote "sensible drinking", estimates that more than one in six aged 18-24, or 1m young adults, regularly drink simply to get drunk. Its poster and radio campaign follows trials in Manchester last year and is expected to include hospital and GP waiting rooms as well as pubs, bars, clubs and public transport. The group will also ask fashion shops to put stickers on changing cubicle mirrors with the message "You're drop dead gorgeous - so don't drop dead drunk."

Jean Coussens, director of the group, said: "This is a tough message to get across. Occasional excesses are part of a normal learning curve. This campaign is the start of a long haul to change the image of drunkenness and the culture of excess around alcohol."

The group's members are Allied Domecq, Bacardi-Martini, Bulmers, Campbell Distillers Pernod-Ricard, Diageo, Interbrew UK, Scottish and Newcastle, and Seagram, but pub chains have also backed the campaign.

Ms Coussens said that the industry opposed drunkenness as much as any one, but one campaign was not the answer: "We would be absolutely mad if we thought this alone could change behaviour." Other partners, including the government, would have to find funds for a whole range of campaigns and for more expensive forms of advertising.

webTitle: Inside story: As an archdeacon in Zimbabwe, Peter Wagner devoted his life to helping others. Last month he was brutally murdered in his church.

fields.headline: 'My brother was a good man. Why was he killed?'
fields.standfirst:
As an archdeacon in Zimbabwe, Peter Wagner devoted his life to helping others. Last month he was brutally murdered in his church. His brother Hugh Wagner travelled to the troubled country for the funeral - and to try to uncover the truth behind a senseless killing

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: As an archdeacon in Zimbabwe, Peter Wagner devoted his life to helping others. Last month he was brutally murdered in his church. His brother  Hugh Wagner travelled to the troubled country for the funeral - and to try to uncover the truth behind a senseless killing.
fields.body:
I was at home with my family when my brother, Tim, phoned with terrible news. Our eldest brother Peter, who was an archdeacon in Zimbabwe, had been found brutally murdered in his church that afternoon - February 26. The church warden had phoned Tim with the news. I was shocked and horrified. I had not expected anything like this, despite the country's recent troubles.

Once the shock had passed, all I could think was that I needed to know more: we had only bare details. I contacted the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and the Zimbabwe high commission in London, but neither had heard anything. I then phoned the Guardian foreign desk. They said nothing had appeared on the news wires about it, and put me in contact with their correspondent in Harare, who confirmed that Peter, who was 67, had been murdered in his church.

It wasn't until Tim and I went to Zimbabwe for Peter's funeral two weeks ago that we were able to glean more details. Peter, who lived in Masvingo, 200km east of Bulawayo, had gone to his church at 5:30am as normal, to carry out early-morning offices. When he didn't turn up for an appointment that afternoon, the church wardens went to his house, and found that it had been broken into. So they searched the church, and finally, behind the door leading to the belfry, they found him. His body was already cold - he had been lying there all day. He had been bound hand and foot, and socks had been forced into his mouth. He had been beaten about the head and body, and his neck had been broken. He died of asphyxiation.

The Masvingo police arrested one man and said they had launched a "massive manhunt" for another. The second man is a former caretaker at the church who was recently released after serving a jail sentence for theft from Peter. He is also alleged to have savagely beaten two elderly white women of Peter's mainly African congregation. However, the police have since stated they have been unable to arrest him because he "is never at home when we call".

Peter had been in Zimbabwe since 1970. He had previously worked in Birmingham, but felt a calling to help people in greater need, so he went to what was then Rhodesia. After a few years, he became dean of a cathedral in Zimbabwe, and most of his parish was African rather than European. He had always cared about others, but working with people in need strengthened that tendency. On my first visit to him in 1987, people told me how he gave away his money and belongings to those in need. He gave away most of his stipend and stopped drawing it two and a half years ago, when he was 65, so it could be used for better causes within the parish. He lived on his meagre overseas pension from the UK. To say it was a frugal life would be an understatement.

Peter and I did not talk on the telephone much, but he loved to write long letters. Although he was not involved politically, he used to write a lot about his feelings towards the Zimbabwean authorities, particularly how they abused their power. He felt that way about the Rhodesian regime, and thought President Mugabe was heading in the same direction.

webTitle: East German officer guilty 42 years on

fields.headline: East German officer guilty 42 years on
fields.trailText: A former East German policeman was yesterday given a suspended prison term for killing an 18-year-old caught listening to a western radio station over four decades ago.
fields.body:
A former East German policeman was yesterday given a suspended prison term for killing an 18-year-old caught listening to a western radio station over four decades ago.

The officer, now aged 64, admitted bodily harm with fatal consequences by the Berlin state court and was handed a six-month jail term, suspended for two years.

In March 1959 the 22-year-old officer came across the teenager and his friends listening to the radio show Hits of the Week, broadcast on the American RIAS station. The station was banned by communist authorities.

The officer, identified in court simply as Rainer Sch, tried to arrest the teenager who fled. A chase through the streets of east Berlin ended when the officer shot the teenager in the back. He died three weeks later.

An investigation into the death only began in the mid-90s when the teenager's mother was asked to pick up his death certificate and argued against the claim that he had died of natural causes.

The court rejected the former policeman and retired taxi-driver's claim that he had tripped during the chase, accidentally pulling the trigger.

The judge took into consideration the officer's young age at the time of the incident, but said he had nevertheless been "a cog in the system" by carrying out orders.

People can no longer be charged with most crimes committed during four decades of communist leadership in East Germany. A statute of limitations barred prosecution after October last year, the 10th anniversary of German reunification, but serious crimes are excluded.

webTitle: Suspected serial rapist and killer in court

fields.headline: Suspected serial rapist and killer in court
fields.trailText: A man suspected of raping and killing seven young women in Paris went on trial yesterday.
fields.body:
A man suspected of raping and killing seven young women in Paris went on trial yesterday.

Guy Georges, 38, is also standing trial for four other assaults carried out during a seven-year spree of violence. He was arrested in March 1998 during a nationwide manhunt.

Between 1991 and 1997, seven young women were discovered murdered with their throats slit in eastern districts of the capital. The attacker apparently got to know his victims and talked his way into their homes before killing them.

DNA tests linked Georges to four of the killings, and he confessed to three others. His trial is expected to last several weeks, with more than 100 witnesses. The suspect risks a life sentence with no parole for 22 years.

webTitle: Mystery of Italian banker extends beyond the grave

fields.headline: Mystery of Italian banker extends beyond the grave
fields.standfirst: Secret theory as police seek stolen corpse
fields.trailText: Secret theory as police seek stolen corpse
fields.body:
Magistrates investigating the disappearance of the body of Enrico Cuccia, Italy's most famous post-war banker, have a secret theory they will not share.

Cuccia's mausoleum in the grounds of a family holiday home in Meina, overlooking Lake Maggiore, was found broken open on Friday, and on Saturday the police confirmed that his coffin was missing.

Yesterday the investigators said they were baffled but had three theories: the body was taken for extortion, by satanists, or for a motive they would not divulge.

The police believe that extortion is the most likely reason - other famous bodies have been snatched for that purpose - but the Cuccia family deny having received a ransom demand.

Yesterday an anonymous caller to the ANSA news agency claimed responsibility on behalf of a group called Revolutionary Unemployed.

Fabrizio Argentieri, the prosecutor in charge, dismissed the claim as absurd. But he admitted that there were few solid clues, and added: "We could be proved wrong in the future if we neglected any lead."

Cuccia died last year aged 92. He was the founder of Mediobanca, Italy's first merchant bank, and for half a century the country's key financial deal-maker and guardian of the control-room of Italian family capitalism.

Famously tight-lipped, he would have been horrified to think he might become the centre of a public scandal after death.

One theory being considered is that the thieves were looking for secret documents concealed in the coffin.

Cuccia's passion for secrecy gave rise to the notion that he was a leading figure in an elite mystical gnostic conspiracy, and that has provided yet another theory about the theft.

On Sunday investigators questioned Mediobanca's chief executive officer, Vittorio Maranghi, for about three hours, hoping for something that might throw a light on the mystery.

A close associate of Cuccia's, the Republican party leader Giorgio La Malfa, said he was deeply perplexed but suggested that it might be the work of an eccentric political group.

"The mystery seems thicker than ever," he said.

The police have not ruled out the possible involvement of satanists, who could have stolen the cadaver for use in occult rites.

Two years ago three people alleged to belong to an organisation known as the Children of Satan were arrested in the neighbouring village of Invorio as they tried to smuggle the body of a friend out of the cemetery.

But this would not be the first time that an illustrious corpse has been seized for ransom. In 1978 the body of Charlie Chaplin was stolen from its grave near Lake Geneva.

Those responsible were arrested two months later and the body recovered.

The bodies of the industrialist Serafino Ferruzzi and Raffaele Bagni, the son of a leading Italian footballer, who died in a road accident at the age of three, were stolen too. In neither of those cases was the body recovered.

Even the corpse of Benito Mussolini went missing from its grave in Milan for more than a decade, although in that instance the kidnappers were a group of the Duce's political admirers.

webTitle: Amniocentesis test led to E coli death

fields.headline: Amniocentesis test led to E coli death
fields.trailText: A woman died after she contracted the E coli bug during an amniocentesis test, an inquest was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman died after she contracted the E coli bug during an amniocentesis test, an inquest was told yesterday.

Jane McCarthy, 33, who was four months pregnant, was only the fifth woman worldwide to be infected by the bacterium during the procedure - which screens for genetic disorders such as Down's syndrome - and only the second to die, Warrington coroner's court in Cheshire heard.

Gynaecologist Michael McCormack, called as an expert witness, said it was likely the E coli had got into her abdomen when the needle accidentally perforated her bowel, or possibly when it pierced the amniotic sac.

Ezzat Kozman, consultant in obstetrics and gynaecology at Warrington general hospital, told the court he had tried to do the test twice on May 31 last year, but there was an unusually small amount of amniotic fluid and one of the samples was blood stained. He abandoned the procedure and advised Mrs McCarthy to return for a check up in five days.

Three hours later Mrs McCarthy, of Great Sankey, was admitted to casualty with what she described as labour pains.

Her husband, Paul, 33, who has a son, said his wife was given no blood tests and was sent away with paracetamol. Next day she was readmitted and septic shock was diagnosed.

Blood tests showed the E coli was taking hold. She began to miscarry late on June 2. Early next morning she had a heart attack and was resuscitated. After finding fluid in her abdomen, doctors decided to operate, but she died in theatre.

Cheshire coroner Nicholas Rheinberg concluded that Mrs McCarthy died from a cardiac arrest caused by septic shock, which in turn was caused by the amniocentesis procedure. He recorded a verdict of misadventure.
Press Association

webTitle: Arts: Air's debut album was one of the biggest hits of 1998. But can they do it again?

fields.headline: 'Music is a god. We want to please the god'
fields.standfirst: Air's debut album was one of the biggest hits of 1998. But can they do it again? They talk to  Kevin Braddock
fields.trailText: Air's debut album was one of the biggest hits of 1998. But can they do it again? They talk to Kevin Braddock.
fields.body:
Nicolas Godin appears in the sombre, wood-panelled bar of Paris's Htel Lutèce, a scarf suspended from his dark ginger mop down past his faded Levi's. One half of Air, France's best-selling music exports, he cuts an instantly forgettable figure, more man at bus stop than million-selling pop star. Then Jean-Benot Dunckel, the other half of Air, arrives in an overlong white leather biker jacket, tricky fringe falling across his elfin features. JB sits down with a twinkly smile, apologising for the sunshine and blue sky outside.

There is some disquiet in the Air today. JB and Nicolas haven't done an interview for two years. Now, with their new album 10,000Hz Legend in the can, they are finding that encapsulating the essence of their music is as easy as bottling fog. Take the track How Does It Make You Feel, a lyrical declaration of love articulated in a husky computer voice so full of feeling, the only reasonable response is tears. "C'est pas de la merde," JB concedes, almost grudgingly. "It's not shit."

Three years after Air's first album, Moon Safari, it's clear that the band's relationship with their capricious muse has matured: 10,000Hz Legend demonstrates the same deepening and broadening, not to mention the off-into-the-audio-cosmos adventuring, that makes Daft Punk's Discovery so diverting. Compared with 10,000Hz Legend, Moon Safari was just Air going through their Westlife phase. Heavier, darker, sillier and more haunting, the new album dips into oceans of blues, rockets off aboard celestial choirs, settles down into genteel guitar musings, shudders with rickety bassline generators and ex presses a hugeness of feeling in 56 varieties of robo-voice.

The first single will be Radio Number One, a meditation on the power of FM rendered in the effusive hi-fi sheen of the Beatles' Revolution. It features the lyrics: "If you need some fun/ Some new stereo gum/ Radio Number One/ Brand new ears at once/ Eject musical trash." Brilliantly, the voice of a radio DJ descends from nowhere two thirds of the way through, begins scatting around the melody, then proceeds to introduce the traffic report followed by the weather.

What do you define as "musical trash"?

"A lot of music is horrible," Nicolas offers. "By making this music, we eject musical trash and make brand new music. This is a manifesto against the international karaoke. The music you hear every day on the radio, the industrial phenomenon of music."

And that's as certain as it gets, although the band do suggest that 10,000Hz Legend is like "a tree", or possibly the Millennium Dome's Body Zone. "You go in . . . it's all craziness," Nicolas explains, windmilling his arms across his torso. It's also like "a book", adds JB, the more intense of the pair, "with many well-built songs. We wanted the listener to understand that the album is extreme, with no limit in imagination. The concept is unconscious," he stipulates. "I mean, it's in the words 10,000Hz Legend."

What is the concept?

JB: "Aaah . . . we don't know yet."

Nicolas: "We are looking for it. In fact, there is no explanation for a lot of things. It's just, go in the studio and record . . . you don't stop."

"For 10,000Hz Legend we wanted to change the sound for two reasons," explains JB. "One, if you don't change, you will die as artists. Two, we consider that the music is a sort of god, and a god who always knows what is your will and purpose. Music is an offering: if you always give the same thing, he won't protect you. We want to please the god. We can't lie."

Thankfully, Air's music has never needed much explaining. If they never made another record, these 30-year-olds would probably be granted immortality alongside Burt Bacharach, Lennon and McCartney and Brian Wilson as musicians who articulated the sound of love, loneliness and longing. They had the ambition and talent to reach beyond the lazy strictures of trip-hop, loungecore or any other micro-genre they at first appeared to inhabit.

In the mid-1990s, just before they formed Air (in 1995), Nicolas was an architecture student and JB a maths teacher. But they were committed to the idea of music like most people are committed to the idea of breathing. JB took lessons at the Paris Conservatoire, and practised rigorous piano études every day. It was - and remains, apparently - "a sexual need" of his.

The road to Moon Safari began five years ago. Initially, Air made the trip across the Channel under the guise of trip-hop producers. Their first release, on the Mo'Wax label, was Modular Mix, an instrumental dream built on woozy analogue washes that recalled the experimentalism of Jean-Jacques Perrey, Pierre Henry and Claude Denjean, dance music's in-vogue sound at the time. Then their Casanova 70 single, released by French label Source, aroused attention beyond the dancefloors with an arrestingly beautiful euphonium line. While fellow Parisians Daft Punk were busily redefining dance music, Air were fusing evocative cinematica, artisan songwriting and easy-listening instrumentation - but not kitsch.

When Moon Safari arrived, it was voted a classic. The 1970s retro sophistication in which Air came packaged - Mike Mills's dreamlike video for Kelly Watch the Stars and the album cover's watercolour line drawings - was only the start of the let's-just-lounge aesthetic. Moon Safari opened a portal to somewhere sunnier, happier and less cynical: their own youth. With the faint homoeroticism of the gurgly Sexy Boy on one side, the taut, opiated All I Need on the other, Moon Safari was instant yet nebulously cinematic; unconstrained by the pop song format, but irresistibly poppy.

And the name seemed so correct for the bluesy, full-of-wonder sweep they conjured from obsolete synths, rudely basic acoustic guitars and crackly old studio technology. While Daft Punk's terse filter disco stomped its way onto the dancefloor, Air floated up to the stars and somewhere beyond.

After Moon Safari came Air's soundtrack to Sofia Coppola's The Virgin Suicides, its subtle melancholia a perfect match for the doomed youth of the film's subjects. It was "a try, a chance to try things", says Nicolas. "For a film, you look at the images and it tells you what to do. For an album, you start from nothing."

For 10,000Hz Legend, that nothing commenced early last year and lasted six months. When making the tracks, the band bypassed the standard procedure of making demos, the rough audio sketches recorded onto tape, later to be adjusted and fleshed out into full songs. They spent time in LA and found a new studio in Paris, away from their native Versailles. "We just need a place to be," Nicolas insists. "We can record anywhere, in any studio." There were five months of recording, and then a final month, they explain, just to spend a few more of the record company's francs.

Much of the time was spent in company: the duo marshalled an assembly of players united by the conviction that they didn't want to make "70s kitsch music". Joining drummer Brian Retzel, Beck's bassist Justin Meldal-Johnsen and guitarist Roger Manning, then, were the "crazy people" - Beck among them - instructed to dance, sing, hit things and generally make a fuss awaiting the arrival of The Music.

"We wanted to make a sort of big band on the album, like a crazy people being all together," Nicolas says. "We wanted to increase the family of Air. And Air is more soul and spirit, a concept of music. It's not about the people who were on the album."

All this was in preparation for a creative constipation that never actually occurred. Air share the conviction that music is lightning, and they are merely the conduit - which can be difficult when there are release schedules to meet. "We don't know where it comes from," says JB. "That's why it's very scary . . . "

"We arrived in the studio to do some improvisation and this is what came out," Nicolas adds. "We are just a box to receive the idea."

And when the music spoke, they became electronic performers, spinning the vocoded voices on Moon Safari into a new cast of robo-dialects. For an album packed with songs, JB and Nicolas's voices are scarcely ever there to hear, instead buried in deep-pile harmonic arrangements percolated through modulating effects.

What's wrong with their own voices? "Nothing. It's just . . . pudeur [modesty]," Nicolas shrugs. "Since the start, we used electronic voice in an emotional way, not a cold way. This is the trademark of Air. When we started using vocoder four years ago, it was like angels' voices, not robots'. We use machines to play human voices. Because we prefer to go out dressed than naked."

It's only as something other than themselves - respectable, well-educated chaps from a posh neighbourhood of Paris - that Air now feel able to operate. It works best that way, JB explains, because, "when you play the keyboard, you feel the currents going into the keyboard and all the messages it sends through MIDI cables. It's coming into your mind and you are part of the machine and the studio and you feel good."

Nicolas chips in: "Now my favourite musical instrument is electricity." For a moment he appears to mean it. But this time around, you suspect Air are not taking their own seriousness very seriously.

"I think most bands in France don't take themselves too seriously. Music is just fun," grins Nicolas. "You know, we have always been Monty Python fans . . . "

 This feature is taken from the April 2001 issue of The Face magazine, on sale now.

Heavier, darker, sillier and more haunting, the new album dips into oceans of blues, rockets off aboard celestial choirs, settles down into genteel guitar musings, shudders with rickety bassline generators and ex presses a hugeness of feeling in 56 varieties of robo-voice. The first single will be Radio Number One, a meditation on the power of FM rendered in the effusive hi-fi sheen of the Beatles' Revolution. It features the lyrics: "If you need some fun/ Some new stereo gum/ Radio Number One/ Brand new ears at once/ Eject musical trash." Brilliantly, the voice of a radio DJ descends from nowhere two thirds of the way through, begins scatting around the melody, then proceeds to introduce the traffic report followed by the weather. What do you define as "musical trash"? "A lot of music is horrible," Nicolas offers. "By making this music, we eject musical trash and make brand new music. This is a manifesto against the international karaoke. The music you hear every day on the radio, the industrial phenomenon of music." And that's as certain as it gets, although the band do suggest that 10,000Hz Legend is like "a tree", or possibly the Millennium Dome's Body Zone. "You go in . . . it's all craziness," Nicolas explains, windmilling his arms across his torso. It's also like "a book", adds JB, the more intense of the pair, "with many well-built songs. We wanted the listener to understand that the album is extreme, with no limit in imagination. The concept is unconscious," he stipulates. "I mean, it's in the words 10,000Hz Legend." What is the concept? JB: "Aaah . . . we don't know yet." Nicolas: "We are looking for it. In fact, there is no explanation for a lot of things. It's just, go in the studio and record . . . you don't stop." "For 10,000Hz Legend we wanted to change the sound for two reasons," explains JB. "One, if you don't change, you will die as artists. Two, we consider that the music is a sort of god, and a god who always knows what is your will and purpose. Music is an offering: if you always give the same thing, he won't protect you. We want to please the god. We can't lie." Thankfully, Air's music has never needed much explaining. If they never made another record, these 30-year-olds would probably be granted immortality alongside Burt Bacharach, Lennon and McCartney and Brian Wilson as musicians who articulated the sound of love, loneliness and longing. They had the ambition and talent to reach beyond the lazy strictures of trip-hop, loungecore or any other micro-genre they at first appeared to inhabit. In the mid-1990s, just before they formed Air (in 1995), Nicolas was an architecture student and JB a maths teacher. But they were committed to the idea of music like most people are committed to the idea of breathing. JB took lessons at the Paris Conservatoire, and practised rigorous piano études every day. It was - and remains, apparently - "a sexual need" of his. The road to Moon Safari began five years ago. Initially, Air made the trip across the Channel under the guise of trip-hop producers. Their first release, on the Mo'Wax label, was Modular Mix, an instrumental dream built on woozy analogue washes that recalled the experimentalism of Jean-Jacques Perrey, Pierre Henry and Claude Denjean, dance music's in-vogue sound at the time. Then their Casanova 70 single, released by French label Source, aroused attention beyond the dancefloors with an arrestingly beautiful euphonium line. While fellow Parisians Daft Punk were busily redefining dance music, Air were fusing evocative cinematica, artisan songwriting and easy-listening instrumentation - but not kitsch. When Moon Safari arrived, it was voted a classic. The 1970s retro sophistication in which Air came packaged - Mike Mills's dreamlike video for Kelly Watch the Stars and the album cover's watercolour line drawings - was only the start of the let's-just-lounge aesthetic. Moon Safari opened a portal to somewhere sunnier, happier and less cynical: their own youth. With the faint homoeroticism of the gurgly Sexy Boy on one side, the taut, opiated All I Need on the other, Moon Safari was instant yet nebulously cinematic; unconstrained by the pop song format, but irresistibly poppy. And the name seemed so correct for the bluesy, full-of-wonder sweep they conjured from obsolete synths, rudely basic acoustic guitars and crackly old studio technology. While Daft Punk's terse filter disco stomped its way onto the dancefloor, Air floated up to the stars and somewhere beyond. After Moon Safari came Air's soundtrack to Sofia Coppola's The Virgin Suicides, its subtle melancholia a perfect match for the doomed youth of the film's subjects. It was "a try, a chance to try things", says Nicolas. "For a film, you look at the images and it tells you what to do. For an album, you start from nothing." For 10,000Hz Legend, that nothing commenced early last year and lasted six months. When making the tracks, the band bypassed the standard procedure of making demos, the rough audio sketches recorded onto tape, later to be adjusted and fleshed out into full songs. They spent time in LA and found a new studio in Paris, away from their native Versailles. "We just need a place to be," Nicolas insists. "We can record anywhere, in any studio." There were five months of recording, and then a final month, they explain, just to spend a few more of the record company's francs. Much of the time was spent in company: the duo marshalled an assembly of players united by the conviction that they didn't want to make "70s kitsch music". Joining drummer Brian Retzel, Beck's bassist Justin Meldal-Johnsen and guitarist Roger Manning, then, were the "crazy people" - Beck among them - instructed to dance, sing, hit things and generally make a fuss awaiting the arrival of The Music. "We wanted to make a sort of big band on the album, like a crazy people being all together," Nicolas says. "We wanted to increase the family of Air. And Air is more soul and spirit, a concept of music. It's not about the people who were on the album." All this was in preparation for a creative constipation that never actually occurred. Air share the conviction that music is lightning, and they are merely the conduit - which can be difficult when there are release schedules to meet. "We don't know where it comes from," says JB. "That's why it's very scary . . . " "We arrived in the studio to do some improvisation and this is what came out," Nicolas adds. "We are just a box to receive the idea." And when the music spoke, they became electronic performers, spinning the vocoded voices on Moon Safari into a new cast of robo-dialects. For an album packed with songs, JB and Nicolas's voices are scarcely ever there to hear, instead buried in deep-pile harmonic arrangements percolated through modulating effects. What's wrong with their own voices? "Nothing. It's just . . . pudeur [modesty]," Nicolas shrugs. "Since the start, we used electronic voice in an emotional way, not a cold way. This is the trademark of Air. When we started using vocoder four years ago, it was like angels' voices, not robots'. We use machines to play human voices. Because we prefer to go out dressed than naked." It's only as something other than themselves - respectable, well-educated chaps from a posh neighbourhood of Paris - that Air now feel able to operate. It works best that way, JB explains, because, "when you play the keyboard, you feel the currents going into the keyboard and all the messages it sends through MIDI cables. It's coming into your mind and you are part of the machine and the studio and you feel good." Nicolas chips in: "Now my favourite musical instrument is electricity." For a moment he appears to mean it. But this time around, you suspect Air are not taking their own seriousness very seriously. "I think most bands in France don't take themselves too seriously. Music is just fun," grins Nicolas. "You know, we have always been Monty Python fans . . . "  This feature is taken from the April 2001 issue of The Face magazine, on sale now.

fields.headline: Expert witness's work 'deficient'
fields.standfirst: Cloud over work of expert witness
fields.trailText: An experienced forensic pathologist who has been involved in several high profile cases was yesterday accused of botching a string of postmortem examinations.
fields.body:
An experienced forensic pathologist who has been involved in several high profile cases was yesterday accused of botching a string of postmortem examinations.

A professional standards committee called for Paula Lannas to be removed from the register of approved forensic pathologists used by the police and coroners to look into suspicious deaths.

Members of the disciplinary tribunal which will decide Dr Lannas's fate were told that in four cases which were examined, the way her evidence was presented to the police and the crown prosecution service "significantly affected the subsequent course of events".

One case which caused particular concern was a postmortem examination carried out on a baby who it was believed had been murdered. So "suspect" were her conclusions that the prosecution had to tell the jury that it could not rely on her evidence.

The tribunal is being watched by at least one legal team representing a person convicted after a trial in which Dr Lannas gave evidence.

Since 1990 Dr Lannas, who qualified as a doctor in 1974, has performed more than 7,300 autopsies, including almost 400 suspicious deaths.

She has been involved in cases including that of Leah Betts, who died after taking an ecstasy tablet on her 18th birthday in 1995, and Joy Gardner, who died in 1993 after police tried to arrest her for deportation.

However, the names of the deceased in the cases which are being considered by the Home Office's policy advisory board for forensic pathology disciplinary tribunal are not being revealed.

The quality of Dr Lannas's work came under scrutiny during a routine audit in 1996. The board's quality assurance and scientific standards committee began to investigate and learned that two Essex coroners, including Dr Malcolm Weir who oversaw the Leah Betts inquest, had stopped her performing autopsies in their areas.

In three cases involving deaths in Essex, said Nicola Davies QC, for the standards committee, Dr Lannas failed to carry out a "vital aspect of the autopsy". In one, for example, she did not dissect the face though a police officer had told her that it was possible the deceased had been assaulted. A subsequent autopsy revealed a recent bruise.

Turning to the autopsy on the baby, Ms Davies said it "fell woefully short of the requisite standards". Though Ms Davies did not give details of the case, it is known that during a trial at the Old Bailey, Home Office pathologist Iain West described the way the baby's neck was dissected as "cack-handed".

A jury at the Old Bailey took only 30 minutes to clear the defendant, who was accused of murdering the 16-month-old child, his girlfriend's son.

Ms Davies said Dr Lannas's pathology work "consistently fell substantially short" of the standards expected of advisory board members. There were "substantive deficiencies" in her technical approach and medical knowledge.

The "sheer number and nature of the professional deficiencies alleged" led to the conclusion that Dr Lannas's accreditation should be terminated or suspended.

Before the hearing a spokesperson for Dr Lannas said she maintained that throughout her career she had acted properly and professionally. She was "confident" that her work would stand up to rigorous inspection.

Dr Lannas has worked in forensic medicine in the UK since 1980, having moved from Zimbabwe where she was a government pathologist.

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: After Kevin Costner's shock announcement over the weekend that the Princess of Wales had talks with him about appearing in a sequel to his hit movie The Bodyguard, Sidelines has a royal exclusive of its own.
fields.body:
After Kevin Costner's shock announcement over the weekend that the Princess of Wales had talks with him about appearing in a sequel to his hit movie The Bodyguard, Sidelines has a royal exclusive of its own. We can reveal that, following months of secret negotiations with the Palace, Her Madge's corgi will be appearing regularly in this column, offering a quirky take on women's issues and small mammal news around the world.

A corgi writes: "Those billboard adverts for the new film of Bridget Jones's Diary have been getting right on my tits. Renée Zellweger, all pink and pouty, is shot from above, thus affording maximum plumped-up thigh and cleavage effect. 'Look, fat English girls!' the shot seems to say. 'Here's that thin actress who put on POUNDS (and moaned about it) in order to allow you maximum empathy, since you're fat English girls! That'll be £6, please.' Ruff."

A corgi writes further: "An internet advertisement for models to appear in adult films received more than 50,000 hits before it was removed from the Reed recruitment website last week. Hardly surprising considering it was offering £45,000pa for a three-day week, which is certainly more than your average pet can hope to earn. While a few ethical concerns militate against my wholesale embracing of the sex industry, I am currently considering posing for a nude calendar, along with my women's page colleagues, discreetly placed badgers and newsprint covering our sensitive parts. One dilemma taxes me, though: should I shave?"

A corgi concludes: "I am disturbed to learn the Argentinians believe eating cats stimulates potency. Make a swift note to self to share this information with as many feline friends as possible, ideally accompanied by some frightening photographs of cats in cages."
