webTitle: Glove story: Kate Sekules on women who box.

fields.headline: Glove story
fields.standfirst: They are seen as a freak show, unnatural and unfeminine. But is that the whole picture? As the row about women in the ring rumbles on,  Kate Sekules fights their corner
fields.trailText: They are seen as a freak show, unnatural and unfeminine. But is that the whole picture? As the row about women in the ring rumbles on,  Kate Sekules fights their corner.
fields.body:
"Now touch gloves, go to your corners and come out fighting. Good luck, ladies." We tap fists. I look up at her. She looks terrified. Good. I'm in sensory overdrive - blinding lights, wolf whistles, heart thumping - but only the skyscraper girl is in focus. She is "Raging Belle", six foot three, six wins, three by way of knockout. I should be the scared one - it's my first time and she's got two weight classes on me - but I've spent two petrified weeks stalked by malevolent raging butterflies. I'm done with nerves.

I take my corner, my trainer hisses our simple plan one last time: "Throw the first punch, Kadie, big right hand. Knock her thoughts out!" He slips off my robe, slides in my mouthguard, whips out the stool and DING! In 12 minutes, 1,500 Philadelphia fight fans will be female boxing converts.

Back then, in 1997, I didn't intend to write a book about boxing. Although I am a writer, I wasn't doing this for the material. What I was doing in gloves in a ring, beating up a giantess (and me a nice middle-class feminist from Holland Park), was what came to interest me as much as the sport itself. What happens when you transpose generic female motivations and confusions into the boxing ring - that was the stuff of a book.

Exhausted and bleeding in shorts, earning roars of approval for violence, how feminine is that? How feminist? Have gender roles warped out of all recognition, or are the thousands of women who now box all freaks? Or perhaps, as many people in England believe, boxing itself is a freak sport which is dangerous and barbaric and should be banned. Being pacific by nature, I tended toward that opinion myself until I came to understand what goes on behind a boxer's eyes. But when a boxer has breasts, what difference does it make, exactly?

In America, where I live, attitudes to female boxing veer wildly between adulation, scorn and terror, but the sport does exist in the public awareness. In Britain there's a bit further to go before anyone takes it for granted that women can and should box. The British Medical Association, of course, hates it: "a demented extension of equal opportunities" was what it called British welterweight Jane Couch's victory at industrial tribunal which won her a licence to box at home.

To me, the undoubted dangers of boxing are a side issue, though, and a convenient platform from which to defend the status quo. It's the sheer nakedness of boxing that really bothers us and it's what drew me to it.

The boxer is the most masculine of archetypes. I, though a big, rather muscly person who looks stupid in a leotard, still found it tough to convert my self-image into the figure of a convincing pugilist. There were hardly any other women there then, back in 1993, so I used men as models. Then more women trickled in. We were mirrors for each other, prototypes. Every permutation of womankind began to troop through Gleason's gym, some to fight, most just to train.

The pace in New York picked up in 1995, when the premier amateur tournament, the Golden Gloves, started a female division, which 40 women entered. What drew them - and me - was that it seemed iconoclastic to be boxing, that it was fun to be a pioneer, that it looked cool, that it was empowering. But boxing touches more subtle places, too. Matters such as what to do with anger, how to be vulnerable yet protected, open-hearted but no fool, aggressive and still kind.

I also found in the boxing gym relief from annoying, tenacious self-loathing in the body department, for lots of reasons, including the fact that there, instead of fighting your weight, you fight at your weight.

Boxing-training can make a girl confront femininity issues, but it's fighting where the paradoxes really start flying. I find sparring, or practice-fighting, with men easy. I have no doubt a man can take my hardest punch. Sparring with women, however, brings up a quasi-feminist quandary that's very uncomfortable. When I first sparred with a woman of equal standard and weight, it felt unnatural to fight her. I was stuck between my burgeoning boxer nature and the role I assume in the world, in which I strive to be kind and want everyone to feel good.

The internal battle that ensued would always cancel out the real one. But eventually I got over it by simply not thinking - which is rudimentary sports psychology, I guess, but which has a parallel outside the ring. I think women do this too much: worry about what the other is feeling instead of standing up for what we want. We're supposed to dislike confrontation, but boxing taught me how nice, how clean, confrontation can be.

Once I got over the frankly insulting impulse to let the other girl win, I found sparring incredibly bonding. You're letting each other violate certain civilised principles we live by, then punishing each other for doing so - instant karma. And boxing releases the pressure of bottled-up fury. I can understand now why men pick fights.

When my book came out in the US, several interviewers posited that the humanity would leak out of a world in which women fighters were commonplace - an attitude I expect to find in Britain, too. This is absurd. Training to box requires such discipline and energy that (Tyson notwithstanding) there's no viciousness left over to spill into the world.

Last year, Muhammad Ali's youngest, Laila, decided to take up her dad's profession, followed by Joe Frazier's daughter Jacqui. In June they will fight each other, a prospect Laila told me she finds ridiculous, though inevitable. She is training right, she is talented and she is all too aware that she can single-handedly kill or cure women's professional boxing.

In the amateur corner, the seventh women's New York Golden Gloves finals take place this month at Madison Square Garden, followed this summer by the first women's internationals on American soil. Athens hosts the 2004 Olympics, where there's a slim chance women will box. It's obvious that there's a split decision from all the judges on where women's boxing is going.

As for me, I quit competition because I lacked the one thing you can't fight without: the overriding need to prevail in the ring. Plenty of women do have this. To date, I am the only retired professional, the Ancient Mariner of the locker room, fighting the compulsion to waylay women and relate my tale at enormous length. Instead, I wrote the book.

 The Boxer's Heart by Kate Sekules is published by Aurum on March 22 at £12.99.

fields.headline: What's not on
fields.standfirst: Trafalgar Square must wait for Whiteread's upturned plinth
fields.trailText: Trafalgar Square must wait for Whiteread's upturned plinth
fields.body:
For some it is the acme of New Age art, for others it belongs in a Glastonbury gift shop. But love it or loathe it, Londoners are going to have to live a while longer with Regardless of History, Bill Woodrow's huge sculpture of a book tangled in the roots of a tree, in Trafalgar Square.

For Rachel Whiteread's long awaited upturned replica of the square's "empty" plinth will not be mounted for some months yet. The Turner prize winner's work was meant to have replaced Woodrow's sculpture last October but is still in her studio.

The translucent sculpture, mirroring the base beneath it, was a typically eerie Whiteread idea, but transferring her creation from page to plinth has proved tricky indeed.

The Royal Society of Arts, which commissioned the piece in its programme to put a new contemporary work on the plinth every six months, said making a 14ft high mass of see-through resin that did not fall in on itself had "severely tested" plastics specialists throughout Europe and the US.

"This is cutting-edge stuff," a spokesman said. "It is not at all as straightforward as it sounds. This is an example of art challenging and advancing technology."

The RSA predicted before Christmas that despite the difficulties it would be in place by March, but yesterday it conceded that it would be summer before the sculpture, paid for out of a £500,000 lottery backed fund, was unveiled.

A spokeswoman at Anthony d'Offay, Whiteread's gallery, said: "The problem with the resin has been solved. We can absolutely assure you that it will be in place early in June; it is just a matter now of confirming the exact date."

The delay is yet another twist in the pantomine of the Trafalgar Square plinths.

fields.headline: Hope of pardon over 1969 murder
fields.standfirst: Appeal hearing may clear names of men convicted of PO killing
fields.trailText: One of the country's most contentious miscarriages of justice cases was referred to the appeal court yesterday, raising hopes that posthumous pardons will be awarded two men convicted of murder.
fields.body:
One of the country's most contentious miscarriages of justice cases was referred to the appeal court yesterday, raising hopes that posthumous pardons will be awarded two men convicted of murder.

The decision gives another remarkable twist to a case known as the Luton post office murder, and may clear the names of David Cooper and Michael McMahon, following a campaign which has lasted 30 years.

Despite fresh evidence that seemed to show both men had been wrongly convicted, the court of appeal had consistently refused to set them free in the 1970s. There had been five hearings.

In 1980, the home secretary, then William Whitelaw, took the extraordinary step of ordering both men released from jail, but he did not quash their convictions.

Cooper died in September, 1993, and McMahon in July 1999, still protesting their innocence. Their families believe the trauma of their wrongful imprisonment led to their relatively early deaths.

The case concerned the death of the sub-postmaster Reginald Stevens, who was shot dead in a bungled robbery in car park near the Luton post office on September 10, 1969. Stevens was killed when he refused to hand over his keys.

The four man gang, who were using their own cars, threw the murder weapon over a railway embankment and made their getaway south down the M1. A witness took down one of the car numbers. This sighting led police to Alfred Matthews, a north London villain already convicted for a post office robbery. The gun was owned by Michael Good. Both men fitted descriptions given by witnesses. Neither of them went to jail, and, on police recommendation each got substantial shares of the reward money put up by the GPO.

The man in charge of the investigation, Detective Chief Superintendent Kenneth Drury, did not arrest Good, and he allowed Matthews to become a prosecution witness against Cooper, McMahon and another man, Patrick Murphy.

At their trial at the Old Bailey in March 1970, the judge, Mr Justice Cusack, told the jury that Matthews would have to be "wicked beyond belief" to have invented the participation of three innocent men. The jury convicted the three and they were sentenced to life imprisonment, with a recommendation that they serve at least 20 years.

The case became a cause célèbre as witnesses for Cooper, McMahon and Murphy came forward. There were also claims that vital evidence was withheld from the defence. Drury was subsequently jailed for corruption.

The case was heard by the court of appeal in 1971, in 1973 - when Murphy's conviction was quashed - and in 1975, 1976 and 1978.

Although there were profound doubts over the guilt of Cooper and McMahon, the court refused to free them, leading Gareth Peirce, their lawyer, to say the case had become "a battle between the judiciary and the executive." Lord Devlin, probably the most widely respected judge of his day, declared: "Doubts do not just lurk; from the first they have flown about the case like bats in a belfry."

Sir Ludovic Kennedy, the champion of wrongful convictions, in 1980 published the book, Wicked Beyond Belief, which contained edited extracts of prison journals written by Cooper and McMahon.

Less than a month later, Whitelaw, a friend of Sir Ludovic, ordered the men's release from prison.

Sir Ludovic revealed in a later book, On My Way to the Club, that Whitelaw had wanted to pardon the men, but had been prevented from doing so by the lord chief justice of the time, Lord Lane.

Cooper and McMahon never came to terms with the unsatisfactory nature of their release.

In January 1993, Cooper, whose real name was John Disher, was found wandering in a dazed state with a huge gash at the back of his head. How he was injured was not established, but he never recovered and died in September of that year, aged 51.

At the time McMahon told the press: "I look at this case and see that everyone is dying. The trial judge is dead, Drury is dead, Lord Devlin is dead, and now poor John is dead. I have to ask myself, is this what they want? Do they want me to die too, so the whole wretched affair just fades away?"

McMahon died of a heart attack on his 55th birthday, on June 25, 1999. Since then, lawyers have found fresh evidence about Matthews's and Good's roles as police informers, and the work of Drury.

Sue McMahon, Michael's widow, said yesterday: "I'm very pleased the case has been referred back, but the fact that John and Mick are not here, that's the saddest part."

webTitle: New foot and mouth threat to festival

fields.headline: New foot and mouth threat to festival
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The revamped Cheltenham Festival suffered a new setback yesterday when a case of foot and mouth disease was confirmed at nearby Sandhurst.
fields.body:
The revamped Cheltenham Festival suffered a new setback yesterday when a case of foot and mouth disease was confirmed at nearby Sandhurst.

The Gloucestershire course is only a mile outside the exclusion zone and its managing director Edward Gillespie said: "It is very worrying. All it needs is a sheep to sneeze in the wrong direction and our meeting would be off."

The three-day festival, whose start was postponed from March 13 to April 17 because sheep had been grazing on the course, has been diluted by the Irish banning their horses from racing in it, and it looks long odds-on that the National Hunt's prime showpiece will be scrapped.

Prospects of the "no entry" signs going up at Cheltenham have been the main topic among trainers and they are now setting their sights on the Grand National meeting, which begins on April 5.

The Aintree executive is confident that the three-day meeting, set in an urban area, will go ahead, and the Ditcheat trainer Paul Nicholls will run See More Business, ante-post favourite for the Cheltenham Gold Cup, in the Martell Cup on April 5.

A suspected case of foot and mouth is being investigated five miles from Lingfield, and all point-to-point racing in Britain will be banned until January next year; point-to-point had already been suspended and yesterday the Jockey Club point-to-point liaison committee unanimously decided to call a halt to the season, which had been due to run until June 16.

Though there have been calls for a complete ban on racing, with the Queen "expressing concern" about the sport continuing, the British Horse- racing Board is determined it will continue so long as courses are outside exclusion zones.

The BHB has been accused of double standards in its policy on racecourses which could go ahead but have cancelled meetings during the crisis; those tracks have been told that they will forfeit all fixtures for the duration of the outbreak.

Peter Savill, chairman of the BHB, said the racecourse planning committee needed to know which courses were willing to race so that a programme could be put in place.

Meanwhile, Wales are considering moving their Six Nations rugby union match against Ireland on April 29 from Cardiff's Millennium stadium to Spain, with Barcelona the favourite to host the game postponed from this month.

The Six Nations committee is meeting on Thursday to discuss the issue and its chairman Allan Hosie admitted last night that the match was unlikely to be held in Cardiff.

webTitle: Senate set for fight on poll cash reform

fields.headline: Senate set for fight on poll cash reform
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Four months after many of them won seats in the most expensive election battle in American political history, US politicians yesterday faced the question of whether to bite the hands that feed them.
fields.body:
Four months after many of them won seats in the most expensive election battle in American political history, US politicians yesterday faced the question of whether to bite the hands that feed them.

Reformers have been promised two weeks of debate on the bill to change the country's controversial campaign finance laws put forward by senators John McCain, a Republican, and his Democratic counterpart, Russell Feingold.

Although their reform package is generally considered to have its best chance of success in a decade of agitation, support for the bill is already beginning to evaporate.

The Senate yesterday began debating the bill which would ban businesses, trade unions and individuals from making unlimited "soft money" contributions to US political parties rather than to candidates. The bill would also prevent organisations from running their own "issue ads" during the 60 days prior to election day.

Recent figures revealed that the Republicans received $244m (£170m) worth of soft money donations in the 2000 election, while Democrats received $243m. Special interest groups spent hundreds of millions of dollars on issue advertising last year, effectively providing a huge pool of extra financing for candidates of the two main parties.

"After one of the closest elections in our nation's history, there's one thing the American people are unanimous about - they want their government back," Mr McCain said.

"We can do that by ridding politics of large, unregulated contributions that give special interests a seat at the table while average Americans are stuck in the back of the room."

Mr McCain, who made campaign finance reform the central plank of his unsuccessful Republican presidential nomination bid last year, joined Mr Feingold for a demonstration outside Republican and Democratic party headquarters in Washington yesterday before the debate began.

"Unfortunately, the party of the people is now engaged in raising $100,000, $500,000 and $1 million contributions from corporations, unions and individuals," Mr Feingold said. "This is not why I became a Democrat, and it is not the future of the Democratic party."

Supporters of reform base their belief that they can force changes through the new congress on two main factors: first, the surge of support in both par ties for Mr McCain's campaign on the issue and, second, the fact that the current 50-50 split in the Senate puts the reformers close to having the 60 votes needed to block a filibuster against their bill.

Mr McCain said a majority of the Senate appears to favour some limits on campaign fiance contributions, but he fears that opponents might kill the bill with amendments that "are sort of like poison pills".

Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, an opponent of reform, said there would be "fascinating" procedural issues in the weeks to come. "We're going to have two weeks of freewheeling debate," he added.

Although there are 50 Democrats in the Senate, one of them, John Breaux of Louisiana, has already said he will vote against the McCain-Feingold bill on the grounds that reform of soft money will give Republicans - traditionally bigger accumulators of regulated "hard money" donations - a funding advantage.

The reformers must also convince sceptics that the bill does not run foul of constitutional free speech guarantees. The provisions on issue advertising, in particular, could ultimately be the focus of a supreme court challenge about the bill's legality.

webTitle: Yorkshire has key role in US defence, says report

fields.headline: Yorkshire has key role in US defence, says report
fields.trailText: The early warning base at Fylingdales, in North Yorkshire, and a nearby missile-tracking radar station would almost certainly play a role in a US national missile defence project whatever weapons system the Bush administration chooses,says a report today.
fields.body:
The early warning base at Fylingdales, in North Yorkshire, and a nearby missile-tracking radar station would almost certainly play a role in a US national missile defence project whatever weapons system the Bush administration chooses,says a report today.

The only alternative options for the US would be entirely different systems - intercepting missiles soon after they were fired, as proposed by Russia - or investing in a string of new worldwide radar bases. These options would be more expensive and less reliable than using British bases, says the International Security Information Service, a think tank, in a report today.

Ministers have refused to say whether they would agree to the upgrading of Fylingdales or the building of a new American radar site on the grounds that the Bush administration has yet to decide which system to go for. Privately, Whitehall officials said it would be inconceivable for Tony Blair to refuse a request from Washington to use British bases for its controversial missile defence project.

An upgraded Fylingdales and a new x-band radar site nearby would give the US the capability to track missiles accurately and early enough to guide interceptors to them, says the report.

Officials in Whitehall believe that the US is exaggerating the threat from so-called "states of concern", and prefer what they call a "strategy of engagement" rather than the building of anti-missile defence shields that could fuel a new arms race.

fields.headline: Pakistani ruler to become president
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, is preparing to appoint himself president as a first step towards establishing a civilian government, politicians and military analysts say.
fields.body:
Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, is preparing to appoint himself president as a first step towards establishing a civilian government, politicians and military analysts say.

Gen Musharraf, who seized power in a coup 17 months ago, has promised to abide by a supreme court ruling which ordered him to restore democratic rule by October 2002.

But the army will ensure that it has a direct say in future policy, particularly on key issues such as Kashmir, Afghanistan and nuclear weapons.

"I think he will make himself president and he will want to retain control of the army," said Talat Masood, a retired general in close contact with Gen Musharraf.

"The army will have a bigger role in government. The question is whether that will make things better or not."

The proposed move mirrors the steps taken by the last military dictator, General Zia-ul Haq, who in 1985 strengthened his powers as president before appointing a civilian prime minister.

Although Gen Musharraf is widely regarded as a moderate, there has been growing disenchantment with his regime. What began as a bold agenda for reform has dissipated.

Pakistan's economy continues to struggle, reliant on securing short-term loans from the International Monetary Fund and rolling over foreign debt repayments.

A drought has destroyed up to a third of this season's wheat crop, cutting forecasts of economic growth to just 3.6% this year. Inflation is rampant while attempts to improve tax collection have provoked riots.

An anti-corruption drive lost credibility after the deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, went into exile in December. Although the military insisted he would face corruption trials, Mr Sharif was pardoned and allowed to leave for Saudi Arabia in an apparent attempt to clean out opposition to the army rule.

"It knocked the bottom out of the accountability drive," said Gen Masood."It is seen more as a tool of political manipulation and less of justice."

The regime has long threatened to crack down on militant religious groups which are involved in sectarian violence, and in the guerrilla war in Kashmir. But there has been resistance from conservative quarters of the army and the Inter-Services intelligence agency, which is still involved in the Kashmir campaign.

"General Musharraf has a great fear of taking on the orthodox forces," said Kamila Hyat, joint director of the human rights commission. of Pakistan

Now the general's priority is to ensure that the next government endorses his coup and provides a legal cover for all the steps taken since the army came to power.

He is expected to extend his term as army chief beyond his retirement in October. As president, he could remain head of the army and would be able to dismiss prime ministers.

"For the military to get this period legitimised the next parliament has to indemnify what they have done and for that reason he has to be president so he can control parliament," said Najam Sethi, editor of the respected Friday Times.

Gen Musharraf has created a national security council, including the armed forces chiefs and some ministers. The council is expected to remain under a civilian government to direct policy in key areas.

The military may revive the parliament suspended on the day of the coup rather than hold a general election immed iately. The Pakistan Muslim League (PML), the traditional party of the establishment which was in government before the coup, would still hold the majority.

"They have come to the conclusion that this parliament will be more amenable than a new one," said Gen Masood. "The PML has always been the king's party."

Since last year the military has tried to stifle political activity and many people are sceptical about the prospect of a civilian government operating under the close watch of the army.

"In a democracy you cannot accept that," said Imran Khan, the cricketer turned politician. "The big problem is that by stopping political activity he has frozen the status quo. If he expects a new leadership to come through he has got to allow political activity."

But there has been resistance from conservative quarters of the army and the Inter-Services intelligence agency, which is still involved in the Kashmir campaign. "General Musharraf has a great fear of taking on the orthodox forces," said Kamila Hyat, joint director of the human rights commission. of Pakistan Now the general's priority is to ensure that the next government endorses his coup and provides a legal cover for all the steps taken since the army came to power. He is expected to extend his term as army chief beyond his retirement in October. As president, he could remain head of the army and would be able to dismiss prime ministers. "For the military to get this period legitimised the next parliament has to indemnify what they have done and for that reason he has to be president so he can control parliament," said Najam Sethi, editor of the respected Friday Times. Gen Musharraf has created a national security council, including the armed forces chiefs and some ministers. The council is expected to remain under a civilian government to direct policy in key areas. The military may revive the parliament suspended on the day of the coup rather than hold a general election immed iately. The Pakistan Muslim League (PML), the traditional party of the establishment which was in government before the coup, would still hold the majority. "They have come to the conclusion that this parliament will be more amenable than a new one," said Gen Masood. "The PML has always been the king's party." Since last year the military has tried to stifle political activity and many people are sceptical about the prospect of a civilian government operating under the close watch of the army. "In a democracy you cannot accept that," said Imran Khan, the cricketer turned politician. "The big problem is that by stopping political activity he has frozen the status quo. If he expects a new leadership to come through he has got to allow political activity."

webTitle: Folk star strikes a chord with Israeli peace camp

fields.headline: Folk star strikes a chord with Israeli peace camp
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The legendary folk singer Pete Seeger, who created the anthems of American protest for nearly half a century, will donate the royalties from one of his best-known songs to an Israeli peace group.
fields.body:
The legendary folk singer Pete Seeger, who created the anthems of American protest for nearly half a century, will donate the royalties from one of his best-known songs to an Israeli peace group.

Jeff Halper, a leader of the Israeli Committee Against House Demolitions, which helps Palestinians resist the destruction of their homes by the Israeli army and civilian authorities, said yesterday that he had received a handwritten letter from Seeger pledging the royalties from Turn, Turn, Turn.

The donation represents a welcome boost for peace activists who have felt increasingly isolated in the last six months after Israel swung dramatically to the right following the Palestinian uprising.

"Recognition from Pete Seeger is very moving, and very meaningful for anyone who has ever been involved in social change," Mr Halper said.

"Pete Seeger is the spiritual father of all of us. He gave a real soul to protest movements. This is something we are lacking in the peace movement in Israel where there are not many victories _ and every day things get worse."

The banjo-strumming Seeger, aged 81, became involved in radical politics in the 1930s, helping to organise trade unions in Tennessee. He was also involved in the integrated school movement which produced Martin Luther King and Rosa Parks.

He set the music to We Shall Overcome, which became the anthem of the civil rights movement, and wrote the songs which inspired anti-Vietnam war protesters. He wrote such folk standards as If I Had a Hammer and Kisses Sweeter Than Wine.

Turn, Turn, Turn, like several of his songs, is based on a passage of the Bible, and the words - "a time to sing, a time to dance" - are drawn from Ecclesiastes.

In the latest uprising, some 500 homes have been bulldozed by the Israeli army or blown up by tanks under the pretext of security. This week, the Jerusalem authorities plan to issue demolition orders on dozens of Palestinian homes in Arab East Jerusalem, occupied illegally by Israel since 1967.

Seeger read about Mr Halper's group in a progressive American magazine called Jewish Currents. The article explained how the group was pioneering a model of peacemaking, supporting Palestinian activists instead of dictating strategy.

The American-born Mr Halper, who grew up in Hibbing, Minnesota, with the other American folk legend, Bob Dylan, said he had no idea how much the royalties of the donated song were worth. Seeger called them modest.

The funds are to be used to rebuild homes in the West Bank and Gaza and to replant some of the thousands of trees ripped up by Israeli diggers.

In the most serious attacks against Israel since Ariel Sharon took power, a Jewish motorist was killed in a roadside shooting, and 60 automatic rifles were stolen from a kibbutz where the security chief was killed.

Mr Sharon, who was in Washington to emphasise his position that violence must end before talks can begin, said Yasser Arafat would pay a high price for the violence.

fields.headline: Senator Clinton tops high-rent league
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton is spending more of American taxpayers' money on her New York office than any other senator, according to figures released by the general services administration, a government department.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton is spending more of American taxpayers' money on her New York office than any other senator, according to figures released by the general services administration, a government department.

Her Manhattan headquarters costs taxpayers $514,149 (£360,000) a year. Charles Schumer, her fellow Democratic senator for the state, spends $209,532 for an office in the same neighbourhood.

The second highest spending US senator is Dianne Feinstein in San Francisco, with an office that costs $424,632.

Jim Kennedy, a spokesman for Senator Clinton, defended the cost of her offices yesterday by saying that New York prices have escalated sharply in the last few years. He pointed out that she could have continued in her predecessor's office, in the landmark Chrysler building, but turned it down as it would have been even more expensive.

However, Republicans and consumer groups have objected to the high cost of the 26th floor office in New York's midtown district.

David Keating at the National Taxpayers' Union told the New York Post: "It's inconceivable to me that somebody can spend almost two and a half times more and be from the same state, representing the same constituents. That's a lot of extra money to spend for getting the same job done."

Mr Kennedy said that Mrs Clinton needed the extra space as more than 50 volunteers were expected to work on caseloads for her constituents, compared with "five or six" for Mr Schumer. Senator Clinton's offices also have two generous conference rooms to cope with the press demands for her appearances, he said.

The controversy over the cost of her office comes just over a month after former President Bill Clinton was forced to withdraw his application for an $811,000-a-year lease on the fifth floor of the Carnegie Hall Tower on West 57th Street in Manhattan because of a public outcry at the expense. He is now negotiating a considerably cheaper lease in Harlem.

webTitle: Hugo Young: liberalism and the Lib Dems

fields.headline: The country needs Kennedy, if he behaves like a liberal
fields.standfirst:
He should be making the case against Straw's excesses

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: He should be making the case against Straw's excesses.
fields.body:
In any given election, significant numbers of people vote Liberal Democrat who have no idea what the party stands for. There have been notorious byelection polls showing that as many as a third of the voters believe the Lib Dems reflect, for example, their own fierce anti-Europeanism.

Of all the parties, the Lib Dems' support depends least on their perceived ideological identity. All those years of Paddy Ashdown's prophetic vision have still come to this: a scrambling around, for at least half their votes, among people who just can't stand the other two, and don't much care about the finer points of what the third lot thinks.

This sounds like a dubious faculty. In fact it's a kind of liberation. It doesn't prevent the party taking positions. To be taken seriously, that is what it has to do. But such position-taking, since it's not being widely listened to, can afford to be less rigidly chained to the vulgar populism that mesmerises other parties. When Charles Kennedy is asked about the euro, yes or no, his monosyllabic clarity, so baffling to interviewers schooled in double-talk, is arresting to witness.

At his pre-election conference in Torquay, however, he sounded different. He barely came over as a liberal at all. There was scarcely anything different between his discourse and his rivals'. It seems that with an election beckoning, the Lib Dem leader thinks he should sound safely familiar, knocking the other two but junking what is unique about his own party.

What Mr Kennedy thinks is bold, the 1p income tax rise, isn't bold at all. It brings some vestigial benefit in terms of political honesty. Lib Dems can beat their pious breasts as they announce this cute positioning. But the promise has no interest. For one thing, we all know they won't be able to do anything about it. For another, it's fatuous to try to outbid Labour on public spending.

The Lib Dems tried that last time, only to find their tax-rise promise hugely outdistanced by Labour's actual spending. As things stand, Labour have cornered the market in the politics of spending. By giving all his effort to following them down that track, Mr Kennedy simply joins an auction at the centre of centre-ground politics where the Tories have been dragged as well. I don't believe it's likely to add a micro-percentage to the Lib Dem vote.

Where the Lib Dems are different, on the other hand, Mr Kennedy was silent. This concerns, in a word, their liberalism. The country has never stood in greater need of liberalism being reaffirmed. The encroachments on it, by a home secretary who grows ever more defiantly hostile to liberal principles, multiply by the week.

The criminal justice and police bill gives the police draconian powers against demonstrators of all kinds, not just the animal liberation front. New powers are being proposed to seize assets merely on suspicion of criminality. Juries and not merely judges may soon be allowed to know about past convictions before a trial begins.

Worst of all in this systematic erosion of the presumption of innocence, the double jeopardy rule has been recommended for abolition. It's an iniquitous proposal, prompted by one notorious case, which proves only that in a populist environment easy cases make even worse law than hard ones.

How a murder jury, retrying what's been announced by the court of appeal as a defective acquittal, is supposed to bring an open mind and fair justice to its work is a question so far answered only by wishful blather about the need not to let them know about the history of the case. Riddled with anomalies, the law commission's destruction of a basic rule is none the less accepted by much bien pensant opinion: final proof that liberal principles, unless reasserted, are heading for the rocks.

In parliament, the Lib Dems have a decent record in this field. They're sometimes a bit slow. On double jeopardy, all they've said so far is that they remain to be persuaded. But they will oppose letting juries know whether the accused in the dock has a criminal record. Their stubbornness in the House of Lords prevented Jack Straw getting his way, first time round, in the curtailment of jury trial. Simon Hughes, the front-bench spokesman on home affairs, has an excellent grasp on the issues and diligent command of the detail of bills that might be open to amendment.

Charles Kennedy is a liberal too. But with him there's a problem. Roaming round the platform at Torquay, letting his stream of consciousness run on, he somehow found no room for the core of liberalism. He alluded to justice and liberty, but dwelt predominantly on the money. Outspending Gordon Brown seemed more important than putting Jack Straw on the liberal rack. Hammering William Hague for the last Tory government's record on crime was accompanied by no ringing defence of the value system, in the courts and in the prisons, with which a decent liberal society should seek to improve upon it.

This has become quite a hard speech to make. There is evidence that the Tories' own efforts to rebalance trials against the defendant, which Straw is emulating, have not worked. For example, the Home Office itself has published evidence that abolishing the right to silence has had the very outcome its opponents predicted.

"Police officers," it reports, "were sceptical about the impact .. on 'professional' criminals .. Legal advisers were concerned about the potential impact of the provisions on vulnerable suspects." Six years on, abolishing the right to silence has "not led to any discernible increase in charges or convictions". Despite that, criticising illiberal penal and judicial regimes remains painfully unfashionable.

Here, however, lies the Lib Dems' unique role and historic opportunity. There ought to be scope for a Tory party that was still sensitive to traditional rights and liberties to take an oppositionist stance against the Straw excesses. But Mr Hague and Ms Widdecombe sold that pass long ago. The Lib Dems have the field to themselves, if only they will march to the high ground standing vacant.

The defence of individual liberties, the protection of due process, a challenge to the crudities of prison, an insistence that certain rights are inalienable even against the Sun: here is a Lib Dem agenda that needs to be taken beyond parliamentary committees, and out of party gatherings where everybody agrees with it, to the widest audience.

Whether the audience will be listening is another matter, and whether it will vote accordingly still another again. But that's the beauty of the Lib Dems' situation. Their principles need not impede their vote. To those who do listen, however, hearing liberalism defended would be an inspiration. That kind of vote may well have existed in Romsey, and may still do so. Mr Kennedy was good in that byelection, standing up for asylum seekers. Now he needs to find an idiom that lets him talk with passion about issues nobody else will touch.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
An extraordinary email regarding Turncoat of Turncoats contender Kim Howells arrives. "Could you confirm whether or not Turncoat candidate Kim Howells is the same Kim Howells from the Hornsey art school sit-ins?" it asks. It is, although the DTI's capitalist competitions minister has moved somewhat right since he stormed the college as a self-styled Red Guard in 1968. "If so," the anonymous sender continues, "I refer you to his part (no small thing) in Roy Battersby's The Body. I expect he himself is too modest to bring your attention to this." Well. Producer Tony Garnett confirms that Kim Howells did indeed take part in this 1970 X-rated psychedelic "medical documentary", for which Pink Floyd's Roger Waters scored such musical gems as More Than Seven Dwarves in Penis Land and Lick Your Partners. We ring Kim's office to discuss what, other than the serial skin-shedding that has defined his career, made him nip a future in progressive X-rated cinema in the bud, but he is not at home. So until we have heard his tortuous explanation and located a copy of this broadminded piece of celluloid, Turncoat betting is frozen on the intriguing Dr Howells. Blimey, though.

 And so to the Diary's imminent web debut, a form guide to Turncoats runners and riders, complete with current odds and before and after photos of our mercurial friends. Discussions yesterday with webmaster Oofy Wegg-Prosser found him on businesslike form, and - a missing picture of Diary pundit Steptoe excepted - the launch looks set to be relatively tension-free. Oofy cloaks the exact day we will "go live" with the kind of secrecy he once reserved for soup quotes, but an off-the-record steer indicates sometime early next week.

 With Matthew Norman sojourning somewhere in Devon's foot-and-mouth exclusion zone, I am compelled to tackle pensioner Sylvia Arbour's fond letter to him."Dear Norman Matthews," she begins. "I read your diary avidly for the express purpose of criticising it and then scribbling a very rude response - which I do not post as 75p a week means rigorous prioritising of who to be rude to and when." Clearly this can't go on, and a cheque is being dispatched to Sylvia so that she can insult Matthew/Norman twice weekly for a year. No room today for her radical plans to form an anti-estate-agent vigilante group with north London neighbour Alastair Campbell, but if our strength holds you may be sure of it tomorrow. Or soon.

 Surveillance: much-admired adult film star Traci Lords, next to a swimming pool, on the cover of the Sunday Times travel section. With heavy make-up hiding the ravages of hard drugs and under-age porn roles, Traci looked fine above a feature on where to meet A-list movers and shakers in Hollywood. Bravo, picture editor!

 A masterfully targeted piece of PR from the weekend postbag exposes just how easy it is to penetrate this Diary's anti-promotional defences. "Dear Guardian Diary," it reads. "Would you kindly put this into your weekend "Late Availability" column. [name deleted] Travel are offering 10% off all short breaks booked online. Spring breaks, Easter breaks, family weekends, romantic weekends. Stock up with wine and French food. Please call Max Clifford should you have any queries." Say what you like, the old magic's still there.

 Many thanks to all of you who have applied for the £50 bounty placed on the head of each of Andrew Neil's vanished internet sites, European.com, EuropeanBusiness.com and e-Scot. However, the original notice did stipulate that they must be brought to us alive, and if we were to pay out for mere information on whom the sites are registered to, well, we'd have no money for abortive attempts to hire kangaroo suits. If they're lucrative and successful e-business ventures, marvellous. Otherwise, the till's closed.

fields.headline: John Phillips
fields.standfirst: Singer-songwriter who founded the Mamas and Papas
fields.trailText: Singer-songwriter who founded the Mamas and Papas.
fields.body:
John Phillips, the founder and principal songwriter of the 1960s vocal group, the Mamas and Papas, has died aged 65. He arranged their dynamic harmonies and wrote, or co-wrote, most of their best-known songs, including California Dreamin', Monday, Monday and Creeque Alley. He also wrote the hippie anthem San Francisco. In less than two years, the group had six American Top-10 hits and sold millions of records worldwide, before internal frictions brought about their downfall.

The son of a marine officer, Phillips was born in South Carolina. He studied at George Washington University, and briefly attended the US Naval Academy before migrating to New York in 1957 to join the Greenwich Village folk scene. There, he formed several groups, including the New Journeymen, whose members included guitarist and singer Denny Doherty and Michelle Gilliam, who became his second wife in 1962. The quartet that was to become the Mamas and Papas was completed by the arrival of Cass Elliot, who had formerly sung with Doherty in the Mugwumps.

The quartet moved to Los Angeles, where they linked up with record producer Lou Adler. He later said of their audition: "They had just come down from about 80 acid trips; they were funky, dirty and grizzly, and yet they sang like angels." Elliot found them a name after hearing a Hell's Angel say, "We call our women mamas," on a television show.

Their first single was California Dreamin', released on Adler's Dunhill label in 1966. Doherty was the lead singer, Glen Campbell played guitar, and the flute solo was by jazz musician Bud Shank. Like another of John Phillips's 1966 compositions, San Francisco (Be sure to wear some flowers in your hair), it portrayed California as a new utopia, and was the first of a series of his powerful ballads. These included the playful Creeque Alley, which told the history of the group, the ecstatic love song, I Saw Her Again Last Night, and the sombre Look Through My Window.

The Mamas and Papas also recorded some deftly-chosen songs from the 50s, notably Dedicated To The One I Love, originally by the Shirelles. Phillips's four-part vocal arrangements were influenced by the jazz singing of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, and by such 1950s pop groups as the Four Freshmen. With Lou Adler, Phillips organised the 1967 Monterey Pop Festival, which introduced Jimi Hendrix and The Who to American audiences.

But the Phillips' marriage had been damaged by Michelle's affair with Doherty, for whom Elliot had an unrequited passion. Michelle was temporarily ejected from the group, and the end came when Elliott left to follow a successful solo career as Mama Cass. She died suddenly in 1974.

In 1970, Phillips made his own solo album, The Wolf-king Of LA, which reflected the growing popularity in Los Angeles of the country-rock sound associated with his friend Gram Parsons. Its lyrics mostly concerned the lifestyle of the new Los Angeles movie and music aristocracy, of which Phillips was a leading member.

By this time, however, he was in the grip of the drug addiction graphically described in his 1986 autobiography, Papa John. He had little incentive to work in the 1970s, as he was reportedly receiving $100,000 a year in composer royalties. The sum total of his musical activity in that decade was the soundtrack music for Nicolas Roeg's film The Man Who Fell To Earth (1976), and the production of an album by his third wife, Genevieve Waite. He also recorded some solo tracks, with Mick Jagger and Keith Richards as producers, which are due to be issued in May under the title Pay, Pack And Follow.

The catalyst for Phillips to return to the stage was a conviction for drug offences that forced him to undergo rehabilitation in 1981. As part of his sentence, he gave lectures on drug abuse, assisted by his daughter, McKenzie.

The following year, he was fit enough to form a new Mamas and Papas group, with Doherty, McKenzie and Elaine "Spanky" McFarlane (formerly of the Los Angeles group Sparky and Our Gang). Later members of the re-formed quartet included Scott McKenzie, an ex-Journeyman and the singer of the hit version of San Francisco. In 1998, Phillips was reunited with Doherty and Michelle when the Mamas and Papas were inducted into the rock 'n' roll hall of fame, and last year he made a new album that is expected to be issued later this year.

Phillips died in a Los Angeles hospital of heart failure, following several years of failing health after a liver transplant and two hip replacements. He was married four times and leaves five children and two stepchildren. They include McKenzie, now a television actress, Chynna, a member of the Wilson Phillips vocal group, and Bijou, a singer and model.

fields.headline: Kangaroo leaps onto Europe's menus
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Demand for kangaroo meat has risen by 20% in Europe in the wake of BSE scares and the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Demand for kangaroo meat has risen by 20% in Europe in the wake of BSE scares and the foot and mouth crisis.

Traditionally used in pet food and for leather football boots, there has been a 50-fold increase in human consumption of the versatile marsupial in Australia in the last decade. The kangaroo industry is now the fastest growing rural business in the country.

"It's cheap, it's safe, it's clean and green. High quality kangaroo meat tastes a little bit like deer and folk say it's good for you," said Don Cairns, a senior Australian trade commissioner based in Bucharest.

Kangaroo now pops up on many Australian restaurant menus, with chefs extolling its leanness. The meat contains less than 2% fat, of which 48% are healthy polyunsaturated fats, and is also high in iron.

Kangaroo is now attractive in Europe because it is free from the health scares associated with factory farmed meats.

The Kangaroo Industry Association of Australia (KIAA) yesterday reported a 20% increase in sales to Germany, France, Holland and Belgium. Demand in Britain remains low because it has little tradition of eating game cuisine, said John Kelly of the KIAA.

There are 35m of the grass-eating animals hopping around Australia and each year national parks officers make an assessment of how many can be culled sustainably.

Mr Kelly said: "It is environmentally wise for us in Australia to produce our food from animals that belong here, rather than use introduced exotics like sheep and cattle which cause considerable environmental damage."

fields.headline: Papuan troops demand caretaker government
fields.standfirst: Mutineers attack defence cuts and economic reform
fields.trailText: Mutinous troops demanded the resignation of the Papua New Guinean government last night in protest at defence cuts and the World Bank's influence.
fields.body:
Mutinous troops demanded the resignation of the Papua New Guinean government last night in protest at defence cuts and the World Bank's influence.

The prime minister, Sir Mekere Morauta, went into hiding after his announcement at the weekend that he was abandoning a series of planned defence cuts failed to pacify the mutineers.

Soldiers from three units stockpiled weapons and barricaded themselves in their barracks, calling on the government to hand over power within seven days to a caretaker administration.

The protests began last week when 100 soldiers seized machine guns at the Murray barracks in the capital, Port Moresby, after the cabinet accepted the recommendation of a group of Commonwealth experts from Australia, New Zealand and Jamaica to cut the defence force personnel from 4,150 to 1,900.

Senior officers were reported to have helped to distribute guns and ammunition to the troops. One officer said: "They want this government to go at all costs - nothing more, nothing less. And they are prepared to shed blood to see this government go."

Several soldiers publicly objected to the World Bank's influence on the government. Since coming to power in 1999, Mr Morauta, a former central banker, has instituted economic reforms in exchange for World Bank and International Monetary Fund loans.

One soldier told the local media that the unions had failed to stop the World Bank's interference. "The only group that can stop them is the defence force. If they reduce the number to 1,900, they can push any issue they want."

An IMF team left Port Moresby last week after its latest review of the country's economic reforms. Mr Morauta said the team was satisfied with the progress of the structural adjustment programme, which is tied to further support of $51.8m (£36m).

Restless soldiers have taken to the streets four times since February, and the unions have expressed anger at the government's recent rejection of a minimum wage.

The government played down the protests yesterday. One source said that several politicians had collaborated with the soldiers' latest revolt.

The government's opponents hope the crisis will force the prime minister to recall parliament, which was adjourned in December for six months to enable him to survive a vote of no confidence.

Mr Morauta still commands reasonable popular support, according to Ron May of the Australian National University. Australia administered Papua New Guinea until it became independent in 1975.

Australia's prime minister, John Howard, said Mr Morauta's democratic government must prevail. "It's very important that the people of Papua New Guinea understand that people around the world would want and expect the constitutional authority of the democratically elected government to be respected and maintained."

Soldiers triggered the downfall of the Papua New Guinea government four years ago when they rebelled against the introduction of mercenaries from the British security company Sandline to crush a secessionist movement on the island of Bougainville.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Six jailed for bombing flats
fields.body:
Six jailed for bombing flats

A Russian court jailed two men for life yesterday for a bombing that the authorities cited as a reason for the renewed war in Chechnya. Four accomplices received lighter sentences.

The September 1999 bombing of a block of flats in Buinaksk, Dagestan, killed 64 people. It was the first of four bombings that year which killed about 300 people. AP, Makhachkala

Professor fired for child porn

A geology professor at Yale University, Connecticut, has been dismissed for downloading 200,000 child pornography images and making two pornographic videotapes of a boy.

Antonio Lasaga, 51, who pleaded guilty last year, faces a possible 20 years in prison. AP, Hartford

Divers locate explorer's ship

Divers have found the wreck of English explorer William Dampier's ship, the Roebuck, over 300 years after it sank in the Atlantic. It was found 100 metres off Ascension Island.

His exploration of the coast of west Australia in 1699 came 71 years before Captain Cook landed on the east coast. AFP, Sydney

Shepherds find ancient statues

Three shepherds on the eastern Aegean island of Kalymnos have uncovered nine marble statues, believed to be 2,300 years old, the Greek authorities said. They were found while the shepherds were digging to erect a fence. AP, Athens

fields.headline: $1m challenge still stands
fields.trailText: As the unnamed "magician" referred to in your article on homeopathy (Thanks for the memory, Science, March 15), the results of Professor Madeleine Ennis in Belfast, interest me greatly.
fields.body:
As the unnamed "magician" referred to in your article on homeopathy (Thanks for the memory, Science, March 15), the results of Professor Madeleine Ennis in Belfast, interest me greatly. If they are eventually replicated, it could mean the definitive validation of the claims that have been made by homeopaths for over 200 years. Perhaps we can look forward to Father Christmas being authenticated at the same time?

You mention "ghost dilutions" without making it clear those dilutions are so extreme that no chemical or physical testing procedure can determine the difference between homeopathic and non-homeopathic water. I differ with your statement that the John Maddox/Walter Stewart/Randi team who investigated for Nature and the US National Institutes of Health "could find no fault with Benveniste's methods - only his results". We controlled the experiments against the possibility of conscious or unconscious bias and/or manipulation, and the result was the only set of experiments in the history of that lab which produced null results. That speaks for itself. You describe the excellent protocol implemented by Professor Ennis, in line with the double-blind, independent techniques this foundation espouses. But the protocol described by Dr Benveniste in his original paper sounded foolproof and unassailable.

My foundation has a standing $1m challenge to anyone to tell the difference between a homoeopathic preparation and a non-homoeopathic control. My colleagues on L'affaire Benveniste are as willing as I to be convinced by proper evidence. But until independent replication is accomplished, we will reserve judgement. James Randi
James Randi Educational Foundation, Florida, USA
randi@randi.org

fields.body:

Preston borough council

 As a mother who breast fed both children for longer than four months (Breast feeding 'link' to heart disease, March 16), taught full time during their pre-school years and am now condemned to socio-economic group two (Pecking order, March 16), what hope is there for my offspring?

Truro, Cornwall

 The Guardian has a well-deserved reputation for corrections and clarifications, but surely printing Join the dots (G2, March 19) by "Michael Atavar" almost two weeks before April Fool's Day is simply careless.
Simon Smith
London

 Re the elucidatory technicalities of the error which caused the false impression that a young boy was holding his penis in his right hand while urinating, when in fact it was in his left hand (Corrections, March 19): is someone taking the piss?
Ray Bellisario
Norwood Green, Middx

 As a fellow 75-year-old, my only response to the account (March 19) of how women threw themselves at the aged John Bayley is, to quote Meera Syal: "In your dreams, buddy."
J Barrell
Lamphey, Pembroke

 When Fabricius named the red admiral genus of butterflies Vanessa in 1863, was he influenced by Swift's poetry (Letters, March 18) or, as Chambers suggests, by Phanes, the ancient Greek mystic divinity?
Copland Smith
Manchester

webTitle: Letters: Shakespeare a threat to literacy?

fields.headline: Can horseplay with lit crit help to get nise jobz?
fields.trailText: Shakespeare a threat to literacy (Bad Report for the Bard, March 17)? Come on. The findings of Sig Prais and his team are yet another example of the philistinism that infects our entire education system.
fields.body:
Shakespeare a threat to literacy (Bad Report for the Bard, March 17)? Come on. The findings of Sig Prais and his team are yet another example of the philistinism that infects our entire education system. There is more to English than teaching kids to fill out forms so that they can take dead end jobs. Education should be about developing qualities of mind as well as skills, about transcending targets as well as meeting them. The idea that reading Romeo and Juliet might damage instead of develop powers of expression is the sort of nonsense that should be rejected by anyone who cares about the arts.

It is time to defend the canon. For too long those of us who care about such things have had to endure eminent professors telling us that there is no such thing as literature. Abolish the canon and you have a bureaucrat's definition of excellence; rubbish the idea of literature and all experience is reduced to the idiom of the market, that human invention that dehumanises.
Gary Day
De Montfort University
gday@dmu.ac.uk

 Professor Prais tells us Shakespeare is useful for the undercultured masses only insofar as his phonetic horseplay wil help them tu rite to bizness and get nise jobz. True, being able to write a gud seevee may help a thousand dull people to earn hundreds of thousands of pounds a year; but I'm jiggered if I know what they're going to spend it on. Certainly not on watching Shakespeare (all that iambic pentameter), or listening to Wagner (you don't need leitmotif when you've got cute little jumpers for your shih-tsu). Perhaps briefcases and mobile phones which play classical music by composers they haven't even heard of.

We're not to care a weasel's pelvis for anything like poetry or music or art or individuality (or anything other than money, in fact). Life, from this viewpoint, is given to us by the Almighty in order to make work possible (a nasty inversion). I'd rather die penniless in a ditch with a copy of Dorian Gray than as a rich man with the soul of a Cro-Magnon.
Paul Harper-Scott
Magdalen College, Oxford

 It is not, in my experience, which texts are read that creates differences between the abilities of continental and English students to use "transactional language skills", but the way in which they are taught to read them. The English largely still teach with a touching emphasis on the need for students to "respond" emotionally and aesthetically to texts, rather than to think critically and analytically about language and meaning. My colleagues are often made nervous by my emphasis on forcing students continually to account to me for why and how they say what they say about texts.

Paradoxically, English students would be better served in acquiring skills for a non-academic career by being asked to be more academic: by having demands placed upon them to grapple with difficulty and complexity.

The findings of Sig Prais and his team are yet another example of the philistinism that infects our entire education system. There is more to English than teaching kids to fill out forms so that they can take dead end jobs. Education should be about developing qualities of mind as well as skills, about transcending targets as well as meeting them. The idea that reading Romeo and Juliet might damage instead of develop powers of expression is the sort of nonsense that should be rejected by anyone who cares about the arts. webTitle: Letters: Loosening London's grip on the arts

fields.headline: Loosening London's grip on the arts
fields.trailText: The proposal to merge the 10 regional arts boards with the Arts Council of England will build on the success of the regional boards in supporting the arts. The Arts Council is not saying that any RAB has failed to do its job (Arts Council axes local boards, March 16).
fields.body:
The proposal to merge the 10 regional arts boards with the Arts Council of England will build on the success of the regional boards in supporting the arts. The Arts Council is not saying that any RAB has failed to do its job (Arts Council axes local boards, March 16). We are saying that the current funding system, involving 11 autonomous organisations, leads to duplication, complexity and inefficiency.

A single national arts funding body with a strong network of regional offices will simplify the arts funding system and make it more efficient. The inclusion of the regional arts boards in a single body will put all frontline responsibility for the arts and artists in the regions and will enhance, rather than reduce, the voice of the regions in national arts policy.

Collectively the RABs have secured massive investment for cultural partnerships in their regions. The RABs invest in quality arts production, education and investment in artists, helping to expand the arts economy and make the arts more accessible. The boards themselves bring valuable experience, advice and advocacy for the arts from artists, the private sector and local government. This expertise will not be lost in this reorganisation. Our primary aim is to deliver the best possible support to the arts, artists and audiences.
Peter Hewitt
Chief executive, Arts Council of England

 In one sense your report on the proposals for regional arts boards is very old news - the Arts Council closed its regional offices in the 1950s. Now it seems to want to reinvent them. But shouldn't there be a little bit of reflection and consultation before rushing into yet another hastily concocted and potentially very costly reorganisation? Southern Arts is consulting the artists and arts organisations in the region - as well as our local authority partners - about the proposals. I hope that my colleagues in other regional boards will also consult widely.

Incidentally, there are no plans for Southern Arts to "absorb" South East Arts. We believe that the vast south east government office/regional development agency region (with a population as big as Austria) is far too large for arts development purposes, and that the current boundaries are effective.
Robert Hutchison
Chief executive, Southern Arts

 The new Arts Council proposals build on the success of the regions in delivering regional partnerships. In the northern region we will be consulting on how best to build on that success in a new single agency structure.

Your comments about South East Arts are ill-informed. They have an excellent staff and board and have at times led the country in new policy initiatives such as their work with older people and the arts.
Andrew Dixon
Chief executive, Northern Arts

 I am very distressed at your casual, unsubstantiated remarks which imply that South East is regarded as the "worst" of the regional arts boards. We are the worst funded of all the regional arts boards, an inequity against which we have been fighting on behalf of the region's artists for years.

South East Arts is an active and successful board. We have recently been instrumental in saving from closure two of the region's leading arts organisations Chichester Festival Theatre and Fabrica gallery in Brighton. We are a crucial part of the development of a brand new gallery in Margate; we conceived the idea of the current Year of the Artist; and we have broken new ground for older people and the arts.

We hope that the net result of the proposed changes will be that artists will be able to draw support from the larger, national pot rather than being limited by the very small amounts of funding available to them in the past.
Felicity Harvest
Chief executive, South East Arts
felicity.harvest@seab.co.uk

 Shame on you. It has taken 15 years to prise even partial control of arts funding out of London's grip and you seem to imply that the whole exercise has been worthless. Gerry Robinson bemoans the "large inconsistencies" across the regions, but surely the whole point of Richard Luce's original idea to devolve spending was that the regions should be able to choose the art that suited them best. Contrary to New Labour thinking, "inconsistency" is one of the markers that suggests devolution is functioning. As for Mr Robinson's discovery that bureaucracy is a provincial invention not encountered in London. Why have I always thought it was the other way around?
Vic Allen
Editor, Artscene Magazine
Halifax, Yorkshire
artscene@btconnect.com

 The last time the Arts Council had regional offices their purpose was to impose metropolitan taste on the regions. In reaction, we established the regional arts associations. Here in the West Midlands there remains a revolutionary cadre that will resist this unwarranted transfer of power to London. Maybe we'll call it the Provisional RAA.
Steve Trow
Oldbury
SteveTrow@compuserve.com

 Given that "equal pain for all" has been the watchword in arts funding for many years, perhaps Mr Robinson will demonstrate his solidarity with the arts community and fall on his own sword?
Tim Bennett-Goodman
London

webTitle: Leader: Mandela's claim to a place with Horatio

fields.headline: Going for the full Nelson
fields.standfirst: Mandela's claim to a place with Horatio
fields.trailText: Call it a curse, but there is something about Trafalgar Square. Every attempt to put something in it seems to bring trouble.
fields.body:
Call it a curse, but there is something about Trafalgar Square. Every attempt to put something in it seems to bring trouble. King William IV wanted a statue to commemorate himself, but he died without leaving enough money to pay for one. Accordingly, his memory was preserved for over 150 years by an empty plinth.

To remedy that problem, a panel of great and good folk, led by John Mortimer, decided to use the empty plinth as a platform for the best of contemporary British sculpture. Every six months a new work is supposed to take its place on the base, while the old one is moved out. Yet here, too, the Trafalgar curse has struck. For Turner prize-winning artist Rachel Whiteread has been waiting for her moment in the sun since October. That was when her work, an upturned replica of the plinth itself, was due to take up its position. But the complexity of plastics science has defeated her: the engineers just cannot make her "Plinth" stand up without collapsing in on itself.

So one can only hope for a better outcome - and a break from the curse - for the latest proposal for Trafalgar Square. Richard Attenborough, Donald Woods and others want to build a new plinth - the fifth - by South Africa House, as the home for a statue of Nelson Mandela. It would mark the very spot where demonstrators throughout the 1980s issued the cry for freedom which rang around the world.

Yet, as if to prove that the Trafalgar jinx knows no bounds, even this outstanding idea has its opponents. RW Johnson has written that "one Nelson statue" is quite enough for the London square, arguing that the Mandela record is not spotless. That's as maybe; but Mr Johnson misses the point. For Mr Mandela has become more than just a hero and a legend. He is now a human symbol, a totem, of the fight for justice and against racism. Trafalgar Square should be honoured to be graced by his presence - even in bronze.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Britain is second only to Greece as the European country with the most uninsured drivers on its roads, according to a report from Direct Line.
fields.body:
Insurer warns on driver crime
Britain is second only to Greece as the European country with the most uninsured drivers on its roads, according to a report from Direct Line.

Claims from accidents involving uninsured drivers have doubled over the past three years to £265m, and are likely to hit £1bn by 2005, it says, adding £60 to the typical car insurance premium.
Direct Line estimates that there are 1.25m cars in Britain without insurance, one in 20 of the total, compared to just one in every 500 in Germany. Yesterday the insurer called for the government to increase fines on uninsured drivers. "With average annual premiums costing £350 compared to typical fines for driving without insurance of £150, many drivers may feel it is worth the gamble."

£70m funding for e-business
The government is to invest £70m in electronic technologies aimed at "transforming" business practices, boosting science and bringing computer power to everyday gadgets, the e-commerce minister announced yesterday.
A network of business advisers will also be funded to help firms trade online. Patricia Hewitt said: "The UK is already one of the world leaders in mobile internet and digital TV. Now we are investing an additional £70m to ensure UK business and scientists can be in the lead for the next generation of electronic networks."

Capital jobs at Sainsbury
J Sainsbury is to invest £500m in new stores and refurbishments in London over the next three years, creating 3,000 new jobs.
The supermarket group, which recently sold its Homebase chain for £969m, said the new funds would bring the total invested in London between 1999 and 2004 to £1bn, and new jobs created to 6,000. Sainsbury at present operates from 104 London stores.

First Choice buys Virgin Sun
First Choice Holidays said yesterday it had bought the short-haul package holiday business, Virgin Sun, from Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group for £5.9m. Virgin Sun operates package holidays from Gatwick and Manchester to the Mediterranean. The group will be run by the existing management team until First Choice takes over on November 1.

XTL moves into fungal territory
XTL, the biotech firm specialising in developing drugs from irradiated mice, is planning to diversify from hepatitis treatments to those for fungal and bacterial diseases. XTL, based in Israel but floated in London last year, increased its operating losses by 36% to £4.9m.

webTitle: Bobos bow to Bertrand's discreet charm

fields.headline: Bobos bow to Bertrand's discreet charm
fields.trailText: In Paris this morning the Metro is running, motorists are insulting one another, and the cafes are laying out their tables on the streets. Like any Monday. Nothing has changed, and yet, everything has changed.
fields.body:
In Paris this morning the Metro is running, motorists are insulting one another, and the cafes are laying out their tables on the streets.

Like any Monday. Nothing has changed, and yet, everything has changed.

For 25 years it was a bastion of De Gaulle's heirs. Now it in the hands of a Socialist, Bertrand Delanoë, who can stick in his scrapbook his most famous response: "You recognise me?" Winning Paris is the best remedy anyone has invented for lack of fame.

Our Bertrand is not your Ken. He is not red but rather a tender shade of pink, and has nothing of the provocateur. Everyone has forgotten that in his 30s he was No 3 in the Socialist party ranks, and that, approaching his 50s, he was not the Socialist hierarchy's first choice: they were thinking of someone more flamboyant to lead the battle of Paris.

This handicap turned into a major asset. At least this one will not dream of the presidential elections and will take care of us and our city, thought Parisians, tired of seeing the town hall used as an electoral war room and national springboard.

Bertrand the discreet has promised to bring morality back into Parisian public life, and no one had much trouble believing him, since the town hall facade has cracked so much in recent years, revealing the RPR system's scandals of every kind.

It is a revolution without revolutionaries, a gasp of fresh air that ends in a change of era. The bobos (bohemian bourgeois) and the lilis (liberal-libertarians) of the capital want to improve their quality of life.

The environment, pollution, public transport head their list of worries. And Bertrand Delanoë has nursed them with practical proposals: a tramway on the boulevards around the capital, 2,000 nursery places, 60 reception classes - even the restoration of the Molitor swimming pool, a 1930s building on the outskirts of the Bois de Boulogne which has become a sad wreck.

Nothing compared with the pharaonic projects of the late François Mitterrand, who was Delanoë's political mentor. But time are changing, and modesty is at stake. Furthermore the new mayor - a man both proud and confident - must not believe himself the ghost of Mitterrand and start dreaming of great projects.

You would not forgive me for forgetting a biographical detail: the new man of Paris "came out " two years ago. This won him a vengeful outburst from a beaten RPR candidate, who grumbled privately: "It's the Cage aux Folles at the town hall!"

Otherwise, in Paris, nobody cares. And that too is a beautiful victory.

 Marie Guichoux is a senior editor at the daily Libération
