webTitle: Blue wave dampens French left's gains

fields.headline: Blue wave dampens French left's gains
fields.standfirst: Paris was cause for celebration, but the right triumphed too
fields.trailText: They got the jewels, but missed the crown: the left's joy yesterday at its historic capture of France's two biggest cities, Paris and Lyon, was tempered by the pounding it received in the provinces.
fields.body:
They got the jewels, but missed the crown: the left's joy yesterday at its historic capture of France's two biggest cities, Paris and Lyon, was tempered by the pounding it received in the provinces.

And while the conservative president, Jacques Chirac, will be lamenting the loss of the capital he ran as mayor for nearly 20 years, there were plenty of reasons for him to take heart from the right's robust showing in this weekend's nationwide municipal elections.

"We don't have to change our policies, but we clearly have to adapt our way of governing," admitted the Socialist party chairman, François Hollande, noting that the ruling leftwing coalition's strong national record on boosting economic growth and cutting unemployment had not sufficiently impressed local voters.

The left lost around 30 important towns and cities in Sunday's second-round run-off, while half a dozen key ministers were humiliated in their bid to wrest provincial conservative strongholds from the right, or even to retain town halls they had run for years.

Commentators warned that the "blue wave" that brought the Gaullist RPR party and its centrist allies, the UDF, to power in town halls around the country would lead to the defeat of Lionel Jospin's Socialist-led government if repeated in parliamentary elections next year.

"The blue wave that swept across France's regions weakens Jospin more than the gains in Paris and Lyon strengthen him," wrote the left-leaning Libération, and the rightwing Le Figaro agreed: "Despite its murderous divisions and culpable errors, the right is in a majority in the country. Based on yester day's results, parliamentary elections would see the 'plural left' back in opposition."

The decline of Mr Jospin's coalition allies, the Communists - who in Nimes on Sunday lost the last town they ran with a population of more than 100,000 - combined with the strong performance by the Greens will create strains within the ruling plural left alliance and may force Mr Jospin into a cabinet reshuffle.

Indeed, looking ahead to the parliamentary and presidential elections due in spring 2002, the right may find it easier to rally its troops than the left does to run its Socialist-Communist-Greens coalition.

"The right wing is alive and well, make no mistake about it," said Stephane Rozes of the polling organisation, CSA. Michele Alliot-Marie, the RPR chairwoman, said the right had a nationwide majority that extended even to Paris, where the left won a majority of seats on the city council despite polling fewer votes.

The right's biggest challenge will be to avoid the in-fighting that cost it the town halls of both Paris and Lyon. In disarray ever since Mr Chirac dissolved parliament in 1997, the right has been torn apart by squabbling egos. Mr Chirac's weakness after the 1997 general election led to leadership challenges, including from Philippe Séguin, the RPR's defeated mayoral candidate in Paris, and François Bayrou, head of the UDF, who lost to the Socialists in Lyon.

Senior rightwing politicians such as the former prime ministers Alain Juppé and Edouard Balladur have redoubled their efforts to unify France's conservative forces under a single banner before the polls in 2002.

For Mr Chirac's bid to win re-election to the Elysée palace, the loss of Paris was a heavy blow. But it may not yet prove a disaster, since even when helped by a catastrophic conservative campaign in the capital, the left still failed to poll an absolute majority of votes.

For Mr Chirac's bid to win re-election to the Elysée palace, the loss of Paris was a heavy blow. But it may not yet prove a disaster, since even when helped by a catastrophic conservative campaign in the capital, the left still failed to poll an absolute majority of votes.

fields.headline: Paris can only get nicer
fields.trailText: In Paris yesterday, every Socialist was a champagne Socialist. "At last", said Renaud from behind his news stand near the Bastille, dispensing glasses of the bubbly stuff to his early-morning customers, "a nice guy is mayor of a nice city. Parisians can only get nicer, can't they?"
fields.body:
In Paris yesterday, every Socialist was a champagne Socialist. "At last", said Renaud from behind his news stand near the Bastille, dispensing glasses of the bubbly stuff to his early-morning customers, "a nice guy is mayor of a nice city. Parisians can only get nicer, can't they?"

Many were still recovering from an impromptu all-night party outside the city hall where some 10,000 revellers feted the news that for the first time since the Commune of 1871, the French capital was to be run by the left.

The results of Sunday's second round of voting gave the victorious Socialist-Green alliance led by Bertrand Delanoë, a modest if colourless senator, control of 12 arrondissements and 92 of 163 seats on the council. Philippe Séguin, the official candidate of President Jacques Chirac's RPR, won 55 seats, with 13 going to the rebel outgoing mayor, Jean Tiberi, and three to other rightwing forces.

"Today, Parisians chose change," Mr Delanoe, 50 - the first publicly declared homosexual to hold such a high post in France - told cheering supporters early yesterday.

Mr Chirac was mayor of Paris for 18 years from 1977 to 1995, before handing the helm to his loyal former lieutenant, Mr Tiberi. Under them, Paris became a cleaner, smarter, wealthier, more bourgeois and ultimately more boring city. But the town hall also fell prey to more dubious practices.

A mountain of evidence suggests that luxury city apartments were given to friends and relatives for little or no rent, electoral rolls were stuffed with non-existent or even dead voters, some RPR activists received well-paid but wholly fictitious city jobs, and building companies were made to pay multimillion-franc commissions to win public contracts.

The resulting scandal proved fatal to Mr Tiberi, who was kicked out of the RPR late last year but refused to be made a scapegoat and fought a renegade campaign for re-election as mayor.

The new mayor's first move will be to order an independent audit of the city's £3.3bn annual budget, an exercise that could send more embarrassing skeletons tumbling out of the RPR's cupboards.

He also wants to create more green spaces in Europe's most densely-packed capital by taking over unused land from the army and the state railway company, SNCF; to discourage car use in large areas of central Paris, offer cheap bikes for rent at most metro stations and turn the polluted Grands Boulevards into a paradise for pedestrians, cyclists and rollerbladers.

fields.headline: A distant memory
fields.trailText: The Paris Commune, the last time the city was ruled by the left, was proclaimed at the Hotel de Ville on March 26 1871. It lasted for nine weeks, until government troops led by Adolphe Thiers defeated the insurgents.
fields.body:
The Paris Commune, the last time the city was ruled by the left, was proclaimed at the Hotel de Ville on March 26 1871. It lasted for nine weeks, until government troops led by Adolphe Thiers defeated the insurgents. Between 10,000 and 30,000 of them died either during the fighting or were summarily executed afterwards

Population

In 1871 France had a population of roughly 36.1m. Around 2m of them lived in Paris, compared to 2.15m in central Paris (and 9.3m in greater Paris) today. The combined circulation of Parisian newspapers in the early 1870s was more than 700,000.

Both the Tuileries Palace and the Hotel de Ville were destroyed by the members of the Commune, who also killed the archbishop of Paris. "Paris will be ours, or Paris will no longer exist," said the revolutionary leader Louise Michels, a school teacher.

Measures included separating the church from the state, creating workers' cooperatives and freeing art from governmental sanctions. A federation of artists, including Corot, Daumier, Monet and Millet was founded.

Downfall

One of the reasons for the Commune's early downfall was Baron Haussmann, prefect of the Seine from 1853 to 1869, who had pulled down some 27,000 houses to build broad boulevards that would make the construction of barricades more difficult.

The government was so terrified by the events of 1871 that it abolished the capital's executive council and the post of mayor until 1977, when Jacques Chirac was elected.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Home accidents kill 76 a week | You win some, you lose some | BT denies Red Nose profit | 'Doctor' film director dies | More time to drink to Queen
fields.body:
Home accidents kill 76 a week

More people are killed in the home every week - an average of 76 - than die in road accidents (66), government figures reveal today. The causes included fires, carbon monoxide poisoning, burns, drowning, and DIY accidents. In 1999 more than 2.8m people needed hospital treatment following domestic accidents.

You win some, you lose some

Elite barristers with earnings of more than £1m a year lose as many cases as they win, according to a survey published by The Lawyer magazine today. When results of appearances in court of appeal civil cases are analysed chamber by chamber, each wins roughly half.

BT denies Red Nose profit

BT yesterday insisted it gave back all profit it made from Comic Relief calls on Red Nose Day as part of its contribution to the appeal. The telephone firm said it also donated £65,000 cash, spent £25,000 on red noses for vehicles and raised up to £60,000 from promotions.

'Doctor' film director dies

Film director Ralph Thomas, best known for his popular Doctor series, has died in London, aged 85. Starting in 1948, he directed 39 feature films. See Obituaries.

More time to drink to Queen

Pub licensing hours are to be extended by two hours to 1am on June 3 next year as part of the Queen's Golden Jubilee celebration. The extra hours will also apply on New Year's Eve.

webTitle: Vaz 'intervened in City sex bias case'

fields.headline: Vaz 'intervened in City sex bias case'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: A new row broke out last night over the judgment of Keith Vaz after it was revealed that he had used his position as a government minister to intervene on behalf of a 46-year-old Asian woman taking a sex discrimination case against a firm of City lawyers.
fields.body:
A new row broke out last night over the judgment of Keith Vaz after it was revealed that he had used his position as a government minister to intervene on behalf of a 46-year-old Asian woman taking a sex discrimination case against a firm of City lawyers.

The intervention came to light during the Commons inquiry into complaints brought against the Europe minister.

Three MPs on the standards and privileges committee were questioning Sarosh Zaiwalla - the City lawyer who was cleared of making large donations to the minister - when he admitted his relations with Mr Vaz were "very cold" following the minister's intervention in a private case involving his firm.

Mr Zaiwalla told MPs under parliamentary privilege: "I had formally complained to the cabinet secretary [Sir Richard Wilson] and the prime minister, because one of my staff took my firm to the employment tribunal under the Sex Discrimination Act because she was not given a training contract.

"At the hearing, surprise, surprise, the minister of the crown, Mr Vaz, gave evidence - his statement was read out - that the individual was a very fit individual and if he was in my place he would have given her a training contract.

"She had come from the lord chancellor's department to join my firm as an eight week contract in the hope that she would get a training contract. She did not get it, so she alleged that I had exercised bias in favour of a male white and she oddly went back to the lord chancellor's department. She was an employee of the lord chancellor's department when Mr Vaz was a minister there."

During the hearing Mr Zaiwala claimed she "boasted that Gary Hart [Lord Irvine's special adviser] is supporting the proceedings against my firm".

Mr Zaiwalla said he lost the case but has won a right to appeal, after getting a judicial review of the finding in which he had argued that the intervention of the lord chancellor's department had interfered with the balance of the case.

He also disclosed that he had discussed the matter with the minister's wife, Maria Fernandes, during an Indo-European Union economic summit in Lisbon - and she told him that the legal assistant did not have Mr Vaz's authority to produce the letter. "This was a serious matter because that meant that the court had been misled," he told MPs.

"After the matter went to the cabinet secretary, Geoffrey Bindman [Mr Vaz's solicitor] wrote to me confirming exactly what Maria had told me: that Mr Vaz had not authorised her to use the copy of the letter for the lord chancellor's file, signed by Mr Vaz."

The lord chancellor's department said it did not want comment on the case and they say the member of staff is no longer employed there.

Last night Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "This curious case once again questions the judgment of Mr Vaz. He is getting involved in a matter which has clearly nothing to do with his ministerial responsibilities. This is another question that Mr Vaz needs to answer."

His colleague, Andrew Lansley, last night wrote to the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin, formally complaining that Mrs Vaz had not disclosed his business connections with the Hinduja brothers.

Downing Street continued to defend the minister. A spokesman said: "Keith has made a detailed rebuttal of the allegations as they have come up."

fields.headline: Sony compensates Jakarta crush families
fields.trailText: Sony Music yesterday admitted it had paid an undisclosed amount of compensation to the families of four girls who died after collapsing in a crush at a Jakarta shopping mall on Sunday during an event it organised for chart-topping British boy band a1.
fields.body:
Sony Music yesterday admitted it had paid an undisclosed amount of compensation to the families of four girls who died after collapsing in a crush at a Jakarta shopping mall on Sunday during an event it organised for chart-topping British boy band a1.

The record company defended its decision not to inform the band immediately after staff heard of the fatalities. The band were allowed to continue a live television performance for more than 45 minutes and then greet fans waiting at the studio before they were told what had happened.

Sony Music Entertainment Indonesia (SMEI) executives stressed the payout to the parents was "a goodwill gesture" and not an admission of guilt.

"It was not compensation because it can't bring back their children or make up for what happened," said Lala Hamid, the SMEI promotions director. "We are not running from anything. This is just to show our condolences."

"It was a tragic accident for the victims and their families but also for Sony Music."

Jakarta police are still investigating the crush at the Taman Anggrek mall which occurred immediately after Mark, Ben, Christian and Paul arrived at a record shop.

More than 1,000 people had been waiting patiently for hours, so the organisers had no reason to predict a tragedy was in the making, according to SMEI managing director Sutanto Hartono. "Then the crowd suddenly swelled, people started pushing and the hysterical fans started to panic."

A doctor was called and four girls were admitted to intensive care. Within an hour they were dead. The Taman Anggrek management yesterday declined to comment.

webTitle: Haughey critically ill after suffering heart attack

fields.headline: Haughey critically ill after suffering heart attack
fields.trailText: The former Irish prime minister Charles Haughey was critically ill yesterday after suffering a heart attack.
fields.body:
The former Irish prime minister Charles Haughey was critically ill yesterday after suffering a heart attack.

He had emergency surgery after being taken from his north Dublin mansion to the Beaumont hospital in the city. His wife, Maureen, stayed at his bedside. His condition was described as critical but stable.

Mr Haughey, 75, who has been Ireland's leader three times, finally stepped down in 1992. He was recently diagnosed with inoperable prostate cancer. A colourful and controversial character, he had just finished testifying to a tribunal examining alleged payments to politicians from businesses.

Dubbed "Houdini" for his knack of escaping a string of political crises, Mr Haughey faced a criminal charge for not cooperating with a previous judicial inquiry, which found he received a £1m payment from the millionaire supermarket boss Ben Dunne. But the charge was adjourned indefinitely after a judge ruled that he might not get a fair trial. Because of his ill health, Mr Haughey was allowed to give evidence in private to the Moriarty tribunal. The hearing has revealed that a succession of rich benefactors bankrolled his lavish lifestyle for more than 20 years.

Mr Haughey has a £25m Georgian mansion on a 250-acre County Dublin estate, a yacht and a 171-acre island off Kerry. Leader of the Irish Republic's largest political party, Fianna Fail, for 13 years, from 1979-92, he was prime minister from 1979-81, then again for a few months in 1982. The last run was from 1987-92.

He is credited with laying the economic groundwork for Ireland's 1990s "Celtic tiger" boom, and trying to forge better Anglo-Irish relations, despite his strong republican roots and conviction that the two parts of Ireland should be reunited.

He was sacked from the cabinet in 1970 and charged in connection with gun running to the Provisional IRA, but later cleared. He recently made a limited admission concerning this in a television documentary.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Ragged remains of defeated Tory army fight on

fields.headline: Ragged remains of defeated Tory army fight on
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: parliament
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Time to salute the real opposition in this parliament. William Hague, whom older readers might recall as nominal leader of the Conservative party, doesn't seem to be doing an awful lot.
fields.body:
Time to salute the real opposition in this parliament. William Hague, whom older readers might recall as nominal leader of the Conservative party, doesn't seem to be doing an awful lot. One assumes that he is keeping up with his judo and, between falls, chatting busily away to his friend Sebastian Coe - although since I have never heard Lord Coe utter a single word, I wouldn't know.

I'm sure that his Australian spin-mistress, Amanda Platell, keeps him amused during the long dreary hours of the day. She is a charming and diverting woman. Many a time she and I have rubbed zinc cream on each other's noses, then nipped down to the OTB pub for a Castlemaine XXXX drinking contest, which she invariably wins.

But it all leaves the question: what on earth does Mr Hague find to do all day? He's already fired anyone who's any good from the shadow cabinet, and it can't take more than 20 minutes to prepare for prime minister's question time each week.

In the meantime, the real opposition is being carried out by a small, dedicated team of troublemakers on the Tory benches. If it weren't for them, the government would get away with everything, not just almost everything. They are like guerrillas fighting in the forests and hills, the rag-taggle remains of a defeated army. Labour may hold the towns and fields, but they never know when a sniper might open fire, a ball-bearing factory set on fire, the telegraph line brought down.

Not all of the motley crew were present for defence questions yesterday, but John Bercow was. He always is. He is indefatigable. The MP for Buckingham shot up a single longing glance at a young female colleague of mine in the press gallery, but then returned to glowering angrily at the ministerial team in front of him.

Mr Bercow is nominally a frontbench spokesman on home affairs - Mini-me to Ann Widdecombe's Dr Evilette - but he is really only happy barking away from the backbenches. Yesterday he accused the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, of making a pact with the French to destroy Nato. The notion of a secret treaty had a fine old-fashioned ring. ("If this paper were to fall into the wrong hands, Mr Holmes, the consequences for Europe would be incalculable ..")

Step forward Julian Lewis. He also attacked the French. "Are they going to allocate a single extra soldier, sailor or airman for the defence of Europe?" he demanded furiously. Mr Hoon looked flustered by all these attacks on our froggie friends. Mr Lewis, like Mr Bercow, is certainly several cherries short of a clafoutis, but that doesn't make him any less effective.

Iain Duncan-Smith - in name the main defence spokesman, but in practice an attack backbencher - had a go at the prime minister, but via the French. Who had Tony Blair meant when he said there were some people who wanted to destroy Nato? He persisted several times. Mr Hoon looked more worried.

Also in attendance were the other guerrillas: Desmond Swayne, the cad of the New Forest, Gerald Howarth, who is becoming persistent and vicious, Anne McIntosh, who I have been rude about in the past, but who is developing a nice line in anxious nagging.

Then there is Edward Leigh, red-faced with fury at the government's misdeeds, and even Michael Fabricant who has, thankfully, given up his attempt to become a world statesman and has settled for the more honourable role of troublemaker.

These people almost never miss a sitting. Where Mr Hague is in the meantime, we cannot know, though I myself have enjoyed the new version of Crossroads.

webTitle: Pile of carcasses is mere glimpse of complex task

fields.headline: Pile of carcasses is mere glimpse of complex task
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Pictures of piles of animal carcasses decomposing in open fields while awaiting the building of pyres are proving a public relations disaster for the Ministry of Agriculture.
fields.body:
Pictures of piles of animal carcasses decomposing in open fields while awaiting the building of pyres are proving a public relations disaster for the Ministry of Agriculture.

The idea of rats, crows and magpies feasting on diseased meat and spreading foot and mouth further is macabre, although any transmission of the disease by this means is extremely unlikely, according to veterinary experts.

Yesterday the animals to be slaughtered passed the 300,000 mark, 50% more than at the same stage of the 1967 outbreak.

The logistics of disposing of the carcasses are enormous, and involve many stages, including the undertaking of an independent valuation of each animal to be killed.

The first stage is diagnosis of the disease or the making of a decision that animals must be killed because they are in dangerous contact with the disease.

Farmers can chose the valuer they want to look at the stock in question. In the case of thousands of sheep on a mountainside, getting them all in one place to be valued individually, and then to be slaughtered, is a major exercise. In Cumbria, 89 outbreaks, and Dumfries and Galloway, 46 cases, valuation is taking time, especially when farmers request a valuer already busy elsewhere.

With rare breeds and pedigree cattle, valuations can vary wildly, and there is an appeals process the farmer can invoke. The ministry is trying hard to streamline this appeal and the consequent delay, but is also anxious not to negate the right to appeal.

The next priority, as chief vet Jim Scudamore has repeatedly said, is to get the animals dead. There are 17 slaughtering teams operating in Cumbria. Priority is given first to pigs, cattle second, and sheep third.

Pigs produce most virus once infected, and simply by breathing can spread it in plumes to infect animals several miles away. Cattle rarely spread the disease more than half a mile. Sheep spread it almost entirely only by contact.

Once animals are dead, the virus begins to die as the bodies decompose. So while the sight of the bodies is appalling, the disease risk has been minimised. There remains the problem of disposal.

Burying has not been used much because of a risk of of contamination of the water supply. However, the effort of building dozens of pyres with thousands of tonnes of straw, railway sleepers and coal has proved difficult. Rendering plants have been hired to run 24 hours a day, seven days a week, as an alternative, and four will soon be in operation.

But burning and rendering are not enough to cope, and yesterday Cumbria county council gave permission for carcasses to be landfilled, although no suitable site has been found so far.

For apparently healthy stock that the ministry wants to kill in case, a new disposal is being organised. Abattoirs idle because they are inside infected areas will kill thousands of animals and place them in cold store to be rendered later.

fields.headline: Warming will raise water bills
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Britain's domestic water users face higher bills to cope with the growing effects of global warming, the industry's trade body warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's domestic water users face higher bills to cope with the growing effects of global warming, the industry's trade body warned yesterday.

Pamela Taylor, chief executive of Water UK, said Ofwat, the industry regulator, had fudged the issue of climate change at its last price review. Charges may have to rise to cover the extra cost of coping with climate change and increased pollution. The issue had to be addressed now, she said, because it could take up to 25 years to put in place the measures such as the construction of reservoirs.

Ofwat would have to take the extra costs into account when it reviewed water charges in four year. This means that last year's reduction in bills - the first since the water companies were privatised in 1989 - could be short-lived.

"We now know that we must expect wetter winter conditions, and longer drier sum mers, and that extreme weather conditions will happen more often and will be more severe," she said.

The recent floods had reduced the industry's ability to supply its 24m customers. Pumping stations and treatment works had been put out of action and industrial pollution had been carried into underground water sources.

She said that if water became polluted or resources dried up, companies would have to seek alternative supplies from further afield, almost inevitably resulting in extra energy, chemicals and sludge disposal costs.

Graham Setterfield, a director of Water UK, said: "Society today is using a cocktail of chemicals and that is finding its way into the water supply underground or in rivers."

Industry leaders also said they were concerned at the growing demand for water in the south-east, where about 4m homes are to be built.

fields.headline: At this price? Chorion
fields.trailText: Chorion, the company that emerged out of Trocadero - the property firm based on the hi-tech attraction off Piccadilly Circus - is an unusual concoction of businesses. It owns trendy London nightspots such as Tiger Tiger, aimed at an affluent over-25s professional crowd, as well as the intellectual property rights to Noddy and Hercule Poirot.
fields.body:
Chorion, the company that emerged out of Trocadero - the property firm based on the hi-tech attraction off Piccadilly Circus - is an unusual concoction of businesses. It owns trendy London nightspots such as Tiger Tiger, aimed at an affluent over-25s professional crowd, as well as the intellectual property rights to Noddy and Hercule Poirot.

Despite the mixture the group seems to be doing something right. Chorion yesterday announced a pretax profit of £9.5m from a loss of £8.8m last year. Turnover rose 37% to £35.3m.

"The nightclubs and bars have been the key driver," Chorion's chief executive Nick Tamblyn said. "I think we have hit upon a very successful formula which is an over-25 bar with a club and restaurant. People often come from work for a drink and stay until 2am."

This business does indeed look lucrative, accounting as it does for almost three quarters of the company's sales.

The group has just opened clubs in Manchester and Birmingham, and is looking to acquire and develop five more in cities including Dublin, Nottingham and Bristol. In 2003 the group plans to take the Tiger Tiger brand to major European cities.

The intellectual property side of the business - the company owns the rights to Enid Blyton's literary canon and has a 64% stake in Agatha Christie's creations - is contributing to growth, but it is playing catch up. Profits from this division were 13% better at £4.7m.

But the real disappointment yesterday came from the company's decision to put on ice its long-mooted plans to demerge the two parts of the business.

According to analysts the full value of the business will not be released until demerger. Although Chorion would not give an indication of the time scale, any move to separate the two sides of the business will probably not go ahead for 12 months or so.

Nevertheless, there is lots of potential for growth and the business is looking good for the future. Buy.

fields.headline: Invensys stymied
fields.trailText: Trying to spot the companies with an above average exposure to the slowing US economy is the City's favourite parlour game at the moment.
fields.body:
Trying to spot the companies with an above average exposure to the slowing US economy is the City's favourite parlour game at the moment.

One company that looks particularly vulnerable, according to analysts at JP Morgan, is Invensys, the controls and automation group.

JP Morgan reckons North America accounted for 47% of Invensys' revenues in the period 1990-2000, with the world's other hot spot, Japan, making up a further 5-6%. It thinks the sharp deterioration in these economies will hit performance and has lowered its earnings forecast for 2001 by 21% and for the following year by 17%, meaning Invensys will have difficulty in achieving the financial targets it set in November.

On the bright side, JP Morgan believes the shares are worth 160p - slightly above last night's closing price of 139p. Invensys is to issue a trading update soon.

fields.headline: Gene therapy for Syngenta
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Syngenta, the world's leading agribusiness company, says it has been besieged by hundreds of requests for access to its map of the genetic structure of rice since completing the project in January.
fields.body:
Syngenta, the world's leading agribusiness company, says it has been besieged by hundreds of requests for access to its map of the genetic structure of rice since completing the project in January.

The group, which yesterday announced a 19% increase in annual profits to $450m (£315m), unravelled the 430m-letter DNA code to design more nourishing, pest resistant strains of rice.

It has pledged to make the information available free to scientists helping subsistence farmers. Syngenta is reviewing applications for access from hundreds of academics who believe the information should be available to all.

Syngenta's head of research and technology, David Evans, said: "The progress we've made with the rice genome really knocks your socks off - we completed the project in just 18 months."

The first product arising from the map, a grain of rice with "markers" displaying different traits, is likely to be on the market within three years.

Syngenta's rice project has alarmed environmental groups such as Action Aid, which point out that rice is a staple for half the planet's population. Charities are concerned about the power multinationals such as Syngenta could exercise over the world's food supply.

Despite its increase in profits, Syngenta revealed a 4% fall in second-half sales due to wet weather in Europe and surplus crops elsewhere. Revenue from its crop protection business, which makes pesticides, was down 11% to $2.16bn. Chief executive Michael Pragnell said: "Very wet autumn weather affected winter cropping - that hit growers right across Europe."

Elsewhere after three years of good harvests, prices had softened and farmers had lacked the confidence to invest in chemicals to boost yields.

Mr Pragnell said he expected little relief this year: "We're not planning on any overall market improvement."

The firm was established last year through a combination of the agribusinesses of AstraZeneca and Novartis.

The merger is likely to create cost savings of $525m by 2004 - partly through the loss of 3,000 jobs.

webTitle: Dow jumps ahead of Fed meeting

fields.headline: Dow jumps ahead of Fed meeting
fields.standfirst: Bank of Japan returns to policy of zero interest rates
fields.trailText: Hopes that the Federal Reserve will announce deep cuts in US interest rates tonight to revive the American economy helped shares rebound on Wall Street in early trading yesterday.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts in Tokyo and Larry Elliott
fields.body:
Hopes that the Federal Reserve will announce deep cuts in US interest rates tonight to revive the American economy helped shares rebound on Wall Street in early trading yesterday.

Following last week's relentless fall in share prices, dealers were hoping that the Fed's open market committee would follow the lead of the Bank of Japan, which yesterday announced that it would let interest rates fall to zero in a bid to haul the country out of its deflationary spiral.

Wall Street has already factored in a cut of 50 basis points from the Fed, with some analysts expecting a reduction of 75 basis points following the confidence-sapping falls in both the Dow Jones industrial average and the hi-tech Nasdaq index last week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average had added around 150 points by late afternoon in New York, al though the FTSE 100 index edged lower in the day.

US treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill said that he saw no value in commenting on fluctuating stock prices on a daily basis. "The markets go up and the markets go down. If you've been watching them as long as I have, you know that," Mr O'Neill said in response to a question whether he was practising a policy of benign neglect toward recent big losses in the market.

In Tokyo, the small fall in the Nikkei Dow index occurred before the Bank of Japan announced that it would allow interest rates to fall to zero and then keep them there until prices had stopped falling. Under intense political and international pressure, the policy board of the central bank agreed during an eight-hour meeting to take steps towards the establishment of Japan's first inflation target, expanded purchases of government bonds and return to the money-for-nothing policy that it abandoned last August.

The measures - radical by the bank's conservative standards - create monetary tools that could allow Japan's financial authorities to actively promote inflation to offset a vicious cycle of falling prices, declining profits and stagnant consumption. Masamu Hayami, the bank's governor, said the policy shift reflected the darkening of the economic outlook in recent months.

"Japan's economy has failed to return to a path of sustainable growth and is once more faced with the threat of deterioration," he said.

"These measures show the central bank's determination to prevent a continuous decline of prices."

Since it raised interest rates from zero last August, the central bank has been used as a political punchbag by the ruling Liberal Democratic party, which blames Mr Hayami for renewed fears of a financial crisis, record unemployment and worrying signs of a deflationary spiral.

The governor was defiant yesterday, however, saying that the recent decline of the economy was the result of external factors - the slowdown in the United States, which is Japan's biggest export market - and the government's failure to implement reforms.

Under the new policy, the central bank will switch its main target in the money markets from the overnight call rate - which determines the premium for interbank borrowing - to its current account for bank reserves.

fields.headline: Broker warns of tougher times
fields.trailText: Stockbroker Collins Stewart, which nearly doubled its profits last year, yesterday warned that it would be hard to match that performance if the poor market and economic conditions continued.
fields.body:
Stockbroker Collins Stewart, which nearly doubled its profits last year, yesterday warned that it would be hard to match that performance if the poor market and economic conditions continued.

The company reported a pretax profit of £29.1m for last year, despite the distractions of its management buyout from investment bank Singer & Friedlander and its stock market flotation.

Terry Smith, the group's chief executive, said: "Not only did our stockbroking business achieve a substantial increase in turnover and profit during 2000, but the operating profits were also higher in the second half than in the first half of the year."

Mr Smith and his fellow directors own 20% of the company.

Its shares ended yesterday at 320p, or 4p above the level at which they were placed in the market in October. City sources believe they have performed well in the light of the stock market rout which has seen many smaller brokers nursing losses on hi-tech stocks.

The company used the £70m it raised at flotation to reduce debt, and the board said it expected to generate sufficient cash over the next few years to repay much of the remaining borrowings.

Mr Smith said that the company was planning to develop its Quest online data base and share evaluation system. He said the directors were committed to establishing a broader range of activities to protect against a downturn in any specific area.

webTitle: BT may have to swap blood for money

fields.headline: BT may have to swap blood for money
fields.standfirst: Investors not in a charitable mood
fields.trailText: Today's meeting between BT and some of its leading shareholders will be a fraught affair. BT is in a bind. It needs to cut its £30bn debt burden. If it doesn't the agencies are likely to cut its credit rating. On the other hand selling assets at depressed prices - current market conditions preclude any other outcome - will lead to accusations that the group is destroying shareholder value.
fields.body:
Today's meeting between BT and some of its leading shareholders will be a fraught affair. BT is in a bind. It needs to cut its £30bn debt burden. If it doesn't the agencies are likely to cut its credit rating. On the other hand selling assets at depressed prices - current market conditions preclude any other outcome - will lead to accusations that the group is destroying shareholder value.

The best way out of the impasse would be a rights issue. The figure being touted is £5bn. Certainly that would give the group breathing space. It would allow it to put forward plans for floating parts of the group - BT Wireless, for example - but without tying itself to a timetable that would effectively put disposals in the firesale category.

Cutting the dividend, that symbol of corporate virility, would also help to conserve cash. Companies are understandably reluctant to contemplate such a course and BT would take a fair degree of flak, but in the present circumstances it needs to show that it is prepared to take difficult decisions.

But can and should investors be persuaded to swallow such a package? The answer is a qualified yes. Despite its problems, BT should not be confused with a basket case. As analysts at Deutsche Bank have noted; the balance sheet problems can be resolved and there is "considerable value" within the group. There is the cold comfort argument, too, that investors may be pre pared to go along, if only because the alternatives are worse.

The question is whether they will have sufficient confidence in the incumbent management to deliver. Expect blood on the carpet as the price of support.

BHP fighting fit

The deal between BHP and Billiton looks to have been designed to provide something for almost everyone. By opting for a dual-listed company structure the combined entity will be able to keep primary listings in Australia and in the UK. That maintains an exposure to the bigger London market without the inevitable ruffling of Australian sensibilities which would have followed BHP hoisting its corporate flag in the UK. Yet the unified management should avoid any suggestion of divided councils.

The commercial logic looks sound, too. The two companies are a good fit. The degree of overlap is unlikely to cause regulatory palpitations. Meanwhile BHP and Billiton are able to argue that they are taking a leading role in the consolidation in the industry - helping to shape events, rather than being forced to follow the lead of others. Though both companies played down any idea the deal was driven by defensive considerations, they should be better placed to survive a downturn in the industry together than separately.

Certainly investors seemed to like the deal. BHP shares were up modestly, Billiton shares up rather more sharply as the market digested the 20% premium on offer.

The key question is the attitude of Anglo American, which holds just over 7% of Billiton and which has long been seen as a possible bidder. Yesterday Anglo was playing its cards extremely close to its chest. The betting in the City, however, is it will have to pay a hefty premium if it wants to disrupt the deal.

Greenspan's goal

As far as Wall Street is concerned, Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan is back on the hook. January's two interest rate cuts helped tumbling markets to take a breather and even rally. But now fear has set in again and Mr Greenspan is being asked to deliver yet further cuts. A reduction of 50 basis points, which would take rates down to 5%, is the least that is expected - some are looking for 75 basis points.

If Mr Greenspan fails to deliver, the likelihood is that he will spark further falls in equity prices.

But should he worry? Well, perhaps. It may be that the gloom that has pervaded the markets of late does have a knock-on effect, particularly in the US. It affects corporate investment and consumer spending. The last thing the global economy needs now is a further slowdown in the US.

Despite the falls, equity prices in some sectors still remain out of line with the underlying performance of the economy. Some price-earnings ratios are still on the seriously scary side. A deep Fed cut might provide a reprieve, but it is rebalancing which is needed.

Mr Greenspan also knows that American consumers are about to get a welcome tax cut from President Bush. Too steep a cut in interest rates would risk over-egging the pudding.

fields.headline: Tata to float IT arm
fields.trailText: India's most venerable industrial group, Tata, is planning to defy the gloom which has enveloped technology stocks by floating its successful software wing, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
India's most venerable industrial group, Tata, is planning to defy the gloom which has enveloped technology stocks by floating its successful software wing, it emerged last night.

The company is considering making an initial public offering for Tata Consultancy Services, or TCS, Asia's largest software exporter.

The move would see Tata selling a 10% stake in TCS. The new firm's shares would be simultaneously listed in the local and US Nasdaq markets, said a source who asked not to be identified.

Tata is one of the subcontinent's largest industrial groups, with huge interests in steel, tea, watches, software and five-star hotels.

Some divisions have performed well in recent years - notably Titan watches - while others have been run "sleepily", the source said. "It is a fairly ramshackle group. They are trying to impose some discipline," he added.

TCS has a much lower profile than its two main rivals in India's burgeoning software market - Infosys and Wipro - even though its sales are twice as big. Both rivals are growing at a much faster rate.

The Tatas, one of Bombay's most illustrious Parsi families, have always maintained they were in no hurry to give TCS a public listing.

The issue is expected to hit the markets in the second half of this year. Before that, the Tata group will spin TCS into a separate company.

Analysts said the offering would enhance TCS's image abroad, improve growth prospects and provide another way of compensating key staff through stock options.

The value of Indian tech stocks has slumped in the meltdown on world markets. An insider trading scandal also rattled investors this month and led to the resignation of the president of the Bombay stock exchange.

fields.headline: Marconi pays for radio silence
fields.trailText: For a company that specialises in communications, Marconi has been of late surprisingly reluctant to talk.
fields.body:
For a company that specialises in communications, Marconi has been of late surprisingly reluctant to talk.

It last updated the City on trading in November and, despite a dramatic change in the fundamentals of the telecommunications equipment industry, has said nothing since.

The latest blow to the sector came yesterday, when Corning, the world leader in fibre-optic cable, said its profits would fall short of Wall Street's forecasts.

This came on top of warnings from Nokia, Alcatel, Ericsson and Siemens in recent weeks which have caused analysts to readjust their assumptions about the industry.

In view of Marconi's radio silence it is hardly surprising that the investors have been giving the stock a wide berth. Last night the shares - 719p at the start of the year - stood at 364p, after falling 28p.

Analysts find it almost inconceivable that Marconi has escaped unscathed from the downturn in telecoms spending - especially as most of its revenues come from the slowing US economy.

Citing this factor, analysts at CSFB, one of Marconi's brokers, yesterday sharply reduced profits and sales forecasts. For 2001, CSFB is now looking for earnings before interest and tax of £792m, rather than the £885m previously, and for the following year, £1.01bn against £1.10bn before.

Although CSFB has retained a "buy" rating on the stock - it says Marconi is cheap compared with its peers - others are not quite as confident. With the joint house broker cutting its estimates just before Marconi goes into its quiet period, ahead of full figures in May, traders sense bad news is on the way.

In the wider market, dealers had to endure a lacklustre session notable only for strong gains in the mining sector after Billiton , up 24p to 544p, confirmed it was merging with Australian rival BHP. Rio Tinto , 20p stronger at £12.05, and Lonmin , 49p better at 925.5p, both benefited from hopes of further consolidation.

However, with most of the Square Mile content to sit on its hands until the US Federal Reserve concludes its latest rate-setting meeting today, the FTSE 100 index slipped 11.2 points to 5,551.6 - its lowest close since December 14 1998. Economists expect Fed chairman Alan Greenspan to lower rates by at least 50 basis-points.

Most of the downside came from the telecoms sector - with Energis , 38.5p worse at 310.5p, and Colt Telecom , 70p weaker at 825p - both posting heavy losses on the back of the news from Corning.

Technology stocks were also weak. The FTSE Techmark 100 index dipped 50.48 points to 2,018.45 with software accountancy group Sage - down 10p to 250p - failing to recover from Friday's mauling.

Dealers attributed the fall to negative noises from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.

Following a meeting with the company, the broker revealed that it had reduced its target price and trimmed its estimates because of the deteriorating prospects on the other side of the Atlantic.

But it was not just hi-tech issues that were feeling the chill from the US economic slowdown. Mail order specialist GUS shed 20p to 450p after UBS Warburg lowered its forecasts - citing concerns that Experian, its American credit rating agency, will lose market share in the downturn, just as it did in last year.

On the second tier, positive feedback from recent presentations helped troubled engineer Tomkins rise 5.5p to 157p.

Meanwhile, property group Great Portland Estates was 7p higher at 277.5p on news that Capital & Counties, a subsidiary of rival Liberty - down 1p to 541.5p - has increased its holding to 7.56%.

In the smaller company universe, tiny building services company Cape ended unchanged at 16p after YJL - which remained steady at 25.75p - declared that it had added to its 15% stake by buying 1m shares on Friday.

Some traders believe that YJL is probably positioning itself to make an approach - despite the fact that Cape is facing legal claims from workers for asbestos poisoning.

fields.headline: US Pru chief's £100m option
fields.standfirst: Shareholders push to stop head of American General cashing in on £17bn merger
fields.trailText: Shareholders are expected to put pressure on the Prudential insurance company to stop the head of American General cashing in more than $150m (£100m) of share options and bonuses as soon as the $24bn takeover by the British company is finalised.
fields.body:
Shareholders are expected to put pressure on the Prudential insurance company to stop the head of American General cashing in more than $150m (£100m) of share options and bonuses as soon as the $24bn takeover by the British company is finalised.

Bob Devlin, the chairman and chief executive of the US insurer, is set to receive more than $150m once the proposed merger with the Prudential is completed as his shares and options will all immediately be able to be realised. The payouts were designed to reward long-term shareholder performance. Mr Devlin has agreed to head the Pru's US operations following the merger.

Nell Minow, a US corporate governance activist, said yesterday that Mr Devlin should be made to keep his options for several years rather than vesting them all at once under the accelerated provision allowed by the takeover rules. "If we believe that money has a motivational impact, we must look more carefully at what it's motivating them to do."

The revelations about Mr Devlin's stock holdings come as the Pru is conducting a transatlantic charm offensive in an attempt to convince both British and US shareholders to accept the deal.

British shareholders have already erased 11% from the value of the all-share offer since it was announced last week as they fear the Pru is overpaying for American General at the start of a downturn in the US economy. Several big investors are expected to discuss the terms of Mr Devlin's contract during their meetings with senior management about the takeover.

Neither the Pru nor American General would comment on the details of Mr Devlin's share option package yester day, citing the fact that an official takeover document will be published in a few weeks.

However, both sides are understood to be negotiating an agreement under which the 60-year-old Mr Devlin will keep a stake in the combined company, rather than cashing out of the merged venture. Mr Devlin also has a 30-year rolling contract, which could lead to a $15m pay and bonus award even if he leaves after just 12 months.

The size of Mr Devlin's payout comes in sharp contrast to that for Jonathan Bloomer, the Prudential's chief executive. Mr Bloomer earned a total of £666,000 last year in salary and bonus whereas Mr Devlin earned almost $5m. The pay differential is expected to continue after the merger in spite of the fact that the American executive will be reporting to Mr Bloomer as the head of the company.

The disparity is likely to raise fresh concerns that the Prudential will increase British executive pay to bring it into line with the US once the merger is completed. "These takeovers tend to catapult executives to American levels of compensation," said Ms Minow.

The largest component of Mr Devlin's package relates to shares and short-term options he already owns, according to a report in yesterday's London Financial News.

He also owns restricted stock worth $20m and more than $5m under an incentive scheme that is meant to realise if certain long-term performance targets are met.

Mr Devlin was also awarded 1.35m share options worth $22.6m last year, when he was understood to have approached several potential suitors about a takeover. Prudential's share price has fallen 11% since the deal was announced last Monday.

webTitle: Leek humbled as RPI's weakest link

fields.headline: Leek humbled as RPI's weakest link
fields.trailText: Just as the Welsh were getting over the shock of being "rubbished" by TV presenter Anne Robinson, Britain's official number crunchers have added insult to injury by consigning leeks to the statistical dustbin.
fields.body:
Just as the Welsh were getting over the shock of being "rubbished" by TV presenter Anne Robinson, Britain's official number crunchers have added insult to injury by consigning leeks to the statistical dustbin.

The vegetable - one of the principality's national symbols - has been dropped from the notional basket of goods and services used by the office of national statistics to calculate the retail prices index.

After careful monitoring of the nation's shopping habits, the ONS says consumers are no longer buying enough leeks to justify their inclusion.

The basket, containing 650 items, is reviewed every February and altered to reflect spending patterns. Out go items on which spending is falling; in come those on which consumers are spending more. An ONS spokesman said the agency did not always publicise the goods and services rejected out of consideration to industry.

But that sensitivity does not seem to extend to leek growers or producers of salad cream and streaky bacon, which have also been given the chop.

Martyn Jones MP, chairman of the Commons Welsh affairs committee, said: "I think it's disgraceful, another example of the English discriminating against the Welsh. It shows a deep-seated leek envy in the English population."

He admitted, however, that the economic impact on Wales was likely to be limited. "I think all our leeks come from East Anglia," he said.

Other items to be dropped include Rainbow trout, nests of tables, bread bins, women's ski pants, jigsaw puzzles, sterilised delivered milk and bank custody of sealed envelopes.

In their place come overdraft charges, home removal costs, baseball caps, lager "stubbies", laminate flooring and greeting cards. Reflecting the nation's growing appetite for foreign holidays, healthy living and hi-tech, the RPI will now also include sunscreen lotion, foreign exchange commission, computer desks, DVDs, mini-disc players, fizzy energy drinks, organic fruit and vegetables, herbal teabags and membership of health clubs.

Most of the data is derived from the Family Expenditure Survey, a regular poll of more than 7,000 households.

webTitle: Exit stage left Eyre quits media group RTL

fields.headline: Exit stage left Eyre quits media group RTL
fields.trailText: Richard Eyre has resigned from RTL, the pan-European media group best known in Britain for its majority holding in Channel 5.
fields.body:
Richard Eyre has resigned from RTL, the pan-European media group best known in Britain for its majority holding in Channel 5.

The departure of Mr Eyre, above, who was head of content and strategy, had long been anticipated amid speculation that he had found the job frustrating. It is believed that he does not have another job to go to.

Mr Eyre, 46, replaced Greg Dyke as the head of Pearson Television just a week before discussions were opened to merge the business with CLT Ufa. The deal was concluded three months later to form RTL.

Mr Eyre, who had formerly been chief executive of the ITV network, found himself in a bigger company but with a far diminished role, reporting to chief executive Didier Bellens and chief operating officer Ewald Walgenbach.

Insiders said he felt it was "the decent thing to do" to stay with RTL and see through the merger but was now keen to move back to a chief executive role. The departure is said to have been entirely amicable.

He was on a one-year contract and is believed to be taking three months off to write a book before starting a search for full-time work. "He found the auton omy issue a bit of a problem. He had been a chief executive for nine years and did find it a little frustrating, although he had a good relationship with Didier," said one insider.

The company is expected to make the announcement at the presentation of its full-year results tomorrow. He is thought to have been replaced by Tony Cohen, chief executive of worldwide production at RTL.

Prior to the top job at ITV, Mr Eyre had been chief executive of Capital Radio.

His career began at advertising agency Benton Bowles, where he planned campaigns for the likes of Camay soap.

fields.body:
Britain's biggest furniture retailer, MFI, has reached the "end of the beginning" of its recovery with annual profits up 55% to £45.4m - and it plans to open five more Conran-designed stores.

The firm, which has been under new management for two years, has sold a series of properties to repay debts and been making efforts to shed its rough and ready image.

Its latest initiative, an edge of town superstore in Speke planned by Conran Design, has proved popular - soaring sales have taken it up from 165th in MFI's ranking to 50th after three weeks of trading.

The group's finance director, Martin Clifford-King, said: "We've been trying to add style without moving upmarket - we're still very much a mass market retailer."

The store features more "real life" displays, with furniture laid out in the way it might look in customers' homes. Five more are planned this year at a cost of £500,000 each - two in Birmingham and one each in Hamilton, Falkirk and Oldham.

MFI is also rolling out its embryonic chain of smaller high street shops, with 20 to open this year and 50 planned within three years at an investment of £250,000 each. Mr Clifford-King said: "We're looking for new routes to market - whether through high street stores or through Hygena kitchens concessions in Curry's shops."

In an attempt to diversify from kitchens and bedrooms, MFI is dipping a toe in the bathrooms market, with trial ranges on sale in 10 of its 190 stores. MFI's shares closed down 2.75p yesterday at 96.75p. Profits were below expectations of £46m-£48m, but analyst Isabelle Payet of Credit Lyonnaise said: "I thought their message was quite strong. As long as they take it slowly and see if the new formats succeed, these openings are a good move."

MFI said its current trading was strong, with sales since Boxing day up 10.5%. It considered changing its name last year but chief executive John Hancock decided against it after a survey showed that 6,000 out of 8,500 shoppers felt well disposed towards the brand.

webTitle: £1bn currency hit wipes out EADS profits

fields.headline: £1bn currency hit wipes out EADS profits
fields.standfirst: Airbus proves main earner for merged entity
fields.trailText: European aerospace and defence group EADS yesterday voted itself a success - even though it clocked up heavy losses last year, including a €1.4bn (£880m) currency hit.
fields.body:
European aerospace and defence group EADS yesterday voted itself a success - even though it clocked up heavy losses last year, including a €1.4bn (£880m) currency hit.

The group, created last July from a merger of Germany's DaimlerChrysler Aerospace, France's Aerospatiale-Matra and Spain's Casa, said its core profits were on the increase -driven by a strong performance from Airbus, the civil aircraft maker in which it holds an 80% stake. Britain's BAE Systems holds the remaining 20%.

Although the group reported a net loss of €909m for the year 2000, it said the figures included a charge of €1.4bn against a high year-end dollar exchange rate and the accounting treatment of currency hedging positions taken out before the merger.

Earnings before tax, interest, goodwill and exceptionals rose 11% to €1.4bn, sales increased 7% to €24.2bn while the order intake was up 50% to €49bn. But earnings before interest and tax from Airbus alone accounted for €1.4bn.

The group is predicting that sales and earnings before interest and tax will both rise by 15% in the current year while it expects to cut costs by streamlining its headquarters functions. Up to 600 jobs are expected to go, although EADS said many employees would be reassigned to other areas within the business.

Joint chief executive officer Philippe Camus said: "The figures presented today demonstrate that EADS delivered and even exceeded its first business year profit targets, proving that our merger is already a success."

The group acknowledged some concern that the downturn in the global economy could force some airlines to seek to delay the delivery of aircraft ordered when demand was more robust.

"There is always discretion," said Mr Camus. Analysts, however, noted that demand had been running ahead of the combined capacity of Airbus and its only rival, Boeing, and that a fall in demand could help to restore the balance between supply and demand.

EADS is seeking to build up its defence arm, which accounts for less than a fifth of total sales, but it ruled out an exclusive alliance with one of the leading American groups.

"We are discussing - with all the big players in the US -the potential for cooperation," said joint chief executive Rainer Hertrich.

webTitle: All together now ... Danny Leigh on corporate anthems.

fields.headline: All together now . . .
fields.standfirst: The Tories aren't the only ones penning musical themes as a marketing ploy. In the business world, corporate anthems are the latest big thing.  Danny Leigh reports on the rise of an alarming trend
fields.trailText: The Tories aren't the only ones penning musical themes as a marketing ploy. In the business world, corporate anthems are the latest big thing. Danny Leigh reports on the rise of an alarming trend.
fields.body:
A piano gently tinkles. A cheap synthesiser set to "orchestral" whines in the background. Finally, the swell turns to outright bombast, and a gaggle of voices lets rip, clear, bold and passionate. And the voices sing this: "KPMG/ We're strong as can be/A dream of power and energy/We go for the goal/Together we hold/On to our vision of global strategy..."

Welcome to musical hell. A place where men and women trill glutinous couplets about teamwork and customer care. These are corporate anthems - vainglorious paeans to company spirit, designed to entice clients and inspire staff.

The tune (of sorts) above, extolling the virtues of chartered accountants KPMG and titled Our Vision of a Global Strategy, is just one among many - the tip of a terrible, oncoming iceberg. And it is not only corporate types who have fallen for the cult, an ear-splitting masterclass in kamikaze marketing. Last week it was announced that William Hague had commissioned an inspiring election theme for the Tories, penned by the songwriter Mike Batt, is the man behind Remember You're a Womble.

But it doesn't end there. You can wig out to management consultancy Pricewaterhouse Coopers's Your World; sway to the lilting calypso of Media-Apps' Back To The Net ("Aggregating information/It's a part of business"); or savour a hip-hop number from IT specialists Asera, wherein the world's most soul less man opines that "Asera's crib is the place to be".

There are more. Lots more. One anthem aficionado, Chris Raettig, has compiled a website dedicated to a startling collection of corporate musical horrors. Amid the litany of unlikely concepts claimed by journalists as the new rock'n'roll, the latest would appear to be corporate finance and customised software solutions.

Not, however, that the companies' UK operations seem particularly keen. Call KPMG to discuss Our Vision Of Global Strategy, and you'll hear a slightly mirthless laugh. "Er, it's Dutch," says a spokesman. "It was written for a local marketing campaign. In Holland." Nothing to do with you then? "Er, no. Definitely not." Neither, sadly, will Pricewaterhouse Coopers admit responsibility for Your World, and its rousing melange of driving keyboards and recruitment advice. "Actually, it was done by one of our European branches. Funny, isn't it? Have you heard the one by KPMG?" The sound of skeletons being hurriedly shoved back into cupboards is deafening.

But that may change. Over at "online creatives" Bluewave - whose dance-flavoured Dive Right In is another popular draw on Raettig's site - the future, however atonal, beckons. Talking eagerly of "audio identities as a part of corporate representation", group brand director Pad Bray sees the company theme not as an embarrassment, but a potent weapon. "Few things in the world can equal the power of music," he ponders. "It can inspire, and corral. Lyrically, for instance, we wanted something that conveyed our brand, and our brand is tied in with the aquatic environment. Hence Dive Right In. The lyrics should fit the metaphor, yeah?"

This could be one of the reasons why the new wave of corporate rock is increasingly likely to be produced in-house. Bluewave's effort, for example, was put together by Bray over three days using the company's own facilities. "Basically, we realised that with digital technology we could do this ourselves, rather than face the prohibitive cost of farming it out. So, within the company, I was able to provoke people. To say OK, put this in your ears and tell me how you feel."

It's an oddly DIY ethic echoed by Asera's programme manager, Phillip Scarborough, writer and performer of both Asera Everywhere and Asera Leads The Way, who doesn't sound nearly so soulless talking from his San Francisco crib. "Basically, I've always loved writing music, and my CEO asked if I'd do something for the firm. So I ended up with five potential anthems, met the board with my boombox, and they were just blown away."

Still, you can't help wondering who these godless hymns are really for - morale-sapped employees, or wide-eyed prospective customers? The answer, apparently, is both. "Obviously on one level, the tune is there to bring people together, happily working under one flag," says Bray. "On another, it's about slotting in with the 360-degree branding."

Scarborough is thinking along similar lines: "It's supposed to rally the troops, but it's also supposed to put Asera's message across. The message that we're excited and we're here to stay." That, in the words of Asera Everywhere, you're hot, dope, def and fly? "Exactly."

For the likes of Bray and Scarborough, these are, of course, early days. Delicious as the prospect of tone-deaf accountants being cajoled into 9am singalongs may be, there isn't - yet - cause for alarm. But a few firms will admit to putting their anthems to stirring use - Dive Right In currently serves as the soundtrack to Bluewave's phone system, while Asera Everywhere is largely aired at "company functions, Christmas parties, that kind of thing".

Bray, indeed, is convinced that the corporate future will be an even more melodic one. "It's unexplored territory, yeah, but the aural logo is certainly getting bigger. And, once it's properly tied into the overall brand strategy, there'll be a time when you don't think of the company without thinking of its anthem." Ladies and gentlemen, please open your hymn books.

The corporate vibe: company songs reviewed

KPMG

Our Vision of a Global Strategy

Sure, it's easy to laugh at KPMG's entry for the worst song of all time. But let's extend to Our Vision of a Global Strategy the compassion that the company clearly doesn't offer its own employees, who have to listen to it. After all, the unsung minion who wrote it won't even have the cold comfort of hearing his or her tune performed as France's Eurovision entry, which in another life would have been its fate. No slur intended on our Gallic cousins. French lounge music by the likes of Air is desperately hip at the moment, and if Our Vision were to be released under Air's name, its tootling synthesisers (nostalgically evocative of 60s test-card music) and choir of Jane "The Cruise" McDonalds (or session singers who sound just like her) would have trendy Hoxton Square types clawing their goatees in ecstasy.

Best moment: when the main Jane spits out the line, "We create/ We innovate/We pass the ones that are lay-ay-ayte."

Pricewaterhouse Coopers

Your World

Your World kicks off with a jaunty stutter of boogie-woogie piano, raising the possibility of Jools Holland being involved. But the spectre quickly recedes as percussion kicks in and a male voice takes the song in another direction entirely. There's a haunting familiarity to both his reedy tones and the unrhymed style as he swings into the second verse: "We don't sell no dogma/What we gotta give/Pricewaterhouse Coopers/For each and every client." There's only one person who can sneer "dogma" with quite such a curled lip - could we be witnessing the corporate-jingle debut of Elvis Costello? And yet, moments later, he is joined by someone who could be Marie Osmond, then the entire Osmond clan, plus string section, who take it to a bumptious finale. Such perverseness would be within Costello's abilities.Yet the track is said to originate in Holland - off the beaten track for him - so we may never know.

Deutsche Bank

Global Technology

Deutsche Bank's offering makes a mockery of the German reputation for stodgy sobriety. It's obvious that someone had been at the schnapps here; in fact, it's likely that everyone from the songwriter to the arranger to the helium-voiced girl and boy vocalists were supping the same drug-enriched brew. Global Technology lurches through a bewildering panoply of styles: lofty prog-rock, psychedelia, house, eastern - and that's just the first 30 seconds. The male singer then cuts in, appositely, with, "Global technology is no easy game to play/A new challenge for all of us, every day." You don't say. It's a challenge just to sit through this potpourri. Listen for the sound of a rocket blasting off toward the end, just before the singers reach a pinnacle of emotion. Best of the lot, no contest.

Caroline Sullivan

fields.headline: Women lead as overseas volunteers
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Professional women are for the first time making up the majority of volunteers overseas, but rarely get the opportunity of a foreign posting in their regular careers, according to an investigation of gender prejudice by the international development charity VSO.
fields.body:
Professional women are for the first time making up the majority of volunteers overseas, but rarely get the opportunity of a foreign posting in their regular careers, according to an investigation of gender prejudice by the international development charity VSO.

It found the number of women volunteers signing up for service abroad has trebled over 20 years, reflecting women's higher qualifications and changing patterns of family life. Last year VSO had 1,130 women working abroad and 840 men.

But women took only 15% of international assignments in companies that commonly regarded overseas experience as a key factor in deciding promotion, according to research for VSO by Hilary Harris, director of research at Cranfield University's school of management.

She said the VSO experience exploded myths about women that were damaging their career prospects by denying them the chance to work abroad.

"There are three very potent assumptions: first that women are not interested in posts abroad; second that family ties prevent them accepting posts abroad; and finally that women sent on overseas assignments are doomed to fail in the face of prejudice in certain countries.

"Yet the VSO figures offer evidence, not only that women are interested in challenging postings overseas, but that they thrive when given the opportunity to do so," she said.

"We have to ask: by denying women such experience, have we created a new glass ceiling? Women make up 30-40% of middle management, but represent just 1% of all chief executive officers."

An NOP poll commissioned by VSO found 51% of women would like the chance to work overseas. But more than 80% of women and men thought it was harder for women to gain respect in some foreign cultures. More than 60% of women and men said it was difficult for women to take up posts abroad because of family commitments. And nearly half said it was harder for women to work abroad than men.

VSO said these public attitudes contrasted sharply with the evidence of its returning women volunteers.

Most of the women volunteers were in their twenties and fifties. The older volunteers said they were prompted by freedom from family ties, an urge to see the world and travel with a purpose. The younger volunteers saw VSO as a boost to career prospects and said they were attracted by the sense of adventure.

Ruth Lewis, the charity's director of recruitment, said: "Here is evidence of a pool of female talent and ability waiting to be tapped, not just by VSO, but by the wider business community."

fields.headline: The Rub
fields.standfirst:
Leeds Cockpit
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Leeds Cockpit
Rating: **
fields.body:
Alan Wren hasn't set foot on stage since June 2 1990. Then, "Reni" was an outstanding drummer in the era's outstanding band, the Stone Roses. With Reni's propulsive, jazz-influenced rhythms forming the cornerstone of immortal songs such as I Am the Resurrection, he played himself into the nation's hearts and history books by his early 20s. However, it all went badly wrong. Reni's last public appearances were in the courtroom, during an attempt to unravel the shambles of the Roses' business deals.

When the band came back, in 1995, Reni mysteriously abandoned the drum stool days before the tour. Rumours have had him variously bloating to 28 stone, and growing a floor-length beard after modelling himself on John the Baptist. But on stage at the Cockpit, he looks almost exactly as he did before. A little darker around the eyes, maybe, but the scrawny hair and mischievous grin are unmistakable. He is greeted like a prophet. And the first words the prophet utters to his flock for more than a decade are: "You wot?"

Grown men gasp as Reni tackles his instrument: a bass guitar. "Get on the fucking drums," someone shouts. The band then launch into a driven, gloriously funky instrumental, the staccato percussive rhythms unmistakably Reni-sounding, even if they are played by someone else. Reni puts down the bass and hearts flutter. Then he picks up a guitar instead and begins an hour-long process of making hearts sink.

Although it's good to have Reni back and clearly enjoying himself, it's a great pity that this world-class percussionist is not behind a drum stool. By determinedly and competently (but nothing more) playing guitar, he is, perhaps, making some personal point - that a former Stone Rose can attract a sizeable audience fronting a pedestrian, jamming band whose members look like medical students.

The few lyrics that one can make out seem to attack the nature of celebrity, and certainly the Rub's chugging, dated material seems highly unlikely to trouble Hear'Say. As the guitar solos seem to be getting longer, the Rub leave the stage to general confusion. A solitary soul cries: "Reni!" Some shake their heads, but an awful lot more line up with their Roses albums at the dressing room door.

 At Manchester University (0161-832 1111), March 20; Birmingham Academy (0870 9032222), March 21; then touring.
