With Reni's propulsive, jazz-influenced rhythms forming the cornerstone of immortal songs such as I Am the Resurrection, he played himself into the nation's hearts and history books by his early 20s. However, it all went badly wrong. Reni's last public appearances were in the courtroom, during an attempt to unravel the shambles of the Roses' business deals. When the band came back, in 1995, Reni mysteriously abandoned the drum stool days before the tour. Rumours have had him variously bloating to 28 stone, and growing a floor-length beard after modelling himself on John the Baptist. But on stage at the Cockpit, he looks almost exactly as he did before. A little darker around the eyes, maybe, but the scrawny hair and mischievous grin are unmistakable. He is greeted like a prophet. And the first words the prophet utters to his flock for more than a decade are: "You wot?" Grown men gasp as Reni tackles his instrument: a bass guitar. "Get on the fucking drums," someone shouts. The band then launch into a driven, gloriously funky instrumental, the staccato percussive rhythms unmistakably Reni-sounding, even if they are played by someone else. Reni puts down the bass and hearts flutter. Then he picks up a guitar instead and begins an hour-long process of making hearts sink. Although it's good to have Reni back and clearly enjoying himself, it's a great pity that this world-class percussionist is not behind a drum stool. By determinedly and competently (but nothing more) playing guitar, he is, perhaps, making some personal point - that a former Stone Rose can attract a sizeable audience fronting a pedestrian, jamming band whose members look like medical students. The few lyrics that one can make out seem to attack the nature of celebrity, and certainly the Rub's chugging, dated material seems highly unlikely to trouble Hear'Say. As the guitar solos seem to be getting longer, the Rub leave the stage to general confusion. A solitary soul cries: "Reni!" Some shake their heads, but an awful lot more line up with their Roses albums at the dressing room door.  At Manchester University (0161-832 1111), March 20; Birmingham Academy (0870 9032222), March 21; then touring.

webTitle: Abbey links with MBNA to improve credit card rating

fields.headline: Abbey links with MBNA to improve credit card rating
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Abbey National yesterday said it was determined to take on the dominance of the big four banks in the credit card market by embarking on a £289m partnership with American card company MBNA.
fields.body:
Abbey National yesterday said it was determined to take on the dominance of the big four banks in the credit card market by embarking on a £289m partnership with American card company MBNA.

Under the terms of the innovative deal, the US company will buy Abbey National's existing 500,000 customer base for £289m, giving Abbey a profit on the sale of £45m. Abbey will also receive a fee for each new Abbey National-branded card issued by MBNA.

Andrew Pople, managing director of Abbey's retail operations, said the move was intended to boost the bank's 1% share of the credit card market, where the big four - Lloyds TSB, Barclays, NatWest and HSBC - are regarded as the largest players.

"It's very difficult to get scale to be competitive," Mr Pople said. However, while the large players have dominated the market, new players such as MBNA and Capital One have come into the market by offering low transfer interest rates on balances.

Analysts noted that Abbey's arrangement with MBNA contrasted with its closest rival Halifax, which bought Bank One, rather than selling its business as Abbey is doing.

As a result of yesterday's announcement, MBNA will produce a new range of credit cards for Abbey under the bank's own brand which will be offered to customers for the first time in the summer.

Abbey is trying to fend off unwanted advances by Lloyds TSB, whose £19bn bid is being scrutinised by the competition commission.

Abbey said existing card-holders would notice little or no difference as a result of the change in ownership, adding that its cards and statements would continue to be branded Abbey National. But the change will mean that customer will lose the protection offered by the British banking industry's code of practice, which lays down minimum standards that banks and card companies must meet.

While Abbey is a subscriber to the voluntary code, MBNA has been criticised for being one of the few players not to sign up to it. The Banking Code Standards Board, the body which monitors compliance with the code, said yesterday: "We take the view that they should be members." MBNA points out it is a member of the Finance & Leasing Association, which has its own code of practice.

fields.headline: BBCSO declares war
fields.standfirst:
BBCSO/ Runnicles
Barbican Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
BBCSO/ Runnicles
Barbican Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Aaron Jay Kernis is one of contemporary America's outspoken radicals - a fiercely political composer whose work is highly charged, uncompromising and emotionally direct. His Second Symphony (receiving its overdue UK premiere) was triggered by the 1991 Gulf war and, by his own admission, marked the start of his political engagement. It expresses his revulsion at the absurdity of mass destruction, decries US imperialist involvement and examines, as Kernis puts it in his own programme notes, "the culture of war and genocide in our time".

In order to achieve his effects, Kernis turns his orchestra into a pulverising machine. An enormous array of percussion - gongs, glockenspiels, vibraphones, thunder sheets - squats over the rest of the musicians with the grim presence of some weapon of mass destruction. Initially the percussionists are held in check, their muffled explosions hinting at distant shelling. At the end, however, Kernis lets them loose with a barrage of sound that gains in force until the rest of the orchestra is battered into silence.

Kernis opens with a relentless toccata, its ricocheting phrases echoing the scherzo of Shostakovich's Eighth Symphony, which also depicts a world flattened by conflict. The slow movement seemingly brings with it a moment's respite, as a languid chromatic nocturne unfolds against a background of gentle percussive tinkling. Its peace proves illusory, however. The tin tinnabulations gradually become clangorous, while the nocturne's harmonies slowly curdle into extreme dissonances that set your teeth on edge. It's an important work. Conducted at white heat by Donald Runnicles, the BBC Symphony Orchestra plays it with outstanding vividness.

Runnicles flanks it with Schoenberg's Verklärte Nacht and Brahms's Second Piano Concerto - both optimistic, conciliatory works - though regrettably he doesn't quite get to the heart of either. His Verklärte Nacht is curiously muted, rarely attaining the requisite level of intensity, and achieving a sense of lacerating sweetness only in its closing section. His soloist in the Brahms is Garrick Ohlsson, who plays with strength and delicacy, though Runnicles finds the work's balance of classicism and romanticism tricky. The first movement is hard-edged and severe at times. When he gets to the Andante, however, Runnicles veers towards sentiment, taking it so slowly that you almost wonder if the work is going to come to a complete standstill.

webTitle: Classical review: Evelyn Glennie's Hit List III

fields.headline: Evelyn and the bonsai pianist
fields.standfirst:
Evelyn Glennie's Hit List III
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Evelyn Glennie's Hit List III
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
The final concert of Evelyn Glennie's Hit List series featured the pianist Emanuel Ax and the toy piano specialist Margaret Leng Tan. Glennie may have given herself the big moments of the programme - the pyrotechnics of marimba pieces by Leigh Howard Stevens and Keiko Abe - but there was no doubt that the real star of the concert was Tan and her menagerie of diminutive pianos and toy instruments.

The centrepiece of Tan's line-up was a bonsai version of a concert grand, complete with gleaming ebony finish, fully functioning lid and music stand. Kneeling down to play the instrument, Tan looked like Charlie Brown's piano-playing friend from the Peanuts cartoons.

The current repertoire for this most dinky of keyboard instruments is as meagre as its dimensions. Tan, who calls herself the "world's only professional toy pianist", has made it her mission to create a collection of contemporary works for the instrument. She gave UK premieres of music by Stephen Montague, Errollyn Wallen, Toby Twining and Guy Klucevsek.

Montague's Mirabella was a fleet-footed study, but Tan's exaggerated performance did not give the toy piano's distinctive, chiming sound enough time to resonate. Wallen's Louis' Loops, for two toy pianos, based loosely on themes from the harpsichord music of Louis Couperin, again suffered from Tan's self-conscious virtuosity; while the charm of Twining's Satie Blues for piano and toy piano quickly outstayed its welcome.

Klucevsek's Sweet Chinoiserie, on the other hand, was much more successful. Using glasses of water, toy drums, pianos and a child's accordion, Klucevsek's music created a miniature world of vivid imagination. With its artful simplicity of melody and rhythm, Sweet Chinoiserie was like a children's fairy-story, full of bizarre but somehow coherent imagery.

Yet the concert as a whole lacked coherence. Ax presented two pieces from Debussy's second book of Images, and contributed to the world premieres of Nebojsa Jovan Zivkovic's Quasi una Sonata for marimba and piano, and to Elena Kats-Chernin's Vitalia's Steps, scored for piano, toy piano and percussion. Both were marked by individual moments of interest but they failed to create any convincing musical momentum.

webTitle: Theatre review: Wired to the Moon

fields.headline: Maeve's antiseptic monologues
fields.standfirst:
Wired to the Moon
Andrews Lane Theatre
Dublin
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Wired to the Moon
Andrews Lane Theatre
Dublin
Rating: ***
fields.body:
In Ireland, it seems, you can't go wrong with Maeve Binchy, and these dramatisations of six stories from the 1980s capture the energetic essence of her best work - chatty, often hilarious depictions of the antiseptic pretensions of the middle classes, with their womenfolk forever in neurotic distress.

Binchy is extraordinarily prolific and, from three big files of her early short stories, Jim Culleton and his Fishamble company have created a theatre piece which is a chimerical beast, like a big woolly jumper with six arms knitted on.

Each story kicks off with a first-person monologue of a gal in a dilemma, often of her own making. The supporting cast whirls through the blank, multi-purpose set, rearranging its blocks into stage furniture, in almost youth-theatre-ish solutions to the demands of the composite text.

There are intriguing strands of autobiography mixed with the extremely sharp observations: a freelance agony aunt having an affair with her unhappily married editor, a self-sufficient, virgin journalist who suddenly discovers the rituals of marriage, femininity and sexuality in her late 30s, and a great listener and problem-solver who almost flings herself into an affair but narrowly escapes with dignity intact, protected by an unbridled wit.

Binchy's is a curious yet recognisable world, where beauty therapists and wedding boutique madames are imperious gorgons terrorising hapless clients, and women have their nerves shredded during expensive dinner parties that inevitably collapse into farce.

Despite the intelligence of the writing, there is very little of darkness or danger, poverty or infirmity in these early tales - just a wise, benign ribbing that manages to deliver a belly-laugh every few minutes.

Surprisingly for such an experienced director as Culleton, there is only a thin veneer of style to the piece, owing perhaps to the occasionally incoherent gabble of text in his adaptation, with its insanely ambitious stage-logistics. Even so, the six actors warm themselves well into their 15 minutes of solo limelight and the capacity crowds lap it up.

 Runs until March 31. Box office: 00 353 1 679 5720.

webTitle: Work: The way we work - Richard Reeves on the New Deal.

fields.headline: The way we work
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Work
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: It is hard to imagine a rosier jobs picture for the government. If the Conservatives were to repeat their famous Labour isn't Working campaign poster, the line of dole claimants would be short indeed. (It would make the poster site cheaper, of course.)
fields.body:
It is hard to imagine a rosier jobs picture for the government. If the Conservatives were to repeat their famous Labour isn't Working campaign poster, the line of dole claimants would be short indeed. (It would make the poster site cheaper, of course.)

Bouquets, then, to Gordon Brown for a steady hand on the fiscal tiller and Alan Greenspan for his soothing balm on the slowing US economy. But also to Labour's big idea - the New Deal, the central plank of its economic and social policy, which has successfully helped young unemployed people into work.

But let's not get too carried away. The New Deal, now to be rolled out across the shrinking unemployed population, has been pretty good at getting people into jobs but relatively ineffective at keeping them there. Most drop out again, victims of a "low-pay, no-pay" cycle.

The New Deal is now pretty old; it has been part of Labour's thinking for six years or more. It was designed when unemployment was high and when the unemployed were relatively employable. But as the jobless total falls, the people left on the rolls are by definition the ones with the most deep-seated problems: for these people, the New Deal is now more hindrance than help. Rules made for one group penalise another.

Here is an example: one requirement of the New Deal is that a person who misses five days of their training or employment option is automatically booted off, sent back to the employment service and made to start again. No mercy is shown. A group of trainees at the Wise Group in Glasgow, a training and employment agency, was recently involved in a minibus accident while on the course. Several were seriously injured and hospitalised for more than a week. When they were discharged they were - wait for it - thrown off the course and made to start again.

"This rule is applied unflinchingly," says Alan Sinclair, who runs the Wise Group. "If we are to help people who are on their uppers then we need more flexibility in dealing with absence."

Sinclair is a man who was engaged in new deal-type activities long before the New Deal - ministers should take notice. A rule that was designed in Whitehall to stop employable shirkers from pulling sickies on the New Deal is now preventing those most in need from getting the help they need.

Car crashes apart, plenty of the unemployed have problems which require a more humane and flexible approach - drug abuse, family problems, domestic violence, mental ill-health. In the US, where welfare-to-work has cut rolls dramatically in many areas, programmes are struggling to adjust to the needs of remaining clients. In one scheme in Wisconsin, a third of the single parents were suffering or had suffered sexual abuse, and only a tiny minority had received help. For many, counselling is required, not career plans.

The New Deal is a victim of its own - and the government's - success. It needs to be reshaped to cope with a harder-to-help client group. And greater emphasis needs to be placed on helping people stay in work. And the administrative effort implied by the push-them-into-work first stage of the New Deal now needs to be reduced. Time with clients is becoming more precious, and time spent on form-filling more wasteful.

One of the forms - ND 12 PS, for those interested, which records "value added" - takes a skilled administrator at least half a day to complete. "I find it Orwellian that a process called 'added value' costs so much to administer and adds nothing to the experience of the New Deal person," says Sinclair. The spirit of the New Deal, which is to help the economically excluded back into mainstream national life, is as powerful as ever. But the practice of the programme is working against its original intent. We need to start again. The New Deal is dead: long live the new New Deal.

Graffiti seen on a bridge in London: Exercise Your Right to Paid Holidays. Perfectly sound and progressive advice, if a little prosaic for the particular medium. But the bridge in question spans part of the capital with a high percentage of newspaper and broadcasting offices; a case, one worries, of preaching to the converted?

 Richard Reeves (rreeves@indsoc.co.uk) writes fortnightly.

webTitle: Jazz review: Just East of Jazz

fields.headline: Jazz for toddlers
fields.standfirst:
Just East of Jazz
Barbican Freestage
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Just East of Jazz
Barbican Freestage
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The free lunchtime platform jazz gig is a nice tradition, a great opportunity for people who rarely go to an evening gig - the retired, the unemployed, working musicians and parents with small children. At the Barbican you can sit on the carpet and concentrate, or wander around a bit and stretch your legs. In this sympathetic context the lightly amplified but gutsy Just East of Jazz sounded just fine.

Led by the composer/reeds player Jeremy Shoham, JEOJ use eastern European melodic styles to breathe life into the familiar line-up of sax, drums, piano and bass. Their arrangements depend on rapid transitions and tight unison playing and their current tour, supported by the Jazz Services scheme, has enabled them to forge a razor-sharp ensemble sound and have fun with it.

The bass and drums can accompany the rapid modal runs of a number such as Dybbuck Chimes, or they can play it as straight klezmer. And some of these snaking lines are so fast that they have a surreal kinship with the chromatic fantasies of early bebop.

The band's two sets featured several new, as yet untitled pieces written specially for the tour. One of them, in three-four time, evolved into a triplet-based pulse with a powerful piano solo by Neil Angilley before sliding into a raggy waltz for Shoham's soprano solo. Drummer Rick Finlay has the necessary light touch, with lots of splashy cymbal work, but is able to drop into solid mainstream fusion at will, nicely complemented by the funky swing of Phil Scragg's bass playing. (At one point Scragg soloed using every technique in the book: strumming, false harmonics and mind-boggling slides.) As the audience grew and warmed to the performance, little children tumbled in front of the band: toddlers dance and run around to jazz polyrhythms as happily as they do to the Tweenies.

Last Saturday night, the first part of the BBC2 documentary Walk On By looked at the way songwriters from Russian Jewish families shaped early jazz, injecting a harmonic and melodic sensibility you can trace from Berlin's Supper Time to Gershwin's Summertime. Yet Shoham's compositions often separate the east European and Afro-American components of jazz like the coloured rings in a paper chromatography demonstration.

Blue Mountain Pyre alternates between rapid bursts of klezmer razzle and a slow slab of dark-hued blues: it's like switching channels between Fiddler on the Roof and Round Midnight. The band switches between rhythmic feels with telepathic ease, and the presence of the talented Angilley gives them an improvisational depth and range that complements the witty and thoughtful compositions. Shoham started JEOJ to forge a link between his family's spiritual roots and his passion for jazz: the band has developed a performing style that both transcends and respects his romantic ideals.

 At Ludlow Assembly Rooms, March 31; Sophbeck Sessions, Cambridge, April 6; then touring. Jazz Services: 020-7928 9089.

Led by the composer/reeds player Jeremy Shoham, JEOJ use eastern European melodic styles to breathe life into the familiar line-up of sax, drums, piano and bass. Their arrangements depend on rapid transitions and tight unison playing and their current tour, supported by the Jazz Services scheme, has enabled them to forge a razor-sharp ensemble sound and have fun with it. The bass and drums can accompany the rapid modal runs of a number such as Dybbuck Chimes, or they can play it as straight klezmer. And some of these snaking lines are so fast that they have a surreal kinship with the chromatic fantasies of early bebop. The band's two sets featured several new, as yet untitled pieces written specially for the tour. One of them, in three-four time, evolved into a triplet-based pulse with a powerful piano solo by Neil Angilley before sliding into a raggy waltz for Shoham's soprano solo. Drummer Rick Finlay has the necessary light touch, with lots of splashy cymbal work, but is able to drop into solid mainstream fusion at will, nicely complemented by the funky swing of Phil Scragg's bass playing. (At one point Scragg soloed using every technique in the book: strumming, false harmonics and mind-boggling slides.) As the audience grew and warmed to the performance, little children tumbled in front of the band: toddlers dance and run around to jazz polyrhythms as happily as they do to the Tweenies. Last Saturday night, the first part of the BBC2 documentary Walk On By looked at the way songwriters from Russian Jewish families shaped early jazz, injecting a harmonic and melodic sensibility you can trace from Berlin's Supper Time to Gershwin's Summertime. Yet Shoham's compositions often separate the east European and Afro-American components of jazz like the coloured rings in a paper chromatography demonstration. Blue Mountain Pyre alternates between rapid bursts of klezmer razzle and a slow slab of dark-hued blues: it's like switching channels between Fiddler on the Roof and Round Midnight. The band switches between rhythmic feels with telepathic ease, and the presence of the talented Angilley gives them an improvisational depth and range that complements the witty and thoughtful compositions. Shoham started JEOJ to forge a link between his family's spiritual roots and his passion for jazz: the band has developed a performing style that both transcends and respects his romantic ideals.  At Ludlow Assembly Rooms, March 31; Sophbeck Sessions, Cambridge, April 6; then touring.
